summary: China's bond market is experiencing a sell-off amid mounting default concerns, with investors rushing to unwind their leveraged bets. The market has seen a 18% drop in outstanding positions in the repo market, which is used to leverage buying power. The cost of overnight repos has risen to one-year highs, making it more expensive for investors to borrow money. This could fuel a downward spiral in the market, posing challenges to government efforts to revive economic growth with cheap credit.

site_title: The terrorist's son speaks
summary: Zak Ebrahim, son of El Sayyid Nosair, a convicted conspirator in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, shares his story in his memoir "The Terrorist's Son". Ebrahim, who was 10 when the bombing occurred, grew up in a life of deception and moved 20 times in the US as a teenager after his father's actions were revealed. He recounts his father's involvement with terrorist figures, including Omar Abdel-Rahman, and his own struggles to understand and distance himself from his father's extremist views. Ebrahim aims to show that someone raised by a terrorist does not necessarily follow in their footsteps.

site_title: Trump reboots the US foreign-policy debate
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump has delivered a major foreign-policy address, challenging the "globalism" that has driven US foreign policy since the end of the Cold War. Trump's "America First" message prioritizes US national interest and military restraint, opposing military intervention in the Middle East and nation-building. He vowed to rebuild the US military and use force only when necessary, while also making deals with Russia and China that benefit the US. This nationalist stance sets him apart from fellow Republican candidate Hillary Clinton, who remains committed to traditional internationalist policies.

site_title: Avengers-lookalike a thrilling ride
summary: The Marvel film "Captain America: Civil War" is a popcorn-friendly, thrilling ride that restores faith in the superhero genre. The film, directed by Anthony and Joe Russo, reunites the Avengers ensemble and explores the United Nations' attempt to regulate superhero crimefighters. The plot sparks tension between Captain America and Iron Man, leading to a spectacular showdown. Screenwriters Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely successfully juggle characters without resorting to goofy dialogue. The film's pacing is slow, but once it clicks, it's an irresistible and thrilling ride.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Throwing out the rule book
summary: Disruptive innovation is changing industries by forcing companies to adopt new business models, simplify complicated processes, and build on technological platforms that improve over time. According to management consultant Scott Anthony, companies must disrupt the market by doing something the market leader is not interested in doing, as Netflix did with its DVD rental service. Disruption can also be seen in companies like Airbnb, Uber, and Amazon, which have made complex services easy and affordable. Incumbents often act too late, and even successful companies can be disrupted by new trends, such as the rise of robots and drones, additive manufacturing, and immersive technology.

site_title: Get message of healthy living across to tackle diabetes-induced kidney failure
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) supports the Health Ministry's plans to tackle diabetes, a major cause of kidney failure. NKF emphasizes the importance of prevention through healthy lifestyle interventions, such as diet, exercise, and regular health checks. The organization has launched various health education and awareness programs, including health screenings and outreach events, to promote kidney health and reduce the risk of kidney diseases. With a growing problem of diabetes-induced kidney failure in Singapore, NKF urges individuals, companies, and the community to work together to adopt healthy lifestyles and prevent kidney diseases.

site_title: Lower R&D costs lift Venture Corp earnings
summary: Venture Corp, a Singapore-based electronics firm, reported a 10.1% increase in net profit to S$35.84 million in its first quarter, driven by lower R&D expenses. Revenue rose 3.6% year-over-year to S$630.72 million, but the company provided vague reasons for the increase. R&D expenses dropped 38.7% due to lower customer requirements for prototyping tooling and services. The company's earnings per share rose to 13 Singapore cents, and shares closed at S$8.39.

site_title: 2 people, not one, charged in Singapore's 1MDB probe (Amended)
summary: Two individuals, Yeo Jiawei and Kelvin Ang Wee Keng, have been charged in Singapore's 1MDB probe. Yeo, a former wealth manager at BSI, faces additional charges of cheating and obstructing investigations, while Ang is accused of corruptly giving a gratification sum to a research analyst. The charges are linked to the ongoing 1MDB probe, which involves multiple authorities in several territories. Yeo's case stems from his alleged role in concealing large amounts of monies and concealing transactions, while Ang is implicated in illicit transactions with Yeo.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

Singapore authorities have charged not one but two people - a former wealth manager at Swiss private bank BSI and someone allegedly involved in corrupt transactions in concert with the former private banker - in an ongoing investigation into 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB).

site_title: DBS: Is GNI a more useful measure as firms go abroad?
summary: DBS economists suggest Singapore can overcome its "productivity trap" by investing in higher-growth neighboring countries. To accurately measure economic growth, Singapore may shift from gross domestic product (GDP) to gross national income (GNI), which includes income earned by Singaporeans abroad. This move could lead to a more accurate capture of the value created by Singaporeans and companies based overseas. The economists believe this strategy will yield positive returns, as seen in Japan and Taiwan, and will help sustain national incomes in the face of domestic challenges.

images.alt_text: Singapore can overcome its "productivity trap" by expanding regionally and tapping higher growth elsewhere, said DBS economists Irvin Seah and Ma Tieying in a report released on Thursday.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as BOJ keeps rates steady
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday after the Bank of Japan held rates steady, with the Dow Jones down 31.16 points, or 0.17%, at 18,010.39. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 3.31 points, or 0.16%, and the Nasdaq down 5.49 points, or 0.11%. The move was seen as a lack of expansion in monetary stimulus, which may have influenced investor sentiment.

site_title: ANZ is first Aussie bank to offer Apple Pay
summary: ANZ bank became the first Australian bank to support Apple Pay, a digital wallet service, allowing users to register credit cards on devices and make contactless payments. This partnership extends Apple Pay's services to ANZ customers, following similar agreements with Westpac Banking Corp and American Express Co. The move is seen as a significant step in digital banking, with ANZ's CEO Shayne Elliott stating that it would be hypocritical to promote digital banking while not being at the forefront of change. The partnership is expected to increase pressure on other banks to follow suit.

site_title: Chinese officials under investigation for selling data: govt
summary: Chinese officials are under investigation for allegedly selling data, with over 300 NBS staff being asked to return 3.23 million yuan for selling annual reports and data to affiliates. This comes after the former head of the NBS was sacked in a corruption probe, highlighting ongoing doubts over the reliability of China's economic data. Critics argue that the data can be manipulated for political purposes, as the ruling party relies on growth for legitimacy.

site_title: UBS to revamp wealth management business: FT
summary: Swiss bank UBS plans to revamp its wealth management business by merging back and middle-office functions, resulting in workforce reduction. The move is expected to save UBS several hundred million francs and will involve the wealth management unit moving to common information technology systems and shared support facilities, eliminating several hundred jobs. The restructuring is set to be announced next Tuesday, but UBS declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: INVADE acquired for S$1.5m, BoxGreen gets S$450K seed funding
summary: INVADE, a Singapore-based retail platform, has been acquired by South-east Asian iFashion Group for S$1.5 million in cash and shares. Meanwhile, BoxGreen, a snack food startup, has secured S$450,000 in seed funding to expand its team and operations in Singapore and other Asian cities. The acquisitions and funding rounds come despite investors' warnings of a more cautious investing environment.

site_title: Comcast to buy DreamWorks Animation for US$3.8b
summary: Comcast Corp, the owner of NBCUniversal, announced it will buy DreamWorks Animation SKG Inc for $3.8 billion in cash, representing a 27.3% premium to DreamWorks' closing price.

images.alt_text: Comcast Corp, the owner of NBCUniversal, said on Thursday it would buy DreamWorks Animation SKG Inc for US$3.8 billion in cash.

site_title: Opportunity for industrialists in slowdown, uncertainty: JTC
summary: Industrial rents in Singapore fell 2.7% q-o-q and 5.1% y-o-y in Q1 2016, while vacancy rates rose to 9.9%, the highest in a decade. Median rentals in areas like Tuas and Jurong decreased 19% to S$15.63 per square metre per month due to new supply outpacing demand. Despite uncertain business conditions, the market remains cautious, with industrialists reluctant to invest or move due to ongoing slowdown and uncertainty.

site_title: Ho Bee's Q1 profit up 59.8% at S$18.46m
summary: Ho Bee Land has reported a 59.8% surge in first-quarter net profit to S$18.46 million, driven by higher rental income and a Shanghai joint-venture project. Revenue rose 19.3% to S$37.69 million. The company's earnings per share increased to 2.77 Singapore cents, while net asset value per share fell to S$4.19 due to a weakening of the pound and other currencies. Ho Bee's chairman and CEO, Chua Thian Poh, expects the group's earnings to remain positive for the year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: SpaceX plans to send a probe to Mars
summary: SpaceX plans to send a probe to Mars, following the successful landing of a Falcon 9 rocket booster on a floating platform in the Atlantic. This achievement demonstrates the company's capabilities in reusable rocket technology. SpaceX's next mission aims to explore the Red Planet, marking a significant step in the company's plans for interplanetary travel.

site_title: Sanofi makes US$9.3b offer for cancer drug firm Medivation
summary: Sanofi has made a $9.3 billion offer to acquire US-based cancer drug firm Medivation, valuing the company at $52.50 per share. The deal would be Sanofi's largest acquisition since buying Genzyme in 2011. The merger would benefit patients and create value for shareholders, according to Sanofi's CEO Olivier Brandicourt. The acquisition would also strengthen Sanofi's position as the 11th largest pharmaceutical company in the world.

site_title: China's biggest bank ICBC reports rise in bad loans
summary: China's largest bank, ICBC, reported a rise in non-performing loans to 1.66% at the end of March, up from 1.50% last year. The bank's first-quarter net profits rose 0.59% year-on-year. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged China to develop a comprehensive plan to tackle bad debts, warning that techniques such as converting loans to equity or repackaging into securities could worsen the problem. China's "Big Four" banks will report first-quarter results this week, amid concerns about excessive corporate debt and impaired bank loans.

site_title: SMRT's Q4 profit rises 27.6%; full-year earnings up 20.1%
summary: SMRT Corporation reported a 20.1% increase in net profit to S$109.3 million for the 2016 financial year, driven by a 4.9% revenue increase to S$1.3 billion. The company's operating profit from non-rail business rose 22.6% to S$133.3 million, while rail operations reported a lower operating profit due to a net property tax refund. SMRT's earnings per share increased to 7.17 Singapore cents, and the board proposed a final dividend of 2.50 cents per share, totaling 4 cents for the year.

site_title: MPA revokes bunker licenses for two companies
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) revoked licenses for Seaquest Tanker and Vermont UM Bunkering due to erroneous record keeping on their tankers. Discrepancies and wrongful declarations were found in records kept on board bunker vessels, including unapproved transfers of bunkers. The revocations took effect on April 26 and April 27, respectively, affecting the companies' sales and operation licenses. The MPA conducted checks in 2015 and 2016, leading to the removals.

site_title: Volkswagen in position to issue bonds: CFO
summary: Volkswagen's CFO, Frank Witter, stated the company is in a position to issue bonds after releasing audited full-year results. Witter expects the VW brand to post an operating profit in the first quarter, reversing a 127 million euros operating loss in the final quarter of 2015. Discounts have risen 10% in the first quarter, but incentives remain 10% lower than competitors. The company's CEO, Matthias Mueller, attributed the use of discounts and incentives to boost sales. A bond issuance is expected to occur before the end of May.

site_title: Japan steel giant's net profit hit by China slowdown
summary: Japan's steel giant Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal reported a 55% decline in annual net profit to 200.9 billion yen due to a slowdown in China and other overseas markets. The company attributed the decline to oversupply, stagnant demand, and a rebound in the yen. Domestic steel demand remained sluggish, and overseas demand conditions worsened due to China's slowing growth and stagnant demand in the Asean region. Nippon Steel did not provide a forecast for the current fiscal year, citing a need for reasonable estimates.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank fines troubled state fund 1MDB
summary: Malaysia's Central Bank fined 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) for failing to comply with bank rules, revoking three permissions for fund transfers. 1MDB must repatriate funds abroad and submit evidence by May 30 to avoid further action. The fine marks the end of the central bank's investigations, following a missed deadline to submit documents on its finances abroad.

site_title: Delta throws Bombardier a lifeline with deal to buy 75 CSeries
summary: Delta Air Lines ordered 75 CSeries CS100 planes from Bombardier Inc worth $5.6 billion, providing a lifeline to the aircraft program. The deal marks a turning point for Bombardier, allowing it to break into the global market for 100-seat planes. The CSeries planes offer improved fuel efficiency and room for two cabin classes, enabling Delta to phase out 50-seat jets and up-sell customers to business. The deal also allows Delta to reduce its reliance on contractors as a shortage of regional pilots looms.

site_title: JAL, ANA flying high on healthy travel demand
summary: Japan's top airlines, All Nippon Airways (ANA) and Japan Airlines (JAL), reported robust annual profits, driven by healthy demand on international routes, particularly to China, and falling fuel costs. ANA's net profit rose 99.2% to 78.2 billion yen, while JAL's net profit jumped 17.1% to 174.5 billion yen. Despite a slowdown in demand on routes to Paris and Brussels following terrorist attacks, international operations remained strong. Both airlines forecast continued growth for the next fiscal year, with ANA projecting 80 billion yen in net profit and JAL expecting a 10% increase in annual net profit.

site_title: Lower R&D costs boost Venture Q1 earnings
summary: Venture Corporation reported a 10.1% increase in net profit to S$35.84 million in its first quarter, driven by lower research and development expenses. Revenue rose 3.6% to S$630.72 million. Earnings per share increased to 13 Singapore cents from 11.8 cents in the previous year. The company's shares rose six Singapore cents to close at S$8.39.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 17.58 points to close at 1,674.76, with 1.78 billion lots traded. Gainers numbered 274, while losers numbered 570, valued at RM2.31 billion.

site_title: Ho Bee Land's Q1 profit rises 59.8% to S$18.46m
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a 59.8% increase in Q1 net earnings to S$18.46 million, driven by higher rental income from new London acquisitions. Revenue rose 19.3% to S$37.69 million. The group's associates contributed S$9.3 million in profits, compared to a loss of S$1.3 million in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Barclays targets "clean and prosperous" 2018 as overhaul continues
summary: Barclays Chairman John McFarlane has set a goal for the bank to achieve a "clean and prosperous" 2018 through a major overhaul, including a 50,000-staff reduction and asset sales. The restructuring aims to reduce the bank's headcount to 80,000, enabling it to reintroduce a "respectable dividend level" and become a "significantly smaller, safer" bank. The plan includes selling its 62% stake in Barclays Africa and addressing rising regulatory costs and poor economic conditions. Barclays expects to reverse years of losses and generate superior returns.

site_title: King Wan secures S$29.5m worth of M&E contracts
summary: King Wan Corporation secured S$29.5 million worth of M&E contracts in Singapore from December 2015 to March 2016. The contracts include the installation of electrical, air-conditioning, and mechanical ventilation systems for a hotel and a condominium development. The projects are scheduled to be completed between 2016 and 2018, providing high revenue visibility for the group until 2018. This brings the group's order book to S$164.5 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher on Fed outlook
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.12% to 21,388.03 after the Federal Reserve provided an optimistic outlook on the world economy, but gains were limited by Japan's refusal to boost stimulus. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.27%.

site_title: Update: Ex-banker in Singapore faces 2 more charges in 1MDB-linked case
summary: Singapore charged former wealth manager Yeo Jiawei with cheating and obstructing justice in a 1MDB-linked case. Yeo, 33, was initially charged with receiving ill-gotten funds and was arrested last month. He now faces two additional charges. The case is related to Malaysia's embattled 1MDB investment fund and involves allegations of money laundering. The charges were brought by Singapore prosecutor Kwek Mean Luck at a hearing in the Singapore State Court.

site_title: Thai finance ministry cuts 2016 GDP growth forecast to 3.3%
summary: Thailand's finance ministry lowered its 2016 GDP growth forecast to 3.3% from 3.7% due to weaker exports. Exports are expected to contract 0.7% this year, down from earlier predictions of a 0.1% rise. The ministry cited a decline in exports over the past three years. The central bank maintained its 2016 economic growth forecast of 3.1%.

site_title: Citic Envirotech posts 39% jump in Q1 profit
summary: CITIC Envirotech reported a 39.1% jump in net profit to S$12.3 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2016, driven by a 62.5% surge in revenue to S$99.5 million. The company attributes the growth to increased engineering business and membrane sales. It remains upbeat about prospects in the water sector in China, citing the government's focus on addressing pollution issues. The company plans to expand its asset portfolio through strategic mergers and acquisitions, particularly in the industrial sectors.

site_title: Jardine C&C's Q1 profit drops 20% to US$141m
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage's (Jardine C&C) Q1 net profit fell 20% to US$140.6 million due to weaker contributions from its Astra subsidiary, which saw a 27% decline in underlying profit. Revenue declined 9% to US$3.6 billion, mainly due to challenging market conditions in Indonesia and a weaker rupiah. Astra's car sales decreased by 7% to 127,000 units, but improved margins. The group continues to face challenging trading conditions across the region.

site_title: Bukit Batok by-election: Police issue permits for PAP, SDP rallies on Friday
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) and the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) will hold rallies in Bukit Batok on April 29 for the by-election. The PAP rally will be held at Bukit Gombak Stadium, while the SDP will hold theirs at the field along Bukit Batok Industrial Park A.

images.alt_text: The People's Action Party (PAP) and the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) will both be holding rallies on Friday (April 29) for the Bukit Batok by-election.

site_title: Citi puts Asia payment processing business up for sale: sources
summary: Citigroup has put its Asia payment processing business up for sale as part of its plan to exit non-core operations. The business, which generates around $400 million in revenue, provides credit and debit card payment processing services to thousands of merchants in Hong Kong, Singapore, and India. Final bids are due in about three weeks, with the sale process being confidential. This move marks the last remaining market where Citigroup still provides this service, following its exit from other regions starting in 2005.

images.alt_text: Citigroup has puts its Asia payment processing business on the block as part of a ongoing global plan to exit non-core operations, people familiar with the matter told Reuters.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets slid at the start of trading on Thursday, following Tokyo's heavy drop after the Bank of Japan decided against fresh stimulus measures. The FTSE 100 index fell 0.8%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also declined by 0.8% and 0.9%, respectively. The move comes after the Federal Reserve signaled a positive outlook on the global economy, despite mixed signals from leading central banks.

site_title: Cancer research firm CEO tops awarded pay list with US$330 million
summary: Patrick Soon-Shiong, CEO of NantKwest Inc, a cancer research firm, received a record-breaking $329.7 million pay package in 2015, making him the highest-paid US executive of the year. The majority of his pay came from 19.4 million stock options granted before the company's initial public offering. His compensation vaulted him to the No. 1 spot on the Bloomberg Pay Index.

images.alt_text: Patrick Soon-Shiong performed the world's first pig-to-man cell transplant to treat diabetes. He sold two drug companies, making enough to become a billionaire and buy a stake in the Los Angeles Lakers basketball team. Now Mr Soon-Shiong can also add this distinction to his resume: the highest-paid US executive of 2015.

site_title: LTA to call tenders for North-South Corridor, targets 2026 completion
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) plans to call tenders for the 21.5km North-South Corridor, expected to be completed by 2026. Construction will start in 2017 after civil contracts are awarded. The NSC will feature cycling trunk routes and continuous bus lanes, potentially reducing travel time by up to 30 minutes. Preparatory works have been completed, and advance engineering studies have been carried out. LTA has identified potential construction and engineering challenges that will require sophisticated construction methods to minimize disruption to adjacent infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Shanghai: China stocks fall as resources firms take beating
summary: China stocks fell on Thursday, led by resource shares, as commodity prices dropped in response to fresh regulatory trading curbs, hitting investor confidence. The CSI300 index dropped 0.2% and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.3%, with trading turnover near four-month lows. Most sectors fell, with a raw material index declining 1%. This marks the sixth consecutive session of shrinking outstanding margin loans, indicating weak market confidence.

site_title: Singapore ICA warns of fake website phishing for visa and passport numbers
summary: The Singapore Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) has warned of a fake website phishing for visa application numbers and passport numbers. The ICA assures that its official website remains unaffected and no data has been compromised. The authority is working to bring down the fake website and will continue to monitor it, taking a serious view of such fake websites that undermine public trust in the system.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Sony reports quarterly loss, holds forecast to assess earthquake
summary: Sony Corp reported a fourth-quarter loss of 88.3 billion yen due to a charge against its chip business and delayed forecasting due to an earthquake that damaged its main plant for camera sensors. The company will reassess its forecast and expects annual net income to rise to 212.2 billion yen. Slowing demand for image sensors, traditionally a profitable business, is expected to impact growth, with Sony focusing on PlayStation 4 consoles, streaming services, and movies and music.

site_title: South Korea says North failed with second mid-range missile test
summary: North Korea attempted to test a mid-range ballistic missile, believed to be a Musudan missile, on April 28, but it failed shortly after launch. The test was the second in two weeks, with the first attempt on April 15 also ending in failure. The missile is thought to be capable of striking US bases on Guam, and its failure comes as North Korea prepares for a ruling party congress next month. The failed test is seen as a setback for the country's nuclear program, which is expected to be highlighted by Kim Jong-Un at the congress.

site_title: Hermes sales buoyed by bags after boosting leather output
summary: Hermes International SCA reported first-quarter leather-goods sales that beat analyst estimates, with revenue reaching 1.19 billion euros. Sales rose 6.2% excluding currency fluctuations, driven by a 15% increase in leather-goods and saddlery revenue. The company's Parisian stores are still recovering from the impact of last year's terror attacks, but the rest of its major product lines saw declines. Hermes warned that 2016 revenue growth could be below 8% due to volatile demand in parts of Asia and the US.

site_title: US economy stalls in Q1 as activity weakens broadly
summary: The US economy experienced its slowest growth in two years, with a 0.5% annual rate in the first quarter, according to the Labor Department. Consumer spending slowed due to a strong dollar and cheap oil, while businesses reduced inventory and cut back on spending. Despite this, economists anticipate a rebound given a robust labor market and improving manufacturing and non-manufacturing surveys. The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, citing improved labor market conditions and diminishing threats from the global economy.

images.alt_text: US economic growth braked sharply to its slowest pace in two years as consumer spending softened and a strong dollar continued to undercut exports, but a pick-up in activity is anticipated given a buoyant labour market.

site_title: China FX regulator says China to step up monitoring of outbound direct investment: paper
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator plans to step up monitoring of outbound direct investment, following discoveries of companies failing to evaluate risks and suffering losses. The regulator also aims to crack down on illegal foreign exchange activities. This move comes as China's non-financial outbound direct investment jumped 55.4% in the first quarter of 2016 to $40.1 billion. Strengthening monitoring is expected to address concerns about the risks associated with China's growing overseas investments.

site_title: ST Engg injects US$66m into US subsidiary VT Systems
summary: ST Engg injects US$66 million into US subsidiary VT Systems, bringing its total investment to US$343.96 million. The capital injection repays US$35.28 million and US$33.08 million in loans of subsidiaries VT Systems and Vision Technologies Land Systems, respectively. The move is expected to have no material impact on ST Engg's financials for the current year.

site_title: Honda expects quake-hit plant to resume full operation in August
summary: Honda Motor Co plans to resume production at its motorcycle plant in southern Japan, which was damaged during a series of earthquakes in April, starting May 6. The company expects full operation to resume in mid-August. Mini-vehicle production at a supplier plant is expected to take about half a year to return to normal.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's labor market saw a decrease in layoffs from 5,370 to 4,600 in Q1 2016, but a notable increase from Q1 2015. A $500m venture debt program was launched for high-growth SMEs. Meanwhile, Malaysia is set to seize RM3 billion of assets belonging to Daim Zainuddin, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow. The UK economy contracted for the second month, and South Korea's trade chief is seeking a "landing zone" in US trade talks.

site_title: Deutsche Bank net income down 58% as investment bank slumps
summary: Deutsche Bank's net income declined 58% in the first quarter to 236 million euros due to its investment bank's slump and ongoing legal costs from past scandals. The lender's profit beat analyst forecasts of a 249 euro net loss. CEO John Cryan stated that 2016 will be the peak year for the bank's restructuring efforts. Despite the decline, Deutsche Bank's results were better than expected.

site_title: Moody's says it will appeal against HK tribunal decision on "red flags" report
summary: Moody's Investor Services has announced its intention to appeal against a Hong Kong tribunal's decision that partly upheld regulatory action for a report on Chinese companies. The tribunal had ruled that Moody's breached the Securities and Futures Commission's code of conduct by publishing a report that raised corporate governance concerns. The decision, which reduced a proposed fine to HK$11 million, could redefine the limits of research reports on public companies, potentially curtailing the activities of research firms in the financial center.

site_title: VW says may have to sell assets to pay for emissions scandal
summary: Volkswagen may need to sell assets to pay for its diesel emissions scandal, which has already provisioned 16.2 billion euros. The company faces uncertainty about the ultimate cost of legal risks and potential financial liabilities, which could lead to asset sales. This could also result in decreased demand, lower margins in the new and used car business, and increased temporary funds tied up in working capital.

site_title: Australia: Shares helped higher by merger news, NZ edges up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.73% to 5225.40, driven by firmer oil prices and a potential merger between Pacific Brands and a bidder. New Zealand's benchmark index also gained 0.59% to 6789.98. The rally came despite US trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Woh Hup, China Jingye Engineering win S$334m LTA contracts to build 2 stations
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded two civil contracts worth S$334 million to Woh Hup and China Jingye Engineering for the construction of Amber and Bedok South stations on the Thomson-East Coast Line. The construction of Amber station is valued at S$146 million, while Bedok South station and its associated tunnels are valued at S$188 million. The East Coast stretch of the TEL is expected to be completed in two stages, with the first seven stations ready in 2023 and the remaining two in 2024.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: India panel clears insolvency law, sets stage for passage
summary: An Indian parliamentary panel has approved a bill aimed at overhauling the country's bankruptcy regulations, setting the stage for its passage. The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code will now include laws to seize overseas assets of defaulting companies and individuals, making it easier to wind up dying companies or recover dues from defaulters. The bill is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's effort to improve ease of doing business in India and revive the government's stalled reform agenda. The legislation is expected to be passed before the current parliamentary session ends on May 13.

site_title: BOJ's new index shows March consumer prices up 1.1% y-o-y
summary: The Bank of Japan released a new index showing Japanese consumer prices rose 1.1% in March from the year earlier, excluding energy and fresh food costs. This follows a 1.1% rise in February. The new index, which strips away volatile costs, suggests inflation is exceeding 1% for the past few months, potentially leading to changes in monetary policy.

site_title: LG Electronics posts 415% increase in Q1 profit
summary: LG Electronics reported a 415% increase in Q1 profits to 198 billion won (S$233.5 million), driven by booming sales of home appliances and high-end TVs. The company's mobile division, however, suffered an operating loss of 202.2 billion won due to declining demand in emerging markets and high-end smartphone sales. LG attributed the decline to consumers waiting for the new G5 smartphone, which was released in March. Despite the slump, the company's cost-cutting efforts and falling display panel prices helped boost profit margins.

site_title: Oil dips in Asia after hitting 2016 highs
summary: Oil prices dropped in Asia after reaching 2016 highs, as traders took profits amid falling US crude production. US production fell to 8.94 million barrels a day, while stockpiles reached a record 540.6 million barrels. Prices surged for two days due to speculation of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, but sentiment shifted as prices edged up over the past two weeks. Analysts attributed the dip to profit-taking, with prices recovering after falling to the lowest level since 2003.

site_title: Prices, rentals of industrial space continue to fall in Q1: JTC
summary: Industrial space prices and rentals in Q1 2016 fell 2.5% and 2.7% respectively, with occupancy rates dropping 0.5%. Year-on-year, prices and rentals declined 4.8% and 5.1%, while occupancy rates fell 0.6%. A large supply of industrial space is expected, with 2.4 million sq m coming online in 2016 and 1.8 million sq m in 2017, potentially lowering occupancy rates.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down, Apple suppliers mostly extend fall
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 1.1% on Thursday, led by a decline in Apple suppliers, amid concerns over the "peak iPhone" scenario. The main Taiex index dropped to 8,473.49, while the electronics and financials subindexes also fell 1.2%. The decline comes after Apple reported its first-ever fall in smartphone sales, wiping out US$36 billion in market value.

site_title: South Korea plans mini-stimulus to shore up economic growth
summary: South Korea has increased its planned spending for 2016 to 96.4% of its budget, aiming to boost economic growth and address risks. The government will also keep monetary policy "flexible" to support economic activity. To stimulate demand-side growth, the government plans to extend mortgage rules and encourage investments in new sectors, such as the Internet of Things. However, measures alone may not be enough to address constraints like an ageing population, and the government will also encourage companies to seek profits in new sectors through tax credits.

images.alt_text: South Korea has increased its planned spending for this year, the finance ministry said on Thursday, in its latest bid to jump-start the economy and pre-emptively address risks to growth.

site_title: Food fight in the sky: Asian airlines woo gourmet flyers
summary: Asian airlines, including Cathay Pacific Airways and Singapore Airlines, are competing to win back premium passengers by introducing new gourmet food and beverage options. The competition comes as Etihad Airways and Emirates Airline offer luxurious amenities such as shower spas and suites. With 4 million meals consumed in the air daily, on-board catering is a key factor in attracting high-paying passengers. Airlines are seeking to outdo each other with premium offerings to retain customers and gain market share in the highly competitive market.

images.alt_text: Ever since Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin served his guests turtle bouillon, lamb chops and champagne on the world's first international passenger flight in 1912, on-board catering has been key to winning the hearts and stomachs of top-paying passengers.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors says US models compliant, shares regain some ground
summary: Mitsubishi Motors has confirmed that its US models from 2013 have accurate mileage readings, easing concerns about a potential global impact from its fuel economy cheating scandal in Japan. Shares surged 8% on the first day of gains since the scandal erupted, but still lost nearly half their value due to fears of hefty compensation costs and fines. The company re-tested vehicles for model years 2013-2017 and found them to be compliant with US standards. Japan's transport ministry plans to test fuel economy data from Mitsubishi and other automakers next week.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei plunges after BOJ inaction stuns investors
summary: Japanese stocks plummeted 3.6% on the Nikkei, wiping out a 5.1% gain for the shortened trading week, after the Bank of Japan failed to expand monetary stimulus. The yen surged against the dollar and euro, hurting Japanese exporters. Financial shares fell, including Kyushu-based banks, and manufacturing giant Fanuc Corp slid 9.9% after disappointing earnings. The broader Topix index declined 3.2% to end the week 4.8% lower. The BOJ's inaction disappointed investors who had expected stimulus to boost the economy.

site_title: Watchers wonder if Apple has lost its magic
summary: Apple's shares plummeted over 6% to $97.82, erasing $40 billion in market capitalization, after the company reported its first year-over-year quarterly revenue drop in 13 years. The drop raised concerns about whether Apple has lost its ability to create must-have gadgets like the iPhone, sparking worries about the company's growth in a tough global economy.

site_title: Three new members appointed to Public Transport Council
summary: The Public Transport Council (PTC) has appointed three new members, including Chua Tsen Leong Adrian, Divisional Director of Manpower Planning and Policy Division. The appointments aim to enhance the council's effectiveness in overseeing Singapore's public transport system. The new members will work alongside existing council members to develop and implement policies that promote efficient and sustainable public transport. Their appointments are part of the PTC's efforts to ensure the continued improvement of Singapore's public transport infrastructure.

site_title: Japan foreign minister to visit China as Abe seeks talks with Xi
summary: Japanese foreign minister Fumio Kishida will visit China on Friday to restore momentum to ties between the two economies, which have been strained over territory disputes. The visit marks the first by a Japanese foreign minister in four and a half years, and comes after Chinese President Xi Jinping and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe met last year. The fragile rapprochement has since frayed, and Kishida's visit aims to rekindle dialogue. No Chinese foreign minister has visited Japan since 2009, and the visit is seen as an attempt to revive stalled talks.

site_title: Yellen becalms global market volatility as Fed signals patience
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen calmed global market volatility by signaling she's in no rush to raise interest rates. The Fed's decision sent US debt prices down, stocks and currencies experiencing reduced volatility. The Bank of America Merrill Lynch MOVE Index and Chicago Board Options Exchange SPX Volatility Index reached their lowest levels in months, with the yen rallying 2% against the US dollar. The Fed's patience on interest rate hikes is seen as a relief for investors, with some predicting further market calm after the Fed and Bank of Japan meetings conclude.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen becalmed markets around the world by signaling she's in no rush to raise interest rates, sending volatility down in bonds, stocks and currencies.

site_title: Seoul: Won gains as BOJ hold knocks US dollar/yen, stocks fall
summary: South Korea's won strengthened 0.9% to 1,138.2 to the US dollar after the Bank of Japan held off from expanding stimulus, sending the yen higher and knocking the US dollar down more than 2%. However, South Korean shares fell 0.7% as offshore investors unloaded 196.2 billion won worth of shares, snapping an 11-day buying streak. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 2,000.92 points, with tech giant Samsung Electronics Co Ltd losing 2.7%.

site_title: Gold jumps as surprise BOJ decision to stand pat batters dollar
summary: Gold prices surged 0.4% to $1,250.35 an ounce after the Bank of Japan unexpectedly decided not to expand stimulus, hurting the dollar. The decision, a surprise to most economists, boosted gold's fourth consecutive day of gains, with a 18% rise in 2016. The stronger yen, which rose after the decision, also supported gold prices. The Federal Reserve left its benchmark rate unchanged, while exchange-traded funds backed by gold rose 1.6 metric tons.

site_title: UK house price growth cools after land tax changes: Nationwide
summary: UK house price growth slowed to 4.9% year-on-year in April, down from 5.7% in March, according to Nationwide's survey. The slowdown followed a surge in activity in March ahead of an April 1 increase in stamp duty tax for second home purchases. This change, introduced by the government, is believed to have cooled the market.

images.alt_text: British annual house price growth cooled in April after the government introduced extra taxes on second home purchases, according to a survey from mortgage lender Nationwide on Thursday.

site_title: Vietnam Air shares to start trading after ANA deal concludes
summary: Vietnam Airlines Corp plans to list its shares on the Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange later this year after completing a strategic partnership deal with ANA Holdings Inc. The company sold an 8.8% stake to the Japanese airline for $108 million in January as part of a plan to offload 20%. Vietnam Airlines expects a three to four-fold increase in pre-tax profit due to rising passenger traffic. The airline is revamping its fleet and adding international routes to meet growing demand for air travel from Vietnam's middle class.

site_title: China's HNA to buy Carlson Hotels in acquisition binge
summary: Chinese conglomerate HNA has agreed to buy US-based Carlson Hotels, owner of the Radisson brand, in a deal that marks the company's third overseas acquisition in as many months. HNA will acquire Carlson's majority stake in Rezidor Hotel Group, with 1,400 hotels in operation and under development across 115 countries and territories. The acquisition aims to establish HNA's presence in the US market and expand its hospitality footprint internationally, with a potential closing in the second half of this year.

site_title: Samsung's drug-manufacturing unit plans to go public
summary: Samsung Biologics, a unit of South Korea's Samsung Group, plans to list its shares on Seoul's stock market by the end of 2016 to fund more investment in the bio-medical business. The firm, which produces biopharmaceutical drugs for major companies, aims to capitalize on the growing global radiopharmaceutical industry, expected to reach $278 billion by 2020. The listing will give Samsung Electronics, the group's flagship unit, a nearly 50-per-cent stake in the company. This move is part of Samsung's efforts to find new growth engines as its core mobile phone business slows down.

site_title: China's Xiaomi aims to double smart home device sales this year to 10b yuan
summary: Xiaomi aims to double sales of smart home devices to 10 billion yuan (S$2.08 billion) this year, up from 5 billion yuan, as it diversifies its business lines to cope with smartphone saturation. The company plans to expand its retail stores in China to 60 and is expecting a significant increase in sales of devices such as rice cookers and air purifiers. This move follows Xiaomi's ranking as the fifth-largest smartphone shipper globally in the first quarter of 2016.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank governor-elect pledges stability
summary: Malaysia's new central bank governor-elect, Muhammad Ibrahim, has pledged to maintain monetary and financial stability, following the departure of his predecessor, Zeti Akhtar Aziz. Ibrahim, who takes over for a five-year term, aims to contribute to a better future for Malaysians and ensure a smooth transition. The ringgit currency rallied after concerns about government influence on the central bank eased. Ibrahim faces challenges, including a slowing economy and rebuilding reserves, but has been praised for his experience and leadership.

site_title: China statistics bureau says staff leaked data for personal gain
summary: China's National Bureau of Statistics reported that 313 employees took bribes for providing internal information, resulting in a return of 3.23 million yuan. The agency also found irregularities in purchasing handheld devices and outdated procedures, which led to inconsistencies in national and provincial GDP data. The bureau's chief, Ning Jizhe, faces challenges in maintaining data credibility. The report comes amid concerns over corruption and the need for updated guidelines to reflect the country's evolving economy.

site_title: Resale prices of completed condos, apartments in Singapore down 1% in March
summary: Resale prices of completed condos and apartments in Singapore fell 1% in March, reversing a 0.5% increase in February. The decline was across all subsectors, with non-central region prices dropping 1.4% and central region prices falling 0.5%. Prices of small units (up to 506 sq ft) also fell 1%. This marks a reversal from February's price increase.

site_title: RM200b bonanza for Malaysian builders attracts top fund
summary: Malaysia's construction sector is experiencing a boom, with an estimated 136 billion ringgit of jobs in the pipeline in 2016. The government's 11th Malaysia Plan, set to allocate 260 billion ringgit for development expenditure from 2016 to 2020, has attracted top fund managers, including Areca EquityTrust Fund's Danny Wong Teck Meng. Construction companies, such as Gamuda Bhd and Ekovest Bhd, are trading at their highest levels relative to the Malaysian equity benchmark in four years, with shares expected to rise further as infrastructure projects, including the Pan Borneo highway, are awarded.

site_title: Opioid medication found on Prince, at death scene: media
summary: Prince's death at 57 was investigated by authorities, who found prescription opioid medication on him. Police initially found no signs of suicide or trauma, and an autopsy may take weeks to complete. A judge appointed Bremer Trust as special administrator to handle Prince's estimated hundreds of millions of dollars in assets, and his sister, Tyka Nelson, was listed as one of his heirs. The investigation is ongoing, with the US DEA assisting local law enforcement.

site_title: Uber taps Arianna Huffington as first woman board member
summary: Uber has appointed Arianna Huffington as its first female board member, marking a significant milestone for the US$60 billion ride-hailing startup. Huffington, founder of the Huffington Post, joins a board that includes venture capital investor Bill Gurley and former Obama campaign manager David Plouffe. Her addition aims to bring "optimistic leadership" and a female perspective to the company, which has faced criticism for its treatment of women. Uber faces increasing competition and pressure to improve its female representation, with its main competitor Lyft touting its more female-friendly service.

site_title: London overtakes Singapore as 2nd biggest offshore yuan clearing centre: Swift
summary: London has surpassed Singapore as the second-largest offshore yuan clearing centre, behind Hong Kong, according to Swift. London's value of yuan payments is 21% higher than two years ago, with 40% of payments between the UK and China/HK made in yuan. The trend reversal started in January, with London's market share increasing to 6.3% and Singapore's to 4.6%. This growth reflects the importance of European companies in their commercial relationships with China, with the UK's yuan hub expected to continue to grow.

site_title: Apple, ANZ Bank strike deal to bring Apple Pay to Australia
summary: Apple has partnered with ANZ Bank to bring Apple Pay to Australia, making it the country's first bank to support the mobile payment service. The partnership allows ANZ customers to register credit cards on their devices and pay for goods and services using contactless payment terminals. The move is part of Apple's expansion into the Australian market, following similar partnerships with American Express and other banks. The partnership aims to make digital payments more convenient for consumers, with ANZ's new CEO saying it's essential to be at the forefront of digital change.

site_title: London luxury hotels in worst year since 2009 on terrorism risk
summary: London luxury hotels experienced their worst year since 2009 due to terrorism risk, Brexit uncertainty, and economic turmoil. Occupancy rates dropped to 65% in the first quarter, with luxury hotels hardest hit, as wealthy travelers and corporate clients are sensitive to these issues. The market is also affected by reduced demand from Russia and the US, with the UK referendum on June 23 causing business travelers to postpone investments.

site_title: SIA in three-year partnership with Indonesia's Tourism Ministry
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has signed a three-year partnership with Indonesia's Ministry of Tourism to promote tourist arrivals into the country. The "Wonderful Indonesia" campaign aims to reach 20 million annual foreign tourist arrivals by 2019. SIA will support the campaign through advertising and promotional activities at its Singapore hub, targeting key source markets.

site_title: Russian law would send bitcoin users to jail as cybercriminals
summary: Russia plans to punish users of cryptocurrencies like bitcoin with fines up to 2.5 million rubles and jail sentences of up to seven years, citing their use in financing the shadow economy and crimes. The Finance Ministry's proposal would prohibit the issuance and use of cryptocurrencies, with penalties starting at four years in prison and a fine of 500,000 rubles. Critics argue that a ban would be futile, as the technology is decentralized and can be easily circumvented. The move joins countries like Bolivia, Iceland, and Vietnam in criminalizing bitcoin.

site_title: Valeant's 'mistakes' raised profit, destroyed value, Ackman says
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals CEO Mike Pearson and hedge fund manager Bill Ackman testified before a Senate committee on high drug prices, admitting the company had made "mistakes" by raising prices too aggressively. The company's stock has plummeted 87% since its peak, costing Ackman's fund billions. Valeant raised prices on four acquired drugs by as much as 525% and 30-fold, causing harm to patients like Berna Heyman, who suffered from Wilson's disease. Ackman recommended reducing prices to use "socially responsible pricing," but promised more action is needed to address the issue.

site_title: China won't allow chaos or war on Korean peninsula: Xi
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated that the country will not allow chaos or war on the Korean peninsula, as it would not benefit anyone. This comes amid North Korea's development of a nuclear weapons capability, which has angered China and raised regional tension. Xi emphasized China's close proximity to the peninsula and its responsibility to maintain stability. The statement highlights China's commitment to preventing conflict on the Korean peninsula, a long-standing concern for the country.

site_title: China says industrial sector faces relatively big pressure to stabilise growth
summary: China's industrial sector continues to face difficulties, with structural imbalances persisting. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology stated that industrial companies face production and operating difficulties, putting relatively high pressure on the sector to stabilize growth. This is attributed to ongoing challenges and challenges in the sector.

site_title: S$500m Venture Debt Programme launched for high-growth SMEs
summary: Singapore's SPRING Singapore has launched a S$500 million Venture Debt Programme (VDP) with DBS, OCBC, and UOB to support high-growth SMEs. The programme provides venture debt loans of up to S$5 million for working capital, assets, or business expansion purposes. The loans offer 50% risk-sharing to financial institutions and have backed companies such as Ascenz Solutions and Conversant since January 2016. The programme aims to catalyze 100 venture debt loans over two years.

site_title: BOJ holds policy steady, adopts loan scheme for quake-hit areas
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its policy steady on Thursday, holding off on expanding monetary stimulus despite global headwinds and a strong yen. The central bank kept its pledge to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen and left its negative interest rate unchanged. It also adopted a 300 billion yen loan-supplying programme to assist banks in quake-hit areas in southern Japan. The decision was made by an 8-1 vote. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda will explain the policy decision in a news conference later.

site_title: Layoffs in Singapore down quarter on quarter in Q1, but up from Q1 last year
summary: Singapore's layoffs decreased by 770 in Q1 2016, reaching 4,600, a quarter lower than the previous quarter but up from 3,500 in Q1 2015. Unemployment remained at 1.9% in March. Employment rose by 11,400 overall, driven by the services sector, with total employment reaching 3,667,600.

site_title: NZ dollar bounces after RBNZ hold, Australia dollar struggling
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) held interest rates at 2.25% on Thursday, causing the New Zealand dollar to bounce and rise to US$0.6940, its highest in 10 months. In contrast, the Australian dollar fell 2% to US$0.7588, its largest one-day drop in eight months, after soft inflation data revived expectations of a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA). Market pricing still implies a 62% chance of a rate cut in June, with economists forecasting the RBA to keep rates steady on May 3.

site_title: Zurich Insurance moves into takaful with Malaysia
summary: Zurich Insurance has acquired full ownership of Malaysia's MAA Takaful, a joint venture launched in 2006, after regulatory approval. The deal marks Zurich's entry into the world's second-largest Islamic insurance market. MAA Takaful held RM1.2 billion in assets as of June 2015. This move is part of Zurich's strategy to reshape its geographic footprint and build more sustainable businesses in the Gulf and southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Zurich Insurance is set to take full ownership of Malaysia's MAA Takaful after the deal received regulatory approval, giving Europe's fifth-biggest insurer a foothold in the world's second largest Islamic insurance market.

site_title: Halal: is it meat you're looking for? says China businessman
summary: A Chinese businessman, Deng Zhijun, co-founder of Sai Wai Xiang Halal Foodstuff Co, sells over $50 million worth of halal food to Muslims in Asia and the Middle East, despite not following Islam. His company is at the forefront of China's drive into the global halal market, exporting to Saudi Arabia. Deng bills his products as "products with Muslim ethnic flavour", but struggles with Islam's dietary tenets.

site_title: Gold retreats as stocks rebound across asia after Fed meeting
summary: Gold declined 0.4% to $1,241.08 an ounce after the Federal Reserve reiterated its gradual approach to raising interest rates, boosting equities and reducing investor demand for a haven. The Fed left its benchmark rate unchanged for the third straight meeting. This marks the first decline in gold prices in four days, following a 17% year-to-date gain.

images.alt_text: Gold declined for the first time in four days after Federal Reserve policy makers reiterated their gradual approach to raising rates, boosting equities and blunting investor demand for a haven.

site_title: Man found dead at Apple headquarters in California
summary: An Apple employee was found dead at the company's Silicon Valley headquarters in California with a head wound and a gun discovered near his body. The incident, deemed isolated, occurred at 8:35 am PDT on Wednesday. Authorities confirmed no other individuals were involved, and an autopsy is underway to determine the cause and manner of death. Apple expressed condolences to the victim's family and colleagues, while the company's headquarters remained calm despite a reported decline in iPhone sales and revenue.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won wobble as BOJ policy meeting results awaited
summary: South Korean shares and the won were volatile on Thursday, awaiting the outcome of the Bank of Japan's policy meeting. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.3% to 2,008.83 points, while the won dropped 0.1% to 1,147.0 against the US dollar. Investors took profits on Samsung Electronics, which rose 12% in the first quarter, while Naver Corp rose 3% before giving up gains. The BOJ's policy meeting outcome is expected to influence the KOSPI's next movement.

site_title: SunEdison bankruptcy floods India market for green projects
summary: SunEdison, a US-based renewable energy company, has filed for bankruptcy, threatening to flood the Indian market with green projects up for sale. The company's 2.4 gigawatts of capacity in India is being searched for equity partnerships, adding 4 gigawatts of clean-energy projects to the market, over 10% of India's existing solar and wind capacity. This surplus of projects could lead to lower prices, making lenders reluctant to finance new projects, potentially endangering India's target to install 100 gigawatts of solar by 2020.

images.alt_text: SunEdison Inc's bankruptcy filing is reverberating halfway around the world in India, where developers say the US company's troubles are adding to a surplus of green capacity up for sale.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rally in opening trade ahead of BOJ decision
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.86% in opening trade on April 28, 2016, ahead of the Bank of Japan's policy meeting. The Nikkei 225 index rose 148.50 points to 17,438.99, while the Topix index gained 12.35 points to 1,396.65. Investors awaited the BOJ's decision, which was not released in the article.

site_title: Philippine central bank foils attempts to hack website: governor
summary: The Philippine central bank has successfully foiled attempts to hack its website, according to Governor Amando Tetangco. This comes amid warnings from global financial network SWIFT about recent cyber fraud incidents targeting its system. The attempts to hack the Philippine central bank's website are seen as a fact of life, but the bank has been able to turn them back. This incident follows a similar cyber theft of US$81 million from the Bangladesh central bank account at the New York Federal Reserve Bank in February.

site_title: Fed keeps key rate unchanged, noting slower US growth
summary: The Federal Reserve kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 0.25-0.50% due to slower US economic growth, despite a strengthening labor market. The Fed cited domestic concerns, such as a slowdown in household spending and weak business investment, as the primary drivers of its decision. While the Fed expressed concern about global economic developments, it downplayed the impact of Brexit uncertainty and other global issues. Only one voting member, Esther George, argued for a rate hike, but the decision was unanimous.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 3.770 points to 1688.700 on Thursday, with a trading volume of 33.6 million lots worth RM13.3 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 110 to 50.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open higher after Fed meeting
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.60% in the first minutes of trade after the Federal Reserve signaled an optimistic view on the world economy. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 21,488.96. In Shanghai, the benchmark composite index edged up 2.07 points to 2,955.74. US markets also rose, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: SunVic says lack of auditor announcement due to 'oversight'
summary: SunVic Chemical Holdings said an auditor's emphasis on "interested person transactions" was due to an "inadvertent oversight" in announcing the matter. The transactions involved the company and its subsidiaries with significant shareholders, including Hu Yanping and Taixing Jinyan Chemical Technology Co. The auditors noted the uncertainty surrounding the outcome of an extraordinary general meeting to ratify these transactions and warned that the company's opinion was not qualified in this respect. SunVic has sought SGX approval for the extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Global smartphone market shrank annually for first time in Q1: Strategy Analytics
summary: Global smartphone shipments declined 3% in Q1, marking the first year-on-year contraction in the market's history, according to Strategy Analytics. Shipments fell to 334.6 million devices from 345 million in the same period last year. South Korea's Samsung Electronics remained the top smartphone maker, but saw a 4.5% decline in shipments and a slight dip in market share. The decline was attributed to matured markets and concerns about the global economy affecting consumer sentiment.

images.alt_text: Global shipments of smartphones shrank 3 per cent in the first quarter from a year earlier in the market's first year-on-year contraction on record, researcher Strategy Analytics said on Thursday, reflecting growing strains on the industry.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rebound amid Fed calm before BOJ with oil above US$45
summary: Asian stocks rebounded, snapping their longest slump since February, amid speculation that the Bank of Japan will boost stimulus and after US policy makers reiterated their gradual approach to raising interest rates. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index rose 0.4% as Japan's Topix index rallied and oil prices surged above $45 a barrel, fueling gains in Australian mining and energy stocks. The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady for the third consecutive meeting, maintaining caution despite evidence of improvement in the US labor market.

site_title: Flash: UOB Group Q1 earnings at S$766m, net interest income grew 6.1% to S$1.27b
summary: UOB Group reported a Q1 earnings of S$766m, with net interest income growing 6.1% to S$1.27b. Meanwhile, MAS and PBOC are deepening collaboration on green and transition finance. Chinese banks face pressure amid Beijing's consumer lending push, while Citigroup sets a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Japan's MUFG plans to boost its US securitisation business and increase headcount. The PBOC adviser urges a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus to counter US tariffs, following Trump's announcement of 35% tariffs on Canada.

site_title: China's biggest oil company posts 52% drop in profit
summary: China National Petroleum Corp, the country's largest oil and gas producer, reported a 52% drop in profit to 82.5 billion yuan due to lower oil prices. Revenue fell 26% to 2 trillion yuan, while oil and gas output rose 1.8%. Chairman Wang Yilin attributed the decline to a shift from rapid expansion to quality growth. The company's profit and revenue decline was largely attributed to the global impact of lower oil prices.

site_title: China property developer Vanke says Q1 core profit up 28%
summary: China property developer Vanke reported a 28% increase in Q1 core profit to 805.1 million yuan, driven by government support measures boosting apartment sales. Net profit rose 28.1% to 833.2 million yuan, while revenue grew 63.1% to 13.7 billion yuan. Market competition remains fierce, but Vanke plans to explore new businesses. China's average new home prices rose 4.9% in March, the fastest pace in nearly two years, but growth may slow due to tightening home purchase requirements.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.6% higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.6% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 17.13 points to 2,891.85. The gains came after the US Federal Reserve reiterated its gradual approach to raising interest rates, supporting investor sentiment. Top gainers included Jardine Matheson Holdings, City Developments, UOB, and Singapore Airlines. The market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with a total of 35.3 million shares changing hands worth S$40.1 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Viva Industrial Trust, Cambridge Industrial Trust, Boustead
summary: UOB Group reported net earnings of S$766 million for the first quarter, down 4.4% from the previous year. Viva Industrial Trust and Cambridge Industrial Trust also released earnings, with distributions falling 12.4% and 9.2% respectively. Boustead Singapore appointed Wong Yu Loon as deputy group CEO, while Serial System, King Wan, and Global Palm Resources issued profit warnings.

site_title: From HP to VP? Feisty Fiorina winds up on Cruz ticket
summary: Carly Fiorina, former Hewlett-Packard CEO, has been selected by Ted Cruz as his potential vice presidential pick in the Republican presidential primary. Fiorina's presidential ambitions fizzled in February, but she's now back in the spotlight with Cruz's announcement. The move is seen as a response to Donald Trump's dominance in debates, with Fiorina known for her tough questioning of Trump. Fiorina's addition to Cruz's ticket could shake up the Republican primary.

site_title: Obama looking for laughs one last time
summary: US President Barack Obama will deliver his final White House Correspondents' Association dinner speech on Saturday, a task deemed one of the hardest speeches of the year. His team, led by speechwriters Cody Keenan and Tyler Lechtenberg, has been working on the speech for months, aiming to strike the right tone and jokes. The speech will include self-deprecation and lighthearted jabs at political opponents and journalists. Obama's past experience with roasting opponents, such as Donald Trump, has been cited as a key factor in his approach, but this year's speech will also mark the end of his time in office.

site_title: Singapore can overcome 'productivity trap' via regional expansion: DBS
summary: Singapore can overcome its "productivity trap" by expanding regionally and investing in higher-growth neighboring countries, according to DBS economists. The report suggests that investing overseas can yield positive returns and contribute to national income and tax revenue. This strategy has been successful in countries like Japan and Taiwan. Singapore's outward direct investment has been rising steadily, but it remains small compared to foreign direct investment inflows. The economists believe that this approach can help sustain national incomes in the face of rising domestic cost pressures and an aging population.

site_title: Zuckerberg borrows Google tactic in splitting stock for control
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is planning to create a new class of non-voting shares, effectively splitting the company's existing stock 3-for-1, to maintain control and prevent dilution. This move, similar to Google's strategy, will strip new shares of voting rights, allowing Zuckerberg to use them for acquisitions and compensation without reducing his influence. The proposal, requiring shareholder approval, aims to ensure Facebook's long-term focus and maintain its founder-led approach, which has contributed to its success.

site_title: PayPal goes mobile to lure customers, fend off competitors
summary: PayPal reported higher-than-expected first-quarter sales and profit, driven by its one-touch mobile payments feature. Over 21 million customers are using the service, which was introduced last year, and the company added 4.5 million new customer accounts. PayPal's transactions volume increased 31% to $81.1 billion, and the company now has 14 million merchants taking payments through the platform. CEO Dan Schulman aims to transform PayPal into a versatile financial tool, expanding its reach beyond online shopping and reducing the likelihood of users defecting to competitors like Apple and Visa.

site_title: URA launches sale tender for residential site at Martin Place
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) launched a sale tender for a 99-year lease residential site at Martin Place, with a 15,936.1 sqm area and a potential for 450 units. The site is located in a well-established residential area near the future Great World MRT station. The site's maximum gross floor area is 44,622 sqm and maximum building height is 153m above mean sea level. The sale is part of the first-half 2016 Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Panama signs bank account info sharing deal with US
summary: Panama and the US signed an agreement to share bank account information, marking a step towards greater transparency in the country's financial sector. The deal comes after the Panama Papers scandal revealed widespread tax evasion and money laundering. Panama's finance minister hailed the agreement as proof of his country's cooperation in fighting tax evasion. The arrangement allows the US to monitor accounts used by US citizens and close tax evasion opportunities, a move seen as a response to international pressure.

site_title: China's Evergrande ups stake in Shengjing Bank for US$1.5b
summary: Evergrande Real Estate Group has acquired an additional 17.28% stake in Shengjing Bank for 10.02 billion yuan (S$2.08 billion), raising its holding to 27.24% of the commercial bank. Shengjing Bank, with a market value of US$8.3 billion, gained a consumer finance licence in China in January and has seen its shares climb 11% this year. The move follows the bank's expansion into retail banking and funding business in the mainland.

images.alt_text: Evergrande Real Estate Group on Thursday said it would buy an additional 17.28 per cent stake in Shengjing Bank for 10.02 billion yuan (S$2.08 billion), after the commercial bank was granted a consumer finance licence.

site_title: Brexit vote nerves turn overseas investors off UK commercial property: RICS
summary: International investors have largely halted purchases of British commercial property ahead of the EU membership referendum, with only 5% of RICS members reporting increased demand from overseas investors. This is the lowest reading since 2014, as 36% of members reported increased demand just a year ago. The survey also found that 43% of RICS members believe leaving the EU would hurt Britain's commercial property sector, while 6% think it would have a positive impact.

images.alt_text: International investors have halted almost all their purchases of British commercial property ahead of the European Union membership referendum, a survey showed on Thursday, adding to signs that the vote is taking a toll on the economy.

site_title: Japan's key price gauge falls most since 2013 as BOJ board meets
summary: Japan's key price gauge fell 0.3% in March, the largest drop since 2013, as consumer prices excluding fresh food slumped. The data, released just before the Bank of Japan's board meeting, suggests the nation is struggling to break free of deflation. The BOJ is expected to consider expanding monetary stimulus to boost inflation, which has been stuck near zero for years. Experts say it's unlikely inflation will reach the 2% goal by the end of 2018, and pressure is building on the central bank to ease monetary policy further.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices in Japan dropped more than expected, adding to evidence that the nation is struggling to break free of deflation as the central bank board meets to decide whether to expand monetary stimulus.

site_title: UOB's Q1 net earnings down 4.4% to S$766m
summary: UOB Group reported a 4.4% decline in net earnings to S$766 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2016, due to lower non-interest income. Total income rose 0.7% to S$1.97 billion, primarily driven by higher net interest income. Net interest margin increased 2 basis points to 1.78%, supporting the growth.

site_title: Ascott buys prime London property via joint fund with Qatar
summary: Ascott Limited, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has invested £52 million (S$100.4 million) in a 108-unit property in Islington, London, its third acquisition in five months through a joint fund with Qatar Investment Authority. The property, Citadines Islington London, is set to open in 2019 and will be part of the Islington Square development. This acquisition strengthens Ascott's position as a major serviced residence operator in Europe, with a portfolio of over 5,300 units across 45 properties.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

Capitaland's serviced residence business unit, The Ascott Limited, is investing S$100.4 million or £52 million in a 108-unit property in Islington, London, its third acquisition within five months through its joint fund with Qatar Investment Authority.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q1 operating profit up 12% vs year earlier
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 12% increase in Q1 operating profit to 6.7 trillion won, driven by strong sales of its Galaxy S7 smartphones. Revenue rose 5.7% to 49.8 trillion won, exceeding the company's guidance. The company's operating profit and revenue beat expectations, with the company attributing the results to strong demand for its flagship smartphones.

images.alt_text: Tech giant Samsung Electronics Co Ltd said on Thursday its first-quarter operating profit rose 12 per cent from a year earlier, buoyed by strong initial sales for its flagship Galaxy S7 smartphones.

site_title: US, European stocks boosted by oil, better Fed outlook
summary: US and European stocks rose on Wednesday, boosted by oil prices and a more optimistic Federal Reserve outlook. The Dow and S&P 500 finished in positive territory, while the Nasdaq fell 0.5% due to Apple's decline in iPhone sales and quarterly earnings. The Fed signaled it's less worried about global economic issues, keeping interest rates unchanged. Analysts disagree on the implications for future interest rate increases, with some expecting a rate hike in June.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust's Q1 DPS falls 12.4% to 1.638 Singapore cents
summary: Viva Industrial Trust's Q1 distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 12.4% to 1.638 Singapore cents, lower than the previous year's 1.87 cents. Gross revenue rose 21.2% to S$21.91 million, and net property income increased 27.3% to S$15.8 million. The trust attributed the increase to additional rental contributions from acquired properties. Despite the growth, Viva Industrial Trust expressed concerns about occupancy and rental reversion rates in the Singapore Reits sector.

site_title: Japan govt to start testing mileage of Mitsubishi Motors cars: minister
summary: Japan's Transport Minister Keiichi Ishii announced the government will start testing the fuel economy of Mitsubishi Motors' cars next week, with results for the first four models set to be announced in June. The tests come after Mitsubishi admitted to manipulating mileage test data and using non-compliant testing methods since 1991. The ministry had previously set up a task force to examine fuel economy data from all automakers, and plans to conduct tests for other models after the initial four.

images.alt_text: Japan will begin tests to measure the fuel economy of vehicles made by Mitsubishi Motors Corp next week and announce results on the first four models in June, Transport Minister Keiichi Ishii said on Thursday.

site_title: Brazil keeps rates on hold in bid to ease inflation
summary: Brazil's central bank, Copom, unanimously voted to keep interest rates at 14.25% for the sixth consecutive meeting, aiming to ease inflation. Despite a recent slowdown in inflation, the bank stated that rate cuts are not imminent, citing high inflation and inflation expectations. Analysts interpreted the decision as a sign policymakers are gearing up to ease monetary policy later this year. The bank's board, led by Alexandre Tombini, may be replaced if Vice President Michel Temer becomes president, further adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Qatar Airways urges Airbus to resolve A350 'issues'
summary: Qatar Airways has urged Airbus to resolve issues with the A350 passenger jet, citing reliability concerns related to the supply chain. The airline, the largest A350 customer, has ordered 80 jets and delivered the first eight. Deliveries have been delayed due to shortages of cabin equipment. Qatar Airways CEO Akbar Al Baker criticized Airbus's performance, stating the company is "losing steam" in resolving these problems. Airbus has no comment ahead of its quarterly results.

images.alt_text: Qatar Airways increased pressure on Europe's Airbus over aircraft reliability on Wednesday, saying it had some "issues" with the A350 passenger jet, barely a year after it entered service.

site_title: Pfizer to pay US$785m for overcharging US government on drugs
summary: Pfizer has agreed to pay nearly US$785 million to settle allegations that its unit, Wyeth, overcharged the US government for anti-acid drugs Protonix from 2001 to 2006. Wyeth knowingly reported false prices and failed to report deep discounts, resulting in hundreds of millions of dollars in avoided rebates to Medicaid. Under the settlement, Wyeth will pay US$413.2 million to the federal government and US$371.4 million to state Medicaid programs. The agreement was reached as part of a settlement with the Justice Department, with both Wyeth and Pfizer denying the allegations.

site_title: Oil prices hit fresh 2016 highs
summary: Oil prices surged to 2016 highs for the second consecutive day, reaching $45.33 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate and $47.18 a barrel for Brent North Sea. The Federal Reserve's more optimistic outlook for the global economy and expectations of declining US production and increasing demand drove the price increase. Analysts attribute the trend to technical factors, citing the breaking of resistance lines and momentum. The US Energy Department reported a slight increase in US crude stockpiles, which initially caused prices to fall but were later offset by the Fed's announcement.
