site_title: FBI will not share iPhone unlocking mechanism, cites lack of ownership
summary: The FBI will not share the iPhone unlocking mechanism used to open a San Bernardino shooter's iPhone, citing a lack of ownership. The agency hired a contractor to unlock the phone, but did not purchase the rights to the technique. As a result, the FBI does not have enough technical information to submit for an interagency review on the vulnerability. The review would decide whether the vulnerability could be disclosed to government agencies or the private sector.

site_title: Japan March industrial output up 3.6% month on month
summary: Japan's industrial output increased 3.6% in March from the previous month, rebounding from a 5.2% drop in February. The rebound was attributed to the Lunar New Year holidays and Toyota's temporary factory halt. Manufacturers expect output to rise 2.6% in April and decline 2.3% in May. The data suggests a tentative pick-up in factory activity, but the recovery may be short-lived.

images.alt_text: Japan's industrial output rose 3.6 per cent in March, rebounding from a big drop logged in the prior month, government data showed on Thursday, in a tentative sign of a pick-up in factory activity.

site_title: Ahead of rare North Korea Congress, money trumps Party for most
summary: North Korea's Workers' Party Congress, set to begin on May 6, highlights the growing influence of money over Party membership. Defectors and academics say that membership no longer guarantees better jobs or status, as a nascent grey market economy has taken hold, providing for most North Koreans. The party's traditional grip on society is weakening, and those at the top are using their connections to accumulate wealth. Meanwhile, ordinary people prioritize private business over Party membership, with some even using their Party affiliation to supplement their income through smuggling and other illicit activities.

site_title: Popeyes S'pore starts using 100% self-order kiosks at some outlets
summary: Popeyes Singapore has introduced 100% self-order kiosks at some outlets, becoming the first quick service restaurant to aggressively use the technology. The move aims to increase productivity and improve service levels. This innovative approach is expected to enhance the in-restaurant experience for customers.

site_title: US: Stocks boosted by better Fed outlook; Apple dives
summary: US stocks rose after the Federal Reserve offered a more optimistic view of the global economy, boosting the Dow and S&P 500. However, Apple shares plummeted 6.4% due to its first-ever drop in iPhone sales and quarterly revenue decline. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.5%. Despite this, the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% to 18,044.08, and the S&P 500 rose 0.2% to 2,095.41. Higher oil prices also lifted petroleum-linked shares.

site_title: New Zealand leaves interest rates at record low
summary: New Zealand's central bank left interest rates at a record low of 2.25% amid inflation concerns. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand warned it may lower rates if inflation remains below target, which stood at 0.4% for the year to March. Governor Graeme Wheeler said monetary policy would remain accommodative, expecting inflation to strengthen as the effects of low oil prices fade. Economists predict at least one more interest cut this year, with differing opinions on when it will occur.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust's Q1 DPU down 9.2% to 1.112 Singapore cents
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) reported a 9.2% decrease in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.112 Singapore cents for Q1 2016, down from 1.225 cents in the same period last year. Gross revenue rose 3.2% to S$28.37 million, while net property income increased 1.2% to S$21.5 million. Approximately 20.2% of CIT's leases are due for renewal in FY2016, with 13.1% and 7.1% for single- and multi-tenanted buildings, respectively.

site_title: US House passes email privacy bill
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a bill with a 419-0 vote to boost email and electronic communication privacy, closing loopholes in digital data protection. The measure requires court orders to access emails, text messages, and cloud data for investigations. Representative Bob Goodlatte said the 1986 law is outdated and insufficiently protects Americans' privacy. The bill now heads to the Senate for consideration.

site_title: Alibaba on verge of leading Chinese takeover of AC Milan: reports
summary: Alibaba is on the verge of leading a Chinese takeover of AC Milan, Italian football club, after a consortium led by Thai businessman Bee Taechaubol's failed bid. Alibaba's Jack Ma, who owns a Chinese football club, is reportedly offering €400 million for a 70% stake in the club. The move comes as AC Milan struggles financially, with debts of around €250 million and losses of €91 million in the 2014-15 season. The club's owner, Silvio Berlusconi, is expected to give shareholders an indication of his intentions at a meeting on Thursday.

site_title: S&P downgrades ExxonMobil's top credit rating
summary: Standard & Poor's downgraded ExxonMobil's top credit rating to AA+ for the first time since the Great Depression, citing the company's stable financial situation despite the worst oil and gas slump since the 1980s. The downgrade signals pressure from low oil prices and investigations into climate change. ExxonMobil's stock price rose slightly despite the downgrade, and the company's refinery and chemical industries remain a saving grace. The downgrade also highlights the challenges large oil companies face in finding additional reserves to replace declining production.

site_title: Facebook profits surge as user base expands
summary: Facebook reported a 300% surge in profits to $1.5 billion in the first quarter, with revenue jumping to $5.4 billion. The company's monthly active users rose 15% to 1.65 billion, and daily users increased 16% to 1.09 billion. Facebook's advertising revenue soared 57% and is expected to capture $10.2 billion in display ad revenue in the US this year. The company also announced plans to create a non-voting class of stock to raise capital while maintaining CEO Mark Zuckerberg's control.

site_title: Lufthansa delays Brussels Airlines acquisition decision after attacks
summary: Lufthansa has postponed its decision on acquiring Brussels Airlines until September, citing the need to prioritize restoring reliable flight operations following the March 22 suicide bombings in Brussels. The delay allows Brussels Airlines to resume flights and comply with security provisions. Lufthansa, which already holds 45% of Brussels Airlines, had initially been required to make a decision by June, but the deadline has been extended to the end of August. The acquisition would give Lufthansa control of Brussels Airlines' parent company SN Airholding.

site_title: Greek PM seeks EU help to break creditor deadlock
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras sought EU help to break a deadlock in debt talks, amid accusations from his spokeswoman that the IMF is "undermining" the process. Tsipras asked EU President Donald Tusk to call a summit to facilitate negotiations, as an expected Eurogroup meeting was postponed. The IMF is demanding additional "contingency measures" that Greece believes go beyond the bailout deal, prompting criticism from EU officials. A summit is set to be held on Thursday to discuss debt relief and unlock promised cash from Greece's massive rescue package.

site_title: First Sponsor's Q1 profit rises 14%
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a 14% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$12.23 million in Q1 2016, despite a 260% surge in revenue. The company's margins were weighed down by the emergence of problematic loans in its property financing business, which now account for 87% of its loan portfolio. Revenue was primarily driven by property sales, with 84.4% of total revenue coming from this segment. The company has initiated legal action on problematic loans and plans to expand its property development project in the Netherlands.

site_title: Trump vows 'America first' foreign policy
summary: US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump vowed a "America first" foreign policy, promising to overhaul the country's alliances and prioritize national interests. In a speech, Trump criticized the US trade deficit with China and warned that allies must pay for defense costs. He also attacked President Barack Obama's record and accused Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton of refusing to name the greatest threat to the US: radical Islam. The speech, seen as a test of Trump's foreign policy credentials, left many questions unanswered, but may provide a "comfort blanket" for non-experts who want to believe he can mount a credible campaign.

images.alt_text: US Republican White House frontrunner Donald Trump promised a top-to-bottom overhaul of US foreign policy Wednesday to put "America first" and make its allies pay up.

site_title: US dollar steady as Fed keeps rates unchanged
summary: The US dollar remained steady after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, as expected, at its latest meeting. The Fed's benchmark federal funds rate remains at 0.25-0.50% and policymakers now see a stronger probability of a rate hike in June due to a mixed US economic outlook. The decision had a small effect on the dollar, with the euro trading down 0.2% against the US dollar. The Bank of Japan is expected to announce more stimulus for its struggling economy on Thursday.

site_title: Lone Star raises US$5.9b for real estate pte equity fund
summary: Lone Star Funds has raised US$5.9 billion for its new real estate-focused private equity fund, Lone Star Real Estate Fund V. The fund will invest in commercial property assets in the Americas, Europe, and Asia Pacific. Investors include corporate and public pension funds, sovereign wealth funds, and wealthy individuals. The fund's initial target was US$5 billion, but was exceeded due to strong demand. This follows a record year for real estate private equity funds, which generated annual returns of nearly 17% between 2012 and 2014.

site_title: Senior Barclays executive denies knowledge of Libor rate rigging
summary: A senior Barclays executive, Michael Bagguley, denies knowledge of Libor rate rigging between 2005 and 2007. He testified in a London court that he never sought to influence rates, instructed others to do so, or seen any evidence of manipulation. Five former Barclays traders and a rate submitter are on trial for conspiracy to defraud by manipulating US dollar Libor rates. Bagguley, a 15-year Barclays veteran, claims he would have considered influencing Libor rates improper at the time, contradicting a lawyer's suggestion that he was denying knowledge due to fear of prosecution.

images.alt_text: Senior Barclays executive Michael Bagguley told a London court that he had never sought to influence Libor benchmark interest rates, instructed others to do so, or seen any evidence of manipulation between 2005 and 2007.

site_title: Do you earn less than a Silicon Valley intern?
summary: Silicon Valley summer interns may earn more than the national median wage of $46,481.52, with median monthly base salaries ranging from $4,500 to $9,000. According to Rodney Folz's survey, companies like Google, Apple, and Uber offer median monthly salaries of $6,666, $6,800, and $6,500, respectively. Other companies, such as Pinterest and Twitch, offer higher salaries, with median monthly salaries of $9,000 and $7,200, respectively. Many interns did not attempt to negotiate their salary, citing the excitement and responsibility of the role.

site_title: Heilongjiang cuts land sales, offers buyers subsidies
summary: Heilongjiang, China's northernmost province, aims to reduce a housing glut by 2018 through restricting land sales and offering subsidies to rural folk buying homes in urban areas. The move is part of China's government goal to destock the real estate sector this year. This effort follows China's economic slowdown and a housing overhang in the province. By limiting land sales and providing subsidies, Heilongjiang hopes to achieve a "reasonable level" of housing supply.

site_title: Home overvaluation seen in many Canadian cities: housing agency
summary: Canada's federal housing agency says many of its major cities, including Toronto and Vancouver, show signs of overvaluation in the housing market. The Canadian Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC) found strong evidence of overvaluation in Vancouver, Toronto, Calgary, and Edmonton, while nine out of 15 cities showed signs of overvaluation. Although overall overvaluation is moderate, CMHC does not consider overheating a concern at this time. The agency attributes the growth in the housing market to low interest rates and a fragmented market, with some regions slowing and others accelerating.

images.alt_text: The housing markets of many of Canada's major cities show signs of being overvalued, including in Toronto and Vancouver, where prices have continued to climb, the country's federal housing agency said on Wednesday.

site_title: Cool Asian fashion brands challenging Western labels
summary: Asian fashion brands from South Korea, China, and Japan are gaining popularity and challenging Western labels, with many Asian consumers under 35 seeking unique, original brands that showcase their own style. Asian brands are experimenting with new textiles and materials, attracting attention for their high quality and distinctive designs. Chinese fashion brands, such as Ms Min and Comme moi, are the fastest-growing contemporary-design labels, with Lane Crawford and other retailers expanding their offerings. Japanese brands, like Sacai and Tsumori Chisato, are also gaining traction, with Lady Gaga frequently wearing Japanese designer Roggykei.

site_title: America is finally putting the home foreclosure crisis behind it
summary: The US foreclosure crisis has finally subsided, with foreclosure numbers falling to pre-2008 levels. After nine years, the number of properties in active foreclosure declined to 631,000 in March, the lowest since October 2007. Delinquencies on home loans have also decreased, with rates falling to 4.08% in March, the lowest since March 2007. This trend is attributed to rising incomes and low unemployment, allowing more borrowers to stay current with their payments. The country's housing market is showing signs of improvement, but still faces challenges ahead.

site_title: KepLand releasing new block at Highline condo
summary: KepLand is launching its Highline Residences condominium on April 30, with a new block featuring 60 units for sale. The project, which comprises 500 homes, has already sold 86% of its units, with prices ranging from S$1 million to S$2.4 million per unit. The development, designed by W Architects, features an elevated green ridge and recreational facilities, and offers privileged membership and concierge services. Aspial Corporation's 50%-owned Urban Vista has obtained its Temporary Occupation Permit, and its Waterfront @ Faber project has been fully sold.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Bosch sets aside 650m euros in legal provisions
summary: Bosch has set aside 650 million euros in 2015 for potential legal costs related to its role in Volkswagen's diesel emissions manipulation scandal. The company, which supplies software and components to Volkswagen, denies responsibility for the scandal, citing its policy of not manipulating emissions or fuel consumption. Bosch expects sales to rise at the lower end of its forecast range despite a slowdown in the first quarter. The company's earnings before interest and taxes rose 24% to 4.6 billion euros last year.

images.alt_text: Car parts maker Bosch set aside 650 million euros in 2015 for potential legal costs, including for an ongoing investigation into the company's role in Volkswagen's diesel emissions manipulation scandal.

site_title: Fake stones may undermine Sri Lanka's gem trade
summary: Sri Lanka's gem trade is under threat from fake stones, with artificial glass sapphires being sold as the real thing to unsuspecting buyers. The industry's reputation is at stake, with gem traders estimating that the fake stones are killing the market for genuine gems. Stories of buyers being conned into purchasing fakes have been reported, with one Australian buyer spending $14,000 on fake stones before they were discovered to be fakes. The Sri Lankan government's National Gem and Jewellery Authority is working to combat the issue, but the problem persists, posing a significant threat to the country's economy.

site_title: Take the twist out of 'death spiral' convertibles
summary: A proxy battle at Magnus Energy involves minority shareholders seeking to stop the company from issuing more "death spiral" convertible bonds, which can be devastating for the underlying stock price. These bonds are issued at a discount to market and create an increasingly dilutive effect with each round of conversion. A group of minority shareholders wants to remove the current directors and appoint their own nominees to ensure they don't exercise an option to buy the remaining convertibles. Regulators and independent directors must ensure that such instruments are not used to skirt rules about control of a company, and shareholders must learn to recognize the risks of these instruments.

site_title: China's corporate debt problem needs urgent attention: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that China's high corporate debt, reaching 160% of gross domestic product, needs urgent attention to avoid serious problems. The IMF suggests that the Chinese authorities should focus on converting non-performing loans into equity and securitizing them to address the issue. However, the IMF cautions that these techniques are not comprehensive solutions and require a sound overall framework to be effective.

site_title: Toyota on top with Altis as No 1 model
summary: Toyota remains the top-selling brand in Singapore, with the Altis model leading the way, accounting for 1,380 registrations. Honda is a close second, with the Vezel sub-compact SUV being its best-selling model, accounting for 2,344 registrations. The Mazda3 is third, followed by the Nissan Qashqai and Nissan Sylphy. The Toyota Wish and Mercedes-Benz C-Class sedan round out the top 6. Honda's popularity in the Vezel model has narrowed the gap between Honda and Toyota, with Honda ending 2015 as the runner-up.

site_title: Trade deficit down to one-year low in March
summary: The US merchandise trade deficit decreased to $56.9 billion in March, the lowest in over a year, due to a 4.4% decline in imported goods. This decline, along with a 1.2% decrease in exports, is prompting economists to revise their estimates for first-quarter GDP. The housing market also showed signs of improvement, with pending home resales rising 1.4% to a 10-month high.

site_title: SpaceX targets 2018 for first Mars mission
summary: SpaceX plans to launch an unmanned Dragon spacecraft to Mars as early as 2018, a key step towards achieving its goal of sending humans to the planet. The Red Dragon program aims to develop technologies for human transportation to Mars, with Elon Musk's company targeting the end of the year to debut its Mars rocket. SpaceX will provide more details of its Mars program at the International Astronautical Congress in September.

images.alt_text: SpaceX plans to send an unmanned Dragon spacecraft to Mars as early as 2018, the company said on Wednesday, a first step in achieving founder Elon Musk's goal to fly people to another planet.

site_title: Latest scandal is second existential threat in decade for Mitsubishi
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp faces its second existential threat in a decade due to a scandal involving the improper testing of fuel economy for nearly a quarter century. The company's president, Tetsuro Aikawa, has admitted the issue, and shares have plummeted by half in value. The crisis may lead to compensation for customers, investors, and Nissan, which supplied about three-quarters of the affected minicars. If the extent of the wrongdoing is not revealed, Mitsubishi's survival could be at risk, according to analysts. The scandal is part of a broader reckoning of vehicle emissions testing in the automotive industry.

site_title: Samsung planning US$9b downpayment on iPhone displays
summary: Samsung is reportedly planning a $9 billion downpayment to become the exclusive supplier of OLED displays for Apple's iPhone models, expected to be released next year. The deal would require Samsung to build capacity for the thinner, brighter, and less battery-draining technology. This move could help Samsung reverse declining smartphone market share and revenue, with analysts predicting a significant price premium for the new displays. The deal would also accelerate Samsung's diversification beyond phones, as the company seeks to reduce dependence on Google's Android operating system.

site_title: Canada's Husky Energy hurt by China gas policy
summary: Canadian oil and gas producer Husky Energy Inc. saw its shares plummet 9.2% amid China's efforts to lower natural gas prices for consumers, threatening the company's contract for its biggest energy project, the Liwan development in the South China Sea. Husky's partner, CNOOC Ltd, warned of lower prices to come, which could have a "meaningful impact" on Husky's financial results. The Chinese government's price cuts are part of its efforts to shift consumption from coal to natural gas, with gas demand expanding 3.3% in 2015.

site_title: Stronger March China industrial profits add to economic recovery hopes
summary: China's industrial profits rose 11.1% in March, reaching 561.24 billion yuan, as the country's economic slowdown may be bottoming out. This marks a 7.4% increase in total first-quarter profits, up from a 4.8% rise in the previous quarter. The improvement in industrial profits adds to hopes for an economic recovery.

site_title: Britain has a proven, off-the-shelf alternative in Efta
summary: Britain has a clear majority of support for rejoining the European Free Trade Association (Efta) rather than remaining in the European Union (EU). A poll by the Bruges Group think tank found that 70% of British people prefer the Efta option, which would allow the UK to trade with the EU without political union. This is seen as a more sensible alternative to Prime Minister David Cameron's EU deal, which achieved nothing of substance. Efta members Norway, Iceland, and Liechtenstein have full access to the EU's single market via the European Economic Area (EEA) agreement.

site_title: The tripartite way to beat economic blues
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say and SNEF president Robert Yap have urged labour, employers, and the government to work together to boost productivity and create good jobs. They emphasized the need for companies to become "manpower-lean" through business transformation, automation, and skills upgrading to drive future growth. The government will also strengthen policies and resources to support companies and workers. The two leaders acknowledged Singapore's demographic challenges, including an ageing population, and stressed the importance of companies adapting to these changes to remain competitive.

site_title: Uber helps its drivers to earn fares even on that last home-bound trip
summary: Uber introduced a new feature, Driver Destinations, in Singapore, allowing drivers to indicate their homebound routes to find trips along those routes. The feature aims to improve efficiency and save drivers time and fuel, potentially attracting and retaining drivers in a competitive market. Market observers believe it will also benefit riders indirectly by making the demand-supply matching more efficient. The feature, which can be set up to twice a day, is currently being tested and will be launched island-wide in the coming weeks.

site_title: US$ dips as market awaits Fed clues; A$ dives
summary: The US dollar inched down against the yen as investors await the US Federal Reserve's statement on interest rates, expected to be unchanged on Wednesday. The Australian dollar plummeted 1.9% after disappointing inflation data, sparking speculation of a potential interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. Markets anticipate the Fed's statement for clues on future rate hikes, with some predicting easing measures, including stock purchases and interest rate cuts.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: China Aviation Oil's share price closed at S$0.905 on April 27, with a target price of S$1.22. This article is not related to the provided article, it appears to be unrelated.

site_title: Singapore sees broader weakening in economic activity
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow between 1-3% this year, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore, due to a weakening global economic outlook. The central bank warned of pockets of corporate stress, easing margins, and weaker business expectations. Growth in the trade-related industries, which drove the economy in the past, has deteriorated amid persistent external weakness. The MAS also noted that the sluggish investment climate, particularly in the electronics and precision engineering industries, may weigh on the economy.

site_title: Barclays' Q1 earnings decline on falling returns on investments
summary: Barclays reported Q1 earnings of £793m, below analyst forecast of £846m, but 7% higher after stripping out a £109m accounting charge. The bank's investment banking revenues declined 11% in dollar terms, but were still considered strong compared to peers. Barclays' core units performed well, with a 9.9% return on equity. The bank is in talks to sell its French retail banking operations and has already announced plans to sell its 62% stake in Barclays Africa Group. New CEO Jes Staley welcomed the earnings, saying they were a "relatively clean and good set of numbers."

site_title: Fighting ISIS like it's a cancer might just work
summary: The US is considering using cancer treatment protocols to defeat ISIS, viewing the terrorist organization as a metastasizing disease. The analogy suggests using strategies like evisceration, starvation, and immunization to combat ISIS, but a complete cure may require stem-cell infusion of good governance and immunotherapies to prevent relapse. The international community is exploring various approaches, including counter-narrative campaigns, social media efforts, and vaccination programs, but each has its limitations and concerns. A consensus on a unified strategy is necessary to effectively defeat ISIS and prevent its re-emergence.

site_title: SembMarine expects protracted O&M down-cycle
summary: SembMarine, a Singapore-based offshore and marine company, reported a 48.2% year-on-year decline in Q1 net profit to S$54.83 million, citing a protracted down-cycle in the industry. Turnover fell 29.6% and gross profit margin declined to 8.8% due to lower revenue recognition from rig-building projects. Despite securing S$60 million in new contracts, the company maintains a cautious outlook due to ongoing challenges in the macro-environment and volatile market conditions.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Marine is expecting the down-cycle in the offshore & marine industry to be more protracted than in previous cycles.

site_title: Investors want mutual funds to toughen up on CEO pay
summary: Investors are urging mutual fund firms to challenge CEO pay, citing that top money managers like BlackRock and Vanguard rarely challenge CEO compensation in proxy votes. Individual investors, who collectively oversee trillions of dollars, are frustrated with the lack of action.

images.alt_text: Top money managers such as BlackRock Inc and Vanguard Group oversee trillions of dollars for individuals, but the firms rarely challenge CEO pay in their proxy votes on behalf of investors.

site_title: Tag Heuer said to pay £5m for Premier League deal
summary: Tag Heuer has agreed to a three-year deal worth £5 million per season to become a sponsor of the Premier League. The deal, which marks the league's shift to multiple corporate partners, is part of a broader marketing strategy aimed at increasing revenue. The agreement, which includes Tag Heuer as the league's official time keeper and watch partner, is seen as a significant expansion of the watch company's sports sponsorship efforts. This marks a departure from the league's previous £40 million per season title sponsorship agreement with Barclays plc.

site_title: AA Reit posts higher Q4 DPU; warns of pressure on rents
summary: AA Reit posted a 1% increase in Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.95 Singapore cents, driven by a 0.7% rise in gross revenue to S$30.29 million. However, Q4's gross revenue declined 6.9% from Q3 due to lower occupancies and a fire incident at one of its properties, which is now being redeveloped with improved specifications. The industrial landlord warned of pressure on rents due to the weak economic climate and oversupply situation in Singapore, focusing on maintaining good tenant relationships.

site_title: Trump, Clinton closer to election showdown after massive wins
summary: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton dominated primaries in Pennsylvania, Maryland, and other Eastern states, gaining enough delegates to close in on their parties' nominations. Trump won all five primaries, defeating Ted Cruz and John Kasich by significant margins, while Clinton secured more delegates than Sanders. The victories intensified the aura of inevitability around their nomination bids, increasing Trump's chances of avoiding a convention fight and claiming the nomination outright. Clinton predicted she would return to the Democratic convention with the most votes and pledged to heal party wounds, while Sanders vowed to stay in the race.

images.alt_text: Mrs Clinton chided the Republican's penchant for harsh language by saying that "love trumps hate", while Mr Trump was more bluntly dismissive, saying her appeal boiled down to her gender.

site_title: Blackstone to buy into three Sime Darby properties worth S$300m
summary: Blackstone is set to acquire a majority stake in three Singapore properties worth S$300 million from Sime Darby. The properties, including Sime Darby Centre and two light industrial developments, are expected to generate a 6% yield. The deal is part of Sime Darby's efforts to reduce debt and is seen as a strategic move for Blackstone, with potential plans to spruce up the properties and offload them or assemble a bigger portfolio for a potential Reit listing.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Campaigning in full swing as PAP, SDP cross swords
summary: The Bukit Batok by-election in Singapore is set to take place on May 7, with two contenders, Murali Pillai of the PAP and Chee Soon Juan of the SDP, having secured the green light to contest. Both candidates successfully navigated the Nomination Day proceedings without issues. The by-election was triggered by the resignation of the incumbent MP. The outcome of the election is expected to be closely watched, with the PAP and SDP engaging in a heated campaign.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
The two candidates, the SDP's Dr Chee (left) and the PAP's Mr Murali met briefly as they filed their papers on Wednesday, Nomination Day.

site_title: Train breakdown reasons: SMRT must be clearer and more transparent
summary: A power fault caused a major train breakdown on Monday evening, affecting three MRT lines and one LRT line, stranding thousands of commuters. The disruption lasted for over an hour, with the Bukit Panjang LRT experiencing a two-hour delay. This incident has highlighted the need for SMRT to be clearer and more transparent about the reasons behind such breakdowns.

site_title: Muhammad Ibrahim takes over from Zeti
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia's governor, Zeti Akhtar Aziz, is retiring after 16 years, and Muhammad Ibrahim has been appointed as his successor, taking office on May 1. Ibrahim's appointment aims to stabilize the central bank amid the 1MDB default, which triggered cross-defaults on two bond tranches. Markets view him as a neutral candidate with considerable central banking experience, and analysts believe his appointment will help maintain market confidence.

site_title: Higher rents, new properties lift Ascendas India in Q4
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported an 8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.4 Singapore cents for the Q4 2016 period, driven by higher rents, new properties, and increased average portfolio occupancy. The trust, which owns six IT business parks in India, attributed the growth to its efforts to diversify its portfolio and increase its revenue streams. The increase in DPU is expected to be paid on May 27.

site_title: Upgraded trade deal to beef up S'pore-Japan cooperation: Vivian
summary: Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan announced the planned upgrading of the Japan-Singapore Economic Partnership Agreement (JSEPA), aiming to be completed by the end of 2016. The agreement, signed in 2002, promotes economic stability and cooperation between the two nations. Balakrishnan also expressed hope for the ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement, citing the need for both countries to transform their economies and address challenges such as low fertility rates and stagnant labor forces.

site_title: Qatar Airways rejects A320neo plane as Airbus awaits engine fix
summary: Qatar Airways has rejected the Airbus A320neo plane due to glitches in the turbine designed to power the revamped jetliner. The European company, Airbus, is awaiting a fix from engine maker Pratt & Whitney, which could delay deliveries to Qatar, Lufthansa, and Norwegian Air Shuttle. The issue may also impact a 50-plane order from Qatar, with CEO Akbar Al Baker stating that the airline will not take delivery until the problem is resolved.

images.alt_text: Qatar Airways' Mr Al Baker said that the issue could even halt a 50-plane order.

site_title: Comcast said to be in talks to acquire DreamWorks Animation
summary: Comcast is in talks to acquire DreamWorks Animation for approximately $3 billion, a 30% increase from its current market value. The deal would combine the studio with Illumination Entertainment, led by CEO Christopher Meledandri, potentially resulting in the departure of Jeffrey Katzenberg and layoffs. DreamWorks Animation, known for franchises like Shrek and Kung Fu Panda, has struggled to maintain profitability despite efforts by Katzenberg to revamp the studio.

site_title: OECD sounds warning of sharp fall in UK and European growth if Brexit happens
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has warned of a sharp decline in UK and European growth if the UK leaves the European Union (EU). The OECD predicts a 3% decline in GDP by 2020, equivalent to £2,200 per household. The warning comes as the UK's economy already shows signs of slowing, with a 0.4% growth rate in the first quarter of this year. The OECD secretary-general Angel Gurría has stated that Brexit would impose a "Brexit tax" on future generations, resulting in a pure deadweight loss.

site_title: Courts' Causeway Point outlet gets versatile layout
summary: Courts, a Singaporean electronics retailer, has revamped its Causeway Point outlet with a versatile layout, featuring modular elements that allow for frequent changes in product placement. The design enables the store to adapt to changing needs, including larger products and sale periods. The revamped store is the first of its kind in Singapore and serves as a test bed for future changes. The design aims to improve customer engagement and productivity, while also catering to growing competition and changing shopper preferences.

site_title: Wong Yu Loon to be deputy group CEO of Boustead from May 1
summary: Boustead Singapore appoints Wong Yu Loon as deputy group CEO, effective May 1, to ensure business continuity. The 41-year-old Wong, son of Boustead chairman and group CEO Wong Fong Fui, will assist the group CEO in overseeing operations and strategic planning. Wong joined the group in 2003 and previously held roles in corporate planning, group investment, and mergers and acquisitions. The appointment is seen as beneficial to the group and aligns with plans to maintain business continuity.

site_title: Oil majors' results surprise, but output fall, volatile trading lurk
summary: Major oil companies BP, Total, and Statoil have delivered surprise first-quarter results, beating expectations with profits of $532 million, $1.3 billion, and $2.2 billion respectively. However, the good times are unlikely to last due to volatile trading operations and a likely fall in production. Despite the market downturn, Europe's big oil producers have managed to report their worst quarterly earnings yet, indicating the industry's struggles ahead.

site_title: Labour pains flagged in central bank's macroeconomic review
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has released its biannual Macroeconomic Review, flagging labour pains in the country's economy, including slower wage growth (2.5-3%) and a rising resident unemployment rate. Despite softening labour demand and supply, MAS has already factored these into its policy move, suggesting that current policy settings may remain unchanged unless the labour market or external environment deteriorates. MAS forecasts core inflation to come in the lower half of the 0.5-1.5% forecast range, driven by smaller price declines in the CPI basket.

site_title: Top airline execs see profitability gains tapering
summary: Airline chief financial officers and cargo industry leaders reported declining expectations for profitability gains, with under 42% expecting an increase in the next year. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) survey also found the cargo industry facing tougher times, with nearly 27% reporting deteriorating traffic in the first quarter. Declining yields and uneven economic growth are contributing to downward pressure on costs, with 70% of respondents reporting a year-on-year decrease in passenger yields.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Buy or bye: Social insights into what customers really want
summary: Companies must adapt to the digital age by understanding their customers' needs and behaviors. Social media provides a real-time pulse on customers' attitudes and behaviors, and customer service is now 52% more important to consumers than value for money. To succeed, brands must define their ideal customer service experience, mine social media data to refine targeting strategies, and engage with customers in a personalized and genuine manner. Successful brands like Apple and T-Mobile have seen significant benefits from leveraging social media for customer service, transforming it from an expense to a critical brand asset.

site_title: China's 'teapot' refiners bolster presence in S'pore (Amended)
summary: A coalition of 17 independent Chinese refiners, led by Dongming Petrochemical, has established a presence in Singapore, bolstering the country's oil trading sector. The group, nicknamed "teapots" due to their smaller refining capacities, has combined crude import quotas of 60 million tonnes and refining capacity of 70 million tonnes. They plan to use a trading office in Singapore to buy and sell crude oil, and may also export refined fuels. This marks a significant shift in the energy sector in China, which has allowed independent refiners to import crude oil for the first time.

site_title: US crude inventories rise less than expected: EIA
summary: US crude inventories rose to a record high last week, increasing by 2 million barrels, beating expectations of a 2.4 million-barrel rise. Crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub rose by 1.75 million barrels. Refinery crude runs fell by 257,000 barrels per day, and distillate stockpiles, including diesel and heating oil, dropped by 1.7 million barrels. US crude imports fell by 688,000 barrels per day, while gasoline stocks rose by 1.6 million barrels.

site_title: Bank of England won't hesitate to act on housing risks: deputy chief
summary: Bank of England deputy governor Jon Cunliffe warned that the central bank won't hesitate to act on housing market risks, citing buy-to-let, lending at high loan-to-income ratios, and commercial real estate as hotspots. The FPC is monitoring property markets closely and has already taken action, with Cunliffe expecting increased attention to these risks as the credit cycle becomes more established. The UK government has taken steps to dampen the growth of buy-to-let lending, but Cunliffe noted the impact on the housing market may not be significant, and household debt remains a concern for financial stability.

site_title: Trudeau: politician and star of his own viral universe
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has become a viral sensation, with nearly 1.5 million views on a YouTube video about quantum computing. Since his election in October 2015, Trudeau has become a digital star, with videos of him explaining feminism and hugging baby pandas regularly going viral on social media. His ability to engage with the public and share his thoughts on various topics has made him a beloved figure among Canadians and beyond.

site_title: Far East H-Trust warns of challenging operating environment
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a higher distribution of 1.08 Singapore cents for Q1FY16, up from 1.07 cents in the same quarter last year. The Reit manager warned that the local hospitality sector faces challenges from new hotel supply and weaker corporate demand.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
According to estimates from Singapore Tourism Board, visitor arrivals were up 12.3 per cent year on year in January and February.

site_title: Serial System, King Wan, Global Palm Resources issue profit warnings
summary: Serial System, King Wan, and Global Palm Resources have issued profit warnings for the first quarter ended March 31. Serial System expects a loss, while King Wan anticipates a loss for its fourth quarter and full year due to impairment and loan allowances. Global Palm Resources expects a lower net profit after tax, citing decreased sales revenue and average selling price for crude palm oil and palm kernel.

site_title: GMG Global minorities unhappy with merger offer
summary: Minority shareholders of GMG Global are unhappy with a merger offer from Halcyon Agri, claiming the firm has been under-valued. The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) stated that the offer undervalues GMG Global, with its net asset value exceeding three times that of Halcyon Agri. The voluntary general offer for GMG Global is valued at $0.70 per share, while Halcyon Agri is valued at $0.75 per share. Minority shareholders are urging the board to re-evaluate the offer and consider the potential undervaluation of GMG Global.

site_title: Manufacturers' import costs would be cut under US house bill
summary: US manufacturers could benefit from lower tariffs on imported materials under a House bill expected to pass on Wednesday. The bipartisan measure would let companies ask for reduced or suspended tariffs on chemicals and other items not readily available in the US, potentially saving them $2.5 billion in higher taxes since 2012. The bill would replace an expired system and is expected to be advanced by the Senate soon.

site_title: US drug prices keep rising despite intense criticism
summary: US drug prices have continued to rise, with brand-name drugs increasing in price by double-digit percentages since the start of the year. Despite criticism from lawmakers and industry experts, drugmakers have raised prices on top-selling products, including those from Johnson & Johnson, Amgen, and Gilead. List prices have risen 12% in 2015, but net prices paid by insurers and employers have increased only 2.8%. The burden of these price increases falls heavily on uninsured patients and those with limited insurance coverage.

site_title: Apple's waning iPhone sales end 51-quarter growth streak
summary: Apple's 51-quarter streak of uninterrupted sales growth has ended, with the company's second-quarter sales declining 13% to $50.6 billion, and iPhone shipments falling 16%. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in the market for high-end smartphones and stalled economic growth in China, Apple's second-largest market. The company's stock dropped 8.3% to $95.68, and analysts are seeking answers on whether lackluster iPhone sales reflect a broader market slowdown or just a pause before the next upgrade frenzy. Apple is boosting its share-repurchase program and increasing its quarterly dividend.

site_title: Twitter sales forecast misses estimates on brand advertising
summary: Twitter forecasted second-quarter revenue of $590-610 million, missing analyst estimates and causing shares to decline 17% as brand advertising sales fell short of expectations. The company added 5 million monthly active users in the first quarter, but struggles to attract mainstream users. Analysts express concerns that Twitter's product improvements may not be enough to revive interest from advertisers and widen the user base. The company's net loss narrowed to $79.7 million, but revenue growth slowed, with brand marketers not increasing spend as quickly as expected.

site_title: Pound's rally amid slower UK growth shows Brexit's dominance
summary: The pound rose 0.2% to $1.4604 amid slower UK economic growth, with investors focusing on the Brexit referendum. The currency has been volatile since the start of the year, driven by sentiment on the UK's EU membership. Growth slowed to 0.4% in the first quarter, matching forecasts, and concerns over Brexit have led to elevated speculative short positioning. Analysts believe the currency will become more volatile in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The pound rose for a fourth day versus the dollar as data showed that UK economic growth slowed in the first quarter, further evidence that the currency's direction is being driven by investors' view on the nation's June referendum on its membership of the European Union.

site_title: Indiabulls sponsor unit launches mandatory cash offer for trust
summary: A unit of Indiabulls Real Estate, Grapene Limited, has launched a mandatory cash offer for Indiabulls Property Investment Trust (IPIT) units, offering S$0.25 per unit. The offer is conditional on controlling more than 50% of IPIT and aims to acquire the remaining units if at least 90% are accepted. Grapene's stake in IPIT rose to 48.51% after buying 7.54 million units at S$0.20 apiece, and IPIT units rose 0.1 Singapore cent to finish at S$0.20.

site_title: US: Wall St lower after weak results from Apple
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday as Apple's weak results raised concerns about corporate earnings ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.28%, the S&P 500 declined 0.22%, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 0.66%. The weak earnings from Apple, a major US company, sparked investor worries about the quality of corporate earnings.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a 16.8% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$16.4 million, driven by a 5.1% year-on-year revenue growth to S$208.5 million. Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust posted a 10.4% year-on-year increase in available distribution per unit to 1.923 Singapore cents. Meanwhile, OSIM International founder Ron Sim has secured an 88.84% stake in the company, with the option to acquire the remaining shares at a 97% level.

site_title: Boeing's profit hit by tanker charge
summary: Boeing reported a nearly 9% fall in quarterly profit due to a $156 million charge related to the KC-46 tanker, down to $1.22 billion or $1.83 per share. Core earnings fell to $1.74 per share, while revenue rose 2% to $22.63 billion. Commercial aircraft deliveries decreased 4.3% to 176.

site_title: Apple's dazzling 13-year surge ebbs as iPhone sales drop
summary: Apple's 13-year revenue growth streak ended in Q2 with a 13% decline to $50.6 billion, largely due to weaker iPhone sales. The company's shares dropped 8% in after-hours trading. Despite a "pause" in growth, CEO Tim Cook believes the future is "very bright." However, analysts point to saturation in the US market, competition from Android devices, and a slowdown in global sales, particularly in China, where Apple's prospects remain uncertain. The company still generates billions in cash and expects to raise its quarterly dividend and buy back more stock.

site_title: Brazil recession likely to fuel higher mortgage defaults: Moody's
summary: Brazil's recession is likely to fuel higher mortgage defaults and reduce the number of mortgages written this year, according to Moody's Investors Service. State-owned lender Caixa Economica Federal faces higher financing costs, threatening its ability to write new mortgages. Lower household income and higher credit costs will weigh on demand for houses through mid-2017. Caixa's credit growth has slowed to about 12% last year, and the bank is seeking alternative funding sources to support mortgage issuance. The recession is expected to lead to increased payment delays and defaults over the next two years.

site_title: 'Panama Papers' to go public May 9
summary: The International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) will release the "Panama Papers" database on May 9, containing information on over 200,000 secret companies and entities from 21 tax havens. The leak, which includes 11.5 million documents, has sparked global investigations and led to resignations, including Iceland's prime minister and a Spanish minister. The public release is the next step in a year-long investigation, with the ICIJ planning to publish more stories in the coming weeks and months.

site_title: Road ahead for rule of law in China is long and twisted
summary: China's rule of law mechanism is still in its early stages, with 247 laws currently in effect and over 120 bills pending approval. According to Wang Zhenming, head of the Law Department of the Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in Hong Kong, China needs at least 1,000 laws to achieve a complete rule of law mechanism. Despite progress, the country's path to rule of law is expected to be "long and twisted," and China's governance structure remains influenced by the Communist Party. A recent debate between a former diplomat and a newspaper editor suggests a shift towards more rational discussions on foreign policy, which could contribute to China becoming a more "normal" country.

images.alt_text: In mid-April, the Foreign Correspondents Club of Hong Kong sponsored a lunch talk on rule of law in China.

site_title: Rent increase lifts Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust's Q4 DPU
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a 10.4% increase in available distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, reaching 1.923 Singapore cents. The trust's distributable income, net property income, and revenue rose 11.9%, 17.3%, and 15.2% respectively, driven by higher rents at its properties and an enlarged portfolio following the acquisition of a third property in June 2015. The trust's DPU is expected to continue to grow, with the second distribution for the financial year set at 3.771 Singapore cents.

site_title: Yahoo strikes board compromise with activist investors
summary: Yahoo struck a compromise with activist investors Starboard Value, agreeing to add four new members to its board, including Starboard's Jeff Smith. The move aims to shake up the board and address concerns about Yahoo's management and valuation. Two current board members will not stand for re-election, increasing the total number of directors to 11. The new board members will work closely with management to maximize value for all shareholders and explore strategic options, including a potential sale of the company's core internet business.

site_title: A distinct analysis of financial crises from a voice of authority
summary: Lord Adair Turner's book "Between Debt and the Devil: Money, Credit, and Fixing Global Finance" critiques prevailing economics orthodoxy and proposes a novel solution to financial crises. Turner argues that debt is the ultimate cause of financial boom and bust, citing historical and economic evidence. He advocates for "helicopter money" to target private sector leverage, but faces challenges in resolving the core issue of debt. Turner's analysis and recommendations, while standard, are compelling and expose the taboo against printing money to finance public debt. His thesis has sparked debate, but also attracted prominent converts, including Martin Wolf, who sees the potential for fiat money to promote public spending.

site_title: World's safest returns signal pessimism in EM bonds is waning
summary: Emerging-market corporate dollar bonds have seen a 5.6% rally this year, outperforming over 130 assets including US Treasuries, gold, and bitcoin when volatility is factored in. Despite last year's sell-off, investors are returning to the sector, attracted by low volatility and yields that average two percentage points higher than Treasuries. Analysts attribute the turnaround to reduced default risk and state support, with economists warning that weakening currencies would raise repayment costs and lead to increased defaults, which did not materialize this year.

site_title: Opening of new mall to add to South Africa's retail space glut
summary: South Africa's retail space glut is expected to worsen due to the opening of new malls, including the 130,000 square meter Mall of Africa in Johannesburg. The country already has over 23 million square meters of shopping center space, with another 2 million under construction or planned. Analysts predict slowing growth or foot traffic decline as new malls compete for consumers, who may be less willing to spend due to economic conditions. Despite this, some real estate investment trusts (Reits) are performing well, such as Redefine Properties and Hyprop Investments, which own dominant regional and super-regional shopping centers.

site_title: US trade deficit in goods plunged to one-year low in March
summary: US trade deficit in goods decreased to $56.9 billion in March, the lowest in over a year. This represents a 10.3% improvement from February and is lower than the median forecast of $62.8 billion. The March deficit was the smallest since February 2015, which could influence the government's initial estimate of first-quarter GDP.

images.alt_text: America's merchandise trade deficit shrank to US$56.9 billion in March, the lowest in more than a year, advanced data issued by the Commerce Department showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Fed set to keep rates unchanged, may nod to ebbing risks
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at a target range of 0.25-0.50% as it continues to monitor global growth risks. Despite the US economy's relative strength, concerns about a slowing China have sparked caution. Markets have turned up since the last rate decision, with the S&P 500 rising over 14% since mid-February. Fed officials may signal a determination to resume policy tightening this year, with a possible rate hike in June, but will be cautious given the uncertainty in global growth.

site_title: AB InBev plays down talk of move beyond beer
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev) CEO Carlos Brito has stated that the company is unlikely to expand beyond beer, citing higher success rates in integrating acquisitions within its core business. Despite speculation about future deals, Brito believes candidates will be drawn from closer to its core business. AB InBev expects to seal its $100 billion acquisition of SABMiller in the second half of the year and is focusing on growth in low and no-alcohol beers, aiming for 20% of overall revenue by 2025.

site_title: FLASH: Sembcorp Marine's Q1 net profit down 48.2%, turnover down 29.6%
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a 48.2% decline in Q1 net profit and a 29.6% drop in turnover, citing lower revenue from its shipbuilding and repair businesses.

site_title: Statoil sees better days ahead after beating quarterly earnings forecast
summary: Norway's Statoil beat quarterly earnings expectations, driven by cost-cutting measures and a rebalancing of the global oil market. The company reported a 70% decline in underlying operating earnings, but above forecasts. Statoil CEO Eldar Saetre expressed optimism on the industry's prospects, citing a potential rise in prices to $80 per barrel. The company's shares rose 3.7% and outperformed the Oslo benchmark index. Statoil maintained its capital spending target and exploration activity level, and proposed a dividend in line with its guidance.

site_title: Too much dividend can be a turnoff, say investors
summary: European companies are paying out 60% of their earnings as dividends, the highest proportion in over 40 years, sparking concerns about the sustainability of such payouts. Investors are reassessing the strategy, favoring companies that invest in growth over dividend returns, as indicated by a Bank of America-Merrill Lynch survey showing the highest percentage of fund managers saying payout ratios are "too high" since March 2009.

site_title: SembMarine Q1 profit down 48.2%
summary: SembCorp Marine reported a 48.2% decline in Q1 net profit to S$54.83 million due to lower turnover and higher finance costs. Turnover fell 29.6% to S$918.43 million, mainly due to customer deferment and restructuring. Finance costs rose 87.4% due to higher interest expense from increased bank borrowings. Earnings per share fell 48.1% to 2.63 Singapore cents.

site_title: Pending sales of existing homes in US rise more than forecast
summary: Pending home sales in the US rose 1.4% to a 10-month high in March, exceeding economists' forecasts of a 0.5% gain. The National Association of Realtors reported a median forecast of 3.4% growth in February. Steady hiring and low borrowing costs are driving purchases, particularly at the entry-level market. Three of four regions saw an increase, with the Northeast and South experiencing significant gains. The pending sales gauge reached a seasonally adjusted high of 110.5, its highest level since May 2022.

site_title: Google faces EU competition case over image search
summary: Google faces an EU competition case over its image search, after Getty Images filed a complaint alleging the search results hurt its business. Getty Images claims Google's 2013 changes to show high-resolution images drove users away from its site, allowing Google to reinforce its dominance. The European Commission will assess the complaint, which is the latest in a series of anti-competition investigations into Google's Android software and web search business.

site_title: Sheng Siong rakes in higher earnings for Q1
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a first-quarter net profit of S$16.4 million, up 16.8% from the same period last year, driven by sales from new stores. Revenue grew 5.1% year-over-year to S$208.5 million, despite a contraction in comparable same-store sales due to weak Chinese New Year demand.

site_title: Football: FIFA boss wants North-South Korea friendly
summary: FIFA President Gianni Infantino proposed a football match between North and South Korea to ease tensions on the peninsula. The match would highlight the unifying spirit of football, bringing together people "beyond borders." Infantino expressed willingness to help set up the match, which would be the first since 2005. The proposal comes amid high military tensions following North Korea's nuclear test and ballistic missile launch.

site_title: Apple upbeat on iPhone SE demand but some Asian retailers, suppliers less cheery
summary: Apple reported its first-ever drop in iPhone sales, citing a 26% revenue decline in the March quarter in its most important market, Greater China. However, the company's latest and cheapest iPhone SE model is in strong demand, with some retailers and suppliers reporting solid early sales. This mixed outlook has raised concerns about Apple's ability to maintain momentum in China, where slowing economic growth and local brands are gaining market share.

site_title: Wong Yu Loon to be deputy group CEO of Boustead Group from May 1
summary: Boustead Group appoints Wong Yu Loon as deputy group CEO, effective May 1, to ensure business continuity. Wong, 41, is the son of Boustead Singapore's chairman and chief Wong Fong Fui. He has over 13 years of experience in the group, including roles as corporate planning manager, group investment director, and executive director. Wong's appointment is seen as beneficial to the group, with the board citing his extensive knowledge of operations and experience in mergers and acquisitions, fundraising, and corporate advisory.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US oil rises above US$45 a barrel for first time since November
summary: US oil prices rose above $45 a barrel for the first time since November, driven by declining crude stockpiles and a forecast of increased refinery demand. West Texas Intermediate futures gained 2.3% as the US production declines and supply tightens. The World Bank boosted its forecast for oil prices this year, projecting $41 per barrel on average, still down 19% from 2015.

site_title: Jakarta to sink without scandal-mired construction project, says president
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo warned that large parts of Jakarta will sink below sea level by 2030 if the $40 billion "Great Garuda" construction project is not completed. The project aims to revamp the capital's image and shore up northern Jakarta, which is sinking at a faster rate than any other city in the world. The project includes building 17 artificial islands and a 15-mile seawall, but has been delayed due to corruption allegations and bureaucratic clashes.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo said on Wednesday that large parts of the nation's capital will sink below sea level if a US$40 billion construction project, mired by accusations of corruption, does not go ahead.

site_title: China's Guangzhou Auto looks to Fiat Chrysler for help entering US
summary: Guangzhou Automobile Group Co Ltd, a Chinese automaker, is seeking Fiat Chrysler's help in entering the US market. GAC Motor, the company's subsidiary, aims to become the first Chinese passenger car brand sold to American consumers. Foreign car makers in China must form joint ventures with local firms to avoid hefty import taxes. GAC Motor is in discussions with potential dealership partners and has begun road tests in China against American standards, but has not yet begun testing in the US.

site_title: Deutsche Bank hopes to conclude key lawsuits by year-end
summary: Deutsche Bank aims to settle key lawsuits by the end of 2016, according to co-CEO Juergen Fitschen. The bank is currently entangled in over 6,000 litigation cases, including probes on interest rate rigging and money laundering. Deutsche Bank has set aside 13 billion euros in provisions since 2012. Fitschen's comments come amid reported tension on the bank's supervisory board regarding its response to scandals. The bank is scheduled to publish its first-quarter results on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Wednesday, closing at 1,692.34 after 1.73 billion lots valued at RM1.87 billion were traded. The index slipped 0.16 points, with 407 gainers and 379 losers.

site_title: China's steel industry may swing back to profit on price rally
summary: China's steel industry may return to profitability this year due to reduced supply and increased demand, leading to a price rally and decline in exports. The China Iron & Steel Association estimates losses will narrow to around 10 billion yuan (S$2.08 billion) in 2016, down from a record 100 billion yuan in losses in 2015. Steel prices have surged 40% this year, driven by policy makers' growth talks, booming lending, and the property market rebound.

images.alt_text: The world's largest steel industry may swing back to profit this year as reduced supply and increased demand spur a rally in domestic prices and a decline in exports, the China Iron & Steel Association said.

site_title: UN chief says end 'madness' of nuclear weapon testing
summary: UN chief Ban Ki-moon urged the US, China, and other nuclear-armed states to end nuclear testing by ratifying the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty, which turned 20 this year. The treaty, signed by 183 states and ratified by 164, bans all nuclear explosions. However, eight countries, including the US, China, and India, have yet to ratify, preventing the treaty's entry into force. Ban called the "madness" of nuclear testing, citing its harm to the environment and human health, and emphasized the need for a legally binding treaty to replace the current voluntary moratorium.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets hold steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets held steady at the open on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index adding 0.02% to 6,286.01 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 gaining 0.2%, and Paris's CAC 40 edging 0.04% higher. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's interest rate meeting announcement, which could impact global markets. Disappointing earnings news from Apple and Twitter also dampened sentiment.

site_title: UK economy slows in Q1, more reliant on services
summary: Britain's economy slowed in the first quarter of 2016, growing 0.4% according to official data. This is down from 0.6% in the previous quarter and in line with economists' forecasts. The slowdown is attributed to uncertainty surrounding the UK's June 23 EU referendum, with business surveys suggesting it's taking a toll on activity and investment.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank governor-elect pledges policy stability
summary: Malaysia's new central bank governor-elect, Muhammad Ibrahim, has pledged to maintain policy stability, ensuring continuity with his predecessor Zeti Akhtar Aziz's 16-year tenure. Ibrahim, a Harvard graduate and deputy governor since 2010, will lead the bank for a five-year term, starting May 1. The appointment has eased investor concerns about the independence of the central bank, which had been facing setbacks, including a political scandal and alleged financial irregularities. Ibrahim will focus on maintaining monetary and financial stability, and contributing to a better future for all Malaysians.

site_title: Jeers from Brexiteers as OECD says UK would suffer outside EU
summary: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has warned that the UK's departure from the European Union would cause lasting economic damage, with a 3% reduction in GDP by 2020 and 5% by 2030. This would impose a "persistent and rising cost" on the economy, equivalent to £2,200 per household. The report joins other warnings from international bodies, including the Bank of England and the International Monetary Fund, about the impact of Brexit on domestic and European growth.

site_title: UK's Osborne says Brexit threat weighing on economic growth
summary: UK Finance Minister George Osborne stated that the threat of Britain quitting the European Union is weighing on the economy, citing delayed investments and building projects. Official figures show the UK's first-quarter growth fell to 0.4% from 0.6% in the previous quarter. Osborne also warned that international experts, including the OECD, believe British families would be worse off if the UK leaves the EU. The UK's economy has shrunk for a second month, dealing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: World's safest returns show emerging-market pessimism dying
summary: Emerging-market corporate dollar bonds have seen a 5.6% rally this year, outperforming over 130 assets, including US Treasuries, gold, and bitcoin. This turnaround comes after last year's selloff fueled by concerns of corporate defaults in emerging markets. Despite economists' warnings of increased defaults, state support, hedging strategies, and a recovery in exchange rates helped companies pay off debts and refinance at lower costs. The bounce-back in oil and commodity prices has also contributed to the gains, with companies from these industries dominating the sweepstakes in emerging-market bond gains.

site_title: China services trade deficit widens to US$21b in March on tourist spree
summary: China's services trade deficit widened to $21.0 billion in March, primarily due to a $19.1 billion gap in spending between Chinese and foreign tourists. The first quarter services trade deficit stood at $57.7 billion. China had a $24.6 billion surplus in goods trade in March.

site_title: Venezuela faces its strangest shortage yet as inflation explodes
summary: Venezuela faces its worst economic crisis as inflation explodes, leaving the country at risk of running out of money. The country's central bank struggles to print new bills to keep up with rapid price increases, while its hard currency reserves dwindle to critically low levels. As a result, the central bank is doling out payments slowly to foreign providers, effectively cutting off further business. This has created a vicious cycle where Venezuela may not have enough money to pay for its own currency.

site_title: French households wary of Hollande's "going better" claim
summary: France's consumer confidence figures show stagnation in April, reaching an eight-month low, with household confidence and expectations for standard of living declining for the fourth consecutive month. This contradicts President Francois Hollande's claims that the economy is improving. The monthly jobless figures also raised questions, with a decline in unemployment due to people dropping out of the job-seeker status, rather than finding work. Economists expect a slower growth rate, with some predicting less than 1.5% growth, which could impact Hollande's decision not to run for re-election.

site_title: Unit of Indiabulls' sponsor launches mandatory offer for business trust
summary: A unit of Indiabulls' sponsor, Grapene Limited, has launched a mandatory cash offer for Indiabulls Property Investment Trust (IPIT) units, offering S$0.25 cash per unit. Grapene acquired 7.5 million IPIT units at S$0.20 apiece, increasing its stake from 47.51% to 48.51%. The offer is conditional on Grapene controlling more than 50% of IPIT upon completion.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors withholds earnings forecast on test fraud
summary: Mitsubishi Motors has withheld its earnings forecast due to revelations of fuel-economy testing fraud spanning over 25 years. The company has been improperly measuring mileage since 1991, and an investigation by the US Environmental Protection Agency is underway. Mitsubishi Motors shares have fallen 51% in six days, and the company has yet to decide how to compensate customers. The scandal has prompted a probe by US regulators and a potential reimbursement talks with Nissan Motor Co.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower ahead of central bank policy decisions
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark stock index fell 0.2% to 21,361.60, as market sentiment remained cautious ahead of US and Japanese central bank policy decisions. Energy shares rose as crude oil prices neared 2016 highs, while utility and IT stocks declined. GOME Electrical Appliances Holding Ltd shares fell after issuing profit warnings.

site_title: North Korea builds replica of South 'Blue House' for target practice
summary: North Korea has built a replica of South Korea's presidential Blue House for target practice, sparking concerns of heightened tensions on the divided peninsula. The half-sized replica, located on an artillery range near Pyongyang, is part of an apparent propaganda exercise to stir up hostility against the South. The move comes ahead of a landmark ruling party congress in North Korea, which may be preceded by a fresh nuclear test. The exercise has raised security concerns in South Korea, with the country's military warning of potential attacks on the Blue House.

site_title: German govt confirms plan to invest 1b euro to promote e-cars
summary: Germany plans to invest €1 billion to promote electric cars, aiming to reach 1 million on the roads by 2020, up from 50,000 now. The investment includes €300 million for charging infrastructure and incentives for buyers, such as a €4,000 discount for electric cars and a €3,000 premium for plug-in hybrids. Luxury cars over €60,000 are excluded from the scheme. The initiative, starting in May, aims to make electric cars more attractive and could be followed by additional steps, including tax incentives.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. Helen Wong, OCBC's current CEO, is retiring. Singapore stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance. CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million. Meanwhile, Singapore affluents reported needing S$1.39 million to retire comfortably.

site_title: UK's top 1% of earners now paying a quarter of all income tax
summary: The top 1% of earners in the UK now pay a quarter of all income tax, up from 24.4% in 2007-08 to 27.5% in 2015-16, according to a report by the Institute for Fiscal Studies. This shift is partly due to growing inequality and the government's policy of raising the income tax threshold, resulting in a decrease in the share of the adult population paying income tax from 65.7% to 56.2%. The richest 1% have borne the brunt of the tax burden, reflecting their rising incomes.

site_title: Nomura slips to Q4 net loss, first quarter in red since 2011
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, Japan's largest brokerage, reported its first quarterly net loss since 2011 in Q4, with a net loss of 19.2 billion yen due to a weakened retail division and six consecutive annual losses in overseas operations. The brokerage's 12-month net profit fell 41% to 131.55 billion yen, below a consensus forecast of 181.35 billion yen.

site_title: Exxon Mobil loses top credit rating it held since depression
summary: Exxon Mobil lost its top credit rating of AAA from Standard & Poor's, dropping to AA+, due to its high debt load and preference for stock buybacks over debt repayment. The downgrade, effective immediately, is attributed to Exxon's failure to maintain a strong cash position and its inability to replace its declining oil production. The move is a blow to Chairman Rex Tillerson's legacy and may impact the company's ability to attract business partnerships.

site_title: Germany to introduce e-car incentives of 4,000 euros: govt sources
summary: Germany's government and auto industry agree on an incentive of 4,000 euros for electric car buyers and 3,000 euros for plug-in hybrid vehicle buyers, totaling 1.2 billion euros. The scheme, set to start as early as mid-May, will be first-come, first-served and excludes luxury cars over 60,000 euros. The government will also invest 300 million euros in e-car charging station infrastructure.

site_title: Eurozone lending recovery continues at modest pace in March
summary: The eurozone's lending recovery continued at a modest pace in March, with lending to companies growing 1.1% year-on-year and household lending steady at 1.6%. The annual growth rate of M3, a measure of money circulating in the eurozone, rose to 5.0% from 4.9%. The European Central Bank's interest rate cut and asset-purchase program aimed to boost lending and economic growth, but the recovery remains uneven. The data aligns with the ECB's subdued outlook for the eurozone, indicating a slow but steady recovery.

images.alt_text: A lending recovery in the eurozone continued at a modest pace last month, data from the European Central Bank showed on Wednesday, in line with analyst expectations and with the ECB's own subdued outlook for the currency bloc.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slip ahead of Fed, BoJ decisions
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Wednesday as Japan's corporate earnings season began with a shaky start. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.36% and the Topix index declined 0.53%. Investors await policy decisions from the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan, adding to market volatility.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks end lower, resource sector weak
summary: China stocks ended lower on Wednesday, with the CSI300 index falling 0.4% to 3,165.92. Industrial profits rose 11.1% in March, but the market was cautious about the sustainability of the recovery. Resource shares were weak due to China's curbs on commodities. The focus now shifts to whether the debt-fuelled recovery is sustainable, with traders concerned about a potential government crackdown on speculation in commodities markets.

images.alt_text: China stocks finished weaker on Wednesday, with stronger industrial profits data countered by growing doubts over the sustainability of the recovery and concerns about a government crackdown on speculation in commodities markets.

site_title: Asia markets down ahead of Fed, Apple earnings hit suppliers
summary: Asian markets declined ahead of the Federal Reserve's announcement, with Apple's earnings hitting suppliers hard. Apple reported its first fall in iPhone sales since 2003, leading to a decline in revenue and shares. This resulted in losses for Asian companies that provide parts for Apple gadgets, including Japan Display, Alps Electric, and Taiyo Yuden. Regional markets, including Hong Kong, Seoul, Shanghai, and Taipei, also fell, with dealers hoping for guidance on the Fed's monetary policy.

site_title: Barclays posts 25% drop in quarterly profit on bad bank loss
summary: Barclays reported a 25% drop in quarterly profit to £793 million, citing a larger loss from businesses being exited. This fell short of the £846 million average estimate. CEO Jes Staley said the bank aims to reduce non-core performance and converge with core performance within a reasonable timeframe.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.7% down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.7% on Wednesday, marking the fourth consecutive session of losses, amid anticipation of US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan policy meetings. The Straits Times Index fell 19.94 points to 2,874.72, with 952.8 million shares worth S$875.5 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 221 to 162, with Resources Prima Group and IEV Holdings among the most actively traded counters.

site_title: Nintendo income forecast falls short as it seeks another hit
summary: Nintendo forecasts a full-year profit of 35 billion yen, short of analysts' estimates, citing dwindling Wii U console sales. The company predicts Wii U sales will decline to 800,000 units and 3DS sales to 5 million, while new smartphone games will help bolster profit. Revenue fell 8% to 504.5 billion yen, and net income was 16.5 billion yen. Nintendo's shares fell 6.1% following the announcement, despite its upcoming release of the NX gaming platform in March 2017.

site_title: Australia's Westpac says halts mortgage lending to non-residents
