summary: Westpac Banking Corp in Australia has halted mortgage lending to non-residents, foreign self-employed applicants, and temporary visa holders, becoming the third major domestic bank to take such a step. The move aims to control rising property prices in big cities and address concerns about lax lending standards. Westpac has also reduced the loan-to-value ratio for domestic applicants with foreign incomes to 70% from 80%. The bank's actions follow similar moves by Commonwealth Bank of Australia and ANZ Banking Group.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's GDP is expected to see modest gains of 1-3% in 2016 due to weak global demand, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Great Eastern Holdings' CFO Tony Cheong has resigned to join a multinational corporation. A by-election in Bukit Batok will feature PAP's Murali Pillai and SDP's Chee Soon Juan on May 7. Clifford Chance has appointed three new Singapore-based partners to leadership positions. Moody's has warned of contingent liability risks for Malaysia's sovereign due to 1MDB's default, with Muhammad Ibrahim appointed as the new central bank governor.

images.alt_text: The Singapore economy is expected to see modest gains in the quarters ahead, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said on Wednesday in its twice-yearly review, while keeping to the guidance of 2016 GDP growth at between one and 3 per cent.

site_title: Komatsu warns of dwindling profits as yen, China slowdown bite
summary: Komatsu Ltd, the world's No 2 maker of construction and mining equipment, warned of dwindling profits due to declining sales in China and a strengthening yen. The company's net income fell 11% to 137.4 billion yen in the year through March, and forecast profit could drop to 92 billion yen by next year. Demand for mining equipment remains slack, and a stronger yen may cost Komatsu 160 billion yen in revenue, with sales falling 6.3% to 1.979 trillion yen.

site_title: Malaysia names new central bank governor to succeed longtime chief Zeti
summary: Malaysia has appointed Muhammad Ibrahim as the new governor of the central bank, succeeding longtime chief Zeti Akhtar Aziz. Ibrahim, a deputy governor, will take over on May 1. Prime Minister Najib Razak expressed confidence in Ibrahim's leadership, citing the bank's role in promoting economic growth and administering monetary policy. This appointment comes after months of speculation and uncertainty.

site_title: Brexit would cost Britons a month's salary by 2020: OECD report
summary: A report by the OECD states that if Britain leaves the EU, the average working Briton would lose the equivalent of a month's salary by 2020. OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria described Brexit as a "tax" and a "bad decision" that would lead to significant economic losses.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends higher on dollar struggle, stocks retreat
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.2% to 1,148.3 to the dollar, ending a three-session losing streak, due to dollar weakness caused by weak US economic data and exporters' month-end dollar selling. South Korean shares retreated 0.2% as domestic institutions took profits, while offshore investors bought KOSPI shares for the 11th consecutive session.

site_title: Saudis open new phase in Asia oil market turf war with China spot sale
summary: Saudi Arabia has sold a spot crude cargo to a Chinese refiner, marking a new phase in its turf war for dominance over Asia's oil market. The sale, made by state-owned Saudi Aramco, is the company's first spot sale to an independent Chinese refiner. The move is seen as a strategy to tap into the market and counter Russia's growing influence, with analysts noting that it signals the Saudis are willing to play hard ball in the rush for Asia's market share.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's sale of a spot crude cargo to an independent Chinese refiner marks a new phase in the turf war for dominance over Asia's oil market and sends a strong message to its rivals Russia and Iran: the fight for market share is on.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares fall, banks hit as weak inflation data revive rate cut talk
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell 0.6% and 0.7% respectively on Wednesday, with banks leading losses, as the Australian dollar dropped amid expectations of a rate cut following weak inflation data. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 32.94 points to 5187.70, while the S&P/NZX 50 index fell 45.32 points to 6,750.40. Brokers cited a pullback from a recent market surge and concerns about bank reporting season as reasons for the losses. The moves come ahead of a potential interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia.

site_title: Comcast in talks to acquire Dreamworks for US$3b: report
summary: US cable operator Comcast is in talks to acquire DreamWorks Animation for over US$3 billion, according to The Wall Street Journal. Comcast, which already owns Universal Pictures, would likely merge DreamWorks with Universal if the deal goes through. DreamWorks, valued at US$2.35 billion, reported revenues of over US$900 million in 2015. The company has previously been targeted for acquisition, with bids from SoftBank and Hasbro being unsuccessful.

site_title: Konecranes says US tax rules will cut Terex deal's synergies
summary: Finnish crane maker Konecranes Oyj says US tax rules will reduce the benefits from its proposed merger with Terex Corp by 32 million euros, casting doubt over the deal. The US Treasury Department's proposals to make tax inversions harder will eliminate financial and tax synergies sought by the companies. Konecranes will continue to pursue the merger, which is expected to yield operational synergies of 110 million euros. The companies have obtained antitrust clearances in several countries, but the deal faces further challenges.

site_title: Brazil recession to fuel higher mortgage defaults, Moody's says
summary: Brazil is expected to experience higher mortgage defaults due to its worst recession in over a century, according to Moody's Investors Service. The country's state-owned lender, Caixa Economica Federal, faces higher financing costs and may write fewer mortgages this year as delinquency rates climb. Lower household income and increased costs for credit will weigh on demand for houses until mid-2017, with payment delays and defaults expected to increase over the next two years.

site_title: Taiwan's president-elect says democracy at heart of China ties
summary: Taiwan's president-elect Tsai Ing-wen vows to maintain the "status quo" across the Taiwan Strait, ensuring peace and stability in cross-strait ties. She emphasizes that future relations with China will be based on democracy and people's desires, rather than individual party positions. Tsai's Democratic Progressive Party takes over from the Beijing-friendly Kuomintang, which has historically been pro-independence. China is stepping up pressure on Tsai's party, which it distrusts. Tsai aims to sustain the peace and stability of cross-strait ties, while making them consistent and predictable.

site_title: STMicroelectronics Q1 margin beats target, sees growth in Q2
summary: STMicroelectronics reported Q1 results in line with expectations, with a 33.4% gross margin, beating the midpoint target. Net revenues dropped 3.3% to 1.613 billion euros. The company predicts a 5.5% increase in Q2 net revenues and a 34% gross operating margin target.

site_title: First shipment of US natural gas to EU arrives
summary: The first shipment of US natural gas to the European Union has arrived at the Portuguese port of Sines, marking a significant shift in the energy market. This consignment, designated for Galp Energia, comes amid the shale gas revolution in the US, aiming to challenge Russia's dominance in the EU market. The move could lead to price wars and reduced Russian market influence.

site_title: Papua New Guinea to shut Australia asylum-seeker camp: PM
summary: Papua New Guinea announced the closure of its Manus island asylum-seeker camp, following a Supreme Court ruling that deemed detaining asylum-seekers there unconstitutional and illegal. Prime Minister Peter O'Neill stated that alternative arrangements with Australia would be made for the 850 men currently held, with those deemed legitimate refugees invited to settle in Papua New Guinea. The move throws Australia's border protection policy into disarray, with Canberra having been criticized for sending asylum-seekers to remote processing centers.

site_title: Thai Facebook group charged for 'foul language' about draft constitution
summary: Thailand's election commission has charged a Facebook group for posting "foul and strong" comments criticizing a military-backed draft constitution. The group, based in Khon Kaen, was accused of using foul language, and the charges serve as the first case filed under a law that prohibits campaigning on the charter. The UN human rights chief has urged the junta to curtail "dangerously sweeping" powers in the draft and encouraged dialogue on the charter. The charges come ahead of an Aug 7 referendum on the constitution.

site_title: Mazda sees operating profit falling 25% this fiscal year
summary: Mazda Motor Corp expects its operating profit to fall 25% in the current fiscal year due to a stronger yen and slowdown in emerging economies. The company forecasts 170 billion yen (S$2.07 billion) in operating profit for the year to March 2017, down from 227 billion yen in the previous year. Mazda also booked a special loss of 40.7 billion yen for the previous year related to air bag inflators.

site_title: Comcast in discussions to buy Dreamworks animation, WSJ says
summary: Comcast Corp is in talks to acquire DreamWorks Animation SKG Inc for more than $3 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. The potential deal would merge Universal Pictures with DreamWorks Animation, bolstering Comcast's collection of animated films. The move may also illustrate the trend of deal activity in Hollywood, as Viacom Inc considers selling part of Paramount Pictures. The acquisition would be a significant move for Comcast, which is seeking ways to grow amid cord-cutters switching to online video services.

site_title: Clampdown on trade secret theft seen passing US Congress
summary: The US Congress is expected to pass the "Defend Trade Secrets Act," which would provide greater legal protections for corporate trade secrets. The legislation, already approved by the Senate, would allow companies to sue in federal court for damages related to trade secret theft, a federal crime. The measure aims to create uniform standards for what constitutes trade secret theft, estimated to cost American firms over $300 billion annually. The Obama administration has expressed strong support for the measure, which is expected to be enacted into law.

site_title: Traffic to Wikipedia terrorism entries plunged after Snowden revelations, study finds
summary: Internet traffic to Wikipedia pages about terror groups plummeted nearly 30% after Edward Snowden's revelations of widespread NSA web monitoring, suggesting a "chilling effect" on information pursuit. This drop, observed over 16 months, was more pronounced for sensitive topics, with views falling to 2.2 million per month. The research, published in the Berkeley Technology Law Journal, provides direct evidence of a negative impact on information access, aiding a lawsuit against the NSA and the Justice Department for violating the Fourth Amendment.

site_title: Lufthansa, Air Berlin cancel flights on German airport strike
summary: Lufthansa and Air Berlin canceled hundreds of flights in Germany due to a strike by public-services workers at airports. Lufthansa eliminated 895 flights, or 60% of its services, with 700 flights canceled in Munich and 350 in Frankfurt. Other airlines, including EasyJet and Ryanair, also cut or canceled flights. The strike, organized by the Ver.di labor union, is part of a pay dispute involving 2.1 million public-service workers across Germany, with the union demanding 6% pay raises. Over 87,000 Lufthansa customers are impacted by the strikes.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Lufthansa AG, Air Berlin Plc and other airlines canceled hundreds of flights in Germany on Wednesday as a strike by public-services workers at airports hobbled operations in Frankfurt, Munich and Cologne.

site_title: Samsung planning US$9b down payment on iPhone displays
summary: Samsung is in talks with Apple to be the exclusive supplier of displays for iPhone models scheduled for release next year, with the potential deal valued at almost US$9 billion upfront. This could help Samsung reverse declining smartphone market share and revenue, as it would need to spend the money building capacity for thinner, brighter, and less draining OLED screens. The deal would also give Samsung a significant price premium, with analysts predicting that it would pay off handsomely.

site_title: Packing a punch online, Daily Mail moves for Yahoo
summary: The Daily Mail, parent company of the tabloid founded in 1896, is in talks with Yahoo as a potential buyer, despite being short of the US$5 billion required. The Daily Mail has built an online empire through its Internet portal MailOnline, which boasts over 200 million hits per month and generates nearly £73 million in revenue. Experts say the site's success lies in its "populist and popular" recipe for entertainment, but also faces challenges from ad-blocking software and competition from sites like Buzzfeed and Vice.

site_title: Japan automaker Daihatsu hasn't cheated on fuel economy, executive says
summary: A senior Daihatsu executive has denied allegations of cheating on fuel economy tests, stating that the company is complying with regulations. Daihatsu, which supplies car bodies and engines to Toyota, specializes in mini vehicles and competes with Suzuki in the Japanese market. The company will become a wholly owned division of Toyota later this year. This comes after Mitsubishi Motors admitted to manipulating test data for some of its cars.

images.alt_text: A senior executive at Daihatsu Motor Co Ltd said on Wednesday he was confident the automaker had not cheated on fuel economy tests, after rival Mitsubishi Motors Corp admitted last week to manipulating test data for some of its cars.

site_title: Great Eastern's CFO, Tony Cheong, resigns to join MNC
summary: Great Eastern Holdings' CFO Tony Cheong has resigned to join a multinational corporation, leaving his position on May 13 after a seven-year tenure. Cheong was appointed as CFO in 2009.

site_title: Modest gain in Singapore GDP expected in 2016 amid weak global demand: MAS
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to see modest gains in 2016, with GDP growth forecast to be between 1-3%, amid weak global demand. Global financial conditions tightening and rising debt service burdens will impede domestic demand growth. Economic activity in Singapore weakened across sectors in the first quarter, with core inflation expected to come in within the lower half of 0.5-1.5% forecast range. Labour market tightness is expected to ease, with wage growth moderating to 2.5-3% in 2016.

site_title: Investors should oppose pay at StanChart, RBS, Deutsche Bank: PIRC
summary: A leading proxy voting firm, PIRC, advises investors to reject pay at Standard Chartered, Royal Bank of Scotland, and Deutsche Bank when they hold their annual general meetings. PIRC backs 'oppose' votes at these banks, citing concerns over executive pay. StanChart's pay report and policy for the next three years are also rejected, while RBS' 2015 report is advised to be rejected. Deutsche Bank's remuneration policy for the executive board is also opposed.

images.alt_text: Pensions & Investment Research Consultants, which advises institutional shareholders, said it backed 'oppose' votes at Asia-focused Standard Chartered, British lender Royal Bank of Scotland and Deutsche Bank.

site_title: US looks into Google edge on Android: report
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is investigating whether Google's dominant position in Android software gives the company an unfair advantage in promoting its search engine. FTC staffers have met with companies about concerns similar to those being targeted by the European Union regulators. The investigation aims to learn about evidence backing a case against Google, which could lead to a review of its business practices.

images.alt_text: The US is looking into whether free Android mobile software is giving an unfair advantage to other Google offerings such as its search engine, the Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday.

site_title: Bukit Batok by-election: PAP's Murali to square off against SDP's Chee on May 7
summary: The Bukit Batok by-election is set for May 7, with only two candidates: PAP's Murali Pillai and SDP's Chee Soon Juan. After a nomination process that initially included two other men, Kwan Yue Keng and Shirwin Eu, both were deemed ineligible to contest. Campaigning will run for nine days until May 5, with a mandatory cooling-off day on May 6. The election will determine the future of Bukit Batok in Singapore politics.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

There are only two contenders for the by-election in Bukit Batok, after both the People's Action Party's (PAP) Murali Pillai and the Singapore Democratic Party's (SDP) Chee Soon Juan made it through the Nomination Day proceedings on Wednesday without fuss.

site_title: Investors want mutual funds to get tougher on CEO pay: Reuters/Ipsos poll
summary: Individual investors in US mutual funds are increasingly critical of CEO pay packages, with 59% saying CEOs are paid "too much." A Reuters/Ipsos poll found 56% of investors want mutual fund firms to challenge executive pay more often. Top asset managers, including BlackRock and Vanguard, rarely challenge CEO pay in their proxy votes, despite having significant influence over executive compensation. The poll results underscore growing angst over large-company CEO pay, with many CEOs earning pay packages worth $10 million or more.

site_title: Australia consumer prices unexpectedly fall, revives easing talk
summary: Australian consumer prices unexpectedly fell 0.2% in the first quarter, with annual inflation slowing to 1.3%. The local dollar dropped as market expectations of a Reserve Bank of Australia interest rate cut rose to 48%. The weak result, driven by tumbling international oil prices, is the lowest core inflation since 2002 and the lowest annual inflation rate on record, at 1.6%. The RBA had projected core inflation to bottom around 2%. The result is seen as a shock and could lead to further rate cuts.

site_title: Gold edges up ahead of Fed on softer dollar, weak US data
summary: Gold prices rose for a third consecutive session ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision, driven by a softer dollar and weak US economic data. Investors expect the Fed to keep interest rates steady, focusing on the tone of its statement and potential timing for a rate hike. The dollar's decline against major currencies fueled the gold price increase, as investors anticipate caution from the Fed due to the US economy's weakness.

site_title: Negative interest rates to have limited impact on economic growth: BOK paper
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, released a research paper stating that negative interest rates are expected to have limited impact on economic growth. The paper cited factors such as half-hearted declines in bank deposit rates and structural low growth and low inflation as reasons for the limited impact. Negative rates could also hurt sentiment by signaling economic trouble and lead to cash hoarding, while countries with reserve currencies may face risks from massive capital inflows. The Bank of Korea's current policy rate is at a record low of 1.50%.

site_title: Alibaba's Jack Ma overtakes Wanda's Wang as Asia's richest man
summary: Alibaba's Chairman Jack Ma has surpassed Dalian Wanda Group's Wang Jianlin as Asia's richest man, with his net worth increasing to $33.3 billion after a record fundraising deal by Ant Financial. Ma's lead may be short-lived, as Wang reorganizes his business and seeks higher valuations in mainland China, potentially affecting his fortune. Ma is also planning to take Ant Financial public, which could be China's largest IPO since 2010.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop ahead of Fed, Bank of Japan policy meetings
summary: Asian stocks fell as Apple suppliers declined and Canon's earnings disappointed investors, while investors awaited policy decisions from the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped 0.5% amid optimism about the Fed's interest rate decisions. iPhone sales in China and Taiwan fell 26% in the quarter, and Canon cut its full-year operating profit forecast by 17%. The BOJ is expected to boost its buying of exchange-traded funds on Thursday, potentially boosting the equity market.

site_title: Technology drive sees 'connected car' link-ups in China
summary: China's young and tech-savvy premium car buyers are driving international automakers to partner with local internet giants such as Baidu, Alibaba, and Tencent. The country's "connected car" market is expected to reach 123 billion euros by 2021, with 60% of drivers willing to switch brands for data and app access. Foreign companies like Apple and Google face regulation barriers, leaving local players to dominate the market. Automakers like Audi and Volkswagen are integrating China-specific operating systems, while local rivals like Baidu CarLife and Alibaba are expanding their offerings.

images.alt_text: China has the youngest premium car buyers in the world, and their tech-savvy demand for "connected cars" - coupled with Communist regulations - is driving international automakers into the arms of the country's Internet giants.

site_title: Nestle agrees on ice cream joint venture with UK's R&R
summary: Nestle has agreed to a 50/50 joint venture with UK's R&R Ice Cream to sell ice cream and frozen food in over 20 countries. The venture, Froneri, will combine Nestle's strong brands with R&R's manufacturing agility and will be based in the UK, with plans to eventually list on the London Stock Exchange. The deal aims to adapt to a changing packaged food market and follows a portfolio review to improve Nestle's performance, which has been weakened by slowing emerging markets and heightened competition.

images.alt_text: Nestle has struck a deal with Britain's R&R Ice Cream to form a joint venture that will sell ice cream and frozen food in over 20 countries, its latest attempt to adapt to a changing and more competitive packaged food market.

site_title: Australian dollar drops sharply after soft inflation data
summary: The Australian dollar dropped 0.9% to US$0.7678 after soft inflation data, sparking concerns of an interest rate cut. This follows a 10-month peak of US$0.7836 reached last week. The drop was attributed to the lower-than-expected inflation reading, which increased the risk of a rate cut.

site_title: South Korea economy still wobbly as April exports seen tumbling, output soft: poll
summary: South Korea's economy remains fragile, with April exports expected to decline 11.0% from last year due to weak global demand. The slump began in January 2015 and has prompted policymakers to seek ways to restore momentum. The country's trade chief is seeking a "landing zone" in US trade talks to boost exports. The decline in exports is attributed to fewer working days in April compared to the previous year, further hurting the numbers. The impact is part of a broader slowdown affecting export-reliant economies in Asia.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors' existence at risk as fraud case widens
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp faces an existential threat as a widening fraud case reveals improper fuel economy testing over the past quarter century. The scandal, initially attributed to 2002, has been found to be ongoing. A three-month investigation by a panel of ex-prosecutors has yet to provide details on affected models and compensation. Customers, investors, and Nissan Motor Co may be left in limbo until the investigation concludes. The company's existence is at risk, with potential consequences for its customers, investors, and business partners.

site_title: Venezuela orders two-day work week in bid to save power grid
summary: Venezuela has implemented a two-day work week for government workers to save its power grid amid a severe drought threatening the capital's main source of electricity, the Guri hydroelectric dam. The two-day work week, which will last at least two weeks, aims to reduce the dam's daily drop from 22 centimeters to 10 centimeters. The country is also seeking international help from the UN to aid in public works construction and has closed schools on Fridays starting this week. The power crisis has exacerbated Venezuela's economic woes, with the IMF forecasting an 8% contraction this year.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump on rate cut prospects after weak inflation
summary: Australian shares jumped 1% by midday on Wednesday, driven by big banks after weak local inflation heightened expectations of a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia next week. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 53.9 points to 5,274.5, near its highest level since early January. Market analysts now see a 40% chance of a rate cut, up from 13%, following the 1.6% underlying annual inflation rate. Fortescue Metals Group and oil stocks also gained, while detention camp operator Broadspectrum Ltd fell 4.9% after a court ruling deemed Australia's detention of asylum seekers on Manus Island illegal.

site_title: Apple says FBI gave it first vulnerability tip on April 14
summary: The FBI informed Apple of a vulnerability in its iPhone and Mac software on April 14, 2016, under the Vulnerability Equities Process, the first time the agency had disclosed a flaw in Apple products. The vulnerability, in older versions of iPhone and Mac, was disclosed nine months prior to the public release of iOS9 and Mac OS X El Capitan, which had already patched the issue. Apple expressed skepticism about the effectiveness of the process, stating the problem had been fixed before.

site_title: Update: Australia dollar sinks on inflation blow, NZ dollar hit by trade
summary: The Australian dollar dropped more than a full cent to US$0.7650 after a soft inflation reading prompted markets to price in a greater chance of an interest rate cut. Core inflation slowed to the lowest on record, with the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) likely to ease rates next week. The New Zealand dollar also fell 0.3% to US$0.6880 after a wider-than-expected trade deficit. Economists expect the Reserve Bank of New Zealand to hold rates at 2.25% but markets are pricing an easing as a 50-50 chance.

site_title: Hit by housing glut, China's Heilongjiang province cuts land sales, hands out subsidies
summary: China's Heilongjiang province aims to reduce a housing glut by 2018 through restricting land sales and offering subsidies to rural folk buying homes in urban areas. The province will not grant new land for residential development to cities taking over 24 months to clear their inventories. This move is part of China's government goal to destock the real estate sector this year. The measure is aimed at addressing the housing overhangs caused by slowing economic growth.

site_title: Clifford Chance appoints new Singapore managing partner
summary: Clifford Chance has appointed Kai-Niklas Schneider as the new Singapore managing partner, effective June 1. Schneider will oversee the office's growth and strategy, following Geraint Hughes's appointment as regional managing partner of Asia-Pacific. The firm has also promoted Nish Shetty to head of litigation and dispute resolution and Nicholas Wong to co-head of finance practice. These appointments come after the practice has doubled in size in the past six years, with recent additions including Gervais Green and Kate Sherrard.

site_title: Moody's says 1MDB default raises contingent liability risks to sovereign
summary: Moody's has stated that 1MDB's default raises contingent liability risks to Malaysia's sovereign, a credit negative. The default increases the probability of contingent liabilities, estimated at 2.5% of GDP, crystallizing on the government balance sheet. This is due to cross-defaults and associated indemnities. The rating agency's comment comes after 1MDB failed to service a coupon payment on a bond issued by a subsidiary.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall as Apple suppliers weigh
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell on April 27, 2016, following Apple's first-ever decline in iPhone sales and revenue drop in over a decade. Major suppliers, such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and Hon Hai Precision, also experienced losses, contributing to the 0.2% decline in the main TAIEX index. The electronics subindex fell 0.5%, while the financials subindex lost 0.3%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to TW$32.301 per US dollar.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust's Q1 DPS rises to 1.08 Singapore cents
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 1.08 Singapore cent distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q1 2016, up from 1.07 cents a year ago. Gross revenue remained unchanged at S$27.37 million, while net property income increased 0.8% to S$24.68 million. Despite a higher average occupancy, revenue per available room was flat due to challenges from new hotel supply and soft corporate demand.

site_title: 'Oh no, not again': Why do stars keep dying in 2016?
summary: In 2016, the entertainment industry experienced a series of high-profile celebrity deaths, including Prince, David Bowie, George Martin, Maurice White, Paul Kantner, Billy Paul, Alan Rickman, and others. The music world was particularly affected, with many considering it a "year of notable deaths." Social media amplified the impact, allowing fans to instantly share their grief and create a larger movement. Experts attribute the increase in celebrity deaths to the aging of the baby-boomer generation and the over-saturation of information from digital media, which can be both comforting and overwhelming.

site_title: FBI decides provisionally not to share iPhone unlock: sources
summary: The FBI has provisionally decided not to share an iPhone unlocking mechanism used to open the phone of one of the San Bernardino shooters, citing that the agency does not own the mechanism. The mechanism was used by a foreign contractor who did not disclose its details to US authorities. The decision means the unlocking method will not be referred to the interagency review process for review, despite the FBI director stating that the agency is assessing the situation.

site_title: Spanish voters set for election re-run in June
summary: Spain's government is set for a re-run election in June after Socialist leader Pedro Sanchez told King Felipe he couldn't form a coalition government, ending a four-month stalemate. The lower house will be dissolved on May 3, and a new general election is expected on June 26. Opinion polls suggest a new vote won't resolve the deadlock, with the parties blaming each other for the impasse. The election comes after the December election produced the most fragmented result in decades, with no party able to form a majority government.

images.alt_text: A new national election in Spain is now inevitable, Socialist leader Pedro Sanchez said on Tuesday after he told King Felipe he could not form a coalition government and resolve a four-month political stalemate.

site_title: China March industrial profits rise 11.1% year on year
summary: China's industrial profits rose 11.1% year-over-year to 561.24 billion yuan in March, with a 7.4% increase in the first quarter. This marks a turnaround from a seven-month losing streak. Industrial debt rose 5.2% from the same period last year, while the economy grew at its slowest pace in seven years in the first quarter. Despite the slowdown, consumer, investment, and factory data suggest the economy may be bottoming out.

images.alt_text: Profits earned by Chinese industrial firms in March rose 11.1 per cent from a year earlier to 561.24 billion yuan (S$116.75 billion), the statistics bureau said on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.29% lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.29% lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 8.52 points to 2,886.14. Ahead of US and Japan central bank meetings, top gainers included Keppel Corporation, Haw Par Corporation, and Sembcorp Industries. A total of 35.8 million shares worth S$42.4 million changed hands, with 68 gainers and 47 losers.

site_title: Work together to speed up productivity growth, say MOM and SNEF in May Day messages
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) and Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) have stressed the need for productivity growth to make the most of Singapore's limited labour supply. The country's productivity growth averaged 0.4% per year between 2010 and 2015. Both organizations urged workers and employers to work together to boost productivity, ahead of May Day celebrations on Sunday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares dip at open, Shanghai edges up
summary: Hong Kong stocks slipped 0.16% at the open on Wednesday, following the previous day's gains, ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,372.33, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.02%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.13%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.190 points to 1689.650. Trading volume was 54.9 million lots worth RM18.2 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 86 to 83.

site_title: Zika outbreaks in Brazil tops 91,000 cases
summary: Brazil's Zika outbreak has surpassed 91,000 cases, with 30,286 in the northeast region, resulting in three deaths. The virus is linked to microcephaly in newborns and adult-onset neurological problems. Despite ongoing research, a vaccine or treatment remains unavailable, and the risk of transmission via sexual contact is still unknown.

site_title: Seoul: Won rebounds on US dollar weakness, stocks edge down
summary: South Korea's won strengthened 0.6% against the US dollar, snapping a three-day losing streak, as weaker-than-expected US economic data led to a decline in the US dollar. The won stood at 1,144.6 won per dollar. Meanwhile, South Korean shares edged down 0.2% due to investor wariness ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. Foreign investors continued to buy KOSPI shares, and screenmaker LG Display fell 1.7%, while LG Household & Healthcare rose 3.4% on strong first-quarter results.

site_title: Trump wins three primaries, Clinton takes Maryland
summary: Donald Trump won three primaries, including Pennsylvania, Maryland, and Connecticut, while Hillary Clinton secured her first victory in Maryland. The wins bring Trump and Clinton closer to securing their party nominations. The results also suggest a strong showing for Trump in the upcoming elections, potentially setting him up for a strong finish in the Republican primary.

site_title: Aussie inflation bets rise even as robust price gains elude
summary: Australia's inflation expectations have risen, with bond traders predicting an annual rate of 1.9% for consumer price increases over the next five years, 30 basis points above the 15-month low in February. Despite signs of labor market strength, the Reserve Bank of Australia is unlikely to cut interest rates, citing subdued wage growth and weak global inflation. The central bank's next meeting is scheduled for May 3, with economists expecting the headline inflation rate to remain steady at 1.7% in the first quarter.

site_title: Remember Nokia? It's buying startup Withings to jolt your memory
summary: Nokia is acquiring French startup Withings SAS for 170 million euros, aiming to revive its consumer business with health bands and scales. The deal marks Nokia's return to consumers after selling its phone business to Microsoft in 2014. The company believes its trusted brand, valued at 3.2 billion euros, is compatible with health products. Withings' products will be re-branded and sold by Nokia, which expects sales of wearable devices to reach $32 billion by 2019. The acquisition aims to capitalize on the growing demand for health-focused consumer devices.

site_title: Kia Motors Q1 profit up on SUV demand, weaker won
summary: Kia Motors Corp reported a 4.6% increase in Q1 net profit to 944.6 billion won (S$1.11 billion) due to a weaker Korean won and strong demand for SUVs and motorhomes. Operating profit jumped 23.8% to 633.6 billion won on sales of 12.65 trillion won, up 13.2% from the previous year. The company's strong performance contrasts with Hyundai's 11.6% drop in Q1 net profit.

images.alt_text: Kia Motors Corp, South Korea's second-largest automaker, posted a solid first-quarter net profit on Wednesday on the back of a weaker Korean won and strong demand for its SUVs and motorhomes.

site_title: Australian PM defends costly submarine local build with France
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull defended a $50 billion submarine build in partnership with France, citing the need for Australian skills and national security. The decision beat bids from Japan and Germany, with DCNS Group winning the lucrative contract. The deal will create 4,000 French jobs and will see DCNS' share amount to about $12.19 billion. Turnbull acknowledged the higher cost but emphasized the importance of a sovereign defence capability in Australia, and the victory underscores France's strengths in defence exports.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat before central bank meetings
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on April 27, 2016, ahead of central bank meetings in the US and Japan. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.09% to 17,369.68, while the Topix index edged down 0.01 points to 1,391.68. Investors remained cautious, possibly due to concerns about the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors CEO, COO likely to resign over mileage scandal: papers
summary: Mitsubishi Motors' CEO and COO, Osamu Masuko and Tetsuro Aikawa, are likely to resign due to the company's manipulation of fuel economy data for 25 years. The scandal, which has halved the company's market value, was discovered after the company flagged the issue on four models last week. An external committee will investigate the matter and report the results in three months, after which Masuko and Aikawa are expected to step down. The company has already set up an external committee to investigate the issue.

site_title: More urgent action needed on air pollution in Britain: MPs
summary: MPs in Britain say a government plan to tackle air pollution in five cities by 2020 is insufficient, calling for more urgent action. The plan to introduce clean air zones in Birmingham, Leeds, Nottingham, Derby, and Southampton will only target polluting vehicles, but lawmakers want councils in other cities exceeding EU pollution limits to have the option to use similar powers. The committee also recommends introducing a diesel scrappage scheme and stricter vehicle emissions standards to tackle air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: AIG to join Two Sigma, Duperreault in technology venture
summary: AIG has agreed to join Two Sigma and Hamilton Insurance Group in a technology venture focused on small to medium-sized enterprise coverage. The joint venture combines Two Sigma's data science platform, Hamilton's underwriting expertise, and AIG's scale. This deal reunites AIG with former executive Brian Duperreault, who led Hamilton with Two Sigma. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Far East Hospitality Trust, AA Reit, Mapletree Commercial Trust, Great Eastern, QAF
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a distribution per stapled security of 1.08 Singapore cents for its first quarter, up from 1.07 cents a year ago. AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit's distribution per unit rose one percent to 2.95 Singapore cents, while Mapletree Commercial Trust's distribution per unit rose one percent to 2.02 Singapore cents. QAF posted a 25 percent rise in net profit to S$16.4 million for the first quarter. Great Eastern Holdings' CFO, Tony Cheong, resigned to join a multinational corporation.

site_title: As tide turns against chip industry, Samsung forges ahead of rivals
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is expected to perform better than its rivals in the semiconductor industry due to its strong technological edge, particularly in premium power-conserving DRAM chips for smartphones and 3D NAND chips for data storage. Despite a decline in chip profits, Samsung's operating profit is expected to rise 10.4% from a year earlier, driven by healthy initial sales of its new flagship Galaxy S7 smartphones. Analysts predict Samsung will seize more market share in NAND chip shipments and outpace the industry average, benefiting from its superior production technology and dominant position in key products.

site_title: "Out means out", German lawmakers warn Britain on Brexit
summary: German lawmakers, including Angela Merkel's governing coalition, have warned Britain that leaving the European Union will result in tough talks and no special treatment. "Out means out" was the message, with lawmakers stating that Britain will lose benefits as a full member. The UK's economy is expected to face devastating consequences, and US President Barack Obama has stated that a Brexit would take years to negotiate a trade deal with the US.

site_title: White House urges Congress to move on Zika funding
summary: The White House urged Congress to pass legislation providing $1.9 billion in emergency funding to combat the Zika virus, which is spreading rapidly in the Americas and linked to birth defects and other health problems. The Obama administration had initially requested the funding in February, but Congress has yet to act. With the mosquito that carries the virus found in 30 states, health officials fear locally transmitted cases could occur. A bipartisan group of senators is set to propose a funding measure, but the White House is concerned it may not be sufficient.

site_title: Oil prices jump on weak US dollar, strong investor appetite
summary: Crude oil futures rose 1.1% to near 2016 highs on Wednesday, driven by strong investor appetite and a weak US dollar. International Brent crude futures traded at $46.26 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.2% to $44.56 per barrel. The American Petroleum Institute reported a drawdown of 1.1 million barrels in US crude inventories, lifting prices. A weak US dollar, which has lost 5% against other currencies, also contributed to the price increase. Analysts warn that the steep gains may test investors' resolve.

site_title: Belgium dropped probe into Paris attackers before massacre: report
summary: Belgian authorities dropped a probe into potential Paris attackers Salah and Brahim Abdeslam nine months before the November 2015 attacks due to a lack of funds, despite flagging them as priority terror suspects. The brothers were reported to authorities in January 2015, and an anti-terror prosecutor asked federal police to investigate, but they lacked the staff and means to do so. The decision has sparked criticism at home and abroad for not preventing the Paris massacre, which killed 130 people. Salah Abdeslam is currently awaiting extradition to France.

site_title: US: Stocks flat ahead of Fed statement
summary: US stocks finished nearly flat on Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy statement, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising less than 0.1% to 17,990.32. Analysts expect the Fed to keep interest rates unchanged, but will scrutinize its commentary for clues on future rate increases. Earnings reports from companies such as Procter & Gamble, DuPont, and Alphabet showed mixed results, with some companies benefiting from a strong dollar and others suffering from weak demand.

site_title: Rare North Korea ruling party congress to open May 6: KCNA
summary: North Korea's ruling party congress, the first in nearly four decades, is set to open on May 6. The event, expected to cement Kim Jong Un's position as supreme leader, will be scrutinized for any policy changes or elite reshuffles. The 1980 congress, the last one before this, lasted four days. The congress's details remain unclear, but it comes amid concerns of a potential fifth nuclear test, increasing international pressure on the North Korean regime.

site_title: English junior doctors stage all-out strike over pay, conditions
summary: Junior doctors in England went on an all-out strike, protesting against the government's proposed pay and conditions contract, which they claim is unfair. The strike, which started on Tuesday and Wednesday, affected 13,000 operations and 113,000 appointments, and was supported by Labour opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn. The British Medical Association, the doctors' trade union, has warned of potential mass resignations if the government does not back down. The government claims the contract is necessary to ensure high-quality care at weekends, but doctors dispute the proposed changes, citing higher mortality rates on Sundays.

images.alt_text: Junior doctors in England staged their first ever all-out strike Tuesday in a bitter row with Prime Minister David Cameron's government over pay and conditions.

site_title: First drop in iPhone sales, Apple revenue streak ends
summary: Apple reported its first-ever drop in iPhone sales, with 51.19 million units sold in the recently ended quarter, down 16% from the same period last year. This decline led to a 7.9% drop in Apple shares and a year-over-year decline in revenue to $50.6 billion. Despite this, Apple's services segment showed strong growth, and the company announced plans to increase its dividend and buy back shares. Analysts attribute the decline to the saturation of the global smartphone market and the shift towards larger-screen models.

site_title: Saudi to overhaul floundering financial district, economic cities
summary: Saudi Arabia is revamping its financial district in Riyadh and six industrial cities due to delays and lack of interest from investors. The King Abdullah Financial District, started in 2006, will now be transformed into a special business zone with competitive regulations and visa exemptions for foreigners. The government aims to salvage the industrial cities, including King Abdullah Economic City, by restructuring and repurposing areas. Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is pushing an economic reform drive, aiming to diversify the economy beyond oil and create jobs by 2030.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia is revising plans for a glitzy financial district in Riyadh and the creation of six industrial cities, after the projects were plagued by delays and a lack of enthusiasm among potential tenants and investors.

site_title: FBI chief sees better cyber cooperation from China
summary: FBI Director James Comey stated that he has seen improvement in cyber cooperation from China, following last year's bilateral agreement on combating cybercrime. Chinese authorities have established a framework for nation-state action and intelligence collection, leading Comey to express optimism about the partnership. In contrast, Comey expressed less optimism about Russia's cooperation. He also emphasized the need for a balance between privacy and security, citing the recent iPhone unlocking case and the importance of discussing the implications of strong encryption.

images.alt_text: FBI Director James Comey said Tuesday he has seen some improvement in cooperation from China in fighting cybercrime following last year's bilateral agreement on the issue.

site_title: US military conducts cyber attacks on IS
summary: The US military has begun conducting cyber attacks on the Islamic State group, according to a general. The cyber attacks aim to overload IS networks and limit the group's communications and ability to recruit new members. This move is part of the US-led coalition's efforts to accelerate the fight against the jihadists, who have been a target since August 2014.

images.alt_text: The US military is now conducting cyber attacks on the Islamic State group, a general said Tuesday as the Pentagon looks to accelerate the fight against the jihadists.

site_title: Europe: Shares supported by firmer oil, earning updates
summary: European shares ended slightly higher on Tuesday, supported by firmer oil prices and encouraging company results. Pulp and paper maker UPM surged 9% and oil major BP rose 4.3% despite a 80% drop in profit. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.2% after a 0.6% drop the previous day. The European oil and gas index also rose 1.1% as oil prices advanced due to a weaker US dollar and increased market cash.

site_title: Trump aims for East Coast sweep in a test of reorganised team
summary: Donald Trump is poised to extend his lead in the Republican presidential race with a string of East Coast primaries on Tuesday, but a complicated contest in Pennsylvania will test his recently reorganized campaign. The state's delegate allocation system has been criticized by Trump, who has accused it of being "rigged." Trump is leading in all five of Tuesday's contests in Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Delaware, and Maryland, which have a total of 118 pledged delegates at stake. In the Democratic race, front-runner Hillary Clinton is set to expand her lead over Bernie Sanders.

site_title: AIMS AMP Reit Q4 DPU up 1% to 2.95 Singapore cents
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) reported a 1% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.95 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2016. Gross revenue edged up 0.7% to S$30.29 million and net property income rose 0.3%. However, Q4's gross revenue was 6.9% lower than Q3's performance due to lower occupancies and a fire incident at one of its properties. AA Reit expects rents to remain under pressure due to a weak economic climate and industrial oversupply in Singapore.

site_title: France warns over EU-US trade pact
summary: France is warning that it will not accept a US-EU free trade zone due to concerns over lower health and environmental standards. Senior French officials, including Prime Minister Manuel Valls and Finance Minister Emmanuel Macron, have expressed skepticism about the deal, citing the need to maintain current standards. The US and European negotiators are seeking a way forward to create the world's largest free trade area, but the French government is drawing a line in the sand, saying it will not compromise on its citizens' health and environment.

site_title: Oil prices jump on report Saudi plans to reduce drilling
summary: Oil prices surged on Tuesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 3.3% to $44.04 a barrel, its highest close since November. The price increase was attributed to speculation that Saudi Arabia plans to reduce its drilling by 10%, according to a report from Nabor Industries. Analysts also pointed to a weaker dollar and poor US data as contributing factors. However, some experts cautioned that the physical market remains well-supplied, and the price movements may be driven by financial demand.

site_title: Twitter stung by stall in user growth
summary: Twitter reported a flat user growth, with 310 million monthly active users, a 3% increase from the previous year. The company delivered a $80 million loss and weaker-than-expected revenue growth of 36% to $595 million. Twitter shares plummeted 10.7% in after-hours trading, extending their two-year slump. Co-founder Jack Dorsey returned as CEO, promising new services to boost growth and user engagement. Despite the struggles, Twitter cited "sequential growth in monthly active usage" and "deepening engagement" in the past quarter.

site_title: S'pore in 'sweet spot' as politics and policies work constructively together: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of a harmonious balance between the civil service's neutrality and responsiveness to the elected government in Singapore. He stressed that civil servants should remain "politically impartial" but understand the political context and thinking of the leadership. The civil service's role is to develop effective policies, which must be sound, well-supported, and properly implemented. Lee warned that if politics and policies do not work together, the system may malfunction, highlighting Singapore's current "sweet spot" as a unique position that has delivered results over the years.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: PLife Reit Q1 DPU falls in absence of one-off distribution
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 7% decline in its first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.99 Singapore cents, due to the absence of a one-off distribution from divestment gains. Despite this, the Reit's recurring DPU grew 5.1% year-on-year. Net property income and gross revenue rose 8.5% and 8.6% respectively, driven by contributions from new properties acquired and higher rent from existing ones. The Reit's long-term prospects remain positive, driven by the growth of the healthcare industry in the Asia Pacific region.

site_title: Powermat's charging technology not taking off
summary: Powermat Technologies Inc, founded in 2006, has struggled to achieve widespread adoption of its wireless charging technology despite its increasing use in phones, cars, and cafes. The company faces management infighting, competition from rival technology Qi, and a lack of convenience, as consumers prefer a simple way to charge devices on the go. Powermat has shifted its strategy to a service model, offering wireless charging to businesses through its mobile engagement platform, but faces challenges in appealing to consumers with ads.

site_title: Costa Coffee owner Whitbread sticks to expansion plans as profit grows
summary: Whitbread, the owner of Premier Inn hotels and Costa Coffee chains, has reaffirmed its expansion plans despite posting a near 12% rise in full-year profit. CEO Alison Brittain rejected speculation about selling Costa Coffee, citing the company's strong track record and future plans. Total sales at Premier Inn rose 12.9% and Costa Coffee sales grew 15.9%, with Brittain believing the UK coffee market still has growth potential.

site_title: US Steel files complaint against Chinese steel imports
summary: US Steel has filed a trade complaint against Chinese steel imports, alleging unfair methods of competition, price fixing, and false labeling. The complaint seeks to bar Chinese steel products from the US market. US Steel claims Chinese companies are flooding the market with products sold below cost, violating global trade rules. The US International Trade Commission will evaluate the complaint within 30 days. This move comes amid concerns over cheap Chinese steel exports blamed for plant closures and job losses in some countries.

images.alt_text: US Steel Corporation filed a trade complaint on Tuesday against big Chinese steel makers and distributors, seeking to bar allegedly unfairly traded Chinese products from the US market.

site_title: National Bank of Panama mulls over opening New York branch
summary: The National Bank of Panama is considering opening a correspondent bank in New York, a move aimed at improving transparency and reducing risks for the country's financial sector, which has faced scrutiny following the Panama Papers scandal. The proposal, submitted by Panamanian banker Moises Cohen, would create a Banconal branch in New York to act as a correspondent for Panamanian banks. The New York Department of Financial Services will review an application from Banconal if it receives one, amid pressure from France to improve transparency and avoid being added to a tax haven blacklist.

site_title: Germany's Glashuette is beating Switzerland
summary: Germany's Glashuette village is home to the world's greatest concentration of high-end watchmakers outside of Switzerland, producing over 32,000 watches valued at at least 500 million euros last year. The town's 10 watchmakers, including A Lange & Soehne, rival Swiss giants in terms of quality and price. Despite Swiss watchmakers facing job cuts due to economic downturns, Glashuette's industry is growing, with most expenses in euros keeping costs low. However, analysts warn that the luxury watch market is global and may soon face similar challenges, potentially affecting Glashuette's success.

site_title: US dollar weakens ahead of Fed rate decision
summary: The US dollar weakened ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate decision on Wednesday, extending losses against the euro and pound. Disappointing economic data, including a lower-than-expected durable goods orders and a decline in consumer confidence, fueled expectations of an unchanged interest rate decision. The Fed's post-meeting statement may provide insight into the outlook for borrowing costs and the timing of a potential rate hike, with some analysts predicting a quarter-point increase in June. The dollar slipped 0.3% to $1.1298 per euro, while edging higher against the yen.

site_title: Xerox Q1 revenue falls on lower printer sales
summary: Xerox reported a 4.2% decline in Q1 revenue due to lower sales of printers and copiers. The company expects to incur $100 million in restructuring costs in the second quarter and $300 million for the full year. Shares fell 13% to $9.68, the worst day since 2009. Xerox plans to split into two companies, one for legacy printer operations and the other for business process outsourcing, and does not plan to repurchase shares this year.

site_title: Learning to do fun, Finns seek to overcome Soviet export legacy
summary: Finns are seeking to overcome the Soviet export legacy through their Finns sports watches, a bright spot in the Finnish economy. Amer Sports Oyj, the parent company of Suunto, has seen its value increase due to the global success of its award-winning timepieces. This growth is a contrast to the struggling Finnish economy, which is still recovering from the demise of Nokia's mobile phone business.

site_title: BT forum turns focus on new economy
summary: The Business Times is organizing a conference, "Singapore's Future Economy," on May 31, featuring Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat and top-level panels to explore the country's economic future amid global and domestic challenges. About 300 business leaders and professionals are expected to attend.

site_title: Untapped potential in contactless payment rests with LTA
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) plans to pilot the use of contactless debit or credit cards for commuting, aiming to refine the fragmented market and move towards an open system similar to London's. The pilot is set for the fourth quarter, and if fully implemented, it would allow consumers to use contactless cards for fare payments without the need for telcos' SIM cards. This move is seen as a significant step towards increasing the adoption of contactless payments in Singapore, with LTA expected to play a key role in opening up the system.

site_title: Rebound in durable-goods orders below expectations
summary: US durable-goods orders rebounded 0.8% in March, below expectations, indicating a continued downturn in the factory sector. Demand for automobiles, computers, and electrical goods remained weak, and orders for manufactured capital goods were unchanged. The report comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, where interest rates are expected to remain unchanged. The US dollar's decline and sluggish overseas demand are contributing to the manufacturing sector's struggles, with the sector accounting for 12% of the US economy.

site_title: Tech industry titans urge US to better fund computer science
summary: Tech industry leaders, including Jeff Bezos, Tim Cook, and Mark Zuckerberg, have urged the US government to better fund computer science education in public schools. In an open letter and petition, they emphasized that access to computer science is crucial for the nation's economic competitiveness. The letter states that computer science education is an "economic imperative" for the US to remain competitive, regardless of a student's career aspirations. The call to action aims to make the US a leader in computer science education, benefiting students and the nation as a whole.

images.alt_text: Jeff Bezos, Tim Cook and Mark Zuckerberg (pictured) were among tech titans who joined school officials, non-profits and state leaders to urge the US government to better back teaching computer science.

site_title: Trek 2000's auditors lodge report with ACRA
summary: Auditors of Trek 2000 International, Ernst & Young, have lodged a report with the ACRA regarding documentation deficiencies in the company's financial statements for the year ended Dec 31, 2015. The report found discrepancies in transactions worth US$3.2 million, including issues with customer identity, delivery orders, and payment notices. Trek 2000 has converted its trading halt into a voluntary suspension and will cooperate with the auditors and complete an IPT inquiry. The company's shares closed 0.2 Singapore cent down on April 21.

site_title: LF Logistics opens S$170m logistics hub in Jurong West
summary: LF Logistics has opened its S$170 million, one-million-square-foot logistics hub in Jurong West, Singapore. The facility, which features automated storage and retrieval systems, can store up to 130,000 pallets at a rate of 550 pallets per hour. The hub has received Green Mark Platinum awards for its "green" building practices and will be used for online and offline inventory management. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam praised the facility's adoption of "omni-channel" logistics networks, citing its potential to support e-commerce growth in the Asean region.

site_title: DBS launches India's first mobile-only bank
summary: DBS Bank, a Singaporean lender, has launched India's first mobile-only bank, aiming to add 5 million retail customers and take in S$10 billion deposits over 3-5 years. The bank uses a biometric identification system, Aadhaar card, for authentication, and offers paperless and branchless services. Customers can earn 7% interest, have no minimum balance requirements, and make unlimited free cash withdrawals at 200,000 ATMs nationwide. DBS plans to break even in three years and is open to expanding mobile-only banking to other Asian markets.

site_title: 60m people worldwide hit by El Nino: UN
summary: The UN reports that 60 million people worldwide are affected by the El Nino climate phenomenon, causing heavy rains and droughts in various parts of the world, leading to malnutrition, disease outbreaks, and food shortages. A shortage of funding threatens the delivery of life-saving aid, with the UN estimating a need for $3.6 billion in critical support. Only $1.4 billion has been provided, putting "lifesaving programmes, including food pipelines in Ethiopia, at risk." The UN warns that a return swing of the pendulum, La Nina, could exacerbate the situation later this year.

images.alt_text: Some 60 million people worldwide need assistance due to havoc wreaked by the El Nino climate phenomenon, but a shortage of funding could threaten the delivery of life-saving aid, the UN warned Tuesday.

site_title: Alibaba unit raises record US$4.5b to fund growth
summary: Alibaba's finance affiliate, Ant Financial, has raised a record US$4.5 billion in funding from state-backed investors, surpassing its initial target. The funding will be used to invest in infrastructure for long-term growth in rural and international markets. Ant Financial, which runs China's largest online payment service Alipay, aims to consider an initial public offering (IPO) on the Shanghai stock exchange this year. The company has over 200 million users and controls the nation's largest money-market fund. The funding marks the technology industry's single largest round of private financing.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: A Singapore-based broker, DeClout Limited, has set a target price of S$0.34 for Raffles Medical Group, which closed at S$0.196 on April 26, 2016. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank announced the appointment of Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing Helen Wong. In other news, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while CGSIC downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected slowing earnings growth in the second half.

images.alt_text: SMRT announced on Monday that its internal investigation showed that a vital safety measure which could have prevented the fatal accident on March 22, 2016 was not applied but reasons were not provided.

site_title: Beleaguered JAC suffers yet another setback
summary: Jurong Aromatics Corporation (JAC), a Singapore-based petrochemical producer, has suffered another setback after a fire destroyed a storage tank on its Jurong Island plant, effectively ending hopes of restarting the plant soon. The fire, which took five hours to extinguish, occurred just as talks with BP on a one-year tolling arrangement were nearing completion. The plant, which had been idle since 2015, had been expected to start up in the second quarter of 2016, but the fire has put paid to these efforts.

site_title: Swee Say: With population ageing, S'pore must become a manpower-lean economy
summary: Singapore's MANPOWER Minister Lim Swee Say emphasized the need for the country to adopt a manpower-lean economy due to its ageing population. This shift is necessary to ensure the country's long-term sustainability. Lim stated that this is the only viable option for Singapore, highlighting the government's efforts to promote lean enterprises, industry, and services.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim said SMEs must become manpower-lean because they employ two-thirds of the Singapore workforce.

site_title: Launching trade wars will lead to job losses, not job creation
summary: US presidential candidates Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders have blamed free trade policies for job losses and stagnant wages among blue-collar workers, proposing trade restrictions to bring manufacturing jobs back to America. However, economists warn that launching trade wars against China and Mexico would lead to job losses, not job creation, and could disrupt the global economy, potentially causing a global recession. A study by Moody's Analytics found that a trade war between the US and China and Mexico would result in a 4.6% contraction of the American economy and a loss of 7 million jobs.

site_title: Prince's old villa in Spain unsold after 2 years
summary: Prince's villa in Marbella, Spain, which he purchased in 1998 as a wedding gift, has remained unsold after 2 years despite being listed for 5.25 million euros (S$8 million). The 6,000 sqm villa, featuring a colonial-style staircase and outdoor jacuzzi, has failed to attract buyers due to its outdated design and location. Experts attribute the failure to a shift in luxury home tastes, with buyers opting for more elegant homes in exclusive areas like Sierra Blanca or La Zagaleta.

site_title: New Magnus major shareholder supports current board: CEO
summary: Minority shareholders of Magnus Energy, a Singapore-based energy equipment and production company, plan to vote out the current board at an EGM on Friday. However, a new substantial shareholder, Lee Chin Cheh, has emerged with a 24.58% stake, supporting the existing board. Lee's acquisition of shares from a fund holding convertible bonds may be converted into stock at a 10% discount. Minority shareholders, unhappy with the "relentless issuance of convertible notes," are unlikely to succeed in ousting the current directors, according to lawyer Lim Chee San.

site_title: Board's role inextricable from good stewardship
summary: A company's board plays a crucial role in fulfilling its responsibility as stewards of long-term success. The board's purpose is to responsibly maximize the company's value-creation abilities, guide management, and ensure that the company creates long-term value, preserves assets, and shares value with stakeholders. To accomplish this, the board must make informed decisions, have a deep understanding of the company and its stakeholders, and communicate clearly with various stakeholders. A formal board mandate outlines the company's purpose, values, and business direction, serving as a framework for decision-making and guiding the company's long-term development.

site_title: Prince left no will, sister tells court
summary: Prince's sister, Tyka Nelson, has filed a court petition stating the pop icon left no known will behind, and has asked a court to appoint a special administrator to oversee his estate. Prince's vast fortune, estimated to be around $27 million, is uncertain in its distribution. His legendary vault of unreleased songs also remains unknown. Nelson, Prince's only surviving sibling, has chosen wealth management firm Bremer Trust to administer the estate, citing their years of financial services to Prince.

images.alt_text: Prince's sister said Tuesday the pop icon left no known will behind, and asked a court to appoint a special administrator to oversee his vast estate.

site_title: Non-graduate Americans return to workforce in larger numbers
summary: US labor market shows signs of broadening economic growth, with Americans with high school education or less returning to workforce in larger numbers. The share of those without high school diplomas who have jobs or are looking for one rose 1.4 percentage points to 46.2% in six months, close to pre-recession levels. This trend could keep wage growth subdued and slow the Federal Reserve's rate hike cycle, as economists expect the Fed to raise rates twice this year.

site_title: Money - a crucial indicator for measuring monetary policy effectiveness
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) stimulus measures are being reevaluated using a new indicator: Divisia money, which measures the growth of money supply. This approach, developed by French economist Francois Divisia, assigns different weights to various components of an index, including new money-like products like money-market funds. Research shows that Divisia money growth has picked up in the last year, but remains below pre-2008 levels, indicating a continued global economic upswing but with disappointing growth. This suggests the US Federal Reserve should raise interest rates slowly, if at all, and supports the ECB's stimulus efforts, potentially leading to a growth surprise in the eurozone.

site_title: Singapore banks' SME exposure now focus of analysts' scrutiny
summary: Singapore banks' first-quarter results are set to report, amid a weakening economic environment and rising concerns over small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Analysts flag SME exposure as a growing risk, despite easing oil price risks. UBS and Morgan Stanley warn that Singapore banks may face headwinds from SMEs and China's industrial sector, while other analysts, such as HSBC and S&P, expect stability and minimal impact on asset quality. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will release its macroeconomic review on Wednesday, providing further insight into the banking sector.

site_title: Reason to be sceptical about China's rebound in residential investment
summary: Chinese property sales surged in March, with national total floor space sold and new housing developments rising 38% and 27% year-over-year, respectively. However, analysts from Macquarie Capital Ltd found a mismatch between sales growth and starts at the provincial level, with some regions experiencing starts outpacing sales by a significant margin. This may indicate policymakers are backsliding on rebalancing economic activity, and the looming value-added tax reform may have prompted local governments to advance project starts to protect their tax bases.

site_title: Australian property obsession becomes election battleground
summary: Australia's obsession with property is becoming a key issue in the upcoming election, with the tax law of negative gearing poised to be a major point of contention. The measure, which benefits landlords, has driven up property prices but also contributed to rising unaffordability. The opposition Labor Party wants to curb the tax break, while Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is betting that Australians will oppose any threat to their home's value. The issue could be a referendum on the housing market, with the outcome potentially deciding the next government.

site_title: 'Public consultation' issue picked up as Murali unveils manifesto
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam expressed puzzlement over SDP chief Chee Soon Juan's comments that Bukit Batok residents should be consulted before taxpayers' funds are committed to upgrading plans. PAP candidate Murali Pillai unveiled a $1.9 million Neighbourhood Renewal Programme, citing extensive consultation with residents. Tharman stressed that the NRP is a government-funded scheme and the PAP has a "decent track record" of implementing NRPs. Murali also unveiled the PAP's manifesto, which includes plans for a healthcare co-operative and job-placement programme.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Utilities drawing down funds to decommission nuclear plants
summary: Central banks may force operators to decommission nearly 150 nuclear plants globally due to dwindling funds. Utilities have been delaying decommissioning to grow their clean-up funds, but with interest rates low and costs rising, industry advocates say owners are opting for full decommissioning. The shift comes 30 years after the Chernobyl explosion and 25 years after Fukushima, which undercut nuclear power as a low-cost option. Utilities worldwide are expected to spend $200 billion on decommissioning over the next 20 years.

site_title: The top error firms make in a downturn
summary: In the face of Singapore's economic downturn, companies must prioritize staff engagement to remain resilient. Despite high levels of layoffs, maintaining employee engagement can lead to improved productivity, reduced turnover, and increased profitability. Leaders can address perceptions of the downturn, build trust, demonstrate compassion, and instill stability. Creating stretch assignments, offering fair rewards, and fostering psychological freedom can also boost employee morale. By controlling staff engagement, companies can mitigate the negative impact of economic conditions and position themselves for recovery.

site_title: Japan eyes more foreign workers, challenging immigration taboo
summary: Japan is considering expanding foreign worker programs to address its rapidly aging population, despite cultural and economic taboos. The Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) has proposed doubling the number of foreign workers to 1.8 million and expanding job categories, such as nursing and farming. The plan aims to alleviate labor shortages and boost economic growth, but lawmakers have expressed concerns about job losses and public safety. The proposal is seen as a significant shift in Japan's immigration policy, which has historically been cautious.

site_title: Futures trading on Chinese commodities heats up
summary: Futures trading on Chinese commodities has surged, prompting exchanges to boost fees or issue warnings. Trade in commodities like steel reinforcement bars and cotton has increased, driven by retail investors speculating on price movements. Analysis shows that 70% of Chinese iron ore and steel futures trading is retail speculation, rather than hedging by producers or consumers. The short tenure of contracts, averaging under four hours, increases the risk of a market overshoot. Exchanges have taken measures to curb excessive trading, including raising fees and adjusting maximum daily moves.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SEMBCORP Marine's unit PPL Shipyard plans to pursue a claim against Marco Polo Marine over a disputed rig-construction contract. The company will either appeal the High Court's stay of action or proceed with arbitration. QAF reported a 25% increase in net profit to S$16.4 million for the first quarter, despite a 2% decline in revenue. Soilbuild Construction Group's Q1 revenue rose 45.6% but its net profit dropped 10.5% due to lower margins and foreign exchange losses.

site_title: March factory output holds out hope for Q1 GDP
summary: Singapore's March factory output data beat forecasts, growing 0.5% year-over-year, prompting some economists to revise their Q1 GDP growth forecasts upwards to 2% or higher. The data contrasts with the manufacturing sector's 2% year-on-year contraction in Q1, previously estimated by the government. Economists caution that the improvement may be due to statistical quirks and that the manufacturing sector still faces challenges.

site_title: Temasek Holdings reorganises to prioritise investment team
summary: Temasek Holdings has reorganized its senior management to focus on investment team priorities amidst volatile markets. Six investment professionals have been promoted, and senior managing directors Chia Song Hwee and Dilhan Pillay Sandrasegara will lead a single investment group. The reorganization aims to streamline investment teams, increase focus on portfolio resilience, and build a stronger institution to address global economic challenges. The changes also include the creation of a new sustainability and stewardship group.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings has reorganised its senior management to refocus its investment team to cope with volatile markets.

site_title: For Gross, Pimco is an obsession
summary: Bill Gross, former bond king at Pimco, is seeking to prove that he was wrongfully terminated after a tumultuous departure in 2014. His Janus Global Unconstrained Fund is beating its Pimco counterpart, but money has not flooded in. Gross is fixated on outperforming Pimco, stating "I have to prove it all over again. Every day." Pimco has filed a legal response, claiming Gross' erratic behavior led to his termination. Gross' lawsuit seeks $200 million, which he plans to donate to charity, and his new fund has outperformed its Pimco counterpart, sparking a public obsession for Gross to prove his worth.

site_title: Even shopaholic Brazilians may not be able to sustain mall rally
summary: Brazilian mall stocks have rallied 54% this year, outperforming the benchmark Ibovespa, but analysts warn of a potential downturn due to the country's worst recession in over a century and high vacancy rates. Credit Suisse analysts predict a decline in mall occupancy and net income this year, citing vacancy and delinquency risks. Despite this, some mall developers, such as Iguatemi and BR Malls, remain optimistic about their growth potential, citing scale and bargaining power with store owners.

site_title: China bars vaccine sales after scandal
summary: China has banned the sale of vaccines by wholesalers after a scandal involving $90 million worth of improperly stored vaccines sold in dozens of provinces. The ban aims to improve the country's home-made medicines and regulate its fragmented supply chain. This move highlights the challenges faced by China's second-largest drug market in ensuring quality control and safety standards. The ban is part of China's efforts to push ambitious healthcare reforms.

site_title: Britain looking at blockchain for tracking taxpayer money, payments
