site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.540 points to 1713.900 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 61.8 million lots worth RM15.6 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 75 to 68.

site_title: Argentina private employment ticks up in February
summary: Argentina's private employment increased 0.5% in annual terms in February, with 6.24 million people employed in the private sector. The construction and exportable-goods manufacturing sectors underperformed. Labor Minister Jorge Triaca expects the economy to start adding jobs in August, driven by foreign investment and public works.

images.alt_text: In a press conference, Labor Minister Jorge Triaca said that 6.24 million persons were employed in the private sector in February versus 6.21 million the same month a year earlier.

site_title: Brexit, a new threat to TTIP transatlantic trade talks
summary: US and EU leaders face increased pressure to conclude the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) talks due to the looming Brexit referendum in the UK, scheduled for June. A British exit from the European Union could devastate TTIP prospects, according to experts. Despite this, accelerated talks may be used to remind the British public of the benefits of staying in the EU. US President Barack Obama has urged the two sides to push for a final deal by the end of the year.

site_title: South Korea Q1 GDP growth slows on weak capex, exports
summary: South Korea's economy grew 0.4% in Q1, below expectations and nearly half the growth in the previous quarter. Poor exports and stagnant capital investment were major contributors to the slow growth. The Q1 growth is the slowest seen since last year's second quarter.

site_title: Singtel launches institute to train companies in cybersecurity skills
summary: Singtel has launched the Singtel Cyber Security Institute (CSI), a 10,000 sq ft educational hub to train companies in cybersecurity skills. The institute provides tailored programs for boards, C-suite management, and technology staff, focusing on threat awareness, risk management, and response capabilities. The move is part of a two-year Cyber Security Associatee and Technologists Programme with the Infocomm Development Authority and Cyber Security Agency of Singapore. The institute aims to enhance cybersecurity skills among Singapore's tech professionals and support the country's digital economy.

site_title: 1MDB says some of its bonds are in default after missed payment
summary: 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) has not made a $50.3 million interest payment on its bonds due 2022, causing a cross-default on two sukuk bonds worth RM5 billion and RM2.4 billion. The missed payment is part of a dispute with Abu Dhabi sovereign fund IPIC over a $1.75 billion bond. 1MDB claims it will meet all its other liabilities, but the dispute raises concerns about the state investor's financial stability.

site_title: South Korea vows more steps to help revamp ailing shipbuilders
summary: South Korea's government has vowed to take more steps to help the country's struggling shipbuilders and shipping industries. The Financial Services Commission will regularly review restructuring plans, monitor charter rates, and require companies to submit additional reform plans. The goal is to reduce debt, address overcapacity, and improve competitiveness. The government has also established a $1.2 billion fund to help local shipping companies pay for new vessels and will push shipyards to downsize and focus on core businesses. Mergers among the country's largest companies are discouraged.

images.alt_text: South Korea said it will take more active steps to help the nation's shipping and shipbuilding industries reduce debt and weather a global slump.

site_title: France's DCNS wins contract to build Australian submarine fleet: sources
summary: France's DCNS Group has won a contract to build Australia's new fleet of 12 submarines worth A$50 billion, beating out bids from Germany and Japan. The contract includes a diesel-electric version of the Barracuda submarine. The move is part of Australia's A$30 billion defense spending plan over the next decade, aimed at protecting strategic and trade interests in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: National Bank of Panama to request to open New York branch
summary: The National Bank of Panama (Banconal) is considering opening a correspondent bank in New York, a move aimed at improving transparency and reducing pressure from international scrutiny following the Panama Papers scandal. The proposal, made by Panamanian banker Moises Cohen, would create a Banconal branch in New York to act as a correspondent for Panamanian banks. The New York Department of Financial Services will review an application from Banconal if it receives one, amid ongoing concerns about money laundering and corruption in the financial sector.

site_title: Google Glass-based startup raises US$17m in funding
summary: Augmedix Inc, a Google Glass-based startup, has raised $17 million in funding led by Redmile Group. The San Francisco company uses Google Glass to provide documentation services to healthcare workers, transcribing notes and updating electronic medical records. With 400 employees, Augmedix serves doctors in nearly all 50 US states and plans to use the funds to expand its service to more health systems and private clinics. This funding round brings the company's total funding to $40 million.

site_title: SK Hynix posts lowest earnings in three years
summary: SK Hynix, the world's second-largest chipmaker, posted its lowest quarterly profit in three years due to slowing demand for computer and smartphone chips. The company's net profit dropped 65% to 448 billion won, with sales and operating profit also declining 24% and 65% respectively. Analysts attribute the decline to weak demand in major markets like China, leading to a 14% drop in chip prices. Unless demand rebounds, the supply-demand condition and prices are expected to remain under pressure.

site_title: France braces for train delays as workers strike on conditions
summary: France's rail network will be partially disrupted on Tuesday as workers go on strike over labor conditions. About half of high-speed trains and a third to half of local trains will operate, with international traffic unaffected. The strike is the third in two months, amid criticism of President Francois Hollande's policies. Rail workers are demanding a branch agreement to regulate new competitors, while SNCF is negotiating a separate company agreement that could be more favorable to employees. The strike comes as France grapples with various protests and economic challenges.

site_title: Mercedes solving China snarls too late to unseat German rivals
summary: Mercedes-Benz's sales surge in China, with a 33% increase to 373,459 vehicles last year, will not be enough to unseat German rivals BMW and Audi from the top spot in the global luxury-car market. Despite a renewed push with the GLA compact SUV, Mercedes is expected to remain behind BMW and Audi until at least 2020, according to researcher IHS Automotive. The company's inability to close the gap in China means the race for global sales lead will likely remain tight, with BMW and Audi re-stocking their lineups to keep Mercedes at bay.

images.alt_text: The sales surge that has put Mercedes-Benz within reach of the top spot in the global luxury-car market this year will be too little, too late to deliver leadership in China, the world's biggest auto market.

site_title: Morgan Stanley asset favors India, Indonesia, Philippine bonds
summary: Morgan Stanley Investment Management has favored bonds of India, Indonesia, and the Philippines in Asia, taking advantage of the January market rout to boost emerging-market holdings. The firm likes telecommunications companies and blue chips in India, Indonesian developers and utilities, and conglomerates and utilities in the Philippines. Indonesian sovereign debt saw $1.3 billion of net buying, while Indian bonds had $453 million of inflows, benefiting from the Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike slowdown and commodity price recovery.

site_title: China's biggest coal-producing province to cut capacity
summary: China's biggest coal-producing province, Shanxi, plans to cut 100 million metric tons of production capacity by 2020 to address overcapacity and pollution issues. This accounts for 8% of the province's total capacity and is part of China's efforts to streamline bloated industries and shift toward consumer-led growth. The move is expected to result in layoffs of about 1.3 million workers in the industry. China aims to cut at least 9% of its coal mining capacity within five years.

images.alt_text: China's biggest coal-producing province plans to cut production capacity of the polluting fuel as part of the nation's efforts to streamline bloated industries.

site_title: EU regulators to block Telefonica's sale of O2 UK to Hutchison: sources
summary: EU regulators plan to block Telefonica's sale of O2 UK to Hutchison due to concerns it would reduce competition in the British mobile market to three operators. The deal, valued at 10.3 billion pounds, would merge O2 with Hutchison's Three UK, sparking regulatory action. European Commissioner Margrethe Vestager has expressed her disapproval, citing a desire for four network operators. The European Commission will formally reject the deal, and Hutchison will face a similar challenge in its proposed merger in Italy.

site_title: For China, friends abroad can be expensive: editorial
summary: China's lavish spending on foreign friends has led to significant financial burdens, particularly in countries like Venezuela. China has lent over $60 billion to Venezuela, primarily in oil, but now faces a crisis as oil prices plummet and the country struggles to repay its debts. Venezuela's reliance on oil exports has left it with limited funds to maintain its oil fields and repay other debts, sparking a vicious cycle. China must now decide between propping up its ally with more loans or suffering a default and massive losses.

site_title: EU bank to lend Britain £1b to build more social housing
summary: The European Investment Bank (EIB) will lend Britain £1 billion to build more social housing, its largest ever support for such programmes within Europe. The loan is aimed at helping housing associations build homes across the country, on top of the £4.2 billion the EIB has already advanced for social housing and urban renewal in Britain since 1998. The EIB denied an accusation that it was seeking to influence the UK's vote to leave the EU, saying decisions were made months in advance and the loan's timing was not linked to the referendum.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q1 net profit falls 56% on unfavourable market conditions
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a net profit of S$96.9 million for Q1 2016, down 56% from the previous year due to unrealised fair value losses from asset and liability valuations amid unfavourable market conditions. Gross premiums increased 21% to S$2.3 billion, while profit from the insurance business decreased 57% to S$89.1 million. Despite the weaker performance, the company's investment portfolio and capital position remain sound.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Cosby sex assault prosecution can move ahead: court
summary: A Pennsylvania appeals court has cleared the way for the prosecution of Bill Cosby to proceed, rejecting his attempt to have the charges thrown out due to a deal he claims was reached with prosecutors. Cosby, 78, is charged with drugging and assaulting Andrea Constand in 2004, one of over 50 women who have accused him of sexual assault. The ruling clears the way for a preliminary hearing, where prosecutors will outline evidence against Cosby. Cosby faces a number of civil lawsuits from alleged victims, but this is the only case that has led to criminal charges.

site_title: US, EU resume trade talks shadowed by election, Brexit
summary: US and European Union negotiators began a new round of talks on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership in New York, amid rising anti-free trade sentiment in the US presidential election and concerns over Britain's potential exit from the EU. The talks, the 13th round, aim to complete the pact by year-end, despite criticism over its potential impact on social and consumer protections. US President Barack Obama urged both sides to press forward, while German economy minister Sigmar Gabriel warned that the deal would fail if the US refused to make concessions.

site_title: Porsche SE flags smaller dividend cut on "positive" VW outlook
summary: Porsche SE, Volkswagen's majority shareholder, proposed a smaller dividend cut than initially announced, citing a "positive outlook" for the company. The dividend cut was from 1.004 euros to 1.004 euros per ordinary share and 1.01 euros to 1.01 euros per preference share, down from 2.004 euros and 2.01 euros respectively in 2014. This comes after Volkswagen agreed to a deal with US authorities to address the emissions test cheating scandal and set up environmental and consumer compensation funds.

site_title: Young Saudi prince holds power beyond his years
summary: Saudi Arabia's Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, 30, holds significant power, dubbed "Mr Everything" by diplomats. He's second-in-line to the throne and oversees economic policy, military affairs, and defence minister. Prince Mohammed is seen as a standard-bearer for a new generation of Saudi royals, introducing a plan to restructure the kingdom's oil-dependent economy.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's hard-charging Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman holds unusual power for a man of just 30, so much so that diplomats have nicknamed him "Mr Everything".

site_title: China expected to see US$538b capital exodus in '16
summary: China is expected to see a US$538 billion capital exodus in 2016, a fifth less than the US$674 billion pulled out last year, according to the Institute of International Finance. The pace of outflows has slowed, but fears of a "disorderly" drop in the yuan could accelerate outflows. Chinese authorities have made progress in easing yuan worries, but the country's currency reserves are still high and vulnerable to large capital outflows, which could lead to a serious tightening of capital controls.

site_title: UK retailer BHS collapses with 11,000 jobs at risk
summary: UK retailer BHS has collapsed with 11,000 jobs at risk after failing to keep pace with traditional rivals. The 88-year-old chain, which has been in business for 88 years, has been struggling to compete with rivals like Marks & Spencer. Administrators Duff & Phelps have been brought in to sell the business as a going concern, with the company continuing to trade as usual.

site_title: Canada targets payday lenders as debt levels soar in oil regions
summary: Canadian authorities are investigating payday lenders amid concerns they prey on vulnerable customers, particularly in oil-producing regions with record household debt and rising unemployment. The industry has grown to over 1,400 stores, with 2 million Canadians taking out loans each year. Critics say interest rates can reach 600% annually, trapping borrowers in debt. The Financial Consumer Agency of Canada and several provinces are reviewing regulations, mirroring clampdowns in other countries, including Britain's introduction of interest rate caps.

site_title: Europe: Stocks retreat as miners slide, German data disappoint
summary: European shares declined for a third day, with the Stoxx 600 slipping 0.5% to 346.68, amid a decline in energy and commodity producers. German business confidence data showed a surprise deterioration, while Royal Philips NV dropped 4.3% after considering an initial public offering. Investors expect low economic growth, reversing earlier calls for growth, and will assess data on consumer prices and growth this week.

site_title: France fires up push for renewable energies
summary: France is raising its renewable energy goals and will issue "green bonds" to fund environmentally beneficial projects. The country's oldest nuclear power plant, Fessenheim, will be closed. French President Francois Hollande aims to further establish France as a leader in energy transition, following the Paris climate pact in December. This move is part of France's efforts to reduce its environmental impact and meet its climate goals.

images.alt_text: French President Francois Hollande also confirmed that the country's oldest nuclear power plant, Fessenheim - which sits near the German and Swiss borders - would be closed.

site_title: Saudi prince unveils sweeping plans to end "addiction" to oil
summary: Saudi Prince Mohammed bin Salman unveiled ambitious plans to end the kingdom's "addiction" to oil and transform it into a global investment power. The plans include raising the capital of the Public Investment Fund to $2.7 trillion, selling up to 5% of shares in state oil giant Aramco, and offering improved status to resident expatriates. The goal is to increase non-oil revenue to $1 trillion by 2030 and reduce reliance on oil by 2020. The plans also aim to increase women's participation in the workforce and introduce a green card system for expatriates.

images.alt_text: The powerful young prince overseeing Saudi Arabia's economy unveiled ambitious plans on Monday aimed at ending the kingdom's "addiction" to oil and transforming it into a global investment power.

site_title: Bottled water infects over 4,000 people in Spain with norovirus
summary: More than 4,000 people in northeastern Spain fell ill with norovirus after drinking contaminated bottled spring water from office water coolers. The water was found to contain human faecal matter, making it the first recorded case of norovirus in bottled water worldwide. 4,146 people were treated, with six requiring hospital treatment. The contamination was detected after a microbiology professor analyzed the water, highlighting a significant public health concern.

site_title: Citadel tops list of private US trading venues
summary: Citadel Securities, a major market maker, runs one of the largest private stock trading venues in the US, executing over 1.1 billion shares in its brokerage in the week of April 4. If Citadel were a public stock exchange, it would be the seventh-largest out of 13. The firm's internaliser platform, which executes stock orders against its inventory, bypasses public exchanges, raising concerns about "payment for order flow" and its impact on the market. Other top firms include KCG, Susquehanna, Goldman Sachs, and UBS.

site_title: Family of Iceland president's wife tied to Panama Papers
summary: Iceland's President Olafur Ragnar Grimsson denied knowing his wife's family had offshore investments revealed in the Panama Papers leak. Grimsson confirmed he would seek re-election in June's election despite previous assurances of integrity. The case could be embarrassing for Grimsson, who has made a reputation for his integrity.

site_title: Canadian executed by Islamic militants in Philippines: Trudeau
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced that a Canadian hostage, John Ridsdel, was executed by Islamic militants in the Philippines. Ridsdel, a retiree in his late 60s, was kidnapped seven months ago along with three others from yachts at a marina near Davao. The Abu Sayyaf militant group demanded a ransom, but after the deadline passed, the head of Ridsdel was found on a remote island, prompting Trudeau to vow to pursue and prosecute his killers.

images.alt_text: Islamic militants in the Philippines have executed a Canadian hostage, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced Monday, after the Filipino authorities said they had found the head of a foreign man on a remote island.

site_title: Attack on police sows panic in Acapulco tourist hub
summary: Gunmen launched two simultaneous attacks on federal police installations in Acapulco's tourist district, killing a suspect and wounding an officer. The attacks, which occurred late Sunday, sparked panic among tourists and locals, with people taking cover in nearby businesses. Authorities believe the attacks were a reaction to the arrest of a suspected leader of the Beltran Leyva drug cartel. The city remains on edge, with several shops and schools closed, as the governor of Guerrero state vows to restore order.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine to pursue claim against Marco Polo Marine
summary: Sembcorp Marine will pursue its claim against Marco Polo Marine through either an appeal to the Singapore High Court or arbitration proceedings. The High Court had granted Marco Polo Marine's request for a stay of the proceedings, but Sembcorp Marine stated it will continue the action. The court has ordered Sembcorp Marine to pay costs to Marco Polo Marine on an indemnity basis. The dispute began in 2015 over a jack-up rig construction contract, with Marco Polo Marine failing to pay a disbursement of US$21.43 million.

site_title: US stocks drop ahead of Fed, data releases
summary: US stocks dropped on Monday ahead of a heavy week of economic news, including the US Federal Reserve meeting and major data releases. The Dow Jones shed 26.51 points, the S&P 500 dipped 3.79, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 10.44. Investors are nervous about sluggish first-quarter US GDP growth and the market's high valuation. Charter Communications rose after US antitrust regulators approved its Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks purchases. Perrigo slumped after its CEO left for Valeant Pharmaceuticals and forecasted lower earnings.

site_title: Oil dips as Saudi Arabia nears completion of oilfield expansion
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday due to concerns over US inventories and Saudi Arabia's impending completion of an oilfield expansion project, potentially increasing global supplies. US benchmark WTI fell 2.5% to $42.64 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude fell 1.4% to $44.48 a barrel. The drop was attributed to bearish market sentiment, partly fueled by US President Trump's tariff outlook.

site_title: Brazil Senate forms impeachment committee against Rousseff
summary: Brazil's Senate formed a committee to consider impeaching President Dilma Rousseff, who faces accusations of illegal government accounting maneuvers. The committee, comprising 21 senators, will debate Rousseff's fate for up to 10 working days before making a recommendation. A Senate vote on May 12 will determine whether to open an impeachment trial, with a simple majority required. If Rousseff is removed, Vice President Michel Temer would take over, and scheduled elections in 2018 would determine her successor. Rousseff has accused Temer of conspiring against her.

site_title: China Minzhong Q3 profit halves to 49.1m yuan
summary: China Minzhong Food Corporation reported a 55% decline in its third-quarter net profit to 49.1 million yuan, due to a poorly-performing beverage division and exchange losses. Revenue slipped 7% to 451.4 million yuan, with the beverage business experiencing a 40% drop in sales volume. The company expects cultivation and processed business segments to face challenges ahead. Meanwhile, shares rose 1.6% after the results announcement.

site_title: San Francisco is torn as crime situation worsens
summary: San Francisco is grappling with a surge in property crime, with thefts from vehicles increasing by over 60% since 2010. The city is divided over whether to adopt harsher law enforcement measures or maintain its forgiving attitudes towards homeless individuals and mentally ill people. Residents and business owners are calling for increased policing, while some supervisors, like Scott Wiener, advocate for more aggressive law enforcement. Others, like David Campos, argue that criminalizing poverty will only exacerbate the problem. The city's liberal ethos is being tested as the tech industry's growth brings new arrivals who prioritize business interests over social welfare.

site_title: IPIC to pay interest only if 1MDB defaults
summary: International Petroleum Investment Company (IPIC) has announced it will only pay the interest on 1MDB bonds if the firm defaults on its payment obligations. The move comes as 1MDB's coupon payment for $50.31 million bonds is due, and the two state-owned entities' relationship has soured. This decision signals a significant escalation in the dispute between IPIC and 1MDB, with the outcome hanging in the balance.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: The gender pay gap may not stem from discrimination
summary: The US gender pay gap may not be solely due to job discrimination, according to a recent study by Cornell University economists Francine Blau and Lawrence Kahn. Adjusting for differences in gender employment patterns, the pay gap is closer to 92% compared to the commonly cited 79%. Women's entry into the workforce and increased participation in various occupations have narrowed the gap, but women still face barriers, such as lower-paying industries and less on-the-job experience. The remaining eight percentage point unexplained gap could reflect discrimination, but other factors, like the "motherhood wage penalty," may also contribute to the disparity.

site_title: US dollar slips, yen rises ahead of central bank meetings
summary: The US dollar slipped against the euro and yen ahead of interest rate decisions by the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan this week. The dollar fell to 1.1266 per euro, down 0.3% from Friday, as traders awaited the Fed's decision on ultra-low interest rates. The yen rose 0.5% against the dollar, rebounding from a decline triggered by a Bloomberg News story on the Bank of Japan's potential policy easing. The Fed's cautious stance amid global economic concerns and weak inflation may lead to a higher probability of a rate hike in June.

site_title: Fed's scope for summer rate hike widens as ECB signals a hold
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has signaled a hold on policy, potentially giving the Federal Reserve room to raise interest rates in the summer. The ECB's move reduces the risk of a sharp dollar rally, allowing the Fed to consider a rate hike. US policymakers expect to raise rates twice this year, but investors see only a 20% chance of a move in June. The Fed's decision will depend on the state of the US economy, which has slowed in the first quarter and still faces low inflation and subdued wages.

site_title: Fire prevention pilot programmes making some progress in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's fire prevention pilot programs are showing progress, with efforts to combat deliberately lit fires in the country's forests. A recent incident in Riau province highlighted the need for continued intervention, with fires destroying a communal forest. Fire prevention officials, such as Craig Tribolet, are working to prevent similar blazes, using water trucks and hoses to control fires. While progress has been made, the issue remains a pressing concern in Indonesia.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to create world's largest wealth fund
summary: Saudi Arabia has announced plans to create the world's largest wealth fund, valuing it at around $2 trillion, as part of its "Saudi Vision 2030" program to diversify its oil-dependent economy. The fund will be established by selling shares in state energy giant Aramco, with the goal of generating $2 trillion in revenue. Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman aims to move Saudi Arabia beyond oil by 2020, with the help of the sovereign wealth fund, which will also be used to finance major structural reforms, privatisations, and government efficiency efforts.

site_title: Toyota pushing hybrid SUV to China despite lack of incentives
summary: Toyota plans to launch a hybrid version of its RAV4 SUV in China despite the government's lack of incentives for hybrid technology. The company aims to localise the development and production of hybrid SUVs, with a goal of boosting local production capacity by 5.6% to 1.13 million units by mid-2018. Toyota's hybrid sales are already showing promise, with orders for 40,000 units of the Corolla and Levin hybrids, and the company expects the hybrid version of RAV4 to meet customer demand without government support.

site_title: Trump blasts Cruz-Kasich team up plan as 'collusion'
summary: US Republican presidential rivals Ted Cruz and John Kasich have formed an unlikely alliance to deny frontrunner Donald Trump the party's nomination. The pair agreed to a non-aggression pact, with Kasich foregoing campaigning in Indiana and Cruz returning the favor in New Mexico and Oregon. Cruz aims to consolidate support in Indiana, a winner-take-all state, while Trump is poised to extend his lead in Tuesday's primaries. Trump has accused Cruz and Kasich of "collusion," calling it a desperate move. The deal has strained the party and its supporters, with billionaire Charles Koch expressing his disapproval and questioning the candidates' fitness to lead.

site_title: London leads world's cities in number of billionaires
summary: London leads the world in the number of billionaires, with 77, ahead of New York (61) and San Francisco (57), according to The Sunday Times' Rich List 2016. The overall fortune of the 1,000 wealthiest people in Britain is £576 billion, up from £547 billion in 2015. Publicity-shy brothers David and Simon Reuben topped the list with a fortune of £13.1 billion, while Queen Elizabeth II ranks 319th with a wealth of £340 million.

site_title: Making digital work for you
summary: A study of 1,160 business managers found that the term "digital" has no universal meaning, with varying definitions across organizations. Digital initiatives are often driven by specific business needs and are launched at a grassroots level. Successful digital initiatives rely on a combination of technology, vision, leadership, and culture, rather than solely on technology. The study concludes that there is no one-size-fits-all approach to digital transformation and that companies must adapt to the rapidly changing digital landscape to achieve a competitive advantage.

site_title: Arrested China exec said to be buyer of Sentosa villa
summary: China businesswoman Zhang Min, implicated in the Ezubao Ponzi scandal, is believed to have purchased a S$23.8 million bungalow in Sentosa Cove with an option to complete the purchase. However, the deal was allegedly aborted, with Zhang withdrawing the caveat on the property in February after her arrest in China. The property, valued at S$2,775 per square foot, is now back on the market after Zhang failed to pay a 5% deposit of S$1.19 million.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: 100 AM mall in Tanjong Pagar to be new home for Parco
summary: AMARA Holdings has signed a lease agreement with Parco to occupy 14,000 square feet of food and beverage space at its 100 AM mall in Tanjong Pagar. Parco plans to open a new restaurant zone named "itadakimasu by Parco" in the last quarter of 2016, featuring a variety of Japanese cuisines. This move is part of AMARA's efforts to tweak its tenant mix in response to the changing retail landscape.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the "itadakimasu by Parco" concept. The addition of Parco increases 100 AM's F&B net lettable area by 6 per cent.

site_title: Yen recovers, data shows swing against US$
summary: The yen recovered from a decline at the end of last week, with investors expecting the Bank of Japan to ease monetary policy further. Bets on the yen to strengthen reached a record high, while positioning on the US dollar turned to betting on falls for the first time in a year. The dollar index fell 0.3% to 94.863, and the yen rose to 111.20 yen per dollar. Market sentiment suggests the US Federal Reserve may not raise interest rates soon, leading to a potential turn in the dollar's fortunes.

site_title: Lessons for SMEs from startups and the sharing economy
summary: Insead dean Ilian Mihov suggests that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can disrupt themselves to preempt rivals, just like startups and sharing economy companies. He cites Uber as an example of a company that innovated a business model by creating a platform for sharing car rides. Mihov predicts that the sharing economy could lead to a future where people pick up and return items, such as bicycles, at different locations, reducing the need for individual car ownership.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
While sustainability and corporate social responsibility are important, they have to be viable in the long run, says Prof Mihov.

site_title: Germans flock to property as interest rates fall and rents rise
summary: Germans are increasingly buying property, driven by low interest rates and rising rents, particularly in urban areas. The trend is shifting from a nation largely of tenants to a more US or British approach to property ownership. This growth in the housing market is being fueled by a growing urban population and high immigration, with 52.5% of Germans now living in their own homes, up from 42% in 2006. However, concerns are growing about a potential property bubble, which could impact the medium-term growth of the German economy.

site_title: A valuable business partnership
summary: Singapore and Japan have enjoyed a fruitful trade and business relationship, with bilateral trade increasing by 20% over the last 10 years. The Japan-Singapore Economic Partnership Agreement (JSEPA) has played a key role in promoting trade, eliminating import duties on various products. The agreement has also attracted major Japanese corporations to set up regional operations and headquarters in Singapore. The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) could further boost trade between the two nations, solidifying their economic partnership.

site_title: Banks, Singtel drag STI down 40 pts to 2,900
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 40.15 points to 2,900.28 on Monday, marking the second consecutive session of decline. Low trading volume of 864 million units, valued at S$820 million, contributed to the selling. Volatile oil prices and a soft day for Hong Kong and the Dow futures were also cited as factors, although the Dow futures later rebounded. The banks and Singtel were the main drivers of the decline, with low-priced issues attracting attention from traders.

site_title: Cab incumbents must accept disruption reality
summary: Singapore has introduced new licensing rules for private-hire drivers, bringing legitimacy to disruptors like Uber and Grab. The rules require drivers to obtain a vocational license, pass medical checks and background screenings, and meet certain requirements. The government aims to level the playing field for taxi operators and promote the vehicle-sharing economy, while also allowing incumbents to adjust to the changing market. Traditional operators like ComfortDelGro and SMRT must innovate and become more flexible to stay relevant, with some already exploring partnerships with private-hire services.

site_title: Warnings pile up for China's steel market after 47% surge
summary: China's steel market is facing warnings of a potential slump after a 47% surge in prices this year. Fitch Ratings Inc. says the rapid increase is unsustainable due to idled capacity being brought back online, raising production. Analysts attribute the price gains to a seasonal recovery in construction and speculation in the futures market. A Singapore-based bank warns of a boom-bust scenario similar to last year's equity market performance, citing elevated speculation. The market is expected to correct itself as policymakers take steps to manage the speculative frenzy.

images.alt_text: Warnings are stacking up fast after China's rally in steel prices.

site_title: To sustain growth, Asia must build resilience to risks
summary: Asia's economic growth and poverty reduction are under strain due to increasing uncertainty and the growing possibility of weak growth. To sustain growth, countries must build resilience to economic, social, and environmental risks. Key areas of focus include boosting productivity, reducing income inequality, and investing in infrastructure that can withstand natural hazards and respond to climate change. Investing in people, such as education and healthcare, and promoting social inclusion and environmental sustainability are crucial for robust economic growth and long-term development.

site_title: Singapore tourism industry to get S$700 million boost over next five years
summary: Singapore's tourism industry is set to receive a S$700 million boost over the next five years through the Tourism Development Fund. The funding will support niche sectors such as cruises, technology adoption, and manpower initiatives. The move aims to reposition the industry for long-term growth amidst short-term headwinds, including an uncertain global economy and regional competition. The Singapore Tourism Board plans to focus on high-yielding tourists, including business travelers, families, and active older travelers, and will develop a career strategy for Singaporeans to enter the tourism sector.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

The local tourism industry will get a S$700 million shot in the arm over the next five years through the latest tranche of the Tourism Development Fund (TDF), which is designed to help the industry reposition itself for growth with an eye on near-term headwinds and future opportunities.

site_title: Singapore named arbitrator in time charter party
summary: Singapore has solidified its position as a top maritime arbitration center by being named a third seat of arbitration for the New York Produce Exchange 2015 time charter party, a widely used document in the dry cargo sector. This marks the first time an NYPE charter party has named a third seat of arbitration since its inception in 1913. Singapore's contribution to the revision of NYPE 2015, which incorporated input from industry players worldwide, has been recognized, and the country is expected to see an increase in maritime arbitration cases in the coming years, driven by its neutral standing point and infrastructure.

site_title: StanChart S'pore's ex-CEO Lim Cheng Teck to retire
summary: Standard Chartered Bank's Singapore division is set to lose its former CEO, Lim Cheng Teck, on May 1. The 56-year-old banker has spent over 28 years with the bank, growing its China franchise and transforming its Singapore business. He will continue to support the bank's regional chief executive of Asean and South Asia and focus on key client relationships. The bank's ongoing restructuring aims to position it for long-term growth, refocusing on more profitable businesses and exiting underperforming ones, with a goal of delivering $2.9 billion in cost rationalization by 2018.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Fund managers war over smart-beta ETFs
summary: Fund managers are debating the merits of smart-beta exchange-traded funds (ETFs), which bridge active and passive management. AQR Capital Management's Cliff Asness argues that timing the market is a bad idea, as smart-beta strategies are often based on valuations that are difficult to time. Pacific Investment Management Co.'s Rob Arnott, a founder of the discipline, warns that a bubble is forming in smart-beta funds due to their popularity. Asness responds that factor timing is tempting but difficult to do well, and that investors should instead focus on diversified exposure to a mix of factors over the long term.

images.alt_text: Mr Asness says that popping in and out of assets based on valuations is rarely a good idea; and the principle applies to all stocks.

site_title: China's biggest banks stand exposed after profit buffers eroded
summary: China's largest banks, including ICBC and Bank of China, are facing their first annual profit declines in over a decade due to eroded profit buffers and rising nonperforming loans. The government is considering lowering the mandatory minimum for bad-loan provisions, currently set at 150%, to help the banks. However, such a move may raise questions about the robustness of the regulatory regime. Analysts predict that combined profits at the top five banks may drop 3% in 2016, marking the first dip in data going back to 2004.

site_title: S'pore is Uber's choice testbed for new moves
summary: Uber Singapore's General Manager Warren Tseng announced that the city-state is a key testing ground for the company's new moves, including setting up a car rental company and allowing riders to pay in cash. The pay-in-cash option has been well-received, with one in three first-time riders opting for cash payments. Uber's recent fare cut has also led to a 10% increase in rides and a 20% rise in new riders. The company's rival Grab agrees that the price cut is a strategic move to boost passenger demand and drivers' productivity, but experts warn that the sustainability of the price cut depends on demand elasticity.

site_title: SembMarine shares slip after Marco Polo's update on rig dispute
summary: SembCorp Marine shares fell 4.9% on Monday after Marco Polo Marine secured a stay of court proceedings in favor of arbitration over a disputed rig construction contract worth US$214.3 million. Marco Polo had been sued by SembCorp Marine's unit PPL Shipyard, demanding payment of US$21.43 million in interest. The court granted Marco Polo's application for a stay, with costs to be paid by PPL on an indemnity basis. SembCorp Marine shares closed at S$1.75, down 11 cents.

site_title: Sales of new homes down for a third month in March
summary: US new home sales declined 1.5% in March, marking a third consecutive month of decrease, with a 511,000 annualized pace. Demand in western states dropped 23.6%. Despite this, economists believe the overall housing market remains strong due to cheap borrowing costs and solid hiring. New-home sales account for less than 10% of the residential market, making them a timely barometer of the market.

site_title: Looming petrol glut, rampant crude output threaten price rebound
summary: A global gasoline glut threatens to derail a rebound in oil prices, which have risen more than two-thirds from 12-year lows. The glut, driven by rampant oil production in Asia, has led to a surge in gasoline exports from China and Japan, and a decline in refining margins in Singapore, where inventories have reached historic highs. This oversupply has caused gasoline prices to slump, with margins in Singapore down nearly 40% since March, and is expected to have a global impact, particularly on emerging economies that drive demand growth.

site_title: Elections Dept issues five political donation certificates
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has issued five political donation certificates to applicants, paving the way for potential candidates to run in the upcoming election. The department did not disclose the applicants' names. This development has sparked a possibility of a multi-cornered fight in the election.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Chinese entrepreneur takes on Tesla with new age electric car
summary: A Chinese entrepreneur has launched a new electric car, targeting Tesla with features such as self-driving capabilities and high-speed connectivity. The car, likely to be produced by BYD, aims to revolutionize the automotive industry with its affordability. With prices expected to be around £10, this could disrupt the market and give Chinese companies a competitive edge. The move is seen as a significant challenge to Tesla's dominance in the electric vehicle market.

images.alt_text: Mr Jia unveiling the LeSEE electric concept supercar, a rival to Tesla's Model S; LeEco hopes to start producing a version of the LeSEE in a few years at a plant being built near Las Vegas.

site_title: China SUV sales surge as drivers seeking safety on roads turn to bigger cars
summary: China's SUV sales surged over 50% in the first quarter of 2016, with sales reaching a new high despite a slowing economy. The surge is attributed to a desire for safety on China's hazardous roads, with over 250,000 fatalities annually. Analysts say consumers are drawn to SUVs for a sense of "survival" and "command" on the road, rather than off-road capabilities. The most popular models are small, car-based crossovers with engines under 2.0 liters, and new 50 models are set to enter production this year.

site_title: SGX wooing China listings in tie-up with key Chinese bank
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has partnered with China Construction Bank (CCB) to increase Chinese companies' presence in the local capital market. The two signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to facilitate Chinese companies' listings on the SGX and issue offshore renminbi bonds. CCB will also explore derivatives trading and other business activities in Singapore. This move aims to boost economic ties between Singapore and China under the "One Belt, One Road" (OBOR) strategy, which aims to build a trade and infrastructure network linking Asia to Europe and Africa.

site_title: A*Star surpasses 5-year targets; industry R&D spend exceeds S$1.6b
summary: A*Star, Singapore's nodal agency for research and development, has exceeded its 5-year targets with 8,965 industry projects and over S$1.6 billion in industry R&D spending. The agency has also signed 1,030 licensing agreements, with 70% with local SMEs. Top global companies such as P&G and Rolls-Royce are collaborating with A*Star on cutting-edge R&D. The government's RIE2015 plan has led to a significant increase in R&D capabilities, with industry projects growing 55% with multinational corporations and 80% with local SMEs.

site_title: Early data for April suggests China recovery gathering pace
summary: China's economic recovery, driven by the property sector, gained momentum in April, with private indicators showing an increase from March. Employment sub-indices also rose, indicating stronger demand for workers. However, business outlook data suggests companies remain cautious about investing. This mixed picture raises concerns about China's GDP growth, which is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Facebook guns for cheap, global Internet access
summary: Facebook aims to triple its 1.6 billion-member social network by making global internet access more affordable, particularly in developing countries. To achieve this, the company plans to reduce telecommunications network costs, potentially disrupting the industry. By embracing open-source technology, Facebook can cut costs and invest in new users, as seen in its successful adoption of Linux and open-source servers. Established companies like Cisco and Nokia are also adjusting to Facebook's new model, with some donating software and others seeking to profit from the shift.

site_title: Train disruption on East-West Line and North-South Line due to traction power fault: SMRT
summary: Train disruptions occurred on the East-West Line and North-South Line in Singapore due to a traction power fault during peak hour on April 25, 2016, affecting over 20 stations. SMRT reported the issue, causing disruptions to passengers.

site_title: Uber can 'help cut car ownership and meet demand for last-mile travel'
summary: Uber's new general manager in Singapore, Warren Tseng, says the ride-hailing app can help reduce private-car ownership and provide last-mile connections for commuters. 25% of all Uber rides in Singapore start or end at train stations. Tseng portrays Uber as a helpful stakeholder in Singapore's public transport ecosystem, rather than a disruptor. This could lead to lower private-car ownership and more efficient use of public transport.

images.alt_text: UBER can help reduce private-car ownership in Singapore, and function as a viable alternative for last-mile connections for commuters, the ride-hailing app's new general manager in Singapore Warren Tseng has said.

site_title: China's 2 largest developers make move to re-list on mainland bourse
summary: China's two largest developers, Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties Co and New World Development, are moving closer to re-listing on the mainland bourse. Dalian Wanda, controlled by billionaire Wang Jianlin, has requested a suspension of its shares pending an announcement on mergers and takeovers. The move is part of Wang's plan to buy out shares and re-list the company on the mainland, where he believes he can get higher valuations. This development is seen as a significant shift in the companies' stock market listings from Hong Kong to China.

site_title: Developers unfazed by Kuala Lumpur's office space glut
summary: Developers in Kuala Lumpur remain optimistic despite an office space glut, with 1.56 million square meters of available space, accounting for one-fifth of the total commercial space. The high availability of office space does not seem to deter developers from launching large developments. The situation is a concern for the property market, but developers appear unfazed by the glut, indicating a strong demand for office space in the city.

site_title: Celebrating 50 years of friendship
summary: Japan's newly arrived ambassador-designate to Singapore, Kenji Shinoda, celebrates the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the two countries. Shinoda aims to deepen bilateral ties by expanding existing opportunities and finding new ones, particularly in the areas of politics, economics, and culture. He expresses gratitude to Singaporeans for their support following Japan's recent earthquake, highlighting the strong partnership between the two nations, which has led to increased tourism, business, and cultural exchanges. Shinoda vows to continue promoting mutual understanding and cooperation between Singaporeans and the Japanese people.

site_title: Korean cinema operator mulls over stake sales to fund growth
summary: Korean cinema operator CJ CGV Co is considering selling stakes in some of its units, including one in China, to fund its growth ambitions. The company, part of the family-run CJ Group, may also explore initial public offerings or a strategic investor. Executive vice-president Byung-Hwan Choi stated that the company aims to become one of the world's biggest movie theatre operators. No decision on the possibilities has been made, according to Choi.

images.alt_text: South Korea's CJ CGV Co is considering selling stakes in some of its units, including one in China, to help fund its ambitions of turning into one of the world's biggest operators of movie theatres, according to an executive.

site_title: BOC Aviation gauging demand for US$1.5b IPO
summary: BOC Aviation, Asia's largest aircraft-leasing company, is gauging demand for a US$1.5 billion initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. The company plans to start taking investor orders in mid-May and list on the Hong Kong stock exchange in late May. BOC Aviation aims to use the IPO proceeds to fund pre-delivery payments and future plane purchases. The company has posted a record net income of US$343 million in 2015, driven by economic growth in China, India, and Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: BOC Aviation owned and managed 270 aircraft at the end of 2015, with narrow-body planes from Airbus Group SE and Boeing Co making up 79 per cent of the total.

site_title: Safety lapses direct cause of fatal accident on tracks: SMRT
summary: A fatal accident on Singapore's MRT tracks in April 2016 was directly caused by a safety lapse, where a train in auto mode entered a section of the track where work teams were present, killing two SMRT workers. The Accident Review Panel's review led to the conclusion that the safety measure preventing auto mode trains from entering work areas was not applied that day. SMRT has completed its investigation into the incident.

site_title: Philips' lighting unit IPO more likely as profit rises
summary: ROYAL Philips NV is leaning towards holding an initial public offering (IPO) of its historic lighting business after beating profit estimates and a private sale attempt being unsuccessful. The company reported a 14% rise in adjusted earnings to 374 million euros, higher than forecast. Philips has not yet decided on all proposals in the private sale process and has not ruled out an IPO. The company's focus on healthcare and a decision on the sale's outcome will be made shortly.

site_title: Raffles Medical's Q1 profit up 3.7%
summary: Raffles Medical Group's net profit for Q1 2016 rose 3.7% to S$15.5 million, driven by 23% revenue growth. Healthcare services revenue increased 36.3%, while hospital services revenue rose 15.2%. The group's operating profit climbed 6% to S$18.7 million, despite higher staff costs. Raffles Medical plans to expand its business in China, particularly in coastal cities, and is targeting the top 20% of the population in the Yangtze River Delta area.

images.alt_text: Dr Loo says the group would seek to expand its business in more cities in China, and explore possibilities of setting up hospitals in Shenzhen and Beijing.

site_title: Making their mark in Singapore
summary: Representatives from Japanese corporations NEC and Tokio Marine spoke about their companies' activities in Singapore, highlighting key milestones and plans for expansion. NEC has been operating in Singapore for 40 years, achieving numerous technological breakthroughs and pioneering the use of biometrics for citizen services. Tokio Marine has grown its agency force and expanded its corporate social responsibility efforts, achieving Monetary Authority of Singapore Tier-1 Significant Insurer status. Both companies attribute Singapore's attractiveness to its business environment, talent pool, and geographic proximity to the Asean region. Challenges faced by NEC include sustaining business growth and adapting to regulatory changes, while Tokio Marine is focused on digitalization and expanding its retirement solutions business.

site_title: Sunningdale Q1 profit hit by forex loss
summary: Sunningdale Tech posted a net profit of S$3.58 million for Q1 2016, down 49.3% from the previous quarter, due to a foreign exchange loss. Revenue rose 4.4% year-over-year to S$161.3 million, driven by growth in the automotive and mould fabrication segments. Despite the decline in earnings per share, the company's gross profit margin improved to 13.6%. Sunningdale plans to conduct a restructuring exercise at its Southern China plant and aims to enhance operational efficiencies.

site_title: Negative rates drive Japan life insurers to take greater risks
summary: Japan's largest life insurers plan to diversify investments due to negative interest rates and central bank stimulus, which have driven yields on Japanese government bonds to historic lows. Nippon Life, Dai-ichi Life, and Sumitomo Life will focus on corporate bonds, infrastructure lending, and foreign debt, while limiting or reducing Japanese government bond purchases. The move aims to find returns in a challenging investment environment, with yields on 10-year JGBs at record lows and dollar hedging costs soaring.

site_title: OCBC launches first biometric business banking mobile app
summary: OCBC Bank launched its first biometric business banking mobile app, allowing Singapore-registered business users to access accounts using fingerprint recognition. The app, part of the Velocity@ocbc portal, provides account balance and transactional activity information. The move aims to enhance customer convenience and security.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: ECB experiments with technology behind bitcoin: Mersch
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is conducting experimental work with distributed ledger technology (DLT), the same technology used in virtual currency bitcoin, to explore its potential adoption as the market infrastructure of the eurozone's central banks. ECB executive board member Yves Mersch stated that while the bank is open to new technologies, further research is needed before considering the adoption of DLT. This technology has already been tested by several brokers and banks for various purposes, including trading and data sharing.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth 'love' letter sold for £14,400 at auction
summary: A rare, handwritten letter from 21-year-old Princess Elizabeth II, detailing her romance with Prince Philip before their 1947 wedding, has been sold at auction for £14,400. The letter, written to author Betty Shew, recounts their wartime meetings and London dances, and describes their engagement ring as being made of Welsh gold. The couple went on to have four children and are now great-grandparents, celebrating Queen Elizabeth's 90th birthday.

site_title: US motor travel at record high in February: government
summary: US motor travel reached a record 232.2 billion miles in February, a 5.6% increase from last year, according to the US Department of Transportation. This marks the largest year-over-year bump since at least 1991. The surge in driving is attributed to cheaper gas and low unemployment, with the average US gas price down to $2.14 per gallon from $2.52 a year ago.

site_title: Marking a major milestone in relations
summary: Singapore and Japan are celebrating the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations with a series of events, dubbed SJ50. The festivities began in 2015 and include 64 accredited activities, such as a Japanese Tea Dedication and the SJ50 Matsuri, a showcase of Japanese culture and products. A new digital media playground, MOSH!, also opened on Sentosa in February, featuring state-of-the-art Japanese multimedia technology. The events aim to promote cultural exchange and friendship between the two countries.

site_title: Accountants, journalist face tax leaks trial in Luxembourg
summary: Two former PwC employees and a French journalist face trial in Luxembourg for leaking corporate tax deals that sparked global demands for reform. The case, dubbed LuxLeaks, has drawn criticism from civil rights and media groups, with the EU's antitrust watchdog investigating similar deals in several EU states. Prosecutors accuse the defendants of passing confidential data to a journalist, while analysts warn that harsh penalties could deter future whistleblowers and harm Luxembourg's reputation as a financial center.

site_title: China has a fair shot at building the car of the future
summary: China's car industry is poised to challenge Western firms in the global market, particularly in the connected car sector, known as the "Internet of Vehicles". China's natural advantages include a large domestic market, ease of industrial and regulatory integration, and a more top-down approach to industry policy. Additionally, China's government has been actively promoting the development of e-mobility and the Internet of Vehicles, and has implemented subsidies to support the sales of electric cars. With its grand vision of twinning e-mobility and the Internet of Vehicles, China is well-positioned to become a leading player in the global car industry.

site_title: Fears mount in quake-hit Nepal as tourists stay away
summary: Tourists are staying away from Nepal's Langtang valley, one year after a massive earthquake that killed nearly 9,000 people and destroyed the valley's tourism industry. Despite villagers rebuilding homes and guesthouses, the area remains largely deserted. The earthquake's impact on the tourism industry has been devastating, with annual revenues falling by 32% in 2015. Authorities are trying to lure visitors back with free mobile SIM cards and repairs to trekking routes, but many fear the industry may not recover this year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group announced a US$95 million construction contract in Myanmar, with the project expected to start in Q2 2016 and complete in Q3 2018. Singapore Press Holdings' portfolio company Snapcart won the inaugural Accenture Consumer Innovation Awards for building the largest purchase-based big data network in Asia. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank named Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong, who is retiring. Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: The US primaries: let's get it over with
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump has secured 845 delegates, surpassing the 1,237 needed to win the Republican nomination on the first ballot at the convention in Cleveland in July. This comes after his victory in the New York Republican Primary and expected wins in Pennsylvania, Delaware, Connecticut, and Maryland. Trump's presumptive nomination is seen as a significant milestone, as it sets the stage for attacks by the Democratic side and paves the way for a potential general election campaign.

site_title: Thai hard disk drive makers brace for demand slump
summary: Thai hard disk drive manufacturers are bracing for a demand slump due to a shift towards flash memory chips. Despite a 45% growth in exports to $1.1 billion in the first two months of 2016, the industry is facing a decline in demand for traditional hard disk drives. The global HDD industry is expected to shrink 3% this year, and Thai exports account for about two-thirds of the country's economic output. Experts warn that the industry's long-term prospects are uncertain, with the rise of solid-state drives and the increasing use of flash memory chips in mobile devices.

site_title: Airbus A320neo has hydraulic noise, temp problems: sources
summary: Airbus A320neo aircraft are experiencing technical issues, including increased hydraulic noise and temperature problems, affecting some planes. The problems are related to the hydraulic systems, particularly a pump that creates noise when taxiing on one engine, and excessive temperature in the system. These issues have delayed deliveries of the A320neo, which is part of Airbus' family of medium-haul jets. Industry sources attribute the problems to a second category of technical issues on top of previously reported engine glitches.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: YTL Starhill Global Reit's occupancy at Wisma Atria has dropped to 96.8% due to tenant mix reconfiguration and renovation. The manager is considering converting level 1 from fashion to F&B-focused, which may yield lower rents but drive higher footfalls. This is expected to have a minimal impact on overall portfolio revenue, estimated at 0.9%. The Reit offers investors income stability and upside potential from positive rental reversions in master leases. A buy recommendation is given with a target price of S$0.84.

site_title: Heeton, KSH, Lian Beng venture buys 5th property in Britain
summary: A joint venture company, Prospere Hotels, led by mainboard-listed developers Heeton Holdings, KSH Holdings, and Lian Beng Group, has acquired a 12-storey, 147-room hotel in Manchester, UK. This marks the trio's fifth joint property acquisition in the UK. The hotel is managed by InterContinental Hotels Group under the Holiday Inn Express brand and is located in Manchester's city centre, near major attractions and transportation hubs. The acquisition is seen as a result of the city's efforts to promote itself as a global destination for sports, art, and culture.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust's DPU rises 6% for Q4
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust posted a 6% increase to its distribution per unit to 2.81 Singapore cents for Q4, driven by higher rental rates and a contribution from the Equinix Singapore build-to-suit project. Gross revenue rose 5.8% to S$84 million, while net property income increased 7.4% to S$62 million. The trust's full-year DPU rose 6.9% to 11.15 cents, despite a 59% drop in net fair value gain. CEO Tham Kuo Wei attributed the results to the trust's resilient performance and growing hi-tech buildings segment.

site_title: 25% of Qingjian's EC units sold at weekend launch
summary: Qingjian Realty's executive condominium project, The Visionaire, in Sembawang sold 25% or 158 units of its 632 units during its first weekend launch, with 70% opting for the "smart home" package at an average of S$811 per square foot. The project received over 859 e-applications, with sales rates considered "satisfactory" given market conditions. This comes as Frasers Centrepoint's Parc Life EC project in the same area received over 700 e-applications and is set to launch with a lower indicative average pricing of S$770-800 per square foot.

site_title: United Food's new auditors flag going-concern risks
summary: United Food Holdings' joint auditors have flagged risks to the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to significant net losses and negative cash flow in 2015. The auditors highlighted the uncertainty surrounding the resumption of the soybean processing division and the group's reliance on cash resources to finance its operations. If the cash flow forecast is not met, it may cast significant doubt on the company's ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Goldman Sachs launches online bank for the masses
summary: Goldman Sachs has launched an online bank, GS Bank, targeting households and small businesses, offering low-cost savings accounts and higher interest rates compared to traditional banks. The online-only bank permits account openings for $1, with interest rates of 1.05% for savings accounts and 2.0% for five-year certificates of deposit. Goldman has no plans to open retail branches, despite acquiring GE Capital's online deposit platform, which added $16 billion in deposits from 145,000 customers. The move aims to diversify Goldman's business and expand into the mass market.

site_title: Airbus takes aim at US market with first US-made jetliner
summary: Airbus delivered its first US-made jetliner, an A321, to JetBlue Airways, marking a significant step in the European plane maker's efforts to win market share from Boeing in the US. The plane was assembled at a new $600 million factory in Mobile, Alabama, which holds strategic and symbolic significance for Airbus. The company plans to boost global A320 output to 60 a month by 2019, aiming to win 50% of the US market for single-aisle jetliners. The plant, which employs 600 people, is expected to build up a network of suppliers in the Mobile area.

site_title: March CPI data underscores MAS move in mid-April easing
summary: Singapore's central bank, MAS, eased monetary policy in mid-April due to a "significant decline in private road transport cost" and falling inflation. The March CPI data showed a -1% decline, the longest period of decline on record. Economists expect a possible second easing move, with some predicting a re-centring lower of the S$NEER policy band. The MAS's decision was influenced by low oil prices, which guided the easing move two weeks ago. Labour market data is crucial for understanding growth prospects, with the advance labour market report due to be released on Thursday.

images.alt_text: The inflation data for March throws further light on the rationale behind Singapore's central bank's surprise easing of monetary policy in mid-April, said economists, as they look for more signs that may prompt a second change in monetary policy.

site_title: US new home sales fall amid weakness in the West
summary: US single-family home sales fell 1.5% in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 511,000 units, despite a strong labor market and low mortgage rates. The decline was concentrated in the West region, where sales plummeted 23.6% after a 21.7% surge in February. Sales rose in the Midwest and South, but economists say the decline is unlikely to signal a slowdown in the housing market, and a shortage of properties remains a constraint.

site_title: Saudi prince unveils sweeping reform plan for economy
summary: Saudi Arabia's Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman unveiled a sweeping reform plan to transform the kingdom into a global investment power by 2020. The plan aims to reduce reliance on crude oil by 2020 and includes restructuring the Public Investment Fund to invest abroad, launching a green card system for long-term expatriate Arabs and Muslims, and increasing global investment capacity. The plan is part of Vision 2030, which also includes the sale of shares in Saudi Aramco to raise funds.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: London's Heathrow Airport is considering increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade, amid concerns about the financial burden on airlines. Indonesia has detained an employee of Trafigura, a company accused of a US$17 billion graft case. OCBC Bank has named Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore's MAS and PBOC are to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. The Singapore stock market has seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in the second half.

site_title: Abe must keep wind behind third arrow to crack Japan's old habits
summary: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's third arrow of structural reforms, aimed at revitalizing the country's economy, is lagging behind. Despite progress in improving corporate governance, the government faces challenges in changing entrenched habits, such as bias towards immigrants and improving gender equality. The success of reforms depends on follow-through, with the upcoming upper house elections and potential lower house poll determining Abe's ability to stay the course. A growing Japan is crucial for Asia, as it serves as a buffer against China's slowing economy.

site_title: Saudi does not expect oil price below US$30 due to global demand
summary: Saudi Arabia's Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman stated that the country does not expect oil prices to fall below US$30 a barrel due to improved global demand. He outlined a sweeping economic reform plan, Vision 2030, which can address any oil price scenario, including US$30, US$28, or US$70. The plan aims to achieve economic diversification and reduce dependence on oil revenue.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia does not see oil prices falling below US$30 a barrel again due to improvement in global demand for crude, Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman said on Monday as he outlined a sweeping economic reform plan, known as Vision 2030.

site_title: Board changes at Olam
summary: Olam International has appointed Rachel Eng Yaag Ngee, 47, as a non-executive and independent director, following the retirement of two directors, Michael Lim Choo San and Robert Michael Tomlin. The appointments are part of Olam's ongoing board renewal plan initiated in 2012. Eng will sit on three committees, including audit and compliance, governance and nomination, and human resources and compensation. Her appointment brings the board size down slightly, as Lim and Tomlin had been on the board since 2004.

site_title: Exit offer for Xyec fair and reasonable: IFA
summary: Mamezou Holdings, a 59.92% controlling shareholder of Catalist-listed Xyec Holdings, has made a fair and reasonable exit offer of S$0.30 per share for the company's voluntary delisting. The independent financial adviser, SAC Capital, advises shareholders to vote in favour of the proposal or retain their stake if they're prepared for a longer-term view or positive prospects for the company. The exit offer is part of a plan to proceed with a merger within six months if the delisting is successful.

site_title: Soilbuild unit bags S$128.7m construction contract in Myanmar
summary: A unit of Soilbuild Construction Group won a S$128.7 million construction contract in Myanmar for a 26½-storey serviced apartment and condominium project. The contract, worth US$95.0 million, was awarded by United GP Development. The project is expected to start in Q2 2016 and be completed in Q3 2018.

site_title: Japan govt weighs shopping vouchers, promotions to boost consumption
summary: Japan's government is considering issuing shopping vouchers and promoting national discount-sales events to boost consumer spending and accelerate economic growth. The aim is to meet Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's target of raising nominal GDP to 600 trillion yen. However, economists note that sluggish growth in real wages and a shrinking workforce make reaching this target challenging. The government also plans to increase inbound tourism, raise the national minimum wage, and encourage IT investment to support growth.

site_title: Oil retreats from 5-month high as global surplus seen persisting
summary: Oil prices retreated from a five-month high as a global surplus is expected to persist, with Saudi Arabia set to increase its oil field capacity to 12 million barrels a day by the end of May. This move, combined with Iran's increased output since sanctions were lifted, has led to a bearish outlook for the market. The International Energy Agency also expects a decline in non-OPEC oil production this year, exacerbating the surplus. As a result, oil futures fell over 1.8% in New York and London, with WTI crude prices reaching $42.81 a barrel.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly lower ahead of Fed meet
summary: US stocks opened slightly lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 41.74 points, or 0.23%, at 17,962.01. Investors remained cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, despite quarterly earnings failing to excite. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite also declined, with the Nasdaq down 14.79 points, or 0.3%. The decline was attributed to investors' risk aversion and uncertainty over the Fed's monetary policy decisions.

site_title: ECB pushes for saver protection, at odds with Germany
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has pushed for a common means to protect savers, setting it at odds with Germany, which has blocked the plan. The ECB, backed by the European Commission, wants to introduce a pan-eurozone deposit protection scheme to replace the current country-by-country patchwork. This move aims to prevent a repeat of bank runs during the financial crisis. However, Germany, led by Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, has opposed the plan, citing concerns about being on the hook for bank failures elsewhere.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank backed plans on Monday for a common means to protect savers, setting it on course for another collision with Germany over a scheme Berlin has so far blocked.

site_title: Heeton, KSH and Lian Beng jointly acquire Holiday Inn hotel in Manchester
summary: Heeton Holdings, KSH Holdings, and Lian Beng Group have jointly acquired a Holiday Inn hotel in Manchester through a joint venture company, Prospere Hotels. The trio holds a 30%, 30%, and 40% stake in the venture, respectively. This is the fifth joint acquisition in the UK by the three firms, but the financial details of the deal remain undisclosed.

site_title: "Me and Mrs Jones" singer Billy Paul dies in New Jersey
summary: Billy Paul, a Grammy-winning American soul singer known for his 1972 No 1 single "Me and Mrs Jones," has died at 81 after suffering from pancreatic cancer. He passed away on Sunday at his home in Blackwood, New Jersey, where he lived for 35 years. Paul had a 65-year music career, performing with notable artists such as Dinah Washington, Nina Simone, and Miles Davis. He was married to Blanche Williams for 50 years and filed a lawsuit against Nike in 2000, which was successful in awarding him an unspecified amount of money.

site_title: Gerard Ee re-elected as ISCA president
summary: Gerard Ee has been re-elected as president of the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) for another two-year term. Kon Yin Tong was elected as the new vice-president, while Vincent Lim Boon Seng was re-elected as treasurer. Ramasamy Dhinakaran stepped down from the Council after a six-year tenure as part of ISCA's leadership renewal process.

site_title: Volkswagen brand to extend China lineup to 10 SUVs in four years
summary: Volkswagen plans to expand its SUV lineup in China to 10 models over the next four years, about doubling its current offerings. The company aims to produce the vehicles locally with joint venture partners, driven by sustained growth in demand for rugged, high-riding models. This move is crucial for Volkswagen, which relies on China as its biggest national market and has set aside 16.2 billion euros to resolve the emissions scandal. The company also plans to introduce seven new locally built plug-in hybrid and electric models.

site_title: Oil corporation allied to east Libya govt loading tanker for export: officials
summary: A Libyan parallel national oil corporation allied to the eastern government successfully began loading 650,000 barrels of oil onto an Indian-flagged tanker, Distya Ameya, at the Marsa el-Hariga terminal. The effort is the first time the eastern NOC has sold oil for export. The loading process started on Monday morning and was expected to be completed later in the day. This comes after previous attempts were thwarted by pressure from the Tripoli-based NOC, which retains control over Libyan exports with Western government backing.

images.alt_text: A parallel national oil corporation allied to Libya's eastern government was loading a shipment of 650,000 barrels at the Marsa el-Hariga terminal on Monday in an effort to sell oil for the first time, officials said.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Monday, closing at 1,714.51 after a 3.45-point decline. 1.85 billion lots valued at RM1.64 billion were traded, with 516 losers and 269 gainers.

site_title: RBS sees China 'black swan' risk from loans for non-bank finance
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland warns of a "black swan" risk in China's financial system due to rapid lending to non-bank financial institutions, such as fund managers. This surge in lending poses a risk of an "abrupt reversal" that could trigger a financial event similar to China's 2013 cash squeeze. The increase in lending, which has been skyrocketing, is unprecedented and could lead to substantial credit and leverage if not properly managed. This highlights concerns about the stability of China's financial system.

site_title: German business confidence slips fractionally in April: Ifo
summary: German business confidence slipped slightly in April, falling to 106.6 points from 106.7 points in March, according to the Ifo economic institute. Analysts had expected a modest increase, but companies are becoming less satisfied with the current situation in Europe's largest economy. This marks a reversal of the previous month's increase. The result suggests a potential slowdown in the German economy.

site_title: 1MDB bonds upgraded by JPMorgan focused on Abu Dhabi's guarantee
summary: JPMorgan Chase upgraded its recommendation on 1Malaysia Development Bhd's 5.99% 2022 notes, citing a buying opportunity due to low yield spreads with IPIC bonds. The bank believes the IPIC guarantee is "explicit, irrevocable and unconditional," making it unlikely that IPIC would dispute it. This upgrade comes as bond prices have dropped amid a dispute between 1MDB and Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: China Minzhong's Q3 profit halved
summary: China Minzhong Food Corporation's Q3 net profit halved to 49.1 million yuan (S$10.23 million) due to higher costs and smaller revenue. This represents a 55% decline from the same period last year, resulting in earnings per share of 0.07 yuan, down from 0.16 yuan a year ago.

site_title: CMI inks deal to buy controlling stake in South Africa iron ore mine company
summary: China Mining International (CMI) has signed a deal to acquire a controlling stake in Aero Wind Properties, a South African company with a prospecting right for an iron ore mine project.
