CMI will acquire shares from Sino-Africa Mining International Limited and Yan-Bing Zhang, who indirectly hold 40% and 34% of Aero Wind Properties, respectively. The acquisition aims to expand CMI's business in mineral resources and provide a regular stream of revenue. A valuation of Aero Wind Properties' assets is ongoing, and CMI will decide on the amount to purchase after completion.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower as banks, Singtel drag STI down 40 points to 2,900
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 40.15 points to 2,900.28 on Monday, marking its second consecutive decline. Low trading volume of S$820 million, with only 864 million units traded, contributed to the drop. The decline was led by banks and Singtel, which had previously driven the STI's rise. Observers attribute the decline to the end of a short-covering rally triggered by oil's rebound from US$30 to US$40 per barrel, and now expect weakness to follow.

site_title: SGX ties up with China Construction Bank to draw more Chinese listings
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has partnered with China Construction Bank (CCB) to attract more Chinese companies to list in Singapore. The two parties signed a memorandum of understanding to promote Chinese companies issuing offshore renminbi bonds and exploring derivatives trading and other business activities. This partnership aims to capitalize on the existing presence of 120 Chinese companies and 103 renminbi bonds on the SGX, with the goal of increasing listings and business activities.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech Q1 profit almost halved
summary: Sunningdale Tech reported a 49% decline in net profit to S$3.577 million for Q1 2016, down from S$7.052 million in the same period last year. Revenue grew 4.4% to S$161.3 million, driven by better performance in automotive and mould fabrication segments. Earnings per share fell to 1.92 Singapore cents, and no dividend was declared. This marks a significant drop in earnings compared to the previous year, with a 50% decline in net profit.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets lower after Asia slumps
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell on Monday, following losses across Asia. London's FTSE 100 index remained flat, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index edged up slightly. Asian markets sank due to oil price drops and the yen's recovery. The week ahead includes key central bank meetings, including the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan, and earnings reports from big-name firms.

site_title: Chinese local governments still look offshore for funding
summary: Chinese local governments are diversifying their funding channels by issuing offshore bonds, despite favorable conditions in the domestic bond market. This move is driven by concerns about potential changes to domestic regulations and the desire to avoid past experiences of funding freezes. The surge in defaults among state-owned issuers has also increased demand for local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) as safer credits. At least three LGFVs have launched public US dollar bonds this year, with some citing market volatility and credit risk as reasons for their decision.

site_title: China: Stocks fall on rising concerns over risks
summary: China's stocks fell 0.4% on Monday due to growing concerns over risks in debt and commodities markets. Investors are nervous about China's debt market, which has seen a slew of defaults this year, and regulators are cracking down on speculation in commodities such as rebar. Jian Yi, executive partner at Winsor Capital, warned of a potential "negative chain of reaction" that could trigger a liquidity crisis. The energy sector was the only sector to end the session in positive territory.

site_title: Philips likely to seek IPO for lighting; Q1 earnings beat expectations
summary: Dutch company Philips is likely to seek an initial public offering for its lighting division, which would be the world's largest lighting maker as a standalone company. The company reported Q1 earnings of 290 million euros, beating analyst estimates of 257 million euros. This move comes as Philips continues to diversify its business.

site_title: Nordic Group secures about S$7.2m worth of contracts
summary: Nordic Group has secured contracts worth approximately S$7.2 million with repeat customers, including multinational corporations and companies in various industries. The contracts are for projects such as supply, installation, and commissioning of tubing and equipment, with expected completion by the third and fourth quarter of 2016.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends at 1-wk low, stocks nearly steady
summary: The South Korean won ended at a one-week low of 1,147.8 to the US dollar, down 0.4% from Friday's close. Despite this, South Korean shares remained nearly steady, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing down 0.1% at 2,014.55 points. Foreigners continued to buy KOSPI shares, offsetting selling by domestic institutions and individuals.

site_title: Golf: Nomura braves wind to take Swinging Skirts title
summary: Japan's Haru Nomura won the LPGA Tour's Swinging Skirts tournament with a nine-under 279, four strokes ahead of runner-up Lee-Anne Pace. Nomura shot a one-over par 73 in windy conditions, becoming the third player to record multiple victories this year. This is her second title of 2016, following her win at the Women's Australian Open in February.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks track regional sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.76% on Monday, mirroring a regional retreat following losses in New York and Europe. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 21,304.44, amid investor anticipation of US economic growth data and a Federal Reserve policy meeting this week. The decline followed a mixed day in Europe, where mining and healthcare stocks rose, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Mystery corn cargo sparks rumors Brazil is buying US grain
summary: Brazil has purchased its first major cargo of US corn in two decades, sparking speculation about the country's efforts to curb record domestic prices and boost supplies. The deal, worth 136,000 tonnes, was booked by an undisclosed buyer, but traders believe it was Brazil. The purchase, if confirmed, would be the nation's largest US corn purchase since 1995. Brazil's decision to scrap import taxes on corn from countries outside the Mercosur trade bloc has triggered a flurry of dealmaking, with traders seeking alternative supplies due to the drought-hit country's supply crisis.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end four-day rally ahead of central bank meetings
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Monday, snapping a four-day rally as investors took profits ahead of central bank meetings and Japan's corporate earnings season. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.76% to 17,439.30, while the Topix index fell 0.40% to 1,401.83. The decline came after a strong rally in the previous four days.

site_title: China commodities pause after frenzied buying from steel to soybeans
summary: China's commodity futures markets paused after frenzied buying led to multi-month highs and concerns of a bubble. The Dalian Commodity Exchange and Shanghai Futures Exchange raised transaction costs to calm speculative buying. Despite this, some futures continued to surge, including steelmaking raw materials. Analysts warn that underlying fundamentals remain weak, and the move is aimed at restoring market calm rather than addressing underlying issues. The Chinese government's actions are seen as a response to concerns about a potential bubble in the market.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz China sales to moderate in remainder of 2016: country head
summary: Mercedes-Benz China sales are expected to moderate in the remainder of 2016, after a 39% year-on-year growth in the first quarter. The brand's China head, Hubertus Troska, stated this during a media roundtable at the Beijing autoshow. Mercedes-Benz surpassed BMW to become the biggest seller of luxury cars globally in the first quarter, with sales in China rising three times as fast as BMW's.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation eased further in March, with headline inflation falling to -1% for the 17th straight month. Core inflation rose slightly to 0.6%. A fatal accident on train tracks was attributed to a safety lapse, and the government allocated S$700 million for a Tourism Development Fund over the next five years. Uber's growth in car supply could help reduce private car ownership, while Standard Chartered Bank's vice-chairman, Lim Cheng Teck, is retiring on May 1. The STI index fell 40 points to 2,900 due to bank and Singtel losses.

site_title: A*Star involved in 8,965 industry R&D projects in RIE2015
summary: A*Star, Singapore's nodal agency for R&D, has reported a significant increase in its involvement in industry R&D projects, with 8,965 projects over the five-year period RIE2015. This resulted in over S$1.6 billion in industry R&D spending, with 55% of projects involving large multinationals and 70% of licences issued to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The report reaffirms Singapore's attractiveness as an R&D destination for large multinationals.

site_title: China to build on disputed Scarborough Shoal this year: report
summary: China plans to construct an outpost on Scarborough Shoal in the South China Sea, within the Philippines' claimed exclusive economic zone, this year. The move aims to project power in the disputed waters, where Beijing claims nearly all of the sea despite completing claims from several Southeast Asian neighbors. China has recently built contested reefs into artificial islands, some with airstrips, further escalating tensions in the region.

site_title: BOC Aviation submits information pack to HK bourse in bid for mainboard listing
summary: BOC Aviation has submitted an information pack to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in its bid for a mainboard listing. The aircraft lessor is seeking a US$1.5 billion initial public offering and plans to test investors' demand this week. The prospectus will be issued later if the proposed listing proceeds. The company aims to provide business and financial information related to its operations and future plans.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Updated quick takes: Further weakness seen in Singapore's near term inflation
summary: Singapore's inflation fell for the 17th consecutive month in March, with CPI-All Items inflation easing to -1.0% from -0.8% in February. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transport costs, edged up to 0.6% in March from 0.5% a month ago. The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects core inflation to average slightly below 2% over the medium term, with CPI-All Items inflation projected to remain negative throughout 2016.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Warnings flash for China's red-hot steel market on 47% surge
summary: China's steel market is facing warnings of a potential slump after a 47% surge in prices this year. Fitch Ratings Inc. predicts that idled capacity will be brought back, increasing supply, and that prices will drop. The rapid price gains have been driven by speculation in the futures market and a seasonal recovery in activity. Analysts warn of a boom-bust cycle, similar to China's equity market, and urge caution.

site_title: Mitsubishi heavy full-year profit misses on cruise ship losses
summary: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd reported a full-year preliminary net income of 66 billion yen, missing analyst estimates due to significant losses in its cruise-ship construction business. The company booked additional losses on a ship order from Aida Cruises Ltd after delivering the first of two vessels, citing delays in handing over the first vessel. Mitsubishi Heavy president Shunichi Miyanagawa will hold a press conference on the results. The company's stock gained 0.4% to 434.8 yen, paring its decline this year to 18%.

site_title: China confirms to strictly control coal-fired power capacity
summary: China's government has confirmed plans to strictly control the total capacity of its coal-fired power sector, halting new construction in 15 regions until 2018 and stopping new projects in 13 provinces until 2018. This move aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, which China has promised to peak by 2030 as part of its Paris climate pact. The country will prioritize building non-fossil fuel power plants and retiring old coal-fired generators that fail to meet efficiency and environmental standards. This decision is expected to impact international coal markets and miners in key suppliers like Australia.

site_title: Game of Thrones season six opener ends months of suspense
summary: Game of Thrones season six premiered with a season opener titled "The Red Woman," ending months of suspense over Jon Snow's fate. The show's writers revealed the brooding Lord Commander's fate without spoiling it for fans, sparking widespread shock and speculation on social media, with #GameOfThrones trending worldwide.

site_title: Indonesia's planned tax amnesty could bring home 560t rupiah: central bank gov
summary: Indonesia's planned tax amnesty program could attract 560 trillion rupiah (S$57.4 billion) of offshore assets, increasing tax revenue by 45.7 trillion rupiah, according to central bank Governor Agus Martowardojo. The amnesty is part of an overhaul of the tax system, aiming to improve people's welfare.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Markets closed
summary: Australia and New Zealand's financial markets are closed on Monday for a public holiday.

site_title: Indonesia to set up "crisis centre" after Philippine kidnappings: minister
summary: Indonesia plans to set up a crisis centre to handle security situations involving its citizens overseas, following recent abductions of Indonesian sailors in Philippine waters. The centre, headed by President Joko Widodo, will include senior ministers and military and police chiefs to respond quickly to situations with strategic impact. The move comes after up to 18 Indonesians and Malaysians were kidnapped by a suspected Abu Sayyaf militant group in Philippine waters, with the Indonesian government refusing to pay a ransom. The centre aims to address the surge in piracy in the region and prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Republicans Cruz, Kasich reach 'stop-Trump' deal
summary: Ted Cruz and John Kasich reached a deal to block Donald Trump's path to the Republican presidential nomination by staying out of each other's way in upcoming state primaries. Cruz will focus on Indiana, while Kasich will shift resources to Oregon and New Mexico, where Kasich is expected to do well. The agreement aims to limit Trump's delegate gain and increase the likelihood of an open convention in Cleveland, where a candidate capable of uniting the party and winning in November could emerge.

site_title: OCBC launches first business banking mobile app in Singapore with biometric authentication
summary: OCBC Bank launched its first business banking mobile app in Singapore with biometric authentication, allowing over 120,000 customers to access their account balances and transactional activities using fingerprint recognition. The app, called The OCBC Business Mobile Banking app, leverages Apple's Touch ID technology and is available for both iOS and Android users. The move aims to provide control, assurance, and accessibility to business owners, following a 30% increase in customer inquiries about account information over the past three years.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
OCBC Bank launched on Monday a new and more convenient business mobile banking application with biometric authentication, a first in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore March inflation eases further to -1%, core inflation up slightly at 0.6%
summary: Singapore's inflation eased further to -1% in March, marking the 17th straight month of decline, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transport costs, rose to 0.6%, driven by higher food prices. Private road transport costs fell 5.9% due to lower petrol prices and COE premiums. Despite the slight uptick in core inflation, the outlook for 2016 remains in the lower half of the 0.5-1.5% forecast range.

images.alt_text: The MAS core inflation figure, which excludes the costs of accommodation and private road transport, was at a positive 0.6 per cent in March, slightly faster than February's 0.5 per cent. This was due to higher food prices.

site_title: Global carmakers see rising competition in China
summary: Global carmakers are facing increased competition in China, where auto sales grew 4.7% in 2015, down from 6.9% in 2014. Despite this, SUV and new energy vehicle sales have boomed, with Chinese brand SUVs dominating the market. Foreign manufacturers such as Ford, Audi, and Toyota are feeling the pressure, with pricing becoming tougher. China's GDP growth slowed to 6.9%, its lowest in a quarter of a century, and car ownership penetration remains low, at below 30% of households. The market is considered still in the midst of motorisation.

site_title: Singapore seen easing again via one-off devaluation if outlook worsens
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), may consider a one-off devaluation of the Singapore dollar if the city-state's economy deteriorates further. The MAS has eased policy three times in 15 months to reanimate growth amid deflationary pressures. Analysts suggest a one-off devaluation could be a possibility if the economy weakens, but a negative policy band, which would allow the dollar to depreciate sustainably, is seen as a high hurdle due to potential market volatility and interest rate implications.

images.alt_text: Markets might do well to prepare for Singapore's central bank to follow up this month's surprise easing with another policy move, analysts say, suggesting a one-off currency devaluation as a possibility in the event the city state's economy deteriorates further.

site_title: As Zeti term ends, Malaysia poised to name central bank governor
summary: Malaysia's central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz is set to step down, leaving investors uncertain about her successor. The economy is already under pressure as Prime Minister Najib Razak faces questions about possible embezzlement at state investment company 1Malaysia Development Bhd. Analysts are concerned about the impact of the uncertainty on the ringgit, which has gained 10% this year. Potential candidates for the governorship include Deputy Governor Muhammad Ibrahim, Finance Ministry official Mohd Irwan Serigar Abdullah, and former banker Abdul Wahid Omar. The government has not announced a timeline for the appointment.

site_title: Obama plans 250 more US troops for Syria, boosting force to 300
summary: US President Barack Obama plans to deploy 250 additional troops to Syria, increasing the US force to approximately 300, as part of efforts to accelerate gains against Islamic State militants. This move aims to capitalize on recent successes, including the recapture of Palmyra by Russian-backed Syrian government forces. Obama's decision follows a speech in Hanover, where he discussed the Syria crisis with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and other European leaders. The deployment is seen as a boost to US-backed forces fighting the group, which controls cities in Iraq and Syria.

site_title: China police hunt for wealth manager who vanished with 1 billion yuan: Xinhua
summary: Chinese police are searching for Yang Weiguo, chairman of wealth management firm Wangzhou Fortune, who vanished with 1 billion yuan (S$208 million) of investor funds. The case is the latest scandal in China's shadow banking sector, which has seen a rise in fraud cases due to economic slowdown and promises of high returns. Yang Weiguo's disappearance has affected over 20,000 investors, with the company planning to repay investors by retrieving 1 billion yuan in principal and interest payments and selling property to cover the shortfall.

site_title: Growth in Uber car supply can help reduce private car ownership: Singapore GM
summary: Uber's collaboration with Lion City Rentals to bid for certificates of entitlement (COE) in Singapore aims to reduce private car ownership. The partnership, part of Uber's "supply growth initiative", has led to 510 successful bids for 630 submitted. This model helps Uber grow its car supply, providing affordable and flexible rental options for drivers while reducing private car usage. According to Uber's general manager in Singapore, Warren Tseng, this model complements public transport, ultimately reducing private car ownership and increasing point-to-point transport options for commuters.

site_title: Yen hindered by BOJ easing hopes, pound up after Obama's UK visit
summary: The yen fell to a three-week low of 111.90 due to expectations of the Bank of Japan's potential easing of lending rates, while sterling rose to a five-week high after US President Barack Obama's UK visit, boosting hopes for Britain's EU stay.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slip as Fed, BOJ meetings eyed
summary: The South Korean won fell to a one-week low due to dollar-long positions ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting later this week. The won dropped 0.5% to 1,149.0 per US dollar, while South Korean shares edged down. Analysts expect the Bank of Japan to consider applying negative rates, which could curb the yen's strength and pressure the won against the dollar. Foreign investors purchased a net 91.2 billion Korean won of KOSPI shares, but the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) was down 0.2% at 2,011.97 points.

site_title: Fears mount in quake-hit Nepal as tourists stay away
summary: Tourists are staying away from Nepal's Langtang valley, one year after a massive earthquake killed nearly 9,000 people and destroyed the tourism industry. The valley, once a popular trekking destination, has been cleared of debris but remains largely deserted. Locals are struggling to rebuild, with many relying on tourism for their livelihood. The industry's annual revenues fell by 32% in 2015, and tour operators predict a slow recovery. Authorities have attempted to reassure tourists by handing out free SIM cards and assessing the safety of trekking routes, but many remain deterred.

site_title: Fed's scope for summer rate hike widens as ECB signals a hold
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has signaled a hold on policy changes, potentially giving the Federal Reserve room to raise interest rates this summer. The move could reduce the risk of a sharp dollar rally if the two central banks diverge in their policies. The Fed is expected to raise rates twice this year, with a 34% chance of a move in July. The US economy faces obstacles, including a slower growth pace and low inflation, which may give the Fed pause.

site_title: UK banks set for grim results showing size of turnaround task
summary: Britain's top five banks, including HSBC, Barclays, and Lloyds Banking Group, are expected to report grim first-quarter earnings due to a weak economic outlook, misconduct charges, and high costs associated with laying off staff and settling lawsuits. Despite strengthening their capital bases and paying strong dividends, the banks' shares have fallen 11% this year, outpacing the FTSE 100's 1.5% gain. Record-low interest rates and regulatory pressures are expected to compound the hit to quarterly profits. The banks' struggle to win over investors raises concerns about their ability to recover from the financial crisis.

site_title: Former Prince engineer wants vault music released
summary: A former sound engineer for Prince, Susan Rogers, is advocating for the release of Prince's unreleased music from the "vault," a collection of decades-old songs. Rogers believes the music should be made available to historians, scholars, and fans, and suggests that musicians who worked with Prince in the 1980s and 1990s could finish the songs in the style they worked with him. Rogers hopes the analogue tapes have been transferred to digital and that there won't be a moral issue with releasing the music, as Prince's estate may not have considered his legacy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.580 points to 1714.380. Volume was 33 million lots worth RM8.36 million, with 90 gainers and 53 losers.

site_title: Stanchart's vice-chairman of Asean, Lim Cheng Teck, to retire May 1
summary: Standard Chartered Bank announced that its vice-chairman of Asean, Lim Cheng Teck, will retire on May 1 after 28 years with the bank. Lim, a veteran banker, led the growth of the bank's China franchise and transformed its Singapore business. He expressed gratitude for the opportunities and teams he worked with during his career.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore puts aside S$700m for Tourism Development Fund over next five years
summary: The Singapore government has allocated S$700 million to the Tourism Development Fund from 2016 to 2020 to support the tourism industry. The fund's next phase will focus on product development, technology adoption, and enhancing manpower capabilities. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran announced the allocation at the Tourism Industry Conference. The goal is to ensure Singapore remains a destination of choice.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Duterte widens lead in Philippines race despite rape comments
summary: Philippines presidential candidate Rodrigo Duterte widened his lead in the election, securing 33% of the vote in a recent poll. He surpassed Senator Grace Poe, who trailed at 24%, and former President Benigno Aquino's chosen candidate, Mar Roxas, at 19%. Duterte's comments on a 1989 rape and murder case sparked controversy, but he has maintained his stance on crime and international ties. The election is set for May 9, and all candidates have pledged to address labor outsourcing and protect the South China Sea from China's claims.

images.alt_text: Rodrigo Duterte jumped further ahead in the Philippine presidential race, according to a new poll taken after the tough talking Davao City mayor's inflammatory comments over the 1989 rape and murder of an Australian missionary as the campaign enters its last two weeks.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.35% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.35% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 10.33 points to 2,930.10. Ahead of central bank meetings in the US and Japan, losers outnumbered gainers 67 to 58, with 59 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks fall to lowest level in month on commodities slump
summary: China's Shanghai stocks fell 1.1% to their lowest level in a month, extending a weekly decline of 3.9%, as commodity companies slumped. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped to 2,925.74, following a central bank signal to reduce monetary stimulus. The slump was partly due to commodity exchanges cooling trading in raw materials and evidence of an accelerating growth rate. This marks the biggest weekly decline in almost three months.

site_title: Low crude prices to spur more M&A deals in oil & gas after slump
summary: Low oil prices are expected to spur more mergers and acquisitions in the oil and gas industry this year, with private equity firms likely to be major buyers. The decline in oil prices has led to a significant increase in debt for oil and gas companies, prompting some to sell assets to avoid bankruptcy. Consultants expect a surge in distressed assets to become available, with energy-focused private equity firms having $38 billion to fund deals. Activity may pick up at the end of the year as crude prices stabilize and investors gain confidence.

site_title: Danger signs in world's top housing market as developers falter
summary: Turkey's housing market, considered the world's best-performing, is showing signs of a bubble due to developers' high debt levels and faltering sales. The share of corporate loans to developers has nearly doubled in the past five years, with nearly a fifth of all corporate loans going bad. To keep sales brisk, builders are offering below-market interest rates and accepting lower deposits, but this strategy may ultimately lead to a financial crisis. Experts warn that the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes have exacerbated the problem, and a weakening currency has increased the risk for builders.

site_title: Safety lapses direct cause of fatal accident on train tracks: SMRT investigation
summary: A fatal accident on train tracks on March 22, 2016, killed two SMRT staff, and an investigation by SMRT has concluded that safety lapses were the direct cause. The investigation found that a vital safety measure, setting the speed limit to 0 km/h before a work team entered the track, was not applied, allowing a train to enter on automated mode. The SMRT Board Risk Committee and independent experts reviewed the incident, leading to the conclusion that the lapses directly caused the accident.

site_title: Behind the scenes at Apple's controversial China iPhone factory
summary: Apple's iPhone factory in Shanghai, operated by Pegatron, has implemented a new ID system to track employee work hours and wages. The system aims to prevent excessive overtime, with only a handful of exceptions from engineers working on emergency repairs. However, China Labor Watch claims that base pay remains too low, requiring overtime to make ends meet. The group collected pay stubs showing evidence of excessive overtime, contradicting Pegatron's claims of compliance with overtime regulations. Apple's chief executive officer, Tim Cook, has faced scrutiny over the company's global supply chain, with recent audits discovering issues with under-aged labor and discrimination.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Raffles Medical Group, Cache Logistics Trust, Boustead
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 3.7% increase in net profit to S$15.53 million for the first quarter, driven by 23% revenue growth. Cache Logistics Trust's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 5% to 2.039 cents, while Boustead's US$18.8 million dispute with Arab Banking Corporation was resolved in favor of Boustead after the Singapore High Court dismissed the appeal.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine obtains stay of entirety of court proceedings instituted by PPL Shipyard
summary: The Singapore High Court granted Marco Polo Marine a stay of court proceedings initiated by PPL Shipyard, a subsidiary of Sembcorp Marine, in favor of arbitration. The court ordered PPL to pay Marco Polo Marine's costs on an indemnity basis. The dispute relates to a US$214.3 million jack-up rig construction contract between Marco Polo Drilling and PPL. Marco Polo Marine maintains that it is not obligated to make payments claimed by PPL, and arbitration proceedings have commenced.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking after rally
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, falling 0.53% to 17,479.34, as investors took profits after a four-day rally ahead of a Bank of Japan meeting. The broader Topix index dropped 0.55%. The market treads carefully, awaiting the Bank of Japan meeting scheduled for later this week.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group's Q1 net profit up 3.7% to S$15.5m
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 3.7% increase in net profit to S$15.5 million for the first quarter of 2016, driven by strong performances from its healthcare and hospital services divisions. Revenue rose 23% to S$116.86 million, despite higher staff costs and operating expenses. The group attributed the growth to increased patient load and revenue from specialist consultants, as well as the acquisition of International SOS. However, it noted that a more measured pace of economic growth may impact healthcare demand.

site_title: Start-up Sirin to launch ultra high-tech phone for executives
summary: A British-Israeli start-up, Sirin Labs AG, plans to launch an ultra-high-tech phone for executives, retailing for nearly $20,000. The device, set to launch in May, will offer advanced technology and military-grade security. Co-founder Moshe Hogeg believes thousands of executives will pay the premium price due to the cost of being hacked. The luxury phone market is valued at $1.1 billion, with top-end phones selling for $10,000 to $300,000. Sirin raised $72 million in private funds to launch the device, which will be based on the Android operating system and run ahead of mass market technology.

site_title: Oil falls as traders cash in after 3 weeks of gains
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday after three weeks of gains, with Brent crude futures trading at $44.66 per barrel, down 45 US cents, or 1%, from their last settlement. US West Texas Intermediate futures were down around half a US dollar, or 1.2%, at $43.22 a barrel. The decline comes as traders took profits and as a jump in the US dollar was priced into fuel markets.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell early on Monday as traders took profits after three weeks of gains and as a jump in the US dollar late last week was priced into fuel markets.

site_title: Serbia's pro-European PM set for landslide win
summary: Serbian Prime Minister Aleksandar Vucic is expected to win a landslide victory in Sunday's general election, securing 52.6% of votes. The far-right Radicals, led by ultra-nationalist Vojislav Seselj, are also set to return to parliament with 7.4% of the vote. Critics have expressed concerns about Vucic's authoritarian tendencies, but he has expressed hope that voters will choose a "European path." The election outcome will allow Vucic to push ahead with EU integration and reforming Serbia's inefficient state-run companies, but the country remains one of the poorest in Europe with high unemployment.

images.alt_text: Serbia's pro-European Prime Minister Aleksandar Vucic was set to win a landslide victory in Sunday's general election, according to initial projections.

site_title: Oil bulls plunge into market as US gasoline demand hits record
summary: US gasoline demand hit a record 9.25 million barrels a day in March, according to the American Petroleum Institute, leading oil bulls to surge 8.3% in the week following failed talks in Doha on an oil output freeze. Investors focus on falling US output and higher fuel use ahead of the peak summer driving season. Speculators' net-long position in benchmark US crude jumped to an 11-month high, while WTI futures closed at $43.73, the highest settlement since November 10.

site_title: Foreign car dealers in China, ubiquitous as KFCs, face shakeout
summary: China's foreign car dealers are facing a shakeout due to declining profits. According to the China Automobile Dealers Association, three-quarters of dealers were unprofitable or breaking even in 2015. The situation may worsen this year due to increased competition and high inventory levels. Experts attribute the decline to low profit margins from new car sales, with dealers struggling to stay in business amidst intense price competition.

site_title: Asia: Stock futures signal losses as oil falls, yen strengthens
summary: Asian stock index futures point to declines as crude oil falls and the yen strengthens, with the Nikkei 225 futures down 0.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index futures 0.2% lower. Crude oil fell 0.5% to $43.53 a barrel, while the yen gained 0.2% against the greenback. Central bank policy meetings in Japan and the US are this week, with economists predicting additional monetary easing in Japan and no interest rate hike in the US.

site_title: China's biggest banks stand exposed after profit buffers eroded
summary: China's largest banks, such as Industrial & Commercial Bank of China and Bank of China, are expected to report their first annual profit declines in over a decade due to eroded profit buffers. The banks' provision coverage for bad loans, a key factor in earnings reports, has fallen close to the regulatory minimum of 150%. The government may intervene by cutting the minimum ratio, which could alleviate the banks' financial strain. If not, the banks may report profit declines, affecting their ability to return money to shareholders and potentially leading to job losses.

site_title: Hong Kong rejoins developed market bourses with closing auction
summary: Hong Kong's stock market will reintroduce a closing auction after a seven-year gap, starting on July 25. The system, which will limit price moves and allow for random closing, aims to reduce manipulation opportunities. The new model was designed after reviewing global peers and will be tested in two rehearsals in May and June. The system is expected to increase liquidity, particularly during index rebalances, and was previously used in the UK, Germany, and Australia.

site_title: Obama calls on China to increase pressure on North Korea
summary: US President Barack Obama urged China to increase pressure on North Korea following a submarine-launched ballistic missile test, calling it "provocative behaviour". China has cultivated cooperation with the US to put pressure on North Korea, but Obama expressed skepticism over a North Korean promise to halt nuclear testing in exchange for US military drills suspension. For progress, North Korea must show willingness to mothball its nuclear weapons programme, and analysts predict a possible fifth nuclear test ahead of the country's ruling party congress next month.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; Apple suppliers down ahead of iPhone maker's results
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.1% to 8,523.40 on Monday, tracking lower regional bourses, ahead of Apple's earnings results. Apple suppliers Largan Precision and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. dropped 3% and 0.3%, respectively. The Taiwan dollar softened to T$32.405 per US dollar. Asian shares and the US dollar edged lower as investors awaited central bank meetings in the US and Japan for clues on future policy moves.

site_title: Gold struggles on stronger dollar, caution ahead of Fed
summary: Gold prices struggled to recover on Monday due to a stronger US dollar, with spot gold unchanged at US$1,231.20 an ounce. The dollar's rise was attributed to the Bank of Japan's consideration of expanding its negative rate policy, which may lead to further rate cuts. Investors took a cautious stance ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting later this week.

images.alt_text: Gold struggled to recover from losses on Monday due to strength in the dollar and as investors took a cautious stance ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting later this week.

site_title: UN Security Council 'strongly' condemns North Korea missile launch
summary: The UN Security Council strongly condemned North Korea for firing a submarine-launched ballistic missile on April 23, calling it a "serious violation" of UN resolutions. The council reiterated its concern over North Korea's development of nuclear weapons delivery systems and the increased regional and global tension. The move follows previous condemnations of North Korea's ballistic missile tests, with the council urging the country to comply with its resolutions.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal equals Vilas clay record with ninth Barcelona title
summary: Rafael Nadal won his ninth Barcelona Open title, equaling Guillermo Vilas's record of 49 clay-court titles, by defeating Kei Nishikori 6-4, 7-5. Nadal, fresh from his Monte Carlo Masters win, has now won his first 10 European clay-court matches ahead of the French Open. Nishikori's 14-match winning streak in Barcelona ended, and he attributed his defeat to missed break-point opportunities. Nadal credited his strong first serve for his victory, saying he was "very happy" to resist mentally and win.

site_title: Sanders pressured to quit White House race as Clinton weighs VP picks
summary: Bernie Sanders is facing pressure to quit the White House race, but has refused to bow out. Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton is considering potential vice presidential candidates, with her team discussing 15-20 prospects. Clinton has set objectives for the search, describing the ideal person as someone who will help her campaign and support her presidency. The search for a running mate is ongoing, with Clinton's team working to find the right candidate to complement her ticket.

site_title: Police charge Australian teenager with planning Anzac terror attack
summary: Australian police have arrested and charged a 16-year-old teenager with a terrorism offence related to planning an attack at Anzac Day commemorations in Sydney. The offence carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment. Police believe the boy was acting alone and took inspiration from the Islamic State movement. This is the second recent case of teenagers being charged with terrorism offences in Australia, following a similar incident last year. The teenager will appear in children's court on Monday.

site_title: With China subsidies elusive, Toyota goes ahead with hybrids
summary: Toyota plans to continue producing and selling hybrid models in China despite the government's lack of subsidies, aiming to meet customer demand. The company has sold over 1 million vehicles in China last year and plans to boost local production capacity. Toyota will introduce a hybrid version of its RAV4 SUV in China as soon as possible, and also plans to produce the C-HR compact SUV locally. The company believes it can still succeed without government incentives, with sales of its Corolla and Levin hybrids holding strong.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp, the dominant maker of gasoline-electric autos, will push forward with its strategy to build and sell hybrid models in China, in spite of the government's unwillingness to subsidize the technology.

site_title: One dead, 26 wounded as rockets hit Turkish town near Syrian border
summary: Rockets struck the Turkish town of Kilis near the Syrian border, killing one person and injuring 26, including 10 more in a mosque attack. Turkish soldiers returned fire into Syria, and Deputy Prime Minister Yalcin Akdogan was in talks at the governor's office when the mosque was hit. This incident comes a day after the government promised to protect the area from Islamic State militants.

site_title: Burkina Faso bans GM cotton because of fall in quality
summary: Burkina Faso, Africa's top cotton producer, has banned genetically-modified (GM) cotton due to a decline in crop quality. The country had previously used GM cotton to boost yields, but it resulted in shorter fibre lengths, making the cotton less attractive for textile production. The government has provided subsidies and price controls to support conventional cotton farmers, and some producers are open to reconsidering GM cotton in the future. The decision is seen as a warning to other African countries against adopting GM crops, with organic activists hailing it as a timely move.

site_title: China's white-collar wages outstrip Southeast Asian salaries
summary: China's average base professional salaries are 1.9 to 2.2 times those of Vietnam and the Philippines, according to a Willis Towers Watson study. Entry-level white-collar professionals in China receive an average annual base salary of US$21,000, outpacing those in Indonesia by 30%. China's labor cost advantage may be short-lived as wages are rising and will likely increase in Vietnam and other Southeast Asian markets in the coming years. This shift could prompt companies to reconsider relocating operations from China.

site_title: Earliest China economic data show recovery gathers pace in April
summary: China's economic recovery gained pace in April, with property-led growth exceeding economists' estimates, according to private indicators. New credit, industrial output, and retail sales increased, while employment sub-indexes rose. However, business outlook data showed companies remain cautious and reluctant to invest. Analysts now expect the central bank to keep interest rates on hold, with forecasts suggesting a rate cut in the fourth quarter. The economy's recovery is seen as enduring, potentially changing forecasts for monetary policy.

site_title: Thai hard disk drive exporters see silver lining in cloud storage - for now
summary: Thailand's hard disk drive exporters are facing a potential decline in demand due to the shift towards cloud storage and mobile devices. Despite a 45% increase in exports to $1.1 billion in the first two months of 2016, the industry is bracing for a fall as electronics makers divert demand to flash memory chips. Cheaper competition from countries like Malaysia also poses a threat to Thai shippers. The rise in cloud storage has been a rare bright spot in Thai tech manufacturing, but its impact is expected to be short-lived.

site_title: Obama, Merkel make case for disputed US-EU trade deal
summary: US President Barack Obama and German Chancellor Angela Merkel made a joint push for a US-EU trade deal, despite opposition, with Obama vowing to complete the agreement by the end of the year. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations aim to boost economic growth in Western economies. Merkel echoed Obama's sentiment, stating the deal would be beneficial for the German economy. However, Obama acknowledged popular opposition to globalization, citing concerns about jobs and the narrative that global trade weakens ordinary people.

site_title: White House to make decision on 9/11 report by June: Bob Graham
summary: The White House plans to make a decision by June on releasing classified material from the 9/11 Commission Report, which is central to a dispute over suing the Saudi Arabian government for damages. The material is currently being reviewed by the US Director of National Intelligence. This decision is expected to impact a lawsuit filed by Americans seeking damages from the Saudi government for their involvement in the 2001 attacks. The outcome will determine whether the government can shield itself from liability.

site_title: Obama urges reinstatement of Syria ceasefire
summary: US President Barack Obama urged the warring parties in Syria to return to peace talks and "reinstate" a ceasefire, as the ceasefire in the country appears to have disintegrated. The White House believes the ceasefire is worth pursuing, despite regime and rebel bombardments claiming 26 lives. Obama defended his refusal to establish a safe zone, citing concerns about military intervention, and emphasized that the US is committed to finding a peaceful solution to the five-year conflict.

site_title: Bells of Minneapolis ring out Prince tribute
summary: The bells of Minneapolis city hall rang out with a 30-minute tribute to Prince, featuring hits like "Kiss," "1999," and "Nothing Compares 2 U." Tony Hill, chair of the Tower Bell Foundation, performed on a two-octave keyboard controlling the bells, accompanied by over 100 fans in the rain. The event was a tribute to Prince's hometown and legacy, with Hill noting it was a difficult but happy occasion to share music with the community. The tribute was a heartfelt way to celebrate Prince's life and music.

images.alt_text: The bells of Minneapolis city hall rang out with some of Prince's best-loved hits Sunday in a tribute to the hometown music icon.

site_title: Second US courtroom battle with Apple ends
summary: The US government has ended its second attempt to compel Apple to unlock an iPhone used by a New York drug dealer, following a March decision that ended efforts to force Apple to help unlock an iPhone used by a San Bernardino terrorist. The government claims it has found another way to access the device, bringing an end to the courtroom battle. This decision follows a similar outcome in March regarding a San Bernardino terrorist's iPhone.

site_title: This week's FOMC meeting expected to be a non-event
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at its upcoming FOMC meeting, as the US economic recovery is hindered by global economic concerns, including a possible hard landing in China, volatile oil markets, and a stagnant European recovery. The probability of a June rate hike has decreased to around 20%, with the futures market pricing a zero probability of a rate hike this week. Investors are advised to maintain an underweight exposure to equities and a cash balance due to the prolonged economic cycle and extreme valuations in bond markets.

site_title: Taking on Tesla: China's Jia Yueting aims to outmuscle Musk
summary: Chinese billionaire Jia Yueting's company LeEco aims to disrupt the electric vehicle industry by offering "smart, connected and self-driving" cars at a lower price point than Tesla. LeEco has unveiled an electric concept supercar, the LeSEE, and plans to start producing it in a few years with US strategic partner Faraday Future. The company's vision is to make electric cars free, with a "disruptive" pricing model similar to phones and TV sets. LeEco has received funding from Chinese tech giants and has partnered with Aston Martin and BAIC Motor. Despite skepticism, Jia believes his company can lead the industry leapfrogging to a new age.

site_title: VW upbeat on China, plans more investments with JVs
summary: Volkswagen AG is optimistic about its sales trend in China, the world's largest auto market, with plans to invest 4 billion euros in joint ventures this year. The company aims to expand its SUV and new energy vehicle markets, with a focus on launching 10 locally produced models. Volkswagen estimates 2 million new energy vehicles will be sold in China by 2020, and plans to build 15 plug-in hybrids or electric cars in the next three to four years. The company is also taking steps to boost online connectivity and reposition itself after the emissions scandal.

site_title: British astronaut runs marathon in space
summary: British astronaut Tim Peake ran a marathon in space on the International Space Station, completing the 42km course in 3 hours, 35 minutes, and 21 seconds. This achievement broke the Guinness World Record for the fastest marathon in orbit. Peake, 44, was aided by a training regime and an iPad showing a moving image of the run. This feat is the second time a person has completed a marathon in space, following US astronaut Sunita Williams in 2007.

images.alt_text: British astronaut Tim Peake ran a marathon in space in record time on Sunday, strapped into a treadmill on the International Space Station as thousands ran the London Marathon below.

site_title: London boasts largest number of billionaires: rich list
summary: London has the largest number of billionaires, with 120 individuals boasting fortunes in pounds sterling, according to The Sunday Times Rich List 2016. This surpasses the US (378) and China (193). Despite some billionaires losing fortunes due to economic downturns, the overall wealth of the 1,000 wealthiest people in Britain increased. The US remains the country with the most billionaires overall, but London leads in terms of those with fortunes in sterling.

site_title: Oil companies set to report worst quarter results
summary: The world's top oil companies are expected to report their worst quarterly results due to the ongoing oil supply glut, which has driven global prices to a 13-year low of $27.10 a barrel. However, a 60% rally in oil prices since January has given energy shares a strong tailwind, raising hopes that the market may have bottomed out.

images.alt_text: The world's top oil companies are set to report their worst quarterly results yet in the current downturn but a recent recovery in crude prices is raising hopes the market has bottomed out.

site_title: IPO of Dell cyber unit SecureWorks fizzles
summary: SecureWorks Corp, the cyber unit of Dell Inc, failed to impress investors with its IPO debut, pricing below its indicated range and closing at $14 per share. Despite hopes it would reinvigorate the US technology IPO market, the company's growing losses and unsold shares from its parent Dell hurt demand. Investors are seeking more profitable companies, and SecureWorks' valuation of over $1 billion remains a fraction of its initial valuation expectations.

site_title: Regulators crack down on carmakers
summary: Regulators worldwide are cracking down on carmakers due to cheating scandals on fuel economy and emissions. China will be the strictest regulatory regime over the next five years, according to Ford CEO Mark Fields, citing societal factors around air pollution. The tougher regulations come as global carmakers face increasing pressure to reduce emissions and improve fuel efficiency.

site_title: Carmakers focus on China as hot market slows
summary: China's car market is experiencing a slowdown due to an economic slowdown, with vehicle demand projected to grow at an average 5% annually from 2015 to 2020. The slowing economy and increasing competition from ride-sharing services are factors contributing to the decline. Despite this, annual passenger vehicle sales are expected to reach 24 million units in 2020, driven by growing demand for SUVs. International carmakers face intense competition from Chinese brands, but analysts see opportunities in the rapidly changing industry, particularly in autonomous vehicles.

images.alt_text: Visitors at an Infiniti Motor event in Beijing. Domestic, international carmakers face increasingly cutthroat competition for consumers whose preferences have become "more practical".

site_title: How Toshiba got paid before a sale closed in a maneuver skirting antitrust rules
summary: Toshiba structured the sale of its medical equipment business to Canon Inc in a way that allowed the company to book the $8.1 billion proceeds before the deal was approved by regulators, potentially evading antitrust scrutiny. Toshiba sold the business to a special-purpose vehicle, MS Holding, with minimal capital, and Canon paid for the rights to acquire the assets before gaining control. This deal bypasses Japan's anti-monopoly law, which requires a buyer to seek approval for deals over $200 million in annual sales. Toshiba is facing financial struggles and seeks to raise capital, while Canon is concerned about potential risks of insolvency.

images.alt_text: Toshiba Corp, in a hurry to raise cash before closing its books for the business year that ended at the end of last month, was able to structure the sale of its medical equipment business to Canon Inc in an unorthodox way so that it could book the 665.5 billion yen (S$8.1 billion) proceeds before the deal had been approved by regulators.

site_title: Mitsubishi may skip earnings forecast
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp is unlikely to issue an earnings forecast due to uncertainty over the financial impact of its misleading fuel economy data. The company is under investigation by the transport ministry after overstating fuel economy for four of its mini vehicle models. This decision comes after the company admitted to the mistake last week.

site_title: Austrian far-right triumphs in presidential vote
summary: Austrian far-right leader Norbert Hofer won 36% of the vote in the first round of the presidential election, defeating candidates from the traditionally powerful governing coalition parties. This marks a historic defeat for the coalition, which has been in power since 2008. Hofer's victory is seen as a reflection of widespread dissatisfaction with the government, and he has vowed to act as a "protector of the Austrian people." A second-round runoff is set for May 22, where Hofer is likely to face Alexander van der Bellen, backed by the Greens.

site_title: 1992: Lots to chew on with Creative, free trade
summary: In 1992, Singaporean entrepreneur Sim Wong Hoo led Creative Technology to a successful initial public offering on Nasdaq, becoming the first Singaporean company to list on the US exchange. The company's Sound Blaster product dominated the personal computing sound card market. Meanwhile, the Asean nations endorsed the creation of the Asean Free Trade Area (AFTA), and Singapore banned the sale of chewing gum, which remains a point of curiosity today.

site_title: 1MDB boss says M'sian fund, IPIC face cross default risks
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state fund and Abu Dhabi's IPIC face cross-default risks if they fail to make a US$50 million interest payment by Monday. 1MDB president Arul Kanda Kandasamy warned that both firms could trigger cross defaults, with IPIC at a higher risk due to its larger debt pile. The stand-off between the firms has worried markets and left bondholders waiting on the payment.

site_title: Few public-private sector projects in S'pore: Maybank Kim Eng report (Amended)
summary: Singapore has few public-private sector partnerships (PPP) projects compared to its total infrastructure projects, mainly due to low funding costs and well-managed government finances. The government's adoption of the Net Investment Returns Contribution (NIRC) framework has increased recurring income support for higher public spending. By 2020, Singapore's development expenditure is expected to increase 50% to S$30 billion, primarily funding infrastructure projects such as water desalination and transportation. The government prices public goods at full cost recovery, with a strong social contract between the government and citizens.

site_title: Japanese fare spiced up by friendly, most obliging chefs
summary: Chikuyotei, a Japanese restaurant in UE Square, Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with its signature unagi rice and 100-year-old teriyaki sauce. Despite its modern kaiseki sets, the restaurant's friendly and obliging chefs make it a welcoming space. While ingredient quality is slightly above average, the dinner sets are priced realistically lower than other fine dining establishments. The unagi don is a standout dish, and the chefs' willingness to accommodate requests makes for a memorable meal. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: SunEdison solar projects in India attract buyers
summary: Four companies have approached India to take over solar projects from SunEdison Inc, the world's largest clean-energy developer, amid bankruptcy. Energy Minister Piyush Goyal said the struggling developer's assets have value, even after filing the biggest US bankruptcy with $16.1 billion liabilities. SunEdison had 1 gigawatt of unfinished projects in India and a total capacity of 1,228 megawatts. Renewable energy companies distance themselves from SunEdison's collapse, saying it won't harm the industry, with some potential buyers eyeing the project assets in a buyer's market.

site_title: Abe orders extra budget for quake reconstruction
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe ordered an extra budget package to fund reconstruction after recent earthquakes in southern Japan, aiming to put it into effect by June 1. The move comes as the government faces pressure to stimulate the stagnant economy ahead of a G-7 summit. The budget package will help rebuild over 5,000 damaged houses and provide relief to 80,000 people displaced by the earthquakes, which killed about 50 people. The government has already set aside 2.3 billion yen from a reserve fund for disaster relief.

site_title: Developing countries are at risk
summary: Developing countries are at risk as industrialization in emerging economies creates fewer jobs than previously. Unlike Western countries, which shifted workers from labor-intensive to capital-intensive production, emerging economies have struggled to adopt and implement new technologies, leading to premature deindustrialization. Automation and globalization have replaced manufacturing jobs, making it difficult for African and South American countries to replicate the growth seen in Asian economies. As a result, developing countries may not experience the same rapid growth by shifting workers from farms to factory jobs, hindering their economic development.

site_title: Can't be 'business as usual', say retail industry stakeholders
summary: Singapore's retail industry faces challenges, including slower economic growth, softening tourism spending, and increased competition from e-commerce. Retailers must adapt to improve customer experience, product mix, and online presence. Industry stakeholders, such as the Singapore Retailers Association, are promoting e-commerce and online shopping as a way to drive foot traffic to physical stores. Landlords are also expected to play a key role in evolving the retail space, with some malls introducing new concepts and events to attract customers. Despite challenges, new brands are still entering the market, and existing retailers are consolidating and expanding overseas.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Many foods loaded with sugar, salt and fat are now in
summary: Bakersfield, California - A shift in consumer perception of what is healthy to eat has led to a resurgence in previously unpopular foods, such as dark chocolate, beef jerky, and full-fat ice cream. Research suggests that not all types of fat contribute to weight gain or heart problems, prompting companies to reevaluate their products and health advocates to question their previous stances. This change is driven by evolving definitions of health and wellness, leaving companies scrambling to adapt to the new landscape.

site_title: World Bank, IMF push for carbon pricing
summary: The World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) are urging governments to impose a price tag on carbon dioxide emissions, citing the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to combat climate change. The institutions are providing financial and technical assistance to countries that are creating a system to put a price on carbon, and have already worked with 18 countries, including China. The goal is to cover 25% of the world's carbon emissions by 2020 and 50% by 2030, with the World Bank aiming to link the systems into a global carbon trading market.

site_title: Governments can't use public-private sector projects to offload all the risks, say industry players
summary: Governments and private investors in the Asia-Pacific region have reached a stalemate on public-private partnerships (PPP) due to unrealistic risk-sharing expectations. Industry players argue that governments cannot offload all risks, and projects must be commercially viable for private investors to participate. The private sector can bring expertise, technology, and innovative revenue streams, but only if governments can provide a viable project and robust feasibility studies. Low success rates of PPP projects in countries like Indonesia and the Philippines highlight the need for governments to reassess their approach and work with concession advisers to improve project viability.

site_title: Think like a city instead of a state to innovate, consultant urges S'pore
summary: Singapore should adopt a city-state approach to innovation, prioritizing a network of virtual hubs around the world, rather than being a regional hub. The Centre for Public Impact, a UK-based not-for-profit, is compiling a report on effective public policies worldwide, featuring Singapore as a case study. The city-state's efficient public services are ripe for disruption, and its small size gives it an advantage in implementing policies quickly. By thinking like a city, Singapore can stay ahead in a digitally diversified economy and remain relevant in the decades to come.

site_title: EU finance chiefs want joint tax-haven blacklist, sanctions
summary: The European Union unveiled measures to tackle tax evasion, with finance chiefs agreeing to work on a joint tax-haven blacklist and common sanctions. This comes after the Panama leaks exposed billions of dollars hidden in tax havens worldwide. The EU aims to increase tax transparency and cooperation among nations to counter populist groups using the leaks to argue against governments. The move follows a joint statement by the International Monetary Fund, United Nations, World Bank, and Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to provide support on international tax matters.

site_title: All the world's a stage honouring the Bard
summary: Prince Charles joined top British actors, including Judi Dench and Benedict Cumberbatch, in a live stage performance of Hamlet at the Royal Shakespeare Theatre in Stratford-upon-Avon to celebrate the 400th anniversary of William Shakespeare's death. The event, which was broadcast live on British television, also featured a parade, fireworks, and performances by Chinese actors at Shakespeare's family home. US President Barack Obama attended a performance at Shakespeare's Globe Theatre in London, praising the enduring appeal of Shakespeare's works.

site_title: Buying and selling by directors flat for second straight week
summary: Singapore Exchange filings show buying and selling by directors were flat for the second straight week, with 12 companies making 27 purchases worth S$2.35 million and four firms making 8 disposals worth S$1.23 million.

site_title: Man behind recent investment woes
summary: A man named Guillianno Mata, estimated to have invested S$160m in 8,700 people through three firms in Singapore and Malaysia, has been linked to numerous investor complaints. The companies affected have received complaints over the past year, with Mata's involvement being a common thread among at least five firms. Authorities have not taken action against Mata, leaving thousands of investors seeking refunds or resolution.

site_title: Risk governance for IT outsourcing
summary: A company's board should prioritize and manage high-risk IT vulnerabilities when outsourcing IT services to third-party providers. This includes overseeing the development of enterprise-wide policies for outsourcing, monitoring implementation, and ensuring robust security controls. The biggest operating risks in outsourcing relate to security and controls, including data integrity, sovereignty, recoverability, confidentiality, and compliance. Boards must work closely with management to address these risks and ensure the proper contracting and implementation of outsourcing arrangements, particularly in cloud computing where risks are more immediate and obvious due to its openness and complexity.

site_title: Cars and the city
summary: A car-lite Singapore, where cars are not the primary mode of transportation, is a realistic prospect, say experts. To achieve this, alternative options such as cost-effective, available, and reliable public transport, driverless cars, and car-sharing services are needed. With advancements in technology, pooling of driverless vehicles can reduce wasted space and make public transport more accessible. However, mindset barriers, such as revering cars as status symbols, must be overcome. Governments and private sectors must invest in public transport infrastructure and educate the public about the benefits of a car-lite society. Experts predict that a car-lite Singapore can reduce carbon emissions and improve liveability, but it requires a gradual and sustained effort to change consumer behavior.

site_title: Cra-Z-Art jewellery-making toys found to have dangerous levels of lead
summary: New York State Attorney General Eric T Schneiderman launched an investigation into Cra-Z-Art jewelry-making toys sold at major retailers, including Target, Kmart, and Toys "R" Us, after finding high levels of lead in some products. The toys exceeded federal safety limits, with some containing up to 10 times the allowed amount. The Attorney General called for a nationwide recall and asked retailers to remove the products from shelves. The Consumer Product Safety Commission is also investigating, and the Attorney General urged the agency to issue a recall.

site_title: Transportation, logistics jobs at risk
summary: A 2013 study by Carl Benedikt Frey and Michael Osborne found that 47% of US jobs are at risk of automation due to advances in technology. However, this does not mean all jobs will be automated. While some jobs, such as cashiers, have been displaced by technology, many remain in employment. The study highlights the need for workers to develop skills that are less susceptible to automation.

site_title: FAA orders Boeing engine fix to avoid failure in icy conditions
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has ordered Boeing to fix engines on 176 787 Dreamliner airplanes due to an "urgent safety issue" in icy conditions. The problem affects General Electric's GEnx engines, which can cause damage and power loss if ice accumulates on fan blades. The repairs, involving grinding down engine casings, must be completed within five months. The FAA directive applies to 43 planes operated by US-based airlines, and other countries are expected to comply. This is the latest issue to affect the 787 Dreamliner, following previous problems with software and electrical issues.

site_title: The future of jobs
summary: A 2016 study by University of Oxford researchers highlights the potential risks of technological change to future low-skilled jobs. While automation has expanded to a broader range of tasks, including non-routine work, jobs requiring creativity, social intelligence, and manual dexterity are less automatable. These tasks include creative work, social intelligence, and tasks requiring perception and manipulation skills. Despite advances in machine learning and robotics, human workers maintain an advantage in these areas, and automation is unlikely to displace jobs in these sectors.

images.alt_text: More advanced robots with enhanced sensors and manipulators perform non-routine manual tasks. Baxter (above), for example, requires no programming and is able to memorise new working patterns as a human worker guides its arms through the motions needed to complete a task.

site_title: Abe orders extra budget for quake reconstruction
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe ordered a supplementary budget to fund earthquake reconstruction, aiming to implement it by June 1. The budget aims to support the reconstruction of quake-hit areas, particularly in southern Japan, where 50 people were killed and 5,000 houses damaged. The move is seen as a response to economic stagnation and ahead of the G-7 summit, where Japan is hosting the event. The government has already set aside 2.3 billion yen for disaster relief and plans to offer regional tax subsidies.

site_title: Murali promises new infrastructure plans for constituency if elected
summary: Murali Pillai, a PAP candidate, has announced plans to upgrade Bukit Batok's infrastructure, including covered linkways, a jogging track, and a multi-generational park, if elected in the upcoming by-election. The plans, under the Neighbourhood Renewal Programme, were conceptualized after a 2015 survey of residents. Murali stated that the PAP-run town council can only execute these plans if the majority of voters elect him, emphasizing the need for voter mandate.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Yahoo likely to cull the list of first-round bidders this week
summary: Yahoo is expected to narrow down its first-round bidders this week, with its advisers reviewing over 10 initial offers ranging from $4 billion to $8 billion. The bidders, including Yahoo's partners and private equity firms, had submitted their proposals after the company put itself up for sale. The decision on which bidders will move forward to the next stage is expected to be made soon, with Yahoo's board of directors set to discuss the proposals. The outcome will have significant implications for the future of the company.

site_title: Little change in US stocks with jobs data hot, earnings not
summary: US stocks were relatively flat last week due to mixed economic data, with new weekly jobless claims hitting a 50-year low, indicating a strong labor market, but earnings reports were underwhelming. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, but may be more inclined to raise them in the future due to the hot jobs data. The market's volatility is driven by "fast money" traders shifting between sectors, and earnings disappointments in the tech sector could continue to weigh on the market.

site_title: EU finance chiefs want joint tax-haven blacklist, sanctions
summary: The European Union unveiled measures to tackle tax evasion as finance chiefs agreed to work on a joint tax-haven blacklist and common sanctions. The move comes after the Panama leaks exposed billions of dollars hidden in tax havens worldwide. EU finance ministers also agreed to exchange information on beneficial owners of companies and explore tougher anti-tax avoidance and anti-money laundering rules. The global response to the leaks has prompted international cooperation, but experts warn that governments face a long fight against tax abuse.

site_title: Japanese banks' rising overseas loan exposure could be risky: BOJ
summary: Japanese banks have significantly increased their overseas loan exposure, with 30-40% of total assets at the country's big three megabanks now represented by foreign loans. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) warns that this growth poses currency risks, as most loans are denominated in dollars or euros, and banks must borrow in these currencies to match their yen deposits. The BOJ advises banks to boost foreign currency deposits or other means to protect themselves from rising funding costs and potential liquidity shortages.

site_title: MMA juggernaut making its mark in Asia
summary: One Championship, a Singapore-based MMA promotion, is poised for an initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange in the next two to three years. Chairman Chatri Sityodtong aims to raise capital to fuel expansion across Asia and beyond. The company has already made inroads in China and the Middle East, and boasts a ten-year cable television deal with Fox Sports Asia. One Championship plans to debut in Thailand, its first market outside of South-east Asia, and integrate sports and entertainment, with a new partnership with Universal Music Group.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: SunEdison solar projects in India attract buyers
summary: Four companies have approached India to take over solar projects from SunEdison Inc, which is navigating bankruptcy. Energy Minister Piyush Goyal said the struggling developer's assets worldwide have value, even after filing the largest US bankruptcy this year with $16.1 billion liabilities. SunEdison is building seven solar projects with a total capacity of 1,060 megawatts in India, valued potentially at $1.1 billion when complete. Renewable energy companies say the bankruptcy won't harm the industry, citing SunEdison's "relentless pursuit of growth" as the main issue.

site_title: In Asia, Netflix trips on content and competition
summary: Netflix faces challenges in expanding its content offerings in Asia, where local competition and regulatory hurdles hinder growth. The company has struggled to provide enough strong content, with smaller programming libraries compared to the US, and has faced delays in offering popular shows due to rights issues. Despite efforts to localize, Netflix still lags behind in markets such as South Korea and Japan, and has yet to win permission to enter the restricted Chinese market. The company's international subscriber base is also smaller than its US counterpart, with 34.5 million subscribers outside the US compared to 47 million in the US.

site_title: Robots replacing Japan farmers seen preserving food security
summary: Japan's aging farmers are being replaced by robots and driver-less tractors as the country struggles to meet increasing food demand. With the average age of Japanese farmers now 67, the government plans to spend 4 billion yen to promote farm automation and develop 20 different types of robots. Autonomous tractors and harvesters are being developed by companies such as Kubota and Hitachi, with the goal of boosting productivity and appealing to younger farmers. Japan aims to reduce its reliance on food imports, which currently account for 60% of its supplies.

site_title: Mitsubishi may skip earnings forecast
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp is unlikely to issue an earnings forecast for the current financial year due to uncertainty about the financial impact of its misleading fuel economy data. The company is under investigation by the transport ministry after overstating the fuel economy of four mini vehicle models made for the local market. The misleading data affected 625,000 vehicles, and Mitsubishi's share price has plummeted, wiping out around 40% of its market value. The company has stopped sales and production of affected models and is facing a pending investigation and requests from US auto safety authorities for information.

site_title: Snapshot of One Championship
summary: One Championship, a Singapore-based mixed martial arts organization, was launched in 2011 and has since expanded globally. The company signed a ten-year deal with Fox Sports Asia in 2012 and held its first international event in Jakarta. In 2014, Manny Pacquiao became a minority shareholder, and the organization won the Promotion of the Year award in 2015. One Championship announced a partnership with Universal Music Group in 2016 and will hold its first event in Bangkok on May 27.

site_title: In finance, front office takes on governance role
summary: The financial industry has established a governance framework known as the three lines of defense, where the business, compliance, and audit teams work together to prevent non-compliance. Front-office surveillance teams, often comprised of ex-traders and regulatory experts, use technology to detect and prevent misconduct, focusing on market abuse, conduct risks, conflicts of interest, and data-loss prevention. Regulations, such as the UK's Senior Managers and Certification Regime, have driven this development, requiring senior staff to demonstrate supervision of daily actions. Companies balance running a business with supervisory obligations by hiring front-office surveillance teams or implementing technology-driven controls.

site_title: Donald Trump's brand gets a lift from his ageing aircraft fleet
summary: Donald Trump's ageing aircraft fleet has received significant media attention, with four of the five planes being over 20 years old. The Boeing 757, Trump's favorite, has undergone extensive renovations, including a gold-plated interior, and is valued at approximately $18 million. Trump has defended the fleet's value, citing its "promotional potential" and the fact that he can get good value for his money. Despite the planes' age, Trump has continued to use them for his presidential campaign, often with minimal passengers. Experts have questioned the wisdom of purchasing such an old aircraft.

site_title: 40% of Sturdee Residences' units sold in VIP preview
summary: SL Capital (1), a subsidiary of Sustained Land, sold 122 units of Sturdee Residences, a 99-year leasehold project, during a VIP preview event at an average price of S$1,550 per square foot. The units comprise one- to five-bedroom units across two 30-storey towers, with 80% sold as one- or two-bedroom units. Foreigners and permanent residents made up about 20% of buyers, with three penthouses sold at S$3.2 million each. The official launch is set for April 30.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Carry trade gains traction as currency volatility turns lower
summary: The US$5.3 trillion foreign-exchange market has turned supportive for the carry trade, a strategy in which investors borrow in low-interest-rate currencies and buy assets with higher rates.
