Returns from the technique have advanced to the highest levels since December, aided by rallies in South Africa's rand and Canada's dollar against the euro. Volatility has waned, and commodity prices have stabilized, bolstering currencies with relatively higher interest rates. Investors will watch the Federal Reserve's policy statement for clues about interest rate plans, but some analysts caution about the risks of diving back into higher-yielding currencies.

site_title: With US economy in soft spot, Fed likely to keep policy on hold
summary: The Federal Reserve is likely to keep interest rates unchanged due to concerns about the global economy, Brexit, and the US economy's modest first-quarter slowdown. Analysts, including Fed Chair Janet Yellen, believe a cautious approach to raising rates is prudent, with some advocating for a delay until inflation picks up. The Fed's decision comes amid a debate about the US economy's resilience to global volatility and slow growth. The International Monetary Fund has cut its growth outlook, citing regional conflicts and Brexit, while the US economy has shown signs of continued strong hiring and a weaker dollar.

site_title: 'Once-a-century' climate hazards will hit Europe yearly: study
summary: A new study published in Climatic Changes suggests that by mid-century, southern Europe will face at least one severe climate hazard, such as extreme droughts, coastal floods, or heatwaves, every year. By 2100, the entire Mediterranean seaboard will be hit annually with these hazards, which also include wildfires, river floods, and windstorms. Some hotspots will experience two or more of these hazards every year, formerly occurring only once a century.

site_title: Halliburton reports US$2.1b charge on job cuts, assets
summary: Halliburton reported a $2.1 billion charge in the first quarter due to job cuts and asset write-offs, aiming to complete its takeover of Baker Hughes by the end of the month. The company eliminated 6,000 more jobs to reduce costs, delaying its full earnings release until May 3. This move is part of Halliburton's efforts to wrap up the deal before the deadline.

site_title: Such stuff as dreams are made on: fans mark Shakespeare's 400th death anniversary
summary: Fans worldwide celebrate the 400th death anniversary of William Shakespeare, marking the playwright's hometown of Stratford-upon-Avon with star-studded performances, concerts, and parades. Top British actors, including Judi Dench and Ian McKellen, will perform famous scenes at the Royal Shakespeare Theatre. Prince Charles will attend the Shakespeare Live! show, which will be broadcast on BBC television and beamed to cinemas globally. The event aims to honor Shakespeare's legacy and bring the town to a standstill.

site_title: 1MDB boss says the Malaysian fund and IPIC face cross default risks: report
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) and Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Company (IPIC) face cross-default risks if they fail to make a US$50 million interest payment by Monday. 1MDB President Arul Kanda Kandasamy warned that if both firms refuse to pay, they could trigger cross-defaults on other debts, including a US$1.75 billion bond and two Islamic bonds totaling US$1.28 billion. Kandasamy believes IPIC is more likely to default due to its larger debt pile, but considers the risk manageable for 1MDB.

site_title: Post-Brexit UK-US trade deal could take a decade, Obama tells BBC
summary: US President Barack Obama predicts a 5-10 year timeline for a post-Brexit UK-US trade deal, stating Britain won't receive preferential treatment. He urged Britons to remain in the EU, warning that negotiations would be slower outside the bloc. Obama's visit and intervention have angered the Eurosceptic "Out" campaign, which claims Britain can easily negotiate deals outside the EU.

site_title: Metals shine on China, oil and weaker dollar
summary: Metals prices surged last week, driven by Chinese demand hopes, rebounding oil, and a weakening dollar. Aluminium reached a seven-month high at $1,655 per tonne, while Nickel soared to a five-month peak at $9,585 per tonne. Copper, lead, and tin also rallied to one-month pinnacles. Precious metals, including gold, silver, platinum, and palladium, surged due to the dollar's weakness and loose central bank policies. China's economy grew 1.1% in the first quarter, and metals demand could be powered higher by restocking, with a potential restocking cycle in the commodity markets.

images.alt_text: Gold rose on Thursday to a five-week high at US$1,270.47 per ounce, helping to push silver to an 11-month peak at US$17.69.

site_title: Key to convenient home-sharing
summary: Igloohome, a Singapore startup, has developed a digital lock system for Airbnb-style home-sharing, providing a convenient and secure key access solution. The system generates a PIN code for each guest, which can be entered into a smart lock installed on the host's front door. This allows guests to come and go freely without needing a physical key. Igloohome has raised $1.25 million in seed funding and is valued at $5-10 million. The company aims to expand its services to other markets and offer additional features, such as on-demand tidying services and utility tracking.

site_title: Chinese firms accelerate in race toward driverless future
summary: Chinese firms are accelerating in the development of driverless cars, competing with US companies. Internet giants Baidu and manufacturer Changan have recently entered the market, with Changan completing China's first long-distance autonomous vehicle test. Two self-driving Changan cars traveled 2,000km from Chongqing to Beijing, demonstrating the country's progress in autonomous vehicle technology. This move is seen as a challenge to US companies like Google, BMW, and Toyota, which have been working on autonomous vehicles for years.

site_title: Canada's golden crop boom devastated by main HK buyer
summary: Canada's premium North American ginseng export to China is facing a significant setback due to the collapse of the main buyer in Hong Kong in January. The collapse has left farmers like Peter VanBerlo with a $2.5 million worth of unsold ginseng, resulting in a devastating blow to the Canadian golden crop boom. The loss is attributed to the spectacular collapse of the buyer, which has left farmers in limbo, awaiting a new buyer to take over the shipment.

images.alt_text: Hang Fat grew to dominate the American ginseng trade, buying as much as 70% of Ontario's crop in recent years. But last year, the company suddenly stopped making payments.

site_title: Dozens of arrests in Egypt ahead of anti-government protest
summary: Egypt has arrested dozens of activists ahead of an anti-government demonstration planned for Monday, with 59 people detained since Thursday, according to a group of lawyers. The arrests are in protest of the government's deal to hand two Red Sea islands to Saudi Arabia, which has sparked outrage among many Egyptians. This comes after a large protest on April 15, where police fired tear gas to disperse demonstrators demanding the "fall of the regime."

images.alt_text: Egypt has arrested dozens of activists ahead of an anti-government demonstration planned for Monday, a group of lawyers said.

site_title: Google seeks to play down EU Android probe
summary: Google is facing an EU anti-trust probe over its dominance of the Android mobile phone operating system. The European Commission claims Google abuses its position by making manufacturers pre-install its search engine as the default, giving it unfair prominence. Google's Europe head, Carlo d'Asaro Biondo, downplays the investigation, saying it's "normal" and Google will seek to explain its system. The EU has accused Google of obstructing innovation and must respond within three months to avoid sanctions of up to $7.4 billion.

site_title: US drops NY fight with Apple after gaining access to iPhone
summary: The US Justice Department dropped its effort to force Apple to unlock an iPhone in a drug case in New York after someone provided the passcode to access the device. The case, which began after a similar effort to access an iPhone used in the San Bernardino killings was dropped, marked the second time the federal government has dropped a contentious fight over its power over private companies. Apple had argued that prosecutors had not provided evidence of other methods to get data from the phone, and the Justice Department stated that the case was not about setting a court precedent but about law enforcement's ability to access evidence.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff may appeal to Mercosur if impeached illegally
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff denounced her impeachment as a "coup" and said she would appeal to Mercosur if the democratic process is broken, potentially leading to Brazil's suspension from the bloc. Rousseff's impeachment process has polarized the country, with supporters viewing it as a "coup without weapons" and opponents saying it follows the law. If impeached, Rousseff will be suspended pending a trial and replaced by Vice-President Michel Temer, who has denied plotting against her. The impeachment process has thrown Brazil into its deepest political crisis since its return to civilian rule in 1985.

site_title: Trump assails Clinton, promises not to become boring
summary: Donald Trump attacked Hillary Clinton as "crooked" and promised not to become overly presidential, undercutting his aides' efforts to project a more serious image. Trump claimed Clinton has "many, many flaws" and said she relies on the "women card." Clinton did not respond to Trump's comments. Trump's win in New York boosted his chances for the Republican presidential nomination, and he will give a foreign policy speech at the National Press Club. Trump's rivals criticize his lack of foreign policy expertise, and some foreign leaders have expressed concerns about his candidacy.

site_title: Japan's justice minister visits Yasukuni shrine
summary: Japan's Justice Minister Mitsuhide Iwaki visited the Yasukuni shrine as part of a three-day spring festival, following Internal Affairs Minister Sanae Takaichi's visit a day earlier. The shrine honors Japan's war dead, including those convicted as Class A war criminals. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe made an offering on April 21. The visit has sparked protests from China and South Korea, who have long been sensitive to the shrine's content. Iwaki's visit is the latest in a series of high-profile visits by Japanese leaders to the shrine.

site_title: No signs of trauma, suicide in Prince death: police
summary: Prince's death at 57 has left the entertainment world in grief, with no signs of trauma or suicide found on his body. Authorities are investigating the cause of death, with preliminary autopsy results and toxicology scans taking weeks to complete. Despite reports of an overdose of painkiller Percocet, US authorities say there's no reason to believe it was a suicide. Fans worldwide are paying tribute to the music icon, with spontaneous celebrations and outpourings of tributes from the entertainment industry.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet misses Q1 targets for profit, revenue
summary: Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google, missed Q1 targets for profit and revenue due to rising costs and a strong US dollar. The company's shares fell 6% in late trading. The results were attributed to increased spending to build traffic for mobile advertising services.

site_title: MAS, CAD raids leave market guessing
summary: Singapore's MAS and CAD broking firms were raided by police on Wednesday, sparking speculation about which stocks were involved in the investigation. Despite speculation, no information was confirmed, and trading floors remained quiet. The absence of clear information kept traders from pulling any triggers.

site_title: McDonald's earnings surge as CEO hails turnaround
summary: McDonald's reported a 35.4% surge in net income to $1.1 billion in the first quarter, driven by strong US sales and improved customer service. The company's turnaround efforts, led by CEO Steve Easterbrook, have yielded sustained positive results, with the launch of all-day breakfast and the "McPick2" value promotion contributing to the growth. Global comparable sales rose 6.2%, with the US up 5.4%, and McDonald's plans to expand in China, Hong Kong, and South Korea over the next five years.

site_title: Russia suspends US$3b debt claim against Ukraine
summary: Russia has temporarily suspended its $3 billion debt claim against Ukraine, giving the new government time to assess the situation. The decision follows a request from Ukraine and takes into account current "political instability." The move comes after Moscow sued Ukraine in London over a 2013 loan, which Kiev views as private debt. The loan was issued before Ukraine's ousting of Moscow-backed president Viktor Yanukovych and was set to be repaid in 2027 under a previous restructuring deal.

site_title: Bahrain bank's appeal against Boustead gets thrown out
summary: The Singapore High Court has dismissed an appeal by Bahrain bank Arab Banking Corporation against engineering firm Boustead Singapore, ruling that Arab Bank acted fraudulently in making a demand for Boustead to pay US$18.8 million. The case, which began in 2007 over a S$300 million contract in Libya, was thrown out after a Court of Appeal decision on Thursday. Boustead shares fell half a cent to S$0.80 after the announcement.

site_title: Trade deal foes plan major German rally on eve of Obama visit
summary: Opponents of a proposed transatlantic trade deal plan a major rally in Hanover, Germany on Saturday, the eve of US President Barack Obama's visit. The rally aims to draw tens of thousands to protest the deal, which is intended to strengthen trade and create jobs in the US and EU. Obama reiterated his support for the deal, saying it will strengthen trade and create jobs, despite growing opposition. The visit is seen as an attempt to lend momentum to the deal's finalization this year.

site_title: Yen dives on report BoJ mulling support for banks
summary: The yen sharply weakened 2.1% against the dollar and 1.5% on the euro after reports emerged that the Bank of Japan is considering cutting interest rates on some loans to banks into negative territory. This move would support banks' earnings and stimulate the economy, reversing a trend that saw the yen reach its highest level against the dollar in 18 months. The news comes ahead of the BoJ's policy meeting, which aims to address the economy's lack of traction following deadly earthquakes.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Marine has been informed that its shareholders approved a resolution for Sete Brasil to file for judicial recovery, affecting seven drillship construction contracts. The company has made provisions of S$329 million and believes it has sufficient resources to deal with the current challenges. Sembcorp Marine's order book remains healthy, with a good pipeline of projects. The company will continue to monitor the situation and evaluate its implications.

site_title: Victoria to more than double property tax for foreign buyers
summary: The Australian state of Victoria will more than double a property tax for foreign buyers, increasing the stamp duty surcharge to 7% from 3% and a land surcharge on absentee owners to 1.5% from 0.5%. The move aims to address surging home prices in Melbourne, with home values rising 9.8% in the past year. The tax increase is expected to affect foreign buyers, including Chinese investors, who have driven demand in the country's largest cities.

site_title: Equities - the 'new safe option' for portfolios?
summary: Investors may be missing out on long-term growth potential by not taking risks, according to a new perspective on equities. Despite recent market fluctuations, historical data shows that equities have provided greater returns than bonds over the long term, with average annual growth of 4% since 1871 and 16.84% since 1800. A 30-year investment in US stocks from 1985 would have yielded a 7.9% real return. The key to managing risk is a long investment horizon, with shorter periods showing higher volatility. Investors should consider diversifying their portfolios to take advantage of equities' long-term potential.

site_title: Obama issues stark trade warning against Brexit
summary: US President Barack Obama warned Britain against leaving the European Union, stating that London would be "at the back of the queue" for a post-Brexit trade deal. This move was seen as undercutting eurosceptics' claims of Britain's ability to sign free trade deals with allies worldwide. Obama's comments, made during a press conference with British Prime Minister David Cameron, were met with a furious reaction from those campaigning to leave the EU, with Nigel Farage dismissing the president's remarks as hypocritical.

images.alt_text: Barack Obama warned Britain on Friday against leaving the European Union, undercutting a key argument of eurosceptics by saying London would be "at the back of the queue" for a post-Brexit trade deal.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to recall more than one million vehicles
summary: Fiat Chrysler announced a recall of over one million vehicles due to a safety issue where cars thought to be in "park" mode could move unexpectedly. The recall affects 2012-2014 Dodge Chargers and 2014-2015 Jeep Cherokees, with 41 reported injuries. The company will enhance the cars' warning and gear shift systems, despite existing protections such as warning chimes and alert messages. The affected models include 812,000 cars in the US, 52,150 in Canada, 16,800 in Mexico, and 248,670 in other countries.

site_title: Lessons from the Solar Impulse project
summary: The Solar Impulse project aims to fly a plane around the world without consuming fossil fuel. The project, inspired by ancient Greek myth Icarus, has demonstrated that renewables can provide reliable power day and night, a crucial step towards a clean energy future. As the project nears the end of its Pacific crossing, it has successfully overcome its biggest hurdle, showcasing the potential for renewable energy to power aviation.

images.alt_text: SOLAR IMPULSE 2: By pushing the boundaries of technology, and challenging conventional ideas of what is possible, we can run the world without consuming the earth.

site_title: Argentina pays 'vulture funds' to end debt saga
summary: Argentina has repaid $6.2 billion to settle disputes with 20 creditors, including hedge funds NML Capital and Aurelius Capital Management, in a long-standing debt saga. The payment ends a 15-year battle and restores Argentina's good standing on international credit markets. The country had defaulted on nearly $100 billion in debt in 2001, and the settlement paves the way for Argentina to re-enter the global financial community. The move is seen as a significant step forward for the Argentine economy, led by President Mauricio Macri, who took office vowing to settle the bitter debt dispute.

site_title: Uber to pay US$100m as part of settlement
summary: Uber has agreed to pay up to $100 million to settle a class-action lawsuit, resolving a challenge to its business model. The lawsuit claimed Uber drivers were employees, entitled to reimbursement of expenses. The settlement allows Uber to keep drivers as independent contractors, but includes changes to its business practices, such as deactivation policies for drivers. The payment includes $84 million guaranteed to drivers, with an additional $16 million contingent on a 150% increase in valuation within a year after an initial public offering.

site_title: HK expects sharp decline in tour groups from China
summary: Hong Kong expects a 40-50% decline in tour groups from China for the May 1 Labour Day holiday, with around 150 tours a day expected. This decline is attributed to cross-border tensions, overseas competition, and the weakening of the Hong Kong dollar. The city's tourism industry has seen a 40-50% fall in mainland tour groups in the last few months, with a low of 120 tours a day recorded recently.

site_title: US: Nasdaq falls on weak tech earnings; oil lifts Dow
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, with the Nasdaq tumbling 0.80% due to disappointing earnings from Alphabet and Microsoft, while the Dow and S&P 500 rose 0.12% and 0.01% respectively. Alphabet shares dropped 5.3% and Microsoft fell 7.1% after reporting earnings below expectations. However, oil prices lifted Dow members ExxonMobil and Chevron, contributing to the overall gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended at 18,004.84, while the S&P 500 reached 2,091.70.

site_title: Days numbered for skewed bank bonuses
summary: US regulators propose rules requiring Wall Street executives to wait at least four years to collect bonus pay, with some potentially returning money if their companies suffer significant losses. The ban on excessive risk-taking practices would primarily affect senior executives at firms with over $250 billion in assets. The National Credit Union Administration's long-delayed measures are part of the Dodd-Frank Act.

site_title: Serving up business advice and investments for Asian families
summary: Golden Equator Capital, a multi-family office firm, offers tailor-made solutions for Asian family businesses to pass on wealth to the next generation. Unlike Western-style wealth transfer, Asian clients often seek to help their children establish their own businesses, allowing them to learn about entrepreneurship and invest in areas they enjoy. The firm's CEO, Shirley Crystal Chua, believes this approach is distinctively entrepreneurial and helps clients ensure their children's involvement in business while preserving family wealth.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Leadership lessons from the edge
summary: Rachael Robertson, a former station leader in Antarctica, shares leadership lessons from her experience. She emphasizes the importance of respect over harmony, especially in diverse teams. Robertson's team used the "no triangles" rule to build trust and reduce conflict, and she stresses the need for leaders to stay visible and communicate effectively during crises. Her book, "Leading on the Edge," offers insights on creating a resilient and successful team in extreme environments. Robertson believes that leaders must be seen leading, communicate openly, and choose their words carefully to instill confidence in their team.

site_title: China eyes nuclear power platforms for S China Sea: report
summary: China is reportedly planning to build maritime nuclear power platforms in the South China Sea, sparking concerns over the region's disputed territories. The move, described as a step towards supporting Chinese projects in the area, has heightened tensions with neighboring countries. China claims most of the islands in the South China Sea for civilian purposes, but its military and construction activities have raised alarms. The development is seen as a significant escalation of China's assertive stance in the region.

site_title: Street food renaissance (Amended)
summary: The World Street Food Congress in Metro Manila has turned the city into a multicultural food paradise, attracting international vendors and food enthusiasts. The event showcased the diversity of street food traditions from around the world, with vendors from the Philippines, China, India, Indonesia, Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, and the US. The event highlighted the economic opportunities for local food entrepreneurs, with plans to develop the old city of Intramuros into a food destination. The growing appreciation for street food is seen as a way to promote local heritage and culture, with the government supporting initiatives to elevate the street food culture in the Philippines.

site_title: Kuroda may once again surprise yen bulls
summary: Haruhiko Kuroda, Bank of Japan governor, may surprise yen bulls by implementing additional stimulus at the April 27-28 policy meeting, potentially pushing bets on a stronger currency to the most on record. This could leave speculators vulnerable if Kuroda decides to reverse course. The move could also impact global markets and economies, particularly in Asia, as Japan's GDP growth is expected to slow.

images.alt_text: CAUSE FOR CONCERN: The yen has gained 9 per cent this year, endangering Mr Kuroda's efforts to stave off deflation.

site_title: Oil prices gain for third week in a row
summary: Oil prices rose for the third consecutive week, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate gaining 55 cents to $43.73 a barrel and Brent North Sea oil rising 58 cents to $45.11 a barrel. Opec officials said discussions on a production freeze could be revived, while the Baker Hughes weekly US rig count showed a decrease in drilling rigs. Analysts remain cautious, citing ongoing geopolitical tensions and concerns about the sustainability of higher oil prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices climbed on Friday, ensuring a third straight weekly gain for the commodity as Opec officials said discussions by producers to limit output could be revived.

site_title: Stock markets skid as car emissions saga widens
summary: Stock markets declined worldwide on Friday due to the ongoing car emissions saga. Volkswagen announced its first loss in 20 years, setting aside 16.2 billion euros for potential fines, lawsuits, and recall costs. Daimler, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, launched an internal investigation into exhaust emissions in the US. Mitsubishi Motors suffered a 40% decline in shares after admitting to cheating on fuel-efficiency tests. The European Central Bank's policy meeting also led to a decline in the euro against the dollar.

site_title: Changi Airport Group conducting new security screening technology trials
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) is conducting two-month trials on new security screening technologies, including an enhanced body-scanning machine using millimetre wave technology to detect metallic and non-metallic items. The system, which takes a few seconds to scan passengers, has been certified safe and is expected to improve efficiency. Trials for a new computed tomography (CT) security screening equipment and automated tray return system will commence in May. The goal is to enhance security screening and passenger experience, with data and feedback to be collected to assess the effectiveness of the new systems.

site_title: SPH iink Awards open for nominations
summary: The 12th annual SPH iink Awards, themed "Your Name in Lights," are now open for nominations. Organized by Singapore Press Holdings Limited, the awards recognize outstanding individuals in Singapore. No other key information is available in this article.

site_title: Retail rents fall further as vacancies creep up
summary: Retail rents in Singapore fell 1.9% in Q1, marking the fifth consecutive quarter of decline, due to weaker demand and increased supply. The vacancy rate rose to 7.3%, with Orchard Road seeing a 1.2 percentage point increase to a five-year high of 8.8%. Experts predict further declines, with Cushman & Wakefield estimating a 3-3.5% drop in Orchard Road rents and 4% in city-fringe rents this year.

site_title: Oil majors' US$100 hangover hurts profit as cost cuts fall short
summary: The world's largest oil companies are facing their worst quarterly earnings in over a decade due to the US$100 oil price, which has led to cost-cutting efforts that have not kept pace with the decline in crude prices. Despite deferring projects, eliminating jobs, and freezing salaries, the process of reducing costs will take three years. Companies such as Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron, and Exxon Mobil are expected to post adjusted losses, with Shell and Chevron likely to report their weakest adjusted profits in over a decade.

site_title: The minimalist cuisinier
summary: Michelin-starred chef Pascal Barbot credits his minimalist cooking style and focus on using the freshest ingredients for L'Astrance's success. Despite the restaurant's lack of pompous decor and menu, it has retained its three Michelin stars since 2007. Barbot emphasizes the importance of building relationships with suppliers and keeping the restaurant small, with only seven tables and 14 staff, to minimize stress and maximize quality. He also values simplicity and allowing diners to add condiments to his dishes, saying "I don't like to mess with the taste of the ingredient."

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: OCBC chairman fees in the spotlight
summary: OCBC's chairman Ooi Sang Kuang received a S$2.21 million salary, making it the highest among the three banks in Singapore. The bank defended the pay, stating it is commensurate with his responsibilities and time spent at the bank. The meeting also addressed the US$320 million acquisition of Barclays' wealth management business, which is expected to provide more inroads into the ultra-high-net-worth individuals segment. The meeting passed all resolutions, with the chairman offering assurance on issues such as credit exposure and the Barclays acquisition.

site_title: Asian financial firms wake up to Brexit risks, make contingency plans
summary: Asian financial firms are taking contingency plans amid growing concerns about Brexit's impact on their operations. The Hong Kong exchange has begun a Brexit impact assessment, and some asset managers are considering relocating to mainland Europe. Central banks of Hong Kong and Singapore are closely monitoring developments around the June 23 EU referendum.

site_title: Office rental decline accelerates
summary: Singapore's office rental index declined 2.1% in Q1 2016, a steeper drop than the 1.8% decline in Q4 last year, as the vacancy rate dropped to 9.2% from 9.5% in Q4 2015. A pipeline supply of over 1 million sq m of office space is expected to further accelerate vacancy rates, with Cushman & Wakefield predicting double-digit levels by year-end and Colliers International expecting average vacancy levels to rise above 15% from the second half of this year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Home away from home
summary: Audemars Piguet's flagship boutique in Singapore has reopened at Liat Towers, marking a significant investment in the region as one of the brand's largest points of sales worldwide. CEO François-Henry Bennahmias emphasizes the importance of customer outreach and long-term growth, with production limited to 40,000 units annually. The boutique features a unique design concept blending wood and metal, showcasing the brand's heritage and craftsmanship. The reopening coincides with the launch of the Royal Oak Offshore Diver Chronograph, a boutique-exclusive limited edition.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Banking & finance body rolls out revised standards for financial planners
summary: The Institute of Banking and Finance Singapore (IBF) has introduced revised standards for financial planning, aiming to provide a clear professional development roadmap and certification pathway for 18,000 to 20,000 financial planners in Singapore. The new standards cover core skills, financial planning for high net worth individuals and business owners, and ethical principles. The IBF standards will be integrated into existing certifications, such as the Certified Financial Planner (CFP) and Chartered Financial Consultant/Singapore (ChFC/S) qualifications, and will be eligible for advanced certification from 2016.

site_title: Need for speed
summary: Businessman Spencer Ong, a car collector and racing enthusiast, commissioned his designer to build a two-story corner terrace house with a spacious car porch that can fit 7-8 cars. The house, designed by Kelvin Bing, won two design awards and incorporates passive cooling features to keep the 4,100 sq ft home cool. Ong's love for speed and cars is evident, with a collection of racing trophies and model cars, and he often spends his weekends polishing and tinkering with his classic cars, including an MG TC and MC A. The house's design allows for cross ventilation and natural lighting, making it a unique and functional living space.

site_title: HDB resale prices in Q1 stay flat
summary: HDB resale prices in Q1 2016 remained flat, dipping 0.1% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. Despite a 10.9% decline in resale transactions to 4,449 cases, year-on-year transactions increased by 7.6%. Property consultants believe the market is at a new equilibrium, stabilizing due to price transparency and conservative buyer behavior. Resale volume is expected to exceed 20,000 units, with a slight decline of less than 1% in 2016.

site_title: Comprehensive cover offered for older cars by most insurers
summary: Comprehensive car insurance cover is generally available for vehicles over 10 years old in Singapore, although owners may face higher premiums. Insurers consider factors such as vehicle value and repair costs, rather than age alone. Some major insurers, like AXA and China Taiping, offer comprehensive coverage for older cars, while others, like NTUC Income, provide it on a case-by-case basis. Insurers argue that older cars often have limited market value, making comprehensive coverage less necessary.

images.alt_text: It may sometimes be on a case-by-case basis but comprehensive insurance cover for cars over 10 years of age is generally available, although motorists may be reluctant to pay the higher premium quoted.

site_title: SDP to launch social programme in Bukit Batok if Chee wins
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) plans to launch a social programme, "We Are One, We Are Bukit Batok", in Bukit Batok if its secretary-general Chee Soon Juan wins the by-election on May 7. The programme aims to provide financial and legal advice to residents in need. This initiative is part of the SDP's plan to build a well-run town with a strong community.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Global bazaar
summary: Global Food Bazaar Highlights Key Products and Trends. At Food & Hotel Asia 2016, various exhibitors showcased gourmet finds, organic products, and unique treats from around the world. Some notable products include organic green beans, gluten-free mayonnaise, dairy-free ice cream, frozen sushi, artisanal French olive oils, Japanese salt jellies, traditional soya sauce, and sweet tipplers such as umeshu, sake, and ice cider. New products launched in Singapore include Hungarian heritage items like canned goose liver and truffle-infused honey, and Mediterranean delights like Cypriot raw honey spreads and Italian soft nougats.

site_title: FBI paid more than US$1.3m to unlock iPhone
summary: The FBI paid over $1.3 million to a third-party company to unlock the iPhone of one of the San Bernardino shooters, exceeding the annual salary of FBI Director James Comey over the remaining 7 years and 4 months of his job. The agency's use of software to access the iPhone has sparked a debate over encryption and law enforcement access to information. The FBI has since unlocked the phone and dropped its case against Apple, but the broader fight over encryption remains unresolved.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust's DPU for first quarter down 5%
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.039 Singapore cents for the first quarter, down 5% from a year ago, primarily due to an enlarged units base. Gross revenue increased 32.7% year-on-year to S$27.9 million, while net property income (NPI) rose 12.0% to S$22.05 million. The trust's Australian portfolio contributed 13.8% of Q1 FY2016 gross revenue, with plans to expand its footprint in the country.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: TWG, its founder lose court case against OSIM
summary: The Singapore High Court dismissed all claims against OSIM International by The Wellness Group (TWG) and its chairman Manoj Murjani for oppressive conduct and conspiracy to injure. The court found TWG failed to prove its allegations, dismissing a counterclaim by OSIM and its founder Ron Sim. Additionally, a defamation claim by Murjani against OSIM and its directors was also dismissed.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Dish, Viacom sign deal, averting blackout
summary: DISH Network and Viacom have reached a multi-year agreement, averting a threatened blackout of Viacom's 18 channels, including MTV and Nickelodeon. The deal will keep these channels available to DISH's 14 million customers, while select content will also be added to DISH's Sling TV streaming service. Viacom's stock surged 10% following the news, while DISH shares remained flat. The agreement extends a nearly 20-year relationship between the companies and is seen as crucial for Viacom, which has faced business woes and uncertainty about its management.

site_title: Goodwood Park bakery suspended
summary: The Goodwood Park Hotel's bakery has been suspended by the National Environment Agency (NEA) after 76 cases of food poisoning were reported in relation to its durian pastries between March 15 and April 16. The NEA, Ministry of Health, and Agri-Food & Veterinary Authority of Singapore are jointly investigating the incidents. The suspension is a precautionary measure to ensure public safety.

images.alt_text: PRICKLY ISSUE: Apart from the suspension of its bakery's licence, Goodwood Park Hotel will also be required to cease the production, sale and distribution of all pastries that are prepared by its bakery.

site_title: Starbucks cafe sales up 6% in second quarter
summary: Starbucks reported a 6% increase in cafe sales in the second quarter, beating analysts' expectations, but missed forecasts in every region it operates in. Global sales rose 6% compared to the previous year, with 7% growth in the Americas and 3% in the China/Asia-Pacific region. The company narrowed its full-year profit forecast to $1.88-$1.89 per share, citing challenges in Europe and Japan. Despite the disappointing results, the stock traded near its all-time high of $62.57 after hours.

images.alt_text: CAFFEINE KICK: Analysts had expected an overall same-cafe sales gain of 6.7 per cent, according to Consensus Metrix.

site_title: Abterra auditors highlight concerns
summary: Abterra Ltd's auditors have issued a qualified opinion on the company's financial statement for fiscal 2015, citing material differences between the audited and unaudited accounts. The key issue lies in a $43.52 million deposit receivable from a third-party company, which may be impaired due to a change in security. The group's net loss and operating cash outflows also indicate significant doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern, raising concerns about its financial stability.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust is recommended to be sold by OCBC Investment Research due to a data centre gambit. Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. Meanwhile, retail investors are predicted to drive 'massive' ETF growth in Asia and Europe, according to Amundi. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, suggesting the worst of the trade war may be behind it. Productivity gains are seen as key to unlocking wealth creation, and de-dollarisation is a growing trend with shifting safe havens. Markets continue to rise despite these factors.

site_title: When it comes to music, Prince calls the tune
summary: Prince, the legendary musician, died at 57, leaving behind a legacy as a champion for artist rights. He was a trailblazer in the music industry, known for his control over his music and artistic freedom. Prince clashed with major labels, including Warner Bros, and eventually started his own label, NPG Records. He continued to break ground, releasing albums and experimenting with new platforms, including online music distribution. His influence can be seen in artists like Kanye West and Drake, who prioritize artistic control and experimentation. Prince's legacy is one of innovation and defiance in the face of industry restrictions.

site_title: China grabs biggest share of global exports
summary: China's exports rose to 13.8% of global exports in 2015, the highest share since the US in 1968, defying predictions of a decline due to rising costs and a strong currency. China's manufacturing infrastructure and ability to produce higher-value products have enabled firms to compete in sophisticated product lines. However, concerns remain over the country's industrial overcapacity and "import substitution" strategy, which may strain global trading relationships. The US and other countries have called for urgent action to address a steel supply glut attributed to China, while China's imports from other countries fell sharply in 2015.

site_title: Oil jumps more than 2%, heads for third week of gains
summary: Oil prices jumped over 2% on Friday, poised for a third week of gains, as market sentiment turned more upbeat amid signs of a global supply glut easing. Strong US gasoline consumption and declining production worldwide have driven investment in the sector. Market analysts believe the current rally is driven by a market sentiment that the worst is over and the global oil market is rebalancing.

site_title: Premiums not always higher for older cars
summary: Singapore's top motor insurers, MSIG and NTUC Income, do not charge higher premiums for cars over 10 years old. MSIG offers the same premium for a 9- and 10-year-old Toyota Corolla Altis, while NTUC Income's classic plan also does not differentiate between the two ages. In contrast, AXA charges a marginal 1.1% less premium for a 10-year-old car compared to a 9-year-old car. The General Association of Singapore notes that demand for comprehensive cover for older cars is generally low, leading owners to opt for third-party cover instead.

site_title: Stay and play for the hols
summary: BT Weekend highlights nearby resorts ideal for a family golf getaway as school holidays approach. Top recommendations include Nirwana Bali Golf Club in Bali, offering stunning ocean views and challenging holes, Bintan Lagoon Resort in Indonesia with two championship courses, and Joondalup Resort in Perth, Australia, featuring a tough layout with great variations in setting and style. Other notable mentions include Laguna Phuket Golf Club in Thailand, Sky Lake Resort & Golf Club in Vietnam, and The Bluffs Ho Tram Strip in Vietnam, all offering unique golfing experiences and resort amenities.

site_title: S'pore charges ex-banker with money laundering
summary: Singapore authorities have charged a former private banker, Yeo Jiawei, with money laundering, stemming from the probe into 1MDB's money flows. Yeo, a former wealth planner at BSI SA, was charged under Singapore's Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act, with possible jail time up to 10 years and a fine of up to S$500,000. The charges raise stakes in global inquiries into 1MDB, with international banks and Malaysian officials also examining claims of money misappropriation.

site_title: Europe stocks fall for 2nd day as Daimler leads carmakers lower
summary: European stocks fell for a second day, trimming a weekly advance, as carmakers led declines. Daimler AG dropped 5.6% after a quarterly operating profit drop, while Volkswagen AG lost 1.1% after more than doubling provisions related to its emissions scandal. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index lost 0.4% as profit-taking on recent gains outweighed the European Central Bank's stimulus program. Despite a rally in commodity and energy producers, analysts predict an earnings decline in 2016 for Stoxx 600 firms.

site_title: FCT posts 2.6% rise in second-quarter DPU
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 2.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.039 Singapore cents for the second quarter ended March 31, 2016, despite a 0.8% dip in gross revenue. The Reit manager attributed the growth to lower utility tariff rates and write-back of provisions for property tax. Tenant sales and shopper traffic rose 11.4% and 2.1% year-over-year, respectively, with suburban malls expected to remain resilient. FCT aims to improve average gross rents at Northpoint by 9% after completing a S$60 million asset enhancement initiative.

site_title: No financial stress over bridal dress
summary: The modern bride is shifting away from expensive, traditional wedding gowns, opting for more affordable and sustainable options. Brands like H&M, Net-a-Porter, and Asos are offering budget-friendly wedding dresses, with prices ranging from $154 to $1,318. Online stores like Rent A Dress and boutique labels like Needle & Thread are also providing affordable wedding wear, allowing brides to prioritize other expenses, such as honeymoons or everyday attire. This trend reflects a shift towards practicality and sustainability in wedding planning.

site_title: VW books deep loss, massive provisions in wake of engine-rigging scandal
summary: Volkswagen has set aside 16.2 billion euros in provisions to cover the costs of the global engine-rigging scandal. The charge pushed the company into a 1.582 billion euro loss in its 2015 accounts. This move comes as the German carmaker faces intense scrutiny and potential fines over the scandal.

images.alt_text: Embattled German carmaker Volkswagen said Friday it is setting aside 16.2 billion euros (S$24.64 billion) in provisions to cover the anticipated costs of the global engine-rigging scandal it is engulfed in.

site_title: Gem of a history
summary: Cate Blanchett attended the preview of Van Cleef & Arpels' exhibition "The Art & Science of Gems" at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore. The exhibition features over 400 jewellery pieces showcasing the brand's 100-year history, including transformable designs and pieces inspired by Eastern and Middle-Eastern cultures. The showcase also highlights the brand's innovative craftsmanship and deep understanding of mineralogical sciences. Notably, Blanchett wore a piece from the yet-to-be-released Bouton d'Or collection, which is set to be released soon.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: VW says cannot release dieselgate probe until DOJ deal struck
summary: Volkswagen said it cannot release preliminary findings from a probe into the emissions test cheating scandal until a deal is struck with the US Department of Justice. The investigation, conducted by lawfirm Jones Day, is nearing completion, but the company expects to release the findings once a final agreement is reached. Volkswagen agreed on a framework deal with the Justice Department, California, the EPA, and the FTC, as well as lawyers for car owners. The deal is expected to address the scandal's consequences, but the company's timeline for releasing the probe's findings remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen on Friday said it could not release preliminary findings from a probe examining what role senior executives played in an emissions test cheating scandal.

site_title: Much abrew at Owl
summary: Owl International, a 60-year-old Singaporean coffee firm, is rebranding itself as the first "complete" coffee company in Asia. The company, acquired by Super Group in 2003, has grown 20% year on year since its rebranding in 2014. Under the leadership of Richmond Te, the son of Super Group co-founder Ronald Te, Owl now occupies all parts of the coffee supply chain, from retailing to running its own cafes. The company is focusing on improving coffee quality and expanding into new markets, particularly in China, where demand for coffee is high despite economic conditions.

images.alt_text: ALL IN THE FAMILY: Mr Ronald Te (left), co-founder of Super Group, with his son Richmond, the assistant general manager of Owl International. Super Group acquired Owl International in 2003.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q3 DPU stays flat
summary: Starhill Global Reit's Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) remains unchanged at 1.26 Singapore cents, matching the same period last year. Revenue grew 12% to S$53.6 million, driven by Myer Centre Adelaide, while net property income (NPI) rose 7% to S$41.6 million. The Singapore portfolio contributed 61.7% of total revenue, but NPI fell 1.5% due to lower occupancy. The reit's chairman, Francis Yeoh, attributed the stable performance to vigilance and portfolio sharpening amidst a challenging retail environment.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: More big carmakers caught in headlights of VW scandal
summary: Volkswagen's supervisory board may set aside over 16 billion euros to cover fines, lawsuits, and recall costs related to the global engine-rigging scandal. This move comes as major carmakers, including Mitsubishi, are caught in the scandal. The provision would cover possible regulatory fines, lawsuits, and the cost of recalling or replacing suspect engines. VW's 2015 accounts are being approved, with the company facing significant financial implications from the scandal.

site_title: Palm oil industry fumes as Jakarta gets tough on forest fires
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has implemented a moratorium on using new land for palm oil production, aiming to boost yields of existing plantations and reduce deforestation. However, the move has been met with criticism from palm oil firms, who claim it could hurt Indonesia's top-producer position and lead to job losses. Industry sources suggest that smallholders, which account for 40% of Indonesia's output, will be particularly affected, and may be forced to sell land to bigger firms. The moratorium is seen as a step towards sustainable farming practices, but its effectiveness remains unclear.

site_title: US: Wall St flat as investors stay cautious
summary: US stock indexes remained flat on Friday, influenced by mixed quarterly reports from major companies. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.07%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.23%, and the Nasdaq composite declined 0.93%. Investors remained cautious, with investors continuing to monitor tariff uncertainty and potential US-EU trade talks. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged closer to fresh records.

site_title: Setting the pace
summary: The Jaguar F-Pace, the brand's first sport-utility vehicle, has been praised for its performance, comfort, and usability. With a sleek design influenced by the F-Type sports car, the F-Pace features a sporty stance, aluminum-intensive monocoque, and a range of powertrains. Its all-wheel drive capability with rear-wheel drive character provides a superb blend of handling and comfort, making it an exceptional performance crossover. The top-of-the-line 3.0 V6 Supercharged First Edition boasts impressive performance, including a 0-100 km/h time of 5.5 seconds and a top speed of 250 km/h.

site_title: Uber settles class action suit with US drivers
summary: Uber has agreed to pay up to $100 million to settle two class action suits filed by drivers who claimed to be employees entitled to benefits, rather than independent contractors. The settlement includes $84 million upfront and an additional $16 million if Uber goes public and reaches a certain market capitalization. Uber will also create a driver's association in California and Massachusetts, providing funding and quarterly meetings to discuss driver issues. Drivers will remain independent contractors, but the agreement aims to address their concerns.

site_title: Private home prices in muted fall: URA index
summary: Singapore's private home prices have eased 9.1% over the past 10 quarters, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) index. The index fell 0.7% in Q1, with prices in the Core Central Region (CCR) and city-fringe areas showing resilience. The rental market also declined 1.3% in Q1, with some predicting a faster drop in the leasing market. Experts expect a possible 2.5-4% decline in private home prices and a 5-8% drop in rental prices this year, citing an oversupply of completed homes and a weakening economy.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Germany raises glass to 500th anniversary of beer purity law
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel celebrated the 500th anniversary of Germany's purity law for beer, the "Reinheitsgebot," in Ingolstadt. The law, enacted in 1516 by Bavaria, requires beer to be made only with barley, hops, and water. Although no longer a law, it remains an important tradition for many brewers. Merkel raised a beer glass at a celebratory event, where a special beer fountain was unveiled, amidst traditional costumes and clinking glasses. The Reinheitsgebot is still regarded as a guideline for traditional German beer-making.

site_title: HSBC overhauls pay policies, warns of Brexit impact
summary: HSBC Holdings is revamping its pay policy for executive directors in response to shareholder concerns. The bank proposes reducing the cash given to directors in lieu of a pension from 50% to 30% of base salary and making long-term incentives subject to a three-year performance period. This change aims to lower the maximum earnings of executive directors by 7%. The overhaul follows investor revolts at BP and Anglo American, and HSBC also warned that Brexit could force restructuring of its wholesale operations in the UK.

site_title: Flocking to the food
summary: Thousands attended the World Street Food Congress (WSFC) in Metro Manila, drawn to 25 food vendors serving traditional and regional Filipino cuisine, as well as international street food from Singapore, Malaysia, and China. The event featured dishes such as satay, duck rice, and seafood tempura, as well as regional Filipino specialties like Pasta Bicolandia and spicy paella lechon. The congress runs until Sunday, with free entry and food starting from 200 Philippine pesos, but food sells out hours before closing time.

images.alt_text: MASS DRAW: The promise of the good and yummy served by 25 food vendors from Manila, around the Philippines and the world has been drawing thousands to the WSFC jamboree.

site_title: Linc Energy's CFO and COO quit
summary: Linc Energy's CFO Chris Munday and COO Michael Mapp are resigning due to the company's restructuring process, which follows voluntary administration. Their resignations, effective immediately, will be assisted by the administrators on a contract basis before pursuing other opportunities. This comes as the company navigates a challenging period, one week after entering voluntary administration.

site_title: ECB chief dismisses talk of scrapping cash
summary: European Central Bank president Mario Draghi has dismissed concerns that phasing out the 500-euro note would lead to the scrapping of cash. In a letter to Fabio De Masi, Draghi stated that any possibility of ending cash note issuance is unrelated to a discussion about limiting or abolishing cash payments. The remarks come after criticism in Germany prompted by the planned phasing out of the note and low interest rates.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank president Mario Draghi sought to soothe concerns on Friday that any phasing out of the 500-euro note would lead to the scrapping of cash.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,717.96 after 1.64 billion lots were traded. The index slipped 3.51 points, with 378 gainers and 396 losers.
