Despite the loss of its star architect, the firm aims to prove itself as a viable and vibrant address for major cultural projects, with a significant pipeline of work and new office openings in cities like New York and Dubai.

images.alt_text: Mr Schumacher says "we want to tell the world we're still a viable, vibrant address for major work of cultural importance".

site_title: France's biggest carmaker PSA Group raided by fraud squad in emissions probe
summary: France's PSA Group, maker of Peugeot and Citroen cars, had its premises raided by France's anti-fraud squad as part of a probe into emissions. The raid comes three months after a similar probe at Renault, amid a global emissions scandal involving Volkswagen, Mitsubishi, and other car manufacturers. PSA Group denies any wrongdoing and claims to comply with pollutant emissions regulations worldwide. The probe is part of a government drive to shed light on emissions practices by car manufacturers, following Volkswagen's admission of installing software to mask emissions levels.

site_title: 45 Taiwanese fraud suspects to be tried in China: state media
summary: China has announced it will try 45 Taiwanese citizens deported from Kenya on charges of participating in a telephone fraud network. The suspects, who have admitted their guilt, will face prosecution and trial in China, not Taiwan. China views Taiwan as one of its provinces awaiting reunification, and the move is seen as pressure on Taiwan's president-elect, Tsai Ing-wen, who is set to take office in May. The case is part of China's efforts to strengthen its authority over Taiwan.

site_title: GIC announces senior appointments (Amended)
summary: The Government Investment Corporation (GIC) of Singapore has announced several senior leadership appointments to strengthen its investment capacity. Lim Chow Kiat will become deputy group president and CIO, while Jeffrey Jaensubhakij will remain as president of Public Markets and become deputy CIO. Other new appointments include Ang Eng Seng as CIO for Infrastructure, Choo Yong Cheen as CIO for Private Equity, Lee Kok Sun as CIO for Real Estate, and Liew Tzu Mi as CIO for Fixed Income. The new appointments take effect on June 1.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Lights, camera, online action!
summary: A startup called 90 Seconds aims to connect users with film industry creatives worldwide, offering on-demand video production services. Founded by Tim Norton, the platform allows users to browse and hire professionals for various video projects, from simple shoots to complex productions. With over 1,000 companies using the platform, 90 Seconds has raised $10 million in funding and aims to revolutionize the video production industry by making it more accessible and efficient.

site_title: CDL heading to Indonesia to promote Gramercy Park
summary: CDL is holding roadshows in Jakarta to promote its freehold condominium project Gramercy Park in Singapore's District 10, targeting regional markets including China and Hong Kong. The project, which includes 174 units, will be launched soon with pricing to be released to agents soon. CDL has appointed marketing agents to promote the project in regional markets, despite suggesting it may offload one of the towers through a bulk sale. The move aims to capitalize on the tax amnesty plan in Indonesia, which encourages wealthy individuals to invest in the country.

site_title: France to hold May meeting on Israel-Palestinian peace process
summary: France will host a May 30 meeting of 20 countries' ministers to relaunch the Israel-Palestinian peace process, excluding Israel and Palestine. The meeting aims to prepare an international summit later in 2016. Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault emphasized the need for a two-state solution, with Jerusalem as a shared capital, citing the 2002 Saudi peace initiative. The initiative calls for Israel's withdrawal from occupied Palestinian territory in exchange for normalization of ties with Arab countries. The French proposal has received a guarded welcome from US Secretary of State John Kerry, who believes international support is needed to resolve the conflict.

images.alt_text: France will host a meeting of ministers from 20 countries on May 30 to try and relaunch the Israel-Palestinian peace process, foreign minister Jean-Marc Ayrault announced on Thursday.

site_title: Chee pledges to press the govt to be 'more sensitised' to citizens' concerns
summary: SDP chief Chee Soon Juan is gearing up for a by-election in Bukit Batok, challenging PAP MP Murali Pillai. Chee pledges to press the government to be more sensitized to citizens' concerns, particularly retirees and retrenched workers. He plans to speak up for these groups and promises to be transparent and accountable in running the town council. The SDP will hold a press conference to reveal its plans, and Chee will target his approach to communicate the party's messages to voters in the constituency.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Clinton criticizes US gun lobby on campaign trail
summary: Democratic presidential frontrunner Hillary Clinton criticized the US gun lobby, calling their arguments "absolutely indefensible" and an "organized effort" to intimidate and silence those who advocate for gun control. Clinton proposed comprehensive gun safety reform and better mental health treatment, but stopped short of proposing specific reforms. She praised President Barack Obama's executive actions, promising to implement them if elected, but declined to say how far she would go in seeking to implement gun control. Clinton leads among Democratic voters in Connecticut, but trails Bernie Sanders nationally by 1.4 percentage points.

images.alt_text: Democratic frontrunner for US president Hillary Clinton strongly criticized the gun lobby Thursday while meeting families of shooting victims days before the next round of primary elections.

site_title: Revisiting the financial markets
summary: Industry veterans Ng Kok Song and Robert Parker predict that fixed-income investments are no longer a safe bet due to low yields. They advise looking at corporate bonds with attractive yields and manageable risk, particularly in Asia's rapidly developing corporate bond market. Parker also revises his stance on China, calling it a relatively cheap market with reasonable valuations and predicting a long-term slowdown rather than a hard landing.

site_title: NEC, SMRT Buses to try out new technologies
summary: NEC Asia Pacific and SMRT Buses are set to unveil state-of-the-art technologies at the Woodlands Temporary Bus Interchange in Singapore. The Living Lab concept will showcase the fusion of IoT, video analytics, and SDN solutions to provide real-time information to commuters. Features include interactive information panels, bus route and fare information, and virtual assistance. Video analytics will be used for safety and security, while SDN solutions will manage the IT system. The implementation is part of a long-term collaboration between NEC and SMRT, which has already introduced Singapore's first telematics system in 2014.

site_title: Oil market, prices to return to balance by 2017: IEA chief
summary: International Energy Agency (IEA) chief Fatih Birol expects the oil market to balance by 2017, provided there is no major economic downturn. Low oil prices have reduced investment by 40% in the past two years, particularly in the US, Canada, and Latin America. The world's reliance on Middle East oil is expected to accelerate, while OPEC's trimmed oil demand forecast for the next four years suggests a gradual return to balance.

site_title: Mitsubishi pushed to brink by manipulated fuel economy tests
summary: Mitsubishi Motors Corp. has admitted to manipulating fuel economy tests for its minicars, with the company's president stating that the fuel efficiency of 625,000 vehicles was exaggerated by up to 10%. This revelation risks putting the company back in a financially vulnerable position, with possible tax rebate repayments, lawsuits, and government penalties. Mitsubishi Motors has a history of scandals and has received multiple bailouts from the Mitsubishi group. The company's low cash reserves and stretched financial resources make it vulnerable to further financial strain.

site_title: First batch of personal data offenders slapped with fines, warnings
summary: Eleven Singaporean organisations, including Challenger Technologies and Metro, have been fined or warned for breaching data protection obligations under the Personal Data Protection Act. K BOX Entertainment Group received the largest fine of S$50,000 for failing to secure its members' data, while Finantech Holdings and the Institution of Engineers Singapore were also fined S$10,000 each. Six organisations received warnings for handling personal data lapses. The Personal Data Protection Commission emphasized the importance of safeguarding personal data as commercially sensitive information, following 667 complaints and 34% of cases resolved through investigations.

site_title: Merger maestro Wee Cho Yaw cautious on acquisitions
summary: UOB chairman emeritus Wee Cho Yaw expressed caution on mergers, citing difficulties in acquiring growth and managing liabilities. He noted that UOB is growing organically and has a strong Asean network. CEO Wee Ee Cheong added that size is not everything, and volatility is expected to continue, with a slowdown in growth rather than a crisis. The bank is confident in managing asset quality and credit costs. Despite being the smallest of the Singapore trio, UOB is growing in line with the industry.

site_title: American Copper Buildings almost done
summary: The American Copper Buildings, a two-towered development on Manhattan's East Side, is nearing completion with the installation of copper panelling. The buildings, designed by SHoP Architects and developed by JDS Development Group, will feature 761 rental apartments, including 20% affordable housing. The distinctive copper cladding, reminiscent of the Barclays Center, will age to a vibrant green. The buildings will also feature a three-story skybridge with a lap pool, hot tub, and private terraces, offering residents a unique living experience. Completion is expected soon, with the skybridge still open to the elements.

site_title: 2016 equities: watch the E's and R's
summary: Key economic factors in 2016 will be defined by the "E's" (energy prices, earnings, and economy) and the "R's" (rates, recovery, and referendum on Brexit). Energy prices have been volatile, with a rebound to above $40 per barrel helping stocks recover, but the market's focus has shifted to earnings and the economy. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in June, and a British exit from the EU is a 50-50 probability, with potential economic consequences. A contracting world economy raises the spectre of recession, and investors should be cautious of heightened uncertainty.

site_title: Fingerprint sensor firms unlocking new markets beyond smartphones
summary: Fingerprint sensor firms, particularly Sweden's Fingerprint Cards (FPC), are expanding into new markets beyond smartphones. FPC expects biometric smart cards to become its fastest-growing market by 2018, driven by increasing demand for fingerprint identification. The company aims to maintain its market value of around $4.1 billion, but analysts question the technology's widespread adoption, with some predicting it may take 5-10 years. FPC forecasts a total addressable market of 500 million sensors in 2018 and plans to discuss smart card projects with potential clients.

site_title: Good governance back in focus after recent scandals
summary: Recent scandals have shifted investor focus back to corporate governance, with valuations now closely tied to good governance. Credit Suisse's John Woods emphasizes the importance of better resource allocation. This renewed emphasis on governance comes as companies like Volkswagen and Mitsubishi face scrutiny.

site_title: China Aviation Oil Q1 profit up 68%
summary: China Aviation Oil Singapore's (CAO) net profit rose 68.2% to US$24.1 million in Q1, driven by higher trading gains despite a 29.6% decline in revenue due to lower oil prices. The company traded 4.9 million tonnes of jet fuel, a 21.7% increase from the previous year. CAO's share of associate and joint venture results also rose 52% to US$14.2 million. The company's CEO attributed the strong performance to its diversified and international growth platform, which will continue to proactively source for M&A opportunities to drive growth.

site_title: Crystal City, once cast off by Washington, reinvents itself
summary: Crystal City, a once-thriving Arlington, Virginia neighborhood, has been revitalized after being cast off by the federal government due to budget cuts. The area, which lost 17,000 jobs after the closure of military agencies and contractors, is now attracting residents and younger workers with competitive rents and convenient transportation options. Retrofitted buildings are being converted into apartments and co-working spaces, and new businesses, including tech startups and restaurants, are moving in. The revitalization is seen as a success, with the goal of making Crystal City a living laboratory for innovation and a diverse environment.

images.alt_text: "We feel very strongly that Crystal City has been a sleeper, in that it has been a federal enclave people always assumed would perform because it's across the street from the Pentagon," Mr Thompson said.

site_title: Stronger US$, bad luck cause MBS to post lower Q1 earnings
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) reported a 34% drop in year-on-year profit to US$274.9 million for Q1 FY16, primarily due to a strong US dollar and bad luck with VIP gamblers. Adjusting for currency and bad luck, earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation would have risen 10.3%. Total revenue declined 23% to US$603.7 million, mainly due to lower casino revenue and a weaker Singapore dollar. Despite this, MBS broke revenue records on its mass gaming floor.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Size doesn't quite matter any more
summary: A Credit Suisse report found that small countries tend to have more resilient and open economies, outperforming larger peers. This is due to their increased exposure to global economic changes. Examples include Singapore and Switzerland, which have thrived economically, while larger countries like China and the US face slower growth. Small countries serve as a test bed for economic trends, and their capital markets have outperformed those of larger countries in the long term. This trend reflects the higher growth attained by small countries during globalization.

site_title: Brexit is in the best interests of both Britain and Europe
summary: A financial expert argues that the UK's decision to leave the EU (Brexit) is in the best interests of both Britain and Europe. The author believes the EU's flaws, including a flawed single currency and democratic deficit, have hindered its ability to reform and that the UK's departure will allow it to align with more dynamic trading nations. The author notes that the UK's attempts to renegotiate its EU arrangements have been unsuccessful, and that the EU is unlikely to achieve significant reforms in the near future.

site_title: Hurtling into an adult's world
summary: The Diary of a Teenage Girl, a 2016 coming-of-age drama, follows 15-year-old Minnie Goetz (Bel Powley) as she navigates her newfound adulthood in 1970s San Francisco. After losing her virginity, Minnie explores her body and sexuality without parental guidance, forming relationships and facing consequences. Writer-director Marielle Heller's film is a refreshingly honest and assured portrayal of adolescence, infused with quirkiness and psychedelic animation. Despite some cliches, the film is a strong impression, thanks to Powley's committed performance, authentic period details, and Heller's knowing direction.

site_title: Laugh-a-minute with McCarthy
summary: Melissa McCarthy stars in The Boss, her latest comedy film, which follows her character's journey to reclaim her company. The movie, directed by Ben Falcone and written by the couple, showcases McCarthy's comedic talent. With a string of successful films like The Heat and Spy under her belt, McCarthy continues her mission to conquer the comedy world, solidifying her status as a leading female comedian. The Boss is largely an extension of her previous work, relying on McCarthy's signature humor to drive the plot forward.

images.alt_text: McCarthy's latest outing is largely indistinguishable from her other comedic forays and involves nothing more complicated than putting her in front of the camera and letting her do her funny schtick.

site_title: Life begins at 74 for Graham Nash
summary: Graham Nash, 74, has released his sixth solo album, "This Path Tonight," after a 14-year hiatus. The album, recorded with CSN's touring guitarist Shane Fontayne, was inspired by his recent divorce and new relationship with artist Amy Grantham. Nash, a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductee, says he's feeling "all fired up again" and is already working on his next album, eager to continue his creative streak after his autobiography, "Wild Tales: A Rock & Roll Life," left him feeling wistful.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Says Nash: "Music affects the soul in a very direct and strong way; and using it to spread ideas is a wonderful way of communication."

site_title: Adelson thinking about selling MBS retail assets next year
summary: Gaming tycoon Sheldon Adelson is considering selling Marina Bay Sands' retail assets in Singapore after a government-imposed moratorium expires next year. Adelson has spoken with potential buyers, citing attractive capitalization rates for the 800,000 square foot mall. The decision comes as Las Vegas Sands reported a profit decline due to a sharp drop in gambling revenue at its Macau unit. Adelson has stated that his company always looks to monetize non-core assets, but a casino license in Singapore won't allow it until 2017.

site_title: Malaysia pension fund to start RM100b Islamic savings plan
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) plans to launch a Syariah-compliant Islamic savings plan worth up to RM100 billion in January 2017. The plan is expected to attract 1.5 million of its 6.7 million members, with 60% of the population being Muslims. The move aims to comply with Islamic finance principles, which prohibit interest payments and restrict investments to Shariah-compliant bonds and shares. EPF expects the plan to complement existing private Islamic retirement plans and strengthen Malaysia's position as a global Syariah hub.

site_title: STI continues to track Wall St futures
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 10.83 points to 2,960.78 on Thursday, driven by a 20-point gain in Dow futures. Average turnover was 1.4 billion units worth S$1.2 billion, with 271 rises and 129 falls. Banks had a mixed performance, with DBS and UOB closing lower and OCBC rising. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally.

site_title: Stress still top health risk for S'pore companies: survey
summary: Singaporean companies cite stress as the top health risk, affecting 56% of employers. Despite 44% offering health programs, these have limited impact due to lack of measurement. Local companies are shifting focus to data-driven approaches and employee choice, using technology to promote healthier lifestyles and workplace culture. Concluding that a holistic and customized approach is necessary, experts emphasize the need for employers to align health programs with overarching strategies to change long-term employee behavior.

site_title: Tokyo interior design and real estate companies cater to cat lovers
summary: Tokyo interior design and real estate companies cater to the growing number of cat lovers in Japan, offering custom housing solutions for both humans and pets. Companies like Wan-nyan Kenko Jutaku Kenkyujo design office and Misawa Homes Co. provide catwalks, guards for windows and entrances, and special features such as bay windows and scratch-resistant wallpaper. The trend is driven by the increasing popularity of cat ownership in Japan, with many people seeking rental homes that allow pets. As a result, websites like neko-beya.com have emerged to cater to cat owners, offering a range of pet-friendly housing options.

site_title: In riposte to Riyadh, Russia says it is prepared to ramp up oil output
summary: Russia is prepared to increase oil production to 12-13 million barrels per day (bpd), a historic high, amid the collapse of a global oil output freeze deal and Saudi Arabia's threat to flood markets with more crude. This move comes as Venezuela predicts a potential price crash if producers fail to resume dialogue. Russia's Energy Minister Novak made the announcement, which could exacerbate the oversupply issue.

site_title: PBOC rates seen on hold until fourth quarter
summary: China's central bank is expected to keep its one-year lending rate on hold until the fourth quarter, when it will be lowered to 4.1% to support stabilizing economic growth. Economists predict the rate will remain at 4.35% through the third quarter. Despite a slowdown in borrowing and debt, growth is expected to stabilize at 6.5% in the fourth quarter, with inflation rising to 3% by the end of the year. The People's Bank of China is signaling a less aggressive approach to monetary policy, prioritizing fiscal support over further rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Mr Zhou said that the economy had a good start to the year and the fundamentals will remain sound in the long run.

site_title: Rise in local prices sees China steel mills ramp up output
summary: China's steel mills have ramped up production despite a global glut, with prices rising 77% this year due to tighter supplies, restocking, and seasonal demand. "Zombie" mills, which halted production, have been revived, and over 40 million tonnes of capacity have been brought back online. China's steel output reached a record high in March, contradicting the government's claims of reducing capacity. Analysts say the rise in prices has boosted profit margins, but the government's supply-side reform efforts remain unresolved, leaving the country in a dilemma.

site_title: Q1 deals may signal market for Good Class Bungalows looking up
summary: Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market may experience a pick-up in transaction volumes this year, driven by lower price expectations by owners and pent-up demand. In Q1, nine properties were transacted for S$209 million, a significant increase from Q1 last year. Agents predict 30-35 GCB sales this year, with some foreseeing a 5% price growth and others a 2-5% drop before prices stabilize. The market's recovery is attributed to buyers' fear of missing out on a desirable property, coupled with the economic slowdown and lower price expectations by owners.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Euro rises as ECB's Draghi surprises traders
summary: The euro rose to a session high of $1.1398, a 0.9% gain, after European Central Bank president Mario Draghi expressed optimism about inflation and the economy. Draghi predicted inflation would pick up in the second half of 2016 and improve through 2017-2018, supporting the euro's value. The euro was also boosted by worse-than-forecast US outlook data. The currency has risen 3% since the last ECB decision in March, driven by the Federal Reserve's gradual approach to policy tightening.

site_title: High hopes for landmark trade pact
summary: A former US diplomat, John Negroponte, says the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) has a good chance of being ratified in the US despite opposition from presidential candidates. Negroponte stated that there is a window of opportunity during the lame duck period after the elections and before the new Congress takes office to pass the pact. This contradicts the negative rhetoric from presidential candidates who argue that globalization and free trade agreements harm US jobs. Negroponte's comments suggest that the TPP may still be viable for ratification.

site_title: Jack Ma pledges not to interfere in SCMP editorial independence
summary: Hong Kong's South China Morning Post, now owned by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, has pledged editorial independence under new owner Jack Ma. In an interview, Ma stated he will not interfere in editorial decisions, assuring objective, fair, and balanced coverage of China. Critics had raised concerns about potential influence or alignment with the Chinese government. Ma emphasized the importance of media objectivity and allowing readers to see China from multiple perspectives. Despite this, Alibaba completed its $266 million purchase of the SCMP in December.

site_title: HSBC faces pay pressure and dividend fears from investors
summary: HSBC faces pressure from investors at its annual meeting in London, with concerns over dividend sustainability, Chinese expansion, and succession planning. Investor advisory firm PIRC urges shareholders to reject the bank's pay plans and oppose Chairman Douglas Flint's re-election, citing a high probability of dividend cuts. Shareholders also question the bank's capital-intensive expansion and compliance bill, and have given a lukewarm reception to a proposal to buy back shares.

site_title: Pteris majority shareholder launches privatisation bid
summary: China International Marine Containers (CIMC) has launched a takeover bid for Singapore-listed airport support equipment provider Pteris Global, aiming to delist the company. CIMC, which controls 54.34% of Pteris, is offering S$0.735 in cash for each share it does not already own, a 16% premium over Pteris' last traded price. However, CIMC expects to fall short of the 90% threshold needed to compulsorily acquire remaining shares, and a minority shareholder has irrevocably rejected the offer, limiting the bid's impact.

site_title: ECB stimulus working, maintains Draghi
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi urged critics to give the bank's stimulus measures time to produce their effect, stating "our policies work, they are effective - just give them time." The ECB maintained record-low interest rates and asset purchases, and Draghi emphasized the need for structural reforms to boost economic growth and drag inflation out of the doldrums. He also warned that if conditions worsen, the ECB will step up stimulus, preserving "an appropriate degree of monetary accommodation."

site_title: City buzz
summary: British singer-songwriter Jamie Lawson achieved global success after being signed to Ed Sheeran's Gingerbread Man Records, with his self-titled album debuting at the top of the UK charts. Lawson's hit single "Wasn't Expecting That" was re-released after Sheeran suggested it. Lawson will perform in Singapore next week. Meanwhile, a playwriting programme called Boiler Room 2016 is available for those interested in writing a script. A Shakespeare in the Park production of Romeo & Juliet is set to run from April 27 to May 22. The Gaumont film exhibition and retrospective is also on display until May 15.

site_title: Australian banks unveil reforms in wake of scandals
summary: Australia's four major banks, National Australia Bank, Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, and ANZ Banking Group, have announced unprecedented reforms to protect consumers and boost transparency following scandals. The reforms include reviewing product sales commissions, supporting whistle-blower employees, and removing individuals from the industry for poor conduct. The package aims to make it easier for customers to do business with banks, particularly when things go wrong. The reforms come ahead of a federal election and are subject to regulatory approval or legislative reform, with an independent expert overseeing the process.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Mediacorp's former CEO Ernest Wong will become the company's new chairman-designate, succeeding Teo Ming Kian at the annual general meeting in July. Wong previously served as group CEO from 2000 to 2005 and chairs Temasek Holdings' unit Fullerton Financial Holdings.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q1 DPU up with help from Park Mall sale
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 6.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.371 Singapore cents for its Q1 2016, despite divesting Park Mall. Distributable income rose 7.2% to S$60 million, driven by the opening of Suntec City mall and higher revenue from office and exhibition spaces. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) increased 5.2% and 5.1%, respectively. The Reit manager expects stable office performance and a "mixed bag" of rental reversion results in retail.

site_title: Sailing on a new wave of technology
summary: Smart ships are integrating advanced technology to improve efficiency, safety, and reliability. These intelligent vessels utilize sensors and data analytics to optimize energy consumption, reduce downtime, and enhance asset value. However, the increased reliance on technology also raises concerns about cyber threats, which can impact maritime operations and navigation. Industry players are taking steps to mitigate these risks through crew awareness training, secure network encryption, and systematic approaches to software upgrades.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Marine engineers commissioning state-of-the-art control and monitoring systems onboard a semi-submersible rig. Equipped with advanced sensor and automation features, these systems ensure safe, efficient and reliable drilling operations.

site_title: Firms' response to new competition a baffling mixture
summary: The Obama administration has launched an initiative to promote competition, citing concerns that US businesses are merging too often, innovating too little, and bilking consumers. The administration points to a recent surge in proposed mergers valued over $10 billion and has rejected several deals, including AT&T and T-Mobile, and Halliburton and Baker Hughes. However, experts argue that the definition of competition is complex, with some industries experiencing Schumpeterian competition, where new products and techniques disrupt existing markets, while others are seeing a decline in start-up businesses and increased market concentration among the top 50 firms.

site_title: India crime agency wants UK to deport liquor baron Mallya
summary: India's financial crimes agency, the Enforcement Directorate, is seeking the deportation of liquor baron Vijay Mallya from the UK, where he is believed to be hiding after leaving India owing over $1 billion. Mallya, a former airline boss, was issued an arrest warrant last week for failing to appear before investigators into the finances of Kingfisher Airlines. The agency has written to the foreign ministry for assistance in the deportation process, which is expected to be decided within the next few days. Mallya's passport has already been suspended.

site_title: 1MDB coupon payment deadline looms amid IPIC row
summary: A $50 million coupon payment on a 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) bond is due this weekend, with 1MDB stating Abu Dhabi sovereign fund International Petroleum Investment Company (IPIC) has assumed responsibility for making the payment. The payment was due on Monday, amid a dispute between the two state firms over obligations. IPIC had agreed to pay interest in exchange for certain undertakings, but last week cancelled a deal to provide $1 billion in cash and assume $3.5 billion in 1MDB debt. 1MDB's bond, due in 2022, has been rattled by the events, but the company says it will meet its other obligations.

site_title: More hi-tech than ever
summary: Commercial shipping has adapted to market developments and regulatory requirements over the past five years, incorporating key technological advancements. Advanced merchant vessels feature intelligent ship technologies that enable autonomous operations for improved efficiency and reliability. These technologies include autonomous systems, advanced navigation, and data analytics. The integration of these technologies has optimized ship performance, but the article does not provide further details on the specific technologies or their impact.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) upgraded to S$9.04 by RHB Research, citing momentum in volume growth from its cash and derivatives businesses. CIMB Research downgraded to S$7.16, citing unsustainable securities revenue growth and margin pressure in derivatives. SATS maintained an "accumulate" call with a target price of S$4.17, driven by strong growth from resumption of service to Jetstar Asia and completion of major projects.

site_title: S'pore must take sustainability reporting bull by the horns
summary: Singapore's Singapore Exchange (SGX) is moving towards mandatory sustainability reporting for listed companies, with a comply-or-explain ruling expected soon. The move aims to bridge the gap between companies and investors seeking transparency on environmental and social issues. The initiative follows a series of government and regulatory changes, including the Association of Banks in Singapore's guidelines on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors. SGX has engaged stakeholders, including small and medium-size enterprises, in the process, and 90% of institutional investors take ESG factors into account when investing. Only 30 of 170 Singapore-listed companies have reported ESG information, lagging behind Malaysia, Thailand, and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: An Indonesian child's appeal for help during last year's haze, which hit the region hard with the burning in the peatlands and poor environmental management. Everyone just wanted to get to the bottom of the burning issue, and that got the sustainability ball rolling.

site_title: Chinese moviefest fetes short films
summary: Singapore Chinese Film Festival has expanded its short films segment, featuring the award-winning Hong Kong drama "Ten Years." The low-budget, dystopian drama, which won Best Film at the 35th Hong Kong Film Awards, premiered at the 10-day event. Made on a shoestring budget of HK$600,000, "Ten Years" explores the erosion of human rights in Hong Kong as the mainland Chinese government exerts its influence. The film was a domestic box-office hit despite limited screens and continues to be screened through guerrilla screenings.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Narratives in motion
summary: Contemporary dance has evolved beyond traditional rhythmic movement, incorporating storytelling and drama. Four productions showcase this progression: "Under the Volcano," a dance theatre piece exploring natural disasters in Indonesia, "Dancing with Death," a Thai folk dance performance capturing the spirit of the Phi Ta Khon festival, "Helix," a double bill featuring T.H.E. Dance Company's founder Kuik Swee Boon and associate artist Zhou Zi Hao, and "Sleeping Beauty," a reimagined ballet by British choreographer Matthew Bourne. These productions demonstrate the art form's ability to convey narratives and emotions through movement, often transcending language barriers.

site_title: Line takes local approach to outflank Facebook in Asia
summary: LINE Corp, a Japanese chat app, is adopting a local approach to outflank Facebook in Asia by creating different strategies for each market. The app has gained popularity in countries such as Indonesia and Muslim countries, offering features like classmate-connecting services and special Ramadan features. LINE aims to become the top messaging service in Asia, surpassing WeChat, which boasts 697 million users. With its unique approach and ability to make money from virtual-sticker sales, LINE is poised to expand its user base and hold an initial public offering this year.

site_title: SME internationalisation: S'pore, EU working together
summary: Singapore and the European Union are strengthening their ties through SME internationalisation efforts, aiming to boost economic growth, innovation, and job creation. Both regions have a high percentage of SMEs, with 99% of EU SMEs and 99% of Singaporean SMEs representing the backbone of their private sectors. To support SMEs in entering new markets, the EU and Singapore are launching joint initiatives, including the Enterprise Europe Network Singapore Centre and EU Business Avenues, which will facilitate partnerships and business collaborations between SMEs from both regions.

site_title: Wright grows up on Game of Thrones set
summary: Isaac Hempstead Wright, 17, talks about growing up on the set of Game of Thrones, where he plays Bran Stark. He auditioned at 10 and didn't watch the show, but received an embarrassing lecture from his mother about sex. Wright's character will play a significant role in Season 6, honing magical powers and bringing balance to the White Walkers. Wright praises co-star Max von Sydow, who plays the Three-Eyed Raven, and believes Sansa Stark should rule Westeros due to her experience and cunning.

images.alt_text: Isaac Hempstead Wright, who plays Bran Stark in the hit TV series, says being on the set is like summer camp for acting.

site_title: Oil prices retreat after US-inspired gains
summary: Oil prices retreated Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate finishing at $43.18 a barrel, down $1.00 from the previous day. The decline followed sharp gains on Wednesday after the US energy department reported a decline in US crude production. The US benchmark surged 4% to near five-month highs on Wednesday, but traders banked profits, leading to the price drop. Analysts attributed the decline to profit-taking, with no immediate support from new producer meetings or US inventory data.

site_title: Captains of industry active in GCB market in Q1
summary: Key captains of industry, including the Wong family behind Charles & Keith, were active in the Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market in Q1, with notable transactions including a S$22.25 million purchase of an old freehold bungalow along Mount Echo Park. The market's prices and demand are expected to be tested in Q3 with condo launches above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: All cars tested by UK exceeded lab emissions limits on road
summary: Britain's transport ministry revealed that all 37 car models tested by the UK exceeded laboratory limits for polluting nitrogen oxides during real-world driving. Only Volkswagen used defeat devices to cheat tests, while other manufacturers met laboratory standards but failed on-road tests. The results led to the launch of real-world driving emissions tests in 2017. The ministry's re-testing cost £1 million and is expected to be mirrored by Germany's testing of 56 vehicles. The findings come after Volkswagen admitted to rigging US diesel emissions tests in September.

site_title: Update: VW, Justice Department reach diesel emissions deal
summary: Volkswagen AG and the US Justice Department reached a deal in principle to address excess diesel emissions in nearly 600,000 polluting vehicles. The settlement includes a buyback offer for 500,000 2.0-liter vehicles and a possible fix, as well as an environmental remediation fund and additional compensation for owners. The government and Volkswagen have until late June to complete a final consent decree, which will face public comment before taking effect.

site_title: The weight of parenthood
summary: A play called "Falling" explores the emotional challenges of parenting an autistic child. Written by Deanna Jent, who is the mother of an autistic son, the play delves into the daily routines and struggles of a family coping with the condition. The production, directed by Tracie Pang, features a cast of actors who researched and consulted with caregivers and individuals with autism. The play premieres at the KC Arts Centre from May 13 to June 5, raising awareness about the often-misunderstood experiences of families with autistic children.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Tan Kheng Hua (inset) stars in Falling as a mother struggling to cope with an autistic son, played by Andrew Marko.

site_title: Provisions back in focus as Sete Brasil gets bankruptcy filing nod
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) and Sembcorp Marine have been closely watching Sete Brasil's bankruptcy filing, which cleared the path for the restructuring of the rig-building contracts. Keppel O&M has stated that S$230m is adequate for now, but the outcome is uncertain. The bankruptcy filing marks the first step towards removing the overhang over these contracts, which are among the largest on Keppel O&M's order book.

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence improves in Month
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence rose by 0.4 points to -9.3 in April, ending three months of decline. This surpassed the average forecast of -9.5 points. Consumer sentiment in the 28-member European Union also increased by 0.5 points to -6.8. These improvements indicate a slight improvement in consumer morale in the region.

site_title: US: Wall Street cedes ground after mixed bag of earnings
summary: US stocks suffered a loss for the first time in four sessions, closing down 0.52% to 2,091.48 on the S&P 500 index, following mixed quarterly reports and a Verizon warning of a potential earnings hit from a strike. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 0.63% and the Nasdaq Composite edged down 0.05%. Despite some strong earnings reports, 77% of S&P companies have beaten profit estimates, and investors seem to have already discounted weak first-quarter earnings.

site_title: Affordable Art Fair tackles tough market
summary: The Affordable Art Fair's spring edition has returned with a smaller show and lower forecasts. Organisers expect to sell S$1.7 million of art and attract 10,000 visitors, down from S$3.7 million in 2014 and S$2.8 million in 2015. The show size has been halved, with 41 galleries on one floor. Fair director Alan Koh notes that economic downturns can affect art sales, and the current market is normal for a cyclical contraction. Despite this, buyers are expected to be more picky about price points, with art sold between S$100 and S$10,000.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Major dilution for Magnus Energy from convertible notes
summary: Magnus Energy's stock price fell 25% to S$0.003 after the company's largest shareholder, Value Capital Asset Management, converted S$750,000 of convertible notes into 288.46 million shares at a discount. The conversion price was 10% lower than the average traded price, a characteristic of "toxic" convertible notes that can lead to significant dilution and erode the share price. The move further diluted Value Capital's stake in the company, which now holds 12.74% of the shares.

site_title: US dollar gains against euro after Draghi remarks, slips vs yen
summary: The euro fell 0.04% against the US dollar after ECB President Mario Draghi's comments, with markets anticipating potential future stimulus measures. The euro initially rose on Draghi's comments but reversed course as investors considered the possibility of increased stimulus. The US dollar slipped against the yen for the first time in four days, while stocks and oil prices dropped. The dollar index rose 0.11%, while the dollar strengthened against the Swiss franc. Markets are watching the Federal Reserve's policy meeting next week for potential rate hikes.

site_title: Kuwait oil output almost at capacity one day after strike ends
summary: Kuwait's oil production has nearly returned to capacity, with output reaching 2.9 million barrels per day after a strike by 13,000 workers ended. The strike, which began on Sunday, was over pay and benefits cuts amid efforts to reduce subsidies and government handouts due to falling oil prices. Kuwait's oil production had fallen to 1.1 million barrels per day during the strike, but has now increased to nearly its 3 million barrel per day capacity.

site_title: Mediacorp names former CEO Ernest Wong as chairman
summary: Mediacorp appoints former CEO Ernest Wong as chairman-designate, succeeding Teo Ming Kian, who will step down at the annual general meeting in July. Wong, a veteran banker, previously led Mediacorp from 2000 to 2005 and currently chairs Fullerton Financial Holdings.

site_title: US home prices rose 0.4% in February From January, FHFA says
summary: US home prices rose 0.4% in February from the prior month, matching the median estimate of 19 economists. This gain follows a 5.6% increase from a year earlier, driven by job growth and low borrowing costs. However, buyers face fierce competition for the limited 1.98 million available houses, a 1.5% decrease from the same month last year.

site_title: Cheung Woh warns of Q4 loss
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies, a hard disk drive component maker, expects to post a loss for its fourth quarter ended February 2016 due to foreign currency translation differences and the striking-off of a subsidiary. However, the company still expects to make a full-year profit.

site_title: Banks face tighter rules on interest rate risk in Basel revamp
summary: Global regulators have strengthened rules for banks to manage interest-rate risk, particularly in customer loans and assets expected to mature at historically low interest rates. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has bolstered the existing system, but stopped short of imposing binding capital requirements due to industry opposition. The new standards include stricter thresholds for identifying outlier banks and enhanced disclosure requirements, which will be implemented by 2018. Banks are expected to consider negative interest rate scenarios and assess asymmetrical effects on their assets and liabilities.

site_title: Britain says could take 25% equity stake in Tata Steel UK assets
summary: Britain is considering a 25% equity stake in Tata Steel UK assets or providing debt financing to support a potential buyer. The government aims to minimize pension impact on the purchaser. It is working with Tata Steel and the British Steel Pension Scheme's Trustees to find a solution. This move is seen as a last-ditch effort to save the UK steel industry, which has faced significant financial difficulties.

images.alt_text: Britain said on Thursday it could take an equity stake of up to 25 per cent in Tata's UK steel assets or provide hundreds of millions of pounds worth of debt financing to help support a potential buyer.

site_title: US, Gulf to work together to deal with low oil prices: Obama
summary: US President Barack Obama announced a high-level economic dialogue with Gulf oil producers to address the impact of low oil prices. The dialogue aims to support GCC reforms, increase economic ties, and help Saudi Arabia and its neighbors adjust to the deficits caused by plummeting oil prices. The process will focus on providing jobs and opportunities to young people and all citizens, while respecting universal human rights. The US and Gulf nations will work together to lessen the impact of low oil prices.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip as ECB keeps rates unchanged
summary: European stocks slipped 0.3% on Thursday after the European Central Bank kept interest rates unchanged, despite announcing plans to start corporate bond purchases and cheap bank refinancing. The euro initially rose but later fell against the US dollar, amid concerns about a potential more hawkish Federal Reserve next week. Most sectors ended in the red, with shares in Ericsson and Pernod Ricard falling 14.6% and 4.9% respectively, despite the ECB's efforts to boost the region's economy.

site_title: Perennial's four-year 4.55% retail bond placement tranche oversubscribed
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' four-year retail bond placement tranche, priced at 4.55% per annum, has been slightly oversubscribed with S$85 million subscriptions received for the S$75 million tranche. The public tranche, initially set at S$125 million, may be expanded to S$225 million based on demand, bringing the total offering to S$300 million. The placement is predominantly from private bank investors, and the public offer closes on April 27.

site_title: Simplify the complexities of AEC for regional growth
summary: The Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) has been operating as an economic community since April 2016, aiming to increase regional trade and competitiveness. However, member countries face challenges such as diverse regulatory frameworks and infrastructure maturity, making it complex for businesses to operate across the region. Digital technology can simplify these complexities, enabling businesses to level the playing field and navigate regulatory changes. Examples include Malaysia's digitization of its processes and Ageas Insurance's cloud-based insurance software. As Asean's young demographic and growing middle class increasingly use the internet, businesses are under pressure to digitize, and investing in digital capabilities is crucial for success in the integrated marketplace.

images.alt_text: The beauty of Asean lies in its diversity. Yet this diversity also results in high barriers to entry for businesses. Across the region, businesses are operating on different regulatory frameworks and policies, and running on varying levels of infrastructure maturity.

site_title: Social media explodes as Prince tributes mark death of music icon
summary: Music legend Prince died suddenly, sending shockwaves through social media as Twitter users flooded the site to express their emotions. Celebrities, including Barack Obama, Madonna, Will Smith, and Justin Timberlake, shared tributes and condolences on social media, with his name being tweeted over 4 million times. Prince's influential music, which combined jazz, funk, R&B, and disco, was widely praised, and he won seven Grammy awards and an Oscar. Tributes poured in from around the world, with Minnesota politicians and fans mourning the loss of a beloved icon.

site_title: US: Wall St flat as investors parse earnings
summary: US stock indexes remained flat at the open on Thursday as investors analyzed mixed earnings reports. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.24 points, the S&P 500 gained 0.39 points, and the Nasdaq composite added 1.30 points. Despite some volatility, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged closer to fresh records, driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks. The flat market reflects investors' continued focus on the impact of US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US regulators issue new proposal to restrict Wall Street pay
summary: US regulators have issued a new proposal to restrict Wall Street pay, limiting incentive-based compensation at big financial firms. The proposal, jointly crafted by the National Credit Union Administration and five other regulators, aims to prevent firms from paying executives who may put the institution at risk. This is a modified version of a proposal first issued in 2011. The plan restricts the way financial firms can pay top executives and other employees, following sweeping financial reform laws passed after the financial crisis.

images.alt_text: A group of US regulators issued a new proposal on Thursday detailing restrictions on incentive-based compensation at big financial firms.

site_title: US manufacturers spend more on regulations than security: Philly Fed
summary: US Mid-Atlantic manufacturers have spent more on regulatory compliance (5.8%) than on data and network security (4.7%) and physical security measures (2.8%), according to a Philadelphia Federal Reserve survey. This highlights a significant investment in regulatory compliance over security, potentially indicating a shift in priorities within the manufacturing industry.

site_title: China looks overseas in bid to slim down bloated steel sector
summary: China plans to shift domestic steel capacity overseas and restrict new capacity additions at home to address its bloated steel sector. The government will provide financing support for enterprises "going out" and encourage coal and steel businesses to build capacity abroad. Meanwhile, it will strictly control credit available for new capacity additions in China, potentially signaling a crackdown on exports blamed for depressing global prices. The move aims to tackle the overcapacity crisis, which has saddled domestic firms with losses and debts.

site_title: Indonesia instructs commercial vessels to avoid piracy-prone waters around southern Philippines
summary: Indonesia has instructed commercial vessels to avoid piracy-prone waters around the southern Philippines due to recent kidnappings and piracy. The Indonesian Navy is increasing patrols in the area to prevent acts of piracy and hijacking, which affects a $40 billion shipping route. A memorandum of understanding (MOU) is being implemented with Philippine and Malaysian armed forces to coordinate patrols in the region. This move aims to protect the busy shipping route, particularly supertankers carrying cargo from the Indian Ocean.

site_title: Lloyds planning to axe about 600 UK jobs in cost-cutting plan: union
summary: Lloyds Banking Group is planning to axe approximately 625 UK jobs in its retail bank as part of a cost-cutting plan, with a net reduction of 430 roles. The bank will primarily cut back office positions, and 21 branches will close in July. Employees will be offered voluntary redundancy, with compulsory redundancies only considered if necessary.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US falls as views on economy backtrack
summary: Consumer confidence in the US fell to 42.9 in the week ending April 17, despite improved views on the economy's future prospects. The current economy measure decreased, while the future outlook index rose to a three-month high. Consumers remain uncertain due to mixed economic signals, including slow wage growth and limited inflation, despite solid job gains. The biggest decline was among households earning over $100,000. The Midwest was the only region to see a slight improvement.

site_title: US jobless claims drop to 42-1/2 year low as labour market firms
summary: US jobless claims fell to 247,000, a 42-1/2 year low, in the week ended April 16, beating economist forecasts. This marks the longest stretch of jobless claims below 300,000 since 1973, indicating a healthy labor market.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality to launch Modena serviced residence in China's Changsha
summary: Frasers Hospitality, the hospitality arm of Frasers Centrepoint Limited, plans to launch a 345-unit serviced residence, Modena by Fraser Changsha, in China's Changsha in December 2016, marking its first entry into the city. The move follows the upcoming launch of Modena by Fraser Bangkok in Thailand in August 2016. This expansion is part of Frasers Hospitality's growing presence in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance Q1 profit dips on weaker income
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 6.6% decline in net profit in Q1 2016 to S$14.5 million, down from S$15.6 million in the same period last year. Net interest income and hiring charges fell 2.1%, while fee income dropped 37.9%. The company attributed the decline to a slowing economy and intense competition for customer deposits.

site_title: China's stock regulator reins in risqué cyber-celebrity analysts
summary: China's securities regulator has ordered brokerages to restrain their staff's online activity, following criticism of analysts using attractive women to drum up business and lowering the professionalism of the stock market. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) urged brokerages to regulate social media promotions and tighten quality control in research reports. Analysts who became "cyber celebrities" by promoting stocks and sharing personal lives online have been criticized for lacking expertise and promoting "entertainment" over serious business. The crackdown aims to rekindle investor interest after the 2015 stock market crash.

site_title: Olympics-Rio Games countdown starts with Olympia torch lighting
summary: The Rio Olympics' official countdown began with the torch lighting ceremony in Olympia, Greece, shifting attention away from Brazil's turmoil. The flame was lit using a parabolic mirror and will be carried through 12,000 runners across 300 cities and towns before reaching Rio on August 5. Despite Brazil's economic crisis, including impeachment and corruption scandals, the IOC President Thomas Bach emphasized the event's focus on human spirit and passion for sport, aiming to showcase Brazil's joy and enthusiasm.

site_title: Wee Hur wins S$82.2m contract to build five-storey warehouse
summary: Wee Hur Construction, a subsidiary of Wee Hur Holdings, has won an S$82.2 million contract to build a five-storey warehouse in Singapore. The project, expected to be completed within 17 months, will commence on May 1 and generate revenue from FY2016 to FY2017. This contract strengthens the group's order book to an estimated S$345.9 million.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: IHH's subsidiary to acquire Bulgarian healthcare provider and merge with another
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad's subsidiary Acibadem has acquired Tokuda Group, a leading private healthcare provider in Bulgaria, for 65 million euros, and will merge with City Clinic Group, a high-quality integrated healthcare provider, for 10.97 million euros. The combined entity, Acibadem City Clinic, will operate in Sofia, Varna, and Burgas, and is expected to close within three months pending necessary approvals. The deals have no effect on IHH's issued and paid-up share capital and substantial shareholders' shareholdings.

site_title: Brexit would strengthen case for Heathrow expansion, says airport boss
summary: A British exit from the EU would strengthen the case for expanding Heathrow airport, according to its CEO John Holland-Kaye. With the UK's need for global trading routes increasing, Heathrow would be better equipped to handle emerging market links, addressing its struggles to add routes to countries like China. A potential Brexit would also allow the government to make a decision on a third runway expansion, which has been delayed due to local objections and environmental concerns.

site_title: YuuZoo eyes Mexico with new franchise deal
summary: YuuZoo, a social e-commerce firm, has signed a franchise agreement with Media Rock, a Mexican digital entertainment agency, to expand its presence in Mexico. The deal gives YuuZoo access to Mexico's 120 million population and 34.4 million gamers, with annual online transactions in the video game market reaching US$200 million. YuuZoo plans to offer its social e-commerce platform in Mexico, with revenues shared between the two parties.

site_title: Guocoland's Q3 earnings plunge 77%
summary: Guocoland's third-quarter earnings plummeted 77% year-over-year to S$11.31 million, primarily due to a 49% drop in revenue from the previous year. The decline was mainly attributed to an en-bloc sale of serviced apartments in Shanghai. Despite the revenue drop, gross profit margin remained stable at approximately 30%. Earnings per share decreased to 0.8 Singapore cents, a significant drop from 4.24 cents the previous year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 12.56 points to close at 1,721.47, driven by a 1.99 billion lots trade valued at RM1.95 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 507-351.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Eleven Singaporean organisations have been fined and warned for data protection breaches, with K Box Entertainment Group facing the largest fine of S$50,000. Sete Brasil shareholders approved a plan to file for bankruptcy, and UOB chairman Wee Cho Yaw stated it's difficult to grow through acquisitions today. BOC Aviation priced US$750m bonds, while NUS and MPA will conduct joint research on ocean governance. Asian banks' bad debt piles have reached their highest since the global financial crisis, according to Reuters data analysis.

site_title: VW reaches deal with US authorities over engine-rigging scandal: report
summary: Volkswagen has reportedly reached a deal with US authorities to pay $5,000 in compensation to each US car owner of a vehicle fitted with emissions-cheating software, with an additional $10 billion set aside to resolve civil claims. The agreement follows a US Justice Department and Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) deadline to reach a settlement. The deal is part of a broader framework to refit affected engines and could include repurchasing the vehicles from owners. The agreement sends VW shares soaring 7.5% on the Frankfurt stock market.

images.alt_text: Embattled German auto giant Volkswagen looks to have struck a deal with US authorities over compensation for car owners in its massive engine-rigging scandal, according to a newspaper report Thursday, sending VW shares soaring on the Frankfurt stock exchange.

site_title: UK 2015/16 public borrowing overshoots target, March retail sales slide
summary: The UK's public borrowing for the 2015/16 tax year slightly exceeded the target of 72.2 billion pounds, falling to 74.0 billion pounds. This represents 3.9% of national income. Meanwhile, March retail sales declined sharply. These figures offer little comfort to Finance Minister George Osborne as he monitors the economy's slowdown. The data contradicts the government's earlier forecast and may pose a challenge to Osborne's economic policies.

images.alt_text: British public borrowing for the year slightly overshot a target set just a month ago and retail sales fell sharply, figures showed on Thursday, offering little comfort to finance minister George Osborne as he watches for signs of a slowing economy.

site_title: Difficult to grow through acquisitions today: UOB's Wee Cho Yaw
summary: UOB chairman emeritus Wee Cho Yaw expressed difficulty in growing through acquisitions, citing risks of acquiring assets and liabilities. Wee Ee Cheong, CEO, stated the bank is growing organically in South-east Asia, emphasizing that size isn't everything and big banks can fail. Wee attributes the current challenge to the changing landscape, where acquisitions are no longer as straightforward as they were in the past.

images.alt_text: UOB chairman emeritus Wee Cho Yaw, who orchestrated several acquisitions in his time as chief executive officer, sees difficulty in executing acquisitions and getting growth from them today.

site_title: China Aviation Oil's Q1 profit rises 68%
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 68.2% increase in its first-quarter net profit to US$24.1 million, driven by higher trading gains despite a 29.6% decline in revenue due to falling oil prices. The company's cost of sales fell 30% to result in a higher gross profit. CAO's CEO, Meng Fanqiu, attributed the strong performance to the group's diversified and international growth platform, and stated plans to proactively source for mergers and acquisitions to achieve vertical integration and sustainable growth.

site_title: Bank of China to open Brunei branch in SE Asia expansion
summary: Bank of China (Hong Kong) Ltd has received regulatory approval to open a branch in Brunei, marking its first entry into Southeast Asia. This move aligns with China's 'Silk Road' expansion strategy, aiming to establish economic and commercial corridors across 60 countries. The branch will expand Bank of China's network to 10 Asean countries, following recent openings in Hungary and Thailand. This comes after HSBC announced plans to wind down its operations in Brunei.

site_title: Palm oil up for 4th day on lower production outlook, strong demand
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures rose for a fourth consecutive session, reaching their highest in over two weeks, due to lower production expectations and strong demand. Hot and dry weather caused by the El Nino weather pattern led to a decrease in production, while purchases by top buyer India were running behind schedule. The contract for July delivery closed 0.9% higher at RM2,734 per tonne, with traders predicting a supply-driven rally in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Malaysian palm oil futures rose for a fourth consecutive session on Thursday, hitting their highest in more than two weeks, on expectations of lower production following hot and dry weather brought on by the El Nino weather pattern.

site_title: Fuel-cheating scandal wipes US$2.5b off Mitsubishi stock
summary: Mitsubishi Motors shares plummeted US$2.5 billion after admitting to cheating on fuel-efficiency tests, further eroding the automaker's reputation. This scandal follows a string of recent scandals in Japan, including Volkswagen's massive emissions scandal. Mitsubishi faces huge lawsuits and fines, raising questions about its future. The news has also raised concerns about the company's ability to recover from the damage.

site_title: Spain hits target with 2.5-billion-euro bond sale
summary: Spain successfully sold 2.5 billion euros of bonds at a triple auction, hitting its mid-range target. The sale is part of Spain's year-end medium and long-term issuance target, with the country issuing about 37% of its goal. Yields rose slightly on some maturities ahead of the European Central Bank meeting, where policymakers are expected to refrain from further stimulus.

images.alt_text: Spain sold 2.5 billion euros (US$2.8 billion) of bonds at a triple auction on Thursday, with yields rising slightly on some maturities ahead of a European Central Bank meeting at which policy makers are expected to refrain from further stimulus.

site_title: Payment deadline looms over Malaysian fund amid IPIC row
summary: A US$50 million coupon payment on a 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) bond is due this weekend, with 1MDB saying Abu Dhabi sovereign fund IPIC has assumed responsibility for making the payment. The interest on the US$1.75 billion bond is expected to be paid, but the stand-off between the two firms has worried markets and left bondholders waiting. IPIC had agreed to pay the interest in exchange for certain undertakings to transfer assets and cash to IPIC, but the Malaysian state fund acknowledged a dispute with IPIC over obligations.

site_title: Draghi keeps rates at rock bottom in face of German backlash
summary: ECB President Mario Draghi kept borrowing costs at rock bottom levels, maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy despite German criticism. The ECB will continue to charge banks 0.4% for parking money and will maintain a holding pattern for its 1.7 trillion euro money-printing scheme. German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble criticized the ECB's policies, citing "extraordinary" problems for Germany, but the ECB may justify its actions by referencing flagging inflation. The decision could have implications for the eurozone's economic health and the success of the ECB's actions.

site_title: Oil extends gains in Asia after US output falls
summary: Oil prices extended gains in Asia after US production fell to 18-month lows, with Iraq pushing for a meeting to limit output. The news comes despite recent talks on an output freeze collapsing. Optimism in world markets, driven by China's economic readings and central bank easing measures, fueled the gains. Oil prices are building on recent advances, with the collapse of talks and a bearish Trump tariff outlook contributing to the upward trend.

site_title: Insured losses from Japan's April 16 earthquake up to US$2.9b: AIR Worldwide
summary: Japan's April 16 earthquake may result in insured losses totaling up to US$2.9 billion, according to catastrophe modeling firm AIR Worldwide. The earthquake, which struck the Kumamoto area, has resulted in 48 deaths and significant property damage. Loss estimates do not include losses to land, infrastructure, cars, business interruption, or workers' compensation. The estimated range is US$1.7 billion to US$2.9 billion for residential and commercial property.

site_title: Thailand exports rose in March: Deputy PM
summary: Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister, Somkid Jatusripitak, stated that the country's exports rose in March from a year earlier, contrary to a Reuters poll that predicted a 4.6% contraction. This marks a gradual recovery in the economy, following a 13-month streak of declines in February, which was driven by unusual items such as military helicopters and gold shipments.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q1 DPU up 6.3%
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 6.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.371 Singapore cents for its Q1 2016, driven by higher revenue from the opening of Suntec City mall and office space. Gross revenue rose 5.2% to S$78.3 million, while net property income (NPI) increased 5.1% to S$54.0 million. The increase was partly offset by the divestment of Park Mall in December 2015.

site_title: China International Marine Containers launches privatisation bid for Pteris Global
summary: China International Marine Containers has launched a takeover bid for Catalist-listed Pteris Global, offering S$0.735 per share, 16% higher than Pteris's last traded price. The bid aims to delist Pteris, which is majority owned by CIMC.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher in line with rise in Dow futures
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 10.83 points to 2,960.78, driven by a 20-point gain in Dow futures. Banks had a mixed performance, with DBS and UOB closing lower, while OCBC rose. Analyst Morgan Stanley downgraded DBS to underweight and OCBC to equal weight, citing valuation multiples and leverage as concerns. The STI has enjoyed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors remaining positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Hong Kong: Energy stocks help Hong Kong market surge
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.82% on Thursday, led by energy firms as oil prices rose. The Hang Seng Index closed at 21,622.25, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.66% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 1.23%. This followed solid gains in New York, with the US stock market pushing to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: NUS and MPA to conduct joint research in ocean governance
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) have established a joint research programme, the CIL-MPA Oceans Governance Research Programme, to address ocean governance challenges. The three-year programme, funded by a $1.56 million grant, will focus on Arctic shipping governance, transit passage regimes under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, and marine environmental governance. Led by Associate Professor Robert C Beckman, the programme aims to generate quality research and promote thought leadership in ocean governance.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds rates, prepares for new benchmark
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held interest rates for the first time this year, maintaining the 12-month benchmark rate at 6.75% and the seven-day reverse repo rate at 5.50%. The decision, which was expected, is seen as a pause before the bank switches to a new benchmark rate in August. The bank cited improving liquidity and consumption, but acknowledged that transmission of monetary policy has been slow, with deposit rates only decreasing by 37 basis points and lending rates by 13 basis points.

site_title: Europe: VW climbs as European shares rise, but Ericsson slumps
summary: European shares rose 0.1-0.3% on Thursday, with Volkswagen climbing 5.3% after a framework deal to buy back diesel cars evading US emission rules. The European Central Bank is expected to hold interest rates unchanged, but ECB head Mario Draghi may reinforce support for ultra-loose monetary policy. In contrast, Ericsson slumped 9% after first-quarter sales and operating profit missed market expectations.

site_title: Indonesia fears piracy surge on busy shipping route could lead to 'new Somalia'
summary: Indonesia fears a surge in piracy on a busy shipping route along its border with the Philippines could lead to a "new Somalia" unless security is tightened. At least 18 Indonesians and Malaysians have been kidnapped in three attacks by suspected Islamist militants, who have demanded ransom. The route, which carries $40 billion worth of cargo annually, has seen a spate of maritime attacks disrupting coal trade between the neighbors. Indonesian and Malaysian foreign ministers will meet to discuss joint patrols to secure the passage, and the armed forces chiefs of the three countries will meet on May 3.

site_title: Asian banks' bad debt pile highest since global financial crisis
summary: Asian banks' bad debt piles have reached their highest since the global financial crisis, totaling $171 billion at the end of 2015, according to a Reuters data analysis. Non-performing loans (NPLs) jumped 28% from a year earlier, with Asian central banks cutting interest rates to ensure liquidity but facing uncertain economic growth and weak export demand. Analysts expect asset quality to deteriorate, leading to more loan defaults and depressed valuations. This trend is expected to worsen as regional economies, particularly China, continue to slow down.

site_title: China: Stocks slip as profit-taking erases early gains
summary: China stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the CSI300 index falling 0.6% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.7%, due to profit-taking in finance and manufacturing shares. Early gains by commodity stocks in the morning, driven by oil's overnight rise, were erased. The decline was attributed to a decrease in trading volume and a shift in market sentiment.

site_title: More than 100 feared dead in India heat wave
summary: More than 100 people are feared dead in India due to a severe heat wave, with schools and outdoor work suspended. The southern Indian state of Telangana has reported 45 heat-related deaths, while Andhra Pradesh and Odisha have also seen fatalities. India's Indian Meteorological Department has issued heat-wave warnings, and neighboring Pakistan is preparing to open 500 response centers to provide shelter and cold water to people if a heat-wave warning is issued.

site_title: Asia-Pacific job growth slated to slow this year: survey
summary: A survey by Compass Offices found Asia-Pacific job growth is expected to slow this year, with 51% of Australian businesses feeling confident about growth, compared to 43% in Singapore and 30% in Hong Kong. In contrast, Japan's confidence level is the lowest at 15%. The survey revealed that sales, marketing, and IT skills are in high demand to support business growth.

site_title: China ramps up espionage warnings in new security push
summary: China has stepped up espionage warnings in a week-long campaign marking the National Security Law, with state media releasing details of spy cases, including a man who was jailed for 7 years for providing information to a foreign power about Chinese military ships in the East China Sea. The campaign includes cartoon posters warning people about the risks of dating foreigners. President Xi Jinping's security overhaul aims to combat domestic and foreign threats, amid concerns over the country's broad state secrets rules.

images.alt_text: China is ramping up its warnings against espionage in a week of activities to mark the passing of a National Security Law last year, with state media giving rare details of spy cases and a cartoon campaign saying it is risky to date foreigners.

site_title: Sony cuts FY2015 profit estimate on weaker camera modules demand
summary: Sony has cut its profit estimate for FY2015 to 290 billion yen (US$2.64 billion) due to weaker demand for its camera modules used in smartphones. The company previously estimated operating profit at 320 billion yen. Additionally, Sony booked an impairment loss of 59.6 billion yen on its devices business. This move reflects the decline in camera module sales, impacting Sony's overall financial performance.

site_title: China aims to expand forex market, unify onshore and offshore yuan rates
summary: China aims to expand its foreign exchange market and unify onshore and offshore yuan exchange rates, according to the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. The regulator plans to develop foreign exchange derivatives and promote market opening to help domestic firms hedge currency risks. The move is expected to deepen and open up the foreign exchange market, including enriching trading products and expanding market players.

images.alt_text: China will take steps to develop the sophistication of its currency trading systems and to promote the unification of yuan exchange rates on onshore and offshore markets, the foreign exchange regulator said on Thursday.

site_title: Draghi to mount defence of ECB in face of German criticism
summary: ECB President Mario Draghi is set to defend the European Central Bank's (ECB) ultra-loose monetary policy against criticism from Germany, which has accused the ECB of causing "extraordinary" problems for the country's economy. The ECB will likely hold interest rates at record lows and reaffirm its guidance for low or lower rates for years to come. Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has criticized the ECB's policies, but some analysts believe the ECB has the upper hand in the debate. The ECB's expansionary monetary policy stance is seen as appropriate by its biggest critic, Bundesbank chief Jens Weidmann, and the bank is likely to reject German criticism.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares up on weaker yen, oil price surge
summary: Tokyo shares rose for a third consecutive session, driven by a weaker yen and another surge in oil prices. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 2.70%, while the Topix index rose 2.04%. Mitsubishi Motors fell 20% after admitting to falsifying fuel efficiency tests.

site_title: Opec invite has Gabon mulling best response to oil nightmare
summary: Gabon is considering rejoining the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) as oil prices continue to slump, with Brent crude reaching $45.89 a barrel. President Ali Bongo Ondimba said the country needs a global price of around $60 a barrel to stabilize its economy, which relies heavily on oil exports. Gabon has already cut its budget twice due to falling crude sales and is in talks with the World Bank about possible financing. The country is also preparing for presidential elections in August, with Bongo facing a challenge from Jean Ping, a former foreign minister.

site_title: Vietnam coffee exports could drop 25% in 2016: industry official
summary: Vietnam's coffee exports are projected to decline 25% in 2016, reaching a decade low of 1 million tonnes, due to drought, lower yields from old trees, and increased domestic roasting. This could boost global coffee prices. The country's coffee processing is shifting to meet the growing demand from coffee shops, while foreign firms like Nestle establish processing facilities. Farmers in the Central Highlands, which produce 80% of Vietnam's coffee, face a 30% drop in output if the drought intensifies.

site_title: Modern finance experience presented by Oracle
summary: Oracle presented its modern finance experience, showcasing its capabilities in the industry. Meanwhile, Singapore's National Institute of Education (NIE) partnered with Amazon Web Services to establish an AI-focused innovation hub for education technology research. Mining giant BHP joined forces with Oracle, Grab, and PwC to launch an AI Hub in Singapore, aiming to drive innovation.
