The company's full-year provisions could be a double-digit billion amount, potentially resulting in no dividend or a very small one, with the amount being under one euro. Volkswagen has declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Intel to cut 12,000 jobs globally as PC industry buckles
summary: Intel to cut 12,000 jobs globally, or 11% of its workforce, as it refocuses on data centre and Internet-connected devices, away from the declining personal computer (PC) industry. The move comes as global PC shipments fell 11.5% in the first quarter. Intel's revenue forecast is also lowered, with revenue expected to rise in mid-single digits. The company will record a pre-tax restructuring charge of $1.2 billion in the second quarter.

site_title: Software that predicts terrorist traits can detect food fraud
summary: A software called EMAlert, developed by Battelle Memorial Institute and the Grocery Manufacturers of America, can predict the likelihood of food fraud by modeling the decision-making behavior of adulterators. The program uses real-time information to weigh 12 attributes of a commodity and calculates the probability of adulteration. This technology aims to combat food fraud, which has led to consumer distrust after high-profile cases of contamination and mislabeling in recent years, including Parmesan cheese, olive oil, and infant formula. The software could help accurately trace products through supply chains and prevent future instances of food fraud.

site_title: Four hundred years after his death, Cervantes intrigues and enchants
summary: Miguel de Cervantes, author of the iconic novel Don Quixote, left an enduring literary legacy despite a tumultuous life marked by survival of a sea battle, five years of captivity in Algiers, and stints in prison. Born in 1547, Cervantes' life was a mix of military campaigns, duels, and financial struggles, which heavily influenced his writing. His novel, published in 1605, became an overnight success, cementing his place as the father of the modern novel, and continues to be widely translated and praised today.

site_title: Top eurozone firms may soon see investors pay to lend to them
summary: The European Central Bank is expected to announce plans to buy corporate bonds under its quantitative easing scheme, potentially depressing borrowing costs and seeing some companies sell debt at negative yields. Over a dozen eurozone companies have already seen yields on existing bonds fall below zero, with some selling bonds with no regular interest payments. The ECB's aggressive negative rates strategy could lead to more companies issuing negative-yielding bonds, but it's unclear if the market is ready for this.

site_title: Update: Oil tank fire at Jurong Island put out after five-hour operation
summary: An oil tank fire at 23 Tembusu Road on Jurong Island in Singapore was extinguished after a five-hour operation by the Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) involving around 150 personnel. The fire broke out at 3pm and was put out at 7:45pm.

site_title: Malaysia markets 10- and 30-year benchmark Islamic dollar bonds
summary: Malaysia issued benchmark Islamic dollar bonds with yields ranging from 135 to 150 basis points over Treasuries. The sale comes amid a dispute between the government and Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund over debt obligations, increasing credit risk. Foreign demand for Malaysian government bonds has remained strong, despite concerns about the nation's finances. The sale is part of efforts to stabilize the ringgit, which has rebounded from its worst annual loss since the Asian financial crisis.

site_title: Albedo changes name to China Medical (International) Group
summary: Albedo Limited has changed its name to China Medical (International) Group Limited to reflect its shift from a metal trading and distribution business to a medical aesthetics and healthcare services provider. The name change, effective April 25, was approved by shareholders.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: World steel production drops in first quarter: trade group
summary: Global steel production fell 3.6% in the first quarter, with significant drops in China (-3.2%), EU (-7.0%), and South America (-14.1%). US steel output declined 1.3%, while North American countries saw a regional decline of 1.1%. The World Steel Association attributes the decline to a slowdown in the Chinese economy and manufacturing weakness. A recovery in steel demand is unlikely before next year, according to the organization.

site_title: Being eco-conscious is the business of everyone and every corporation
summary: On Earth Day, various groups and organisations will mark the occasion by going green, while world leaders convene at the UN to sign the Paris climate pact, aiming to limit warming below 2°C. The pact requires nearly 200 countries to legally join and commit to reducing greenhouse gas emissions, with a goal of peaking by 2020. Despite a surge in investments in alternative energy, carbon emissions are expected to continue to rise, and the UN estimates emissions will peak no earlier than 2030. Countries like Singapore have committed to reducing emissions, but individual and corporate actions are crucial to achieving the goal.

site_title: US crude stockpiles rise less than expected in week: EIA
summary: US crude oil stockpiles rose 2.1 million barrels in the last week, slightly less than the 2.4 million barrels forecast by analysts. Gasoline and distillate inventories fell. Crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub decreased by 248,000 barrels. The data from the Energy Information Administration provided a less-than-expected increase in crude inventories, indicating a slight adjustment to market expectations.

images.alt_text: US crude stocks rose slightly less than expected last week, while gasoline and distillate inventories fell, data from the Energy Information Administration showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Gulf's biggest buyer of US property to double investments
summary: Investcorp, the Gulf's largest private investor in US property, plans to double its assets under management to $25 billion over the next five to seven years. The company expects to spend $1.5 billion on US property in the fiscal year, up from $860 million in the previous year, and will also invest $200 million in European property. This marks a return to European property after abandoning the market in 1994 due to low returns. The investment is part of a new growth plan under executive chairman Mohammed Al Ardhi, aiming to expand investment products and rebuild its hedge-fund business.

site_title: US opens criminal probe linked to Panama Paper revelations: ICIJ
summary: The US Justice Department has opened a criminal investigation into matters linked to the Panama Papers, according to a letter from Manhattan US Attorney Preet Bharara. The investigation, which has no specific details, was initiated after the release of 11.5 million confidential documents revealing offshore shell companies used to hide wealth and launder money. The International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, which released the documents, has been asked to discuss the investigation. Reports linked several international leaders to the offshore companies, including Russian President Vladimir Putin and British Prime Minister David Cameron.

site_title: Manulife's Reit IPO in Singapore back on track
summary: Canadian financial services group Manulife has revived plans to list its US office Reit in Singapore with a May 20 target. The IPO is expected to raise around $500 million, with an annualised dividend yield of 6.5-7% for 2017. Manulife has removed a Washington, DC office from its portfolio and replaced it with a 28-storey office building in Atlanta, Georgia. The new portfolio includes two Grade-A office buildings in the US and has increased net lettable area by 23% and net asset value by 10.5%. Market watchers expect higher odds of success, citing improved market conditions and a dovish US Federal Reserve stance.

images.alt_text: Canadian financial services group Manulife has started pre-marketing for an initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore of its US office Reit (real estate investment trust), a plan it had shelved for nine months due to market conditions.

site_title: Panama, Japan aim to exchange tax-related information
summary: Panama and Japan agreed to start talks on a bilateral framework for exchanging taxation-related information, following a leak of confidential documents highlighting Panama's failure to cooperate in international efforts to curb tax evasion. Panamanian President Juan Carlos Varela and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe made the announcement. The move aims to boost transparency in the financial system and is seen as a step towards implementing automatic exchange of taxation information.

site_title: Far East Orchard's Q1 net profit jumps
summary: Far East Orchard reported a Q1 net profit of S$16.88 million, up from S$3.80 million a year ago, due to lower currency translation losses and stronger joint venture performance. Revenue fell 51% to S$51.09 million, mainly due to the absence of progressive revenue from the euHabitat project and lower hospitality division revenue. Earnings per share rose to 4.11 cents, but no dividend was recommended.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US mortgage application index rises to 9-week high
summary: US mortgage applications rose to a 9-week high, with the Mortgage Bankers Association's weekly index increasing 1.3% to 526.80. The average interest rate on 30-year mortgages reached 3.83%, the lowest in over a year. Refinance applications rose 3% to 2,177.4, while purchase applications dipped 1% to 240.8. The increase follows disappointing news on housing starts, which fell 8.8% in March to the lowest annualized rate since October.

images.alt_text: US mortgage applications edged up to their highest level in nine weeks as interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages hovered at their lowest in more than a year, a Mortgage Bankers Association data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Obama meets Saudi king as US Iran policy strains alliance
summary: US President Barack Obama met Saudi Arabia's King Salman to address security threats, including Iran and the Islamic State, amidst strained US-Iran relations. The visit aims to reassure Gulf leaders of Washington's commitment to their security. However, Gulf Arab monarchies have been disappointed with Obama's presidency, feeling the US has pulled back from the region, allowing Iran to expand its influence. The meeting is Obama's fourth and likely last visit to Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Gold retreats as dollar firms; silver hits 11-month high
summary: Gold prices retreated 0.2% to $1,247.36 an ounce, halted by a firmer dollar, while silver hit an 11-month high of $17.23 an ounce, boosted by technical momentum and perceptions of undervaluation. The price of silver has risen nearly 10% this month, driven by rising inflation expectations and negative interest rates in Japan and the eurozone.

site_title: US companies rated B3 or lower at 7-year high: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service reported a 7-year high of 291 US companies rated B3 or lower, surpassing the 2009 peak. The oil and gas sector led the increase, with 32% of its companies carrying B3 negative or lower ratings, up 17% from the previous quarter. The sector's concentration of low-rated companies is contained, unlike during the 2009 crisis when the list featured a wider variety of industries. Moody's warns that the number of companies with B3 negative or lower ratings could expand beyond its current tally if downgrades continue.

site_title: Growth still the missing link in emerging markets bounce
summary: Emerging markets have experienced a rally since 2015, with bonds and equities gaining double-digit returns. However, the underlying economic growth remains weak, with the International Monetary Fund cutting 2016 growth forecasts for developing countries to 4.1%. Bank of America Merrill Lynch has turned positive on emerging equities, but some analysts argue that the gains are driven by US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts and may not be sustainable. Despite some positive signs in subsets of the emerging universe, the sector's earnings are expected to decline for a fifth year in a row, raising questions about the long-term viability of the rally.

site_title: China to implement proactive import policies: cabinet
summary: China's cabinet announced proactive import policies to support advanced equipment and technology imports. The government will give tax rebates to machinery product exports and encourage banks to lend to profitable trading companies with overseas orders. This move aims to boost the country's economy, which is expected to slow down, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: US: Wall St flat as strong earnings counter fall in oil
summary: US stock indexes were little changed on Wednesday as strong earnings reports offset a decline in oil prices. The S&P 500 breached 2,100, but fell 0.06% to 2,099.63. Six of the 10 major S&P sectors were higher, driven by better-than-expected quarterly profits from companies like VMWare, Discover Financial Services, and EMC. Oil prices slid 2% after Kuwaiti oil workers called off a strike, helping to lift the index earlier in the week.

site_title: US existing home sales rise sharply; prices advance
summary: US existing home sales rose 5.1% to an annual rate of 5.33 million units in March, exceeding economists' forecasts. Despite a potential economic slowdown, housing remains a bright spot due to a strong labor market and household formation. However, a lack of available homes for sale constrains sales, with the number of unsold homes increasing 5.9% to 1.98 million units. Median house prices rose 5.7% to $222,700, outpacing wage gains and potentially making home purchasing expensive for first-time buyers.

site_title: Vouchers, gifts, food served at AGMs are board's prerogative, says SIAS
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) says vouchers, gifts, and food served at annual general meetings (AGMs) are a privilege, not a right, of shareholders. SIAS President David Gerald stated that shareholders should not pressure companies to provide these items and that the decision is entirely up to the board. Some shareholders have misbehaved by rushing for food, spilling it, and bringing family members, tarnishing the reputation of other shareholders. SIAS recognizes that these items are a privilege, not a right, and urges shareholders to respect this.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China's LeEco unveils all-electric concept car with sights set on industry leaders
summary: China's LeEco unveiled an all-electric concept car, LeSEE, at the Beijing auto show, aiming to compete with Tesla's Model S. The car is fully electric, "smart", "connected", and "automated self-driving", and LeEco plans to launch it in the future. The company hopes the car will help China's auto industry reach the global forefront. LeEco is not alone in developing electric vehicles, with several Chinese-funded startups and tech firms, including Baidu and Alibaba, also investing in the industry.

site_title: Shell starts voluntary redundancy process for Dutch staff
summary: Shell has started a voluntary redundancy process in the Netherlands as part of its plan to cut around 10,300 jobs worldwide due to a slump in oil prices. The oil company has around 11,000 directly employed staff in the Netherlands and has previously announced a 2,800 job cut as part of its $50 billion takeover of BG Group. The voluntary severance programme may be rolled out elsewhere, with staff notified before external announcements.

site_title: German government sees economy growing by 1.7% in 2016, 1.5% in 2017
summary: The German government has forecast 1.7% economic growth in 2016 and 1.5% in 2017, according to Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel. This prediction is unchanged from January's forecast, with domestic demand expected to drive growth. The announcement marks the first time the government has released a prediction for 2017.

site_title: ST Electronics bags S$505m contracts in Q1
summary: ST Electronics secured S$505 million worth of contracts in Q1 2016, including S$41 million for Rail Electronics & Intelligent Transportation, S$91 million for Satellite & Broadband Communications, and S$373 million for Advanced Electronics & Information Communications Technologies. The deals were won from local and overseas customers, including government and private-sector organizations. The contracts are expected to have no material impact on ST Engineering's consolidated net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Swedish regulator says may need to do more to cool housing market
summary: Sweden's Financial Supervisory Authority may need to tighten mortgage rules further to curb the rapidly growing housing market. Record low interest rates and strong economic growth have sparked a borrowing binge, with property prices soaring 14% last year. The regulator's General Director, Erik Thedeen, warned that the market is "driving too fast" and may need a loan-to-income cap to prevent a potential crash. The government must act to boost house building or reduce tax incentives to avoid triggering a slump. Tighter rules will take effect on June 1.

site_title: Coca-Cola sales fall on strong dollar, weak Europe demand
summary: Coca-Cola's sales declined for the fourth consecutive quarter due to weak demand in Europe and a strong dollar eroding sales in international markets. The company's shares fell 1% to $46, and its net income dropped 4.5% to $1.48 billion. Excluding items, Coke earned 45 cents per share, beating analyst estimates. Revenue fell 4% to $10.28 billion, but excluding currency impacts, it rose 2%. The decline is attributed to consumers cutting back on fizzy drinks and turning to healthier alternatives.

site_title: Quake measuring 6.1 strikes off eastern Japan: USGS
summary: An earthquake measuring 6.1 magnitude struck off northeastern Japan on April 20, 2016, with no immediate tsunami warning or reports of damage or casualties. The quake, centered 104 km east southeast of Sendai, Honshu, was 51 km deep. This comes after a series of strong quakes in south Japan that killed nearly 50 people, leaving survivors struggling with food and water shortages.

site_title: Falcon Private Bank tiptoes 'selectively' into emerging market equities
summary: Falcon Private Bank has started allocating funds into emerging market equities "selectively" amid a weakening US dollar. The move comes despite projected substantial outflows of $500 billion from emerging markets in 2016. The bank's chief investment officer, David Pinkerton, attributes the outflows to US dollar strength, which has hindered emerging market equities' performance over the past four years. Falcon plans to invest in markets where currencies have already depreciated, and the Institute of International Finance notes a "striking turnaround" in recent EM asset prices and inflows.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: GIC to buy stake in US power group ITC for US$1.23b
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC has agreed to buy a 19.9% stake in US power transmission company ITC Holdings Corp for US$1.23 billion. The deal is part of Fortis Inc's US$6.9 billion acquisition of ITC, with GIC purchasing the minority stake to help fund the deal. Fortis and ITC's parent company, Canadian utility Fortis Inc, made the announcement in a joint statement. Financial advisors Scotiabank and Citigroup Global Markets Inc assisted with the deal.

site_title: Cordlife yet to receive letter from shareholders for meeting to appoint nominee directors
summary: Cordlife Group has yet to receive a letter from shareholders Bonvests Holdings Ltd and Tai Tak Estates Sdn Bhd, who collectively own 22.5% of the firm, on their intention to call for a shareholder meeting to seek board representation. The two shareholders had previously nominated candidates for non-independent, non-executive director positions. Cordlife's chairman Ho Choon Hou stated that a nominating committee meeting will be convened to discuss the suitability of the nominees. The company's shares slipped 3.5 cents or 2.3% on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China to speed up infrastructure construction in remote regions
summary: China plans to accelerate infrastructure construction in remote rural areas, aiming to build a comprehensive transportation network by 2020. The programme includes 100 highway, railway, and airport projects, focusing on roads, bridges, and improving transport conditions to boost tourism. The initiative aims to drive investment, employment, and poverty alleviation, with the goal of benefiting millions of people. The move follows a slowdown in China's economy, with a 6.7% GDP growth rate in the first quarter, and is seen as a credit-fueled investment strategy.

site_title: India says 330 million people suffering from drought
summary: India reports that approximately 330 million people are suffering from drought, with 10 states hit by two consecutive years of weak monsoons. This has led to severe water shortages and crop losses, prompting the government to release funds to affected regions and ration drinking water.

images.alt_text: About 330 million people are suffering from drought in India, the government has said, as the country reels from severe water shortages and desperately poor farmers suffer crop losses.

site_title: Small, medium-sized UK firms face 35.6b pound Brexit hit: report
summary: Small and medium-sized UK firms face a 35.6 billion pound currency risk due to uncertainty surrounding the Brexit referendum, according to a report by World First and YouGov. Despite a 75% rise in sterling volatility, only 35% of SMEs extended their FX protection, leaving them exposed to foreign exchange market swings. The uncertainty has resulted in significant financial risks for British SMEs, with the potential for losses of up to 35.6 billion pounds.

site_title: SilkAir appoints new chief executive
summary: SilkAir appoints FOO Chai Woo as its new chief executive, effective May 18, replacing Leslie Thng who will return to parent company Singapore Airlines. FOO has 21 years of experience at SIA, holding various roles including divisional vice-president of sales and marketing.

site_title: Singapore Savings Bonds have drawn S$810 million after first six offerings: MAS
summary: Singapore Savings Bonds have attracted S$810 million from 32,000 investors after six offerings, with 46% of bondholders aged 49 and above. Almost half of applications were for S$10,000 or less, and 19% of bondholders had recently opened Central Depository accounts, indicating a presence of first-time investors. Singapore Savings Bonds drew S$810 million from 32,000 investors in their first six offerings. Passenger car COE premiums surged in a surprise bidding exercise, while Perennial Real Estate Holdings plans to issue up to S$200 million of bonds. SMRT will showcase an automated vehicle system by year-end, and Manulife is reviving its office Reit IPO plan. Singapore shares closed 0.1% down on Wednesday.

site_title: Indonesia Q1 growth around 5 per cent: president
summary: Indonesia's president, Joko Widodo, stated that the country's growth rate has stabilized around 5% in the first quarter, attributed to infrastructure investment. This marks a reversal from the 4.8% growth rate in the previous year, and Widodo expressed optimism that the country could achieve its 5.3% target. Indonesia's slowest growth pace in six years has been driven by falling commodity prices and a cooling economy in China.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's president Joko Widodo said on Wednesday the country's growth rate had stabilised around 5 percent in the first quarter, and the goal was to gradually raise the rate from these levels.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipped 2.24 points to close at 1,708.91 on Wednesday, ending lower. 1.75 billion lots valued at RM2.06 billion were traded, with 413 gainers and 385 losers.

site_title: Number of UK unemployed rises for 1st time since mid-2015
summary: The number of unemployed people in the UK rose for the first time since mid-2015, increasing by 21,000 in the three months to February, according to the Office for National Statistics. This rise was attributed to caution among employers ahead of the EU membership referendum and the introduction of a higher minimum wage. The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.1%, while total earnings, including bonuses, rose by 1.8% in the same period, below expectations.

site_title: Toshiba preparing Westinghouse writedown, CEO to step down: sources
summary: Toshiba is preparing to write down the value of its US nuclear subsidiary Westinghouse by around $1.84 billion, following the deterioration of the nuclear business' fundamentals. The company's CEO, Masashi Muromachi, is set to step down, and a company committee has met to discuss his resignation. The writedown, to be posted for the financial year ended in March, comes on top of a forecasted net loss of 710 billion yen. Toshiba is restructuring its laptops-to-nuclear conglomerate as it cleans up its books.

images.alt_text: Japan's Toshiba Corp is preparing to write down the value of its stake in US nuclear subsidiary Westinghouse by around 200 billion yen (US$1.84 billion), sources familiar with the matter said on Wednesday.

site_title: EU charges Google with abusing its Android dominance
summary: European Union antitrust regulators have charged Google with abusing its dominance of the Android mobile operating system through deals with phone makers and network operators. The investigation found Google's behavior denies consumers choice and innovation, potentially jeopardizing the company's $11 billion in ad sales. This is the second antitrust case against Google, following a 2010 case that led to the European Commission charging the company with promoting its own shopping service at the expense of rivals.

site_title: Malaysia Air CEO cites reasons 'beyond my control' for quitting
summary: Malaysia Airlines CEO Christoph Mueller is leaving the national carrier in September due to personal reasons beyond his control. Mueller, who was instrumental in reviving the airline after two plane crashes in 2014, wrote to staff that the company is making progress and is on track with its plan. Despite the challenges, Mueller expressed optimism about the airline's future, stating that "the show must go on." Mueller's departure comes as the carrier is beginning to turn around after a period of significant losses and reputational damage.

site_title: Commerzbank expects earnings decline in first quarter: CEO
summary: Commerzbank expects its first quarter earnings to decline due to low interest rates and capital market volatility. The bank's CEO, Martin Blessing, stated that this decline will make it challenging to reach the full year result achieved in 2015, which was €1.06 billion. This is a reversal of the bank's previous prediction of a slight improvement in net income for the year. The bank reports first-quarter results on May 3.

site_title: SGX Q3 net profit up 1% to S$89m
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 1% increase in net profit to S$89.2 million for the third quarter ended March 2016, with revenue rising 3% to S$205.8 million. The earnings per share increased to 8.3 Singapore cents from 8.2 cents. An interim dividend of five Singapore cents per share was declared, payable on May 6, 2016. CEO Loh Boon Chye attributed the growth to higher market activities in response to changes in benchmark interest rates and commodity prices.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: VW resists move for trial instead of EPA settlement
summary: Volkswagen is resisting a demand from US plaintiffs to go to trial in its diesel emissions case with the Environmental Protection Agency instead of settling. The plaintiffs, representing thousands of consumers who claim to have been tricked into buying polluting diesel vehicles, proposed an expedited hearing or bench trial. Volkswagen's court filing stated it does not believe an expedited trial is necessary, and a status conference is set for Thursday to discuss its progress towards reaching a deal.

site_title: S-chip Sunmart Holdings mulls over delisting from SGX
summary: Sunchip Sunmart Holdings is considering a voluntary delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after trading in its shares was suspended in 2012 due to suspicious transactions. The company's board aims to get the business back on track and potentially return to trading on the SGX. However, no certainty is given on the outcome, and the announcement does not constitute a firm intention to make an offer. This decision comes amid efforts to revive the company's operations after a period of trading suspension.

site_title: Venezuela minister warns oil prices may collapse if producers don't talk
summary: Venezuela's Oil Minister Eulogio Del Pino warned that oil prices may collapse if producers don't resume talks to freeze output levels. Global oil stocks are nearly full, with producers producing 1.5-2.0 million barrels per day more than market demand. Del Pino stated that a price of US$60-70 per barrel is needed to allow producers to invest in new fields, replacing declining mature fields.

site_title: Sembcorp, NUS jointly set up S$60m corporate laboratory
summary: SembCorp Industries has partnered with the National University of Singapore (NUS) to establish a S$60 million corporate laboratory focused on energy, water, and waste-to-resource solutions. The laboratory, supported by the National Research Foundation Singapore, aims to develop new, sustainable solutions through public-private partnerships. This joint venture will foster innovation and competitiveness in the industries.

site_title: Seroja Investments wins new 4-year coal transportation contract
summary: Seroja Investments' subsidiary, PT Pulau Seroja Jaya, has secured a 4-year coal transportation contract with PT Maritim Barito Perkasa, an Indonesian energy group. The agreement, signed on April 20, 2016, will transport 7 million metric tons of coal annually for four years, generating an estimated cumulative revenue of $48 million. The contract replaces an old agreement and has an option for a three-year extension. The move aims to establish a stable and reliable stream of business for PT Pulau Seroja Jaya.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.1 per cent down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.86 points to 2,949.95, closing 0.1% down, amid a slump in crude oil prices. About 1.11 billion shares worth S$1.06 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 245 to 169. The market was affected by the decline in oil prices, with Magnus Energy being the only active counter to rise.

site_title: Four global shipping giants form new alliance
summary: Four major shipping lines, CMA CGM, COSCO Container Lines, Evergreen Line, and Orient Overseas Container Line, have formed the "OCEAN Alliance" through a Memorandum of Understanding. The alliance aims to offer competitive services and comprehensive networks across various global trades, covering Asia-Europe, Asia-Mediterranean, and Trans-Pacific routes. The deployment is expected to begin in April 2017 and will cover over 40 services globally, with the initial period set to last five years, subject to regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Chip designer ARM beats forecasts with Q1 profit rise
summary: ARM Holdings reported a 14% rise in Q1 profit, beating forecasts, due to strong demand for its advanced chips. Revenue reached $398 million, exceeding expectations. ARM's royalties from chip sales grew 15%, outpacing a 3% decline in global semiconductor sales. The company expects full-year revenues to be in line with expectations, despite macroeconomic uncertainty. ARM dominates mobile processing and is expanding into the Internet of Things and enterprise servers.

site_title: UK households see inflation pick-up, earlier BoE move: Markit
summary: UK households have raised their inflation expectations to the highest level in eight months, citing rising income from employment and a pick-up in inflation. The Household Finance Index, compiled by Markit, rose to 45.3, above the no-change mark of 50. For the first time since January, more than half of respondents expect a rise in the base rate over the coming year, while the proportion of households predicting a rate cut decreased. This suggests the Bank of England may consider a long-awaited interest rate hike, contrary to most economists' expectations of a late 2016 or 2017 move.

site_title: Tankers line up at Kuwait oil port after strike ends
summary: Kuwait's oil and gas sector has largely returned to normal after a three-day strike, with six supertankers lining up at the country's crude export terminal to load oil. The strike, which cut crude production by nearly half, has ended, and Kuwait has raised its output to 1.6 million barrels per day. Global oil prices have fallen over $1 a barrel due to the strike's end, easing prompt Dubai monthly spreads. However, delays at the Kuwaiti port and queues of supertankers at other ports, including Iraq and China, persist due to a global oil glut.

site_title: FLASH: Nomination Day for Bukit Batok by-election is Apr 27; Polling Day on May 7
summary: The Bukit Batok by-election in Singapore will take place on May 7, with the nomination day set for April 27. This follows the vacancy created by the death of former Member of Parliament (MP) Dr. Tan Choon Meng. The by-election is expected to be a significant event in Singapore's politics.

site_title: Philippines rushing to auction US$2.76b worth of infrastructure projects
summary: The Philippines is rushing to auction eight infrastructure projects worth US$2.76 billion before President Benigno Aquino steps down in June, amid concerns over a potential leadership change. The projects include five regional airports, a port modernization project, and a railway maintenance deal. Six consortia, including San Miguel Corp and Metro Pacific Investments Corp, have expressed interest in the airport projects. The auction is seen as a key step to award and sign contracts before the June transition.

images.alt_text: The Philippines is scrambling to auction eight infrastructure projects, mostly airports, worth a total of US$2.76 billion, before a leadership change in June, a top official said on Wednesday.

site_title: European stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.2% to 6,391.54 points, and the Paris CAC 40 losing 0.4% to 4,546.35. The decline came after oil prices fell back on Wednesday following a strike in key OPEC producer Kuwait. The drop in oil prices, combined with declining global crude prices, weighed on markets.

site_title: Lukoil CEO sees oil price of US$50 per barrel by year-end
summary: Lukoil CEO Vagit Alekperov forecasts an oil price of US$50 per barrel by year-end, citing a period of "stable oil prices and growth" in the industry. Russian oil companies have adapted to low global prices, and the failed Doha meeting did not have a significant impact. Lukoil is prepared to increase investments and production at its West Qurna-2 oilfield in Iraq, with a potential production peak of 1.2 million barrels per day by 2021.

site_title: China: Shanghai shares tumble on profit-taking, economy and valuation worries
summary: Shanghai stocks plummeted over 2% on Wednesday, breaching a key technical support level, as investors took profits from a long rally due to concerns over the Chinese economy, reduced stimulus hopes, and rising credit risks. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 2.3% to 2,972.58 points, while small-caps were severely affected, with Shenzhen's ChiNext shedding 5.5%. Analysts cited lofty valuations and a lack of fundamentals as contributing factors to the sell-off.

site_title: Passenger car COE premiums in surprise spike
summary: Passenger car COE premiums in Singapore have surged, with Category A (cars below 1,600cc and 130 hp) increasing from S$1,291 to S$47,300, and Category B (cars above 1,600cc or 130 hp) rising from S$2,602 to S$49,602. Category E, the open category, also saw a significant jump to S$49,501. The increases are attributed to a 14.7% increase in COE quotas starting May, with all categories experiencing a boost in numbers.

images.alt_text: The final certificate of entitlement (COE) bidding exercise before next month's new and bigger quota produced unexpected increases in passenger car premiums.

site_title: Queen marks 90th birthday, as popular as ever
summary: Queen Elizabeth II celebrates her 90th birthday with a family gathering and a cake made by reality TV star Nadiya Jamir Hussain. A new poll finds 70% of the British public want her to reign for as long as possible, with 76% expressing support for the monarchy. Despite passing on some duties to younger royals, the queen remains popular and dedicated to her role, with Prince William paying tribute to her as "the boss". The queen will mark her birthday with low-key events, including a military parade and a family dinner, with US President Barack Obama and UK Prime Minister David Cameron also paying their respects.

site_title: Germany plans to boost electric cars via tax exemption: newspaper
summary: Germany's coalition parties plan to boost demand for electric cars by exempting them from vehicle tax for 10 years for purchases made by 2020. A research programme to develop batteries is also being considered. The goal is to increase the number of electric cars on German roads to 1 million by 2020, a significant increase from the current 50,000. This move aims to address the country's lag in electric car adoption, which is influenced by a strong demand for petrol and diesel engines among German drivers.

site_title: Heineken starts year strongly, but cautious on Nigeria
summary: Heineken NV, the world's third-largest brewer, reported a 7.0% like-for-like increase in beer volumes to 43.5 million hectolitres in the first quarter, exceeding expectations. The brewer retained its full-year forecast despite currency fluctuations and warned of difficulties in Nigeria due to the lower oil price. Despite this, Heineken remained cautious on the Nigerian market.

site_title: British surveyors report weakest private housing growth in nearly 3 years
summary: British surveyors report the weakest private housing growth in nearly 3 years, citing planning delays and EU referendum uncertainty. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said growth in private housebuilding slowed sharply in the first quarter of 2016, with fewer expected growth over the next 12 months. The government aims to build 200,000 homes for first-time buyers by 2020, but planning delays and uncertainty are hindering progress.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends slightly stronger, underpinned by Wall Street's gains
summary: Japanese stocks edged up on Wednesday, with the Nikkei share average ending 0.2% higher at 16,906.54, driven by Wall Street's gains and the dollar trading above 109 yen. However, the yen's firming marginally against the dollar hampered exporters' prospects. Mitsubishi Motor Corp shares plummeted 15% after announcing misconduct in fuel economy tests. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also rose 0.2%.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall tracking China, HK markets
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 1.3% to 8,526.17, tracking losses in Chinese and Hong Kong equities, erasing early gains. The electronics and financials subindices also declined, with the electronics subindex sinking 1.2% and the financials subindex losing 0.6%.

site_title: Nestle extends pharma push with new bet on gut drugs
summary: Nestle has invested 14.5 million euros (US$16.5 million) in biotech company Enterome Bioscience, which is developing a gut drug to combat inflammatory bowel disease by restoring a healthy gut bacteria balance. The investment aims to advance the development of its leading drug candidate, with the company also working on diagnostic tests for the condition. This move extends Nestle's push into medicine, following its previous investments in pharmaceuticals and diagnostics.

site_title: Half of Australia's Great Barrier Reef coral "dead or dying": scientists
summary: Australian scientists report that half of the Great Barrier Reef's coral is "dead or dying" due to mass bleaching caused by rising sea temperatures. Only 7% of the reef remains untouched. Professor Terry Hughes described the bleaching as "like 10 cyclones have come ashore all at once." The bleaching is expected to destroy the remaining coral, which attracts around $5 billion in tourism annually.

site_title: EU citizens fear Brexit more than the Brits: survey
summary: European citizens are more concerned about a potential Brexit than the British people themselves, according to a survey. 78% of Germans, 67% of Spaniards, and 60% of French want Britain to stay in the EU, while 38% of Britons back staying and 34% want to leave. The survey was conducted two months before the UK's June 23 referendum on whether to leave the EU.

images.alt_text: European citizens are more concerned about a so-called Brexit than the British people themselves, said a survey published on Wednesday, two months before Britain votes on whether to leave the European Union.

site_title: Australia: Shares end up on strong showing by iron ore miners
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Wednesday, driven by gains in major iron ore producers BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, which lifted the S&P/ASX 200 index to 5216.00, just shy of a 3-1/2-month high. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also gained 0.411%. The rally followed stronger iron ore prices, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto experiencing significant gains.

site_title: Bukit Batok to vote for new MP on May 7
summary: Bukit Batok to hold a by-election on May 7, with approximately 25,600 eligible residents voting for their new Member of Parliament (MP) after former People's Action Party (PAP) lawmaker David Ong's resignation. The Elections Department announced April 27 as Nomination Day, and polling stations will open on May 8.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: France to extend state of emergency to cover Euro 2016 football tournament
summary: France plans to extend its state of emergency for two months to ensure security at the Euro 2016 soccer tournament, set to start on June 10. The current state of emergency, which runs until May 26, will be prolonged to cover the tournament. Prime Minister Manuel Valls stated that the state of emergency is necessary for big events like the tournament, despite it not being a permanent solution.

site_title: Hong Kong: Share index sheds 0.9% as China tumble sours sentiment
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 0.9% to 21,236.31, its largest loss in two weeks, due to a sharp sell-off in mainland China markets. The China Enterprises Index also declined 1.2%. The market was dragged down by the Shanghai market's worst performance in eight weeks, with all main sectors falling. Tencent Holdings Ltd fell 1.9% after its founder announced a $2 billion donation to a charity fund.

site_title: Crude falls in Asia as Kuwait oil workers end strike
summary: Oil prices resumed their decline in Asia after Kuwait oil workers ended a three-day strike, halting a brief rise in prices. The strike, which cut Kuwait's production by more than half, was called off after the oil minister appealed to workers. Despite the short-term impact, analysts say the general trend of oversupply remains. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 2.41% to $40.09 a barrel, while Brent crude fell 2.23% to $43.05 a barrel.

site_title: SMRT to showcase automated vehicle system by year-end
summary: SMRT Corporation, a Singaporean rail operator, will showcase an automated vehicle system by the end of this year in partnership with Dutch developer 2getthere. The joint venture, 2getthere Asia Pte Ltd, will be 51% owned by SMRT and 49% by 2getthere, and will feature 2getthere's automated vehicles, including the six-metre-long Group Rapid Transit (GRT) and smaller Personal Rapid Transit (PRT) models. The partnership aims to provide future mobility solutions for Singapore's first and last-mile connectivity needs.

site_title: Aftershocks bring misery for Japan quake survivors; death toll to 47
summary: Aftershocks from Japan's deadly earthquakes, which killed 47 and displaced nearly 100,000, continue to affect survivors. Hundreds of people remain in cars due to fear of landslides and aftershocks, with some experiencing "economy class syndrome" due to prolonged sitting. Heavy rain is expected, raising concerns of further damage. Authorities have begun condemning unsafe structures, including homes with traditional tile roofs. Experts warn of the danger of further quakes and landslides, with some areas expected to experience temperatures above 25C.

site_title: Asia: Stocks take breather, oil down as Kuwait strike ends
summary: Asian shares moved cautiously, struggling to extend the previous day's surge, as oil prices fell after a strike in key producer Kuwait was called off. The US and European markets rallied, driven by upbeat German data and gains in oil prices, while commodity prices retreated. Equity markets in Asia moved in and out of positive territory, with profit-taking offsetting optimism over the world economy. The Fed is expected to delay raising interest rates amid signs of weakness in the US economy.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors to brief on misconduct in fuel economy tests
summary: Mitsubishi Motors will address misconduct in fuel economy tests at a news conference on Wednesday. The company confirmed one of its models failed part of a fuel economy test. President Tetsuro Aikawa will attend the conference, which is expected to discuss the issue. Shares in the Japanese automaker plummeted over 15% in their largest one-day drop in nearly 12 years, likely due to the misconduct allegations.

site_title: China's central bank injects most funds in almost two months
summary: China's central bank injected 250 billion yuan (S$52 billion) into the financial system through open-market operations, the largest injection in nearly two months, to avoid a seasonal cash squeeze. The move aims to keep borrowing costs low despite the economy showing signs of stabilization. Private economists have upgraded their growth forecasts, with Goldman Sachs predicting a 6.6% GDP growth for 2016. The central bank has also increased its short-term cash injections to meet the seasonal demand, with maturing loans and tax bills expected to drain over 1 trillion yuan from the financial system in April.

site_title: Payday borrowers can pay hundreds in bank fees: US consumer agency
summary: US consumer agency reports that online payday lenders often collect loan payments by automatically debiting bank accounts, resulting in borrowers incurring an average of $185 in bank fees and penalties. Half of borrowers experience overdrafts or failed debits, with a third losing their accounts due to negative balances or excessive fees. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is set to propose a rule to limit payday lenders to two consecutive attempts to debit a borrower's account. This move aims to protect lower-income individuals who often rely on payday loans.

site_title: Toshiba preparing Westinghouse writedown, CEO to step down: source
summary: Toshiba is preparing to write down the value of its Westinghouse stake by around 200 billion yen ($2.45 billion) amid efforts to address a US$1.3 billion accounting scandal and streamline its bloated businesses. Toshiba's CEO, Masashi Muromachi, is set to step down following a company committee meeting. The company aims to move on from the scandal and improve its financial performance.

site_title: China suspends G20 anti-corruption task force: sources
summary: China suspended the G20 anti-corruption task force, which aimed to increase transparency of offshore financial structures, after Chinese companies declined to participate. The task force, led by a company from the nation holding the presidency, was suspended in late January. The decision has been met with disappointment from international businesses and NGOs, who had built up momentum on the task force. China's reluctance to cooperate on anti-corruption efforts has been a concern, despite President Xi Jinping's efforts to crack down on corruption.

site_title: China's CIC, KKR consortium in talks to buy control of Yum China unit: sources
summary: A group of investors, including China Investment Corp, KKR & Co, and Baring Private Equity Asia, are in talks to buy a controlling stake in Yum China, the Chinese unit of Yum Brands Inc. The deal could value Yum China at $7 billion-$8 billion. The US-based company plans to spin off its 6,900 China restaurants by the end of 2016, as it struggles to revive flagging sales in the face of growing competition from local rivals and a slowing economy.

site_title: Japan's Suga: Situation after Kyushu quakes not like post-March 2011
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that conditions following the recent Kyushu earthquakes are not comparable to the situation after the 2011 disasters, contradicting previous remarks. Suga reiterated plans to raise the sales tax to 10% in April unless a major crisis occurs. The government has also ruled out a staged increase in the sales tax, despite suggestions by a ruling party official.

images.alt_text: Japan's top government spokesman said on Wednesday conditions following the deadly earthquakes in the southern island of Kyushu this month were not similar to the situation after the natural disasters in March 2011.

site_title: Indonesia expects wider fiscal deficit in 2017: deputy fin min
summary: Indonesia's deputy finance minister expects a wider fiscal deficit of 2.3-2.6% of GDP in 2017, larger than the planned 2.15% for 2016, due to a weaker rupiah and stronger economic growth. The government projects 5.5-5.9% economic growth and 4% inflation in 2017, with crude oil selling at $35-45 per barrel. This is part of the 2017 state budget preparation.

site_title: Communist Laos appoints new president, prime minister
summary: Laos' National Assembly has appointed Communist Party chief Bounnhang Vorachit as the country's new president and named foreign minister Thongloun Sisoulith as prime minister. The moves are seen as a continuation of the status quo in secretive Laos, where the communists have ruled since the end of the Vietnam War. Bounnhang vowed to pursue "peaceful international policies" and unity, while Laos continues to grapple with the legacy of the Vietnam War and unexploded ordnance devices. The country's economy, one of the fastest-growing in East Asia, has averaged 7% GDP growth over the past decade.

images.alt_text: Laos's National Assembly on Wednesday appointed Communist Party chief Bounnhang Vorachit as the country's new president and named foreign minister Thongloun Sisoulith as prime minister.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares hit more than 3-1/2-mth high, NZ shares edge lower
summary: Australian shares rose nearly 0.5% on Wednesday, reaching a 3-1/2-month high, driven by stronger commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 17.1 points to 5,205.8, with miners leading the way, particularly BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. However, the financials segment weighed on the index, with shares in major banks falling. New Zealand's benchmark index edged down 0.13%, while shares in dairy company A2 Milk rose 2.17% after global milk prices increased.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda signals readiness to top up ETF purchases
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda signaled readiness to top up purchases of exchange-traded funds (ETFs), citing the market's size as "not too big." The central bank holds about 7.8 trillion yen in ETFs, roughly half of Japan's market. Kuroda suggested topping up ETF purchases could be a strong future policy option to affect risk premium and boost asset prices, amid a stock market tumble and weak global growth threatening Japan's economic recovery. A rate review next week may discuss further easing monetary policy measures.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Wednesday the central bank's presence in the exchange-traded fund (ETF) market is "not too big," signalling that topping up purchases of ETFs could be a real, near-term option.

site_title: Hot stock: China Star Food shoots up on debut trading
summary: China Star Food Group, a Fujian-based food products company, made a successful debut on the Catalist exchange, with shares rising 24% to 28.5 cents on active trade. The company had completed a S$168 million reverse takeover of Brooke Asia in September last year and issued 25.25 million placement shares at 23 Singapore cents apiece.

site_title: Gold advances for second day as silver extends bull-market rally
summary: Gold prices rose for a second day, gaining 0.3% to $1,254.10 an ounce, driven by the US dollar's 10-month low and demand for alternative investments. Silver extended its bull-market rally, increasing 0.6% to $17.03 an ounce. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell to its weakest level since June, citing new-home construction in the US. Financial-market turmoil and global economic concerns have driven gold and silver prices up 18% and 23% this year, respectively.

site_title: United Airlines poised to shake up board further: sources
summary: United Airlines is set to announce new board appointments, including Barney Harford and Edward Shapiro, to settle with activist investors PAR Capital Management Inc and Altimeter Capital Management LP. The deal avoids a fight over a proposed slate of six new directors, including Gordon Bethune. United President and CEO Oscar Munoz will postpone his non-executive chairman appointment to 2018, and Robert Milton will become non-executive chairman at the annual meeting in June. The settlement stops short of the activists' requested slate and avoids a protracted fight over the board.

site_title: Thai Airways Q1 revenue 1% lower than 49b baht target
summary: Thai Airways International Pcl's Q1 revenue fell 1% short of its 49 billion baht target, according to President Charumporn Jotikasthira. The carrier is undergoing a restructuring plan and aims to return to annual profit this year. Thai Airways is one of several state-controlled companies undergoing reform since the military seized power in 2014. The airline posted a smaller annual loss in 2015 due to reduced operating expenses and fuel costs, with a goal of becoming one of the world's top five airlines this year.

images.alt_text: Thai Airways International Pcl's Q1 revenue came in one per cent below its 49 billion baht (S$1.87 billion) target, the company's President Charumporn Jotikasthira said on Wednesday.

site_title: From Paris to New York, climate pact to cross next hurdle
summary: More than 160 nations will gather in New York on April 22 to sign the Paris climate pact, following a four-month agreement to combat global warming. The pact, which requires a radical overhaul of the global economy, must be ratified by 55 countries responsible for 55% of global greenhouse gases to enter into force. This marks an important step after the agreement was sealed in Paris on December 12. The pact's next hurdle is ratification, which will pave the way for a significant shift in the global economy to combat climate change.

site_title: Air quality in eastern China improves but slips elsewhere: Greenpeace
summary: Air quality in eastern China improved in the first quarter, with key population centers like Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangdong experiencing cleaner air due to government policies. However, central and western regions saw worsening air pollution as investment in coal-fired power plants increases, with lax emissions regulations. This trend is expected to worsen air quality in these areas, contradicting the improvements in eastern China, according to a Greenpeace report analyzing government data.

site_title: China said to mull Shenzhen-Hong Kong link approval before July
summary: China is considering approval of a stock-trading link between Shenzhen and Hong Kong exchanges before July, possibly coinciding with a visit by a high-ranking official. The connection, which would be the second link between the mainland and Hong Kong, would allow offshore investors to access Chinese technology and high-growth shares. The China Securities Regulatory Commission did not immediately respond to a comment request. An official approval may not include a commencement date, and the timing may change. Premier Li Keqiang had previously stated that the link would be initiated this year.

site_title: China wants ships to use faster Arctic route opened by global warming
summary: China plans to encourage ships flying its flag to take the Northwest Passage via the Arctic Ocean, a route opened by global warming, to cut travel times between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. This move aims to save time and money for Chinese companies. The Arctic route is 2,800 nautical miles shorter than the Suez canal, and China is increasingly active in the polar region with investments in mining and trade deals. The move is part of China's efforts to expand its influence in the Arctic region.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars carried by yield play
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose to near 10-month peaks due to fading concerns about global growth and rising metal prices, sparking demand for carry trades. The Australian dollar reached US$0.7827 on Tuesday and is now at US$0.7785, with a potential target at US$0.8164. Rising iron ore prices and ultra-loose monetary policies in Japan and Europe are supporting the Aussie. The New Zealand dollar also rose, reaching a 10-month peak of US$0.7055, driven by a rise in global dairy prices.

site_title: Clinton defeats Sanders in New York, solidifying hold on race
summary: Hillary Clinton won the New York Democratic primary, solidifying her hold on the presidential nomination. Clinton defeated Bernie Sanders, despite trailing him in votes and delegates, by emphasizing her New York roots and ability to deliver results. Clinton now leads the delegate race with a 1,758-1,076 advantage over Sanders, making it difficult for him to catch up. She is next scheduled to compete in primaries in Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, and Rhode Island, where her campaign hopes to accumulate a lead in delegates.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks strengthen on oil bounce
summary: South Korea's won strengthened to 1,131.4 against the US dollar, its highest level since early November, due to a rise in global oil prices and risk appetite. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.1% to 2,014.24 points, with offshore investors purchasing a net 81.9 billion won of KOSPI shares. The won's gains were attributed to reduced government intervention, as officials await a US report on exchange rate policies that may determine if South Korea is designated a currency manipulator.

site_title: China's yuan opens slightly weaker, shrugs off central bank's stronger midpoint
summary: China's yuan opened slightly weaker against the US dollar on April 20, 2016, despite a stronger official guidance rate set by the central bank. Corporate dollar demand remained strong, offsetting the rate increase, due to increased overseas asset purchases by Chinese companies. The yuan opened at 6.4642 per US dollar, narrowly moving around the opening in early trade. This move was influenced by the US dollar's weakening in global markets and a growing appetite for risky assets.

site_title: Restructuring, softer economy main reasons for redundancies in 2015: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore reported 15,580 redundancies in 2015, up from 12,930 in 2014, mainly due to restructuring and softer economic conditions. The redundancies were concentrated in manufacturing and professional services, with 8,550 PMETs laid off. Residents were less vulnerable to redundancy, with a lower incidence rate compared to foreigners. Despite the rise in redundancies, the unemployment rate remained low, and 81% of residents who re-entered employment secured a new job within three months.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose in early trade on April 20, 2016, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.08% and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.25%. Analysts warned that gains would be limited as investors cash in profits.

site_title: Asian investors ink US$3.6b deal to buy Lexmark
summary: Lexmark International has agreed to sell itself to a consortium of Asian investors for $3.6 billion. The deal, led by Apex Technology, will take the US printer maker private if cleared by shareholders and regulators. The sale is expected to close in the second half of this year and will allow the company to focus on expanding its business in the Asia Pacific market. Lexmark's headquarters will remain in Kentucky, and the company's management team will continue to work with the new investors.

site_title: Obama dives into Brexit debate on London trip
summary: US President Barack Obama will visit London ahead of the June 23 Brexit referendum, where he will be asked to weigh in on the issue of European Union membership. Obama has consistently favored a strong Britain within a strong EU, and his visit may reinforce this message. However, pro-Brexit supporters, including London Mayor Boris Johnson, have criticized Obama's comments, calling them "outrageous and exorbitant hypocrisy." The visit could have significant implications for Washington's "special relationship" with Britain and the stability of the European Union.

site_title: Crude futures fall after Kuwaiti oil workers end strike
summary: Crude futures fell globally after Kuwaiti oil workers ended a three-day strike, cutting production from the Middle Eastern country. Kuwaiti crude production, which had been reduced to 1.1 million barrels per day, recovered to around 1.5 million bpd. The strike's end revived bearish market sentiment, which was also fueled by US crude stockpiles rising 3.1 million barrels in the week to April 15. Brent crude futures fell 55 US cents to $43.48 a barrel, while US crude fell 66 US cents to $40.36 a barrel.

site_title: New Zealand steps up scrutiny of RBNZ after inflation misses
summary: New Zealand Finance Minister Bill English has stepped up oversight of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), sending a "letter of expectations" to the bank's board for the first time. The letter outlines English's specific interests for the board's monitoring role and sets expectations for regular meetings to discuss the bank's performance. The move comes as Governor Graeme Wheeler struggles to return inflation to the 1-3% target band, and faces criticism for his communication. English's request for more information is seen as a routine practice, with similar letters sent to other state entities.

site_title: Perennial to issue up to S$200m of bonds in public offer
summary: PERENNIAL Real Estate Holdings announced a public offer to issue up to S$200 million of bonds due 2020 with a 4.55% coupon rate, with an option to issue an additional S$100 million if oversubscribed. The bonds have an issue price of S$1 per S$1 principal amount.

site_title: Japan PM Abe unlikely to call snap election due to quakes: Sankei
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is unlikely to call a snap election after deadly earthquakes on southern Kyushu island, citing the need to focus on reconstruction efforts. The quakes, which killed 44 people, have also led to a postponement of the ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement. Abe is expected to delay a planned sales tax hike, previously set for next April, amid concerns about the economic impact of the disasters.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is unlikely to call a snap election after deadly earthquakes on southern Kyushu island and may postpone ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade agreement until the next session of parliament, the Sankei newspaper reported Wednesday.

site_title: Food fraudsters targeted with software to protect your cheese
summary: A software called EMAlert, developed by Battelle Memorial Institute, uses methods to predict terrorist behavior to detect food fraud. The program models the decision-making behavior of fraudsters and weighs 12 attributes, including prices and geopolitical conditions, to calculate the probability of adulteration. This technology aims to protect consumers from food fraud, which has been on the rise, with cases including Parmesan cheese, olive oil, and fish being mislabeled. The software is seen as a solution to the growing issue of consumer distrust in the food supply, with some estimates suggesting up to 10% of food in the marketplace may be adulterated.

site_title: Panama president denies country is tax haven
summary: Panama President Juan Carlos Varela denied his country is a tax haven, amid the global "Panama Papers" scandal that revealed offshore dealings of wealthy individuals. Varela established a high-level commission to improve transparency of Panama's financial system, including Nobel Prize-winning economist Joseph Stiglitz. The country will also cooperate with an Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development initiative to share tax information. Varela's visit to Japan came after the Group of 20 nations supported proposals to share identities of shell companies' real owners and create a blacklist of tax havens.

images.alt_text: Panama has been "wrongly" labelled a tax haven, President Juan Carlos Varela said in an interview with a Japanese news agency, defending his country amid the global "Panama Papers" scandal.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC keeps 'buy' on CapitaLand, with fair value at S$3.68 a share
summary: OCBC Investment Research maintains a "buy" rating on CapitaLand, citing a 35.4% increase in net profit to S$218.3 million in the first quarter. Analyst Eli Lee has set a fair-value estimate at S$3.68 per share. As of the article's date, CapitaLand's share price was trading at S$3.20, down 0.62%.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.2% higher on Wednesday, driven by upbeat US stock performances and oil price recovery. The Straits Times Index rose 6.03 points to 2,957.84, with gains led by Singapore Telecommunications, Acromec, and Noble. The market saw 80.2 million shares traded, with 78 gainers and 38 losers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.180 points to 1713.360. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 55, with a total trading volume of 33 million lots worth RM13.9 million.

site_title: Australia government boosts resources, power for market watchdog
summary: Australia's Treasurer Scott Morrison announced a boost to the resources and power of the market regulator, the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC), with an additional A$120 million. The move aims to enhance ASIC's ability to investigate financial misconduct amid growing calls for a Royal Commission inquiry. ASIC will also receive a new commissioner with prosecuting experience and Chairman Greg Medcraft's term will be extended by 18 months, ahead of a general election in July.

site_title: Trump wins in New York, moves closer to Republican nomination
summary: Donald Trump won New York's presidential nominating contest, moving closer to capturing the Republican White House nomination with 95 delegates. Trump secured more than 50% of the vote, surpassing rivals Ted Cruz and John Kasich. The victory sets him up for a strong performance in upcoming Northeastern states. Trump now needs 1,237 delegates to secure the nomination, and a contested convention is possible if he falls short. The outcome also affects the Democratic nomination, where Hillary Clinton seeks to wrap up the nomination.

site_title: Manulife revives office Reit IPO plan: report
summary: Manulife, a Canadian financial services group, is reviving its plan to list an initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore of its US office Reit. The deal, expected to raise around $500 million, aims for a May 20 listing. The new deal offers a 6.5-7% annualized dividend yield, higher than the previous deal. Manulife has removed one US office building from its portfolio and added two new Grade-A office buildings in Atlanta, Georgia, increasing the portfolio's total net lettable area by 23%. The net asset value is expected to increase by 10.5% to $799 million.

site_title: Saudi Arabia said to hire bankers for planned US$2t sovereign wealth fund
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is hiring senior bankers to manage a potential $2 trillion sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest, according to sources. The fund, which currently holds $100 billion, aims to expand to $2 trillion by diversifying its investments and preparing for the oil age's end. Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman announced the plan earlier this month, seeking experienced international candidates to fill key positions, including private equity, real estate, and risk management.

site_title: Shops and shophouses overtake homes in auctions in Q1: Knight Frank
summary: Shops and shophouses surpassed residential properties in total sales value in auctions in Q1, with S$5.5 million worth of sales, more than double the S$2.5 million for residential properties. This marked the first time since 2014 that residential properties were not the top sellers in auctions. The shift may be due to buyers avoiding the additional buyers' stamp duty, which only applies to residential properties. The total number of properties put up for auction decreased 19.4% quarter-over-quarter, but shops and shophouses saw a 145.5% increase in units.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks extend global equities rally
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for the second straight session, extending a global equities rally. The Nikkei 225 index increased 1.06% to 17,053.83, while the Topix index rose 0.89% to 1,375.11. The gains followed positive leads from Wall Street and rising oil prices. This rally comes despite ongoing uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: US, other countries call for urgent action on steel overcapacity
summary: The US and seven other countries, including Canada, the European Union, and Japan, have called for urgent action to address global steel overcapacity. They agree that steel industry restructuring must be market-driven and that governments should not provide subsidies to sustain loss-making plants. The US and its partners will continue to lobby for action with trade partners, including China, which they blame for the crisis. China denies it is not taking sufficient steps to curb capacity, and its steel production reached a record high last month.

site_title: SMRT forms JV firm with 2 Getthere Holding
summary: SMRT Corporation formed a joint-venture (JV) agreement with 2 Getthere Holding BV to market, supply, and operate automated vehicle systems in the Asia-Pacific. A JV company, 2getthere Asia Pte Ltd, was incorporated in Singapore on Tuesday. The parties will finalize and execute the definitive JV agreement within the agreed deadline, marking the partnership's next step.

site_title: Plato Capital to issue S$10m of convertible stocks to controlling shareholder
summary: PLATO Capital plans to issue S$10 million of redeemable convertible unsecured stocks (RCULS) to its controlling shareholder Lim Kian Onn. The RCULS, due 2021, have a principal value of S$100,000 and 0.5% interest per annum. The issue is subject to shareholder approval and Lim obtaining a waiver to avoid a mandatory general offer. This move is aimed at raising capital for the group.

site_title: Ringgit rises a second day on resurgent oil as US dollar weakens
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose for a second day, its biggest two-day rally in three weeks, as Brent crude surged to an eight-month high and the US dollar weakened due to poor housing data. The US dollar hit a 10-month low, with only 16% odds of a rate hike by June. This provides relief for the oil exporter, whose finances were impacted by the World Bank's cut to the nation's growth forecast. The ringgit is now trading near an eight-month high.

site_title: BHP Billiton weighs getting out of Indonesian coal
summary: BHP Billiton is considering giving up its coal stakes in Indonesia due to uncertainty over regulations and a weak coal outlook. The company, which holds a 75% stake in IndoMet Coal, has been conducting a strategic review of its Indonesian coal interests. BHP last year started producing coal at the Haju mine, but has held off larger developments amid regulatory uncertainty. The company's decision comes as Indonesia's Adaro Energy holds the remaining 25% stake in IndoMet, which is estimated to hold at least 1.27 billion tonnes of resources.

site_title: Japan March exports fall 6.8% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports fell 6.8% in March from the previous year, marking the sixth consecutive decline, as a slowdown in China and emerging markets hurt external demand. Imports also fell 14.9% in March, resulting in a trade balance surplus of 755 billion yen. The data follows a 4.0% drop in February and compares to economists' expectations of a 6.9% decrease.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, SMRT, Acromec
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Stocks to watch on April 20, 2016, include CapitaLand's 35.4% increase in net profit to S$218.3 million, SMRT's joint-venture agreement with 2 Getthere Holding BV for automated vehicle systems, and Acromec's secured contracts totaling S$7.1 million. SMRT also announced a partnership with ride-booking platform Grab. These updates may provide trading impetus.

site_title: Bank of Canada head says inflation target still 'live issue'
summary: Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz stated that the central bank is closely examining its inflation target of 2% as it prepares to discuss its mandate with the government. The threshold for changing the target is high due to its successful framework, but Poloz described it as a "live issue." The bank is also evaluating the right measure of inflation and integrating financial stability concerns. Recent Canadian data have been encouraging but variable, and concrete evidence of higher investment is lacking.

site_title: Kuwait oil, gas workers end three-day strike
summary: Kuwaiti oil and gas workers have ended a three-day strike that temporarily cut crude production by nearly half, with the Oil & Petrochemicals Industries Workers Confederation announcing the cancellation of the general strike and return to work. The strike, which began over planned public sector pay cuts, will continue until the government overhaul is canceled. Kuwait's oil minister stated that production will continue despite the strike, and negotiations will not proceed during the strike. US oil prices fell slightly following the news, which came after oil production recovered to around 1.5 million barrels per day.

site_title: Britain to give lawmakers veto power over banking regulator appointment
summary: Britain's finance minister George Osborne plans to give parliament a veto over future appointments to the Financial Conduct Authority, the country's banking regulator. The move comes after concerns that the FCA was being politicized. The new system would give the Treasury Select Committee a recommendation to parliament on the FCA's chief executive, with parliament having the final say. However, critics argue that this will only politicize the appointment process.

site_title: CapitaLand's Q1 profit up 35% mainly on fair-value gain
summary: CapitaLand reported a 35.4% increase in net profit after tax and minority interest to S$218.3 million for Q1 2016, driven by a fair-value gain from the divestment of a Chinese property for S$125 million. Revenue dipped 2.3% to S$894.2 million, but operating profit grew 10.6% excluding gains from property changes. The company expects to ride through market challenges and seize opportunities, focusing on core markets and growth markets.

site_title: Pound advances for third day as global stocks, crude rally
summary: The pound strengthened for a third consecutive day, reaching its strongest level this month against the euro and US dollar. Bank of England Governor Mark Carney stated that a Brexit would be "unhelpful" for the UK economy, contradicting expectations of a potential currency devaluation. Global stocks and crude oil futures also rallied, contributing to the pound's gain. Despite a risk premium remaining high before the June 23 Brexit vote, analysts believe a persistently bad news flow may not be enough to stop the pound's strengthening.

images.alt_text: The pound gained for a third day as a rally in global stocks brought some relief for this year's worst- performing major currency.

site_title: Asia: Stocks set for second day of gains after commodities jump
summary: Asian stocks are poised to rise for a second day after the S&P 500 Index reached a four-month high and commodities jumped 2.5% on Tuesday. Futures indicate gains in Japan, Australia, and Hong Kong, while the yen holds losses ahead of a report on Japan's exports. The "risk on" tone in markets has led to speculation that the Bank of Japan may ease monetary policy further, hurting exporters. The Bloomberg Commodity Index, a measure of 22 components, jumped its biggest gain since August 27.

site_title: Bank of England's Carney hits back at critics over EU comments
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney defended his comments on the potential economic impact of a Brexit vote, stating it's the Bank's duty to assess risks and report them. Carney warned that a Brexit could hurt the economy and weaken sterling, echoing a report by the British finance ministry. He acknowledged the potential for a weaker growth outlook and higher inflation, and said monetary policy would aim to meet the inflation target while anchoring expectations.

images.alt_text: Bank of England governor Mark Carney hit back at critics who have accused him of venturing into politics with his comments that a vote to leave the European Union could hurt Britain's economy, saying it would be political for him to stay silent.

site_title: AccorHotels sales rise despite France and Brazil as Jin Jiang ups stake
summary: AccorHotels reported higher underlying sales despite weaker performance in France and Brazil, driven by robust demand in most markets. The company's first quarter revenue reached €1.161 billion, a 1.9% increase excluding currency effects, acquisitions, and disposals. Jin Jiang International further increased its stake in AccorHotels to 14.98% of its capital and 13.07% of its voting rights. The group's domestic business is expected to return to positive year-on-year growth in the second quarter, driven by the Euro 2016 soccer tournament.
