site_title: In Malaysia's biggest state, indifference to Najib is his friend
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak's coalition is expected to retain power in the Sarawak state election on May 7, despite opposition efforts to capitalize on the 1MDB scandal. In rural areas, where basic issues such as electricity and water supply are more pressing concerns, Najib's opponents have struggled to gain traction. Najib has made several visits to Sarawak, promising infrastructure projects and development, which may help him retain support in the state. A court ruling on vote-buying in a 1996 election has also been cited as a challenge to opposition efforts.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise to 3-month high; Roche, Danone gain on sales
summary: European stocks rose to a 3-month high, driven by gains in miners and better-than-forecast sales from Danone and L'Oreal. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index climbed 1.5% to its highest close since January, with Anglo American up 8.5% and Akzo Nobel up 5.4%. The European gauge has still fallen 16% since its record last year, but optimism over bond-buying measures by the European Central Bank has given way to skepticism about its efficacy.

site_title: US Senate passes bill to boost travel security after Brussels
summary: The US Senate passed a bill to boost domestic travel security, sending it to the House of Representatives, after the Brussels attacks. The bipartisan measure includes provisions to double bomb-sniffing dog teams, strengthen airport vetting and security, and authorize FAA spending. The bill also addresses commercial drones and requires airlines to compensate passengers for lost bags. Senate Chairman John Thune said the legislation would make travel "safe and secure and more passenger-friendly." The Senate's 95-3 vote sidesteps privatization of the air traffic control system, a point of contention with the House.

site_title: Emerging market debt mountain grows too large for comfort
summary: Global investors are increasingly cautious about emerging market sovereign bonds due to rich valuations and high supply from countries with slowing growth. The International Monetary Fund cut its world economy outlook for the fourth time, citing poor emerging market growth as a risk factor. Despite favorable factors such as low interest rates, investors are forced to hold longer-duration debt, increasing the risk of defaults. Countries like Argentina and China are raising billions of dollars in debt, which could become more expensive if US rates rise, further exacerbating the risk of defaults.

site_title: Canada's competition watchdog drops probe into Google
summary: Canada's Competition Bureau has dropped its investigation into Google, citing evidence supporting one of the allegations against the company but finding insufficient evidence to support others. Google had made changes to remedy concerns and agreed not to reintroduce anticompetitive clauses in its contracts. The decision comes as Google faces charges from the European competition commission, which could fine the company up to $7.4 billion and force it to change its business practices. Google's Android mobile operating system and Chrome web browser also raised concerns, with the EU potentially charging the company with giving unfair prominence to its own apps.

site_title: VW "Dieselgate" software developed at Audi in 1999: report
summary: Audi engineers developed "defeat devices" to cut emissions in 1999, 6 years before parent company Volkswagen (VW) used similar software in 2005 to cheat diesel emissions tests. VW's emissions scandal involved 11 million diesel cars across its brands. Audi's software was never used, but VW engineers installed it after failing to meet emissions thresholds. VW and Audi declined to comment on the report, citing ongoing investigations. A report by US law firm Jones Day is expected to be published by the end of April, detailing the findings of the diesel emissions scandal.

site_title: US: Stocks hold gains despite key blue-chip earnings drops
summary: US stocks ended with modest gains on Thursday despite disappointing earnings from Goldman Sachs and IBM, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 49.44 points (0.27%) to 18,053.60. The Nasdaq Composite Index, however, fell 19.69 (0.40%) due to Netflix's 13% plunge. Tech stocks were also affected by Google's possible antitrust charges in Europe. Despite this, strong earnings reports from Johnson & Johnson and UnitedHealth Group supported the broader market.

site_title: Washington seeks Gulf special force, naval cooperation
summary: The US is seeking greater special forces and naval cooperation with Gulf states to counter Iran's "destabilising activities" in the region. Defence Secretary Ashton Carter will meet with Gulf counterparts to discuss ways to prevent Iran from supplying Shiite groups, and the US is proposing to help train Gulf special forces and develop their naval capacity. The US also plans to increase support for Iraq to combat the Islamic State group, and Carter will urge Gulf states to provide funds and support to the Iraqi government.

site_title: 165 Air France passengers stuck in Montreal
summary: Air France passengers, 165 in total, are stranded in Montreal after a scheduled departure to Paris on Sunday turned back due to a breakdown. Passengers are being transferred to other Air France flights on Tuesday night, with the rest traveling on competitor airlines such as KLM and Air Canada. All passengers are expected to reach Paris by Wednesday, with some passengers expressing frustration over the prolonged wait.

site_title: In a world of look-alike cars, can Japanese pop culture heroes help?
summary: Japanese automakers, including Nissan and Toyota, are incorporating elements of Japanese pop culture to differentiate their designs and give them a unique "J-factor." Designers are drawing inspiration from anime and manga franchises, such as Gundam and Pokémon, to create cars with distinctive shapes and features. This approach aims to set Japanese brands apart from other global automakers and tap into the country's rich cultural heritage. By incorporating elements of Japanese pop culture, Nissan and Toyota hope to create cars that not only look unique but also evoke a sense of national pride and identity.

site_title: Airbus close to selling 37 A321 jets to Delta
summary: Airbus is close to a deal to sell 37 current-generation A321 passenger jets to Delta Air Lines for $4.3 billion at list prices. The deal, if finalized, would be worth a significant amount to Airbus. However, a Delta spokesman stated that no decision has been made on any aircraft transaction, suggesting the deal may not be confirmed yet.

site_title: Clinton, Trump tipped to win as New York votes
summary: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump are favored to win the New York presidential primary, with Clinton leading by a double-digit margin and Trump well ahead of Ted Cruz and John Kasich. A victory in New York would secure the Democratic and Republican nominations, respectively, and give Clinton a strong chance to clinch the nomination. Trump is banking on a big home-state victory to sew up the nomination before the Republican convention in July.

site_title: Indonesia's Garuda in US$4b Airbus A330 order
summary: Indonesian carrier Garuda has signed a firm purchase order for 14 Airbus A330-900neo airliners worth US$4 billion. The deal, sealed in London, is designed to bolster Garuda's expansion and replaces an existing order for seven A330-300 planes. Deliveries are expected to begin in 2019, replacing the older aircraft.

site_title: North Korea on path to develop inter-continental missiles: US general
summary: US General Vincent Brooks warns that North Korea will eventually develop intercontinental ballistic missiles, posing a threat to the US. Brooks stated that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is determined to build rockets capable of reaching the US, and unless stopped, the country will acquire these capabilities. The US military has a significant presence in South Korea, and Brooks plans to work closely with the Republic of Korea to ensure readiness. The Pentagon is confident in its missile defenses, but the situation remains a concern due to North Korea's continued nuclear tests and missile program.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees much better market after bruising first quarter
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 56.3% decline in first-quarter earnings to $1.2 billion, with revenues sinking 40.3% to $6.3 billion. The firm attributed the decline to turmoil in global markets. However, Chief Financial Officer Harvey Schwartz expressed a bullish outlook for the mergers and acquisitions business, citing improving market conditions. He noted that the M&A market "feels good" despite the "chilling" effect of new US Treasury rules on deal-making. Goldman's shares rose 2.1% to $162.29 after the earnings report.

site_title: Oil prices rise as Kuwait strike drags on
summary: Oil prices rose sharply as Kuwait's petroleum workers went on strike, cutting production and easing the global crude glut. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate jumped 3.3% to $41.08 a barrel, while European benchmark Brent North Sea crude rose 2.6% to $44.03 a barrel. The strike, in its third day, has managed to restore some production, with output reaching 1.5 million barrels per day. Market analysts attribute the price increase to the loss of Kuwait's output and the weaker US dollar, which supports dollar-priced commodities like crude oil.

site_title: Ecuador quake: 480 confirmed dead, but 1,700 more missing
summary: A 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck Ecuador's Pacific coast, killing 480 people and injuring approximately 2,560. However, the death toll could rise as 1,700 people are still missing. Rescue efforts are ongoing, with sniffer dogs and mechanical diggers searching for survivors in the rubble of coastal towns. Emergency teams from Colombia, Mexico, El Salvador, and other countries are assisting Ecuadorian officials, but hope is fading of finding more people alive in the wreckage.

site_title: Yahoo logs loss as it courts potential buyers
summary: Yahoo reported a quarterly loss of $99 million, with revenues slumping to $1.09 billion, as it continues to explore strategic alternatives. The company has made progress towards potential buyers, including Verizon, which has emerged as a leading contender. Other potential bidders, such as TPG and YP Holdings, are also in the running. Yahoo's board committee has been in talks with interested parties, but no specifics have been released. The company's shares rose 1.5% in after-hours trade following the release.

site_title: Brazil's leader warns of instability in impeachment bid
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff warned that the impeachment process against her will harm the country's stability and suggested sexism played a role in her ouster. She claimed the process is a "coup" attempt and that there's no legal basis to remove her from office. The Senate prepares to schedule a vote on whether to open an impeachment trial in mid-May, with Rousseff facing a possible six-month suspension and replacement by Vice President Michel Temer.

site_title: Argentina borrows US$16.5b in return to markets: govt
summary: Argentina successfully returned to international credit markets after 15 years with a $16.5 billion bond auction, exceeding initial forecasts. The bonds carry an average rate of return of 7.2% and have maturities ranging from 3 to 30 years. The funds will be used to settle a 15-year lawsuit with US investment funds, known as "holdouts," who demanded full repayment of debts dating to the 2001 default. This move marks a significant step for President Mauricio Macri's efforts to boost the country's economy and bring it back into the international fold.

site_title: Dollar falls as weak US economic data weighs
summary: The US dollar fell as weak economic data showed new home construction slumping to the lowest pace since October, reinforcing the view that the Federal Reserve will remain cautious about raising interest rates. The euro rose 0.4% to $1.1359 per euro, while the yen slid to 109.20 yen per dollar amid expectations of further easing from the Bank of Japan following deadly earthquakes in southern Japan. Traders await Wednesday's existing-home sales report for March, which could shore up confidence in the housing market.

site_title: China launches yuan gold fix to have bigger say in global bullion market
summary: China has launched a yuan-denominated gold benchmark, marking an effort to exert more control over the global bullion market. This move follows years of reforming its domestic gold market to boost its influence. The benchmark is seen as a step towards increasing China's say in setting the global spot price, currently set in London.

site_title: Intel to slash up to 12,000 jobs in restructuring
summary: Intel plans to cut up to 12,000 jobs worldwide as part of a restructuring effort to shift focus from the slumping personal computer market to emerging technologies like mobile and healthcare. The move aims to reduce dependence on PCs and accelerate evolution into a company that powers the cloud and connected devices. The restructuring will eliminate about 11% of Intel's workforce by mid-2017, with estimated annual savings of $750 million. Despite the job cuts, Intel reported a modest 3% rise in first-quarter profit and $13.7 billion in revenues.

site_title: Obama heads to Saudi Arabia, Britain, Germany
summary: US President Barack Obama is on a six-day, three-nation trip to Saudi Arabia, Britain, and Germany. In Saudi Arabia, he will discuss crises in Yemen and Syria with Gulf leaders, despite tensions over Iran. Obama will then meet with British Prime Minister David Cameron and Queen Elizabeth II in London, where he will address concerns about the UK's potential exit from the European Union. The trip concludes with meetings with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and a speech at the Hanover industrial technology fair. Obama's visit aims to strengthen relationships with key allies amidst global challenges.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama on Tuesday left the United States for Saudi Arabia, the first stop on a six-day, three-nation trip that will also take him to Britain and Germany.

site_title: 'We have not provided source code to China': Apple
summary: Apple's top lawyer, Bruce Sewell, testified at a congressional hearing that the company has not provided its source code to China, refuting rumors about data security. Sewell defended Apple's use of strong encryption, stating it's a necessary defense against hostile attacks. The company had previously refused to help the FBI weaken the encryption of an iPhone used in the San Bernardino shooting case, leading to similar cases pending in the courts. Sewell denied allegations that Apple had provided source code to the Chinese government, citing a refusal within the past two years.

site_title: Eastspring: Hope in Asia's reform-minded leaders
summary: Eastspring Investments' chief investment officer, Ooi Boon Peng, believes Asia can reach a turning point despite its problems, thanks to reform-minded leaders in China, India, and Indonesia. Peng expects a gradual recovery in the US, with bond yields rising slowly but still providing attractive returns for investors. He attributes Asia's dynamic growth environment and the right mix of yields and risk to its bond market advantages. Peng also notes that the threat of Brexit and the EU's fragmentation are concerns, but he does not expect the EU to break up.

site_title: Foreigners pump US$12b into S-E Asian notes
summary: Foreigners have invested over $12 billion in Thai, Indonesian, and Malaysian debt notes this year, more than double the amount in 2015. The region's economy benefits from the US Federal Reserve's interest rate delay, China's economic stabilization, and a commodity price recovery. Despite risks such as delayed elections and financial scandals, investors are drawn to the region's growth prospects. Thailand has received the most inflows, while Indonesia has benefited from inflation easing and Malaysia's rebound in oil prices.

site_title: Eurozone banking sector is on the mend, shows ECB survey
summary: The European Central Bank's quarterly bank lending survey showed eurozone banks easing credit standards for enterprise loans, a positive sign for the region's financial sector. This easing was driven by competitive pressures and low interest rates, while credit standards for household loans tightened. Demand for loans, particularly for housing and working capital, also increased. The ECB's stimulus measures, including quantitative easing and ultra-cheap loans, are seen as contributing to the recovery.

site_title: Weak markets hurt wealth management profits at big US banks
summary: Big US banks, including Morgan Stanley, Wells Fargo, and Bank of America, reported weaker wealth management profits in the first quarter due to a volatile financial market environment. Lower client activity and fewer trading days contributed to the decline, with Morgan Stanley's wealth management profits falling 8% to $493 million. Despite the weaker results, analysts expressed little concern, citing the banks' relatively strong performance considering the market conditions. The banks are looking to boost wealth management profits by lending more money to clients to reach desired profit margins.

site_title: Ninja Van owner raises US$30m in Series B funding
summary: Singapore-based express delivery company Ninja Logistics, operating under the Ninja Van service, has raised US$30 million in Series B funding led by Abraaj Group. Existing investors Monk's Hill Ventures and new investors B Capital Group and Yahoo Japan's YJ Capital joined the round. The funds will be used to expand into Thailand and the Philippines, and triple customer-service headcount. Abraaj sees considerable potential for e-commerce growth in the region, with a projected 10% penetration rate by 2020.

site_title: US voters sick and tired of 'free-rider' world
summary: US voters are increasingly rejecting the "free-rider" world, with protectionist and isolationist messages resonating with them. Presidential candidates Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders are capitalizing on this sentiment, advocating for the US to focus on nation-building at home and protecting its interests abroad. This shift in sentiment is not limited to the candidates, as President Barack Obama has also expressed similar views. The article suggests that this trend may mark the beginning of the end of a strong internationalist consensus on foreign and trade policies, potentially leading to a shift in US foreign policy under a Trump presidency.

images.alt_text: Mrs Clinton, who as secretary of state was a driving force behind the TPP accord, is now opposing the TPP.

site_title: What causes housing in the US to be too expensive?
summary: The US faces two interconnected housing affordability problems: a shortage of housing in coastal metropolitan areas due to local regulations and a chronic issue of millions of Americans unable to afford modest housing. Building new housing for low-income households is a challenge, as most new construction is built for middle- and upper-income households. While new construction may help lower housing costs for some, it may not be enough to address the issue, and a combination of less government regulation and more government subsidies for the poor may be necessary to solve the problem.

site_title: Obama trip comes at critical moment in UK history
summary: US President Barack Obama's visit to the UK comes at a critical moment in the country's post-war history, with the EU referendum on the brink of a knife-edge decision. Obama's support for Britain remaining in the EU is expected to attract controversy, with over 100 MPs signing an open letter requesting he not interfere in the domestic political affairs. Despite concerns in the US over the potential weakening of the EU's balance of power, Obama believes his intervention will outweigh the negatives, citing the UK's close alignment with US interests and values.

site_title: Post-attacks France urges elite police units to end rivalries
summary: France's interior minister, Bernard Cazeneuve, urged elite police units to end their rivalries following the 2015 Paris attacks that killed 130 people. The minister emphasized the need for unity and cooperation in the face of terrorist threats. To achieve this, Cazeneuve announced the creation of new branches of GIGN and RAID units nationwide and plans to double the staff of the BRI anti-gang brigade. The reforms aim to improve response times and coordination during serious crises.

images.alt_text: France's interior minister on Tuesday urged the country's elite police forces to end their traditional rivalries following November's jihadist attacks on Paris that claimed 130 lives.

site_title: Singapore property may be heading for long-term drop in value
summary: Singapore's property market may experience a long-term drop in value due to the introduction of cooling measures, which have led to oversupply and stagnant demand. The cooling measures, including the Additional Buyer Stamp Duty and Total Debt Servicing Ratio, have limited the demand for properties and reduced the value of real estate assets. The article highlights six issues that contribute to this trend, including the exhaustion of demand for executive condominiums and the limitation of wealth planning options for wealthy families. Experts predict that the cooling measures will not be relaxed until profits turn negative, leading to a potential decline in property values over the next few decades.

images.alt_text: A series of cooling measures progressively introduced in the last six years has led to a patchwork quilt covering the property market that is now uncomfortably scratchy and somewhat suffocating.

site_title: Startup money making its way to US tech hubs outside Silicon Valley
summary: US venture capital firms invested $12.1 billion in US startups in the first quarter of 2016, with 40% going to young companies in the Bay Area. However, notable deals were made in cities outside the Bay Area, including Magic Leap in Florida ($794 million) and Domo in Utah ($131 million). This trend has helped cities such as Phoenix, Austin, and Salt Lake City experience growth in high-tech jobs, which outpaced overall office jobs. Lower costs and lower valuations in non-Bay Area startups are attracting investors.

site_title: No Wi-Fi, unknown location - but tiny house vacation is a hit
summary: Getaway, a company offering tiny house vacations with unknown locations, has seen success with its unique concept. Founded by two Harvard classmates, the company has raised $1.1 million and is building 10 new tiny houses in the New York City area. Its three Boston-area houses are currently booked until July, with guests paying $99 per night without knowing the exact location. The company plans to start operating in June and is expanding its operations. The concept aims to encourage guests to unplug and engage in a stripped-down adventure.

site_title: China's property market recovering from deep slump
summary: China's property market is recovering from a deep slump, with new home prices rising sharply in major cities such as Shenzhen, where prices increased 62% in March. The resurgence is a welcome boost to the economy, but it also raises concerns that the rebound is too narrow to be sustainable, concentrated in China's biggest and richest cities. Policymakers face challenges in justifying further economic stimulus and risk of complaints from urbanites priced out of the housing market.

site_title: Gold's best forecasters see rally resuming as confidence in the metal returns
summary: Gold is expected to continue its rally, with top forecasters predicting a surge to $1,350 an ounce by the end of the year. Despite signs of losing steam, real interest rates are expected to remain low, supporting the metal. Capital Economics Ltd and Cantor Fitzgerald LP are bullish on gold, citing low interest rates and potential inflation. Gold traded at $1,235 on Monday, and its price may climb at a slower pace.

site_title: Better data collection on medical devices needed for safer use
summary: A lack of systematic data collection on medical devices in the US contributes to an estimated 3,000 deaths annually due to device-related problems. Unlike prescription drugs, medical devices do not have unique identifiers in standardised medical claims data, hindering the tracking of potential issues. Implementing a surveillance system similar to the FDA's Sentinel Initiative could improve safety, but concerns over costs and implementation are raised.

site_title: Poor housing data adds to signs of weak Q1 GDP growth
summary: US housing starts fell 8.8% in March to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.09 million units, the lowest level since October, amid signs of a weak Q1 GDP growth. Permits for future home construction hit a one-year low, mirroring a moderation in housing market activity. The decline in groundbreaking points to a slowdown in economic growth, with first-quarter GDP growth estimates as low as 0.2% annualized rate.

site_title: Morgan Stanley keeps cutting costs as revenue growth stays elusive
summary: Morgan Stanley cut total expenses by 14% in the first quarter, with 3% staff reduction and a 19% decline in compensation-related expenses. The bank's return-on-equity was 6.2%, below CEO James Gorman's target of 9-11% by 2017. Analysts question the bank's ability to hit the target, with some warning that Morgan Stanley may be cutting too much and risking losing market share. The bank plans to continue cost-cutting, including shifting operations to low-cost cities and outsourcing, but analysts expect it to take time for these efforts to be reflected in earnings.

site_title: IBM Q2 profit forecast falls short of analysts' estimates
summary: IBM forecasted second-quarter profit fell short of analysts' estimates, signaling a multi-year effort to become a cloud products and technology purveyor may not soon stop its four-year sales slump. The company's full-year earnings forecast of at least $13.50 per share projects to $2.78-$2.92 per share, below analysts' estimates. IBM's strategic imperatives, which include cloud, analytics, and social products, grew at double digits to $7 billion, but its legacy business declined. The company's shares fell 5.4% in extended trading.

site_title: Press freedom under serious threat in Japan, says UN official
summary: A UN official, David Kaye, expressed concern over Japan's press freedom, stating it is facing "serious threats". He urged media to show solidarity and push back against erosion of freedoms.

site_title: The sub-zero club: getting used to the upside-down world economy
summary: Almost 500 million people live in countries with interest rates below zero, a phenomenon that began with the 2008 financial crisis. Central banks, including the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan, have lowered interest rates to stimulate inflation, but the policy has raised concerns about bank profits, money markets, and consumer behavior. Critics argue that negative interest rates may not be effective in sparking growth, while supporters point to benefits such as lower funding costs for banks and reduced bad loans. The policy is expected to continue, despite risks and criticism, as central bankers seek new ways to stimulate economies.

site_title: Latin American oil producers may rebalance market
summary: Latin American oil producers, including Mexico, Venezuela, and Colombia, are expected to contribute to market rebalancing by reducing production, with estimates suggesting a decline of around 1.1 million barrels per day. This would complement US production cuts of 700,000 barrels per day and pipeline cuts in Nigeria. The decline in Latin American production could be more significant than forecast, with Venezuela's output potentially falling by as much as 400,000 barrels per day if its financial situation worsens. This reduction in production could help balance the global market, which is currently oversupplied by 1.5 million barrels per day.

site_title: EU Android antitrust probe may affect Google's mobile model
summary: EU antitrust regulators are set to unveil charges against Google, alleging the company stifles innovation by giving its apps prominence on Android devices. The probes focus on agreements requiring phone makers to pre-load Google services, potentially forcing the company to change its mobile strategy and pay more to distribute its services. This could lead to a decrease in mobile searches and ads sold, affecting Google's revenue. Google has denied breaking antitrust rules and will likely fight the charges, which could impact the company's mobile model and revenue.

site_title: Australia's No 3 estate agent gives earnings downgrade
summary: McGrath Ltd, Australia's No 3 residential real estate agent, downgraded its pre-tax earnings forecast to A$26-27 million for the year to June 30, down a sixth from November's forecast. The downgrade, attributed to fewer home listings, has sent shares tumbling 31% and raised concerns about the country's property market. The company also cut its dividend target to 3-3.5 Australian cents per share. The move has sparked fears that Australia's property market may be set to flatline or even fall after years of double-digit growth.

site_title: Keppel not resuming work on Sete Brasil rigs until client restarts payments
summary: Keppel Corp, the world's largest builder of oil rigs, will not resume work on a key Brazilian client's orders until payments are restarted. The client, Sete Brasil Participacoes SA, has stopped paying for rigs due to a corruption probe and is debating bankruptcy. Keppel has cut 9.4% of its workforce and faces a prolonged period with low oil prices, with crude falling below $30 a barrel. The company's global offshore business is impacted by the Lava Jato scandal and the worst recession in over a century.

site_title: Apple Pay debuts in S'pore; analysts say it'll take time to catch on
summary: Apple Pay has launched in Singapore, becoming the sixth country in the world to adopt the mobile-payment platform. Initially available to American Express cardholders, the service will be extended to DBS, UOB, and Standard Chartered cardholders in the coming months. Analysts are divided on its adoption rate, with some predicting quick adoption due to its security features and compatibility with iPhone users. However, others believe it will take time for consumers to get used to mobile wallets, citing the need for education and awareness.

site_title: Myanmar's 'long-necked' women return home as entrepreneurs
summary: Myanmar's "long-necked" women, known for wearing bronze neck coils, have begun returning home from Thailand where they were employed as tourist attractions. The Kayan tribe women, who were driven to Thailand by poverty and conflict, have set up an entrepreneurial plan to reverse the trend and attract tourists to their homeland. Several women, including 33-year-old Mu Par, have returned to their village in Panpet, selling handmade crafts and promoting a more ethical window into their unique culture. The move is part of Myanmar's growing tourism industry, which has seen arrivals double in the past five years.

site_title: Oil rebounds as Kuwait strike enters third day
summary: Oil prices rebounded on Tuesday as a strike by Kuwaiti petroleum workers entered its third day, outweighing disappointment over failed output talks. West Texas Intermediate rose 33 cents to $40.11 a barrel, while Brent crude climbed 44 cents to $43.35 a barrel. Kuwait's state oil firm reported restored production at 1.5 million barrels per day, 50% of normal output. Analysts predict the strike may have a temporary effect on the market, with a key Opec meeting in June expected to focus on output levels.

site_title: Commodity currencies at 10-month highs
summary: Commodity currencies, including the Australian and New Zealand dollars, reached 10-month highs against the US dollar due to stabilizing oil prices and improved risk sentiment. The Australian dollar rose 0.6% to US$0.7803, while the New Zealand dollar jumped 1% to US$0.7028. Oil prices rose above US$43 a barrel, supporting commodity-linked currencies, with the safe-haven yen slipping. The Bank of Japan and Federal Reserve are set to hold policy meetings next week, potentially influencing currency markets.

site_title: Japan quakes damage castle, unnerve tourists; death toll rises to 44
summary: Japan's Kyushu region, a popular tourist destination, has been devastated by a series of earthquakes, resulting in a death toll of 44 and over 1,000 injured. Tourist groups from China, South Korea, and Taiwan have cancelled trips to the area, with travel agencies anticipating further cancellations. Japan's tourism industry, which has been a bright spot in the country's economy, is expected to be hit, with a potential spillover effect on the rest of Japan.

images.alt_text: Residents standing next to their collapsed houses in Mashiki, Kumamoto prefecture, on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines CEO Christoph Mueller to leave in September
summary: Malaysia Airlines CEO Christoph Mueller will leave the airline in September, six months before the end of his three-year contract, citing "changing personal circumstances." Mueller will remain with the airline as a non-executive director. The airline has begun a search for a new CEO, considering both internal and external candidates, and has appointed Peter Bellew as executive director with immediate effect. Mueller led the airline's restructuring efforts, which included cutting 6,000 jobs and trimming capacity, and reported the airline's first small profit in "many years" in February.

site_title: Franklin Templeton sees 'middling' returns for stocks and bonds
summary: Franklin Templeton predicts 'middling' returns for stocks and bonds due to slow economic growth and sliding corporate profit margins. The firm favors European stocks, inflation-linked bonds, and high-yield bonds, citing attractive valuations. Emerging markets are also a potential opportunity, with company fundamentals favoring developed markets but valuations on the side of emerging markets. The investment solutions group manages $742.6 billion in assets, with a focus on multi-asset portfolios and asset allocation advice.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Mr Nelson said his team is "very interested'' in potentially building up an overweight position in EM against DM

site_title: Are emerging market equities cheap?
summary: Emerging market equities have seen a 20% gain since January 2016, with the MSCI Emerging Markets Index trading at a 12.0x forward price-earnings ratio, significantly higher than its January level of 10.4x. However, valuations vary across regions, with Asia being the only region where valuations are relatively low. In contrast, Latin America and EMEA indices are trading above average, and within Asia, some countries like China and Taiwan are undervalued, while others like India and Indonesia are overvalued. Despite these variations, emerging market equities remain undervalued relative to developed market equities.

site_title: Two Cordlife shareholders seeking board seats
summary: Two long-time shareholders of Cordlife Group, Bonvests Holdings Ltd and Tai Tak Estates Sdn Bhd, plan to call for a shareholder meeting to secure board seats following the sudden resignation of CEO Jeremy Yee. The shareholders, who collectively own 22.5% of the firm, have hired a legal firm to assist in calling for the meeting, seeking to appoint two non-executive nominee directors to the board. The move signals disenchantment among shareholders since Yee's abrupt departure and may potentially impact the firm's succession plans.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China sovereign fund seeking control of US$8b Yum unit: sources
summary: China's sovereign fund, China Investment Corp (CIC), is seeking control of Yum China, the US$8 billion Chinese unit of Yum! Brands Inc, with a potential deal valuing the business at US$7 billion to US$8 billion. A consortium backed by CIC, KKR & Co, and Baring Private Equity Asia is conducting due diligence. This move could give a domestic entity control of a leading fast-food chain in China for the first time, and provide Yum with cash to fund a dividend and share buyback.

site_title: London first-quarter home presales drop 33%
summary: London's home presales dropped 33% in the first quarter, with 5,947 homes sold prior to completion, down from 8,927 a year earlier. The decline is attributed to a new tax on overseas buyers and high home values, which has dampened demand. Developers are offering discounts to institutional investors to offset the tax changes. The number of new homes started in the first quarter fell 39% to 6,379, the lowest for seven quarters. Affordability remains a major issue for domestic buyers.

site_title: Citibank opens smart banking branch in Punggol
summary: Citibank has opened its 11th smart banking branch in Punggol, Singapore, offering enhanced technology and services to residents. The 1,800 sq ft branch features Smart Teller Assist Terminals, media walls, and integrated workbenches. This is Citibank's latest effort to digitize banking and engage younger customers. The branch is open from 10:30am to 7:30pm daily, including public holidays.

site_title: DBS partners two P2P lending platforms in bank-fintech collaboration
summary: DBS Bank has partnered with two peer-to-peer lending platforms, Funding Societies and MoolahSense, in a first-of-its-kind collaboration between established financial institutions and emerging fintechs. The partnership enables DBS to refer small businesses to the lending platforms, while the platforms refer borrowers to DBS for larger commercial loans. This collaboration aims to support the funding needs of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, where they often face difficulties in accessing credit due to lack of audited accounts and personal income statements.

site_title: Ferrari's luxury ambitions face reset as Prada hits the skids
summary: Ferrari's luxury ambitions have stalled six months after its initial public offering, with its stock tumbling 20% due to skepticism over the company's prospects. The new board, comprising luxury experts, must address the challenge of balancing its pricey presence in Formula One racing with high-end products. Ferrari's sluggish start coincides with a rough time for the luxury-goods industry, and the company's efforts to expand into luxury products have so far fallen flat, with merchandising generating less than 1% of total revenue. A new strategy is expected to be unveiled next year.

site_title: Hutchison Port predicts more mega ships calling at Shenzhen hub
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust predicts an increase in mega ships calling at its Shenzhen hub, citing the region's importance in China's exports. The company's Shenzhen facility is set to handle more cargo from the Pearl River Delta, potentially eating into volumes at its Hong Kong terminal. The global shipping industry's restructuring and changes in alliances are expected to impact transshipments in Hong Kong, with Hutchison Port increasing tariffs at its Hong Kong terminal.

site_title: Malaysia faces bailout question after Abu Dhabi fund terminates debt deal
summary: Malaysia's government is facing a bailout question after a US$4.6 billion debt deal with Abu Dhabi's IPIC collapsed, leaving 1MDB with a US$1.1 billion payment shortfall. This collapse increases pressure on Prime Minister Najib, already facing graft and mismanagement allegations. A bailout would add to Najib's woes, potentially jeopardizing his position.

site_title: Founder of China's Tencent to give US$2b in shares to charity
summary: Pony Ma, founder of China's Tencent Holdings Ltd, plans to donate 100 million company shares, valued over US$2 billion, to the firm's charity foundation in support of medical, educational, and environmental causes in China. This is one of the country's biggest philanthropic pledges, following Alibaba Group founder Jack Ma's 2014 US$3 billion donation. China's parliament has recently passed its first charity law, and experts predict a boom in philanthropy in the country, driven by wealthy entrepreneurs with business acumen and government connections.

site_title: Smart ship technology is ballast for beleaguered shipping industry
summary: Smart ship technology is being seen as a potential game-changer for the struggling shipping industry, with automation and autonomy expected to optimize resource usage, enhance productivity, and improve safety. Industry experts, including Singapore Shipping Association president Esben Poulsson and Finnish researcher Antti Saurama, emphasized the benefits of digital competencies such as data analytics and robotics. They noted that smart ships can reduce fuel costs by up to 30% and potentially increase revenue, while decreasing shipbuilding costs. The technology is also seen as a way to remove humans from dangerous tasks, improving overall operational safety.

site_title: China out to isolate South China Sea claimants, US
summary: China has intensified its efforts to isolate countries that support the Philippines in a territorial dispute with China in the South China Sea. Foreign ministers from the US, Japan, Australia, and New Zealand issued a joint statement on maritime security, but China has warned these countries against discussing the issue, threatening financial consequences. China has also warned New Zealand Prime Minister John Key, saying he should avoid discussing territorial disputes in the South China Sea, and that any attempt to "take sides" could risk complicating trade ties.

site_title: OSIM drops dividend as Q1 earnings fall 42%
summary: OSIM International, a lifestyle products group, has dropped its Q1 dividend due to a 42% decline in net profit to S$7.84 million. Revenue fell 7.7% to S$138.3 million, mainly due to a weaker market environment. The company cited rising fixed cost pressure and a need to maintain margins as challenges. Analysts describe the earnings as "poor," with CIMB analyst Kenneth Ng attributing the share price's stability to the company's privatisation bid.

images.alt_text: Lifestyle products group OSIM International, the target of a privatisation bid by its founder Ron Sim, has dropped its usual first-quarter interim dividend after a dismal set of earnings.

site_title: Time to take rotor sails seriously
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is considering a cap on carbon dioxide emissions from international shipping, which could lead to a carbon levy. Meanwhile, wind power is being explored as a way to reduce emissions, with the International Windship Association (IWSA) supporting the call for shipping to commit to its "fair share" of emissions reduction. IWSA claims that wind technology devices can save significant fuel and emission savings on commercial ships, and that several companies, including Rolls-Royce and Wartsila, endorse wind power in shipping. A technology called the Flettner rotor has already shown promise in reducing emissions, with a 6.1% reduction in fuel consumption and 1,200 tonnes of CO2 emissions avoided annually.

site_title: Dr M seeks court order to freeze PM Najib's assets
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has applied to a court to freeze Prime Minister Najib Razak's assets due to the 1MDB state fund scandal. Mahathir's lawyers are also seeking a court order for Najib to disclose all his assets, including those held under his nominees' names. This move comes as Mahathir calls for Najib's resignation over the scandal.

site_title: Steel producers fail to solve overcapacity crisis
summary: China and other major steel-producing countries failed to agree on measures to tackle a global steel crisis, with the US criticizing Beijing's approach as Washington prepares for potential trade action. The global steelmaking capacity is 2.37 billion tonnes, with only 67.5% being used, down from 70.9% in 2014. China has ramped up steel exports, despite a slew of anti-dumping measures, and officials claim it has already reduced capacity by 90 million tonnes. The US and other countries argue that China needs to take more concrete actions to reduce excess production.

images.alt_text: China has been ramping up exports of steel in recent years as it battles to steer its economy into services-led growth and away from traditional manufacturing, while keeping employment levels high.

site_title: IVAS, NTU launch business valuation course
summary: The Institute of Valuers and Appraisers of Singapore (IVAS) and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) have launched Asia's first business valuation course, the Chartered Valuer and Appraisal programme. The 18-month course aims to equip participants with specialised knowledge and skills in business valuation. With the increasing demand for professionals in business valuation, the programme is designed to provide flexibility, allowing participants to choose between attending classes or self-study. Upon completion, participants may apply for IVAS certification, supported by the SkillsFuture Study Awards, offering S$5,000 in funding.

site_title: RHB lists '25 jewels' in small-cap stocks
summary: RHB Research has released its list of top 25 small-cap companies in Singapore, known as "25 jewels." The list includes under-researched stocks from various sectors, such as real estate investment trusts and consumer segments. The companies, with market caps of up to S$2 billion, were selected based on factors like managerial effectiveness, business model, and financials. More than half of the picks are new companies, including Cambridge Industrial Trust and Spackman Entertainment Group. RHB Research hopes to help these companies graduate into mid-sized or large caps in the near future.

site_title: Opec's glory days as an effective cartel are well and truly over
summary: Opec's meeting in Doha ended without an agreement to freeze oil production, leading to a 5% correction in oil prices. The collapse was largely due to Iran's refusal to participate and cooperate, as it ramps up oil production to regain lost market share. This re-emergence of Iran in the oil market, combined with the rise of non-Opec producers and shale oil, makes it difficult for Opec to reach a credible agreement on an output ceiling. As a result, the oil market remains a free-for-all, and Opec's glory days as an effective cartel are considered over.

site_title: Background screening for high-level hires should be a priority for all organisations
summary: Background screening for high-level hires is crucial for organisations to ensure they appoint the right captain to set strategic direction. Discrepancies in employment history, education, and database checks are common among senior executive candidates. A 2016 Asia Pacific Annual Trends report found that 57.7% of discrepancies relate to employment history. Conducting thorough, in-depth background checks, including financial and regulatory checks, can help mitigate hiring risks and uncover "the good, the bad and the ugly" about a candidate. A background screening partner experienced in the dynamic regulatory environment can deliver a reliable and compliant screening programme.

site_title: DHL opens S$160m logistics centre
summary: DHL has opened a S$160 million logistics centre in Tampines LogisPark, Singapore, featuring an advanced automation system with 130 robotic shuttles that pick and store products from 72,000 locations. The centre, dubbed the Asia-Pacific Innovation Center (APIC), aims to improve efficiency and reduce space usage by 40%. The facility showcases DHL's commitment to adopting technologies for enhanced productivity and efficiency in the region, with a focus on automation and innovation. The centre is seen as a model for future warehousing in land-scarce countries and dense cities.

site_title: Auditions open for 12th ChildAid
summary: The ChildAid charity concert is returning this November at Resorts World Sentosa with a theme of "Living Dreams." The event is looking for young performers aged 19 and below to join its cast, with auditions set for June 18 and 19. Past beneficiaries of the charity will also share their stories on stage. Since its inception in 2005, ChildAid has raised over S$12 million for two children's charity funds, providing arts training and school support to financially disadvantaged children.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: STI rises for fifth time in six days
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose for the fifth time in six days, gaining 34.06 points to 2,951.81, driven by the banks and Singtel's 10-point rise. The rise was in response to an overnight jump on Wall Street and a 40-point rise in the Dow futures. Turnover was 1.3 billion units, with 264 rises versus 134 falls.

site_title: Boardroom gender diversity: Singapore lags Malaysia, India, Indonesia
summary: Singapore lags behind Malaysia, India, and Indonesia in terms of gender diversity on the boards of its largest listed companies, with only 7.7% of female directors, compared to 12.5% in Malaysia and 11.1% in India. The study attributed the improvement in regional diversity to regulatory changes in these countries, including targets and quotas for women representation. Singapore's current regulations are silent on board gender diversity, and experts suggest the country needs more substantial action to increase diversity, citing the low turnover of directors and the current "survival mode" of companies.

site_title: Turnbull to seek July 2 election as reform bill fails
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull plans to hold an election on July 2 after the Senate blocked legislation to curb trade union powers. The government now has a constitutional trigger to call an early ballot, despite concerns about voter perceptions of a lack of direction. Turnbull must deliver a budget that addresses the country's economic challenges, including a projected national deficit of A$37.4 billion, without growing the deficit. The election will feature all 150 House of Representatives seats and all 76 Senate seats, a double dissolution election that hasn't been held since 1987.

images.alt_text: Mr Turnbull must now overcome voter perceptions that his government lacks direction, and he has little in the coffers to offer as pre-election sweeteners in the budget.

site_title: Negative rates push central banks to take more risk
summary: Negative interest rates have prompted central banks to take more risks in managing their reserves, with 80% of surveyed managers citing an impact on their strategy. The shift has led to increased investment in longer duration instruments, credit risk, and new asset classes, such as China's renminbi, which has seen a significant rise from 20 to 32 central banks. This rebalancing has affected exchange rates, with the euro's share in global reserves shrinking to less than 20% for the first time in nearly 14 years.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Acromec, a CATALIST-listed cleanroom specialist, has secured two contracts worth S$7.1 million from a healthcare customer, bringing its order book to S$47 million.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) reported a Q1 FY2016 adjusted net profit of HK$210 million, down 26% year-on-year, due to an 8% year-on-year drop in total throughput/revenue. The company lowered its total debt to EBITDA gearing from 5 times to 4 times by FY2021. DBS Group Research upgraded Singapore Airlines, citing the low oil price environment and potential for higher dividends, while downgrading HPHT to "underweight".

site_title: Keppel shares up; analysts warn of long drought
summary: Keppel Corporation's shares rose 1.17% to close at S$6.07, despite a 42% drop in net profit to S$210.6 million for the first quarter. Analysts warn of a long drought ahead for the oil and gas giant, citing concerns over contract wins and gearing levels. The company's property division drove profit growth, but the offshore and marine business saw a 58% decline in revenue. Analysts have downgraded their ratings, with some warning of a "long drought" and others expecting the company's valuations to be largely reliant on its property segment.

site_title: Rising temperatures may accelerate spread of Zika virus
summary: Rising temperatures may accelerate the spread of the Zika virus, which has already infected millions in Latin America, according to experts. Climate change is contributing to the expansion of mosquito habitats, with Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus species thriving in warmer conditions. The latter, found in southern Europe, is also competent to carry Zika and could drive its spread in Europe. Experts warn of a potential outbreak in Europe next summer, with localized cases possible but a fear of microcephaly looms large.

site_title: EU to charge Google over Android on Wednesday: sources
summary: The European Union will formally charge Google with anti-trust charges on Wednesday over its marketing of the Android mobile phone operating system, alleging it gives unfair prominence to its own apps. Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager will announce the charges, which could result in a $7.4 billion fine. The EU is examining whether Google's deals with manufacturers such as Samsung and Huawei restrict competition and favor its own apps, altering the global smartphone sector.

site_title: Malaysian auto sector hopes mega car fest will perk up sales
summary: Malaysia's automotive sector is banking on the "My Auto Fest" car fest next month to boost sales amid a slowdown in consumer spending. The three-day event promises generous offers and discounts. This comes as private-consumption indicators point to a marked slowdown in activities. The auto fest aims to tempt motorists and revive sales.

site_title: Plenty of nuggets to pick from DBS annual report
summary: DBS Group Holdings' annual report highlights its "Live more, Bank less" mission, aiming to make banking easy and effortless. CEO Piyush Gupta discussed the loss of trust in bankers following the global financial crisis. The report also touches on DBS' efforts to simplify banking services.

site_title: Big ad agencies find it tough to attract, keep young talent
summary: The advertising industry is struggling to attract and retain young talent due to the changing media landscape and the industry's stodgy image. Agencies are trying to match perks offered by tech companies like Google and Facebook, but this is not enough to combat the industry's loss of cachet. The industry faces deeper issues, including the decline of traditional advertising methods and the inability to compete with tech companies in terms of pay. Agencies are revamping their offices and training programs to attract young professionals, but it remains to be seen if these efforts will be enough to save the industry.

site_title: Maritime briefs
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) hosted its inaugural Maritime Administrators Forum, attended by nearly 50 administrators from Asia, Europe, Africa, and Latin America. The forum aimed to exchange best practices and ideas to support the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) efforts in promoting safe, efficient, and sustainable shipping. MPA also announced plans to issue a call for proposals under its S$200 million Maritime Innovation & Technology (MINT) Fund, focusing on key themes such as future logistics, drone technology, and data analytics.

site_title: IMF, World Bank, UN, OECD form new group to stop tax erosion
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF), World Bank, United Nations, and Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) have formed a new group to combat tax erosion and develop tools for taxing multinational enterprises. The group aims to build effective tax systems in developing countries and address tax base erosion. This move comes after the Panama Papers controversy highlighted widespread tax avoidance by wealthy individuals using tax haven countries. The new group's formation was welcomed by the IMF, following heightened attention on tax issues.

site_title: US oil investors rush for protection at US$35 as Doha talks collapse
summary: US crude oil investors rush to protect themselves as prices sink 7% after Doha talks collapse, erasing hopes for a global oil glut easing. Record high open interest in June puts, equivalent to 36,000 contracts, and high turnover of 10,000 lots traded, indicate a bearish sentiment. Analysts warn crude prices could drop to as low as $30, citing a lack of coordinated action among Opec and non-Opec producers.

site_title: MH17 families mulling lawsuit against Malaysia Airlines
summary: Families of 91 people killed in the MH17 disaster are considering a lawsuit against Malaysia Airlines for compensation, citing the airline's offer as "offensive" and "insufficient". The families, representing 168 people from the Netherlands, are seeking damages for loss of earnings and psychological trauma. The lawsuit, if filed, would also hold Malaysia Airlines liable for flying over Ukraine during a conflict. The families want a "just" settlement, but the airline's offer has not met their expectations, with the case to be decided in The Hague or Malaysia.

site_title: US stocks open higher despite Goldman, IBM Q1 disappointments
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday despite disappointing Q1 earnings reports from Goldman Sachs and IBM. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 35.30 points, while the S&P 500 increased 5.13 points. A strong quarterly earnings report from UnitedHealth Group also contributed to the gains. In contrast, Netflix's poor forecast weighed on the market. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.56 points.

site_title: Malaysia's Mahathir seeks court order to freeze PM's assets
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has applied for a court order to freeze Prime Minister Najib Razak's assets over the 1MDB state fund scandal. Mahathir's lawyers claim Najib is guilty of corruption and abuse of power, and is seeking disclosure of all assets held by Najib and his nominees. This is part of a lawsuit filed by Mahathir and two others against Najib in March, which also accuses him of interfering in 1MDB probes.

images.alt_text: Former Malaysian premier Mahathir Mohamad, calling for Prime Minister Najib Razak to resign over the 1MDB state fund scandal, has applied for a court order to freeze Mr Najib's assets, Mr Mahathir's lawyers said on Tuesday.

site_title: Indonesia tackling dysfunctional money markets
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, is shifting to a seven-day operating rate as its policy rate, aiming to fix the country's dysfunctional short-term money markets. The current 12-month reference one will be abandoned, and the policy rate will be set at 6.75%. Analysts believe this change will help influence rates and encourage lending, but other issues need to be resolved, including a shortfall of free cash in the banking system and the absence of tools and products for markets to price cash.

site_title: dnata Singapore looking to technologies, new revenue streams to fight headwinds
summary: dnata Singapore is facing a tough year ahead due to high operational costs and stiff competition. To combat this, the company is investing in technologies and exploring new revenue streams, such as introducing food & beverage concepts at Changi Airport. dnata is also cross-training staff and investing in a ramp handling tool to boost productivity and enhance operations. The company aims to reduce its dependence on staff and protect its bottom line, having cut costs and outsourced IT functions. Despite losing a contract to rival Sats, dnata remains a 20% market share leader at Changi Airport.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Goldman Sachs profit slumps for fourth straight quarter
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 56.3% fall in net income to $1.2 billion for the first quarter, marking its fourth consecutive quarter of declining profits. The decline was attributed to market volatility affecting bond trading and investment banking businesses. Revenue from trading bonds, currencies, and commodities fell 47% to $1.66 billion, a significant drop from pre-crisis levels. The result missed analysts' expectations of $2.45 per share.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc's profit slumped for the fourth straight quarter as market volatility hit the company's bond trading and investment banking businesses.

site_title: Audi delays Q1 results until June 1, following VW
summary: Audi has delayed the publication of its first-quarter results until June 1, following Volkswagen's decision to postpone its own results until May 31. Audi's results were originally scheduled for April 29. This move comes after Volkswagen delayed its full-year results and annual shareholders' meeting due to the effects of its diesel emissions scandal.

site_title: Iran struggles to find enough ships for oil exports
summary: Iran is struggling to increase oil exports due to a shortage of suitable tankers and foreign reluctance to carry its cargoes. The country has 55-60 oil tankers in its fleet, with 25-27 stored in sea lanes for unsold cargoes and 20 needing modernization. Foreign ships are needed to meet Iran's target of reaching pre-sanctions sales levels this year, but US restrictions on Tehran remain in place, prohibiting trade in dollars and US firms. So far, no Iranian tankers have made deliveries to Europe, and many tanker owners are hesitant to do business with Iran due to the risks and uncertainty associated with the US connection.

site_title: Malaysia faces bailout question after US$1b spat with Abu Dhabi fund
summary: Malaysia's government is facing a potential bailout for the scandal-tainted state fund 1MDB after a $4.6 billion debt deal with Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Company (IPIC) collapsed. 1MDB failed to make a $1.1 billion payment, leading to the termination of the debt deal. The Malaysian government may need to intervene to avoid default, which could pile pressure on Prime Minister Najib Razak, who founded 1MDB and is on its advisory board.

site_title: Singapore dollar shakes off last week's losses against the greenback
summary: The Singapore dollar has strengthened 1.5% over the past three trading days, erasing losses from last week's surprise easing by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The dollar had dropped 0.9% against the US dollar on April 14, when the MAS shifted to a neutral stance. Traders attribute the recent gains to the Federal Reserve's cautious stance, with futures indicating a less than even chance for a US interest rate increase by December. Analysts predict the Singapore dollar will weaken to S$1.38 this quarter and S$1.40 at the end of the year.

site_title: Political, business leaders size up stability risks from fintech growth
summary: US Senators Sherrod Brown, Jeff Merkley, and Jeanne Shaheen have asked the Government Accountability Office to review fintech, raising concerns about data security, regulation, and potential risks to financial stability. Executives from banks, start-ups, and regulatory agencies have proposed four recommendations for a global approach to fintech, including debating the ethical use of data and establishing industry standards. Fintech firms are expanding globally, with Citigroup expanding its digital platform in China, and companies like Lenddo providing credit scores using non-traditional data in developing countries.

site_title: Commodity currencies at 10-mth highs as oil boosts risk sentiment
summary: Commodity currencies, such as the Australian and New Zealand dollars, reached 10-month highs against the US dollar, driven by stabilizing oil prices. The Australian dollar rose 0.6% to US$0.7803, while the New Zealand dollar jumped 1% to US$0.7028. Oil-linked currencies, including the Canadian dollar, also surged due to the oil price bounce. This positive market sentiment is attributed to the stabilization of oil prices after a slide, and is seen as a positive sign for risk appetite in global markets.

images.alt_text: Commodity currencies like the Australian and New Zealand dollars soared to 10-month highs against the US dollar, drawing support from oil prices which stabilised from a slide and underpinned broad risk sentiment in global markets.

site_title: MPA to call for maritime innovation and technology project proposals in May
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) will issue a call in May for research project proposals under its S$200 million Maritime Innovation & Technology (MINT) Fund. The fund supports development programmes for the maritime technology cluster and will prioritize projects in areas like future logistics, drone technology, and data analytics. MPA will also commit an additional S$50 million to the fund, extending its term to 2021. Industry players can submit project proposals from May to August this year, with a focus on innovative solutions for the maritime industry.

site_title: Maersk Line to increase Asia-Europe shipping rates by US$550 per TEU
summary: Maersk Line plans to increase freight rates from Asia to Northern Europe by US$550 per 20-foot equivalent unit (TEU, effective May 1), and by US$1,050 per TEU to some Central and South American ports, starting May 15. This move comes as the industry grapples with overcapacity, leading to a 78% drop in freight rates this year. The rate hikes aim to make shipping more profitable, but may impact global trade.

site_title: Apple report shows 30,000 law enforcement data queries
summary: Apple received 30,687 law enforcement data queries globally in the second half of 2015, with 80% of US requests fulfilled. The company provided data in 63% of cases in its Asia-Pacific region and 52% in Latin America and North America. Apple only complies with information requests after verifying their validity and delivers the narrowest possible set of information. The company emphasizes that government agencies must obtain a search warrant before accessing customer data, and Apple reviews each request carefully.

site_title: Portugal at risk of breaking EU budget rules
summary: Portugal is at risk of breaking European Union budget rules, according to European Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis. The country's fiscal situation and government plans may not comply with the Stability and Growth Pact, which could lead to an updated assessment in May. This development poses a risk to Portugal's economic stability and adherence to EU regulations.

site_title: Apple updates MacBook with faster processors
summary: Apple has updated its 12-inch MacBook line with faster processors, a Retina display, and a Force Touch trackpad, available in rose gold. The new device is 13.1 mm thin, weighs 2 pounds, and has a battery capable of up to 10 hours of wireless web browsing. Starting at US$1,299, it will be available for sale starting Wednesday.

site_title: Mobile ad startup Adtile in partnership with SPH, secures fresh US$2m funding
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) partnered with mobile ad startup Adtile to enhance interactivity in mobile ads, using Adtile's Motion Ads in SPH's campaigns. Adtile secured an additional US$2 million in Series A funding from private investors, bringing total funding to US$4 million.

site_title: Japan opens prison to shelter quake evacuees
summary: Japan has opened a prison to shelter tens of thousands of people left homeless by two deadly earthquakes that struck the southwestern island of Kyushu, leaving 46 dead and over 1,000 injured. The prison, which can accommodate up to 250 people, is being used as an evacuation center due to issues with delivering food and essentials to those in temporary shelters. The move is part of Japan's efforts to cope with the country's worst humanitarian disaster in five years, with over 95,000 people still in evacuation shelters.

site_title: Japan's Seven & i names Loeb-backed executive as new president
summary: Japan's Seven & i has named Ryuichi Isaka, backed by US activist investor Daniel Loeb, as the new president of the company, replacing Toshifumi Suzuki. Isaka, credited with driving 7-Eleven's growth in Japan, will lead the company following Suzuki's failed attempt to oust him. Isaka's appointment may impact the company's loss-making supermarket chain Ito-Yokado, with some shareholders calling for overhaul.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines CEO Mueller to leave in September
summary: Malaysia Airlines CEO Christoph Mueller is set to leave the company in September, six months before the end of his three-year contract, due to "changing personal circumstances". Mueller will serve a notice period and will remain as a non-executive director. The airline has begun a search for a new CEO, considering both internal and external candidates. Mueller took over in May last year to lead restructuring efforts after the airline suffered twin disasters in 2014.

site_title: Senior maritime officials meet at Singapore's inaugural Maritime Administrators Forum
summary: Senior maritime officials from Asia, Europe, Africa, and Latin America gathered at Singapore's inaugural Maritime Administrators Forum, convened by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore. The forum aimed to exchange best practices and ideas to support the International Maritime Organisation's efforts in promoting safe, efficient, and sustainable shipping. Key needs identified by participating officials include a more integrated approach to maritime policies, better stakeholder engagement, capacity-building, and addressing emerging concepts like the Blue Economy and sustainable ocean governance. The forum facilitated discussions on tackling challenges such as economic volatility and new international regulations.

site_title: Iran says oil production freeze would prolong sanctions
summary: Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Zanganeh stated that the country will not accept an oil production freeze, as it would prolong sanctions. Iran aims to regain market share lost under sanctions, but adding to a global glut. The proposed freeze was seen as a response to the recent price slide, but collapsed after no decision was taken. Zanganeh blamed other producers for the oversupply, saying they are trying to distract from their role in market instability. Iran has had no role in destabilizing the market, and the country will not compromise on sanctions.

site_title: Global market turbulence overdone, no lasting shock: RBA chief
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Glenn Stevens says recent global market turbulence was overdone and not a risk to world growth. He believes diminishing returns are setting in for monetary policy globally, with market confidence easily rattled. The latest market rebound suggests it's not the start of a major financial shock. The RBA initially considered cutting interest rates due to market turmoil but has since dropped that condition. Stevens' comments suggest the global market turbulence was an overreaction to signs of softening world economic growth.

site_title: Spain targets slower deficit cut to preserve growth
summary: Spain's caretaker government has revised its public deficit targets for 2016 and 2017, aiming to cut the deficit to 3.6% of economic output this year and 2.9% in 2017, down from previous targets of 2.8% and 1.4%, respectively. The move is aimed at preserving economic growth, following a wide miss on 2015 targets. The European Commission has warned that Spain's efforts to cut the deficit have stalled, and further reforms are needed to rebalance the economy.

site_title: Oman builds industrial outpost in desert to escape oil trap
summary: Oman is investing heavily in its desert region to diversify its economy beyond oil exports. The Duqm Special Economic Zone, a sprawling business area, aims to create tens of thousands of jobs and attract foreign investment. The zone includes a ship repair yard, oil refinery, and petrochemical complex, as well as a fish processing district and tourism area. Oman's government has spent billions of dollars on infrastructure and will continue to invest, despite the financial risks, as the country's limited oil reserves are expected to last only 15 years.

site_title: Sim Lian's Wandervale project draws strong demand
summary: Sim Lian Group's Wandervale executive condominium project has been fully sold out, with 320 units booked as of April 19. About 60% of the 534 units remain unsold. The four-bedroom units were the most popular, with 82 units sold. Half of the sold units were booked by HDB upgraders, and 20% were purchased under the Fiancé/Fiancée Scheme. The strong demand comes despite a challenging economic environment.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Sim Lian Group's four-bedroom units at Wandervale - the first executive condominium to be launched this year - have been fully sold out.

site_title: US housing starts plunge, building permits hit one-year low
summary: US housing starts plummeted 8.8% to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.09 million units in March, the lowest level since October, and building permits hit a one-year low. This decline suggests a cooling housing market, aligning with signs of a slowdown in economic growth in the first quarter. Economists had forecast a 1.17 million-unit pace.

site_title: Olam signs five-year US$175m loan from IFC
summary: Olam International has signed a five-year, $175 million loan agreement with the International Finance Corporation (IFC) to finance food processing facilities in Nigeria and India. The loan will support the agri-business group's permanent working capital and capital expenditure requirements. The facilities, including a sugar mill and spice processing units, are expected to generate local employment and provide farmers with market prices. Olam's CFO stated that the project aligns with IFC's mandate of promoting inclusive growth and economic prosperity in developing nations.

site_title: Singapore hopes Israel, Palestinians, can restart talks on two-state solution: PM
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed hope that Israel and the Palestinians can restart talks towards a two-state solution, with a lasting and just peace. Lee made the statement during an official welcome ceremony in Jerusalem. He emphasized the importance of a two-state solution with Israel and Palestine living in peace and security.

site_title: EU membership is good for UK environment, committee of MPs says
summary: A UK parliamentary committee found that EU membership has positively impacted the country's environmental policies, allowing for faster and more thorough action on air and water pollution, and biodiversity. The committee's report states that EU membership has given Britain a platform to pursue environmental aims internationally and influence long-term policy. Even if the UK leaves the EU, it will still need to follow some EU environmental laws, but will be less able to influence their development.

site_title: Latest Earning
summary: London's Heathrow is considering increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade, amid rising costs and increasing demand. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, was named OCBC's new CEO, replacing Helen Wong who is retiring. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while CGS Investment downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth in H2. Additionally, Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Negative rates force central banks to take more risk
summary: Negative interest rates have forced central banks to take more risks to maintain the value of their trillions of dollars in reserves. A survey of 77 reserve managers showed that 32 central banks now invest in China's renminbi, up from 20 last year. Negative rates have led to withdrawal of capital from some currencies and investment in previously avoided markets, including longer duration instruments and new asset classes. Reserve managers have made significant changes to their portfolios, with 80% saying negative rates have impacted reserve management strategy.

site_title: Abu Dhabi to build US$1b Warner Bros theme park
summary: Abu Dhabi-based Miral Asset Management will build a $1 billion Warner Bros theme park, Warner Bros World Abu Dhabi, set to open in 2018. The park will feature rides and a hotel linked to Warner Bros' comic and cartoon characters, including Batman and Bugs Bunny. Miral will invest $1 billion, while Warner Bros will provide expertise. The project competes with neighboring Dubai for tourist dollars, offering a new entertainment option in the emirate.

site_title: Argentina gets warm investor welcome on return to credit markets
summary: Argentina successfully returned to the sovereign debt market with a bond offer, receiving vastly more demand than supply. The operation aims to raise at least $12.5 billion and is nearly five times over-subscribed, with demand reaching $70 billion. This marks a significant milestone for Argentina's economic recovery and access to international capital markets.

images.alt_text: Global investors gave Argentina's return to the sovereign debt market a warm welcome with demand for its first bond offer in 15 years vastly outstripping supply, a source close to the matter said Tuesday.

site_title: VW managers should voluntarily forego bonuses: works council chief
summary: Volkswagen's works council chief, Bernd Osterloh, suggests that executives should forego bonuses due to the company's massive engine-rigging scandal. This move is seen as a moral response to the controversy. The company's CEO, Matthias Mueller, had previously proposed belt-tightening measures, but details of the bonus waiver will be agreed upon by the supervisory board. The move could also include a waiver in the dividend payout to shareholders, which has not been seen since the 1980s.

site_title: Dubai property prices fell 10% in Q1: JLL
summary: Dubai residential property prices fell 10% in Q1 due to a strong dollar and reduced spending following the oil price slump. The market has softened since 2014, with tougher borrowing regulations and higher fees contributing to the decline. Apartment prices dropped 10% and house prices fell 11% year-on-year, while rents decreased 5%. The UAE currency's peg to the dollar has made properties more expensive for international buyers, and the low oil prices are affecting regional liquidity, affecting the real estate market. Despite this, JLL remains positive on the long-term outlook due to future growth drivers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 6.53 points to close at 1,711.15 on Tuesday, with 1.49 billion lots valued at RM1.91 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 329 to 422.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Keppel Corp will not resume work for Brazilian client Sete until it starts making payments on its orders. Apple Pay is being rolled out in Singapore with American Express and StarHub. DBS Bank partnered with peer-to-peer lending sites Funding Societies and MoolahSense. The Singapore dollar reversed its drop from the MAS surprise easing.
