Singapore's board diversity ranks behind its less developed neighbors. Asia's wealthy families are buying US dollars as regional currencies rally. The STI rose for the fifth time in six days, gaining 34.06 points.

site_title: Eurozone bank sector on mend, ECB survey shows
summary: The European Central Bank's quarterly bank lending survey shows the eurozone bank sector is on the mend, with banks easing credit standards for loans to enterprises. This is an encouraging sign, as credit activity has previously been blamed for the euro area's slow recovery. Competitive pressures were the main factor behind the easing, while credit standards for household loans tightened. Demand for loans also increased, driven by low interest rates and a favorable housing market. The ECB's ultra-easy monetary policy is starting to feed through into the real economy, with banks passing on money to the small and mid-sized enterprises that are the region's backbone.

site_title: Yen falls as haven appeal dulled by recovery in crude, stocks
summary: The yen declined 0.5% to 109.33 per dollar against its 16 major peers, as investors shifted to riskier assets amid a recovery in stocks and commodities, with oil reaching above $40 a barrel and European stocks reaching a three-month high. This trend is attributed to a "risk-on phase," with investors betting on currency appreciation, particularly for commodity-exporter nations like Australia and New Zealand.

site_title: OSIM drops interim dividend after Q1 earnings dive
summary: OSIM International reported a 42% drop in net profit to S$7.84 million in Q1, driven by weaker sales and cost pressures. Revenue fell 7.7% to S$138.3 million, mainly due to a "weaker environment." The company adopted a cautious approach, rationalizing unprofitable stores and maintaining margins amid rising fixed costs. OSIM also declared no interim dividend, down from a one-cent interim dividend last year. The group's net asset value per share remained unchanged at 51 Singapore cents.

site_title: Eurozone's current account surplus narrows: ECB
summary: The eurozone's current account surplus narrowed to 19 billion euros in February, down from 27.5 billion euros a month earlier. Direct and portfolio investment rose to 121.6 billion euros, up from 50.2 billion euros in the previous month. The increase in investment suggests a strengthening of the eurozone economy.

site_title: China seeks to establish own gold benchmark
summary: China has established its first-ever gold benchmark, setting the price for 99.99% gold at 256.92 yuan (S$53.94) per gram, aiming to increase liquidity and efficiency in the gold market. The move is part of China's strategy to expand the use of the yuan as a global currency, with the goal of eventually making the currency fully convertible. The Shanghai Gold Exchange plans to study yuan-dominated benchmark prices for other precious metals, including silver, platinum, and palladium.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher for fifth time in six days
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 34.06 points to 2,951.81, marking its fifth consecutive gain in six days, driven by banks and Singtel's 10-point increase. The rally was influenced by the US market's overnight jump and Dow futures rise, with investors seeking a safe haven amid China's slowdown and Europe's stagnation.

site_title: Panama says will adopt international tax reporting standards by 2018: media
summary: Panama has committed to adopting international tax reporting standards by 2018, as part of efforts to improve transparency following the "Panama Papers" controversy. President Juan Carlos Varela made the announcement during a visit to Tokyo, where he also agreed to participate in the automatic exchange of tax information. A committee will be established to make the Panamanian financial system more transparent, and members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development will visit Panama to negotiate specific methods for sharing information. This comes after the OECD chief confirmed Panama's decision to adopt international tax reporting standards.

site_title: Experts examine new debris for MH370 clues
summary: Australian investigators are examining two new pieces of debris from Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 for clues to the missing jet's fate. The debris, found in South Africa and Mauritius, were brought to the Australian Transport Safety Bureau's laboratories for testing. Similar debris found in Mozambique last year was confirmed to be from the Boeing 777 aircraft. Tests revealed marine ecology and biological material on the debris, which may provide clues to the plane's sea journey. The results will be shared with the Malaysian investigation team.

site_title: Asahi says buying Peroni and Grolsch brands from AB InBev
summary: Japanese beer giant Asahi plans to acquire the Peroni and Grolsch brands from Anheuser-Busch InBev for 2.55 billion euros (S$3.8 billion). The deal is part of a tie-up with SABMiller and is expected to be completed in the second half of this year. Asahi's acquisition will give it a significant presence in the global beer market.

site_title: Thai cabinet approves 82b baht Bangkok rail project
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a 82 billion baht (S$3.16 billion) rail project in Bangkok, part of a larger infrastructure push to revive the country's sluggish economy. The 21.2-kilometer Orange Line will connect central Bangkok to eastern suburbs, with a cost lowered by 14% from an earlier estimate.

site_title: EU won't water down criteria for Turkish visa waiver: Juncker
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker stated that Turkey must meet all requirements for a visa waiver with the EU and the criteria won't be watered down. The EU is relying on Turkey to curb migrant flow, with some progress made. However, Ankara has threatened to walk away from the deal if the EU doesn't meet its part of the March accord. Juncker emphasized that Turkey must fulfill all remaining conditions for the EU to adopt its proposal in the coming months.

site_title: China: Stocks end up, but rebound loses steam
summary: China stocks closed marginally up on Tuesday, with the CSI300 index rising 0.3% to 3,238.30, and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.3% to 3,042.82 points. Investors weighed conflicting signals over China's economic recovery. The slight rebound lost steam, as conflicting economic signals weighed on market sentiment.

images.alt_text: China stocks closed marginally up on Tuesday, as investors weighed conflicting signals over the path of China's economic recovery.

site_title: American Express, StarHub among first in Singapore to roll out Apple Pay
summary: American Express and StarHub have become the first companies in Singapore to roll out Apple Pay, allowing customers to make contactless payments with their Apple devices. American Express card members can add their eligible cards to Apple Pay, while StarHub customers can also make mobile payments with Apple Pay at participating stores. Visa cardholders are expected to follow suit soon. This move aims to provide customers with a convenient and secure payment experience.

site_title: Kuwait oil output rises to 1.5 million barrels a day amid strike
summary: Kuwait's crude oil output rose to 1.5 million barrels a day after the state oil company resumed production at halted facilities amid a labor strike. The strike, now in its third day, had reduced output by 60% to 1.1 million barrels a day. Kuwait Petroleum Corp, the main national oil company, managed to meet its supply commitments despite the strike, with oil prices rising 2.2% to $43.86 a barrel. The strike, which began over pay and benefits cuts, may last 10-15 days, according to analysts.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit one-month high, L'Oreal leads
summary: European equities reached a one-month high, driven by gains in commodities-related stocks and encouraging company updates. The FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.6% as L'Oreal led the gains, increasing 4.6% on its pledge to outperform the market in 2016. Shares in mining companies like Anglo American, Glencore, and Rio Tinto also surged, while oil prices advanced following a strike in Kuwait. The rally came as investors looked beyond global economic uncertainty and focused on company performance.

site_title: Silver surges to 10-month high; lifts gold
summary: Silver prices surged 3% to a 10-month high of US$16.73 an ounce, lifting gold by 1% to a session high of $1,246.40 an ounce. The surge was driven by a softer dollar and robust buying in China, with spot silver triggering stops and prompting heavy purchases. A weakening dollar and oil price stabilisation also contributed to the price increase.

site_title: German investor morale rises more than expected in April
summary: German investor morale rose more than expected in April, with the economic sentiment index increasing to 11.2 points from 4.3 in March, according to a ZEW survey. Despite concerns about the impact of weak emerging markets on Germany's export-reliant economy, the result was higher than the Reuters forecast of 8.0 points. The current conditions gauge fell to 47.7 points from 50.7 in March. The improvement suggests that German investors are cautiously optimistic about the economy.

site_title: South Korea fin min says downside risks to economy bigger than expected
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Yoo Il Ho, stated that downside risks to the local economy are bigger than expected due to domestic consumption's slow pace and global sluggishness. The Bank of Korea lowered its GDP forecast to 2.8% and the IMF downgraded its projection to 2.7%. To bolster the economy, the minister emphasized the need for structural reform.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index soars 3.7%, extending global equities rally
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index surged 3.68% to 16,874.44, extending a global equities rally. Investors shrugged off failed oil output talks, with a weaker yen lifting exporters. The broader Topix index jumped 3.25%. The rally comes as traders brush off new US President Trump threats, focusing on US-EU trade talks and S&P 500, Nasdaq records.

site_title: Seoul: Won jumps to a new 2016 high as c.bank holds rates; stocks wobble
summary: The South Korean won jumped to a new 2016 high, reaching 1,136.3 to the US dollar, as the Bank of Korea held interest rates for the 10th consecutive month. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.1% at 2,011.36 points. Governor Lee Ju Yeol stated that rate changes would have limited effect in boosting the economy, contributing to the currency's rise.

site_title: Singdollar reverses all of the drop from MAS surprise easing
summary: The Singapore dollar has reversed its drop from last week's surprise easing by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), strengthening 1.1% over the past three trading days. The MAS shifted to a neutral stance, targeting zero appreciation for the currency, after dropping 0.9% against the greenback on April 14. Traders expect the Federal Reserve to proceed cautiously due to global economic risks, and a change in Fed rhetoric is needed to weaken the Singapore dollar further.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks climb as oil kicks higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.30% on Tuesday, following a global rally, as oil prices increased due to a crude workers strike in Kuwait. The Hang Seng Index closed at 21,436.21, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.30%. The global economic hopes and oil price rise lifted market sentiment, contributing to the stocks' upward trend.

site_title: Indonesia starts on long road to fix its dysfunctional money markets
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, is taking steps to fix its dysfunctional short-term money markets by shifting to a seven-day operating rate in August, abandoning the 12-month reference rate. The policy rate is currently 6.75% and will be lowered to 5.50% for one-week reverse repo contracts. The move aims to reduce the high cost of funds, which has been volatile. However, experts say the journey to fix the money markets will be long.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit highest since early 2016, NZ shares top record
summary: Australian shares reached their highest level since early 2016, rising 1% to 5,219 points on Tuesday, driven by buoyant iron ore prices. New Zealand shares also hit a record high, with the S&P/NZX 50 index increasing 0.3% to 6,873 points. BHP Billiton and Fortescue gained over 5% on the back of rising iron ore prices. The gains come as investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records.

site_title: Powerful blast rattles central Kabul
summary: A powerful explosion occurred in central Kabul on Tuesday, a week after the Taliban announced the start of their annual spring offensive. The blast, which occurred during morning rush hour, struck a densely packed neighborhood near military compounds, but no immediate casualties were reported. The explosion rattled windows and sent thick smoke into the sky. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred amidst ongoing efforts to bring the Taliban back to the negotiating table. The Taliban warned of "large-scale attacks" during the spring offensive, dubbed Operation Omari.

site_title: China looks to broaden free trade agreement with New Zealand
summary: China aims to expand its free trade agreement with New Zealand, with Premier Li Keqiang stating the goal of broadening the agreement and increasing cooperation in areas such as agriculture and food safety. The move comes as China seeks to counter the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership and promote the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership. The agreement, signed in 2008, has already made New Zealand China's largest export market. China and New Zealand will work together to upgrade the agreement, with Prime Minister John Key expressing his commitment to the expansion.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks up on global equities rise, BOK rate decision
summary: South Korean shares rose to a new high for the year, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) up 0.1% at 2,011.44 points. The won strengthened 0.6% against the dollar, following the Bank of Korea's decision to keep interest rates steady for the 10th straight month at 1.50%. The central bank's decision supported a "broad risk-on mood" in global equities, with offshore investors purchasing 53 billion won worth of KOSPI shares.

site_title: Australia PM Turnbull sets up July 2 election
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has set a July 2 election date after the budget is delivered on May 3. The election will be a double dissolution, contesting all seats in both the lower and upper houses of parliament. Turnbull seized power from Tony Abbott in September, aiming to revive the Liberal Party's popularity. The election comes after the Senate rejected legislation to overhaul unions, giving Turnbull the trigger to call the election.

site_title: Busy skies a tailwind for Asian jet fuel demand
summary: Asian jet fuel demand is expected to rise, cutting the region's aviation fuel surplus in 2017 by the most in at least five years. With 100 million new passengers per year, the travel boom is eroding Asia's structural surplus of jet fuel. The surplus is expected to tighten by 38,000 barrels per day (bpd) in 2017, with Asia's jet fuel demand growing 128,000 bpd this year to 2.175 million bpd. This will cut the surplus by 44,000 bpd to 222,000 bpd in 2017, providing a rare pillar of support for Asia's refining sector.

site_title: China launches yuan gold fix to boost power in global bullion market
summary: China has launched a yuan-denominated gold benchmark, aiming to exert control over the global bullion market and boost its influence. The benchmark price, set at 256.92 yuan per gram, is a culmination of efforts to reform China's domestic gold market. The move is seen as a stepping stone to a new multi-axis trading market, with China's influence expected to increase on the global gold market. The benchmark is complementary to prices in London and New York, and its launch signals a shift in demand from West to East.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB bonds rally as fund row stokes volatility
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB bonds rallied as the state investment company's dispute with Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund sparked volatility. The US$3 billion 4.4% notes jumped 4.3 cents to 84.3 cents on the dollar, halting a three-day slide. 1MDB failed to make a payment of over US$1 billion, creating a default, but the bonds are not yet in default due to a grace period. The dispute raises doubts about the company's debt restructuring efforts and may impact Malaysia's sovereign guarantee.

site_title: Buying insurers shows China builders straining in debt load
summary: Chinese insurance companies have set records for their real estate acquisitions, prompting developers to seek insurers. Country Garden Holdings Co and Future Land Development are bidding for Dah Sing Financial Holdings Ltd's life insurance operations. This trend reflects a growing appetite for cash-yielding assets as developers struggle with soaring land costs and high debt levels. Insurers, meanwhile, are benefiting from increasing demand from savers, with their total assets jumping 22% last year. The move could help developers secure stable external funding and manage their debt load, but also raises concerns about the risks associated with such acquisitions.

site_title: Japan quake survivors struggle with shortages, search for missing goes on
summary: A series of Japanese quakes measuring up to 7.3 caused widespread damage, with 44 deaths and over 1,000 injured. Survivors struggled with food and water shortages, while rescuers continued to search for the missing, with hopes of finding survivors dimming. The death toll rose as aftershocks continued to rattle the region, and flights resumed to the damaged airport in Kumamoto. Over 94,000 people remained in evacuation centers, and the government warned of further aftershocks, with the benchmark Nikkei rising 3.7% in mid-morning trade.

site_title: New York votes, Clinton and Trump tipped to win
summary: New York holds a pivotal presidential primary, with Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump expected to secure victories in the Democratic and Republican primaries. Clinton leads Bernie Sanders by double digits, while Trump is streets ahead of Ted Cruz and John Kasich. A win in New York would stall Sanders' momentum and secure Clinton's nomination. Trump hopes to sew up the nomination before the Republican convention in July, while Sanders may be willing to support Clinton if she moves further left on issues.

site_title: Queen marks 90th birthday, as popular as ever
summary: Queen Elizabeth II celebrates her 90th birthday with a family gathering and a cake baked by reality TV star Nadiya Jamir Hussain, as a new poll finds she remains as popular as ever with 76% of the public supporting the monarchy. The queen has reigned for over 63 years, showing no signs of retiring, and her determination to remain above politics has been emphasized. Public events, including a military parade and lunch for 10,000 guests, will take place in June as part of her official birthday celebrations.

images.alt_text: Queen Elizabeth II celebrates her 90th birthday on Thursday with a family gathering and a cake baked by a reality television star, as a new poll finds Britain's longest serving monarch is as popular as ever.

site_title: Oil prices dip as freeze talks failure trumps Kuwait strike
summary: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday, extending losses from Monday's collapse of oil output talks in Doha. Despite a potential impact from a strike by oil workers in Kuwait, the losses were tempered by news of industrial action by thousands of Kuwaiti oil workers. The oversupply concerns persist, with prices continuing to fall amidst global market uncertainty.

site_title: Macau's security chief appointed to gaming commission
summary: Macau's Secretary for Security, Wong Sio Chak, has been appointed to the local gaming commission, further strengthening supervision and control in the territory's casino hub. The move comes amid declining casino revenues and increased gaming-related crimes, including loansharking and false imprisonment. Wong's appointment is part of a review of the gaming industry, which aims to diversify the sector and reduce its reliance on casinos, contributing to over 80% of government revenues.

site_title: South Korea cuts 2016 growth outlook, holds interest rates
summary: South Korea's central bank cut its economic growth outlook for 2016 to 2.8%, down 0.2 percentage points from its previous forecast, citing slumping exports and weak global demand. Despite this, the bank kept interest rates unchanged at 1.5% and expects a moderate recovery in the second quarter. The move comes amid a slowdown in China, the world's second-largest economy, and a global economic slowdown. The bank also lowered its inflation outlook to 1.2% from 1.4%.

images.alt_text: South Korea on Tuesday cut its outlook for economic growth and inflation this year blaming slumping exports but kept interest rates on hold saying it expected to see a modest pick-up in the second quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares rebound at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded at the open on Tuesday, rising 1.31% to 21,438.13, following a decline the previous day. The Shanghai composite index also gained 0.44% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.41%. The rebound is attributed to dealers ignoring the collapse of weekend oil output talks.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares rally on commodities, NZ hits record high
summary: Australian shares rose to a 3-1/2-month high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 1% to 5,190.800 points, driven by a surge in oil prices and gains in energy and mining companies. New Zealand stocks also reached a record high, with the S&P/NZX 50 index up 0.1% at 6,860.40 points. Investors took comfort in the 11% rise in iron ore shipments and confirmation of a record 350 million tonnes in 2016.

site_title: Climate change may boost spread of Zika, other viruses
summary: Climate change may accelerate the spread of mosquito-borne diseases, including Zika, due to rising temperatures that expand the range of mosquitoes. Experts warn that the Zika virus, likely to arrive in Europe and the US this summer, could spread more rapidly. Climate change contributes to the expansion of mosquito habitats, increasing the risk of disease transmission.

site_title: Hyundai Motor, Cisco to team up on Internet-connected car technology
summary: Hyundai Motor and Cisco Systems have partnered to develop Internet-connected car technology, aiming to create "high-performing computers on wheels." The partnership, announced on April 19, 2016, will co-develop in-vehicle network technology for high-speed data transfer. This collaboration is part of Hyundai's strategy to establish an industry-leading connected car platform through technology partnerships.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse set to re-introduce closing auction on July 25
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEx) has scheduled the re-introduction of a closing auction on July 25, aligning with international peers. The mechanism aims to reduce volatility at the end of trading sessions. The HKEx first launched a closing auction in 2008 but scrapped it due to design flaws. International investors have campaigned for its re-introduction, citing it as crucial for Hong Kong's status as a financial center. The exchange began testing the auction in February, with further details on timings to be announced.

site_title: DBS partners two peer-to-peer lending sites to serve small businesses
summary: DBS Bank has partnered with two peer-to-peer lending sites, Funding Societies and MoolahSense, to refer smaller businesses to these platforms for loans. In return, the lending platforms will refer borrowers to DBS for larger loans and financial solutions. This collaboration marks a first-of-its-kind partnership between established financial institutions and emerging fintechs, expanding DBS's lending capabilities and providing more access to funding for small businesses.

images.alt_text: DBS Bank on Tuesday announced it has signed cross-referral agreements with two local peer-to-peer (p2p) lending platforms, Funding Societies and MoolahSense - in a first-of-its-kind collaboration between established financial institutions and emerging fintechs (financial technology startups).

site_title: Australia's Turnbull sets course for long election campaign
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced on Tuesday that the country will likely go to the polls on July 2, after parliament voted down a key labour reform bill. The move paves the way for an unusually long election campaign, expected to last 74 days. Turnbull's government will function as normal until May 3, when it will deliver its budget, and he plans to use the "double dissolution" manoeuvre to revamp the Senate. The election will be held if the parliament is dissolved, allowing Turnbull to deliver a budget despite opposition.

site_title: Singapore loses to less developed neighbours in board diversity
summary: Singapore ranks near the bottom in female representation on company boards in the Asia-Pacific region, according to a Korn Ferry study of 2014 annual reports. Women made up 7.7% of boards in Singapore, 2.6% in South Korea, and 3.3% in Japan. This falls behind other less developed peers, highlighting a gap in achieving gender diversity in corporate leadership. The study's findings suggest Singapore's more developed economy may not be translating into better representation of women in key corporate roles.

site_title: Google's mobile model threatened by EU's Android antitrust probe
summary: Google's mobile model is under threat in Europe due to an antitrust probe. Regulators are expected to unveil charges that could require Google to change how it offers tools like Search on phones, making it harder for the company to generate revenue from mobile ads. This could have a significant impact on Google's business, with analysts warning of "large-scale business model changes." The outcome of the probe could have far-reaching consequences for the tech giant's mobile revenue.

site_title: Japan govt taps Shinsei Bank exec Takako Masai for BOJ board
summary: The Japanese government has nominated Takako Masai, a 51-year-old executive officer of Shinsei Bank Ltd, to join the Bank of Japan's policy board. Masai, who advocates for aggressive monetary easing, will replace Koji Ishida, whose term expires in June. This move is seen as a shift towards more expansionary monetary policies.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank latest to tighten mortgages to foreigners
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia has tightened its mortgage lending criteria for foreigners, no longer approving applications citing self-employed foreign income or foreign-currency income of temporary residents. The lender, which accounts for one in four mortgages, will only approve up to 70% of the property's value for such borrowers, a change similar to that made by Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. The move follows warnings from the Reserve Bank of Australia about risks to property prices and banks' loan losses due to declining Chinese demand.

site_title: Oil price bounce boosts ringgit; 1MDB woes push up credit costs
summary: Malaysia's ringgit strengthened 0.7% to 3.9012 per dollar after Brent crude stabilized, reversing a three-day loss. The currency's gain is attributed to the stabilization of oil prices, which boosted revenue for oil-exporting Malaysia. However, 1Malaysia Development Bhd's failure to make a payment of over US$1 billion has raised concerns, increasing the cost to insure Malaysian bonds to the highest this month. The country's finance ministry has denied default, but credit-default swaps rose 11 basis points to 163.

site_title: 1MDB's Abu Dhabi dispute puts restructure in doubt, Moody's says
summary: Malaysia's state investment company 1MDB is facing a loan dispute with Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, putting its debt restructuring efforts in doubt. Moody's Investors Service says 1MDB failed to make a payment of over $1 billion, making it and Malaysia's finance ministry in default. The dispute raises concerns about the progress of 1MDB's debt rationalization plan, which aims to cut borrowings after accumulating over $17 billion in debt. The move has led to a rise in the cost to protect Malaysia's sovereign notes and a depreciation of the ringgit currency.

site_title: Chernobyl zone turns into testbed for Nature's rebound
summary: The Chernobyl nuclear disaster site, abandoned for nearly 30 years, is now a nature reserve where wildlife has begun to recover. The area, tainted by radiation, has seen a resurgence of species, including wild horses, as humans have left. Biologist Denys Vyshnevskiy notes that "nature returned" after the site was abandoned, highlighting the site's potential as a unique ecosystem. The Chernobyl exclusion zone has become a testbed for nature's rebound, offering insights into the area's recovery and potential for future conservation efforts.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally with Wall St after oil shock
summary: Asia's stock markets rallied on Tuesday, led by Tokyo's 3.5% gain, as Wall Street recovered from oil shock and positive comments from US Fed officials lifted investor sentiment. The US economy is seen as "fundamentally sound" and likely to outperform its trading partners, according to President Eric Rosengren. Gains in New York and Europe were followed by similar gains in Asia, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Sydney also rising. Oil prices pared losses, but Brent was still down 0.4% and West Texas Intermediate 0.3%.

site_title: It's all suddenly going wrong in China's US$3 trillion bond market
summary: China's $3 trillion corporate bond market is experiencing a significant downturn, with yields rising for nine consecutive days and triggering a selloff in junk debt. Defaults by state-owned enterprises have led to cancellations of bond sales, with Standard & Poor's cutting its assessment of Chinese firms at a pace unseen since 2003. The economy's reliance on cheap credit is under threat, and investors are becoming increasingly bearish, with analysts cutting profit forecasts and credit ratings. The government faces a balancing act to avoid tighter credit conditions and maintain economic growth, with the potential for a deeper selloff in the bond market.

site_title: Bill Gates says US needs limits on covert email searches
summary: Bill Gates expressed support for Microsoft's lawsuit against the US government, which seeks to notify customers when federal agencies have sought their data. Gates acknowledged that there may be cases where the government should access data covertly, but believes it should be extraordinary and not automatic. He emphasized the need for collaboration between law enforcement and privacy advocates to strike a balance on government access to private data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.400 points to 1713.870, following a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks. Volume was 31.6 million lots worth RM17.2 million, with 83 gainers outnumbering losers 49.

site_title: China sovereign fund said to seek control of US$8b Yum unit
summary: A Chinese sovereign fund, China Investment Corp, is seeking control of Yum! Brands Inc's China business, valued at $7 billion to $8 billion. The consortium, also including KKR & Co and Baring Private Equity Asia, is conducting due diligence on the unit. A majority purchase would give a domestic entity control of a leading fast-food chain in China for the first time, and could provide Yum with cash to fund a dividend and share buyback. Other investors, including Singapore's Temasek Holdings and Chinese private equity firm Primavera Capital, are also vying for stakes in Yum China.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars scale 10mth peaks as oil bounce spurs risk-on mood
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached 10-month highs on April 19, 2016, as oil prices stabilized, boosting risk-on sentiment and causing the yen and government bonds to decline. The Australian dollar reached $0.7784, its highest since June, and the New Zealand dollar reached $0.6995, benefiting from global risk appetite. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cautioned that a rising Aussie could tilt the economy off balance, but the RBA kept rates at a record low 2.0% for an 11th month.

site_title: Fed's Rosengren takes another shot at pessimistic markets
summary: Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren warned that US markets are too pessimistic about the economy and monetary policy, urging a more rapid interest rate hike than expected. Rosengren downplayed weak growth in the first quarter and said inflation is closer to the Fed's 2% goal. He expressed concern that an overly cautious interest rate path could risk overheating the economy, contradicting market predictions that imply no further rate hikes until December.

site_title: China widens graft curbs on business activities by officials' families
summary: China's ruling Communist Party expands a pilot anti-graft scheme to four more regions, including Beijing, Chongqing, Xinjiang, and Guangdong, to restrict business activities by the families of senior officials. The scheme, which was initially introduced in Shanghai, bars spouses and children of officials from registering businesses, investing abroad, or holding top positions in private companies. The move aims to curb corruption and follows criticism of officials' families enriching themselves through their relationships. The government will establish detailed rules and procedures to implement the scheme, which is part of President Xi Jinping's crackdown on corruption.

site_title: MMP Resources to issue convertible notes worth S$600,000
summary: MMP Resources has agreed to issue S$600,000 in convertible notes to Maiora Asset Management. The lender will receive up to 25 million free detachable warrants, exercisable into new shares at S$0.007 each. The issuance is subject to Singapore Exchange and shareholder approval.

site_title: Japan quakes damage castle, unnerve tourists as deaths rise
summary: Japan's Kyushu region has been severely damaged by a series of earthquakes, resulting in a 44-death toll and over 1,000 injuries. Tourist groups from China, South Korea, and Taiwan have canceled trips to the area, with travel agencies anticipating further cancellations. The region's peak spring travel season coincides with the damage, with carriers canceling flights to Kumamoto. Analysts predict a "spillover effect" on Japan's tourism industry, with Chinese tourists hesitant to visit the country due to the disaster.

images.alt_text: Tourist groups from China, South Korea, and Taiwan, the three biggest sources of visitors to Japan, have scrapped trips to the quake-devastated Kyushu region and travel agencies are anticipating further cancellations.

site_title: White House: Not in Saudi interest to destabilize global economy over 9/11 bill
summary: The White House stated that Saudi Arabia would not sell US assets worth $750 billion in response to a bill that could hold the kingdom responsible for any role in the 9/11 attacks. President Barack Obama opposes the bill, citing concerns it could expose the US to lawsuits from citizens of other countries. The bill has 22 co-sponsors in the Senate, but no vote has been scheduled. Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton supports the bill, while Senator Bernie Sanders expresses concern about potential liability.

images.alt_text: The New York Times reported on Friday that Saudi foreign minister Adel al-Jubeir told US lawmakers that the country would be forced to sell up to US$750 billion in Treasury securities and other US assets in response to the bill if it passed.

site_title: Yen strength helps South Korean exporters stomach won resurgence
summary: South Korean exporters are benefiting from the won's 7.1% slide against the yen, boosting their competitiveness against Japanese rivals. The yen's 10% surge against the dollar this year has reduced the won's depreciation against the dollar, allowing Korean exports to remain competitive. The Bank of Korea (BOK) has maintained its policy rate at a record low of 1.5% for the 10th consecutive month, citing the country's current-account surplus and potential economic improvements. Experts expect the won to continue appreciating, but warn that a rate cut is likely by the end of the year to boost growth.

site_title: Penny-pinching Indonesians seen imperiling Jakarta stock rebound
summary: Indonesian investors are shifting their focus to cash, citing signs of an economic slowdown, which may impact Jakarta's stock market rebound. Fund manager Jeffrosenberg Tan has increased cash holdings to the highest levels in six months, concerned that reduced spending may cut short gains in consumer stocks. This shift in investor behavior could imperil the recent surge in Indonesia's consumer-focused stocks, which reached a record this year.

site_title: US poised to approve Boeing fighter jet sales to Qatar, Kuwait
summary: The US government is set to approve sales of Boeing fighter jets to Qatar and Kuwait, worth around $4 billion and $3 billion respectively. The sales, which have been delayed due to concerns over equipment falling into the wrong hands, have been signed off by the Pentagon and State Department. The deals are seen as a way to shore up relations with Gulf allies and maintain production of fourth-generation Boeing fighter jets, which will be replaced by the newer F-35 in coming years.

site_title: Asia: Stocks gain as oil rebounds, weaker yen boosts Japan shares
summary: Asian stocks rose 1.4% to 132.04 as of 9:10 am in Tokyo, following US shares higher after crude oil advanced for the first time in five days. The yen retreated, boosting Japanese shares. Investors shrugged off oil's losses on failed output talks and looked towards corporate earnings this week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed above the 18,000 level for the first time since July.

site_title: Annual Apple developers gathering set for June
summary: Apple will hold its annual Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) in San Francisco in June, kicking off on June 13 with a keynote presentation showcasing its software platforms for various devices. The event will feature innovative operating systems and a new programming language, and conference sessions will be streamed live online. This year's conference follows Google's annual developers conference in May, highlighting the growing importance of third-party developers in the popularity of rival operating systems.

site_title: 'Limited' activity at North Korea nuclear test site: US think-tank
summary: US think-tank reports limited activity at North Korea's nuclear test site, despite intelligence suggesting a possible fifth underground test. Satellite images show "very limited" activity at the Punggye-ri test site, with key areas clear of snow. Analysts note that North Korea's preparations can be masked, and a test is still possible. The assessment comes amid speculation that a test could be conducted before a ruling party congress early next month, where leader Kim Jong-Un is expected to take credit for advancing the nuclear program.

site_title: Malta government survives Panama Papers no confidence vote
summary: Malta's left-of-centre government survived a no-confidence vote linked to the Panama Papers, with 38 parliament members voting against the opposition motion. The vote, which lasted 13 hours, followed revelations naming the energy minister and prime minister's chief-of-staff. Prime Minister Joseph Muscat stated the vote was "strong and without ambiguity" and will allow the government to continue working towards results.

site_title: Acromec secures two contracts worth S$7.1m
summary: Acromec, a Singapore-based cleanroom specialist, has secured two contracts worth S$7.1 million from a healthcare customer, bringing its order book to S$47 million. The contracts include the refurbishment of hospital operating theatres, scheduled for May to October this year. This win demonstrates the company's growing presence in the healthcare sector, with its shares trading on the Catalist board since Monday.

site_title: China's crowded smartphone market heads for an epic shakeout
summary: China's smartphone market is undergoing a significant shakeout, with around 150 vendors expected to remain in the industry, down from 300. The market has plateaued due to intense competition and economic growth slowing to a quarter-century low. Domestic brands such as Xiaomi and Huawei, which once dominated the market, are now expanding into lower price tiers to stay competitive. Many smaller players, like Dakele, are shutting down, while others are shifting focus to international markets like India and Africa. The market is expected to consolidate, with the top brands controlling around 30% of the market share.

site_title: Stocks to watch: First Reit, Keppel Corp, Darco, Addvalue, SMRT
summary: Singapore stocks to watch on April 19, 2016, include First Reit, which reported a 6.2% rise in distributable income to S$16.2 million for the first quarter. Keppel Corp saw a 41.5% slump in net profit due to a decline in revenue. Other notable updates include Darco Water Technologies securing a contract worth S$8.5 million, Addvalue Technologies entering a three-year distribution contract with Zhongyou Century, and SMRT Corporation's unit signing a one-year partnership with Grab.

site_title: No money from Brazil means no work by Keppel for client Sete
summary: Keppel Corp, the world's largest oil rig builder, has halted work for Brazilian client Sete Brasil Participacoes SA due to non-payment. Keppel reported a $230 million charge on the delinquent projects in January and will not resume construction until payment resumes. The move comes as Sete Brasil faces a corruption probe and considers filing for bankruptcy. Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua stated that the company will only restart construction when payment recommences.

site_title: China's Xi sets aside usual rancour to express sympathy over Japan quakes
summary: China's President Xi Jinping sent a message of condolence to Japan's emperor after a series of earthquakes hit Japan's southwestern island of Kyushu, killing at least 42 people. Xi expressed sympathy, extending condolences to bereaved families and the injured, and hoped Japanese people would overcome their difficulties. This rare display of sympathy from Xi comes despite China's strained history with Japan, including conflicting claims over uninhabited East China Sea islets. The gesture is seen as a thaw in recent ties between the two countries, with meetings between Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Xi.

site_title: Everybody Loves Raymond star Doris Roberts dies at 90
summary: Emmy-winning actress Doris Roberts, star of "Everybody Loves Raymond," has died at 90. She won four Best Supporting Actress awards for her portrayal of Marie Barone in the show, which ran for nine seasons. Tributes poured in from colleagues, including Patricia Heaton, who described the end of an era. Roberts' passing marks the end of an era for fans of the beloved sitcom.

site_title: Crude prices edge up on Kuwait oil worker strike
summary: Oil prices rose in early trading on Tuesday due to a strike by oil workers in Kuwait, which cut the country's production to 1.1 million barrels per day. However, analysts predict a short-term disruption, and markets will refocus on a global supply glut. Kuwaiti officials plan to increase production by using inventory stocks and taking legal action against unions, and may compromise with strikers to get exports running again. Oil prices are expected to stabilize once exports resume, with Brent crude futures at $42.95 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate futures at $39.93 a barrel.

site_title: Gold dips as firmer oil prices boost equities
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.3% to $1,228.02 an ounce as oil prices steadied and equities edged higher, reducing safe-haven bids. The decline came after oil prices recovered from a slump and global supply glut concerns resurfaced. Analysts warned that the recent oil producer agreement failure would lead to a short-term market disruption. The US Federal Reserve's dovish comments, including a possible interest rate hike in June, also weighed on gold prices.

site_title: Tencent's Pony Ma says to give shares worth US$2b to charity
summary: Pony Ma, founder of China's Tencent Holdings Ltd, plans to donate 100 million company shares worth over US$2 billion to the firm's charity foundation. The donation will support medical, educational, and environmental causes in China. Ma's estimated fortune is US$18.8 billion, making his donation one of the largest by a Chinese billionaire. The Tencent Foundation, established in 2007, will receive the donation, which is valued at about US$2.1 billion at the time of the announcement.

site_title: South Korea central bank holds interest rates steady as expected
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, held its base interest rate steady at 1.50% on Tuesday, as expected. The decision was made in consideration of the fallout from a parliamentary election earlier this month and the impact of economic policies in major economies. Despite 21 of 27 analysts predicting no change, many forecast a rate cut in the coming months. The decision was made without elaboration by a media official, and Governor Lee Ju-yeol is set to hold a news conference later in the day.

site_title: IBM's revenue beats Street as cloud push begins to pay off
summary: IBM's quarterly revenue beat analysts' estimates, falling 4.6% to $18.68 billion, as the company's shift to high-growth areas such as cloud-based services begins to yield results. Revenue from "strategic imperatives" rose 14% and cloud revenue increased 34%. IBM maintained its full-year adjusted earnings guidance and its shares have risen 10.83% this year, outperforming the S&P 500 index.

site_title: US regulators concerned about leverage in large hedge funds
summary: US regulators have expressed concerns about the high leverage in large hedge funds, but did not designate any asset managers as "systemically important" in a report on asset management. The Financial Stability Oversight Council will form a working group to analyze data on hedge funds and propose standards for measuring leverage by year-end. Regulators have been concerned that a market sell-off could result in funds struggling to sell assets quickly enough to pay investors seeking to redeem shares. The SEC has proposed rules to manage liquidity risks and broaden disclosures about funds' liquidity and redemption practices.

site_title: Football: US releases three Fifa guilty plea transcripts
summary: A US judge released transcripts of guilty pleas from three Fifa defendants, Jeffrey Webb, Alejandro Burzaco, and Jose Margulies, who admitted to racketeering, wire fraud, and money laundering conspiracies. The defendants, who are confined to US house arrest, will be sentenced in June for corruption in New York. They confessed to receiving bribes for commercial rights to soccer matches, including the 2018 and 2022 World Cup qualifying matches. The defendants expressed regret and agreed to pay $37.5 million in compensation, bringing the total number of guilty pleas to 15.

site_title: YP Holdings plans first-round bid to merge with Yahoo: source
summary: YP Holdings LLC, a digital advertising business, plans to submit a first-round bid to merge with Yahoo Inc, valued at $34.6 billion. YP Holdings, controlled by Cerberus Capital Management LP, is exploring strategic alternatives, including selling itself or merging with Yahoo in a tax-free transaction. The deal would see Cerberus acquiring Yahoo, potentially leading to AT&T buying part of the company. Yahoo shares rose 0.03% after the report, closing at $36.52.

images.alt_text: YP Holdings LLC, the digital advertising business of what was formerly called Yellowpages.com, is planning to submit a first-round bid on Monday to merge with Yahoo Inc, a source familiar with the matter said on Monday.

site_title: Droids not drones are the future of e-commerce deliveries
summary: Delivery robots, not drones, are poised to revolutionize e-commerce's final frontier, the Last Mile. Companies like Starship Technologies and Dispatch are testing autonomous ground robots that can navigate sidewalks and deliver packages. The robots have advantages over drones, including lower costs, reduced damage risk, and easier regulatory approval. Amazon is also exploring drone delivery, but its focus on rural areas and congested roads may limit its effectiveness. Experts say the future of delivery may involve a combination of robots, drones, and human couriers, depending on population density and urbanization.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda: excessive yen appreciation could affect inflation trend
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned that excessive yen appreciation could affect Japan's inflation trend, citing its impact on business confidence and inflation expectations. Kuroda stated the BOJ could lower interest rates to minus 0.4% if needed to meet its 2% inflation target. The BOJ is not targeting currencies, but will monitor their movements. Kuroda also emphasized the central bank's commitment to easing further if necessary.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said the trend in inflation could be affected if the yen continued to appreciate excessively, the Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB at risk of default as partner ends bond support
summary: Malaysia's state investment company, 1Malaysia Development Bhd, is at risk of default after failing to make a US$1 billion payment to Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, International Petroleum Investment Co (IPIC). The default, which leaves IPIC with no obligation to make interest payments, comes amid global investigations into allegations of money laundering and embezzlement. 1MDB has denied any wrongdoing, but its bond prices have slumped, and the company's finance ministry claims it will continue to honor all outstanding commitments.

site_title: Theranos under investigation by SEC, US Attorney's Office
summary: Theranos, a blood-testing startup, is under investigation by the US Securities and Exchange Commission and the US Attorney's Office for the Northern District of California. The company is also being probed by the FDA, state health departments in Pennsylvania and California, and has cooperated fully with all investigations. Theranos has closed several inquiries, but the investigations are ongoing, with the company continuing to work closely with regulators.

site_title: Addvalue in three-year distribution contract with China firm
summary: Addvalue Technologies' unit, Addvalue Innovation, has entered into a three-year distribution contract with Zhongyou Century to supply satellite communication terminals to China's maritime vessels market. The first batch of US$4 million worth of supplies will be delivered from May 2016 and contribute positively to Addvalue's financial performance for the 2017 financial year. This contract is part of an alliance forged in 2015 to distribute satellite communication-based products and solutions in China, including the "One Belt, One Road" initiative.

site_title: China defends ground in steel crisis talks
summary: China defended its efforts to address the steel crisis, denying subsidies for its exports and claiming compliance with World Trade Organization rules. At talks in Brussels, China's Assistant Trade Minister Ji Zhang stated that China does not subsidise its steel export industry. The meeting aimed to address plant closures and job losses caused by cheap exports, but no concrete solutions were announced.

site_title: Asia's rich urged to buy US dollars as Singapore fuels easing bets
summary: Money managers for Asia's wealthy families are advising clients to buy US dollars as regional currencies rally this year is slowing. Credit Suisse, UBS, and Stamford Management are recommending a bet on the greenback versus peers like the South Korean won and Philippine peso. The Singapore dollar is also seen as a weak currency, with Stamford urging clients to buy the US dollar each time it falls below S$1.35. This shift is driven by concerns about slowing regional growth and the potential impact of US tariffs on global trade.

site_title: Google searches for more consumer eyeballs with live, VR videos
summary: Google is adding live, 360-degree video and audio to YouTube, allowing users to view live events like sports games and music concerts in immersive, interactive format. The feature can be viewed on standard computers or with virtual reality headsets via the YouTube app on Android phones. The upgrade aims to capture users' attention and advertisers' budgets with more elaborate content, competing with Facebook and traditional TV channels. Advertisers are excited about the new format, and Google plans to broadcast live, 360-degree videos from the Coachella music festival and develop new musical talent.

site_title: Siemens and Valeo team up to produce electric car engines
summary: Siemens and Valeo are teaming up to produce electric car engines, with headquarters in Erlangen, Germany, and facilities in five countries. The partnership, set to be operational in late 2016, aims to support the growing demand for electric and hybrid vehicles. No financial details were disclosed.

site_title: Jason's group financial controller quits; another appointed
summary: Jason Holdings' group financial controller Andrew Loke Yew Kong resigned and was replaced by Alison Yong Mue Fun, effective April 18. Yong, 51, brings 10 years of experience to the role, having previously worked at AEM Holdings and Worldbiz Management Services. The move comes as Jason Holdings faces a lawsuit from sub-contractor Far East Engineering & Construction Pte Ltd over disputed housing projects, with DBS Bank demanding payment of about S$7.29 million.

site_title: US to send more troops to Iraq to tackle Islamic State
summary: The US will deploy approximately 200 additional troops to Iraq to advise Iraqi forces in their battle against Islamic State militants. The troops will be positioned closer to the front lines, supporting Iraqi forces as they advance towards Mosul. US President Barack Obama stated that the deployment is in response to the Iraqis' willingness to fight and gain ground, emphasizing the need for more support. The deployment aims to bolster the Iraqi military's efforts to retake the city of Mosul, currently under Islamic State control.

site_title: Ecuador counts over 400 quake deaths, damage in the billions
summary: A magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck Ecuador, killing at least 413 people and causing widespread damage. President Rafael Correa warned of a "huge" economic impact, with billions of dollars in damage and a potentially devastating effect on the fragile Opec economy. The disaster has also led to looting, with survivors seeking basic necessities like water and food. International support is pouring in, with over 13,500 security personnel deployed and rescue workers from Latin America and Europe arriving on the scene. The death toll is expected to rise further, and reconstruction efforts are expected to be costly.

site_title: Houston deluged, 5 reported dead in Texas floods
summary: Torrential rainfall in Houston, Texas, on April 18, 2016, caused widespread flooding, resulting in five reported deaths. Over 1,000 homes were flooded, and more than 1,000 water rescues were conducted. The city's mayor canceled a scheduled speech and turned a shopping mall into an evacuation center. Power outages affected over 40,000 customers, while numerous highways, including Interstate 10, were blocked. The governor declared a state of disaster in nine Texas counties, warning that flooding risks would persist for several days.

site_title: Silicon Valley veteran Bill Campbell has died: Re/code
summary: Silicon Valley veteran Bill Campbell, who advised tech leaders including Steve Jobs and Jeff Bezos, has died after a long struggle with cancer. Campbell, former CEO of Intuit Inc, held the company's chairman position from 1998 until his retirement in January. He also served on the boards of Apple Inc and Columbia University.

site_title: Women get less than 3% of new CEO jobs as global progress stalls
summary: Women captured less than 3% of new CEO positions globally, the lowest since 2011, according to a PwC study of 2,500 global public companies. In the US and Canada, less than 1% of new CEOs were female, marking the worst showing in 16 years. Despite having 4.4% of S&P 500 companies led by women and 20% of board seats, progress towards gender parity stalls, with the US potentially 40 years from achieving equality.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares surge more than 3% in opening trade
summary: Tokyo shares surged more than 3% in opening trade on Tuesday, driven by a weaker yen and strong gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 3.25% and the Topix index gained 3.04%. The rally follows recent positive momentum on US stock markets.

site_title: Blackberry CEO says tech firms should comply with lawful access requests
summary: BlackBerry CEO John Chen criticized rival tech firms, particularly Apple, for refusing to comply with lawful access requests to protected data. Chen stated that tech companies should prioritize the greater good over their reputations, citing a 2014 case where Canadian law enforcement accessed BlackBerry devices to unravel an organized crime network. Chen emphasized that BlackBerry complies with reasonable access requests, unlike Apple, which declined to unlock an encrypted iPhone used by a San Bernardino shooter.

site_title: China, major producers fail to reach deal over steel
summary: China and other major steel-producing countries failed to agree on measures to tackle a global steel crisis, citing disagreements over the causes of overcapacity and subsidies. Global steelmaking capacity is 2.37 billion tonnes, with only 67.5% used in 2015. China claims the issue is a global problem and that demand collapse after the 2008-2009 financial crisis is the cause, while others blame subsidies and cheap imports. The OECD will hold a further high-level discussion in September to address the issue.

site_title: Darco unit gets 40.9m yuan wastewater treatment system contract
summary: Darco Water Technologies' subsidiary, Wuhan Kaidi Water Services Co, has secured a 40.9 million yuan contract from Tianjin SDIC Jinneng Electric Power Co to construct a Phase II desulfurisation zero-liquid-discharge wastewater treatment system in North China. The project utilizes proprietary brine recovery technology and mechanical vapour recompression technology from Vacom Systems LLC. The successful bid is seen as significant for the group's future development, according to CEO Thye Kim Meng.

site_title: UK probe of British Airways plane-drone strike finds no debris
summary: A UK police investigation into a British Airways Airbus A320 aircraft allegedly struck by a drone found no evidence of a strike and no suspects. The pilot reported a hit on the front of the aircraft while descending over Richmond Park in southwest London. No debris was found, and the police are asking the public for evidence. The incident highlights the dangers of reckless drone use and the need for regulation. UK regulators require drone users to keep their devices away from airports and planes, while the US has stricter distance requirements.

images.alt_text: A UK police investigation into the alleged crash of a drone into a British Airways Airbus A320 aircraft has so far elicited no evidence of a strike and no suspects.

site_title: US dollar weakens on risk appetite as Doha meeting impact fades
summary: The US dollar weakened against most currencies on Monday due to a decline in risk appetite following the failure of oil producers to agree on a plan to curb global supply. Commodity-linked currencies such as the Australian, New Zealand, and Canadian dollars rose against the US dollar, with the Australian dollar reaching a nearly 10-month high of US$0.7759. The move was also influenced by a strike in Kuwait that supported oil prices and greater risk appetite.

site_title: Growth in New Zealand's service sector expands at slower rate: survey
summary: New Zealand's service sector growth expanded at a slower rate in March, with a seasonally adjusted performance of services index (PSI) at 54.8, down 1.9 points from February. This is the lowest level of expansion since November 2014. Despite the slowdown, momentum remains above the historical average of 53.9.

site_title: Argentina wows market with first bond in 15 years
summary: Argentina successfully issued its first international bond in 15 years, garnering over $65 billion in orders. The $15 billion bond, priced at 7.5% interest, will help pay creditors and mark a significant step towards Argentina's economic recovery. The deal, which sets a precedent for economic liberalization in emerging markets, is seen as a positive reform story. Litigant bondholders, who rejected the debt restructuring terms, will receive 75% of the proceeds, while Argentina benefits from a return to the market and a line under the messy litigation.

site_title: BlackBerry responds to police eavesdropping report
summary: BlackBerry acknowledged helping Canadian police crack a Montreal crime syndicate by providing access to its encrypted messages. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police obtained BlackBerry's global cryptographic key, allowing them to read over 1 million messages. BlackBerry CEO John Chen stated the company complies with reasonable lawful access requests but maintains its enterprise servers are "impenetrable" due to client-controlled encryption keys. This comes amid a broader discussion on balancing security and user privacy rights, following Apple's refusal to assist the FBI in accessing an iPhone.

site_title: Morgan Stanley takes another jab at costs as revenue remains elusive
summary: Morgan Stanley cut total expenses by 14% in the first quarter, primarily through reducing staff and compensation costs. The bank aims to cut up to $1 billion in costs by 2017 through Project Streamline, which includes shifting operations to low-cost cities and outsourcing. Analysts question whether Morgan Stanley can hit its 9-11% return-on-equity target by 2017, with some warning that the bank may need to be more aggressive on the cost front. The bank's cost-cutting measures are leading to concerns about its ability to maintain business and gain market share in key areas.

site_title: Euro, pound push higher
summary: The euro and pound strengthened against the US dollar, with the euro reaching US$1.1315 and the pound at US$1.4279, following a broad pullback in investor risk appetite. This was attributed to the failed oil producers meeting, which led to falling stocks and commodities, forcing investors to unwind riskier bets and buy back the euro. The yen initially surged but later declined, ending with slight losses.

site_title: Zika mosquito found in Chile, first time in decades
summary: Chile has identified a specimen of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which carries the Zika virus, on the mainland for the first time in six decades. The finding is a concern, as the mosquito is linked to birth defects and rare neurological diseases. Authorities had previously reported cases of Zika in people who contracted it abroad and one case of it being sexually transmitted in Chile. The discovery in the northern city of Arica has prompted health minister Carmen Castillo to take precautions, highlighting the country's vulnerability to the mosquito.

images.alt_text: The species of mosquito that carries the Zika virus has been found in mainland Chile for the first time in six decades, the country's health minister said Monday.

site_title: Oil recoups heavy losses from Doha talks collapse
summary: Oil prices rebounded from heavy losses after a strike in Kuwait knocked out over 60% of the country's production, supporting the market. Despite a failed agreement by major crude producers to curb output, US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 58 cents to $39.78 a barrel, while Brent crude fell just 19 cents to $42.91 a barrel. The collapse of Doha talks highlights a continued market glut, with rising production and slower global growth contributing to the decline in crude prices.

images.alt_text: The oil market late Monday recouped heavy losses spurred by the failure of major crude producers to agree curbs on output that could have firmed up the market.

site_title: Netflix shares sink as outlook disappoints
summary: Netflix shares declined over 10% after the company reported quarterly earnings and forecasted subscriber growth, despite a record 6.74 million new memberships and a 42% international presence. The streaming service's profit rose to $28 million, and revenue from streaming subscriptions increased to $1.8 billion. The disappointing forecast, which expected 2.5 million new members, overshadowed the company's achievements, with shares closing at $97.40.

site_title: Signs of China growth reduce urgency for more stimulus
summary: China's economic growth appears to have stabilized, with the annual pace slowing to 6.7% in the first quarter, its weakest pace since 2009. While policy advisers caution that easing measures are still necessary, the urgency to cut interest rates has decreased due to concerns about reviving yuan pressure and capital outflows. The central bank is considering alternative policy tools, such as special lending facilities, to support the economy as it undergoes restructuring.

site_title: Elon Musk ahead of pace for US$1.6b Tesla Motors payday
summary: Elon Musk is ahead of schedule to receive a US$1.6 billion payday from Tesla Motors, achieving 50% of the 5.27 million options tied to milestones. He earns 1/10th of the options every time Tesla hits a pair of goals, including market value and operations. To receive the full award, Musk must boost Tesla's value by 28% and meet production and profit targets. Despite recent recalls and sales misses, Tesla's stock price has risen 22% in the past year.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk is ahead of schedule to get a huge payday from Tesla Motors Inc even though he earns less than US$40,000 in annual salary.

site_title: Twitter's new China head wants to 'work together' with state media
summary: Twitter's new China head, Kathy Chen, has called for a "closer partnership" with state media, sparking concerns among users. Chen, an IT engineer, previously worked with the Chinese army and tech giants like Microsoft and Cisco. As managing director for the greater China region, she will oversee Twitter's operations in China, despite the site being blocked in mainland China. Her appointment has raised questions about Twitter's ties to the Chinese government.

site_title: New Mitsubishi CEO seeks 'urgent' shift after commodity sting
summary: Mitsubishi Corp shifts focus away from energy and mining-related businesses due to the metals and oil collapse, forecasting its first-ever annual loss. New CEO Takehiko Kakiuchi aims to rebalance the portfolio, replacing assets in resource businesses with non-resource sectors such as agricultural machinery, automobiles, and salmon farming. The company expects writedowns of up to 430 billion yen, primarily on commodities businesses. Kakiuchi plans to release a three-year plan next month, aiming to survive under the current price environment for commodities.

site_title: SIAS says it will take errant companies to court if need be
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association (SIAS) will take errant companies to court on behalf of minority shareholders if necessary, said SIAS president David Gerald. This comes after recent market and corporate governance lapses involving companies such as OSIM International and SingPost. Gerald stated that SIAS will defend itself against legal action and has lawyers advising it on a pro bono basis. He emphasized that companies should not take minority shareholders for granted and that SIAS is willing to pursue representative actions, similar to class-action suits, to protect investors.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Panama Canal restricts ship depth due to drought
summary: The Panama Canal has started restricting the depth of ships passing through due to severe drought, reducing the maximum allowed draft by 5.9 inches from 39.5 feet to 39 feet. The restriction is expected to last until May 9, with further reductions planned. Three years of drought have depleted water levels in the canal, which relies on two lakes for its water. Officials predict the rainy season in Central America will break the drought, but no early signs of improvement are expected. The restriction is expected to have a minimal impact on the canal's finances.

site_title: China central bank credit engine proves most powerful since 2006
summary: China's central bank has shown the most powerful credit engine since 2006, according to March credit data. The money multiplier, a gauge of new credit created by base money, has reached its highest level since 2006. This indicates the People's Bank of China's efforts to spur new lending and support growth are effective, despite challenges in adopting a new monetary policy structure. In contrast, Japan's ratio declined in the 1990s due to a surge in bad debt following asset-bubble implosions.

site_title: The global oil deal that never came to be
summary: In 2016, a global oil deal was set to be signed by 18 countries, including major Opec and non-Opec nations, to tackle the global oil glut. However, the meeting in Doha, Qatar, collapsed due to disagreements between Saudi Arabia and Iran, which compete for influence in the Middle East. Saudi Arabia demanded that Iran freeze its output before attending the meeting, and when Iran refused, Saudi Arabia scuppered the agreement. The collapse of the deal was attributed to deep mistrust between Saudi Arabia and Iran, and it highlighted the changing leadership in Saudi Arabia under Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

site_title: Bond trading platforms seen getting winnowed
summary: Bond trading platforms are being reduced due to dwindling liquidity, despite the presence of 99 electronic platforms worldwide. Stricter regulatory capital rules and technological advancements have led to a shift away from traditional Wall Street dealers, allowing startups and technology firms to enter the market. However, the increased competition may ultimately be hindered by the same factors that drive demand, such as liquidity concerns. This could lead to a further consolidation of the market.

site_title: Bomb rips through Jerusalem bus, 21 wounded
summary: A bomb blast ripped through a bus in Jerusalem, injuring at least 21 people and sparking a fire, in what Israeli authorities described as a "terror attack". The blast occurred in a relatively isolated area, with flames spreading to another bus and a car. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed to find those responsible and vowed to "settle the score" with terrorists. The attack marked an escalation in a wave of violence that began in October, with most of the recent attacks being stabbings.

site_title: US top court divided on major immigration case
summary: The US Supreme Court is divided on President Barack Obama's plan to delay deportation for nearly half of the nation's 11 million undocumented immigrants. The court's eight justices are expected to deadlock by late June, leaving the plan on hold and dealing a blow to Obama's presidency. The plan, which would shield from deportation people who have lived in the US since 2010 and whose children are US citizens or residents, is being challenged by Texas and 25 other states. The court's decision could have significant implications for the immigration debate and the next president.

site_title: Court orders Mallya's arrest as pressure builds on loans
summary: A special court in Mumbai has ordered the arrest of Vijay Mallya, the founder of Kingfisher Airlines, due to unpaid debts of approximately $1.4 billion. The arrest warrant follows the suspension of his passport by the Indian government, which aims to force his return from abroad. Mallya's UB Group has denied the charges made by the Enforcement Directorate, stating that all foreign-exchange transactions were used for legitimate business purposes. The court's order adds to the pressure on Mallya to repay his dues, which have been outstanding since the airline's collapse in 2012.

site_title: Brazil's leader vows long battle against impeachment
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff has vowed to fight a "long" battle against impeachment as Congress moves closer to putting her on trial. The lower house of Congress voted 367-153 to send her case to the Senate, where she faces charges of manipulating government accounts. Rousseff has branded the process a "coup d'etat" and accused her Vice President Michel Temer of conspiring against her. The Senate is expected to vote on whether to open the proceedings by mid-May, with financial markets betting on Rousseff's exit and the advent of a more business-friendly government.

site_title: GIC, S Korean partner to build Incheon mall
summary: Singapore's GIC partners with South Korean retail player Shinsegae to develop a 59,730 sqm retail mall in the Incheon Free Economic Zone, with completion scheduled for 2020. The land was acquired for US$197 million. This is GIC's second collaboration with Shinsegae, following a prime retail mall in Dongdaegu Station, which is set to complete this year. The Incheon mall will feature entertainment and leisure facilities, and is part of a growing trend of Singapore companies investing in South Korea's real estate market.

site_title: White House hopefuls make final NY campaign push
summary: US presidential hopefuls Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump made last-minute pitches in New York, with Clinton aiming to secure a decisive win in the state's primary election. Clinton leads Trump by 53.7-40.9% in a RealClearPolitics poll average, and has 1,790 delegates compared to Trump's 1,113. Trump hopes to win the majority of the 95 Republican delegates to lessen his chances of a contested nomination. Clinton is on course to secure the party's ticket with 2,383 delegates needed, while Sanders desperately needs a win in his home state to keep his presidential hopes alive.

images.alt_text: US presidential hopefuls made last-minute pitches in New York Monday on the eve of the state's most decisive primary in decades, with Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump hoping to cut their rivals down to size.

site_title: Absence of Doha deal hits commodity currencies
summary: Commodity currencies slipped on Monday as a plan to cap oil production fell apart in Doha, sending oil prices tumbling 7% in early trade. The failure to agree on an output freeze left the credibility of OPEC in tatters, with the yen gaining ground as investors sought refuge. Despite expectations of a stronger impact, the impact was short-lived, and the US driving season could prop up oil prices. The Canadian and Australian dollars also fell, with the yen reaching its highest against the euro since 2013.

site_title: SMRT joins on-demand private hire car bandwagon
summary: SMRT has partnered with ride-hailing platform Grab to offer limousine, chauffeured, and car rental services, marking the transport operator's entry into the on-demand private hire market. The partnership allows up to 200 Strides drivers to receive performance-based cash incentives from Grab. SMRT aims to expand its fleet to 300 brand-new Toyota Altis sedans and offer incentives to safe drivers. The collaboration is seen as a natural progression for SMRT, allowing it to tap into the growing private hire market while maintaining its taxi services.

site_title: 1MDB scandal triggering one perfect storm after another
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB scandal has triggered a perfect storm in its bilateral relations with the Emirates and its top banker, Nazir Razak of CIMB Group. CIMB's chairman voluntarily stepped down pending a review of bank processes amid revelations of a US$7 million payment from his brother, Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak. The dispute with Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund International Petroleum Investment Company (IPIC) over a US$3.5 billion cash deposit has escalated, threatening 1MDB's debt default and potentially a cross default by the Malaysian government.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

Malaysia's rancorous scandal centred around troubled 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) claimed its latest "casualties" of sorts on Monday - the country's bilateral relations with the Emirates and its top banker, Nazir Razak of CIMB Group.

site_title: Google wins long US court battle on book-scanning
summary: The US Supreme Court denied an appeal from the Authors Guild, upholding a 2013 federal court ruling that Google's book-scanning project is "fair use" under copyright law. Google's massive project, which digitized millions of books, allows users to search and view snippets of text without compensation to copyright holders. The ruling, seen as a landmark decision for the digital era, was hailed by consumer groups and libraries as a victory for public access to culture and knowledge, while the Authors Guild expressed disappointment and concern over the potential harm to authors.

images.alt_text: Google's massive book-scanning project cleared its final legal hurdle Monday as the US Supreme Court denied an appeal contending it violates copyright law.

site_title: LNG producers open new markets to soak up surplus
summary: LNG producers are investing in new markets to combat a fuel surplus expected to last into the next decade. Companies like Royal Dutch Shell, Total, and Malaysia's Petroliam Nasional Bhd are creating demand for liquefied natural gas by offering it as a fuel for transport, including ships, trucks, and buses. The goal is to secure 10% of the heavy transport market, which could add 70 million tonnes of extra demand. To achieve this, companies are co-investing in floating import terminals, power plants, and ship-fuelling operations, with costs ranging from $100 million to $30 billion.

images.alt_text: The world's top producers of liquefied natural gas (LNG) are investing in ship-fuelling operations, floating import terminals and power plants to open new markets and keep from drowning in a fuel surplus expected to last into the next decade.

site_title: Opportunities still available amid slow growth: BDO conference
summary: Global growth is slow, but opportunities remain for companies that reinvent themselves to avoid obsolescence. Keynote speakers at a BDO conference emphasized the need for innovation and technology, particularly in Asia. Despite China's economic slowdown, optimism about the future persists, with the Chinese government investing in start-ups and innovation. Experts predict a period of decline before growth resumes, but some companies may still secure funding and hire foreign workers.
