Banks can support companies with existing relationships, and businesses must balance China and US interests to take advantage of the One Belt, One Road initiative.

site_title: Iron ore rally expected to fade in H2 as oversupply kicks in
summary: Citigroup predicts the global iron ore market will face an increasingly severe oversupply, leading to a decline in prices in the second half of 2016. The bank attributes this to increased production, including from miners restarting output, and likely losses in steel prices. Iron ore prices surged 23% in the first quarter, but are expected to fall to an average of $45 a tonne in 2016, $39 in 2017, and $38 in 2018.

site_title: Australia Parliament rejects labour Bill, July election likely
summary: Australia's Parliament voted down a labour reform Bill, giving Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull the excuse to dissolve both houses and hold a general election in July. The Senate rejected the Bill, 34-36, and Turnbull used the "double dissolution" manoeuvre to clear both government houses, putting the entire legislature to a poll. This is the fourth time in over 50 years a government has used this measure, following sliding opinion polls and a deadlocked upper house. The election is expected to take place on July 2, amid concerns about Turnbull's leadership and the ruling Liberal Party's low popularity.

site_title: Asian fintechs a magnet for investments in Q1
summary: Asian fintech firms attracted US$2.7 billion in investments in Q1, accounting for nearly 20% of global fintech funding. Chinese players dominate the region, while Indian fintechs are gaining traction. Payments remain the most popular segment, with fintech investments targeting collaboration with incumbents doubling over the year. Established fintechs like Amazon are also investing in fintechs, and banks are deploying better technology to boost services.

site_title: US: Dow ends above 18,000 as market shrugs off Doha
summary: The US stock market ended above 18,000 for the first time in nine months on Monday, defying concerns over the failure of major oil-producing countries to agree on a deal to strengthen prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 106.70 points, or 0.60%, to 18,004.16. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also saw gains, with the S&P 500 up 13.61 points, or 0.65%, to 2,094.34, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 21.80 points, or 0.44%, to 4,960.02.

site_title: Affected OSIM shareholders to get 'goodwill' compensation
summary: OSIM International founder Ron Sim is making a "goodwill" payment to shareholders who sold shares on April 5 below the revised final ex-dividend offer price of S$1.39. Affected shareholders will receive the difference between the transacted sale price and the final ex-dividend offer price. SIAS describes this as a "very good outcome" and a move to take the sting out of a controversy stemming from share purchase errors on April 5.

site_title: China tax rules to cool grey market for Danone, a2 baby formula
summary: China is tightening its tax rules on foreign infant formula sold through overseas websites, effectively increasing the tax on these products by 11.9% starting this month. The move aims to curb the grey market, where Chinese consumers purchase products online and have them shipped to the country, often avoiding taxes. This change may impact foreign companies like Danone, a2 Milk Co, and Bellamy's Australia Ltd, which rely on these websites for sales. The regulation may force companies to shift towards direct sales in China, posing a challenge to smaller premium brands.

site_title: How Disney spread Jungle Book fever
summary: Disney's marketing campaign for The Jungle Book included a mix of social media, star power, merchandise, and targeted promotions to appeal to diverse audiences. The film's opening weekend grossed $103.6 million in the US, thanks to a combination of sneak-peek screenings, dramatic promotional photos, and partnerships with ESPN, Univision, and Disney theme parks. The strategy, which included 3D trailers, action-oriented promos, and immersive experiences, helped to create a positive buzz and attract a wide range of viewers, including men, Hispanic audiences, and families.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney Studios used marketing sleight of hand to fill seats on opening weekend and as a result The Jungle Book took in an astounding US$103.6 million in North America.
Most of director Jon Favreau's animals are not cartoonish and cuddly, not by a long shot.

site_title: Cost-cutting at AGMs: we may not have seen the worst yet
summary: Companies in Singapore's Annual General Meetings (AGMs) are cutting costs by reducing printed copies of annual reports, making it difficult for investors to reference them. The board lot has been reduced to 100 shares, allowing more investors to attend, but concerns remain about accessibility for CPF investors and those of Bermuda-incorporated companies. The trend has led to instances of communication breakdowns and frustration among investors, highlighting the need for companies to improve their communication and accessibility.

site_title: March NODX falls 15.6%; Q1 output, GDP may be revised downwards
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 15.6% in March, its worst performance in 3 years, exceeding market forecasts of a 12.3% decline. Economists attribute the drop to a high base effect from March last year. Despite a 0.2% seasonally adjusted increase in March compared to February, economists predict a downward revision in manufacturing output and GDP growth for the first quarter, citing weak external demand and a slowdown in China.

site_title: Oil expected to whipsaw en route to normalcy
summary: Oil prices plummeted over 6.8% on Monday after the failure of producer talks to freeze output, but a Kuwait oil-worker strike may support the market. Goldman Sachs and Barclays warn of increased volatility, while Citigroup predicts price swings. The strike in Kuwait has cut output by 60%, while non-Opec production is expected to drop by 1.1 million barrels a day in 2016. Analysts forecast a sustainable deficit in the third quarter and warn of re-balancing months ahead.

site_title: India's steel policy draws Japanese-led criticism at WTO
summary: India's steel policy has drawn criticism from the World Trade Organization's Goods Council, led by Japan, over minimum import prices and emergency "safeguard" tariffs on some steel imports. China, the world's largest steel producer, commented on India's restrictions on trade in apples but did not join the criticism on steel. The US also raised concerns about India's import tariff increases and other protectionist measures. India's representative defended its policies, saying they were necessary to protect its domestic industry, but acknowledged that concerns would be relayed to New Delhi.

site_title: Beauty, fashion brands eye Iran's US$4b market
summary: Beauty and fashion brands are eyeing Iran's estimated $4 billion cosmetics market, despite potential resistance from conservative factions. Dubai-based businesswoman Negin Fattahi-Dasmal has opened a luxurious nail salon chain in Iran, catering to the country's fashion-forward young women. International brands such as Dolce & Gabbana and Louis Vuitton are also entering Iran directly, but may face challenges due to complex business regulations and conservative opposition.

site_title: Don't cut costs when it comes to food for shareholders
summary: A Singaporean investor expresses disagreement with the trend of companies cutting costs on food for shareholders at Annual General Meetings (AGMs). The investor suggests that companies should provide lunch boxes or food vouchers instead, as holding buffets can be a hassle. The AGM is an opportunity for companies to announce achievements to a large turnout of shareholders, who contribute to the company's success. The investor believes that companies should be proud to share their achievements, rather than cutting costs on a gesture of appreciation.

site_title: Big Apple: it'll be Trump and Clinton
summary: The 2016 New York primary has become a pivotal moment in the presidential election, with Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton emerging as the top contenders in their respective parties. Trump, a native New Yorker, has capitalized on his reputation as a quintessential New Yorker, appealing to the city's blue-collar workers and construction industry. Clinton, a transplant from Illinois, has struggled to connect with the city's voters, despite her Senate experience representing New York. Trump leads the Republican primary, while Clinton remains in second place in the Democratic primary, despite a narrow lead over Bernie Sanders.

images.alt_text: New York son Donald Trump (back to camera) is beating Ted Cruz, the Cuban-American senator from Texas, 60 per cent to 17 per cent, going by the latest polls in New York. Ohio governor John Kasich is between them in terms of level of support.

site_title: Japan PM sticks to script on sales tax plans after deadly quakes
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has reaffirmed plans to raise the country's sales tax to 10% from 8% in April 2017, barring a major financial crisis or natural disaster. Despite two deadly quakes in southern Japan causing at least 42 deaths and disrupting major manufacturers, Abe has stuck to his script, citing no change in the country's stance. Economists predict the quakes could delay the tax hike, citing negative impact on consumer and business psychology, but Abe is expected to announce a decision around the time of a May 26-27 Group of Seven summit.

site_title: Japan quakes reveal again vulnerability of regional supply chains
summary: A series of earthquakes in southern Japan has disrupted manufacturing operations, with major companies like Toyota, Honda, and Sony halting production or reducing output. The country's already faltering economy is expected to take a hit, with Tokyo share prices slumping 3.6%. The Japanese government has promised financial support, while the Bank of Japan may ease monetary policy to mitigate the impact. Supply chains, which were improved after the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, are still vulnerable to disruptions from natural disasters. The country's inbound tourism industry may also be affected.

images.alt_text: Mr Kuroda had warned about the dangers of natural disasters crippling production chains.

site_title: Market players see hope of oil price rebound in 2-3 years
summary: Maritime industry players expect an oil price rebound within 2-3 years, driven by consolidation and cost restructuring. Low oil prices have led to sharp declines in operating day rates for offshore marine sub-sectors, but field development costs have fallen dramatically. Industry chairman Kristian Siem predicts a recovery in exploration and production activity in 2018, supported by an expected oil price rebound. Over 60% of polled delegates see oil prices rebounding to $70 within three years, justifying the economics for deep-water field developments.

site_title: The global economy is stronger than you think
summary: The global economy is stronger than initially reported, with data revisions often showing inflation and growth numbers increasing. Since 2010, revisions have been larger and more frequent, reversing the way data is expected to surprise investors. This bias towards revisions has led to previously reported weaker data being revised to stronger numbers, contrary to the traditional expectation of downward revisions.

site_title: New acquisitions drive First Reit's Q1 growth, DPU up 2.4%
summary: First Reit, a Singaporean healthcare trust, reported a 2.4% year-on-year increase in distributable income to S$16.2 million in Q1 2016, driven by new acquisitions. The trust's distribution per unit (DPU) rose to 2.11 Singapore cents, maintaining a 6.9% annualised distribution yield. Revenue grew 7.1% to S$26.5 million, with net property income increasing 8.1%. The trust's CEO noted the seventh consecutive rise in DPU since 2014, with new acquisitions and a proposed joint acquisition set to drive further growth.

site_title: Finding cost savings in the least obvious of places
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can increase competitiveness by finding cost savings in logistics. Despite government incentives, SMEs should look inward to reduce logistics costs, which can impact customer satisfaction and business results. By engaging with logistics service providers, SMEs often end up paying a premium due to lack of time or knowledge of alternatives. Investing in automation software can help SMEs streamline logistics processes, choose the best providers, and reduce costs. Adopting a forward-thinking approach can lead to healthier companies and reduced dependence on subsidies.

site_title: Let shareholders at AGMs grill directors before voting
summary: Shareholders at annual general meetings (AGMs) in Singapore are increasingly holding directors accountable, but the practice of reappointing long-serving directors remains a problem. A study found that shareholders often fail to scrutinize directors' qualifications and tenure, leading to "busy" officials being voted in year after year. Australia's guide to AGM procedures, which requires directors to address shareholders before voting, offers a model for improvement, promoting transparency and accountability in corporate governance.

site_title: Struggling Chinese shipbuilder diversifies into parking lot business
summary: China Ocean Industry Group Ltd, a struggling shipbuilder, is diversifying into the parking lot business. The company acquired a car-park operator last year to address China's estimated 50 million parking space shortage. China Ocean plans to build and operate 100,000 parking lots in three years, generating 70% of its operating profit. The move comes as the company faces financial strain from the shipbuilding industry.

site_title: Crocodile skin supplier Padenga to boost output
summary: Padenga Holdings Ltd, the world's largest supplier of Nile crocodile skins, plans to boost profitability by feeding the reptiles a corn-rich diet and increasing their space to grow. This will result in faster growth and improved hide quality. However, the crocodiles will be slaughtered after 2.5 years, rather than 3, to meet demand. The move aims to increase profitability, but raises concerns about animal welfare.

site_title: Acromec shares up 18% in debut trading
summary: Acromec Ltd, a Singapore-based cleanroom specialist, made its debut on the Catalist board with shares rising 18% above its IPO price of 22 cents. The company raised S$4.5 million, with plans to use S$3.5 million for working capital and S$1 million for expansion and acquisitions. Acromec aims to scale up operations in Singapore and expand into the Asean region, serving healthcare, research, and electronics sectors. The listing brings the total number of companies on Catalist to 178 with a combined market capitalisation of S$9 billion.

site_title: Keppel's Q1 profit falls 42%
summary: Keppel Corporation's Q1 net profit fell 42% to S$210.6 million, driven by a 58% drop in revenue from its offshore and marine division. The division's reduced sales were attributed to lower work volume, project deferments, and suspension of contracts. Despite this, Keppel secured S$200 million of new orders and cut overheads by 28%. The company believes the outlook for the offshore and marine side will remain challenging, but is focused on executing projects well and strengthening its presence in core and growth markets.

site_title: Making digital disruption work
summary: Traditional companies and hybrids can learn from pure digital plays, which have successfully rewritten the rules of strategy. Key takeaways include starting with a vision and purpose, being obsessed with customers, embedding the right planning horizons, understanding competitive differentiation, harnessing technology effectively, building a robust business model, not tolerating mediocrity, reinventing oneself frequently, designing a fit-for-purpose governance model, and building a fit-for-purpose organisation. These principles have enabled pure digital plays to thrive in the digital economy, while traditional companies can adapt to remain competitive.

site_title: UK Treasury warns country will be much poorer with Brexit
summary: The UK Treasury has warned that leaving the European Union would result in a 6% smaller economy by 2030, equivalent to £4,300 per household. The report, which examined three potential Brexit scenarios, found that a "Canada-style" bilateral agreement with the EU would lead to a decline in tax receipts of £36 billion, with tax rates potentially rising by 8%. Brexit campaigners have dismissed the claims as "absurd" and "worthless", citing the Treasury's past forecasting errors.

site_title: How SMEs can create value to build sustainable businesses
summary: Singapore's government has emphasized the need for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to innovate and transform to build sustainable businesses. According to Terence Ang, a partner at RSM, SMEs must adopt a pervasive transformation from the top down, with a focus on behavior and mindset change. This involves asking why they want to transform, communicating the change to the organization, and ensuring key people are committed to transforming. Key aspects of value creation include innovation, good corporate governance, internal controls, and succession planning, which take time to implement, typically 12-24 months.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Banks see capital requirements spiking on Basel market-risk rules
summary: Global regulators' Basel market-risk rules are expected to significantly increase capital requirements for banks' trading desks, with some firms needing up to 2.4 times current capital levels. Industry estimates suggest a 40% increase, but bankers say this underestimates the impact, with some models potentially leading to 6.2 times increases for certain desks. The rule, set to take effect in 2019, aims to protect against losses on securities during market plunges, but the financial industry is pushing back on the increased capital charges.

site_title: Airbus, SIA launch new flight training centre to cater to rising pilot demand
summary: Airbus and Singapore Airlines (SIA) have launched a new US$100 million flight training centre in Singapore, aiming to cater to the rising demand for pilot training in the Asia-Pacific region. Seventeen carriers, including SIA and Qatar Airways, have signed up for the centre's training services, which will feature eight full-flight simulators and six fixed cockpit training devices. The centre is expected to train over 10,000 trainees annually and create highly-skilled jobs, including flight instructors and simulator technicians.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Alibaba finance unit plans IPO on Shanghai: sources
summary: Alibaba's finance affiliate, Zhejiang Ant Small & Micro Financial Services Group Co, plans an initial public offering (IPO) on Shanghai's main board, potentially China's highest valuation since 2010. The company has been profitable for three years, meeting listing requirements, and may begin the process this year. Ant Group prefers a dual listing with Hong Kong if regulatory approval is obtained.

site_title: The least ugly economy
summary: The US economy is considered "the least ugly" among major economies, with a projected 2% annual growth rate, compared to 1.5% for the euro area and 0.4% for Japan. China's growth, while still strong at 6.4%, is decelerating rapidly, and a "hard landing" could drag down global economies. The Peterson Institute's projections suggest a prolonged economic sluggishness, with global growth expected to remain at 3% annually. This could have significant implications for the US, with slower growth potentially triggering a synchronised slump and jeopardizing the country's reliance on strong economic growth to satisfy popular demands for government services and higher personal incomes.

site_title: Easing measures boost China home prices further
summary: China's home prices continued to rise, with new-home prices excluding government-subsidised housing increasing in 62 cities in March, up from 47 in February. This growth was driven by surging liquidity in major hubs like Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen. However, prices dropped in eight cities, down from 15 the previous month. The National Bureau of Statistics reported these findings, highlighting the ongoing upward trend in the country's housing market.

site_title: Dow futures' rebound trims STI loss
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 6.19 points to 2,917.75 on Monday, following the failed oil talks in Doha, which led to a sharp fall in oil prices. Dow futures rebounded 60 points, suggesting Wall Street may not plunge as badly as expected. Regional markets ended mostly weaker, with offshore and marine stocks being targeted by short sellers. China Environment reported a first-quarter loss, and the Singapore non-oil domestic exports (NODX) dropped 15.6% in March.

site_title: UOB sets up private equity fund with Ping An, Chinese partners
summary: UOB has established a private equity fund in partnership with Ping An Insurance and Chinese partner Chongqing Yufu Asset Management Group, targeting a 100 billion yuan (S$20.9 billion) investment. The fund, to be managed by UOB Venture Management, aims to capitalize on the growing economic ties between China and Singapore. This move marks Chongqing's first Sino-Singapore private equity fund and further solidifies Singapore's presence in the Chinese market.

site_title: Govt refund for HK terminal props up HPH Trust's Q1 earnings
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPHT) reported a 94.2% net profit increase to HK$554.9 million in Q1 due to a government refund of HK$430 million for rent and rates at Hongkong International Terminals. Revenue dropped 6.7% year-on-year to HK$2.75 billion, primarily due to weaker intra-Asia and transshipment cargoes. Container throughput fell 12.1% at one of its key assets, mainly due to weaker intra-Asia and transshipment cargoes.

site_title: Low fuel prices, unwinding of hedges drive upbeat view on SIA
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is gaining a more positive outlook due to low fuel prices and better hedging. Analysts see the carrier as an "attractive buy" with 11 out of 17 analysts recommending a "buy" call. Despite yield erosion, SIA's growth strategy, including new aircraft deliveries and partnerships, is expected to drive earnings recovery. The carrier's fuel costs are expected to decrease by $515.1 million in FY17, and its subsidiary airlines, such as SilkAir and Scoot, are also expected to improve profitability. SIA's balance sheet and strategic partnerships also provide a strong foundation for its future growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Startups stand to gain as Chengdu woos venture capitalists, researchers
summary: China's city of Chengdu is attracting venture capitalists and researchers with a push to promote innovation and entrepreneurship. Local businesses, including startups like Revotek and AllTech Medical Systems, are benefiting from the city's rich supply of funding and favorable policies. The city's government has set up seven startup-focused funds and incubators to support industries such as biotech and healthcare. This effort is part of China's broader push to create new engines of growth, following the country's economic expansion hitting its slowest pace in 25 years.

site_title: Panama Papers raises London anti-graft summit stakes
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron is preparing for a landmark anti-corruption summit in London, amid international pressure following the Panama Papers revelations. The summit aims to increase global tax transparency and combat corporate secrecy. The UK has already taken steps to address tax avoidance in its overseas territories, but critics argue that more needs to be done. The meeting may see significant new measures announced, including automatic exchange of tax information and central registries to increase transparency. The summit comes as the global community seeks to tackle corruption, punish perpetrators, and support those affected.

site_title: F&B tech startup, programming institute bag multi-million-dollar venture capital
summary: TabSquare, a food and beverage technology startup, has secured S$3.5 million in Series A funding to deepen its presence in South-east Asia, New Zealand, and Australia. The funding will be used to enhance its integrated restaurant management platform, SmartTab, which helps reduce front-of-house manpower costs by 20-40%. Co-founder Anshul Gupta said the fund raise will help TabSquare move to a platform-as-a-service model, where the complete platform will be available to restaurants at less than one waiter's salary. Meanwhile, programming institute Make School will set up its first international subsidiary in Singapore, offering intensive iOS programming courses.

site_title: US: Wall St lower at the open as oil slides
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, tracking a decline in crude oil prices after a meeting of major oil producers failed to reach a deal to reduce a global glut. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.11%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.2%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 0.39%.

site_title: World wine trade buoyed by rebound in China demand
summary: China's wine consumption rebounded in 2015, with imports jumping 44% to 5.5 million hectolitres and overall consumption growing 3% to nearly 16 million hectolitres. This growth contributed to a 2% increase in global wine trade to 104.3 million hectolitres, and a 10.6% rise in value terms to €28.3 billion. The improved trend in China has led to a significant expansion of its vineyards, making it the world's second-largest grower by area after Spain.

site_title: UAE sovereign wealth fund pulls support for 1MDB
summary: The UAE's International Petroleum Investment Company (IPIC) has terminated its financial support for 1MDB, a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund, due to its failure to meet debt obligations, including a US$1.1 billion payment. This move comes amid concerns over a potential non-payment of a US$50 million bond instalment, which could affect Malaysia's bond and currency markets. The decision marks a souring of ties between the two sovereign wealth funds and may trigger cross defaults in other debt papers issued by 1MDB.

site_title: Sabana Reit Q1 DPU falls 25%
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 25.3% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.33 Singapore cents in Q1 2016, from 1.78 Singapore cents a year ago. Distributable income fell 24.7% to S$9.77 million, while net property income slipped 18.4% to S$15.17 million. The decline was attributed to negative rental revisions and higher property expenses.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: European stocks rise as carmakers, miners gain, oil pares drop
summary: European stocks rose 0.5% to 344.34 on the Stoxx Europe 600 Index, driven by gains from carmakers, such as BMW AG, and commodity producers, including Rio Tinto Group and BHP Billiton Ltd. Energy companies, led by Total SA and Royal Dutch Shell Plc, saw their losses pare. The Stoxx 600 has traded in a tight range in the past month, amid concerns over global growth.

site_title: HSBC chief Stuart Gulliver to step down in two years: report
summary: HSBC Holdings plc CEO Stuart Gulliver will step down in two years as the bank undergoes leadership changes amid shareholder pressure. HSBC plans to appoint a new chairman first, followed by a search for Gulliver's successor. The bank has also revamped its board after announcing over 87,000 job cuts and exiting 80 businesses since 2011. Senior independent director Rachel Lomax is leading the search for Gulliver's replacement, with AXA SA CEO Henri de Castries reportedly tipped to be the likely successor.

images.alt_text: Oxford-educated Mr Gulliver started at HSBC in 1980 and excelled as a trader, rising through the ranks to become CEO in 2011. He has held roles in cities including London, Hong Kong and Tokyo.

site_title: Data centres, logistics bright spots for 2016 industrial demand
summary: Singapore's industrial sector experienced a weak start to 2016, with rentals for factory and warehouse space falling 1.7% and 2.3% year-on-year, respectively. Leasing volume also declined. However, specialized spaces like data centers and logistics facilities are expected to see healthy demand, driven by automation and higher-tech industries. Data centers are expected to see a 47% increase in supply by the end of the year, while logistics players are focusing on upgrading capabilities to handle specialized cargo.

site_title: Oil prices tumble after failure of Doha talks
summary: Oil prices plummeted after a meeting of major exporters in Qatar collapsed without an agreement to freeze output, dealing a blow to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and sparking concerns of a global oil glut. The failed deal, which was expected to slow the oversupply of oil, revived fears of higher Opec supply and steeper discounts. Oil prices have fallen by 70% since mid-2014, and analysts predict further volatility and a growing risk of higher Opec supply.

images.alt_text: "The meeting concluded that we all need time for further consultation," says Mr al-Sada. "Participating countries will consult among themselves and with others" until the next Opec meeting, he adds.

site_title: Bracing for Brexit on June 23
summary: On April 18, 2016, the article discusses the upcoming Brexit referendum in the UK, where the author predicts a massive protest vote as ordinary people may disagree with the opinions of "unelected technocrats" who believe the UK should stay in the European Union. The author argues that those who have benefited from EU membership, such as multinational companies and wealthy individuals, have failed to convincingly argue in favor of staying, leading to a potential majority vote for leaving the EU on June 23.

site_title: Parents sue sperm bank for misleading them about donor
summary: Parents Angela Collins and Elizabeth Hanson are suing Xytex Corp, a sperm bank in Georgia, for misleading them about donor Donor 9623, who had a history of mental illness and a criminal record. The couple, who have a son conceived through the donor's sperm, claim the bank failed to accurately describe the donor or disclose his medical history. Three lawsuits are filed, seeking over C$4 million in damages, and at least a dozen other families are planning similar lawsuits, raising concerns about the risks of using sperm banks and the importance of public education on this issue.

site_title: China Star Food to make trading debut after RTO, placement
summary: China Star Food Group, a Chinese sweet potato snack specialist, will make its debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board on April 20 after completing a reverse takeover of Brooke Asia and a compliance placement issue. The company posted revenue of 418.9 million yuan in FY2015, with a 51.5% compounded annual revenue growth between FY2012 and FY2015. China Star Food aims to expand its business in Asia and globally, citing Singapore's status as a global financial hub. The company raised S$5.8 million through the placement, which will be used for working capital and expansion.

site_title: Gold boosted by dollar and equities after oil freeze fails
summary: Gold prices rose on Monday following the failure of oil producers to agree an output freeze, with Brent crude futures plummeting 7% as a result. The US dollar fell, and European shares dipped, contributing to gold's 0.1% gain to $1,233.65. The failure of the oil freeze deal, which had been seen as a key factor in supporting crude prices, led to a rebound in gold prices.

site_title: Largest-ever diesel cargo heads to Europe: traders, Reuters data
summary: Europe is set to receive its largest-ever diesel cargo, with Total chartering a super tanker to ship 270,000 tonnes of diesel from Asia to the port of Antwerp in Belgium. The cargo, which is three times the typical size, comes amid Europe's diesel storage near maximum capacity and a global glut of diesel fuel. The delivery is expected to put pressure on Europe's diesel prices, which are considered the global benchmark for the road fuel.

site_title: Largest Philippine luxury brand seller tempers outlook
summary: SSI Group Inc., the largest Philippine seller of luxury brands, has tempered its earnings expectations due to intense competition in the market. The company's president, Anthony Huang, stated that profit estimates are "too rosy" and revenue forecasts are "a little bit optimistic" as consumer spending continues to grow. SSI's sales are expected to increase, but at a slower pace, with adjusted net income reaching 1.11 billion pesos this year and rising to 1.41 billion pesos in 2017. The company plans to maintain its gross profit margin at around 50-51% through 2018.

images.alt_text: SSI, also known as Stores Specialists, has a portfolio of more than 100 brands. It opened its first Prada store in 2003 in metro Manila and followed five years later with Jimmy Choo and Hermes stores, according to its website.

site_title: New acquisitions lift First Reit's Q1 distributable income by 6.2% to S$16.2m
summary: First Reit's Q1 distributable income rose 6.2% to S$16.2m, driven by new acquisitions, including the Kupang Property. Revenue increased 7.1% to S$26.5m, while net property income grew 8.1%. The trust maintained a 6.9% annualised distribution yield. CEO Ronnie Tan attributed the growth to new acquisitions and expects continued DPU growth with the upcoming acquisition in Yogyakarta.

site_title: Greek reform talks to resume, aim for swift deal: Commission
summary: Greece's international lenders are resuming talks in Athens with the aim of concluding a review of Greek reforms "as soon as possible", the European Commission said. The review has been delayed due to disagreements between the International Monetary Fund and European Union on economic scenarios. A preliminary deal is expected to be reached this week, ahead of a Eurogroup meeting on April 22, but a clear agreement date has not been set. The review must be concluded before more bailout money is released.

site_title: BRC Asia issues profit warning for Q2 2016 due to forex losses
summary: BRC Asia issued a profit warning for Q2 2016, expecting a net loss due to foreign exchange losses from currency forward contracts to hedge raw material purchases in US dollars. The loss is attributed to the non-recognition of hedge accounting changes in profit or loss. The stock price fell 1.6% to 60 Singapore cents following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: In digital push, Citi downsizes China branch presence
summary: Citigroup has downsized its branch network in China, closing four branches in the past 12 months, citing a 95% shift in client transactions to digital platforms. The move aims to adapt to China's mobile Internet adoption and intensified competition from FinTech companies. Citi now sees its current 46 branches as adequate, with a "bricks and clicks" strategy to remain relevant to clients. Foreign banks face rising regulatory costs and competition from local FinTech players, with HSBC and Bank of East Asia also considering digital-led strategies to grow.

site_title: India's March trade deficit narrows to US$5.07b: govt
summary: India's trade deficit narrowed to US$5.07 billion in March, its third consecutive decline, driven by a faster-than-expected decrease in imports. This marks a shift in the country's trade dynamics, as the collapse in oil prices benefits India, the world's No 3 crude importer. The country's trade deficit for the 2015/16 fiscal year was US$118.5 billion, down from US$137.7 billion in the previous fiscal year.

site_title: Cheap oil slows appetite for LNG as alternative shipping fuel
summary: Low oil prices are slowing the adoption of liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a cleaner fuel for ships. The global shipping sector is under pressure to reduce emissions, but the low price of oil is discouraging a shift away from traditional fuels. Industry officials say it will take time for LNG to grow as a bunker fuel due to infrastructure costs. Despite this, some companies, such as Qatargas and Royal Dutch Shell, are investing in LNG as a marine fuel. LNG can reduce NOx and SOx emissions by 90-95% and CO2 emissions by 20-25%.

site_title: Quakes put chill in south Japan's hot spring tourism boom
summary: A series of deadly earthquakes on Japan's southern main island of Kyushu is threatening to quash the island's hot spring tourism boom, with thousands of foreign visitors, mainly from China, fleeing the area. The earthquakes, which include a magnitude 7.3 quake, have damaged attractions such as Kumamoto Castle, and prompted the Chinese foreign ministry to urge caution about travel to the region. The Kyushu tourism industry had targeted a 75% increase in tourism over the next seven years, but the earthquakes are expected to significantly impact this goal.

site_title: UK house prices hit record
summary: UK house prices reached a record high in April, with average asking prices rising 1.3% to £307,033, 7.3% higher than a year earlier. The increase was driven by demand from landlords before a tax hike on second homes took effect on April 1, prompting many homeowners to trade up to larger properties. The strongest monthly performance was seen in the East Midlands, with prices rising 3.6%.

site_title: Alibaba financial affiliate valued at US$60b: reports
summary: Ant Financial, Alibaba's affiliate, is reportedly valued at US$60 billion, meeting China's listing requirement of three years profitability. It plans to list on the Shanghai stock exchange, potentially becoming China's largest IPO since 2010. Ant Financial seeks US$3.5 billion in private funding and has partnerships with Alibaba, Alipay, and other financial services firms. Analysts expect a premium in value if it lists domestically, as its users are also potential retail investors.

site_title: US economy looks good but Fed remains cautious: Dudley
summary: US Federal Reserve President William Dudley stated that the US economy is "mostly favourable" but remains cautious in raising interest rates due to uncertainties and lingering financial crisis headwinds. Dudley expressed confidence in inflation rising to a 2% goal over the next few years and hinted at a gradual and cautious approach to monetary policy normalization.

site_title: Japan battles to care for 100,000 evacuees after quake
summary: Japan is struggling to care for over 100,000 evacuees after a series of earthquakes in the country's south, leaving 42 dead and over 1,000 injured. The US military has sent aircraft to airlift supplies, and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has pledged to find survivors and provide assistance. However, delays in delivering emergency supplies have been reported, with some evacuees forced to sleep in makeshift shelters. The disaster has raised concerns about Japan's preparedness for natural disasters, particularly given the country's history of devastating earthquakes and tsunamis.

site_title: Sony says Kumamoto plant not main site for smartphone components
summary: Sony's image sensor plant in Kumamoto, Japan, which was shut down due to earthquakes, primarily produces components for digital cameras, not smartphones. The company's Nagasaki plant, which resumed operations, is the main site for smartphone image sensors. The plant's restart is expected to have a limited impact on Apple's iPhone 7 production. Sony shares fell 6.8% on the news, despite concerns that the shutdown could affect iPhone production. The company has yet to decide when to restart the Kumamoto plant.

site_title: Indonesia to suspend land reclamation in north Jakarta
summary: Indonesia's government has suspended land reclamation in north Jakarta until regulatory and environmental conditions are met. The move comes after a mega project involving 17 artificial islands faced bureaucratic wrangling, a bribery probe, and opposition from environmentalists. The project, which included apartments, offices, and shopping malls, was set to be halted due to a dispute over permits and a presidential spokesman's refusal to comment. A joint committee will be formed to address the issues, potentially delaying the multi-billion-dollar project.

site_title: Fund managers, convinced oil bottom is here, buy up energy stocks
summary: US fund managers are betting that the energy sector has finally hit bottom, buying up exploration and production companies after several quarters of shedding them. The sector is up 9% for the year to date, outpacing the broader market, as fund managers expect oil prices to stabilize and production to halt, leading to a rally in revenue and earnings in 2017. Despite earnings expected to fall 66.5% in 2016, growth-focused managers are shifting their energy exposure to companies that were hardest hit by low oil prices.

site_title: China cuts working hours for coal miners in bid to tackle supply glut
summary: China has reduced the number of statutory working days for coal miners to 276 per year, aiming to tackle a chronic supply glut. The move is part of efforts to cut 2 billion tonnes of surplus coal production per year. The country plans to shut down 500 million tonnes of coal production capacity over the next three to five years.

images.alt_text: China will reduce the number of statutory working days for its coal miners to 276 a year from 330 as it bids to tackle a chronic supply glut that has sapped prices, the country's work safety watchdog said on Monday.

site_title: Govt refund for Hong Kong terminals props up HPH Trust Q1 earnings
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings (HPH) Trust reported a 94.2% jump in net profit for the first quarter, reaching HK$554.9 million, despite a 6.7% drop in revenue to HK$2.75 billion. The boost came from a government refund of HK$430 million for Hongkong International Terminals, offsetting lower container throughput and operating expenses. Earnings per unit increased to 6.37 HK cents, and net asset value per unit decreased to HK$4.76.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

London's Heathrow Airport is considering increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade, a move that could affect airlines and travelers. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's new CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, leading to a downgrade to 'hold' by CGSI. Additionally, Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increased by 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: China urged to fix 'life or death' steel crisis
summary: Major steel producers from 30 countries, including the US and EU, urged China to scale back its overproduction, blaming it for plant closures and job losses globally. China produces over half of the world's steel and is accused of flooding the market with cheap steel at below-cost prices. The OECD plans to issue a joint statement to address the crisis, but a positive outcome remains uncertain due to high tempers. The US has already imposed tariffs on Chinese steel, while the EU has proposed a 20% tariff, with some countries calling for harsher measures.

site_title: ST Engineering's aerospace arm secures S$443m worth of new contracts
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm secured S$443 million worth of new contracts in the first quarter of 2016, including heavy airframe maintenance, cabin interior modifications, and component repair projects for commercial airlines and VIP customers. The contracts include landing gear orders from Asia-Pacific customers and a long-term contract to support a European customer's Q400 components, marking the first time German company Elbe Flugzeugwerke has ordered from ST Engineering.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: TEHO Int'l acquires property in Netherlands for 1.335m euros
summary: TEHO International has agreed to purchase a freehold property in the Netherlands for 1.335 million euros, with the goal of consolidating its Rotterdam operations into a centralised venue. The 4,034 square metre property, located in Ridderkerk, will serve as a hub for the company's offshore and marine solutions business. The acquisition is expected to raise operating efficiency and effectiveness, allowing TEHO International to better serve its customers in the marine and offshore oil and gas industries, with completion anticipated by September 1, 2016.

site_title: UOB sets up Sino-Singapore private equity fund with PingAn, Chinese partners
summary: UOB Venture Management (Shanghai) has partnered with three Chinese companies to establish a Sino-Singapore private equity fund with a target size of up to 100 billion yuan (S$21 billion). The fund will primarily invest in Chongqing-based projects, focusing on financial services, aviation, and transportation logistics. The partnership involves Chongqing Yufu Asset Management Group, Ping An Insurance, and Tus-Holdings, which operates the Tsinghua University Science Park. The fund aims to promote economic connectivity between Singapore and western China.

site_title: India says British queen should keep her crown jewel
summary: India's Supreme Court was told that the 105-carat Koh-i-Noor diamond, part of the British crown jewels, was given to the British as a gift by an Indian king in 1851, making it a gift rather than stolen property. The Indian government advised the court to forgo its claims to the diamond, as it was not taken forcibly. This decision contradicts Indian campaigners who believe the diamond was looted by the British during colonial rule, and that its return would be a gesture of atonement.

images.alt_text: India should relinquish its claim to a huge diamond that it has fought for decades to get back from the British, the government told the Supreme Court on Monday, because the stone was given to its former colonial ruler rather than stolen.

site_title: Kuwait to boost oil production despite strike: Arabiya
summary: Kuwait plans to boost oil production to normal levels despite an ongoing strike by thousands of oil and gas workers, who are protesting a government plan for public sector pay reforms. The strike, which began on Sunday, has not affected non-Kuwaiti workers. Kuwait National Petroleum Co. expects a big increase in crude inventory in the coming days and has enough stocks for export. Output is currently at 1.1 million barrels per day, but will reach normal levels soon. Partner companies are participating in the increase in production, according to the company's deputy chief executive.

images.alt_text: Kuwait plans to increase crude oil production to normal levels, despite an open-ended strike by Kuwaiti oil workers, an official from state refiner Kuwait National Petroleum Co (KNPC) told Al-Arabiya television on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 10.31 points lower at 1,717.68, with 1.73 billion lots valued at RM1.69 billion traded. The market saw 251 gainers and 558 losers.

site_title: Qian Hu's Q1 net profit down 89.3% to S$12,000
summary: Qian Hu Corporation reported a 89.3% drop in Q1 net profit to S$12,000, citing a persistently sluggish global economy as the reason. Revenue fell 5.6% to S$19.6 million, with the core ornamental fish segment down 6.9% and core accessories segment down 5.7%. Despite challenges, the company remains focused on its business fundamentals and technology, aiming to become the world's largest ornamental fish company.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: 20 foreigners linked to US$81m Bangladesh bank heist: police
summary: Bangladesh police have identified over 20 foreigners involved in a $81 million cyber-heist from the central bank, which saw hackers transfer funds to the Philippines. The thieves used malwares to breach the central bank's computer system and attempted to steal $850 million. Local hackers were initially suspected, but evidence points to foreign involvement. The government has taken action, with top officials losing their jobs, and is seeking assistance from Interpol to arrest the foreigners. The heist has embarrassed the government and raised concerns over the security of Bangladesh's foreign exchange reserves of over $27 billion.

site_title: Airbus targets 700 commercial airplane orders this year: sources
summary: Airbus has set a target of 700 commercial airplane orders for 2016, according to industry sources. This target is higher than its latest official guidance, which expects orders to exceed deliveries of more than 650 aircraft. In the first quarter, Airbus sold 32 aircraft and delivered 125, posting 10 net orders, its slowest start to the year since 2011.

site_title: Morgan Stanley profit slumps 54.4%
summary: Morgan Stanley's quarterly profit plummeted 54.4% to $1.06 billion, or 55 cents per share, in the quarter ended March 31, due to market volatility and lower revenue from trading and investment banking. Sliding commodity and oil prices, Chinese economic concerns, and uncertainty over US interest rates contributed to the decline. This marks the third consecutive quarter of lower earnings from investment banking and trading, following similar reports from other major US banks.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley's quarterly profit more than halved as the Wall Street bank's trading and investment banking businesses took a hit from market volatility early in the year.

site_title: Saudi flag carrier to launch low-cost offshoot
summary: Saudi Arabian Airlines plans to launch a low-cost offshoot, "Flyadeal", in the middle of next year as part of the kingdom's efforts to restructure its oil-dependent economy. The airline will operate independently and serve domestic or international routes, with no further details on financing or administration. The move comes as Saudi Arabia seeks alternatives to its biggest revenue source, oil, following a global collapse in oil prices. The low-cost carrier will be an addition to the National Transformation Programme, a key part of the kingdom's economic redevelopment plan.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall, in line with others, as oil prices drop
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.7% on Monday, tracking regional markets lower, as crude oil futures dropped in response to a failed agreement on production cuts by 18 oil exporting nations. The Hang Seng index fell to 21,161.50, while the China Enterprises Index lost 1.3% to 9,090.85 points. The failed agreement occurred after Saudi Arabia demanded Iran join the deal, which ultimately fell apart.

site_title: One of Accordia Golf Trust's courses suspends operations following Japan quakes
summary: Accordia Golf Trust suspended operations at its Kikuchi Country Club in Kumamoto, Japan, due to safety precautions following a 7.0-magnitude earthquake on April 16. The trust, which manages 89 golf courses, reported no material damage or casualties. Operations at other courses in the Oita area remain unaffected. CEO Yoshihiko Machida expressed condolences to the victims of the earthquakes. The trust will disclose further information if damage affects the trust.

site_title: Indonesia Feb loan growth slows to weakest since 2009
summary: Indonesia's loan growth in February slowed to 8.2% from a year ago, the weakest pace since 2009, according to the Financial Services Authority. This slowdown comes despite the central bank easing policy, cutting its benchmark rate by 75 basis points to boost loans and economic growth. Bank Indonesia targets 12-14% loan growth at year-end, but the recent slowdown may impact these goals.

site_title: Australia: Shares slide on Qantas profit warning, resources; NZ hits record
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% to 5,137.1 due to Qantas' profit warning and sliding mining stocks. New Zealand stocks hit a record, up 0.1% to 6,851.2, as its benchmark index rose for the fourth time in a row.

site_title: Baker Tech warns of Q1 loss
summary: Baker Tech, an oil and gas contractor, expects to report a first-quarter net loss for the three months ended March 31. The company posted a 99% drop in net profit in the fourth quarter of 2015, to S$54,000. Baker Tech shares closed at 17.8 Singapore cents, down 1.7%. The company will announce its results no later than May 13.

site_title: Lazy to blame China for global steel woes: Xinhua commentary
summary: China's official news agency Xinhua has defended the country against blame for global steel woes, calling it a "lazy excuse for protectionism." The agency stated that cheap Chinese steel has created jobs in Europe and elsewhere, and that the issue is a global problem that requires dialogue and cooperation. Xinhua warned that protectionism would lead to more job losses, and that the Chinese government is working to address the challenges posed by overcapacity. The commentary reflects the government's stance on the issue, which is not an official policy statement but can be seen as a reflection of government thinking.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB says it will meet other obligations amid debt dispute with IPIC
summary: Malaysia's state fund 1MDB announced it will meet its "other" financial obligations despite a debt dispute with Abu Dhabi sovereign fund IPIC. IPIC had accused 1MDB of defaulting on a bond deal, but 1MDB stated it would assume interest payments and maintain liquidity. The fund clarified it would fulfill all other obligations under separate financing arrangements.

images.alt_text: Malaysian state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) said on Monday it would meet all its "other" financial obligations, after an Abu Dhabi sovereign fund said 1MDB had defaulted on a an obligations relating to a US$1.75 billion bond.

site_title: UAE's IPIC says Malaysia's 1MDB in default on June rescue deal
summary: IPIC, a UAE fund, terminated a June agreement to support Malaysia's 1MDB after the fund failed to meet obligations, including a $1.1 billion payment. The agreement, which included a $1 billion cash infusion and assumption of $3.5 billion debt, was terminated due to non-payment. IPIC is now considering its options, including referring the matter to a dispute resolution forum. The Malaysian side is expected to honour its commitments, but IPIC is seeking remedy for the default.

images.alt_text: International Petroleum Investment Company (IPIC) said on Monday a June agreement to provide financial support to Malaysia's 1MDB had been terminated after the troubled sovereign vehicle failed to meet obligations to the Abu Dhabi fund.

site_title: China's richest investors multiply as stocks rebound from lows
summary: China's wealthiest investors increased in number by 20% in March, while those with the least funds dropped 3.9%, amid a 12% rebound in the Shanghai Composite Index. The index's largest gain since April 2015 was driven by signs of economic stabilization and currency recovery. New investors poured into the market, with 535,000 joining in the week through March 25, as risk appetite picked up. The Shanghai Composite Index is still down 15% in 2016, but the increase in wealthy traders is seen as positive for the world's worst-performing stock market.

site_title: Osborne warns of decades of economic pain if UK quits EU
summary: Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne has warned that the UK's economy would shrink by 6% by 2030 if the country were to leave the European Union, citing a Treasury analysis that highlights permanent damage to trade and investment. Osborne's intervention comes as the government seeks to dissuade voters from the "Leave" campaign ahead of the June 23 referendum, with US President Barack Obama also set to offer his own warning against leaving.

images.alt_text: Leaving the European Union would be an economic blow that would shrink Britain's economy 6 per cent by 2030, according to a Treasury analysis produced as the government attempts to dissuade the electorate from voting to quit the bloc.

site_title: Moody's downgrades South Korea banking to 'negative'
summary: Moody's downgraded South Korea's banking system to 'negative' from stable, citing a deteriorating operating environment due to slow economic growth and corporate sector restructuring. The agency predicts a decline in creditworthiness over the next year, driven by high household debt and potential interest rate cuts. Moody's assumes an economic growth rate of 2.5% in 2016, with external demand remaining weak. The downgrade comes amid concerns over government efforts to address high household debt and inflation running below targets, which could further depress lending margins.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker but off their lows, thanks to Dow futures rebound
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 6.19 points to 2,917.75 on Monday, despite a rebound in Dow futures, which recovered from an early 100-point drop. The failure of oil talks in Doha led to a sharp decline in oil prices, with offshore and marine stocks being the main targets of short selling. The FTSE ST Oil and Gas Index fell 2.4%. The market's weakness was partly offset by the Dow futures' rebound, suggesting that Wall Street may not plunge as badly as initially feared.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB says has repaid all bank debt and short-term debt
summary: Malaysia's state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) has repaid all bank debt and short-term debt, totaling approximately RM7.25 billion, and has a cash surplus of RM2.3 billion. The fund also repaid a US$150 million term financing facility from EXIM bank in advance. This repayment comes after a four-week period of debt principal repayments.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) said on Monday that it has repaid all bank debt and short term debt, and has a cash surplus of approximately 2.3 billion ringgit (S$794.1 million).

site_title: Keppel Corp's Q1 net profit down 42%
summary: Keppel Corp's Q1 net profit fell 42% to S$210.6 million, largely due to a 38% decline in revenue. The property division's revenue offset reduced sales in offshore and marine, infrastructure, and investment divisions. The company secured S$200 million in new orders for its offshore and marine division, with a S$8.6 billion net order book.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares dive 3.4% on Japan quake, failed oil deal
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted 3.4% on Monday after deadly earthquakes halted Japanese factories, while plunging oil prices hurt energy shares following failed talks to freeze crude output. The Nikkei 225 index fell 572.08 points to 16,275.95. Oil prices dropped, affecting energy shares.

site_title: Reckitt Benckiser affirms targets after strong first-quarter
summary: Reckitt Benckiser reported a 5% increase in like-for-like sales for the first quarter, beating analyst expectations of 4.9%. The company's consumer health business saw a 10% sales jump, driven by growth in aging populations and urbanization. Reckitt reaffirmed its full-year forecast of 4-5% group sales growth and a moderate operating margin expansion. The company attributed a 5% tailwind from foreign currency exchange rates.

site_title: Australia parliament rejects bill, likely triggers July election
summary: Australia's parliament voted down a labour reform bill, leading to Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's decision to dissolve both houses and hold a general election on July 2. The bill's defeat came after a quick vote in the Senate, with 34 senators opposing and 36 supporting the proposal. The election is seen as a result of the government's inability to pass key legislation, giving Turnbull the excuse he needed to call for an election.

site_title: Hutchison Port predicts more mega ships calling at Shenzhen hub
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust predicts an increase in mega ships calling at its Shenzhen hub, driven by growing cargo from China's export manufacturing region. The company is expanding its facilities, including a new berth and a second berth set to open in the second half, to handle the larger vessels. This growth may eat into volumes at the company's Hong Kong terminal, which has seen a decline in cargo due to transshipments declining. Hutchison Port Holdings Trust handled 12.2 million 20-foot boxes at its terminals last year, a 1% decrease from 2014.

site_title: Shanghai steel jumps 3% on firm demand, lifts iron ore
summary: Shanghai steel futures rose 3.2% to 2,391 yuan a tonne, driven by firmer seasonal demand and stabilizing Chinese economy data, including rising home prices and slower economic growth. Iron ore prices also increased, with September iron ore climbing 2.8% to 425.50 yuan a tonne and June iron ore advancing 3.2% to US$55.05 a tonne. However, analysts predict that the gains will be short-lived, citing a persistently oversupplied steel market and rising supply.

site_title: India says Koh-i-Noor diamond belongs to Britain
summary: India's government told the Supreme Court that the 108-carat Koh-i-Noor diamond belongs to Britain, citing a 19th-century Sikh king Ranjit Singh's voluntary gift to the British as compensation for help in the Sikh Wars. The diamond was presented to Queen Victoria in 1850 after Britain gained control of the Sikh empire, and its true origins remain a mystery. India's Solicitor General Ranjit Kumar stated that the stone was not stolen and that the government supports Britain's ownership claim. The court will continue to hear a suit seeking the diamond's return.

site_title: Asia energy firms sink with oil as Doha output talks fail
summary: Oil prices plummeted in Asia, sending energy firms and regional stock markets tumbling, after Doha output talks failed. The collapse of talks, which aimed to ease a global supply glut, led to a 4.7% drop in US West Texas Intermediate and 4.4% drop in global benchmark Brent crude. Energy firms, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, fell sharply, while regional markets, including Hong Kong and Tokyo, also declined. Analysts warn of further price collapse, predicting a 15% drop in oil prices, as Saudi Arabia's decision to walk away from the talks sent shockwaves through the market.

site_title: Oil, petchem plants in Kyushu, Japan, running normally after quakes
summary: Oil and petrochemical plants on Kyushu island in Japan are operating normally after a series of earthquakes measuring up to 7.3 magnitude. JX Nippon Oil & Energy Corp's 136,000-barrel-per-day Oita refinery and Showa Denko's naphtha cracker facility continued normal operations with no injuries or damage. The plants had briefly halted operations on Saturday, but resumed normal operations by Saturday afternoon. Shares of JX Holdings, the parent company of JX Nippon Oil & Energy Corp, rose 0.2 yen after concerns about the operations were temporarily alleviated.

site_title: China growth hopes reduce urgency of more stimulus steps, policy advisers say
summary: China's economic growth has stabilized, reducing the need for urgent policy stimulus steps, according to policy advisers. Despite quarter-century lows in growth, China's leaders remain cautious, citing the need for policy easing to cope with potential domestic restructuring and US interest rate hikes. While some advisers believe the urgency for stimulus has decreased, others note that policy easing is still necessary, but for now, the central bank has room to hold off on further easing.

site_title: Malaysia inflation seen easing to 3.6% year-on-year in March
summary: Malaysia's annual inflation rate is expected to ease to 3.6% in March from a 7-year high of 4.2% in February, according to a Reuters poll. Lower fuel prices in March are expected to offset higher costs of food and consumer goods. The inflation rate is expected to moderate after the first quarter, reflecting a higher base from a year earlier.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as Doha oil deal fails
summary: European shares fell on Monday as a meeting of major oil exporters in Doha failed to agree on output freezes, leading to a 3.4% decline in the STOXX Europe Oil and Gas index. The FTSEurofirst 300 index also dropped 1.2%. However, Reckitt Benckiser rose 1% after reporting better-than-expected quarterly sales and affirming its full-year forecast.

site_title: Australia state bans underground coal gas drilling
summary: Australia's Queensland state has banned underground coal gasification (UCG), a process that converts coal into gas, due to concerns over water contamination and greenhouse gas emissions. The ban was initiated by the state's mines minister, Anthony Lynham, who cited the potential risks to the environment and agricultural industries. This move follows a similar moratorium imposed by Wales in the UK and comes after a Singapore-listed company, Linc Energy, was charged with causing environmental harm following a gas leak at one of its UCG pilot plants. The ban is set to be made law by the end of the year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports fell 15.6% in March, a decline that reverses a 2.0% rise in February. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. The UK economy shrank for the second month, while Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May. Asean agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority. Meanwhile, Citigroup predicts a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026, and Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident that his daughter will be cleared of suspension as Thai PM in an ethics case.

images.alt_text: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) plunged 15.6 per cent year on year in March, proving that the 2.0 per cent rise in February was what private-sector economists had predicted - a "one-month wonder".

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks close lower on renewed appetite for safety
summary: South Korean stocks and the won closed lower on Monday due to a renewed appetite for safety amid the global oil price slump and a series of earthquakes. The won dropped 0.4% to 1,150.2 to the US dollar. Despite this, shares pared some losses as foreign investors continued buying throughout the day.

site_title: China launches pollution probe after hundreds of students fall sick
summary: China has launched an investigation into a language school in Changzhou after hundreds of students developed health problems, including cancer, due to suspected pollution from nearby former industrial sites. 493 out of 641 students underwent health checks and were found to have conditions ranging from chronic coughs to lymphoma and leukemia. The school opened on the polluted site in September, prompting parents to call for relocation. Environmental assessments had previously found high levels of contamination in the soil and water, and a soil restoration project was underway at the time of complaints.

site_title: Australia accelerates naval shipbuilding program to secure jobs
summary: Australia is accelerating its naval shipbuilding program to secure jobs, with construction of 12 offshore patrol vessels starting in 2018. The program, valued at A$3 billion, will create over 2,500 jobs and boost defence spending by nearly A$30 billion over 10 years. The program will be built in Adelaide and Western Australia, with three companies shortlisted to build the vessels. The Liberal Party hopes the move will boost support ahead of a likely federal election on July 2.

site_title: Yen rallies, emerging currencies dive after oil talks fail
summary: The yen rallied against the dollar after weekend talks in Doha to cap oil output failed, while emerging currencies, including the Malaysian ringgit and South Korean won, slumped. The collapse of talks, led by Saudi Arabia's refusal to include Iran, led to a rush for safe investments and a decline in commodity-linked currencies. The yen surged to 108.01 yen per dollar, while the euro slipped to 121.93 yen. The failure to reach an agreement has limited prospects for another near-term round of talks and has hit commodity currencies lower.

site_title: South Korean president 'humbly' accepts shock electoral defeat
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye accepted her party's shock electoral defeat, acknowledging the public's dissatisfaction with her economic record and soaring youth unemployment. The ruling Saenuri Party lost its parliamentary majority for the first time in 16 years, with the opposition holding 167 seats. Park vowed to work with the new parliament and prioritize policies for boosting job creation, as her single five-year term comes to an end. The defeat leaves her struggling to push through her conservative economic agenda, with her approval ratings having fallen significantly.

site_title: Japan PM: No change to sales tax plan barring financial crisis or major natural disaster
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe confirmed the government's plan to raise the sales tax next year, barring a financial crisis or major natural disaster. This comes after deadly earthquakes struck the southern island of Kyushu, causing at least 42 deaths and disrupting major manufacturers. Abe did not specify if the earthquakes would prompt a reconsideration of the tax hike, citing no changes to the plan.

site_title: China: Shares end lower as oil price drop rattles confidence
summary: China's stocks fell 1.3% and 1.4% in the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively, due to a drop in crude oil prices and concerns over the market's sustainability. Analysts attribute the decline to China's fragile economic recovery and a stretched rally, with some warning of escalating risks and a potential growth revival.

site_title: Credit Suisse to halt earnings previews in Japan following probe
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG will stop publishing research that previews companies' financial results in Japan following a probe into a leaked earnings forecast by one of its analysts. The Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission found the analyst leaked information to a colleague and at least one customer, prompting the firm to halt such previews and conferences. Credit Suisse takes the recommendation seriously and plans to strengthen internal controls. The move comes as Japan's financial regulator grapples with ensuring fair access to corporate information before publication.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group AG will stop publishing research that previews companies' financial results in Japan after the securities watchdog found that its local securities unit leaked information about a company's earnings.

site_title: China state enterprises likely to suffer more defaults, S&P says
summary: China's state-owned enterprises are likely to face more defaults over the next year due to the government's willingness to shut struggling companies in industries with overcapacity, such as steel, mining, and shipbuilding. This policy shift, according to Standard & Poor's, will exacerbate problems in cyclical sectors facing sluggish demand and slowing investment growth.

site_title: SIA, Airbus officially launch new flight training centre at Seletar
summary: SIA and Airbus launched the Airbus Asia Training Centre at Seletar Aerospace Park in Singapore, offering type rating and recurrent training courses for Airbus aircraft. The 9,250-square-metre facility will be Airbus's largest flight crew training center, with eight full-flight simulators and capacity for over 10,000 trainees annually. Seventeen airlines from Asia and the Pacific have signed up to use the center's services, catering to a growing demand for flight crew training in the Asia-Pacific region, where the in-service fleet is expected to grow to 14,000 aircraft over the next two decades.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China's Panda bond market leaves foreign issuers unimpressed
summary: China's Panda bond market, established last year, has failed to attract foreign issuers due to regulatory delays and policy uncertainties. Despite the initial enthusiasm, only a handful of foreign companies have been able to access the market, with most opting for the offshore Dim Sum market instead. The main obstacle to foreign issuers is the restrictive use of proceeds, which requires specific project allocations, limiting the market's growth potential. Regulators acknowledge the frustrations and are open to discussions on private placements, but the market remains underdeveloped, with yields stabilizing in the Dim Sum market.

site_title: Alipay owner said to start Shanghai IPO process as soon as 2016
summary: Alibaba's finance affiliate, Zhejiang Ant Small & Micro Financial Services Group Co, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) on Shanghai's main board, potentially China's highest IPO valuation since 2010. The company, which owns Alipay, is expected to raise at least $3.5 billion at a valuation of $60 billion. Ant Financial has met China's listing requirements, having been profitable for three years and accumulating significant cash flow. The IPO could be dual-listed with Hong Kong, with Alibaba founder Jack Ma expressing openness to this option.

site_title: Australia funds lead bids for A$5.3b Port of Melbourne sale
summary: Three Australian and international consortia have submitted bids for a 50-year lease of the Port of Melbourne, Australia's largest shipping container terminal. The state government aims to raise A$5.3 billion, part of a broader privatisation program to cut debt and upgrade infrastructure. Australian banks Macquarie Group, QIC, and Hastings have teamed up with international funds such as APG, Borealis, and Wren House. The Victorian state treasurer expects strong market interest, with no Chinese players bidding on the deal, unlike a previous Port of Darwin sale. The sale is expected to proceed despite previous concerns over Chinese involvement.

images.alt_text: Three consortia of Australian and international funds have submitted bids for a 50-year lease of the Port of Melbourne, Australia's biggest shipping container terminal, people familiar with the matter said on Monday.

site_title: Australia funds lead 3 consortia bids in A$5.3b Port of Melbourne sale: sources
summary: Three consortia, including Australian banks Macquarie Group, QIC, and Hastings, have submitted bids for a 50-year lease of the Port of Melbourne in Australia, worth at least A$5.3 billion. The state government of Victoria aims to raise the funds through the privatization of the port. The bids were submitted after the state government launched the sale last month, with Morgan Stanley and Flagstaff Partners advising the government on the sale. The winner will be announced in the coming weeks, with the lease expected to be signed in 2017.

site_title: South Korea's Park confirms signs North preparing nuclear test
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye confirmed that North Korea is preparing for a possible fifth nuclear test, despite tightened UN sanctions. Intelligence reports suggest a spike in activity at the Punggye-ri nuclear test site, and a test would be a defiant move ahead of the country's ruling party congress. The South Korean Defence Ministry is monitoring the situation, warning of a possible underground nuclear test. The move comes after North Korea conducted its fourth nuclear test in January and a rocket launch in February, prompting the UN Security Council to impose strong sanctions.

site_title: Over 50% of global fintech investment in Asia-Pacific this quarter
summary: Fintech companies in the Asia-Pacific region received over 50% of global fintech investment in the first quarter, totaling US$2.7 billion. This represents a significant increase from US$445 million in the same period last year. China remains the largest recipient of fintech investment in the Asia-Pacific, accounting for 45% of all investments.

site_title: China posts slowest quarterly growth on record: govt
summary: China's economy grew at its slowest quarter-on-quarter rate since 2011, expanding 1.1% in January-March over the last quarter of 2015. The real-estate sector rebounded, with property services growing 9.1% year-over-year, contributing to the growth. Analysts say the recovery is driven by policy easing and strong property sales, but expect it to be short-lived due to oversupply in the housing market and tightening policies. The government is managing a transition to a more consumer-driven economy, but the change is proving bumpy.

site_title: Quakes may sway Japan's Abe to boost spending, delay tax hike
summary: A series of large earthquakes in southern Japan has raised the possibility of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe increasing fiscal stimulus and delaying a planned sales tax hike. The quakes, which have killed at least 42 people and left over 1,000 injured, may justify a stimulus package, according to economists. The disaster may also affect Abe's thinking on calling a snap general election. The government is expected to compile a large budget to aid the recovery and prepare for future disasters, potentially accelerating the transfer of tax revenues to local governments.

site_title: Singapore households' inflation expectations inch up in March: survey
summary: Singapore households' inflation expectations rose to 2.79% in March, up from 2.74% in December 2015, according to the Singapore Index of Inflation Expectations (SInDEx) survey. This is the lowest reading since the survey's start in 2011. Despite a weak global growth climate, households expect one-year-ahead price changes to have flattened somewhat compared to a year ago. The survey of 500 individuals showed a slight decrease in mean one-year-ahead inflation rate to 2.94%.

site_title: Kuwait oil strike to support Brent, Dubai, reduce fuel exports: analysts
summary: A workers' strike in Kuwait has cut crude output by over 60% to 1.1 million barrels per day, supporting oil price benchmarks Brent and Dubai, and reducing fuel exports. Kuwait's refinery runs and exports have also decreased, tightening oil product supplies. The strike comes as OPEC producers failed to coordinate output at Sunday's Doha talks, causing global oil futures to drop 5% on Monday. Analysts say the production cuts will have a positive impact on oil prices, while also highlighting the challenges in coordinating output among OPEC producers.

site_title: Amazon rivals Netflix with stand-alone video subscriptions
summary: Amazon is launching a stand-alone video subscription service, Prime Video, to rival Netflix, with a monthly payment option of $8.99. Amazon Prime, which previously cost $99/year, will also be available on a monthly plan of $10.99. Those making the annual payment will receive a 25% discount. This move aims to cater to customer calls for more flexible options, following the company's experiment with a monthly payment option through a partnership with Sprint.

site_title: Osborne to lay out economic cost of UK voting to leave EU
summary: Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne will release a Treasury analysis on the economic cost of a UK vote to leave the European Union, warning that an exit would shrink the economy and make British households poorer. The report predicts a permanent 6% shrinkage of gross domestic product by 2030, with each household losing £4,300 per year.
