IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde described the spring meetings as "collective therapy" to address gloomy economic prospects. The IMF cut its global growth forecasts for the fourth time in a year, citing weak demand, a potential UK exit from the EU, and low commodity prices. Lagarde emphasized the need for collective action to address the global economic situation.

site_title: China's AMAC to impose tough new rules on hedge funds in "Wild East" crackdown
summary: China's Asset Management Association of China (AMAC) will impose stricter regulations on hedge funds in a crackdown on "Wild East" fraud and illegal money raising. The new rules, set to take effect in July, require fund managers to disclose investment risks, review investor identities, and set up special accounts. The regulations aim to protect investors' rights and regulate the private fund management industry, which has seen increased scrutiny amid concerns of fraud and shadow-lending. Private fund registrations more than doubled to over 25,000 in 2015.

site_title: Bombardier close to clinching largest C Series order: source
summary: Bombardier is close to clinching its largest C Series order, with Delta Air Lines seeking up to 125 carbon-fibre aircraft, equaling half of the total orders Bombardier has in hand. This deal would be the largest for the struggling aircraft program. The potential commitment is part of Delta's efforts to replace its oldest and smallest planes in its fleet.

site_title: Fed's Evans says bar high for any rate action in April
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Charles Evans stated that the central bank is unlikely to raise interest rates in April, but sees at least two increases over the rest of the year as likely. Evans cited the economy's fundamentals as consistent with gradual normalization, but emphasized the need for inflation to reach its 2% target. The path of inflation will inform the Fed's decisions, and Evans warned that the central bank is responsible for achieving its inflation goal, even if it means overshooting.

site_title: Two years after tragedy, cranes brace to raise Korea ferry
summary: South Korea marked the two-year anniversary of the Sewol ferry disaster, which killed over 300 people, mostly students. The ferry's wreckage lies 40 meters beneath the sea's surface, and a salvage operation is set to begin next month. The project aims to recover the remains of nine missing bodies, with an 80% chance of success. Families of the victims continue to demand the recovery of their loved ones' remains, with some expressing frustration over the government's lack of transparency. The operation is expected to be completed by late July.

site_title: New personal relief cap makes tax system more progressive
summary: Singapore introduces a new personal relief cap of S$80,000 on total income tax reliefs, affecting only 1% of taxpayers. The cap aims to make the tax system more progressive, targeting high-income working mothers with two or more children claiming the Working Mother's Child Relief (WMCR). Most Singaporeans support the new cap, and it is expected to raise an additional S$100 million in tax revenue from 2018 onwards. While some high-income earners may face increased tax bills, the cap is seen as a necessary measure to prevent tax avoidance loopholes.

site_title: G20 embraces crackdown on tax havens, warns over 'Brexit'
summary: The G20 nations agreed to crack down on tax havens, supporting proposals to require authorities to share the identities of real owners of shell companies and creating a blacklist of uncooperative tax havens. This move follows the Panama Papers scandal and aims to combat money laundering. The G20 also warned that Brexit could lead to a loss of global cooperation on financial issues, but no concrete conclusions were reached.

site_title: Obamas paid 18.7% in taxes on US$436,065 gross income in 2015
summary: US President Barack Obama and his wife Michelle reported a 2015 adjusted gross income of $436,065, down 8.7% from the previous year. They paid 18.7% in federal taxes, with the majority coming from the president's salary and book royalties. The Obamas also donated 14.7% of their income to charity, totaling $64,066. Meanwhile, Vice President Joe Biden and his wife Jill reported a 1% increase in income and paid 23.3% in federal taxes.

site_title: Major quake hits near Japan's Kumamoto; tsunami advisory lifted
summary: A magnitude 7.1 earthquake struck southern Japan near the city of Kumamoto, 24 hours after a 6.4-magnitude quake killed nine people and injured 1,000. The quake triggered a tsunami advisory, which was later lifted after no irregularities were reported at nuclear power plants. Damage was reported, including collapsed buildings and cracked roads, but no immediate casualties were confirmed. The quake occurred at a shallow depth of 10 km, and several aftershocks were felt in the region.

site_title: Oil down ahead of producer meeting
summary: Crude oil prices fell ahead of a weekend meeting by major producers, potentially leading to an output freeze. Global energy stocks declined, while the US dollar and stocks posted weekly gains. Apple shares dropped due to reported reduced iPhone production. The S&P 500 had its seventh positive week in nine.

site_title: US dollar falls on lackluster data
summary: The US dollar fell against the euro and yen following lackluster US economic data, including a 0.6% decline in industrial production in March and a drop in consumer confidence to 89.7 in April. Analysts predict the Federal Reserve may refrain from further interest rate increases and could downgrade its assessment of the US economy. A failure to reach a deal on oil production cuts at the Doha meeting could lead to a collapse in oil prices, depressing the stock market and lifting the dollar.

site_title: No guarantee of oil deal at Doha talks
summary: Major oil producers are set to meet in Doha to negotiate an output freeze, but doubts remain over whether Iran will join. Analysts expect a deal to freeze production at January's levels, potentially boosting prices. However, Saudi Arabia has insisted that Iran must join an output freeze, and Iran seeks a waiver until its production reaches pre-embargo levels. The outcome is uncertain, with some experts warning against overexpectation and others predicting a possible agreement could lead to balanced markets and higher prices.

images.alt_text: Major oil producers will meet this weekend to try and negotiate an output freeze to drain crude oversupply and boost prices, but doubts remain over whether Iran will join any accord.

site_title: Advantages of a coronary CT scan
summary: A non-invasive coronary CT scan, also known as coronary CT angiography (CCTA), has been found to have virtually 100% accuracy in detecting heart artery disease. The test uses X-rays to image the heart arteries and is particularly useful in diagnosing patients with exertional shortness of breath, as many who die suddenly from a heart attack do not have any symptoms. CCTA has been shown to reduce the duration of hospital stays, avoid unnecessary hospitalizations, and is extremely accurate in ruling out heart disease, making it a cost-effective alternative to invasive coronary angiography.

site_title: China crackdown on cross-border online shopping creates panic
summary: China has implemented stricter rules on cross-border online shopping, leading to panic among consumers and businesses. The country raised taxes on goods bought on overseas e-commerce platforms and introduced a "positive list" of restricted products, prompting some to be removed from shelves. The measures threaten to slow China's fast-growing cross-border e-commerce market, which attracted domestic shoppers with lower tax rates and less red tape. The regulations have also spooked informal shopping agents and raised concerns about increased costs for delivery firms, with some companies scrambling to respond and lobby local regulators for clarity.

site_title: Two successful launches help revive new-home sales in March
summary: Singapore's new-home market has seen a boost in sales after two successful condominium launches in March, with developers selling 843 private homes and 1,328 units including executive condominiums, more than triple the February numbers. The successful launches, particularly CapitaLand's Cairnhill Nine and The Wisteria, have reinforced the market's belief in strong underlying demand for good-quality properties at the right price. Market confidence appears to have returned, with analysts predicting continued improvement in sentiment and demand in Q2.

site_title: India suspends Mallya's diplomatic passport for four weeks
summary: India has suspended Vijay Mallya's diplomatic passport for four weeks, citing creditor banks' pressure to recover $1.4 billion in debt from his defunct airline, Kingfisher Airlines. The move comes after Mallya failed to appear before investigators in a loan fraud probe. The Enforcement Directorate had requested the government to revoke his passport, which Mallya had used to leave the country in March. Mallya's whereabouts remain unknown, and he has denied being an absconder.

images.alt_text: MR MALLYA: The embattled tycoon has not revealed his whereabouts since his departure from India on March 2, but has said he is not an absconder.

site_title: Indonesia to use new policy benchmark
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, announced it will use the 7-day reverse repurchase rate as its benchmark policy rate starting August 19, aiming to deepen the country's inter-bank market and guide money market rates. The change is expected to help Bank Indonesia better guide market rates from overnight to 12-month tenure.

images.alt_text: GUIDING HAND: BI's rate cuts this year have been aimed at spurring economic growth, which in 2015 was 4.8 per cent.

site_title: Hong Kong Disneyland cuts staff after first loss in four years
summary: Hong Kong Disneyland cut jobs for the first time in four years due to a slump in mainland visitors. The park fired fewer than 100 workers, citing operational adjustments to improve efficiency. Disney stated that the moves are necessary to maintain a solid foundation for sustainable growth and to pave the way for future development. The park reviews operational needs regularly to ensure great guest and cast experiences in the most efficient way possible.

site_title: UN rights chief to Trump: 'Bigotry is not strong leadership'
summary: UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Zeid Ra'ad Al-Hussein criticized US Republican presidential frontrunner Donald Trump, accusing him of exploiting fear and resorting to bigotry in his campaign. Trump has promised to build a wall on the US-Mexico border and ban Muslims from entering the US. Zeid warned that such rhetoric is a "road to violence" and could lead to harm to a great nation. He urged the US to reject hate speech and marginalization of minorities, saying "bigotry is not proof of strong leadership."

site_title: Linc enters voluntary administration
summary: Linc Energy, a Singapore-listed oil and gas exploration firm, has entered voluntary administration following a prolonged slump in crude oil prices. The company's directors appointed administrators to work with the management team to explore restructuring options. Linc's business includes onshore US oil and gas operations and exploration in South Australia. The move follows a voluntary suspension of its stock in March, and the company's substantial shareholder, Genting, appears to be one of the parties involved. The administrators aim to fully understand the options available to the company, which may include a restructure.

site_title: LSE to launch trading of China firms' GDRs
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) plans to launch trading of global depositary receipts (GDRs) of Chinese companies next year, starting a partnership with its Shanghai counterpart. GDRs will allow investors to access Chinese companies without direct equity trading, overcoming technical challenges. The move is seen as a relatively easy way for the exchanges to deepen ties, with the LSE having success with this model in Russian names. A formal agreement is expected in the second half of the year, with actual issuance dependent on the companies' needs.

site_title: Placing faith and funds in wisdom of a robot
summary: Investors are increasingly relying on algorithms to analyze environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors when making investment decisions. A robot has made a key investment choice for a fund manager, Arabesque Partners, choosing Cracker Barrel as a top investment, despite the company's vintage specialty. Arabesque's algorithm uses vast amounts of ESG data to inform its decisions, and the firm is part of a growing trend among investors to incorporate ESG analysis into their portfolios. This approach aims to identify companies that perform well both financially and socially.

site_title: Argentina, IMF restore regular fiscal checkups after decade
summary: Argentina has agreed to resume regular fiscal checkups with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) after a 10-year hiatus. The move marks a repair of relations following the country's 2001 debt default. The IMF will restart its Article IV missions in September, assessing Argentina's economy and discussing policy changes with the central bank, government, and private sector. The shift comes after President Mauricio Macri's economic reforms, which include repaying defaulted debt and implementing market-friendly policies.

images.alt_text: Argentina will resume annual fiscal checkups with the International Monetary Fund this year after a 10-year hiatus, an IMF official said Friday.

site_title: Tax benefits of US homeownership no longer a draw for buyers
summary: US homeownership no longer offers significant tax benefits due to low mortgage rates. A married couple borrowing 80% of a median-priced home's value would pay $2,500 less in taxes by itemizing mortgage interest and property taxes compared to the standard deduction. The standard deduction has risen to $12,600, making the first $12,600 of itemized deductions tax-free. This has led to a decrease in first-time buyers, with the share remaining depressed. As mortgage rates rise, the interest deduction will help offset increased borrowing costs.

site_title: Investors spooked by 'overvalued' properties
summary: Investors in Singapore are concerned about the perceived overvaluation of local properties, with 78% of core investors (40-75 years old) and 89% of millennials (18-39 years old) sharing similar sentiments. This has led to a decrease in real estate investment opportunities, with the proportion dropping to 29% from 41% in 2015 and 49% in 2014. As a result, investors are shifting focus to international investments, particularly in the US, with 67% of core investors and 50% of millennials viewing international stocks as top investment opportunities.

site_title: Japan plants shut down after quake, fuelling economic fears
summary: Japan's 6.5-magnitude earthquake in southern Japan's Kyushu region has killed at least nine people, toppled houses, and damaged infrastructure. Several major companies, including Sony, Toyota, and Honda, have temporarily shut down operations due to safety concerns. Analysts believe the economic impact will be less severe than previous disasters, with some damage concentrated in Kumamoto and limited supply chain disruption. The broader Nikkei stock index ended 0.4% lower, but some losses were attributed to profit-taking. The Japanese economy is already struggling, and the quake may push the nation into a recessionary phase if unexpected shocks occur.

site_title: Steel exporters underprice products as pressure mounts
summary: The global steel industry is facing pressure as countries such as Japan and South Korea underprice their steel products, leading to a flood of cheap imports. Steelmakers in these countries sell their products overseas at prices 35% lower than in their home markets, contributing to chronic oversupply and sluggish demand. This has led to job losses and bankruptcies in countries like India and Australia, with Tata Steel pulling out of Britain and Arrium Ltd being placed in administration. The issue has prompted countries to impose protections and raise objections through international channels.

site_title: Ron Sim's S$1.39 a share offer 'fair and reasonable'
summary: OSIM International's founder Ron Sim is offering to privatise the company at S$1.39 per share, which PwC has deemed "fair and reasonable". The final offer price has a premium of 40.9% to the one-month VWAP and 42.5% to the three-month VWAP. PwC recommended independent directors to recommend shareholders to accept the offer, citing a high price-to-earnings ratio and trading liquidity concerns. The offer price is the same as the company's last trading price, allowing shareholders to sell their shares at the same price.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Yahoo's suitors uncover few financial details
summary: Yahoo's potential buyers are set to bid on the company's core Internet business despite financial concerns, with Verizon Communications, The Daily Mail, and private equity firm TPG expected to participate. Despite Yahoo's reluctance to share financial details, several big companies, including Google, AT&T, and CBS, are unlikely to bid due to antitrust concerns or a lack of interest. Yahoo's CEO Marissa Mayer has expressed her desire to make the company's services a "daily habit" for Internet users, but the company's declining business and lack of disclosure have raised concerns among potential bidders.

site_title: Swiss bliss
summary: Switzerland offers a unique blend of culture and nature, with its snow-capped mountains and picturesque towns. The country's four official languages - German, French, Italian, and Romansh - are spoken by its eight million inhabitants. Visitors can explore the iconic wooden Chapel Bridge in Lucerne, the ski resort town of St Moritz, and the charming town of Brig. The Glacier Express and Bernina Express trains offer breathtaking views of the Swiss Alps, while the Matterhorn mountain offers a thrilling experience. The country's rich history and culture are also evident in its castles, such as Chillon Castle, and its vibrant cities like Geneva, which boasts landmarks like the United Nations Building and the Jet d'Eau fountain.

site_title: Long-lost art now takes centre stage
summary: Conductor William Christie and Les Arts Florissants revived 18th-century French opera-ballet "Les Fetes Venitiennes" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, bringing a rare and forgotten art form back to the stage. The production, which combines dance and singing, was a celebration of spectacle and fun, with a modern twist. The opera-ballet was known for its lively dances and short, self-contained plots, making it a natural fit for modern audiences. The revival aims to showcase the excitement and vitality of Baroque music, which was often overshadowed by more famous composers.

site_title: Midas CEO comfortable with acquisition target's profit goal
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based train car body maker, is set to acquire aluminium product manufacturer Dalian Huicheng for up to 1.2 billion yuan. The acquisition is expected to be earnings-accretive and accelerate Midas' diversification programme. The deal, valued at 80 million yuan, will be funded through a massive issue of new Midas shares. Midas shareholders will vote on the acquisition on April 29. If successful, the deal will result in an earn-out consideration of 271.3 million Midas shares paid to the seller.

images.alt_text: MIDAS CEO PATRICK CHEW: He says the deal to acquire Dalian Huicheng can be earnings-accretive and will accelerate Midas' diversification programme.

site_title: Chowdown before touchdown!
summary: A business-focused section of a publication, including updates on its social media presence and various company partnerships, was published. The section highlights recent events and initiatives, such as the launch of a Telegram channel, collaborations with organizations, and the promotion of sustainable practices. Additionally, it touches on the concept of corporate purpose, although the article does not delve deeply into this topic. The section appears to be part of a larger publication focused on business and lifestyle news.

site_title: March industrial output falls, signals weak Q1 GDP growth
summary: US industrial production fell 0.6% in March, marking the sixth decline in seven months, with economists expecting a 0.1% drop. The decline signals weak Q1 GDP growth, with estimates ranging from 0.2% to 1.4% annualized rate. A slowing global economy, robust dollar, and lower oil prices have eroded demand for US manufactured goods, but recent manufacturing surveys are turning higher, suggesting the worst of the downturn may be over.

site_title: Ascott Reit posts 1.1% rise in Q1 distributable income; DPU dips
summary: Ascott Reit reported a 1.1% year-on-year rise in Q1 distributable income to S$27.3 million and a 1.75 Singapore cents DPU, down from 1.76 cents a year ago. Revenue rose 17.2% to S$105.5 million, mainly due to new acquisitions. The Reit declared an advanced distribution of 1.585 cents per unit, which will be paid on April 27. The company's asset size is expected to expand to S$5 billion with the completion of its second New York acquisition later this month.

site_title: NYT investing US$50m in global digital expansion
summary: The New York Times announced a $50 million investment to boost digital readership and revenue globally. The investment will create a new international digital growth team to promote the Times to global audiences. The newspaper has identified international growth as a top priority, aiming to attract tens of millions of international readers. The investment is part of the company's efforts to transition from print to digital and meet the challenges of the changing media landscape.

site_title: President Tony Tan gives his assent to Supply Bill
summary: President Tony Tan gave his assent to the Supply Bill, authorizing government expenditures for the new financial year. The Budget, which includes a surplus of S$3.4 billion, aims to transform Singapore's economy and build a caring society. The government's initiatives focus on enterprise and innovation, skills development, and supporting vulnerable communities. This marks the first Budget for Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat and the 13th Parliament.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Cortina opens S-E Asia's biggest Patek Philippe boutique
summary: Cortina Watch, Singapore's second-largest watch retailer, has opened South-east Asia's largest Patek Philippe boutique in ION Orchard, a 265.48 square meter space offering personal service and a showcase of the luxury watch brand's timepieces. The new boutique comes as the luxury watch business faces a downturn, with global sales slipping 3.3% in 2015. Despite this, shipments to Singapore rose 1%, and retail orders still rose in January. Cortina plans to open a larger Rolex shop at Marina Square later this year, with renovation costs estimated at around S$4 million.

site_title: US unveils new offshore O&G drilling rules
summary: The US Obama administration has unveiled new offshore oil and gas drilling rules, aiming to tighten safety requirements for underwater drilling gear and well-control operations. The rules are a response to the 2010 BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, which killed 11 and released millions of barrels of oil. The regulations, published just before the sixth anniversary of the disaster, are expected to prevent similar equipment failures. The rules will take effect once they are finalized and published in the Federal Register.

site_title: Civil society also 'critical' in fight against haze: Masagos
summary: Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Masagos Zulkifli emphasized the role of civil society in combating the smoky haze in the region. Civil society organizations can ensure consumers are informed and support sustainable products, while also holding companies accountable for their supply chains. The Singapore Environment Council has already led to the suspension of the use of the Singapore Green Label by APP and the removal of their products from Singapore supermarket shelves. The council plans to launch a new certification category for companies with exemplary peatland management and fire-prevention standards.

site_title: US: Oil shares, Apple lead stocks lower
summary: US stocks finished the week on a down note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 28.97 points (0.16%) to 17,897.46. The S&P 500 dropped 2.05 (0.10%) to 2,080.73, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 7.67 (0.16%) to 4,938.22. Oil-linked shares retreated due to lower oil prices, and Apple shares declined on reports of sluggish iPhone sales. Despite a strong week, the decline marks a solid week for US stocks.

site_title: GIC in tie-up to develop logistics assets in Indonesia
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC partners with PT Mega Manunggal Property Tbk to develop a portfolio of logistics warehouses in Indonesia, focusing on the Greater Jakarta and Greater Surabaya regions, with a target of 500,000 square meters of net leasable area over the next three years.

site_title: Robo-advisory company looks to Asia
summary: Parmenion Capital Partners, a UK-based robo-advisory firm, plans to expand in Asia, particularly in Singapore, where it would work with financial advisers to provide a platform for fund selection and model portfolios. The company, acquired by Aberdeen Asset Management last year, has assets under management of £2 billion. Parmenion's business model has been successful in the UK, enabling financial advisers to offer low-cost services to inactive clients. The company may also provide financial technology to institutions such as banks, as it believes outsourcing the system would be more cost-effective.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Yen stabilises as report forecasts big depreciation of renminbi
summary: The Japanese yen stabilized on Friday after a brief retreat against the dollar, despite warnings from the Bank of Japan about excessive volatility. A report by Hong Kong-based brokerage CLSA forecasts a 25% or more drop in the renminbi by the end of next year due to China's inability to defend the currency against capital outflows. The CLSA report also predicts financial volatility and risk-aversion will negatively impact Asian markets, including Hong Kong and Singapore, and cause deflationary forces in the region.

site_title: March data suggests China's economy may be stabilising
summary: China's economy showed signs of stabilization in March, with GDP growth slowing to 6.7% in the first quarter but industrial output, retail sales, and exports rising. The National Bureau of Statistics attributed the improvement to stimulus measures implemented over the past 18 months, boosting the real estate and industrial sectors. Economists expect the trend to continue, with the central bank indicating a willingness to maintain "prudent monetary policy with flexibility" to support growth.

site_title: Variable space
summary: The Volkswagen Golf Variant offers a spacious cabin and boot with minimal additional length. Measuring 4,562 mm in length, it is only 307 mm longer than the standard Golf hatchback. This compact wagon provides a roomy interior without compromising manoeuvrability, making it an ideal choice for urban transportation. The Variant's extended length allows for increased load-carrying capacity, making it a practical option for those requiring more space. Its proportions are pleasing, with a short tail that maintains a compact overall length.

site_title: Alternative lifestyle
summary: Audi has released the facelifted A6 Avant, combining estate functionality with distinctive style. The model features a new single frame grille, floating between the LED headlights, and dynamic turn signals. The A6 Avant is now a standard offering in Audi's line-up, unlike some competitors. The update aims to elevate the estate model's position in the market.

site_title: Ezra awash in red with S$249m Q2 loss
summary: Ezra Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore services provider, reported a net loss of US$249.9 million in the second quarter due to significant challenges in the global oil-and-gas industry. The company plans to divest its stake in a floating vessel by June to streamline its businesses. Ezra's gross profit margin fell to 6% from 20% last year, and its earnings per share declined to a loss of 8.12 US cents. The company aims to boost liquidity and strengthen its balance sheet amid low oil prices.

site_title: Brewing beauty
summary: Tea-infused beauty products are gaining popularity, with top beauty brands incorporating tea extracts into fragrances, skincare, and haircare products. Companies like Jo Malone, Atelier Cologne, and Bulgari have launched tea-based perfumes and scents, while Kiehl's and IDS Clinic offer tea-infused skincare products. Meanwhile, Innisfree and Plant Skincare have introduced tea-infused sunscreens and moisturizers. These products harness the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties of tea to promote healthy skin and hair, and provide a unique twist on traditional beauty products.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Asia's asset diversification is expected to drive growth, both within the region and globally. A low-profile property trust is investing in data centers, while Jack Ma-backed Ant plans to add a stablecoin to its global network. Amundi predicts retail investors will drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, potentially indicating an end to the worst of the trade war. Productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation, and de-dollarization is shifting safe havens. Markets continue to rise despite uncertainty.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust posted a 4.2% increase in distributable income to S$96.7 million for the first quarter, driven by 4.9% growth in shopper traffic and 4.6% in tenants' sales. Gross revenue grew 7.4% to S$179.8 million, with portfolio occupancy remaining high at 97.7%. Olam International and Mitsubishi Corp announced a 70-30 joint venture in Japan, starting operations on Oct 1, to import and distribute various food products.

site_title: Payrolls rose in 37 US states in March, led by Maryland
summary: US payrolls rose in 37 states in March, with Maryland leading with a 19,300 gain, followed by Ohio with 18,300 jobs. The jobless rate fell in 21 states, marking a robust start to the first quarter for the US labor market.

site_title: STI in the black after week of wild fluctuations
summary: The Straits Times Index gained 115 points or 4.1% over a week, moving into the black for the year after a short-covering bounce triggered by China's better-than-expected exports. The index rose to 2,923.94, with the largest daily gain on Friday, and turnover fluctuated wildly throughout the week, excluding warrants. This week's rally comes ahead of GDP data, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore also announcing a weaker Singapore dollar.

site_title: As Bryant departs, Curry steps up
summary: Kobe Bryant scored 60 points in his final NBA game, leading the Los Angeles Lakers to a 101-96 comeback victory over the Utah Jazz. Meanwhile, Stephen Curry achieved a milestone by becoming the first player to make 400 three-pointers in a single season, leading the Golden State Warriors to their 73rd win of the regular season. The Warriors, led by Curry, are favored to retain their NBA Championship this June.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: European shares trim best week in two months as automakers slide
summary: European shares trimmed their weekly gain, closing 0.4% lower on Friday, after automakers led the Stoxx Europe 600 Index lower. Volkswagen and Daimler slid 2.3% and 2.1% respectively, while energy producers and miners also declined. The Stoxx 600's weekly gain was cut to 3.3%, despite Nestle's climb after beating sales forecasts. Analysts predict shrinking profit for Stoxx 600 companies in 2016, with the index's valuation at 15.7 times estimated profit, higher than the five-year average.

site_title: COE supply for May-July to rise by 15%
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore announced a 15% increase in the supply of certificates of entitlement (COEs) from May to July, with an average of 9,634 COEs per month. This is a 14% increase for car COEs, 21% for big car COEs, and 9.3% for small car COEs. The commercial vehicle category will see the largest expansion, with a 40.7% increase to 456 pieces per month. The increase is attributed to high vehicle scrapping rates in March, with 13,580 vehicles deregistered, exceeding the average of the preceding two months.

site_title: Singapore can help with restoring of peatland: Indonesian official
summary: The head of Indonesia's Peatland Restoration Agency, Nazir Foead, has proposed collaboration with Singapore companies to invest in agriculture suited for peatlands and create a market for these crops. Foead aims to restore 2.26 million hectares of peatland in seven provinces, with a focus on preventing peatland fires, which were a major contributor to last year's haze. The agency plans to raise water levels, improve farmer livelihoods, and build a monitoring system using satellite images and sensors.

site_title: US still seen growing above potential in 2016: NY Fed
summary: The US economy is expected to expand at a 2% rate in 2016, above its potential rate of 1.75%, according to the New York Federal Reserve's staff forecast. This growth rate is lower than the 2.5% estimate from last year. The forecast suggests the US economy is still growing above its potential, despite some global economic challenges.

site_title: S'pore tourism regains some shine in 2016
summary: Singapore's tourism industry rebounded in 2016, with a 12.3% increase in arrivals in January and February, reaching 2.74 million visitors. The surge was driven by a near 34% increase in Chinese visitors, surpassing Indonesia's 11% growth. The Singapore Tourism Board's partnership with online travel services like Alitrip contributed to the boost. The rebound marked a turnaround from the uninspiring year in 2015.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Newly-appointed accountants for Workers' Party-run town council submit first report
summary: The Workers' Party-run town council in Singapore has submitted its first report to the Housing Board, led by newly-appointed accountants. The Housing Board will review the report without disclosing its content. This move comes as the Workers' Party faces scrutiny over its financial management.

site_title: Lean, mean F&B machines
summary: Singapore's restaurants are experiencing a decline in business due to the country's sluggish economy. With seasonal highs behind them, establishments are settling into a normal routine, but with fewer people dining out and drinking. The higher-end market is particularly affected, with fewer tables filled at each service. Restaurateurs are finding creative ways to tackle the challenges, awaiting the return of boom times.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Six new corporate partners on board for OCBC Cycle 2016
summary: OCBC Cycle 2016 has added six new corporate partners, including Millennium Hotels and Resorts, Polar, and 2XU, bringing the total to 21. The event, set for October 1-2, aims to attract 8,000 cyclists and will support four charities, including the Dyslexia Association of Singapore and NUHS Fund Limited. The event will feature seven categories and retain its four main-event categories. Online registration starts on Monday, with activities leading up to the event, including a registration launch with a 24-hour stationary bike challenge.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: ECB sees no evidence of asset bubbles from ultra low rates: Draghi
summary: ECB President Mario Draghi stated that the European Central Bank will continue to boost inflation with ultra-low rates, citing no evidence of asset bubbles. Draghi noted uncertainty in the eurozone's economic outlook due to emerging market risks, oil prices, and geopolitical tensions. The ECB will maintain its current or lower policy rates for an extended period, well past the end of asset purchases, according to its forward guidance.

site_title: Private bank investors warmly receive Frasers Centrepoint bond
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Ltd issued a 10-year, 4.25% bond worth S$250 million, attracting 81% of the issue from private bank investors, with 98% allocated to Singapore. Despite rising interest rates, the central bank's depreciation move and a 5 basis point price guidance range helped secure the deal. OCBC Bank, the sole lead manager and bookrunner, reported the transaction was driven by institutional accounts and internal allocations, with 50% going to OCBC entities. The deal follows six real estate issues by OCBC this year, raising S$995 million.

site_title: Asia's richest man building Chicago's priciest penthouse
summary: Asia's richest man, Wang Jianlin, is building Chicago's priciest penthouse in the 95-storey Vista Tower, set to be completed in 2020. The 7,000-square-foot duplex penthouse is offered for US$17.1 million, potentially setting a record for Chicago's most expensive residential real estate. Wang's personal net worth is estimated at US$31.7 billion, and the penthouse's price is just 0.05% of his wealth. The building will feature luxury condos and a Wanda Vista Hotel chain, attracting wealthy buyers from Asia and other regions.

site_title: Mars Food tells customers to go easy on the pasta sauce
summary: Mars Food is labeling certain products, such as pasta sauces and macaroni cheese, as suitable for consumption only once a week due to high levels of salt, sugar, or fat. This move aims to encourage healthier eating as the company faces pressure from public health advocates and regulators amid the growing obesity epidemic. The plan does not apply to Mars' chocolate or sweets businesses.

site_title: Taiwan's CTBC to buy RBS assets in Malaysia for US$314 million
summary: Taiwan's CTBC Financial Holding Co. plans to purchase Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc's Malaysian assets for US$314 million, marking a move by the British bank to retreat from its overseas operations. The deal includes the purchase of Royal Bank of Scotland Bhd for US$189.7 million and RBS's offshore banking unit in Labuan for US$123.9 million. This is the latest step in RBS's wind-back of its offshore operations, following a taxpayer-funded rescue during the global financial crisis.

site_title: Large donation to Najib was 'genuine', says Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Arabia has confirmed a large donation to Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak was "genuine" with no strings attached, according to Foreign Minister Adel Al-Jubeir. The donation, which raised questions about its source, was made without expectation of return, and Malaysian authorities have found no wrongdoing. The comments follow earlier reports linking the donation to 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB), a debt-ridden state fund chaired by Najib. Najib's government has denied any wrongdoing and claims the donation was for promoting "moderate Islam".

site_title: UK lawmakers to review new capital requirements for banks
summary: UK lawmakers will review new capital requirements for banks, following a row between the Bank of England and John Vickers, chairman of the Independent Commission on Banking. The Treasury Select Committee will examine whether banks hold sufficient capital to cushion them against potential losses. BoE Governor Mark Carney said UK banks already hold more capital than recommended by the ICB, and increasing requirements could harm the real economy. The review aims to ensure banks remain resilient in an economic downturn, despite controversy over the issue.

site_title: VW's star hire risks 'lame-duck' status
summary: Volkswagen's CEO Herbert Diess is facing a crisis as labor leader Bernd Osterloh has lost trust in his leadership, citing a "grave problem of trust" and saying management lacks reliability. Efforts to placate workers risk undermining Diess's position, with Matthias Mueller overseeing talks on safeguarding jobs and factories. The company's supervisory board needs to express stronger support for Diess to avoid him becoming a "lame duck," according to analysts. Diess's push to make the VW brand more independent has also raised concerns, particularly as the company struggles to recover from the emissions-cheating scandal.

images.alt_text: BUMPY RIDE: Mr Diess, a former BMW AG executive and one of Volkswagen's most high-profile hires in years, will help draft the brand's strategy objectives, which could end up being sidelined by the union talks.

site_title: Bank shell company rule nears approval as final draft sent to White House
summary: The US Treasury Department's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) has submitted a final rule requiring banks to identify the legal owners of shell companies, aiming to prevent money laundering and other illicit activities. The rule, which began in 2012, comes after a massive data breach at Mossack Fonseca, a Panamanian law firm that specializes in setting up off-shore shell companies. The White House's Office of Management and Budget will review the rule, which could take about 90 days, before it becomes final.

site_title: Beyonce jumps on athleisure bandwagon
summary: Beyoncé's Ivy Park fashion line has launched, offering a premium activewear label with on-trend mix of workout gear and casual clothing. However, the brand's success is uncertain, as many celebrity clothing lines have failed in the past. Experts say that celebrity brands fail due to a lack of effort to learn customer needs, and that the product itself, not the celebrity's name, determines sales. Despite this, Beyoncé has taken a hands-on approach to the brand, reaching out to designers and prioritizing product quality, with items ranging from leggings to sweatshirts and outerwear available at Topshop and other retailers.

site_title: Why one should travel to Hiroshima to revisit the past
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry recommends visiting Hiroshima's peace memorial, calling it a "gut-wrenching" experience. The city, known for its pleasant atmosphere and elegant design, is home to a memorial that commemorates the atomic bombing in 1945. Kerry's visit marked the first time a US government official had seen the memorial in 70 years, emphasizing the importance of revisiting the past to learn from history.

site_title: Sri Lankan Airlines plane made to return to Singapore due to 'security reasons'
summary: A Sri Lankan Airlines flight, UL309, took off from Singapore's Changi Airport on April 14 but was made to return to Singapore "due to security reasons" shortly after take-off. The flight was delayed for three hours and arrived in Colombo past midnight on April 15. The airline attributed the decision to return to Singapore as a precautionary measure. The exact reason for the security concerns is not specified. The flight was later cleared to proceed to its destination, Colombo.

site_title: Looking into the future of the EU
summary: Academics and analysts predict varying outcomes for the European Union, ranging from collapse to unity, due to economic anxiety, refugee crises, and rising nationalism. The EU's largest country, Germany, is under pressure due to cumulative burdens, while the UK's potential exit and Greece's economic struggles also pose threats. Meanwhile, unrelated news includes Malaysia seizing assets, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: An investor gripes about the Annual Giam-siap Meeting
summary: A Straits Times Index company has eliminated hard-copy annual reports and vouchers at its annual general meeting (AGM), citing cost savings. The move has frustrated investors who prefer to receive printed reports and vouchers. The company has also limited options for investors to receive annual reports in hard copy, instead requiring them to affix postage stamps. In contrast, other companies have adopted webcasts and electronic polling, which have been praised as improvements for minority shareholders. The writer calls for companies to prioritize investor needs, offering webcasts, transcripts, and printed reports, rather than cutting costs at the expense of investor satisfaction.

site_title: Lufthansa makes new offer to pilots in pay row
summary: Lufthansa has made a new offer to pilots, seeking to resolve a four-year pay dispute. The airline proposes a one-off payment of 12,000 euros per pilot and a 1.2% pay rise from July 2016 and 1.3% from January 2018. However, many pilots view the offer as insufficient, considering a 7% drop in pay when adjusted for inflation. Further strikes are possible if the offer is not improved. A meeting between the two sides is scheduled for April 22.

site_title: US: Wall St lower as oil slips, earnings in focus
summary: US stocks were flat on Friday due to concerns over a potential oil output freeze, which may not address the global oversupply. Despite positive Chinese data showing a 6.7% GDP growth, US industrial production fell more than expected in March. Citigroup's quarterly profit beat estimates, boosting the S&P 500, while the Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite also fell. Investors await comments from finance ministers and central bankers at the Spring Meetings in Washington.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: London's Heathrow is considering raising fees for its £10 billion upgrade, potentially affecting travelers. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. OCBC's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, previously worked at DBS, while Helen Wong is retiring as OCBC CEO. Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and CGSI downgraded Grab's stock to 'hold' due to expected slowing earnings growth. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Ron Sim's offer for OSIM 'fair and reasonable': PwC
summary: OSIM International founder Ron Sim's offer to privatize his company at S$1.39-a-share is deemed "fair and reasonable" by independent financial adviser PwC. The offer price is 17.3 times the median price ratio of comparable companies, above the median and mean of successful delisting or privatization transactions. PwC recommended that independent directors recommend shareholders to accept the offer, which was made after OSIM last traded at its final ex-dividend offer price of S$1.39.

site_title: Japan counts quake cost as rescuers search ruins
summary: A powerful 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck southern Japan's Kyushu island on Thursday, killing at least nine people and injuring hundreds. The quake left tens of thousands without water, with 24,900 households affected, and caused widespread destruction, including the collapse of houses, factories, and a high-speed train. Rescuers continued to search for survivors, but officials said the death toll was unlikely to rise significantly. An eight-month-old baby girl was pulled from the rubble alive, and a major castle was damaged. The government has confirmed 881 people injured, with at least 52 seriously.

site_title: G-20 warns of Brexit shock to global economy in draft statement
summary: The Group of 20 economies warned of a potential shock to global growth from a UK exit from the European Union, citing continued financial volatility, low inflation, and geopolitical conflicts. The G-20 reaffirmed its pledge to refrain from using exchange rates for domestic advantage and resisting all forms of protectionism. The statement also acknowledged the ongoing challenges faced by commodity exporters and the uncertainty of the global economic environment.

site_title: Can S'pore be an icon for service productivity?
summary: Singapore's economy is experiencing stagnant growth, with a 2% GDP increase in 2015 despite manufacturing output declining by 4.8%. Meanwhile, median gross income from work grew by 7% in real terms. However, the annual growth in value added per worker is almost zero, indicating that workers are not producing more value but getting better paid. To sustain growth, Singapore needs to either innovate or become more productive, with only two possible ways to achieve this without increasing the workforce.

images.alt_text: SHARING ASSETS: Customers collecting bicycles from terminals at a station in Taiwan's capital under the city's Taipei City Bike Sharing System.

site_title: Consumer sentiment falls on concerns over US wages, elections
summary: US consumer confidence fell to its weakest level in seven months in April, dropping to 89.7 due to concerns over unsatisfying wage growth and the upcoming presidential election's impact on the economy. Despite steady employment gains, Americans remain impatient as they balance their finances. Economists expect no recession, but concerns have risen about consumer resilience. The current conditions index declined, and expectations for future economic growth also decreased, with respondents expecting a 2.7% inflation rate and 2.5% price growth over the next five to 10 years.

site_title: Citigroup earnings tumble but beat expectations
summary: Citigroup reported a 26.6% decline in first quarter net income to $3.5 billion, beating analyst expectations. Revenues dropped 11.4% to $17.6 billion, primarily due to weak trading revenues and the energy bust. Investment banking revenue fell 27% and trading divisions saw lower revenues. Despite this, Citigroup benefited from reduced expenses and increased lending to core clients. The company's earnings per share translated to $1.10, seven cents better than expected, and its shares rose 2.3% to $46.00.

site_title: US industrial output falls, signals weak Q1 GDP growth
summary: US industrial output fell 0.6% in March, the largest decline since February 2015, as manufacturing and mining production decreased. This signals weak Q1 GDP growth, with estimates suggesting a 0.2% annualized rate. The decline is attributed to a slowing global economy, robust dollar, and lower oil prices. However, recent manufacturing surveys have turned higher, and the dollar's rally has fizzled, indicating the worst of the industrial sector downturn may be over.

images.alt_text: US industrial production fell more than expected in March as manufacturing and mining production decreased, the latest indication that economic growth braked sharply in the first quarter.

site_title: Growing wealth inequality 'dangerous' threat to democracy: experts
summary: Growing wealth inequality is a fundamental risk to democracy, experts warn. The US has seen a $2 trillion annual redistribution of wealth from the bottom 99% to the top 1% over the last 30 years, with the top 1% expected to earn 37-40% of income by 2030. Globally, half of the world's wealth is held by just 1% of the population. Experts say this trend is driven by tax policies and the power of corporate lobbyists, leading to widespread dissatisfaction with democracy's ability to deliver results. Reversing inequality will depend on revamping government policies and making rules fairer, driven by public pressure.

site_title: Citigroup's Saunders to join Bank of England as Weale leaves
summary: Michael Saunders, an economist at Citigroup, will join the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee, replacing Martin Weale. Saunders has a "wealth of experience" and has published research on the UK's EU referendum, predicting economic uncertainty. His appointment may shift the committee's dovish stance, but Saunders is known for being adaptable. Saunders' views on the UK economy may prompt criticism from Brexit campaigners, who see him as a potential proponent of the economic damage caused by a vote to leave the EU.

images.alt_text: Michael Saunders, an economist at Citigroup Inc, will join the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee, replacing academic Martin Weale.

site_title: Nokia chairman, Skype founder invest in Finnish food delivery startup
summary: Nokia Chairman Risto Siilasmaa and Skype founder Niklas Zennstrom have invested in Finnish food delivery startup Wolt, which has raised $11 million in new funding. Wolt, which has partnered with EQT Ventures, plans to expand to other countries, starting with the Nordic region. The company, which has partnered with 400 restaurants and 100,000 users in Finland, has launched in Stockholm and aims to improve the food delivery experience through its mobile app and Uber-style map tracking.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.21 points to close at 1,727.99, driven by 1.58 billion lots valued at RM1.71 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 326 to 422.

site_title: Update: Cityneon cites UOB Kay Hian's 'buy' call as possible spark for rally
summary: Cityneon Holdings shares surged 11.1% or 5.5 Singapore cents to close at 55 cents after a trading query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company attributed the rally to a "BUY" call by UOB Kay Hian, which published a report with a target price of 72 cents. Cityneon was not aware of any other possible explanation for the trading activity.

site_title: London bourse to launch trading in Chinese depositary receipts: sources
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) plans to launch trading in Chinese depositary receipts (GDRs) of Shanghai-listed companies in 2017, marking a partnership between the LSE and Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE). This move is seen as an alternative to a direct equity trading link, which is unlikely due to technical challenges. GDRs will be traded during London hours, allowing for a relatively easy and straightforward way to deepen ties between the exchanges.

site_title: Investors dump US$3b of Treasury ETFs as haven appeal ebbs
summary: Investors are dumping US$3 billion of Treasury ETFs in April, with net redemptions reaching US$2.9 billion, as a revival in equity and commodity prices reduces demand for US debt safety. This follows US$4.8 billion in March redemptions. Treasury yields fell to 1.78% on Friday, while oil prices rose ahead of a potential output freeze. The IMF is set to meet in Washington to discuss global economic growth, with some analysts predicting US yields will rise as the Fed considers two interest rate hikes this year.

site_title: Japan's Abe to soon meet Putin in Russia: FMs
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will visit Russia to discuss a decades-long territorial dispute with President Vladimir Putin. The two leaders will meet in Russia to tackle the issue, which dates back to the end of World War II when Soviet troops seized the four southernmost islands in the Kuril chain. This is Japan's latest effort to resolve the dispute, which has been hamstrung by previous meetings between leaders.

site_title: Spanish industry minister Soria resigns over Panama leaks
summary: Spanish Industry Minister Jose Manuel Soria resigned due to conflicting explanations over his involvement with an offshore company listed in the Panama leaks. He initially denied involvement, but later admitted to being involved in a similarly named UK company after a document carrying his signature was released by El Mundo newspaper. Soria's resignation followed intense scrutiny and calls for his departure over his ties to the firm Mossack Fonseca.

site_title: US says China to scrap some export subsidies
summary: China has agreed to scrap some export subsidies on products such as metals, agriculture, and textiles, a step to reduce trade frictions with the US. The US Trade Representative's office announced the deal, which ended a program providing $1 billion in subsidies over three years to Chinese companies in seven sectors. Despite this, industry executives remain skeptical about the impact of the deal due to ongoing disputes over other forms of support for Chinese exporting industries.

site_title: Belgian transport minister steps down over airport security lapses: official
summary: Belgian Transport Minister Jacqueline Galant resigned over the deplorable state of airport security in Belgium, following the March 22 suicide attack. The resignation was accepted by Prime Minister Charles Michel. The decision comes after EU reports highlighted security lapses at the country's airports. Galant had been accused of ignoring the reports, leading to her resignation.

site_title: Iran oil minister won't attend Doha output freeze talks: ministry
summary: Iran's oil minister, Bijan Zanganeh, will not attend Doha output freeze talks, instead, his Opec representative will attend. Iran's oil production in March was 3.3 million barrels per day, below its pre-embargo level. Iran has announced it cannot join the plan to stabilize oil prices due to its still-low output. The country is expected to seek a waiver to increase production after the lifting of nuclear-related sanctions. Saudi Arabia has vowed not to join the output freeze unless Iran does the same, which could impact the global crude supply glut.

site_title: Traders vulnerable as market volatility breaks familiar correlations
summary: Market volatility has led to a breakdown in familiar correlations between asset classes, particularly between the Japanese yen and oil. Oil prices have surged 60% since January, while the yen has risen 10% against the dollar. This has caused significant losses for investors and damaged trading patterns. The impact has been particularly devastating in the first quarter, with revenue from market trading at JPMorgan and Bank of America declining 13% and 17% respectively. Hedge funds also experienced significant losses in early 2016, but have since recovered.

site_title: Corporate green bond issuance could triple this year: S&P
summary: Corporate green bond issuance is expected to reach up to $28 billion this year, tripling last year's $9.6 billion, driven by the Chinese green bond market. The Chinese market is expected to add around $13 billion to corporate green bond volumes. Moody's expects green bond issuance to rise to over $50 billion this year. The growth is attributed to high-profile companies issuing large green bonds, increasing investor demand, and the Chinese government's efforts to widen financing channels for environmentally-friendly projects.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust's Q1 distributable income up marginally at S$27.3m
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) posted a distributable income of S$27.3 million for its Q1 FY2016 results, a 1.1% increase from the same period last year. The distribution per unit (DPU) was 1.75 Singapore cents, down from 1.76 cents a year ago. The company raised S$100 million through an equity placement to fund its second acquisition in New York.

site_title: Malaysia keeps May crude palm oil export duty at 5%
summary: Malaysia has maintained its crude palm oil export tax at 5% for May, based on a reference price of RM2,531.53 per tonne. The tax was previously raised to 5% in April, ending a 2015 duty-free policy. The tax rate is applied if the price exceeds RM2,250 per tonne, with a range of 4.5% to 8.5% depending on the price. This decision aims to support the country's palm oil industry amid global market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Malaysia, the world's second largest palm oil producer after Indonesia, will maintain its crude palm oil export tax at 5 per cent in May, a government circular showed on Friday.

site_title: New Taiwan appointments spotlight China ties, homegrown defence aims
summary: Taiwan's pro-independence government has appointed a foreign affairs official and a former fighter pilot to key positions, signaling its intention to engage with China and build its own defense capabilities. Chang Hsiao-yueh, 63, is the new chief of the Mainland Affairs Council, while Feng Shih-kuan, 71, is the defense minister. The appointments come amid tension over the deportation of Taiwanese nationals from Kenya to China and ahead of President-elect Tsai Ing-wen's inauguration. The move aims to strengthen Taiwan's defense and economy, with a focus on building homegrown jets and submarines.

site_title: CMT posts Q1 DPU of 2.73 Singapore cents, up 1.9%
summary: Capitaland Mall Trust (CMT) posted a Q1 distributable income of S$96.7 million, up 4.2% from last year, translating to a 2.73 Singapore cent distribution per unit, a 1.9% increase. The company saw 4.9% year-on-year growth in shopper traffic and 4.6% in tenants' sales, with portfolio occupancy at 97.7% as of March 31.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Mitsubishi Corp, Olam form joint venture to import and distribute food products in Japan
summary: Mitsubishi Corp and Olam International formed a 70-30 joint venture, MC Agri Alliance, to import and distribute food products in Japan. The venture will import and distribute coffee, cocoa, sesame, and other products starting October 1, 2016. The joint venture will leverage the combined strengths of both companies to tap into the Japanese market.

site_title: Singapore shares post weekly gain of 4% on strong China exports, MAS easing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.1% over the week, ending in the black for the year, driven by a large short-covering bounce after China reported better-than-expected exports. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) also eased monetary policy, weakening the Singapore dollar. The index gained 115 points, with Friday's 10.01 point rise marking its fourth consecutive uptick for the week, and now stands at 41 points or 1.4% for the year to date.

images.alt_text: A LARGE, short-covering bounce on Wednesday that was triggered by China reporting better-than-expected exports for March was followed by a surprise announcement by the Monetary Authority of Singapore which essentially made for a weaker Singapore dollar - these were the highlights of the week in which the Straits Times Index finally moved into the black for the year.

site_title: Czechs pick "Czechia" as one-word name after decades of hesitation
summary: The Czech Republic's leaders have chosen "Czechia" as the country's one-word alternative name, agreed upon by key officials on Thursday. The choice, which must still win cabinet approval, aims to simplify use on products and name tags. The name "Czechia" is believed to have originated in the 19th century and was previously used by the Czech surveying and mapping authority as a possible one-word alternative. However, some critics argue it may sound ugly or be confused with "Chechnya", and the country has invested millions in its full name in tourism promotion campaigns.

images.alt_text: The Czech Republic's leaders have chosen "Czechia" as the one-word alternative name of their country to make it easier for companies, politicians and sportsmen to use on products, name tags and jerseys.

site_title: The Future of Commerce has Arrived: Understanding the New Asian Consumer
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The new Asian consumer expects seamless shopping experiences that save time and make life easier. With digital commerce transforming the path to purchase, companies must move now to capture opportunities or risk losing control to digital players. Accenture and IPSOS research shows that consumers now expect instant solutions, personalization, and value, delivered seamlessly. By 2025, consumers will expect smart assistants that can provide what they want, before they want it. Companies must recognize this shift and develop capabilities to meet changing consumer needs, or risk losing market share to digital-born companies.

site_title: India's smog-choked capital imposes driving restrictions
summary: New Delhi, India, has imposed driving restrictions for the second time this year, aiming to improve air quality in the city. The "odd-even" scheme restricts cars to alternate days based on license plate numbers, taking around 1 million cars off the roads. The restrictions were brought back by popular demand, with the city's transport minister stating that the people of Delhi wanted it. The move aims to reduce pollution and improve air quality, which was severely affected earlier this year due to hazardous levels of haze. The restrictions will last for another 15 days.

images.alt_text: New Delhi on Friday imposed driving restrictions that will take around a million cars off its roads for the second time this year, seeking to improve air quality in the world's most polluted capital.

site_title: China Eastern to expand fleet to over 800 aircraft by 2020 vs 561 at end-2015: pres
summary: China Eastern Airlines plans to expand its fleet to over 800 aircraft by 2020, up from 561 as of 2015. The airline aims to boost long-haul traffic to and from the US after a $450 million equity deal with Delta Air Lines last year. Delta acquired 3.55% of China Eastern, becoming the first US carrier to own part of a Chinese airline. The expansion plans are part of China Eastern's efforts to increase its global presence and compete with other airlines.

site_title: This shipyard is so unprofitable it's becoming a parking lot
summary: China Ocean Industry Group Ltd, a struggling shipyard, is transforming into a parking lot to meet China's estimated 50 million parking space shortage. The company plans to build and operate 100,000 parking lots, generating 70% of its operating profit by 2019. Shipbuilders are diversifying into parking to compensate for the global shipbuilding slump, with about 140 yards going out of business since 2010. The company expects to generate 500 million yuan in profit from parking, with annual revenues of 2 billion yuan.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's March retail sales fell 3.2% year-over-year despite a 51.3% surge in motor sales, with only three categories registering year-on-year increases. Developers sold 843 private homes in March, more than double February's sales. Cityneon, an event services provider, is set for strong earnings growth after acquiring an Avengers exhibition developer. Linc Energy has gone into voluntary administration, while Singapore's exports are forecast to have contracted due to weak global demand. The Straits Times Index rose 4% for the week, driven by a bounce on China's better-than-expected exports.

images.alt_text: Successful launches of several condominium projects in March lent boost to new home sales done by developers in Singapore.

site_title: Goldwind eyes mass production of 6MW turbines in three years
summary: Xinjiang Goldwind Science & Technology Co, China's largest wind turbine seller, plans to start mass-producing 6-megawatt turbines for coastal wind power projects in about three years. The company is currently testing the operation of the larger turbine and is expected to roll out a second-generation model by the end of the year. This move aims to expand China's offshore wind capacity, which is expected to double this year, driven by completed projects. Goldwind is also upgrading its onshore products to meet growing demand from developers seeking to build new projects in southern regions.

site_title: Saudis back embattled Malaysia PM on huge payment
summary: Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir has confirmed that a $681 million payment received by Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak was a "genuine donation" from the kingdom. Al-Jubeir's comments come as Najib has faced allegations that billions were looted from an investment company he founded. The Malaysian government had initially claimed the payment was financial backing for Najib's promotion of "moderate Islam," but Saudi Arabia's endorsement has helped to close the matter, with al-Jubeir stating that the matter is now "closed."

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's foreign minister has become the first official from the country to verify the Malaysian premier's claim that a US$681 million payment he received was a "donation" from the kingdom.

site_title: Global stocks hold near 2016 high as China data boosts won, kiwi
summary: Global stocks held near their 2016 high, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index declining 0.2% after China's first-quarter economic growth of 6.7% matched estimates, boosting the won and kiwi. Japanese shares fell after a magnitude 6.5 earthquake struck Japan, while US crude rose 0.1% to $41.55 a barrel ahead of OPEC talks in Doha. The Shanghai Composite Index stayed near a three-month high, and the Stoxx Europe 600 Index was little changed. Investors are now focusing on corporate earnings and central bankers' meetings in Washington.

site_title: Brexit would cause major legal issues for derivatives market: ISDA
summary: The International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA) warns that a British exit from the EU, or Brexit, would pose significant legal challenges for the $550 trillion derivatives market, affecting millions of interest rate, credit default, and commodities swaps contracts. If Britain votes to leave the EU on June 23, ISDA would need to reassess its "master agreement" template, potentially creating barriers for regulators dealing with a failed cross-border bank.

site_title: UK construction slips in February, housebuilding strong
summary: The UK construction sector experienced a slight decline in February, with a 0.3% decrease in output, but construction of new homes reached a record high, contributing to a 1.5% annual growth rate. This growth rate is the fastest in nearly a year, driven by a 6.8% increase in housebuilding, its fastest rate in almost two years. The sector's performance suggests that the construction industry is resilient to concerns about the EU referendum and tax changes.

site_title: Obama to back campaign against Brexit on trip to UK next week
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to visit the UK next week, where he will advocate for Britain to remain part of the European Union. Obama believes that a Brexit vote would diminish Britain's influence in the world, and that the EU's unity is crucial for advancing shared interests with the US and other countries. He will meet with Prime Minister David Cameron and Queen Elizabeth II, and will likely make a clear call for Britain to stay in the EU ahead of the June 23 referendum.

site_title: Disruptive Uber gets taste of own medicine in Singapore: Gadfly editorial
summary: Uber has reduced its prices in Singapore by about 15% amid fierce competition from local startup Grab and aggressive strategies from existing taxi companies. The ride-hailing app's private car service, UberX, will charge S$3.00 as its base fare, lower than the cheapest flag-down rate of S$3.20 for local taxis. This move is a response to the competitive environment in Singapore, where companies must adapt quickly to maintain profits.

site_title: Seoul: Won recoups Thursday's sharp loss; stocks flat
summary: The South Korean won recovered from Thursday's sharp decline, closing at 1,146.2 to the US dollar, a 0.9% gain. South Korean shares were steady, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing down 0.1%. Foreigners bought 97.8 billion won worth of shares for three consecutive sessions, contributing to the market's stability.

site_title: Europe may become swing LNG buyer as market braces for surplus
summary: Europe may become a swing LNG buyer, helping determine global prices, as the US and Asia's price gap narrows. Surplus cargoes will end up in Europe, driven by the start of US shale gas exports and a boom in flexible supply. Europe's excess regasification capacity and growing LNG traders, like MET Holding AG, will enable it to take advantage of the oversupplied market. The company's CEO, Benjamin Lakatos, expects Europe to be a swing buyer in 3-5 years, potentially influencing global LNG prices.

site_title: Top Chinese officer visits disputed South China Sea reefs
summary: A top Chinese military officer, Fan Changlong, recently visited disputed South China Sea islands and reefs, inspecting building work and meeting with soldiers. The visit was part of his role as vice chairman of the Central Military Commission. The exact islands or reefs visited were not disclosed. The move is seen as a demonstration of China's growing military presence in the disputed waters, which have been a point of contention with neighboring countries.

site_title: China: Stocks dip at end of bullish week as GDP growth meets forecast
summary: China's stocks ended a bullish week on a downbeat tone, dipping 0.1% as GDP data met forecasts, with the economy growing at 6.7% in the first quarter, its slowest since 2009. Despite this, the CSI300 index rose 2.7% for the week, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 3.1%. Analysts warned that signs of recovery may limit further monetary easing due to potential inflation risks, while banking and real estate sectors were the only main sectors in positive territory.

site_title: Singapore March exports seen contracting on weak global demand: poll
summary: Singapore's exports are forecast to contract 13.2% in March from a year earlier, according to a Reuters survey of 12 economists, amid weak global demand. This follows a surprise policy easing by the central bank last week. Non-oil domestic exports are expected to rise 2.3% month-over-month, while factory activity shrank for a ninth straight month. The contraction was less severe than in February, with new orders improving. The forecast suggests the economy is struggling with sluggish growth.

site_title: Japan's MHI opens Australian unit as Canberra ponders subs deal
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) has established a unit in Australia to bid for a $50 billion submarine contract. The unit will focus on power generation equipment and joint research projects. Japan is competing with France and Germany for the contract, with the Australian government seeking industrial innovation to boost its economy. A decision on the contract is expected within months, possibly ahead of a national election. The move is seen as a bid by Japan to bolster its chances of landing the contract and burnish its submarine bid.

site_title: China steel output rises despite reduction pledges
summary: China's steel output rose 2.9% in March to 70.65 million tonnes, the highest monthly output ever, despite government pledges to cut production by up to 150 million tonnes over three years. The increase followed a decline in 2015, when output fell 2.3% on-year. The move has raised concerns about the global steel industry's glut and has led to calls for protection from cheap imports from China. The price recovery is expected to be short-lived as output increases and traders end restocking, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: Chinese steel output rose in March, official data showed Friday, despite repeated pledges by the world's top producer to cut capacity as the worldwide industry languishes under a global glut.

site_title: Sterling steady, investors wary on Brexit campaign
summary: Sterling steadied near recent lows on Friday as investors remained wary of the Brexit campaign. The official campaign for the June 23 referendum has begun, with opinion polls indicating a tight race between "Yes" and "No" camps. The Bank of England warned that a British exit from the EU would create uncertainty and damage the economy. Bookmakers price in a one-in-three chance of Britain opting out of the union. The UK economy shrank for the second month, adding to concerns about the impact of Brexit on the economy.

site_title: Indonesia central bank to adopt new policy benchmark on Aug 19
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, announced it will adopt a new benchmark policy rate, the seven-day reverse repurchase rate, starting August 19 to make its monetary policy more effective. The new benchmark rate was 5.50% in its last auction, replacing the current policy rate. This change aims to guide money market rates and enhance the bank's monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank said on Friday it will adopt a new benchmark policy rate starting August 19 to make its monetary policy more effective in guiding money market rates.

site_title: Credit Suisse faces penalty in Japan for leaking information
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG faces punishment in Japan for leaking private information about a company. The Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission recommended a penalty for Credit Suisse's Japanese brokerage unit, which shared non-public information about a company's earnings forecast with at least one customer and 33 other investors. The SESC cited inadequate internal controls as the root cause, stemming from a post-downsizing lack of measures to ensure internal controls. This is the second securities firm to face penalties in Japan since December for information leaks.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group AG faces punishment in Japan after the nation's securities watchdog found that it leaked private information about a company.

site_title: China's Spring Airlines to double fleet size to 100 aircraft by 2018
summary: Spring Airlines, China's largest budget carrier, aims to double its fleet size to 100 aircraft by 2018. Chairman Wang Zhenghua stated the company will not introduce long-haul routes or purchase wide-body aircraft. The airline signed a $6.3 billion deal in December to buy 60 A320neo jets from Airbus Group SE. Rising air travel demand from Chinese tourists is driving the need for more jets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares snap 7-day winning streak
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index fell 0.1% on Friday, snapping a 7-day winning streak, after China's Q1 GDP data met forecasts. The index jumped 4.6% for the week, its best performance in nearly two months. China's economy grew 6.7% in Q1, the slowest pace since 2009, but showed signs of recovery. The data beat expectations, with industrial production and investment picking up, leading analysts to predict a cyclical upturn.

site_title: China bank lending rebounds strongly in March
summary: China's bank lending rebounded strongly in March, with new loans extending to 1.37 trillion yuan, up sharply from 726.6 billion yuan in February. This beat a median forecast and was lifted by the government's monetary loosening and a recovery in the property market. China's GDP grew 6.7% in the first quarter, meeting market expectations, and total social financing surged to 2.34 trillion yuan. Analysts expect less aggressive monetary policy easing, but the People's Bank of China will likely maintain a low interest rate environment to tackle slowing growth.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian initiates on Cityneon with 'buy'
summary: Brokerage UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on Cityneon with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$0.72, citing strong earnings growth potential following the acquisition of Victory Hill Exhibitions. The analysts believe Cityneon's scalable business model and high barriers to entry could support a 107% three-year earnings per share compounded annual growth rate. The acquisition gives Cityneon rights to use the "Avengers S.T.A.T.I.O.N." and "The Transformers Experience" franchise to open more exhibits based on Marvel comics and Transformers characters.

site_title: European stock markets slip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined at the start of trade on Friday, following a sharp rally earlier in the week.
