London's FTSE 100 index dropped 0.1% to 6,357.72 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices shed 0.3% and 0.2% respectively. The decline was attributed to a mix of factors, including the impact of US trade tensions and the uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve's future policy decisions.

site_title: European car sales rise 5.7% in March but VW brand dips
summary: European car sales rose 5.7% in March, driven by growth in Italy and France, but Volkswagen's core brand sales fell 1.6% despite a rebound in February. The European auto industry association ACEA reported 1.745 million car registrations, a 8.1% increase from the same period in 2015. All major European countries except Spain and Germany recorded growth, with Italy experiencing the strongest rise at 17.4%. This marks the 31st consecutive month of sales growth in the EU.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall after powerful quake
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Friday, snapping a three-session winning streak, amid concerns over a deadly quake in Japan's southwestern island of Kyushu. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.37%, while the Topix index eased 0.73%. The decline followed a three-session rally, with investors weighing the quake's impact on the economy.

site_title: Update: Linc Energy goes into voluntary administration
summary: Linc Energy, a suspended mainboard-listed company, has entered voluntary administration in Singapore, effective April 15, 2016. The company's directors appointed PPB Advisory as administrators to explore options, including restructuring. Linc Energy's business includes oil and gas operations in the US and exploration in South Australia. The move is seen as a strategic decision to restructure the company within a limited timeframe, following legal and financial advice.

site_title: US dollar firms, on track for weekly gains; G20 meeting in focus
summary: The US dollar rose on Friday, poised for weekly gains, as investors awaited the outcome of the G20 meeting in Washington, where currency policies are likely to be discussed. The dollar index added 0.1% to 94.948, while the euro edged down 0.1% to $1.1261, tracking the yen's decline. Risk sentiment improved after Chinese economic data suggested the slowdown in the world's second-largest economy may be bottoming out, and Japanese officials expressed concerns about one-sided currency moves.

site_title: Man Group reports US$500 million first-quarter net inflows
summary: Man Group reported a net inflow of US$500 million in the first quarter, driven by computer-driven funds attracting investors. Sales of US$5.1 billion outweighed redemptions of US$4.6 billion, resulting in a stable group fund under management of US$78.6 billion. Despite a 0.8% decline in hedge funds, Man Group's shares have fallen 14% this year, outperforming the STOXX Europe 600 Banks index's 18% drop.

site_title: Seven & i said to endorse Loeb's lead candidate as president
summary: Seven & i Holdings Co has endorsed Ryuichi Isaka, head of its Seven-Eleven Japan Co, as president after activist investor Dan Loeb intervened to stop an attempt to oust him. The nomination committee met and voted in favor of Isaka, with Katsuhiro Goto set to become vice-president. Isaka will replace Kazuki Furuya as head of Seven-Eleven Japan. The board of directors will confirm the decision on April 19.

images.alt_text: Seven & i Holdings Co is a step closer to promoting Ryuichi Isaka, head of its Seven-Eleven Japan Co convenience store unit, to president of the holding company after activist investor Dan Loeb intervened to stop an attempt to oust him, a person familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Formula One: Alonso gets all-clear after horror crash
summary: Fernando Alonso has received the all-clear from medics to compete in the Chinese Grand Prix after recovering from a horrific crash at the season-opening race in March. He passed tests after Friday's first free practice in Shanghai and was deemed fit to participate in all remaining sessions. Alonso, who spent several nights in hospital, insisted he was pain-free and 100% after the crash. The FIA will only conduct further medical checks if he develops any abnormal symptoms. Alonso posted the 12th fastest time in morning practice, returning to McLaren after missing the Bahrain race with fractured ribs.

site_title: Ikea finalising its biggest overhaul in decades
summary: Ikea is undergoing its largest overhaul in over 30 years, aiming to adapt to changing consumer tastes, manage size, and avoid market disruption. The company is transferring ownership of some operating entities to Inter Ikea, a small Delft-based company that owns the Ikea brand. This change will allow Inter Ikea to control design, manufacturing, procurement, and logistics, while Ingka Holding will focus on managing stores. The move is driven by the need to innovate and compete with new market entrants, including Amazon. The restructuring aims to protect the Ikea concept and drive growth.

site_title: Hyundai, Kia to meet 2016's 1.5% sales growth goal despite Q1 drop: chairman
summary: Hyundai and Kia, South Korea's fifth-largest automakers, are on track to meet their 2016 sales growth target of 1.5% despite a 6% drop in Q1 sales to 1.81 million vehicles. The companies aim to sell 8.01 million vehicles this year, surpassing the global industry's projected 2.9% growth. The Q1 decline was attributed to weak sales in China and emerging markets.

site_title: Hope fades for Rousseff as Brazil court rejects impeachment halt
summary: Brazil's Supreme Court rejected President Dilma Rousseff's last-ditch attempt to halt an impeachment vote in Congress, further reducing her chances of survival. Rousseff's attorney general asked the court to suspend the vote due to procedural flaws, but the motion was dismissed 8-2. A new poll shows Rousseff short of crucial support from lawmakers, leaving her with dwindling options. The vote is set for Sunday, and Rousseff's fate remains uncertain.

site_title: Sesame Street's first Afghan Muppet empowers girls
summary: Sesame Street has introduced its first Afghan Muppet, Zari, who promotes girl power and empowerment in a country where girls still trail behind boys in education and literacy. Zari, a 6-year-old character, debuted on the local version of the show in April and aims to inspire young girls to exercise, pursue education, and use Islamic greetings. The character is a welcome move in a country where millions of girls were excluded from schools during the Taliban regime, and her introduction is seen as a step towards promoting gender equality.

site_title: FLASH: Singapore retail sales fall 3.2% on year in Feb
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 3.2% year-over-year in February, despite a 51.3% surge in motor sales. This marks a reversal from previous months, where retail sales had shown signs of improvement. The decline in retail sales is attributed to various factors, including a weak economic outlook and reduced consumer spending. The data highlights the challenges faced by the Singaporean economy, which is heavily reliant on consumer spending.

site_title: China Q1 growth slows but green shoots appearing
summary: China's economy expanded at 6.7% in Q1, the slowest rate in seven years, but beat forecasts and showed signs of stabilization. Industrial output rose 6.8% in March, exports surged 11.5%, and retail sales increased 10.5% year-on-year. The government's target for the year remains at 6.5-7.0%. While growth slowdown may be bottoming out, challenges persist, and policymakers must continue to rely on stimulus to hit ambitious growth targets.

images.alt_text: China's economy expanded at its slowest rate in seven years during the first quarter, the government said Friday, but forecast-beating readings for March raised hopes a growth slowdown in the Asian giant may be bottoming out.

site_title: Ferrari's luxury ambitions face reset as Prada hits the skids
summary: Ferrari's luxury ambitions are facing a setback after its stock price plummeted 20% since its October initial public offering. The company's new board must reset its strategy to balance its high-end cars, Formula 1 racing, and luxury product expansion without sufficient financial resources. Ferrari's identity crisis is evident, according to Adam Wyden, founder of ADW Capital Partners. The company's luxury aspirations have failed to gain traction, raising concerns about its long-term prospects.

site_title: G20 ministers face pressure on economic growth, tax evasion
summary: Finance ministers of the G20 nations face pressure to boost global growth and combat tax evasion during their spring meetings. The world economy is at risk of stalling, and ministers are urged to take action on job-creating investments and protectionist sentiment. An ambitious proposal from Europe's top five economies responds to the Panama Papers scandal, calling for increased transparency. The meetings come amid rising concerns over the UK's potential pullout from the EU and China's slowing GDP growth. Policymakers are under pressure to address these issues and drive economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Finance ministers of the world's top economies face pressure to do more for global growth and crack down on tax evasion when they gather Friday during the spring meetings of the IMF and World Bank.

site_title: Japan plants shut down after quake, fuels economic fears
summary: Japan's earthquake, with a 6.5-magnitude quake striking the southwestern island of Kyushu, has led to the shutdown of operations at major firms including Sony, Toyota, and Mitsubishi Electric. At least nine people were killed, and widespread damage has caused concerns about supply chain disruptions and economic impact. While the Nikkei stock index showed only slight losses, some companies' shares fell, and economists warn that the quake could push Japan's economy into recession due to weak growth momentum.

site_title: North Korea's failed missile launch prompts "sabre-rattling" jibe from Chinese state media
summary: North Korea attempted to launch an intermediate-range ballistic missile on Friday, but it failed, drawing criticism from China, a major ally. The failed launch comes after North Korea's fourth nuclear test in January and a long-range rocket launch in February, leading to new UN sanctions. China's state media called the launch "sabre-rattling" and an "embarrassing setback" for leader Kim Jong Un. The failed launch highlights North Korea's continued pursuit of its missile program despite international pressure.

site_title: Air traffic control officers charged over deadly Taiwan crash
summary: Taiwan has charged two air traffic control officers with causing a 2014 TransAsia plane crash that killed 49 people. The pilots were also found negligent in their duties, but will not face prosecution. Prosecutors claim the air traffic control officers failed to grant approval for the plane to land during a typhoon, contributing to the crash. The pilots were flying too low as they tried to land, and poor communication and coordination issues at the airport also contributed to the disaster. The officers could face up to five years in jail.

images.alt_text: Taiwan has charged two air traffic control officers with causing a TransAsia plane crash that killed 49 people in 2014, the first prosecutions in the country's worst air disaster for a decade.

site_title: Successful launches lead to jump in developer sales in March
summary: Successful condominium launches in Singapore in March led to a significant increase in developer sales. Developers sold 843 private homes, more than double the 303 units sold in February, with 682 units launched. Inclusive of executive condominiums, 1,328 units were sold, and 1,216 units launched. Some notable projects included Sim Lian's Wandervale EC, Northern Resi's The Wisteria, and CapitaLand's Cairnhill Nine, which saw high sales figures. The surge in sales is attributed to successful project launches in the traditionally slow month of March.

site_title: World's biggest steelmaker pushes output to record after rally
summary: China, the world's largest steel producer, reached a record 70.65 million metric tons of steel output in March, up 2.9% from the previous year. This follows a surge in steel prices since the start of 2016, with production for the first quarter falling 3.2% to 192 million tons. The steel rally is expected to end soon as Chinese mills increase output and traders restock. Rising steel output is a concern for the global steel industry, which is grappling with slowing demand in China.

site_title: Yen falls on speculation of BoJ intervention
summary: The yen fell against the dollar, heading for its biggest weekly fall in over two months, due to speculation that the Bank of Japan may expand its monetary easing program to boost the economy and drive up inflation. The yen has fallen 1.5% this week, its steepest slide since January, as investors expect the BoJ to cut its outlook for inflation and growth at an upcoming meeting. This could lead to a weaker yen, benefiting Japanese exporters. The dollar climbed to 109.63 yen, while the euro hovered around US$1.1261.

images.alt_text: The yen fell against the dollar on Friday, heading for its biggest weekly fall in over two months over expectations the Bank of Japan may soon expand its already massive monetary easing programme.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks add to rally in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.17% on Friday, adding 36.08 points to the Hang Seng Index, following a seven-straight gain. The Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.09%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.02%. Despite profit-taking, the rally continued, driven by investor optimism and reduced tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Hot stock: Cityneon volume spike prompts SGX query
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Cityneon Holdings after its shares surged 8.1% in early trading on Friday, with 8.1 million shares traded. The company's counter rose to 53.5 Singapore cents. The unusual volume movements led the SGX to issue a query, but no further information has been provided.

site_title: Microsoft, Apple dig in for long data-privacy fight with US
summary: Microsoft and Apple are engaging in a long-standing data-privacy battle with the US government. Microsoft sued the Justice Department to block the seizure of customers' data without notice, escalating a two-year dispute over privacy and cloud computing. Apple is set to continue its fight to keep government access to an iPhone seized from a Brooklyn drug dealer. The cases mark a significant escalation of the technology industry's fight for data protection, following the FBI's earlier attempt to force Apple to help break into an iPhone used by a San Bernardino terrorist.

site_title: Tencent said in talks for syndicated loan of up to US$2b
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd, Asia's largest internet company, is in talks with banks for a syndicated loan of up to $2 billion to fund its expansion and acquisitions. The five-year facility is separate from a $2.45 billion loan secured last year, and is part of a growing trend among Chinese internet giants seeking financing. Tencent's billionaire Chairman Ma Huateng is investing heavily in startups and e-commerce platforms, while companies like Baidu Inc are also seeking loans to fund their operations. The loan is expected to be finalized as early as next week, involving 5-6 banks.

site_title: Growth risks spur Bank Indonesia to adopt new key rate
summary: Bank Indonesia is adopting a new key rate policy to stimulate lending, following three interest-rate cuts this year that failed to boost economic growth. The central bank will use the seven-day reverse repo rate as its main policy instrument, currently at 5.5%. This move aims to counter falling exports and weaker commodity prices, despite a 75 basis point cumulative rate cut. The change is an attempt to address the economy's slow response to rate cuts, with lending rates not falling by the same magnitude as the rate cuts.

site_title: India's smog-choked capital imposes driving restrictions
summary: New Delhi, India's capital, has imposed driving restrictions for 15 days, aiming to improve air quality by taking around 1 million cars off the roads. The "odd-even" scheme restricts cars to alternate days, as it did in January, after high pollution levels. Despite initial concerns, many drivers are adhering to the rules, and traffic congestion has eased. However, scientists say the scheme is insufficient to tackle the city's severe pollution problem, and pollution levels remain "very unhealthy." The restrictions will be re-evaluated after a public holiday on Monday.

site_title: Singapore's Feb retail sales down 3.2% year on year despite 51.3% surge in motor sales
summary: Singapore's February retail sales decreased 3.2% year-over-year despite a 51.3% surge in motor sales. Excluding motor sales, retail sales fell 9.6% year-over-year, with only three categories experiencing year-over-year growth. Total sales improved 1.7% from January, driven by a 15% increase in motor sales.

site_title: Rescuers scramble for survivors after deadly quake hits Japan
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck southern Japan's Kyushu island, killing at least nine people and injuring hundreds. Tens of thousands fled their homes as buildings collapsed, factories stopped work, and a high-speed train was derailed. Dozens of aftershocks followed, and rescue workers searched through the night, finding an eight-month-old baby girl alive and unharmed. The government confirmed at least 860 injured, with 53 seriously, and warned of potential further damage from aftershocks and rain.

site_title: Asia: Shares drop after Japan quake as China data boosts Australian dollar
summary: Asian stocks declined for the first time in eight days after Japan's strongest earthquake in five years caused a retreat in Japanese stocks. The Australian dollar strengthened after China released economic data, with China's GDP increasing 6.7% in the first quarter. Oil rebounded from a 13-year low, and the International Energy Agency expects global crude markets to balance out. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index fell 0.4%, trimming its weekly gain to 4.2%.

site_title: High youth joblessness explains Korea ruling party setback
summary: South Korea's ruling party, the Saenuri party, suffered a setback in the recent election due to high youth joblessness, with the jobless rate for workers ages 15-29 remaining at 11.8% in March. The number of discouraged workers, those who have given up seeking jobs, also rose to 431,000. Analysts attribute this to poor job prospects and slower economic growth, with many young people taking temporary, low-income positions. This has led to frustration among voters, particularly among young people who feel they cannot enter bigger companies.

site_title: China may have US$1.3t of risky loans, IMF report shows
summary: China may have $1.3 trillion in loans to borrowers with insufficient income to cover interest payments, equivalent to 7% of its GDP, according to the IMF. This amount is 15.5% of total commercial lending, with potential losses equivalent to $756 billion. The IMF urges "prompt action" to address rising corporate sector vulnerabilities, particularly in sectors such as real estate and manufacturing. China's government is drawing up plans to address high corporate leverage and nonperforming loans, including debt-to-equity swaps and lowering bad-loan coverage ratios.

site_title: In China, Australian prime minister urges greater openness
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull urged China to continue opening up to the world during his visit, citing Deng Xiaoping's words that a closed China becomes weak. Turnbull met with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang to discuss concerns over internet freedoms and market access for foreign firms. China's economy, the world's second-largest, is trying to shift to a consumption-driven model as growth stalls, with a 6.7% growth rate in the first quarter. Turnbull also emphasized the importance of peaceful resolution of disputes in the South China Sea, where China claims most of the waters.

site_title: Kuroda breathes easier after yen pares this year's gain to 10%
summary: The yen's value has declined to 109.71 US dollars, paring its gain for the year to 9.6%, after Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated he has no plan to intervene in foreign-exchange markets. This move came after a gauge of the US dollar versus its major peers narrowed gains, boosted by Chinese industrial production beating analyst estimates. The yen's decline is seen as a result of expected policy measures from the BOJ, which could weaken the currency.

images.alt_text: The yen headed for its worst week since Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda announced a negative interest rate policy, falling from near levels that some analysts have said may spark market intervention and lead to additional policy easing.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares reach 3-wk high, NZ touches another record
summary: Australian shares reached a three-week high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 20.4 points to 5,139.0, driven by defensive healthcare stocks and a positive report from China on its annual growth rate. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also hit a record high, 0.2% higher at 6,839.25. Despite a pullback predicted by analysts, the Australian market is poised for its best week since early March, up over 4% so far.

site_title: Teamwork or torture? Japan's bone-breaking gym class
summary: In Japan, kumitaiso, a group gymnastics discipline, has been linked to over 8,000 medical treatments annually, with some cases resulting in brain damage, spinal injuries, and even death. The practice, which involves forming human pyramids and towers, has prompted parents and doctors to campaign for a ban, citing the risk of serious injury to children. Experts warn that the emphasis on teamwork and competition is putting pupils' welfare at risk, and some schools have resisted efforts to regulate the practice, despite a growing number of serious incidents.

site_title: Gold heads for weekly decline ahead of Chinese economic data
summary: Gold prices are expected to decline for the first time in three weeks ahead of Chinese economic data releases. The metal fell 0.2% to $1,225.54 an ounce in Singapore, with a weekly decline of 1.2% and a year-over-year gain of 16%. Investors await data on China's gross domestic product, retail sales, and factory output, which could indicate the economy is stabilizing. Analysts say the data is likely to support risk, with Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd stating that Q1 GDP and March data will show China is rebalancing.

site_title: No guarantee of oil deal at Doha talks
summary: Major oil producers from Opec are meeting in Doha to discuss an output freeze, aiming to drain crude oversupply and boost prices. However, doubts remain over Iran's participation, with Saudi Arabia insisting it will not freeze production unless Iran does so. Analysts predict a deal may be reached, potentially boosting prices, but some warn that a freeze agreement could have limited impact and oil prices could drop back to $30-33 a barrel if producers fail to strike a deal.

images.alt_text: Major oil producers meet this weekend to try to negotiate an output freeze to drain crude oversupply and boost prices, but doubts remain over whether Iran will join any accord.

site_title: Lyft is gaining on Uber as it spends big for growth
summary: Lyft is gaining on Uber as it spends heavily to fuel growth. The ride-sharing company has been running promotions such as handing out $50 vouchers and offering half-off fares to attract new customers. Lyft has also raised $1 billion in funding to support its spending spree, aiming to cap monthly losses at $50 million. The company's efforts are helping it steal market share from Uber, as Lyft continues to expand its presence in 20 major US cities.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says donation to Malaysian premier was genuine
summary: Saudi Arabia has confirmed a large donation to Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak was "genuine" and came without strings, according to Foreign Minister Adel Al-Jubeir. The donation was previously linked to 1Malaysia Development Bhd, a debt-ridden state fund chaired by Najib, amid probes into its finances. Najib faces his biggest political crisis since power, with questions over US$681 million in his accounts before the 2013 election. The Saudi comments come after Malaysia's Attorney General cleared Najib of wrongdoing over the funds in January. The matter is now considered closed by Saudi authorities.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near 10-mth peaks on upbeat China data
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose to multi-month peaks against the US dollar and sterling due to encouraging Chinese economic data. China's economy grew 6.7% in the first quarter, alleviating concerns about its strength. The Aussie dollar gained over 2 US cents this week, while the Kiwi dollar rose 0.3% to a 10-month high. The strong currency may prompt the Reserve Bank of Australia to reconsider cutting interest rates, and the New Zealand dollar's rise may be influenced by upcoming inflation data.

site_title: US defence secretary to visit carrier in disputed South China Sea
summary: US Defense Secretary Ash Carter is set to visit a US aircraft carrier in the disputed South China Sea, a move likely to anger China, which claims almost the entire sea. The visit follows similar actions in November and is part of a trip to highlight the US's expanding partnerships in the region. The US has conducted "freedom of navigation" patrols in the area to challenge China's maritime claims, drawing rebukes from Beijing. The visit caps off a week of US-Philippine military ties and joint patrols in the South China Sea, amid tensions over China's actions.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% up on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% higher on Friday as traders awaited Chinese economic data. The Straits Times Index rose 1.69 points to 2,915.62, with 62.9 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 62 to 43, following a 5-day rally.

site_title: Uber, Lyft hit Los Angeles taxi industry hard
summary: Uber and Lyft have significantly impacted the Los Angeles taxi industry, with taxi trips dropping 42% and total trips by a third since 2013. The ridesharing services, which enable independent drivers to use smartphone apps, have made it easier and cheaper for people to get around the city, causing licensed taxi drivers to struggle. The drivers accuse the ridesharing companies of disregarding laws, failing to provide adequate security, and undercutting their wages. Despite this, the number of licensed taxi drivers in Los Angeles has remained constant at around 2,400.

images.alt_text: Uber and Lyft are eviscerating the taxi industry in Los Angeles three years after they began operating in the city, officials say.

site_title: China economy stabilised in first quarter as stimulus took hold
summary: China's economy stabilized in the first quarter, with a 6.7% rise in gross domestic product, meeting economists' median projection and the government's growth target of 6.5-7%. The property sector rebounded, markets steadied, and loose monetary policy contributed to an improvement in factory conditions. Industrial output, fixed-asset investment, and retail sales also showed signs of improvement in March.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 0.740 points to 1722.460. The index saw a trading volume of 36.8 million lots worth RM9.31 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 68 to 60.

site_title: Indonesia has US$490m trade surplus in March
summary: Indonesia reported a US$490 million trade deficit in March, a decrease from the previous month's surplus of US$1.14 billion. Exports fell 13.51% to US$11.79 billion, while imports decreased 13.39% to US$12.29 billion. This marks the 18th consecutive month of declining trade. The trade surplus was lower than the median forecast of US$500 million.

site_title: Brazil sees rising threat from Islamic militants: intelligence agency
summary: Brazil's national intelligence agency has reported a rising threat from Islamic militants ahead of the August Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. The threat was fueled by attacks in other countries and a rise in Brazilian nationals suspected of sympathizing with Islamic State militants. A credible threat to state security was confirmed last year, and authorities have taken measures to avert a potential attack, including sharing information with foreign security forces and improved training. Security experts warn that the Olympics' large scale and global attention make it a prime target for terrorism.

site_title: Goldman embarking on biggest cost cuts in years
summary: Goldman Sachs is undertaking its largest cost-cutting effort in years, with plans to slash expenses by 29% to $4.76 billion, according to analysts. The firm, led by CEO Lloyd Blankfein, is cutting support staff, rejecting non-client-related expenses, and deferring projects to reduce costs. The move aims to weather a slump in trading and dealmaking, and analysts expect the company to report a steep drop in expenses for the first quarter. The cost cuts may not be enough to offset a 37% drop in revenue, and investors will be watching the quarterly results on April 19.

site_title: Clinton, Sanders trade blows in crunch Brooklyn debate
summary: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders clashed in a heated Democratic presidential debate in Brooklyn, with Clinton holding a 13.8-point lead in New York polls. The debate centered on Clinton's voting record, trade agreements, and gun control, with Sanders questioning her judgment on the 2003 Iraq war and Clinton accusing him of waging a "phony attack." Clinton seeks to capitalize on her momentum in the key New York primary, while Sanders aims to capitalize on his momentum and keep the nomination alive.

site_title: Consumers, brands scramble after China crackdown on cross-border shopping
summary: China's crackdown on cross-border online shopping has created commercial panic, with increased tariffs and stricter rules prompting local consumers to seek ways to skirt the restrictions. The new regulations, which restrict some products from being sold through overseas e-commerce platforms, have led to sharp share price gyrations and the removal of products from shelves. The measures threaten to put the brakes on China's fast-growing cross-border e-commerce market, which had lured domestic shoppers with lower tax rates and less red tape.

site_title: French youths learn to resist jihadi 'sellers of dreams'
summary: In France, youths in poor immigrant neighborhoods are being targeted by jihadi recruiters, who promise a sense of purpose and belonging. Many have joined the Islamic State, with over 2,000 French citizens involved in jihadist cells. Recruiters use social media and online games to contact potential recruits, often posing as friends or brothers. Experts say the appeal of jihad lies in the promise of wealth, heroism, and self-affirmation, rather than religious fervor. To counter this, schools are being encouraged to provide alternative activities and safeguards to protect students from online recruitment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slump in opening trade
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 1.13% in opening trade on Friday, ending a three-session winning streak, following a weak lead from Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index dropped to 16,720.39, and the Topix index eased to 1,353.48. The decline came after a strong rally in previous sessions, with investors seemingly brushing off recent US President Trump's threats to extend the stock market rally.

site_title: BP investors say "no" to CEO Dudley's US$20m pay deal
summary: BP's shareholders have voted 59% against CEO Bob Dudley's $20 million pay deal for 2015, a rare investor revolt for the major company. The decision comes after BP recorded a record annual loss due to plunging oil prices. The vote is non-binding, but executives said they would consider making changes to the way remuneration is calculated. The review will assess how the remuneration committee deals with oil price fluctuations and engage with major shareholders.

site_title: US government worse than all major industries on cyber security: report
summary: The US government ranks last in cyber security among 17 major industries, according to a report by SecurityScorecard. The analysis found government agencies struggled with vulnerabilities to malware, social engineering, and password exposure. The report tracked 35 major data breaches across government from 2015 to 2016. Despite President Obama's efforts to improve cyber defenses, federal agencies scored poorly on network security and software patching. Some government organizations, like NASA, performed the worst, while others, such as Clark County, Nevada, had strong security postures.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up; TSMC falls on outlook, Q1 results
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.2% to 8,688.91, despite TSMC's 2% decline due to trimmed smartphone market outlook and below-expectation Q1 net profit. The electronics subindex fell 0.2%, while the financials subindex gained 0.6%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.360 per US dollar. This marks the third consecutive session of gains and the first weekly rise in four.

site_title: Putin blasts Panama Papers 'provocation', soothes crisis-hit Russians
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin dismissed media reports linking him to a US-backed "provocation" over billions in offshore accounts as a "manipulation" designed to discredit Russian politicians. He assured ordinary Russians that the country's economic crisis will ease next year, while fielding questions about economic issues and promising to resolve issues affecting citizens. Putin also avoided discussing his personal life, saying he might reveal any romantic relationships in the future, and maintained a cautious tone on foreign policy, emphasizing a peaceful resolution to the Syria conflict and good ties with Turkey and Ukraine.

site_title: China's economy stabilises as property stages a comeback
summary: China's economy stabilized in the first quarter with a 6.7% GDP growth, meeting the government's 6.5-7% target. A surge in new credit helped the property sector rebound, with new credit, industrial output, fixed-asset investment, and retail sales all beating forecasts. The stabilization is seen as a positive sign for the economy, which had been raising concerns over debt-fueled expansion. The improvement in China's economy has also boosted global markets, including oil, metals, and equities.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Reit, Keppel T&T, Soilbuild Reit
summary: Keppel Reit, Keppel T&T, and Soilbuild Reit announced their first-quarter results, with Keppel Reit's DPU decreasing 1.2% to 6.8% annualized yield, Keppel T&T's net profit falling 15.6% to S$13.31 million, and Soilbuild Reit's DPU dipping 4.7% to 1.557 Singapore cents while distributable income rose 9.6%.

site_title: With plenty of punch, central bankers wait in vain for the world to drink
summary: Central bankers are facing a challenge in stimulating global demand as households, corporations, and banks in developed nations have become cautious about borrowing. Despite a flood of cheap money and negative interest rates, credit growth has flat-lined, and metrics indicate a more cautious world. Policymakers are focused on how to inflate demand, with the IMF suggesting government spending on infrastructure and labor market reforms. However, central bankers agree that further policy moves may have limited impact, and the economic outlook is likely to remain mediocre.

site_title: Ezra and Emas Offshore to sell vessel
summary: Ezra Holdings and an Emas Offshore unit plan to divest their combined 78.4% stake in PV Keez, a special purpose vehicle that owns the Lewek Emas vessel, to a global infrastructure investment firm. The vessel is chartered to Premier Oil Vietnam Offshore, operating the Chim Sao field offshore southern Vietnam. The proposed sale sum was not disclosed.

site_title: Fed's Lockhart sets high bar for possible June rate hike
summary: US Federal Reserve President Dennis Lockhart expressed skepticism about a June rate hike, citing slower-than-expected economic growth and inflation not yet firmly in place. Lockhart stated that to support a rate hike, economic growth would need to rebound to a 2% annual rate and inflation would need to show clear signs of firming. He also emphasized the need for continued monthly job gains of 200,000. Lockhart's comments underscore concerns about the US recovery in the face of global weakness, and suggest that the Fed may not raise rates until later this year.

site_title: CapitaGreen and Raffles City lift CCT Q1 distributable income
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 3.3% increase in distributable income to S$64.85 million for Q1 2016, driven by higher income from its interests in CapitaGreen and Raffles City Singapore. This offset a 3.6% decline in net property income and a 1.9% drop in gross revenue. The distributable income per unit rose 3.3% to 2.19 Singapore cents, surpassing the previous year's DPU of 2.12 cents.

site_title: Brazil govt sees fourth straight fiscal deficit in 2017: source
summary: Brazil's government is considering a 60 billion reais deduction from its 2017 key fiscal savings goal, which could lead to a fourth consecutive annual deficit. The move is part of President Dilma Rousseff's administration's efforts to address a widening fiscal gap. The government has already expected a deficit for 2016 due to plummeting tax revenues, and this deduction would further erode its primary budget goal of zero percent of gross domestic product for 2017.

site_title: Canada moves to legalise doctor-assisted suicide
summary: Canada's Liberal government has introduced a bill to legalize doctor-assisted suicide, following a Supreme Court ruling that struck down a prohibition on the practice. The proposed law would allow consenting adults with serious health problems to end their suffering, but critics say it falls short in protecting vulnerable groups. Despite 85% public support, the bill's passage remains uncertain, with the government facing opposition and calls for further safeguards.

site_title: Funan revamp to create integrated development the size of Ion Orchard
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust announced a revamp of its Funan DigitaLife Mall, set to close on July 1 for a three-year redevelopment. The mall's size will increase to 870,000 sq ft, roughly the size of Ion Orchard, with the addition of 388,000 sq ft. The project aims to create an integrated development.

site_title: Fed income US$105b last year, to drop off less dramatically
summary: The Federal Reserve earned a net income of US$105 billion last year, slightly less than expected, and expects income to decline by a less dramatic amount in the coming years. The Fed's portfolio of Treasury and mortgage bonds has grown to US$4.3 trillion, earning interest and topping up maturing assets. Projections indicate a cumulative net profit of US$610 billion over the next decade, with annual net income expected to reach US$50 billion by 2019. This more optimistic outlook could provide the Fed with political cover as it faces criticism for its policies.

images.alt_text: Profits on the Federal Reserve's vast stable of bonds dipped only slightly last year, to a net US$105 billion, and the Fed now expects income to fall off less dramatically in coming years in what could give it some political cover.

site_title: Oil inches up after mixed IEA report ahead of Doha meeting
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Thursday, with Brent crude futures increasing 17 US cents to US$44.35 a barrel. US crude rose 15 US cents to US$41.91. The International Energy Agency (IEA) reported a trimmed estimate of 2016 global demand growth, but a US production decline was anticipated. A meeting of major oil producers in Doha, Qatar, is set to finalize a deal to freeze oil output at January levels, but analysts expect little impact on physical oil supplies. Oil prices found support after US economic data pushed the US dollar to session lows.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose slightly on Thursday in choppy trade as the market processed a mixed report from the International Energy Agency (IEA) and skepticism that an upcoming meeting of major producers would do much to tighten the supply demand balance.

site_title: Seoul: Won bounces after sharp decline; stocks nearly flat
summary: The South Korean won strengthened 0.6% against the US dollar on Friday, rebounding from a sharp decline sparked by Singapore's central bank surprise easing. The won stood at 1,149.5 to the dollar, with analysts expecting subtle changes in the day's trading. The decline was attributed to Singapore's central bank easing, which was seen as a positive sign for the region's economy.

site_title: Thousands march for US$15 hourly wages across United States
summary: Thousands of low-wage workers in the US marched across cities, calling for a national minimum wage of $15 per hour. The "Fight for $15" campaign, which began in 2012, has gained momentum with recent legislative victories in California and New York. Demonstrators, including those at McDonald's restaurants, expressed frustration over stagnant earnings and rising living expenses. Supporters argue that higher wages are necessary to help low-paid workers escape poverty. The movement combines a push for wage increases and unionization, with supporters saying they will continue to fight for their demands.

site_title: North Korea's attempted missile launch failed: Seoul army
summary: North Korea attempted to launch a missile on Friday to mark the birthday of its founding president, Kim Il Sung, but it appears to have failed, according to South Korea's joint chiefs of staff. The failed launch occurred near the east coast, and South Korean media had reported that Pyongyang was preparing the test. The incident comes amid celebrations for Kim Il Sung's birthday, which falls on April 15. The failed launch does not appear to have caused any casualties or significant damage.

site_title: Bankers steer clear of Tata Steel's UK sale
summary: Tata Steel's UK sale, including its flagship Port Talbot plant, is proving unattractive to major investment banks, with only two out of 10 major banks expressing interest in advising potential buyers. The business is considered a distressed sale, with a loss-making nature and complex negotiations, making fees likely to be small. The UK government's potential involvement in the sale and the need for a role for the government in helping any deal could also squeeze fees.

site_title: Saudi, India discuss oil market situation, boost cooperation
summary: Saudi Arabia's Deputy Oil Minister Prince Abdulaziz Bin Salman discussed oil market stability and cooperation with India's Oil Minister Dharmendra Pradhan. The talks included boosting India's crude oil purchases and joint investments. The two officials also explored energy cooperation between the two countries. The Saudi state news agency reported that the kingdom plays an "evident role in achieving stability of the oil markets."

site_title: Linc Energy goes into voluntary administration
summary: Linc Energy, a suspended mainboard-listed company, has entered into voluntary administration. Its directors appointed PPB Advisory administrators, effective April 15, to explore options, including restructuring. The company's business includes oil and gas operations in the US and exploration in South Australia. The administrators will work with the management team to understand available options.

site_title: China Q1 GDP growth could be weakest since financial crisis
summary: China's economy may have grown at its slowest pace since the global financial crisis in the first quarter of 2016, with a potential GDP growth rate of 6.7% down from 6.8% in the previous quarter. This would be the weakest pace of expansion since 2009. Despite some economic green shoots, analysts expect the central bank to keep monetary policy accommodative to hit growth targets and support heavily indebted firms. Rising consumer price rises and diverging global interest rates remain key policy challenges.

site_title: Who you gonna call? Hong Kong braces for first competition probe
summary: Hong Kong's Competition Commission is set to begin its first probes into anti-competitive activities, following the city's first competition law coming into effect in December. Over 750 complaints have been received, with business groups waiting to see if the commission has "teeth." The commission has already highlighted 12 trade associations for reviewing their business practices, and is expected to target companies with unfair market power. The commission's first case is expected to be a strong one, with lawyers advising clients to prepare for investigations and potential fines.

site_title: US firms stash US$1.4t in offshore tax havens: Oxfam
summary: US corporations, including Apple and General Electric, have stashed nearly $1.4 trillion in offshore tax havens between 2008 and 2014, denying governments needed tax income. The 50 top US companies used over 1,600 subsidiaries to store and move funds outside fiscal authorities. Oxfam America says these companies are dodging billions in taxes while benefiting from government support. The report coincides with the Panama Papers scandal, highlighting the issue of tax evasion and its impact on global poverty.

site_title: Delta vows to cut seating capacity if needed to boost fares
summary: Delta Air Lines plans to cut seating capacity if it can't boost fares, aiming to reverse five straight quarters of falling unit revenue. The airline expects unit revenue to drop 2.5-4.5% in the second quarter but expects it to rise later this year. Delta's first-quarter profit exceeded analysts' estimates, and the company plans to expand its Basic Economy fare to more markets. The airline also plans to upgrade its fleet, potentially replacing its old MD-88 jets with new planes.

images.alt_text: Delta Air Lines Inc will cut seating capacity if it can't make speedy progress in turning around flagging fares.

site_title: Japan, US agree to honor G7, G20 forex commitments
summary: Japan and the US have agreed to honor their commitments to manage exchange rates within the G7 and G20 frameworks, following a meeting in Washington. This comes after the G20 finance leaders in Shanghai agreed to refrain from competitive currency devaluations. However, the two sides also acknowledged that excess volatility and disorderly currency moves are undesirable. Japan has maintained its right to intervene in the currency market if necessary, while the US Treasury will continue to push for market-driven exchange rates during this week's G20 meetings.

site_title: First case of Zika infection after sex between gay men: US
summary: US health authorities reported the first case of Zika infection transmitted through sex between gay men, involving a man who traveled to Venezuela and infected his partner in Texas. The couple, who had been monogamous for over 10 years, experienced symptoms but no lasting complications. This finding suggests an emerging mode of Zika virus infection, contributing to more illness than initially anticipated. The CDC also confirmed that Zika can cause birth defects, making it the first mosquito-borne virus to do so.

site_title: China deputy central banker says does not want big yuan overshoot
summary: China's deputy central banker, Yi Gang, stated that the country does not want a "severe" yuan overshoot, as the economy is expected to grow between 6.5 and 7.0 percent this year. Yi expressed confidence in the economy's robustness based on first-quarter data, and emphasized that the central bank will strike a balance between pursuing its policy and allowing the market to trade the currency. This comes as the IMF estimates that a slowdown in China's GDP could cut global growth by 0.25 percentage points.

site_title: Deep in red ink, Ezra books impairments and write-offs in Q2
summary: Ezra Holdings reported a net loss of US$249.93 million in Q2, down from a net profit of US$138,000 a year ago. Revenue fell 14% to US$111.15 million, mainly due to weakness in its offshore support and production services division. The company booked impairment losses of US$60.5 million and US$38.3 million, as well as write-offs of bad debts and doubtful debts. Loss per share was 10.38 US cents, and net asset value decreased to 35.53 US cents.

site_title: Are 'chatbots' the future of online business?
summary: Chatbots, AI-powered conversational interfaces, are expected to revolutionize online business, allowing users to interact with companies through simple text messages, bypassing apps and search engines. Brands like Taco Bell, Facebook, and Microsoft are investing in chatbots, with the potential to transform the digital landscape. While some analysts remain skeptical, others see chatbots as a natural extension of how consumers interact with technology, offering a more seamless experience.

site_title: Oil, low interest rates weigh on BofA, Wells Fargo
summary: Big banks Bank of America and Wells Fargo reported lower earnings due to the impact of the oil bust and low interest rates. Both banks increased their reserves for bad oil loans, with Bank of America boosting its reserves by $525 million to $1 billion. Despite this, Bank of America's shares rose 2.7% after the report, while Wells Fargo's shares dipped 0.2%. Executives from both banks downplayed concerns of a US recession, citing a resilient US economy and broad increases in lending.

site_title: BOJ warming to idea of buying more stocks funds: sources
summary: Bank of Japan officials are considering increasing their exchange-traded fund (ETF) purchases to boost the stock market, amid a weak global growth and economic recovery. The BOJ is currently buying 3.3 trillion yen ($40.88 billion) in ETFs annually, but this is a fraction of the 80 trillion yen in government bonds it buys. Policymakers are wary of intervening too heavily in the stock market, but seek to address diminishing returns from interest rate cuts and negative interest rates.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge ahead, led by Nestle and Ferrovial
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, led by Nestle's 2% gain after an encouraging earnings update and Ferrovial's 3.8% rise after a broker's upgrade. The FTSEurofirst 300 index remains down 6% since the start of 2016 due to concerns about a China-led economic slowdown. Oil prices rose slightly after the International Energy Agency reported a decline in US oil output, helping shares in oil companies like Total and Royal Dutch Shell.

site_title: Microsoft sues US over secret warrants to search email
summary: Microsoft has sued the US government, arguing that secret warrants to search people's email violate constitutional rights of Americans. The company claims that a requirement to keep silent on warrants for data erodes trust in US technology companies and tramples on citizens' and businesses' rights. The lawsuit, filed in federal court in Seattle, seeks to address the situation and argues that the government must give notice when it searches and seizes private information or communications.

site_title: US: Stocks drift mostly higher
summary: US stocks rose mostly higher on Thursday, driven by gains in financials, including Bank of America and Wells Fargo, which reported lower profits. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 18.15 points, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.36 points. JPMorgan Chase led the Dow higher, and Delta Air Lines' strong earnings report also contributed to the gains. However, the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.53 points due to a decline in tech stocks.

site_title: Top European countries call to end shell company secrecy
summary: European top economies, including Britain, France, Germany, Italy, and Spain, have called for an end to shell company secrecy, urging the G-20 to crack down on tax havens that enable tax evasion and money laundering. The proposal includes a blacklist of countries that don't share corporate registry data and the establishment of transnational registries to identify beneficial owners of companies. The move follows the leak of thousands of documents on anonymously-owned shell companies, including those linked to prominent politicians and business leaders.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff mounts late bid to block impeachment
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff has launched a late bid to block her impeachment, seeking a court injunction to halt the proceedings after key allies deserted her. The impeachment vote is set for Sunday, and Rousseff's government alleges procedural failings in the case against her, including the inclusion of unrelated evidence. If impeached, Rousseff would be suspended from office for six months, and Vice President Michel Temer would take over. Rousseff has vowed to fight until the last minute, despite her coalition's defections and the country's deepening economic crisis.

site_title: Passengers profiled at Paris airport since Brussels attacks: official
summary: Profilers have been operating at Paris's Charles de Gaulle airport since the Brussels airport attacks, watching for "abnormal behavior." A facial recognition system will be tested, allowing for immediate identification and automatic alerts to police. The airport plans to double the number of automatic security checks and increase security cameras in high-risk areas. These measures aim to prevent similar attacks, which claimed 32 lives at Brussels airport and 130 at Paris airport in November, both attributed to the Islamic State group.

site_title: China gives nod to foreign central banks to remit funds
summary: China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) has allowed foreign central banks to remit funds without regulatory approval in the domestic interbank market, a step to open up its debt markets. This move aims to attract foreign capital into its domestic bond market, boosting domestic liquidity and restoring confidence in the yuan. The rules apply to central banks and similar institutions, but lack of clarity on taxation and concerns about foreign investors may limit flows.

site_title: Dollar mostly flat after cool US inflation data
summary: The US dollar remained steady against most major currencies after the release of weak US inflation data, suggesting the Federal Reserve has more flexibility to maintain low interest rates. US consumer prices rose 0.1% in March, with core prices slowing to a 0.1% increase, indicating the Fed may hold rates steady.

images.alt_text: The US dollar changed little against most other major currencies Thursday as weak US inflation data suggested the Federal Reserve has more leeway to hold interest rates at ultra-low levels.

site_title: Strong quake in southwestern Japan kills nine, topples homes
summary: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck southwestern Japan, killing nine people and injuring hundreds. The quake toppled homes, sparked fires, and damaged infrastructure, with at least 780 injured. Rescuers worked through the night to find residents trapped in rubble, and an eight-month-old baby girl was pulled alive from the rubble. Japan's nuclear reactors were functioning normally, but the country remains on edge due to its seismic activity, particularly after the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster.

site_title: IMF 'won't walk away' from Greece: Lagarde
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) will not abandon Greece as it struggles with the EU over its bailout program, according to IMF chief Christine Lagarde. Despite disagreements over economic reforms and debt relief, Lagarde urged quick movement on both issues to avoid delay. The IMF will work with the EU to achieve economic stability and sustainability, but will not participate in the latest plan without credible reforms and an EU agreement to ease Greece's debt burden.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund will not abandon Greece as it struggles with the EU over its bailout programme, fund chief Christine Lagarde said Thursday.

site_title: China's big four banks, StanChart, ANZ to join yuan gold benchmark
summary: China's big four banks, alongside Standard Chartered and ANZ, will join a new yuan-denominated gold benchmark, set to launch on April 19. The Shanghai Gold Exchange will act as the central counterparty, with the price-setting process derived from a one kg-contract traded by 18 members. The move aims to give China more power in setting the price of gold, with the yuan gold fix expected to pose a long-term threat to the dominance of London and New York.

site_title: IMF, World Bank focus on economic risks of Brexit, tax evasion
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank emphasized the global economy's risks, including Brexit, tax evasion, and climate change, during their Spring Meetings. The IMF lowered its growth forecast for 2016 to 3.2% and warned of a potential recession if debt levels and low growth continue. The organizations called for developed countries to take immediate action to stimulate growth, with World Bank President Jim Yong Kim suggesting a $25 billion loan for middle-income countries. They also highlighted the need to address tax evasion and public debt in advanced economies.

site_title: Obama in fence-mending trip to see Saudi king
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to visit Saudi Arabia, his fourth trip to the kingdom, in an effort to mend strained ties between the US and Saudi Arabia. The visit comes after Obama's administration has made efforts to improve relations, including meetings with Saudi officials on regional security issues. Despite tensions, the two countries cooperate in the fight against the Islamic State group. Obama's visit is seen as a step towards deeper cooperation, with senior adviser Rob Malley citing progress in stabilizing conflicts in Libya and Yemen.

site_title: New York suburb, officials charged in landmark bond fraud case
summary: US authorities charged Christopher St Lawrence, a top official of Ramapo, New York, with securities fraud, wire fraud, and conspiracy in a landmark bond fraud case. The indictment also named N Aaron Troodler, a former executive director of the Ramapo Local Development Corp. The case, which began with a whistleblower complaint, alleges that the defendants concealed Ramapo's deteriorating finances to secure funding for a minor league baseball stadium. Authorities claim bond investors lost millions due to the defendants' actions, and a federal court case seeks to restrict Ramapo and the RLDC from issuing bonds for five years.

images.alt_text: A top official of a New York City suburb was charged on Thursday with defrauding investors who helped finance a controversial minor league baseball stadium, in what authorities called the first criminal securities fraud prosecution involving municipal bonds.

site_title: Obama to head to London to warn against Brexit
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to visit London on April 21 to urge Britain not to leave the European Union ahead of the June 23 referendum. The visit aims to express the US's support for Britain's EU membership and warn of potential economic consequences. Obama will meet with British officials, including Prime Minister David Cameron, and stage a joint news conference. His visit coincides with Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday and comes as opinion polls suggest the referendum will be a close one.

site_title: China takes aim at steel, coal gluts with curbs on land use
summary: China has implemented curbs on land use for steel and coal projects to reduce excess capacity and tackle structural economic problems. Applications for new coal mining projects will not be approved for the next three years, and restrictions on land use will also apply to steel projects. China's crude steel production capacity is expected to drop from 1.2 billion tonnes to 781 million tonnes this year, while coal output is estimated to reach 3.7 billion tonnes. The move aims to eliminate overcapacity in heavy industries and promote sustainable growth.

site_title: The global economy is in a fragile state
summary: The global economy is in a fragile state due to slowing economic growth, technological disruption, and social/geopolitical instability. Central banks' adoption of negative interest rates is punishing savers and creating risk, particularly in the US and China. Markets are also affected by the shift in energy costs, declining corporate earnings, and electoral uncertainty. The prolonged period of low interest rates and negative rates is reducing consumer spending and affecting retirement savings, posing significant economic risks.

site_title: Singapore's NRA Capital emerges as valuer of 1MDB's Cayman investments
summary: Singapore's boutique finance house NRA Capital was hired by 1Malaysia Development Berhad to value the firm's $2.318 billion Cayman Islands investment. The valuation was part of a larger controversy surrounding 1MDB's investments, including a $1 billion joint-venture with PetroSaudi International that flopped. Deloitte, the auditor of 1MDB, disclosed that NRA Capital met with the fund manager to understand its methodology and competence in valuing the Cayman-Islands registered Bridge Absolute Return Fund. The investment was valued at over RM13 billion, one of two "level three assets" deemed illiquid by 1MDB.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Aussie jobless rate falls to 5.7% in March, a 2 1/2 year low
summary: Australia's jobless rate fell to 5.7% in March, its lowest level in two-and-a-half years, as business confidence lifted. This signals that the central bank is unlikely to ease policy soon. The Australian dollar surged after the data release, with the economy growing 3% in the final quarter of last year. Despite a weaker resource boom, the labour market remains positive, and accommodative monetary and fiscal policy settings have boosted interest-sensitive areas of the economy.

site_title: Norway's US$860b fund drops 52 companies linked to coal
summary: Norway's $860 billion sovereign wealth fund has excluded 52 companies linked to coal from its portfolio due to a ban on coal investments. The excluded companies include major power producers and miners such as American Electric Power Co Inc and China Shenhua Energy Co Ltd, based on new criteria that require at least 30% of activities or revenues to be coal-related. This move is part of Norway's efforts to reduce its carbon footprint and transition away from coal investments.

site_title: MAS stuns market by flattening Singapore dollar policy band
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) unexpectedly flattened the Singapore dollar policy band to a neutral stance of zero percent appreciation, marking the first time this was done without recessionary conditions. The move was seen as a surprise, with economists calling it "a new paradigm." The decision was made to temper core inflation forecasts, which are now expected to rise at a milder pace, and to adjust the growth outlook to align with recent forecasts. The Singapore dollar slid 0.93% against the US dollar following the announcement.

site_title: China's stifling laws depriving its people of common vaccines
summary: China's strict regulations are hindering access to common vaccines, affecting 1.4 billion people. Pharmaceutical companies face challenges in bringing vaccines to market due to lengthy registration timelines. The lack of approved vaccines for conditions like pneumonia and HPV has led to patients traveling abroad, such as to Hong Kong, to receive essential vaccinations. A recent scandal involving the sale of improperly stored vaccines has further eroded public trust in China's vaccine system, with Pfizer's pneumococcal vaccine being one of the most affected.

site_title: Magnitude 6 earthquake hits Japan, nuclear plants safe
summary: A magnitude 6 earthquake struck southern Japan on Thursday, causing dozens of injuries and some building collapses. The quake, initially reported as 6.2, was later revised to 6.4. There was no tsunami warning, and the nuclear regulator reported no issues at power plants. At least 40 people were treated at a hospital, and a fire broke out in a town near the epicentre. Some 16,000 households were without electricity, and 38,000 homes had no gas supplies. An aftershock also struck the region, but no irregularities were found at nuclear plants.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Q&M Dental Group plans to spin off its manufacturing business, Aidite, to enhance shareholder value by listing it on China's emerging over-the-counter market. Aidite will remain an associated company with Q&M. The company also plans to spin off its healthcare services business in Shenyang. Q&M's financial forecast earnings have been revised downward due to a challenging business environment. Keppel Infrastructure Trust is recommended to buy with a target price of S$0.56, while Q&M Dental Group is downgraded to neutral with a lower target price of S$0.70.

site_title: Having a ball at Icon's 11th anniversary bash
summary: Icon, a Chinese luxury magazine, celebrated its 11th anniversary with an exclusive ball at the Shangri-La Hotel. Over 300 socialites and businessmen attended the event, featuring a "Wonder and Whimsy" theme and a curated list of influential women, including Chinese actress Sun Li. The magazine crowned 20 women as Best Dressed 2016 and partnered with several brands for the event. Editor Elsie Yah expressed pride in the magazine's impact on multiple platforms and engagement with readers. The event was documented by socialite Rosalynn Tay, providing a unique perspective on the celebration.

site_title: AA Reit awards redevelopment of Tuas property to Boustead
summary: AA Reit has awarded the redevelopment of an industrial property at 8 and 10 Tuas Avenue 20 to Boustead Projects for approximately S$27 million, with the project expected to be completed by Q3 2017. The redevelopment will increase the property's gross floor area by 35% and improve the plot ratio, making it suitable for production and warehouse usage. Boustead Projects' order book backlog has expanded to S$258 million following the contract win.

site_title: SIA seen gaining from weaker Singdollar
summary: Singapore Airlines is expected to benefit from the weaker Singapore dollar, which is expected to boost visitor arrivals and lift yields and loads. A weaker dollar should also bolster airline's revenue, with Morgan Stanley analysts estimating a 0.5% increase in top line for SIA. However, the depreciation of the Singdollar against the greenback will also lead to cost pressures, with a 0.53% rise in operating costs. Despite this, SIA shares closed at S$11.46, up six cents, with Morgan Stanley citing the airline as their top pick of the sector and a price target of S$14.25.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Enlarged unit base sees Keppel Reit trimming Q1 DPU by 1.2 per cent
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 1.2% drop in first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.68 Singapore cents due to an enlarged unit base. Despite a 0.8% rise in income available for distribution, net property income slipped 4.8% to S$32.9 million, mainly due to the absence of contribution from a divested property. The Reit manager expects to renew most of the expiring leases in 2017 and 2018, with average positive rent reversion of 7% in the first quarter.

site_title: Foreign inflows making NZ stocks pricey
summary: Foreign investors are driving up stock prices in New Zealand, with the S&P/NZX 50 Index rising 7% this year, the best performance among developed markets. Overseas buying has led to record-high valuations, with the index trading at 19.4 times estimated earnings, more than double the global average. Foreigners now own about one-third of the market, attracted by high dividend yields and expectations of interest rate cuts. However, some investors are warning of overvaluation and potential price corrections, with market expert Chris Green stating that the market is "vulnerable" to a decline.

site_title: Indian tales, universal themes
summary: Two Indian plays, Ek Mulaqaat and The Siddhus of Upper Juhu, will be performed in Singapore in the coming weeks. Ek Mulaqaat is a love story about poets Sahir Ludhianvi and Amrita Pritam, while The Siddhus of Upper Juhu explores economic meltdown and urban angst in Mumbai. The plays, directed by Saif Hyder Hasan and Sreyashi Sen, respectively, will feature renowned Indian actors and focus on universal themes. They mark a shift towards more diverse and realistic content in Singapore's theatre scene, with Darpan Theatre co-presenting the events and aiming to fill a gap in showcasing quality Indian art productions.

images.alt_text: Naval (left) and Suman are the lead actors in Ek Mulaqaat, which tells the real-life love story of eminent poets Amrita Pritam and Sahir Ludhianvi.
The two lead roles in The Siddhus of Upper Juhu are played by Patel (left) and Kapur. It is a contemporary play about a Mumbai family.

site_title: Software flaws used in hacking more than doubled in 2015: report
summary: A new report by Symantec Corp. reveals that the number of previously unknown software flaws used by hackers more than doubled in 2015, reaching 54 vulnerabilities. This increase in zero-day exploits, which are unknown to software vendors and users, poses a significant threat to online security. The majority of these flaws were found in Adobe Systems Inc's Flash software, and experts warn that the rapid spread of new flaws through underground forums is making it easier for hackers to obtain and exploit them.

site_title: Foreign beer brands threatening South Korea brewers on price
summary: South Korean beer drinkers are increasingly opting for foreign brands due to their more robust flavors and attractive discounts, leading to a surge in imports that has seen local brewers' market share decline from 99% in 2012 to 82% in the first half of last year. The two main local brewers, Anheuser-Busch InBev SA's Oriental Brewery and Hite Jinro, are seeking government help to compete with foreign brands, which have more flexibility in pricing and can offer discounts below factory prices. The government's Fair Trade Commission is reviewing competition in the beer industry, which analysts view as a potential solution for local brewers.

site_title: New scheme to encourage corporate giving
summary: Singapore's National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) and the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) are launching the "Company of Good" initiative to encourage corporate giving. The program, set to launch in June, will provide tailored support and resources to businesses, including training and access to networks. Companies can earn a "Company of Good" logo and recognition as champions. Senior Minister of State Sim Ann emphasized the importance of businesses being civic-minded and playing active roles in their communities, aiming to train 200 companies in two years.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: A family wine business called Gaja
summary: Italian winemaker Angelo Gaja emphasizes the importance of both making and selling high-quality wine. He attributes the success of his family's wine business, Gaja, to its ability to be featured in restaurants and wine lists. Gaja, a trained oenologist with a degree in economics, credits his marketing savvy and business acumen for the family's international success. He plans to step back and let his children, Gaia and Rosanna, take over the business, allowing them to pursue their own paths while maintaining the family's legacy.

images.alt_text: Christopher Lim

site_title: Perennial turns to court amid rift with Pontiac over Capitol Singapore
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings Ltd is seeking court action to wind up three associated companies, Capitol Investment Holdings, Capitol Retail Management, and Capitol Hotel Management, due to a deadlock with co-owner Pontiac Land over key issues related to the Capitol Singapore project. The development, which includes a luxury hotel, high-end retail shops, and residential units, has received temporary occupancy permits. Perennial is considering selling its stake to Pontiac or a third party, with an analyst suggesting this option may be most favorable for the company.

images.alt_text: The Capitol Singapore project includes a luxury hotel, mostly high-end retail shops, residential units, and the refurbished landmark Capitol Theatre.

site_title: Rediscovering the real thing
summary: Record Store Day returns, encouraging music lovers to support brick-and-mortar stores over online purchases. Three unique record stores, Past Image, Surface Noise, and Ravage Records, offer unusual offerings in unexpected locations. Past Image, a vintage collectibles store, features a 40% vinyl selection with 70% Mandarin records, while Surface Noise, an underground alternative music store, offers a diverse mix of local and regional indie titles. Ravage Records, an extreme metal music shop, doubles as a museum with a vast collection of music and paraphernalia, attracting both local fans and international visitors.

images.alt_text: Local music fans can check out shops like Surface Noise (above), Ravage Records and Past Image on Record Store Day to give themselves an aural treat.
Although the vast assortment of memorabilia in Past Image spans the entire shop, vintage records make up about 40 per cent of the sales.
Of special interest is Surface Noise's strong selection of local and regional indie titles on vinyl, CD and even cassette tape.
In addition to the CDs, vinyls, tapes, T-shirts and accessories on sale, Ravage Records also doubles as a museum of the owner's impressive personal collection of music and related paraphernalia.

site_title: NY commercial property market goes cold
summary: New York's commercial real estate market is experiencing a downturn, with sales forecast to drop 30% this year. The market saw $14 billion in transactions in the first quarter, the lowest since 2014. A slowdown in Manhattan is driving the decline, with prices for centrally located office buildings slumping 5.2% since December. The market is attributed to a combination of factors, including a slump in oil prices, China's slowing economy, and a volatile stock market, leading to increased borrowing costs and a decrease in demand.

site_title: Keppel T&T's Q1 profit down 15.6%
summary: Keppel T&T's Q1 net profit fell 15.6% to S$13.31 million due to lower share of results from associated companies and higher taxation. Revenue increased 0.7% to S$48.27 million.

site_title: An extreme and extremely hard-to-stomach movie
summary: The film "Hardcore Henry" is a hyperkinetic, first-person-perspective action movie that follows a cyborg-like warrior as he battles an army of Russian thugs in Moscow. Shot entirely on GoPro cameras, the film features intense, graphic violence and a frenzied pace, but lacks a coherent narrative and smooth storytelling. Writer-director Ilya Naishuller's debut film is intended for a gamer generation and action movie enthusiasts, but may not appeal to a wider audience. The film's rating is a C, indicating a mediocre viewing experience.

site_title: Deep-water vessel marks McDermott's turnaround
summary: McDermott International has delivered a high-specification deep-water derrick lay vessel, the DLV 2000, designed by Keppel Singmarine, to support its subsea expansion efforts. The vessel's delivery comes three months after the company's turnaround under CEO David Dickson. Despite low oil prices, McDermott's backlog has risen to $4.2 billion, driven by new contract wins in the Middle East, Asia, and Latin America. The company aims to boost its revenue share from subsea to 25/75 by 2017 and has secured a significant contract with Inpex-operated Ichthys gas project off Western Australia.

site_title: Shareholders raise concern over Noble's thinning margins
summary: Noble Group's shareholders expressed concerns over the company's thinning margins and sustainability of its business model at its annual general meeting. Despite a lower operating income margin of 1.76% and higher interest costs, CEO Yusuf Alireza assured that Noble's overall funding costs will remain the same. The company plans to refinance a $1 billion unsecured loan with a higher interest margin, and its asset-light structure aims to boost profit margins as competitors are forced out of business.

site_title: Flattening expectations
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has unexpectedly flattened the country's policy band for the Singapore dollar, a move that may impact the local economy. This decision is seen as a response to economic uncertainties and market fluctuations. The MAS aims to maintain stability and promote economic growth. The news has caused a stir in the market, and its implications are being closely monitored.

site_title: US pickup transitory as March CPI rises by less than previous 2 months
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.1% in March, the smallest gain since August, with the core CPI increasing 0.1% and total prices rising 0.1%. The moderate increase was attributed to a modest rebound in energy costs and a decline in food prices. Fed officials may not be in a hurry to raise interest rates, as inflation has lingered below the 2% goal for four years, with economists citing "soft inflation profile."

site_title: New York Times adds US$50m for global digital expansion
summary: The New York Times is investing $50 million over three years to boost digital readership and revenue globally. The move aims to promote the paper to international audiences and achieve its goal of being an "indispensable leader in global news and opinion." The investment will support a new "international digital growth team" and involve all aspects of the company, including the newsroom, product, technology, advertising, and consumer marketing. The paper has seen growth in digital-only subscribers, with 1,094,000 paid subscribers as of the end of the fourth quarter.

site_title: Luxury or bust for foreign automakers in Japan
summary: Luxury foreign automakers, such as BMW, Porsche, and Lamborghini, are thriving in Japan, with sales doubling in 2015. Despite the country's strict market regulations, these brands have found success by focusing on driving experience and quality. In contrast, domestic Japanese brands, such as Toyota and Honda, have struggled to compete, with luxury brands like Lexus lagging behind. Foreign brands' ability to overcome stereotypes and offer a more engaging driving experience has contributed to their success, with some brands selling over 40,000 vehicles in 2015.

site_title: Weak Q1 data prompts full-year downgrades by economists
summary: Singapore's economy grew 1.8% in the first quarter of 2016, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry's advance estimate. However, this narrowly beats expectations and deepens fears of a technical recession. Economists have downgraded their full-year growth forecast, with OCBC and Business Monitor International predicting 1.8% and 1.7% growth, respectively.
