The US$8,000 plate, 1/10th the size of the original, is available in two colors, yellow and magenta. Production is limited to 2,300 pieces, with all net proceeds benefiting the Los Angeles Museum of Modern Art. The collaboration marks Koons' second foray into plate production, following a 1995 and 2002 edition. Demand for the miniature sculpture has been high, with previous editions selling for thousands of dollars on the secondary market.

site_title: China's mysterious stock-market king reveals its trading secrets
summary: China Securities Finance Corp, a state-run investing agency, has been shrouded in mystery since receiving over $480 billion in funding last summer. Now, with mandatory shareholder disclosures, its trading secrets are slowly revealed. The agency has been accused of using its power to manipulate the world's second-largest stock market. According to annual reports, the King's tactics have been to buy and sell stocks in hundreds of Chinese companies, generating significant profits. This has sparked fierce speculation among investors and short sellers, with some calling for greater transparency and regulation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.800 points to 1722.310. Volume was 53.5 million lots worth RM13.3 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 81 to 55.

site_title: South Korea says govt has no current plans for a supplementary budget
summary: South Korea's government has no current plans for a supplementary budget, according to a finance ministry spokesman. This stance was reiterated after Finance Minister Yoo Il Ho mentioned the possibility of drawing up an additional budget if the economic situation changes. Another senior finance official stated that the current economic situation does not meet the legal conditions for an additional budget.

site_title: Australian unemployment rate unexpectedly falls to 5.7% in March
summary: Australia's unemployment rate unexpectedly fell to 5.7% in March, lower than economists' predictions of 5.9%. Employment rose 26,100, exceeding the forecasted 17,000 gain. The decline in unemployment rate suggests the economy's resilience to a resurgent currency. This unexpected drop may indicate a more optimistic outlook for the Australian economy.

site_title: Kuroda says markets would have been worse without negative rate
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said the nation's financial markets would have been worse without the adoption of a negative interest rate, rejecting suggestions the policy has been counterproductive. The yen has rallied 11% since January, while the benchmark Topix stock gauge has fallen 5%. Kuroda believes his monetary policy is having its intended effects, aiming to spur inflation to a 2% target, and will continue to add stimulus if needed. The BOJ is not targeting currency markets and will not excessively cut bank profits.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate seeks to wind up Capitol entities over deadlock with Pontiac Land
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings (PREHL) has filed applications with the Singapore High Court to wind up three Capitol entities due to a deadlock with its partner, Pontiac Land Group. The entities, which hold assets for the Capitol Singapore integrated development, are in a state of deadlock over key issues. PREHL owns a 50% stake in each entity, while Chesham Properties, a Pontiac Land Group affiliate, holds the remaining 50%. The winding up proceedings are not expected to impact PREHL's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Perennial Real Estate Holdings (PREHL) has filed applications for the Court to wind up three associated companies related to its integrated development, Capitol Singapore at City Hall, due to a deadlock with its partner.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks add to global rally at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose in early trade on Thursday, extending a global rally. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong added 1.30% to 21,432.92, while Shanghai's composite index rose 0.44% to 3,080.09. The US earnings season and upbeat Chinese data contributed to the rally.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares extend global rally in opening deals
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.52% in opening deals, extending a two-day rally. The Nikkei 225 index increased to 16,629.83, while the Topix index gained 1.47% to 1,352.03. This follows a strong lead from global equity markets.

site_title: Dark economic cloud over IMF-World Bank meeting
summary: Finance ministers and central bankers gather in Washington for the IMF-World Bank Spring meetings amid concerns that the global economy is nearing a stall. The IMF has cut its forecast for world economic growth for the third time in six months, warning of a possible recession if growth and consumption are not boosted. The meetings come as Brexit uncertainty and slowing GDP growth in China add to the economic cloud, with policymakers under pressure to take immediate action to stimulate growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets follow Wall St to extend rally
summary: Asian stock markets rallied for a second session, driven by Wall Street gains from JPMorgan Chase's earnings report. Investors shifted out of yen, supporting Japan's Nikkei. Singapore's decision to loosen monetary policy also lifted sentiment, causing the currency to tumble. Analysts attribute the rally to renewed confidence, with traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: GoPro shares jump with hire of Apple designer
summary: GoPro shares rose 19% to $13.90 after the company hired Apple designer Daniel Coster as vice president of design, reporting directly to founder Nick Woodman. Coster, who spent 20 years at Apple, aims to energize the company's design efforts. The hiring comes after GoPro reported a quarterly loss of $34.5 million and a 31% decline in revenue. The company had previously cut 7% of its workforce to better align resources with growth initiatives.

site_title: Oil prices extend fall with no end in sight for glut
summary: Oil prices fell further, with Brent crude futures at $43.89 a barrel and US WTI at $41.60, amid concerns over slowing demand and a potential lack of commitment from Opec and Russia to rein in production. Goldman Sachs attributed the deflationary outlook to US shale producers' productivity gains, which keep drilling despite lower prices. A weak Opec demand forecast and potential oversupply may lead to continued downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Noble Group CEO says markets 'difficult' as debt deal sought
summary: Noble Group CEO Yusuf Alireza stated that the commodities markets remain difficult, making it hard to predict a recovery. The company, Asia's largest commodity trader, is seeking to refinance its debt, with a weighted average cost of debt expected to remain the same. Noble Group's shares have rebounded 10% this year, and its March 2018 notes have surged to 78.6 US cents. The company aims to re-finance before a May deadline, with plans to use revolvers and bond-based financing.

site_title: Seoul: Won at 1-wk low on Singapore central bank easing, stocks jump on China data
summary: South Korea's won fell to a one-week low against the US dollar after Singapore's central bank eased its exchange rate-based policy, weakening other Asian currencies. The won dropped 0.8% to 1,154.6, despite a parliamentary election in South Korea that had little impact on the currency. Meanwhile, South Korean shares jumped 1% as China trade data boosted foreign buying, with tech giants Samsung and Kia rising 1.8% and 2.4% respectively.

images.alt_text: The South Korean won slipped to its lowest intraday level in a week early on Thursday after Singapore's central bank unexpectedly eased its exchange rate-based policy, weighing on other Asian currencies.

site_title: FLASH: Singapore GDP up 1.8% on year in Q1, unchanged from previous quarter: MTI
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 1.8% in Q1, matching the previous quarter's pace. The country's economy remains resilient, despite global challenges. A new sustainable aviation centre will be set up in Asia, and the government is exploring opportunities for advanced chip packaging. To address workforce shortages, the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) can provide training and support. The country's relationship with China is deepening, with diplomatic ties established 35 years ago. Economists are optimistic, saying the worst of the economic headwinds have passed.

site_title: Boustead Projects bags Tuas redevelopment project
summary: Boustead Projects has won a design-and-build contract to redevelop an industrial property in Tuas, Singapore, for S$258 million. The project, expected to be completed by Q3 2017, is the second redevelopment project won by Boustead from industrial landlord AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit. This contract expands Boustead Projects' order book backlog.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore leverages on twin policy levers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has shifted to a neutral policy stance, flattening the Singapore dollar policy band to zero per cent appreciation of the S$NEER. This move aims to address potential downside risks to growth and inflation, as well as a deteriorating labour market. Despite a surprise move, MAS maintains that this is not a policy of SGD depreciation. The Singapore economy grew 1.8% in Q1, beating forecasts, and core inflation is expected to average slightly below 2% in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: US Air Force says combat-ready F-35 fighter jets on track for 2016
summary: The US Air Force expects to declare an initial squadron of F-35 fighter jets ready for combat between August and December 2016, despite delays in the Autonomic Logistics Information System. The Air Force has confirmed the aircraft's performance exceeds expectations, but is continuing to evaluate its capabilities compared to older aircraft. The F-35's advanced interdiction capabilities and ability to operate in areas legacy platforms cannot are highlighted as key benefits.

site_title: Singapore Q1 GDP growth at 1.8% year on year, beats estimates
summary: Singapore's economy grew by 1.8% year-on-year in Q1 2016, beating estimates, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry's flash estimates. The services sector, however, posted its weakest performance in over a year, growing 1.9% year-on-year, while the construction sector expanded 6.2% year-on-year. The manufacturing sector showed signs of slowing its contraction pace, shrinking 2% year-on-year. The government will release preliminary GDP estimates in May.

site_title: Singapore dollar drops most since November after surprise easing
summary: Singapore's dollar dropped 0.9% to S$1.3626 against the US currency, its largest decline since November 6, after the central bank unexpectedly eased monetary policy to combat growing global growth threats. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will seek a policy of zero appreciation against an undisclosed basket of currencies, reversing its policy of modest and gradual appreciation since 2010. The decision comes after the economy stagnated in the first quarter, with 12 of 18 economists surveyed predicting the central bank would maintain policy, while the rest forecast an easing.

site_title: BOJ has "many ways" to ease as price expectations weaken: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the central bank is prepared to ease monetary stimulus if inflation expectations continue to weaken, despite recent price expectations weakening. Kuroda dismissed the notion that negative interest rates were aimed at weakening the yen to boost exports, saying the policy isn't targeted at exchange rates. He acknowledged the risk of declining inflation expectations affecting the BOJ's 2% inflation target, signaling readiness to ease monetary conditions as early as this month.

site_title: China clarifies rules for online imports of infant formula
summary: China has clarified rules for online imports of infant formula, stating that imports through international websites will need official approval by 2018, rather than immediately. The move follows China's recent tariff increase on online retail imports. The finance ministry also requires cosmetics imported through online channels to obtain a permit, with 136,000 international brands already approved. The clarification aims to alleviate concerns among firms and investors affected by the new rules.

site_title: Anti-Muslim threats on rise across United States
summary: US attorneys are concerned about a rise in anti-Muslim threats across the United States following terrorist attacks in Brussels, Paris, and San Bernardino. The Justice Department, led by Attorney General Loretta Lynch, is working with local law enforcement and community leaders to address the backlash against Muslim, Arab, Sikh, and South Asian Americans. Lynch stated, "There is no place for intolerance in our country," as the department aims to defend the safety and dignity of all people. Town hall discussions are planned to address the growing tensions.

site_title: To Brazil traders, Rousseff ouster may be boon to central bank
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff faces impeachment, which may benefit the central bank in controlling inflation. The real has surged 13% this year, making imports cheaper and reducing cost-of-living expectations. Analysts expect a one percentage point rate cut this year, aiding disinflation and the central bank's inflation control. This could lead to a quicker reduction in inflation, according to Carlos Kawall, chief economist at Banco Safra.

site_title: Coal slump sends mining giant Peabody energy into bankruptcy
summary: Peabody Energy, the largest private-sector coal company, filed for bankruptcy in US court, seeking to reorganize its US operations and reduce $10.1 billion in debt. The company, founded in 1883, is facing a coal slump due to environmental policies, cheap natural gas, and a global glut of metallurgical coal. Peabody will continue to operate during the reorganization and has agreed to $800 million in financing. The outcome of the case may turn on the trajectory of coal prices and environmental obligations. The company's Australian operations remain unaffected.

site_title: Stocks to watch: M1, Keppel DC Reit, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, CRCT
summary: M1's net profit dropped 6.9% to S$42.5 million for the first quarter, largely due to higher upfront customer acquisition costs. Keppel DC Reit posted a 3.7% year-on-year rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.67 Singapore cents. Keppel Infrastructure Trust announced a 0.93 Singapore cent DPU despite a net profit plunge to S$2,000. CapitaLand Retail China Trust increased DPU by 2.7% to 2.71 Singapore cents, but weaker yuan eroded its returns.

site_title: Update: MAS eases monetary policy, flattens S$ policy band
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has eased monetary policy by moving to a neutral policy stance, removing the modest appreciation of the S$NEER band. This decision aims to ensure price stability over the medium term. MAS projects a modest economic expansion and core inflation to rise at a milder pace than expected, averaging below 2% in the medium term. The policy band's width and level will remain unchanged.

site_title: Oil investors load up on near-month Brent amid tightening supplies
summary: Oil investors are loading up on near-month Brent crude due to tightening supplies, driven by demand from Korea, loading delays in Iraq, and North Sea maintenance. The prompt Brent spread has flipped out of contango and into backwardation, indicating a decrease in forward prices. Analysts believe the market is realizing a change in fundamentals this year, with Brent and US crude prices locked in contango. This shift suggests a potential increase in oil prices.

site_title: Nomura said to cut senior staff in London fixed-income unit
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc is restructuring its European fixed-income operations, cutting senior staff jobs in London's high yield, distressed debt, and asset-backed securities divisions. The firm plans to close certain businesses in Europe and "rationalise" operations in the Americas. This move is part of Nomura's broader efforts to streamline its overseas activities.

site_title: About 40,000 unionised Verizon workers walk off the job
summary: Nearly 40,000 Verizon unionized workers went on strike on April 13, 2016, after contract talks with the Communications Workers of America (CWA) and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) broke down. US Democratic presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders joined the strikers at a Brooklyn rally, while Hillary Clinton also voiced support for the workers, urging Verizon to return to the bargaining table. The strike affects employees in traditional wireline phone operations, including customer services representatives and network technicians.

site_title: Russia jets make 'simulated attack' passes near US destroyer: US
summary: US warplanes intercept two Russian Sukhoi SU-24 warplanes that made 18 simulated attack passes near a US destroyer in the Baltic Sea. The incident occurred in international waters, with the nearest Russian territory 70 nautical miles away. The US military described the Russian actions as "one of the most aggressive interactions in recent memory," and the US is reviewing the incident through diplomatic channels. The incident comes amid rising tensions between Russia and NATO, with the alliance planning its largest build-up in eastern Europe since the Cold War.

site_title: Operation "L": China's Geely to launch new car brand: sources
summary: China's Geely is set to launch a new car brand, codenamed "L", next year with a sport-utility vehicle and sedan based on Volvo's Compact Modular Architecture (CMA) platform. The brand aims to compete with Chinese-foreign venture brands and will be sold through Geely's existing dealership network. Despite concerns about the crowded Chinese market, Geely has turned around Volvo's fortunes and is forecast to maintain its growth rate. The launch of L-brand cars could be a significant move for Geely, which has already beaten the industry growth rate last year.

site_title: Federal regulators investigating Wall St Journal's 'living wills' story
summary: The Federal Reserve and FDIC are investigating how The Wall Street Journal obtained information on the regulators' "living wills" determinations, which were announced just hours after the outlet reported that several major US banks, including JP Morgan Chase, would receive failing grades. The WSJ's story was published before the official announcement, sparking concerns about a leak. The regulators have given failing grades to five big banks, including JP Morgan, and are investigating the leak to determine the source of the information. The investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.9% up on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.9% higher on Thursday after the Monetary Authority of Singapore announced a neutral policy stance on the S$NEER band, easing currency expectations. The Straits Times Index rose 25.79 points to 2,916.2, with blue chips and energy-related counters driving gains. About 52.5 million shares changed hands, resulting in an average unit price of S$1.70. The market saw a five-day rally ahead of GDP data, with gains outnumbering losses 89 to 18.

site_title: Don't 'over-dramatise' low inflation, says ECB's Nowotny
summary: European Central Bank policymaker Ewald Nowotny said low euro zone inflation shouldn't be "over-dramatized" as energy prices are expected to rise this summer, normalizing prices. Nowotny noted that core measures of inflation are higher and relevant. He attributed low inflation to depressed energy prices, which should rebound this summer.

site_title: Russian economy ministry sees 2016 average oil price at US$40 per barrel: agencies
summary: Russian economy minister Alexei Ulyukayev forecasts an average oil price of US$40 per barrel for 2016, with prices rising to US$45 in 2017 and US$50 in 2018. If oil prices average US$40 per barrel, Russia's GDP is expected to contract 0.3% this year. The government is unlikely to amend its annual budget until autumn.

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow global gains as weaker yen buoys Japan shares
summary: Asian stocks rose, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index advancing 0.8% to a 7-day winning streak, driven by a weaker yen and positive global equities. Japan's Topix index gained 1.6%, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 0.8%. China's exports rose 16% in February, supporting commodities and shares. The yen's weakness is expected to boost Japan's Nikkei 225 Stock Average, while Singapore's central bank eased policy to shore up growth.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore economy "ran out of steam" in Q1
summary: Singapore's economy grew 1.8% year-on-year in Q1 2016, unchanged from the previous quarter, beating estimates. The services sector posted its weakest performance in over a year, while construction sector expansion quickened. Economists warn of a potential technical recession due to the rapid services deceleration. However, the construction sector showed resilience, growing 6.2% year-on-year. The divergence in growth numbers between services and manufacturing sectors is unsustainable, with strong growth in construction not sustainable due to weakened lending.

site_title: AIMS AMP Reit taps Boustead to redevelop Tuas property after fire
summary: AIMS AMP Reit will redevelop an industrial property at 8 and 10 Tuas Avenue 20 in Singapore for about S$27 million after a fire caused partial damage. The redevelopment will turn two adjoining spaces into an industrial facility suitable for production and warehouse usage. The project is expected to be completed in H2 2017 and will increase the property's value to S$32 million. Boustead Projects has been appointed as the redevelopment design-and-build partner.

site_title: Manhattan Resources CFO and audit committee chairman quit
summary: Manhattan Resources' CFO, Choo Hsun Yang, and audit committee chairman, Lim Say Tai, are resigning, with Yang stepping down due to "pursuing other interests" and Lim leaving due to health reasons. Yang will cease to be an executive director and CFO on April 29, while Lim will also step down on the same day from his roles as audit committee chairman and member of the nominating committee and remuneration committee. No reason was given for Yang's departure, and Lim's resignation is attributed to health concerns.

site_title: Gold retreats as stocks, dollar rally after China's trade data
summary: Gold prices fell 1.1% to $1,241.11 an ounce after equities rose and the dollar rallied its most in three weeks, driven by stronger US stocks and China's exports. The dollar's gain was attributed to optimism over improved equity markets and China's economy. Global equities erased their 2016 losses, and the dollar made its largest gain against a basket of 10 currencies since March 23. The decline in gold prices, which had risen 17% this year, was attributed to the "risk on" rally and the markets' expectation of US Federal Reserve normalization.

site_title: Long-stalled email privacy bill advances in Congress
summary: The US House Judiciary Committee unanimously approved the Email Privacy Act, which would require law enforcement to obtain a search warrant to access emails older than 180 days. The bill updates a decades-old law, mandating federal authorities to get a warrant before accessing such communications, rather than relying on a subpoena with less judicial oversight. Its prospects for becoming law this year remain uncertain.

site_title: London property prices feel pressure of 'Brexit', pound's slide
summary: London's property market is feeling pressure from the UK's vote on European Union membership and the pound's slide, with demand from house buyers falling sharply in March. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reported a 42 house-price gauge, down from 50 in February, and near-term sales expectations slipped below zero for the first time since 2008. Despite this, long-term expectations remain positive, with house prices expected to rise by 25% over the next five years. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit is affecting the market, particularly in central London areas.

site_title: MAS eases monetary policy, flattens S$ policy band
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, has eased monetary policy by moving to a neutral policy stance, removing the modest appreciation of the S$NEER policy band. The width and level of the policy band remain unchanged. This decision aims to maintain economic stability without depreciating the domestic currency.

site_title: FLASH: MAS moves to neutral policy stance of 0% appreciation of S$ policy band
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has shifted its policy stance to neutral, with no appreciation of the S$ policy band. This move is aimed at supporting economic growth and stability.

site_title: Macquarie lays off 15% of US investment banking group: sources
summary: Macquarie Group Ltd has laid off approximately 15% of its US investment banking workforce as part of a restructuring effort to focus on star performers and gain market share. The layoffs targeted industry coverage, with some bankers joining other groups, while the division will continue to employ over 200 staff. The move follows similar layoffs by Nomura Holdings Inc, and comes as Macquarie seeks to expand its private equity advisory and financing capabilities, with a focus on the US middle-market.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing activity growth slows slightly in March: survey
summary: New Zealand manufacturing activity expanded at a slightly slower rate in March, according to a survey, with the seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index (PMI) at 54.7, down from 55.9 in February. This marks the lowest level of expansion since October 2015. Employment in manufacturing contracted for the second month in a row.

site_title: Argentine court stops Uber in its tracks
summary: An Argentine court has ordered Uber to suspend its service in Buenos Aires until a final ruling on whether the app is unfair competition. The suspension comes after Uber launched its service without authorization, triggering protests by taxi drivers who claim the app is endangering their jobs by flooding the market with cheaper drivers. The city's transport chief says Uber is not delivering transport under existing laws, and licensed taxi drivers accuse Uber of not paying permits or taxes. The suspension will remain in effect until the court makes a final decision.

images.alt_text: A Buenos Aires court ordered Uber to suspend service on Wednesday and launched an inquiry into whether the app is unfair competition, a day after it began operating in the Argentine capital.

site_title: Obama names cyber experts from business, academia to new panel
summary: President Barack Obama has established a Commission on Enhancing National Cybersecurity, co-chaired by Tom Donilon and Sam Palmisano, to strengthen US cyber defenses. The panel includes experts from MasterCard, Microsoft, Uber, and academia, among others. The commission aims to provide long-term recommendations on tightening cybersecurity in the private sector and government, part of Obama's $19 billion proposal to boost defenses against hackers. The panel's first public meeting is scheduled for Thursday at the Commerce Department.

site_title: Regulators confirms 85m Takata air bag inflators in US
summary: US auto safety regulators confirmed that approximately 85 million unrecalled Takata airbag inflators are in US vehicles, with 28.8 million already recalled by 14 automakers. Takata has until 2019 to prove the safety of the remaining inflators. A recent incident in Texas, where a 17-year-old driver was killed by a ruptured Takata airbag in an unrepaired recalled vehicle, highlights the ongoing issue. The US government has never publicly disclosed the total number of unrecalled Takata airbags until now.

site_title: Exxon says 'US$25 billion rule' will sink deepwater oil drilling
summary: The US government is set to issue new regulations on deepwater oil drilling, expected to cost around $1 billion and impose strict safety measures, including redundant safety devices and continuous monitoring. The rules are aimed at reducing the number of well blowouts after the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster. Industry experts, including Exxon, warn that the regulations could lead to a 70% decline in exploration outlays in the Gulf, wiping out 190,000 jobs over two decades. Environmental groups argue that the new rules do not go far enough to protect marine life and the people who depend on it.

images.alt_text: The world's biggest oil explorers are fighting a US plan to toughen offshore drilling rules that Exxon Mobil Corp said will cost US$25 billion over 10 years and render many offshore discoveries worthless.

site_title: Sterling falls against US dollar as three-day rally fizzles
summary: Sterling fell 0.4% to US$1.4221 against the US dollar on Wednesday, reversing a three-day rally, amid concerns over a potential Brexit. The pound has lost nearly 7% in the past four months. Polls show the "In" and "Out" campaigns neck-and-neck before the June 23 referendum, with some banks predicting a 7% or more decline in sterling's value if Britain votes to leave the EU. The International Monetary Fund warned of "severe global damage" if the UK exits the EU.

images.alt_text: Sterling fell for the first time in four days against the US dollar on Wednesday, reverting to a trend that has seen the pound fall almost 7 per cent in the past four months, amid worries that Britain will vote to leave the European Union.

site_title: World Bank to invest US$2.5b in education for girls
summary: The World Bank has announced a new US$2.5 billion initiative to support education for girls, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, where 62 million girls aged 12-17 are not in school. US First Lady Michelle Obama emphasized the importance of investing in girls' education, stating it benefits not only them but also their families and communities. The funding will be used for facilities, scholarships, and other needs over the next five years. World Bank President Jim Yong Kim highlighted the initiative as part of the institution's anti-poverty mission.

site_title: South Korea ruling conservatives suffer upset defeat in parliamentary vote: media
summary: South Korea's ruling conservative Saenuri Party suffered an upset defeat in the parliamentary election, with the main opposition Minjoo Party winning 123 seats and the People's Party taking 38. The Saenuri Party secured 122 seats, a stinging blow to President Park Geun-hye. The results marked a significant shift in the country's politics, with the Minjoo Party's victory seen as a major upset.

site_title: Takata cash burn complicates air-bag maker's search for a savior
summary: Takata Corp, the air-bag supplier behind the auto industry's largest recall, has burned through 40% of its cash in two years, with estimated cash and equivalents projected to drop 24% to 49.7 billion yen by March 2017. The company seeks financial sponsors to replenish its capital and emerge as a new entity, amid a rising death toll from faulty air-bags. With a market capitalization of $295 million, down 80% since 2013, analysts consider its survival uncertain, but note that carmakers may ultimately support Takata.

site_title: World Bank and China-backed infrastructure bank join hands
summary: The World Bank and the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), backed by China, signed an agreement to co-finance infrastructure projects. The framework allows the World Bank to oversee project planning and implementation, with the AIIB approving $1.2 billion in financing in its first year, including joint projects with the World Bank. This collaboration aims to promote cooperation and coordination in infrastructure development.

site_title: Ben Affleck to direct, star in yet another Batman movie
summary: Ben Affleck is set to direct and star in a standalone Batman movie, following his disappointing performance in "Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice." This marks the first official confirmation of the project, which was rumored but not previously confirmed. Affleck has previously expressed interest in directing a superhero blockbuster, citing Zack Snyder's work as a valuable learning experience. The film is part of Warner Bros' pipeline of DC superhero movies, including "Wonder Woman," "The Flash," and "Justice League."

site_title: Kuwait to raise power, water price on expats
summary: Kuwait's parliament approved a bill to raise power and water charges on foreign residents and businesses, but exempted citizens. The move aims to cut consumption by 30% and reduce subsidies, which the government pays around $8.8 billion annually. Water prices will more than double, and power charges will be raised from $0.95 to $15 per kilowatt. The bill, which passed with 31 votes in favor and 17 against, is the first time Kuwait has raised power charges in 50 years. The government plans to hike heavily-subsidized petrol prices as well, citing a $20 billion budget deficit.

site_title: Magnitude 6.9 quake hits northern Myanmar
summary: A magnitude 6.9 earthquake struck northern Myanmar on April 13, 2016, with tremors felt in neighboring India and China. The quake, 134 kilometers deep, hit 396 kilometers north northwest of the capital Naypyidaw, affecting areas with poor communication infrastructure.

site_title: US: JPMorgan earnings spur stocks higher
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday following JPMorgan Chase's better-than-expected earnings, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 187.03 points to 17,908.28. Other large banks, including Bank of America and Wells Fargo, also surged. Despite weak US retail sales and producer prices, Chinese trade data showed exports rose 11.5% in March, supporting stocks. Most leading technology shares advanced, with Apple and Amazon rising 1.4% and 1.9% respectively.

site_title: 'Lock up the crooks' protest at Panama Papers law firm
summary: Protesters gathered outside the Panamanian law firm Mossack Fonseca, calling for the "Lock up the crooks" movement in response to the Panama Papers revelations. The demonstration came after police searched the law offices for evidence of a crime. Demonstrators, including Luis Gonzalez Marin and Genaro Lopez, demanded proper investigations and punishment for those involved in money laundering through offshore companies. Mossack Fonseca maintains its activities were legal, but protesters see the firm as a problem in the system. The protest was a sign of unease in Panama triggered by the revelations.

site_title: Panama raids law firm at centre of tax leaks scandal
summary: Panama's police raided the headquarters of Mossack Fonseca, a law firm at the center of the Panama Papers tax leaks scandal. The raid, which took place without incident, is part of a global investigation into offshore financial transactions used to hide assets and evade taxes. The scandal has led to the resignation of several high-profile leaders, including Iceland's prime minister, and has sparked diplomatic tensions between Panama and other countries, including France. The raid is a significant blow to Panama's financial services sector, which has been trying to improve transparency.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to settle US silver price-fixing litigation
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to settle US litigation alleging it conspired with Bank of Nova Scotia and HSBC Holdings to fix silver prices, distorting prices on $30 billion of silver traded annually. The settlement includes a monetary payment, with terms not disclosed. The agreement follows allegations of abusing power to dictate silver prices through a secret meeting known as the Silver Fix, violating US antitrust law. The case is part of several in Manhattan federal court, where investors accused banks of conspiring to rig rates or prices in financial and commodities markets.

site_title: 'Deep and disturbing' decline in press freedom since 2013: RSF
summary: Reporters Without Borders (RSF) stated that there has been a "deep and disturbing decline in respect for media freedom" since 2013, primarily due to repressive governments in countries like Turkey and Egypt, and places with law and order issues such as Libya and Burundi. Independent news coverage is under increasing threat, according to the group.

site_title: US economic growth 'modest to moderate': Fed Beige Book
summary: The US economy is growing at a "modest to moderate" pace, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book, with the jobs market strengthening, wages rising, and consumer spending up moderately. Ten of the 12 Fed districts reported economic growth between late February and early April, with labor market conditions continuing to strengthen and tepid wage growth suggesting some momentum. The report also noted modest increases in consumer spending and weak inflation, but low prices affecting the energy and mining sectors. The Federal Open Market Committee is not expected to raise interest rates after its meeting on April 26-27.

site_title: Labour row hits flights at bomb-struck Brussels airport
summary: A labour dispute at Brussels airport led to the cancellation of approximately 200 flights on Wednesday, with about half of the scheduled flights affected. The protest was sparked by staff from Belgium's air traffic control organisation Belgocontrol, who were protesting the terms of their labour contract, including the delay of the retirement age to 58. The airport had reopened just a day after the deadly jihadist bombings in March. The airport said it was unclear whether more cancellations would occur into Thursday, with the dispute expected to continue.

site_title: Moderate quake shakes southern Philippines
summary: A 5.9-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of southern Philippines at 2:21am on April 13, 2016, with its epicentre about 28km north-west of Siocon town. The quake occurred at a depth of 12km and no damage or casualties were reported. No tsunami warning was issued, and the quake was about 750km south of Manila.

site_title: Craft beer fans face squeeze with hops in short supply
summary: Craft beer enthusiasts may face higher bar bills due to a shortage of hops, a key ingredient in beer, caused by last summer's hot and dry weather in Europe. The shortage, exacerbated by strong demand for craft beers, has driven up prices by up to 50%. Small brewers, particularly those without hop contracts, are struggling to maintain profit margins and may be forced to raise prices. The scarcity may worsen as multinationals buy up craft brands and increase production, leaving some brewers vulnerable to sudden price surges.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff fights as impeachment noose tightens
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff vowed to "fight to the last minute" as impeachment proceedings against her gained momentum, with two key allies abandoning her and opposition parties closing in on securing the 342 votes needed to approve the impeachment motion. Rousseff has repeatedly offered to forge a compromise, but analysts say her grip on power is tenuous, and if she survives the vote, her popularity has plunged, making backing her politically risky. The impeachment trial, if approved, will proceed to the Senate for a further vote.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit posts 3.7% rise in Q1 DPU
summary: Keppel DC Reit posted a 3.7% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.67 Singapore cents in Q1, surpassing its forecast by 1.2%. The Reit's gross revenue and net property income slipped 4.5% and 2.5% respectively due to various factors, but its balance sheet remains healthy with an aggregate leverage of 29.6%. The Reit manager remains committed to growing the portfolio through third-party acquisitions and the Rights of First Refusal arrangement with its sponsor.

site_title: 'The Beast' gobbling up IS fighters in Iraq: US
summary: A US-made M-1 Abrams tank nicknamed "The Beast" is driving the Islamic State group from the Iraqi town of Heet, according to a Pentagon official. The tank has been blasting IEDs, punching holes in enemy defenses, and maneuvering between engagements. The Iraqi security forces' progress against the IS group is seen as a fresh resolve to fight back, with 75% of the city now clear. The US military highlights the example as a ripple effect, boosting morale and confidence among units, with the IS group expected to be completely pushed out of the city in the coming days.

images.alt_text: An American-made Iraqi army tank that locals have fondly nicknamed "The Beast" is playing a major role driving the Islamic State group from a town on the frontlines, a Pentagon official said on Wednesday.

site_title: Facebook pushes Internet to more corners of the world
summary: Facebook unveils new land-based systems to provide Internet connectivity to people in urban settings, using low-cost, off-the-shelf components to create antenna-based networks. The technology, called Terragraph, can be mounted outside high-rises and connected to Internet connections inside, increasing customer reach and reducing interference. Facebook also announced a satellite to provide Internet service to sub-Saharan Africa and plans to launch its first satellite in the coming months. The social network aims to make Internet connectivity more widely available around the world, with a goal of connecting four billion people who currently lack access.

site_title: Analysts see Australia GDP growing 2.6% in 2016
summary: Australia's economy is expected to grow 2.6% in 2016, unchanged from the previous poll, despite a rise in the local dollar and uncertainty over China. The forecast is based on gains in consumer spending, new home building, and export volumes. Analysts believe the economy is weathering the global challenges well and transitioning out of the mining boom. This growth is a step down from last year's 3% expansion, but still a positive outlook for the country's economy.

site_title: Ford's new HQ takes cue from Silicon Valley campuses
summary: Ford Motor is transforming its corporate headquarters in Dearborn, Michigan, into two high-tech campuses, mirroring Silicon Valley's design, as part of its effort to rebrand itself as a "mobility company". The $7.7 billion project, expected to take 10 years, will consolidate 30,000 employees in 70 buildings into two energy-efficient campuses with autonomous shuttles, electric bikes, and green spaces. The goal is to spur innovation and showcase the future of transportation, with a focus on sustainability and energy efficiency.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Ford's proposed engineering and headquarters facilities. The project will take 10 years to complete and consolidate some 30,000 employees now housed in 70 buildings.

site_title: EU ministers to discuss caps on bank holdings of public debt, officials say
summary: European Union finance ministers will discuss five options to limit banks' exposure to sovereign debt at their meeting next week. The options include capping maximum exposure to a single sovereign issuer and introducing non-zero risk weights for sovereign exposures. This comes amid concerns about the risk of affecting bond markets. The move aims to address the current lack of regulation on sovereign debt, which is currently exempt from limits imposed on corporate or household debt. The outcome of the discussion is expected to provide clarity on the EU's stance on sovereign debt regulations.

images.alt_text: European Union finance ministers will consider five options to reduce the exposure of banks to sovereign debt when they meet next week, European officials told Reuters.

site_title: Facebook to let users buy tickets directly
summary: Facebook is expanding into e-commerce by allowing users to buy tickets directly for selected US events. The company will connect to ticketing leaders Ticketmaster and Eventbrite, offering users an option to purchase tickets on the site. This move is part of Facebook's efforts to further integrate into e-commerce, providing users with a seamless experience for buying tickets and other products.

site_title: US health authorities confirm Zika causes birth defects
summary: US health authorities have confirmed that the Zika virus, a mosquito-borne virus, causes birth defects, including microcephaly, a condition where babies are born with unusually small heads. The confirmation was made after months of debate, based on studies in Brazil where thousands of babies were born with birth defects coinciding with a spike in Zika virus infections. The CDC cited "increasing evidence" and a careful evaluation of scientific criteria to reach the conclusion. The virus was first identified in 1947, but the outbreak in Brazil in 2015 led to a surge in microcephaly cases.

site_title: Olympics: Brazil crisis will not affect Rio games, says IOC
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) says Brazil's political and economic crisis will not affect preparations for the Rio de Janeiro Olympics in August. Venue construction is on schedule, and organizers are confident in the games' success, despite the turmoil. Chairwoman Nawal El Moutawakel stated that preparations are proceeding as planned, with some last-minute work remaining. This contrasts with the 2014 World Cup, where several stadiums were finished late and infrastructure projects were still unfinished two years later.

site_title: Spain holds 'trafficker' of arms that may have been used by Paris jihadist
summary: Spanish police detained Antoine Denevi, a 27-year-old Frenchman, on Tuesday for allegedly trafficking arms that may have been used by one of the Paris jihadist attackers. Denevi, from northern France, was charged with arms trafficking but not terrorism charges. He allegedly supplied arms and munitions to Amedy Coulibaly, who killed four people in a Jewish supermarket in January 2015. Two other suspects were also detained in the operation, one from Serbia and the other from Montenegro.

site_title: China gives a boost to global box-office takings
summary: China's booming box office has fueled a record-breaking global earnings of $38.3 billion for movie theaters worldwide in 2016, up 5.2% from the previous year. China's growth was particularly notable, increasing by 51.2%. The trend is attributed to improved theaters, diversity in movie casting, and the appetite of young people, with teenagers accounting for 16% of movie ticket purchases. The growth is expected to continue, with box office receipts up 12.7% in the first quarter of the current year.

site_title: CRCT first-quarter DPU up 2.7%
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 2.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.71 Singapore cents for the first quarter of 2016. Despite a weaker yuan, gross revenue rose 1.9% to S$55.6 million, while net property income increased 6.2% to S$36.7 million. However, occupancy rates and rental growth were affected by tenant adjustments at CapitaMall Wuhu. The trust remains well-positioned to benefit from China's transition to a consumption-driven economy.

site_title: Two weeks of paid paternity leave from January 2017
summary: Singapore's government will legislate a second week of state-funded paternity leave for all fathers of Singapore citizen children born from January 1, 2017, with the extra week capped at S$2,500 a week. The government will also quadruple government-paid shared parental leave to four weeks for citizen children born from July 1, 2017. This enhancement aims to encourage young fathers to be more involved in raising their children, and the government will provide up to eight weeks of leave, including six days of childcare leave and a week of unpaid infant care leave.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: March retail sales fall unexpectedly by 0.3 per cent
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.3% in March, the first decline in six months, as demand for cars and clothing dropped. Despite a 0.2% increase in non-auto purchases, sustained gains in consumer spending are needed to offset depressed exports and sluggish US manufacturing. Wholesale prices fell 0.1% in March, indicating contained inflation. The decline in retail sales raises concerns about consumer spending momentum, with experts citing a need for sustained wage growth to boost spending.

site_title: Businesses do not innovate, it's people who do
summary: The Singapore government's budget announcement on innovation and growth is insufficient to drive business innovation, as it relies on people's motivation to innovate. A study of 215 SMEs found that only 17% of leaders assess new technology solutions and 34% undertake this exercise annually. To encourage innovation, businesses must make time for employees to innovate, create an enabling work culture that rewards team-based performance, and allow people to unlearn and relearn. By adopting these strategies, businesses can tap into their employees' potential to drive innovation and growth.

site_title: UK's FCA proposes new IPO process amid competition concern
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has proposed changes to the initial public offering (IPO) process to reduce favoritism and better inform investors. Analysts not underwriting the IPO should have more access to the company's management, and the timing of prospectus publication should be changed to provide more information to investors. This aims to prevent investment banks from allocating shares to favored customers, potentially shutting out smaller investors.

site_title: Dollar surges on higher oil prices, improved China data
summary: The US dollar surged to a two-week high against the euro, reaching 109.18 yen, due to higher oil prices and improved Chinese data. This move was driven by investors seeking riskier assets, despite low-yielding European and Japanese assets. A deal to stabilize oil output and reduced expectations of US interest rate hikes also contributed to the dollar's strength. However, the euro and yen may continue to weaken, and the dollar's gains may be short-lived, according to analysts.

site_title: Panama Papers and the risk of Brexit
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron faces potential damage to his premiership due to the Panama Papers revelations, which expose offshore holdings of politicians and officials, including Cameron's father. Cameron admitted to personally profiting from a sale of shares in 2010, but claims it was not a tax-avoidance vehicle. The scandal could erode his credibility and increase the likelihood of Brexit, potentially leading to his resignation and the end of his tenure in 10 Downing Street.

site_title: Banks expect big AGM turnout as shareholder base soars
summary: Banks in Singapore are preparing for a large turnout at their upcoming annual general meetings (AGMs) due to a significant increase in shareholder base. The reduction in minimum board-lot size has led to a surge in investor rolls, with DBS seeing a 50% increase, OCBC a 35% increase, and UOB a 37% increase. Shareholders are expected to ask tough questions about CEO salaries, board practices, and business strategies, including the high pay of DBS' Piyush Gupta and OCBC's Samuel Tsien.

site_title: Govt wages war on diabetes, sets up task forces
summary: Singapore's government has declared a "war on diabetes" amid rising obesity rates and a growing number of Singaporeans living with the condition. The declaration follows worrying trends of decreased physical activity and excessive calorie consumption, leading to a rising obesity rate and increased risk of chronic diseases like type 2 diabetes. To combat the issue, the government has set up two task forces to address the problem.

images.alt_text: Singapore's healthy life expectancy may be among the top three in the world but Singaporeans are also living with longer ill health now than before, with diabetes a particularly worrying trend that has prompted the government to declare war on the condition and set up two task forces.

site_title: UBP completes Coutts purchase, may expand through JVs
summary: UBP has completed its acquisition of Coutts International, expanding its private banking and institutional asset management capabilities. With assets under management of 130 billion Swiss francs, UBP aims to grow both its private banking and institutional businesses, potentially through joint ventures. However, CEO Guy de Picciotto has paused integration efforts to focus on integrating systems, bankers, and culture. UBP's strength lies in its asset management capabilities, which it believes can offer an attractive proposition in the competitive market.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

Mr de Picciotto says UBP's strength is in its asset management capabilities, both in terms of advisory and discretionary services. The group manages 33 billion Swiss francs through UBAM funds and segregated mandates.

site_title: China banks push into Australia by financing investments
summary: China's banks are expanding their presence in Australia, financing Chinese property and corporate investments, with total loans growing by 36% in the year to end-February. This rapid growth has raised concerns at the Reserve Bank of Australia, which warns that foreign lenders could pose a systemic threat to the domestic banking system. Chinese lenders, such as Bank of China and ICBC, are dominating the US$75 billion syndicated loan market, and their expansion is seen as a potential threat to the Australian economy. The RBA governor has expressed worries about overheated markets and loan losses.

site_title: STI shoots up on China export surge
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) surged 2.69% on Wednesday, closing at 2,890.41, driven by a 11.5% increase in China's March exports. The rebound follows a 25% decline in February. The STI is now eight points up for the year, its second positive start. The Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Composite also rose 3% and 1.4%, respectively.

site_title: Drones to be tested for solar and wind farms
summary: DNV GL, a multinational energy-services provider, has partnered with local drone technology startup SwarmX to test autonomous drones for monitoring solar and wind farms. The drones equipped with thermal-imaging technology will scan solar panels and detect faults, enabling quicker fixes and increasing efficiency. The partnership aims to save companies time and cost by replacing human inspectors, with a pilot set to begin in Thailand next month. The technology has potential applications in oil-and-gas exploration, power transmission, and distribution, and is also being explored for security and surveillance projects.

site_title: Yangzijiang bags orders worth US$510m from ICBC unit
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has secured orders worth US$510 million from ICBC Leasing for six 400,000-deadweight-tonne dry bulk carriers, valued at nearly US$60 per tonne. This marks a "rare case" of a state-owned ship owner placing orders with a private shipyard in China. The contracts, valued at US$510 million, are scheduled for delivery from 2018 to 2019 and are part of a larger contract with Vale to transport iron ore from Brazil to China.

site_title: JPMorgan cuts 30 jobs in Singapore, HK
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has cut 30 jobs, or 5% of its headcount, at its Asia wealth management business in Singapore and Hong Kong. The move aims to focus on tapping wealthier clients. The job cuts do not affect the bank's other Asian operations. This is part of JPMorgan's broader efforts to streamline its business and adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Time for a new tack to get the global economy moving
summary: The International Monetary Fund has expressed concern over the global economy's slowdown, urging a shift from monetary easing to fiscal stimulus. The Group of Seven (G-7) summit in Japan is expected to endorse a significant boost in collective fiscal spending by member governments, potentially boosting the global economy. Commodity prices, particularly oil, are also recovering, which could have a positive impact on commodity-producing countries. This policy shift could help set advanced and emerging economies on a path to recovery, as the drawn-out drama of monetary easing may be coming to an end.

site_title: 1MDB says it may be victim of US$3.5b fraud
summary: 1MDB, a Malaysian state fund, claims it may be a victim of a $3.5 billion fraud after US$3.5 billion payments intended for an Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund never reached their destination. Swiss authorities are investigating two former UAE officials over the matter. The company denies any wrongdoing, stating it negotiated "various legal agreements" with the previous heads of IPIC and Aabar. Authorities from the US to Switzerland and Singapore are trying to determine if billions of dollars were siphoned out inappropriately by 1MDB.

site_title: FCL launches new executive condo in Sembawang
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) launches its new executive condo project, Parc Life, in Sembawang, Singapore, with an average price of S$770 to S$800 per square foot. The project features 628 units, including Verandah, Vista, and Viva layouts, and a full suite of facilities. Despite a new competitor, Qingjian Realty's The Visionaire, FCL remains confident in the market, citing healthy demand from HDB homeowners and first-time buyers. E-applications for Parc Life begin on April 16, with bookings set for April 30.

images.alt_text: Parc Life consists of 11, 15 and 16-storey blocks, and a total of 628 units. The project, whose average prices range from S$770 to S$800 per square foot, comes with a full suite of facilities usually available at private condominiums

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Acromec, a homegrown engineering services provider, made its IPO debut with a price of S$0.22. Analysts see potential in the healthcare and biomedical sectors, where the government has committed funds. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings secured a $510 million contract for six valemax ships. ComfortDelGro Corp is maintained as a "buy" with a target price of S$3.60 due to its robust taxi business and low risk profile.

site_title: Rental transactions jump in March: SRX
summary: Rental transactions for condominiums, private apartments, and HDB flats increased by 35.5% in March, driven by rental renewals and property hopping, rather than new demand. Rentals for private condominiums and apartments fell 1% year-over-year, while HDB rents dipped 0.1%. The rental volume for HDB flats rose 44.3% in March, with some types of flats experiencing declines in rentals. Experts expect private residential rents to fall by 5% in 2016, and HDB rents to fall by up to 5% as more flat owners move to completed condominiums.

site_title: Fintech's aim is to cut costs, lift customer convenience
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the goal of fintech in Singapore to make finance cheaper and more convenient for customers, rather than competing with other financial centers. He noted that success in fintech development depends on partnerships between players and cities, and that it's too early to determine if fintech will disrupt traditional players significantly. Regulators will balance innovation with preserving trust in the financial system, and will only start regulating fintech companies when they reach a sufficient size to pose risks to the wider financial system.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: FRASERS Property Australia sold Satellite Corporate Centre in Mulgrave to Stockland for A$87.6 million. Croesus Retail Trust issued S$60 million of senior unsecured notes, while Citic Envirotech secured its first sludge treatment project in China. Hi-P International disposed of its startup investment for 52.6 million yuan. Meanwhile, Citic Envirotech expects a pre-tax gain on the project, and Hi-P International expects a 50.4 million yuan gain. These deals are part of various corporate transactions in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Keppel Infra Trust's DPU up despite loss of Basslink fees
summary: Keppel InfraTrust reported a 18% increase in DPU to 0.93 Singapore cents for Q1 2016, despite a net profit drop to S$2,000 due to the loss of Basslink fees. The electricity interconnector had not received facility fees since a cable fault in December. This was a year-over-year decrease from S$2.66 million in net profit. The trust's DPU increase was driven by other revenue streams.

site_title: Higher starting pay for graduate engineers joining public sector
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean announced an increase in starting salaries for graduate engineers in the public sector, with those in engineering starting from S$3,800 a month and those in information and communications technology (ICT) starting from S$4,000, representing a 20% average increase. The revised salaries will take effect from the middle of this year. The government also plans to recruit 1,000 new engineers, with 70% supporting infrastructure development and the rest contributing to the country's Smart Nation efforts.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: No dead end art for graveyard Sydney Biennale
summary: Swedish artist Bo Christian Larsson has created an art installation at Camperdown Cemetery in Sydney, Australia, as part of the city's 20th Biennale. The installation, titled "Fade Away, Fade Away, Fade Away," involves covering graves with white cloths to strip away social hierarchy and hierarchy of class, highlighting the equality of all those buried beneath. The work is a reflection on the theme of fading away, both in life and death, and the artists are careful to respect the historic nature of the cemetery.

site_title: US presidential candidates' isolationist stance sends out dangerous message
summary: US presidential candidates, including Donald Trump, Bernie Sanders, and Hillary Clinton, are promoting an isolationist stance, which could lead to global instability and prosperity. Trump's plan to have US allies bear the financial burden of their own defense is seen as abandoning allies, while Sanders and Clinton express concerns about the US being a global policeman. This stance echoes the disastrous consequences of US isolationism in the 1930s, and experts warn that it could embolden rival powers to fill the vacuum left by the US retreat.

site_title: Spielberg, Foster and Penn likely to feature in Cannes line-up
summary: Steven Spielberg, George Clooney, and Jodie Foster are expected to attend the Cannes Film Festival next month. The festival's lineup, including the Palme d'Or prize, is set to be revealed on Thursday. Woody Allen's "Cafe Society" will open the festival, and Nicolas Winding Refn's "The Neon Demon" is likely to be included. However, the presence of festival favorite Pedro Almodovar is uncertain due to his involvement in the Panama Papers scandal, while Sean Penn's film "The Last Face" and Jeff Nichols' "Loving" are predicted to be part of the lineup.

images.alt_text: Steven Spielberg, George Clooney and Jodie Foster are tipped to be among those who will walk the red carpet at Cannes next month when the line-up for the world's top film festival is revealed on Thursday.

site_title: China's scrap mounds threaten global iron-ore industry
summary: China's growing middle class is shifting towards using recycled metal, making it more profitable to melt down scrap metal than traditional iron-ore and coal in a furnace. China's scrap supply is expected to double in the next decade and accelerate further, potentially shrinking iron-ore demand by 50% by 2040. As a result, iron-ore producers such as BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto are facing significant challenges, with prices plummeting by over 50% since 2011. Governments may need to intervene with subsidies and policies to encourage the switch to electric-arc furnaces, which already account for 60% of US steel production.

site_title: Disenchantment with Cameron and Osborne helping Brexit campaign
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron and Chancellor George Osborne's support for the "remain in EU" campaign has led to a four-point lead for Brexit in a recent poll, despite both leaders' efforts to counter criticism of their past tax avoidance schemes and other policies. Critics argue that their actions and decisions have damaged their credibility and have not addressed key issues such as immigration, property values, and economic uncertainty. The government's pro-EU campaign has been widely criticized, and the poll suggests that the public is increasingly skeptical of their advice.

site_title: Malaysia's EPF plans to double property assets
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) plans to double its real estate assets, aiming for 10% of its $178 billion fund size, over the next 5-7 years. The move is part of a diversification strategy, with EPF seeking to increase its exposure to continental Europe and focus on private market assets. The fund has seen significant growth in its foreign real estate investments, with a 50% annual average growth rate since 2009. EPF's CEO, Shahril Ridza Ridzuan, also favors Malaysian plantation companies and sees value in the financial sector following recent declines in banking stocks.

site_title: M&A increasingly favoured as internationalisation strategy
summary: Singapore companies increasingly favor mergers and acquisitions (M&As) as a strategy to internationalize and address capability gaps. According to International Enterprise (IE) Singapore, the agency awarded S$8.3 million in M&A grants to 95 projects from 2011 to 2015, with the grant amount doubling to S$2.4 million in 2015. The top sectors and markets for M&A include consumer and logistics industries in China, South-east Asia, and the US. The government provides assistance for M&A, including tax allowances and financing schemes, to support companies' internationalization efforts.

site_title: VW executives to accept 'sharp reductions' in bonuses
summary: Volkswagen executives are willing to accept "sharp reductions" in their annual bonuses amid the carmaker's struggles to stem the fallout from its massive engine-rigging scandal. The decision comes as the regional state government in Lower Saxony, where VW is based, believes a clear signal is needed regarding management board pay. The move is seen as a response to the controversy surrounding CEO Matthias Mueller's bonuses and the carmaker's expected significant losses due to the scandal.

site_title: PulteGroup founder hires lawyers to oust CEO
summary: PulteGroup's founder, Bill Pulte, has hired lawyers from Olshan Frome Wolosky LLP to pressure CEO Richard Dugas to step down, citing departures of executives, aggressive land purchases, and weaker stock performance. Pulte, who founded the company in 1950, has a history of conflict with Dugas and has been backed by former CEO James Grosfeld. The move indicates an intensifying battle over the company's direction, with Pulte seeking to oust Dugas as CEO.

site_title: Industry Transformation Programme a timely move, say panellists
summary: Panellists at the Deloitte Budget Seminar 2016 support the government's plan to phase out the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) Scheme and replace it with the Industry Transformation Programme (ITP). Industry experts, including DBS group head of consumer banking and wealth investment Tan Su Shan, believe the PIC scheme has run its course and that more industry-specific measures are needed. However, Tan noted the blurring of industry lines in the economy, making it difficult to implement targeted measures, potentially leading the government to revert to the PIC scheme in the future.

images.alt_text: The theme of disruptive developments dominated the discussion of the roundtable comprising (from left) Mr Tsang, Ms Tan, Mr Khanna, Mr Song and Mr Low.

site_title: Abe ally urges fresh double dose of stimulus
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe needs a fresh, 10 trillion yen fiscal package to counter economic weakness, according to Kozo Yamamoto, a Liberal Democratic Party lawmaker. The central bank should also add the same amount to its easing programme. This move aims to stimulate the economy, which is facing mounting signs of weakness. The proposed package and monetary easing are seen as necessary to support the country's economic recovery.

site_title: Relatives of Germanwings crash victims sue suicide pilot's US school
summary: Relatives of Germanwings crash victims filed a class action lawsuit against Airline Training Center Arizona, Inc., claiming the US flight school should not have trained suicidal pilot Andreas Lubitz. The lawsuit states Lubitz's "unacceptable behavior" made him unfit for the training program. The victims' families seek damages for the wrongful death of their loved ones in the 2015 crash in the French Alps.

site_title: M1's Q1 earnings fall 6.9% to S$42.5m as revenue slips
summary: M1's Q1 earnings fell 6.9% to S$42.5 million, primarily due to higher upfront customer acquisition costs. Revenue declined 12.6% to S$257.6 million. The company attributed this to the launch of the Samsung S7 in the first quarter instead of the second quarter. Despite this, M1 expects stable performance for 2016.

site_title: IMF urges govts of advanced economies to use fiscal policies to support demand
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged governments of advanced economies to use fiscal policies to support demand amid slowing global economic growth. In its Fiscal Monitor report, the IMF emphasized the need for prompt action to reduce vulnerabilities and support growth. This comes after a warning in its World Economic Outlook that global economic growth risked falling to "below stalling speed".

images.alt_text: A bolder and more proactive approach is needed by governments - especially those of advanced nations - toward leaning on fiscal policy as the global economy continues to slow, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said in its latest Fiscal Monitor report on Wednesday.

site_title: Aeon Co sets up RM1 billion Islamic debt programme
summary: Aeon Co Malaysia, a 51% owned mall operator by Japan's Aeon Co Ltd, has established an RM1 billion Islamic debt programme through twin debt facilities. The 15-year Islamic medium-term notes and seven-year Islamic commercial papers have been rated AA2/Stable and P1 respectively by RAM Ratings. This marks Aeon's first external funding, with the company previously relying on internal funding for expansion needs.

site_title: The Ascott launches prized selection of properties
summary: CapitaLand's The Ascott launches The Crest Collection, a selection of its most prestigious and unique luxury apartments, with four serviced residences in Paris and one in Bangkok. The collection includes three Citadines Suites properties in Paris and the newly added Metropole in Bangkok. CEO Lee Chee Koon emphasizes the importance of Europe, particularly France, as a key market for Ascott, with plans to expand through acquisitions and management contracts. The collection marks a significant milestone for Ascott, with over 3,000 apartment units in Thailand and 5,200 units in France.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Sino Grandness moves to list juices unit in Hong Kong
summary: Sino Grandness, a Singapore-listed Chinese food manufacturer, plans to list its juices unit, Garden Fresh, in Hong Kong, driven by strong demand in China for its loquat juice. The company aims to expand its market presence in Hong Kong, Macau, and Southeast Asia, and is in talks with an international superstar to be its spokesperson. Sino Grandness also plans to strengthen its distribution through e-commerce platforms and gain better access to Chinese consumers and investors. The company has submitted an application to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange to list Garden Fresh, which is expected to directly own 63.96% of the issued share capital upon completion.

site_title: Take corp governance to the next level at SingPost
summary: Singapore Post (SingPost) is reconstituting its board, sparking hope for transformation. However, concerns remain over the composition of the reformed Nominations Committee, which includes retiring chairman Lim Ho Kee and lead independent director Keith Tay. The committee's effectiveness in driving real change is uncertain. SingPost should avoid relying on familiar faces and instead seek candidates with the necessary skills and experience to take the company to the next level in corporate governance. The outcome will demonstrate Singapore's ability to demonstrate effective corporate governance to international investors.

site_title: Facebook opens Messenger app to chatbots
summary: Facebook has opened its Messenger app to chatbots, aiming to revolutionize customer service by connecting 900 million users with over 15 million businesses. Companies like Spring, 1-800-Flowers, and Poncho are already testing the feature, which allows users to interact with chatbots to complete tasks such as shopping and ordering. The move is part of Facebook's broader vision to create a global system of communications, virtual reality, and shopping. The bot wave is gaining momentum, with other messaging services like Kik and Telegram also introducing bot stores and platforms.

site_title: US mortgage applications jump as loan rates fall: MBA
summary: US mortgage applications surged last week, with the Mortgage Bankers Association's index rising 10% to 520.2, the highest since February 2016. Mortgage requests to buy homes increased 8% to 241.9, while refinancing applications jumped 11.3% to 2,122.0. The average interest rate on 30-year mortgages fell to 3.82%, its lowest in over a year. This decline supports a sturdy housing market, with interest rates now at their lowest point in more than a year.

site_title: IMF says negative rates a "net positive" for economies
summary: The International Monetary Fund's monetary and capital markets chief, Jose Vinals, stated that negative interest rates are a "net positive" for economies where they are deployed, benefiting banks from asset repricing and a stronger macroeconomic environment. However, Vinals noted that there are limits to how low interest rates can go.

site_title: Singapore Airlines dilemma: Use US$3.2b cash on Virgin or China
summary: Singapore Airlines is considering investing US$3.2 billion in either Virgin Australia or China, amid a power-sharing agreement at the Australian airline that is on the verge of fracturing. With Air New Zealand's 25.9% stake in Virgin Australia valued at US$249 million, Singapore Airlines may need to increase its holdings or jointly buy the stake to maintain its interest. However, a purchase could drain cash from Singapore Airlines' faster-growing markets in India and China, and the airline's decision could impact its international routes to Asia and the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines Ltd. has a decision to make: throw more cash at Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd., which has burned up shareholder wealth in four of the past five years, or risk an unwelcome rival muscling in.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on China data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by strong trade data from China and JPMorgan Chase's better-than-expected quarterly results. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 40.61 points, the S&P 500 gained 8.18 points, and the Nasdaq composite increased 32.71 points.

site_title: Maersk Oil presses on with upstream projects with backing from AP Moeller-Maersk
summary: Maersk Oil is expanding its Africa portfolio with the backing of its parent group AP Moeller-Maersk, allowing the oil and gas company to make counter-cyclical decisions despite lower oil prices. This move gives Maersk Oil room to invest in upstream projects, potentially increasing its presence in the region.

site_title: China's March exports in surprise surge, boosting stock markets
summary: China's exports surged 11.5% in March, the strongest pace since February, and imports contracted less than expected, narrowing the trade surplus to $29.86 billion. This positive trade data suggests the Chinese economy is stabilizing, with recent indicators pointing to growth in import volumes and a rise in electricity output and housing starts. However, economists warn that China's exporters will still face headwinds due to a weak global growth outlook, and the data may be influenced by over-invoicing and volatile trade patterns.

site_title: China in two minds about Japan?
summary: China appears to be divided on its stance towards Japan, with Foreign Minister Wang Yi publicly criticizing Japan for "double dealing" while also indicating a desire for improved relations. China is pressuring Japan and other G-7 countries not to discuss the South China Sea, a move that the US has rejected. China's Premier Li Keqiang has expressed frustration with Japan's lack of progress on implementing their joint economic development plans, but Japan's recent appointment of a new ambassador to Beijing suggests a shift towards improving relations. A G-7 summit in Japan will take place in May, and China will host the G-20 meeting in September, where it may seek to influence the agenda and potentially establish a one-on-one meeting with Japanese Premier Shinzo Abe.

site_title: Paris attacks concert hall to reopen in November: managers
summary: The Paris concert hall where 90 people were killed in 2015 terror attacks is set to reopen in November with a series of concerts. British singer Pete Doherty and Senegalese star Youssou N'Dour will perform on November 16 and 18, respectively. The reopening marks a significant step towards recovery for the venue, which has been closed since the attacks last year. The concerts are scheduled to take place after a thorough renovation and safety assessment.

site_title: IMF says financial stability risks rising, urges bank asset repair
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns of rising financial stability risks due to slowing global growth, weak commodity prices, and concerns over China's economy. The report states that financial system risks have increased since the last report in October and that market turmoil could recur if bank balance sheets are not cleaned up, particularly in China and Europe. The IMF estimates that bank loans to struggling Chinese companies could translate into potential bank losses of approximately 7% of China's gross domestic product.

site_title: Tata Steel falls victim to globalisation desire
summary: Tata Steel, the second-largest steel producer in Europe, is set to close its operations in Britain due to heavy losses caused by China's economic slowdown. China's growth rate has slowed from 10.4% in 2010 to 7% in 2015, leading to a decrease in demand for coal, iron ore, and steel. This has resulted in a surge in China's steel exports, hurting European steel industries. Tata Steel's acquisition of Corus Group in 2007, valued at a premium, has now become a liability as the company loses £1 million a day due to cheap Chinese steel imports.

images.alt_text: Cheap Chinese steel imports into Britain forced Tata Steel to halve prices on some of its products. As a result, the company now loses £1 million a day.

site_title: No recovery for steel demand this year: trade group
