summary: A steel demand recovery is unlikely before next year, according to the World Steel Association, citing a slowdown in the Chinese economy and weakness in manufacturing. Global steel demand is forecasted to decrease by 0.8% to 1,488 million tonnes this year, with growth expected in the US, Canada, and Mexico, but modest growth in the EU. Chinese demand is expected to decline by 4.0% this year and 3.0% in 2017. Industry groups are calling for protection from cheap Chinese steel imports.

site_title: Oil prices ease on strong US gasoline demand
summary: Oil prices eased on Wednesday as strong US gasoline demand offset a larger-than-expected build in crude inventories. US crude rose 6 cents to $42.11 per barrel, while Brent crude fell 5 cents to $44.64. Gasoline inventories fell 4.2 million barrels, and US crude production declined, suggesting a limited downside to inventory figures. A meeting of oil producers in Doha on Sunday to discuss freezing output is expected to have little impact on the market, which may still underestimate the potential near-term headline upside risk.

site_title: IEA chief sees oil prices rebound in second half of 2017
summary: IEA executive director Fatih Birol predicts oil prices will rebound in the second half of 2017, driven by a rebalancing of the market. This comes after an unprecedented decline in investment in new oil projects, leading to increased reliance on Middle Eastern crude imports. Birol's comments come as oil prices have been declining amid global market uncertainty.

site_title: VW executive board accepts bonus cuts by at least 30%
summary: Volkswagen's executive board has accepted a 30% cut in bonus payments as the company struggles to resolve a dispute over executive compensation. Further measures to trim variable remuneration for senior managers are also under discussion, with one option being that executives invest in the company. This move comes as Volkswagen grapples with the fallout from its diesel emissions scandal.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

London's Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade, with the goal of generating additional revenue. Meanwhile, Indonesia has detained an employee of Trafigura in a US$17 billion graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, has been named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks have rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data. CGSI downgraded Grab's rating to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth in the second half. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increased by 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Dubai commodities exchange ties up with Chinese banks
summary: The Dubai Gold & Commodities Exchange (DGCX) has agreed to collaborate with China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and Agricultural Bank of China to develop yuan products and clear transactions in the Chinese currency. This move could pave the way for yuan-clearing transactions and attract Chinese investors. The DGCX has previously launched yuan futures contracts and spot gold contracts in the yuan, and has seen a 37% year-on-year rise in trading volume. The partnership is part of the UAE's plan to establish a centre for clearing yuan transactions, following Qatar's similar centre.

site_title: YuuZoo critics need first to understand its business model
summary: YuuZoo, a Singapore-listed social media, e-commerce, and entertainment company, is facing criticism due to its complex business model. Co-founder and chairman Thomas Zilliacus aims to simplify the company's explanation to investors, likening it to a virtual shopping mall where users can engage in e-commerce, social networks, and entertainment. The company earns revenue through e-commerce sales, gaming, and advertising, and has a scalable franchise model that allows it to grow internationally at low costs. Despite a net profit of US$23.8 million in FY15, YuuZoo's shares have declined due to market uncertainty, and analysts expect the company to demonstrate commercial viability to re-rate its stock.

site_title: US business inventories fall slightly, sales weaken further
summary: US business inventories fell 0.1% in February, matching economists' expectations, but weak sales suggest businesses may take longer to reduce a glut of unsold merchandise. Auto inventories rose 1.3%, while retail inventories excluding autos rose 0.3%. The high inventory-to-sales ratio suggests businesses may continue working through the inventory overhang, hurting manufacturing and curbing GDP growth. This could lead to a 0.2% annualized rate of economic growth in the first quarter, down from a 1.4% pace in the fourth quarter.

site_title: US crude stocks soar while gasoline falls more than expected: EIA
summary: US crude oil stocks rose 6.6 million barrels last week, exceeding expectations of a 1.9 million-barrel increase. Gasoline inventories fell 4.2 million barrels, more than expected, while distillate stockpiles rose 505,000 barrels. Refinery crude runs and utilization rates declined. US crude imports increased by 686,000 barrels per day. The surge in crude stocks may indicate reduced demand or increased production, while the decline in gasoline inventories could signal increased consumption.

site_title: Oil price rally peters out, as Opec warns over supply
summary: Oil prices retreated on Wednesday, falling 60 cents to US$41.57 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate, as a rally fueled by reports of an output freeze by Saudi Arabia and Russia petered out. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) warned of a global supply glut, citing high inventories and oversupply. The Doha talks, set for Sunday, aim to ease the oil glut, but Iran's refusal to join the freeze calls raises concerns. Prices remain below US$100-a-barrel mark, which was reached in mid-2014.

site_title: Global tax authorities probe Panama Papers
summary: Tax authorities from 38 nations, including Australia, the US, and Europe, are investigating offshore dealings revealed in the Panama Papers leak, which exposed 11.5 million confidential financial documents. The probe comes after a year-long investigation by journalists, which implicated wealthy individuals and politicians worldwide, including Iceland's former prime minister and Russian President Vladimir Putin. Tax officials met in Paris to discuss cooperation and data sharing, with Australia's Tax Commissioner Chris Jordan saying the goal is to "get the bigger picture" and crack down on tax cheats.

site_title: Fathers to get longer paternity leave and shared parental leave from 2017
summary: Singapore announces that fathers will receive two weeks of paid paternity leave starting from January 1, 2017, up from the current one week of compulsory leave. The new policy aims to support young parents.

site_title: Amazon launches new slimmer Kindle e-reader
summary: Amazon has launched the Kindle Oasis, its eighth and slimmest e-reader, with a built-in charger and a battery life lasting up to weeks. The device weighs 4.6 ounces and starts at $289.99. With its sleek design and advanced features, Amazon aims to attract high-end readers. The company's CEO, Jeff Bezos, described the Kindle Oasis as "thin and ultra lightweight," designed to "get out of the way" and allow readers to immerse themselves in books. The device will be available for orders on April 13 and start shipping on April 27.

site_title: China to cut 100b yuan in companies' benefit costs: cabinet
summary: China's State Council announced a plan to cut companies' benefit costs by over 100 billion yuan, easing burdens and boosting jobs growth. The plan reduces the maximum old age pension contribution to 20% of monthly salary and unemployment insurance contribution to 1-1.5%. The measures will take effect on May 1, as China battles an economic slowdown. The goal is to fuel consumer spending and stimulate growth.

site_title: US producer prices fall on weak services costs
summary: US producer prices unexpectedly fell 0.1% in March, driven by a decline in services costs, offsetting rising energy prices. The decline suggests tame inflation, supporting the Federal Reserve's cautious approach to raising interest rates. Economists had forecast a 0.2% increase in producer prices, and the 12-month decline of 0.1% indicates inflation will remain below the Fed's 2% target. The decline in services costs, particularly in final demand trade services, accounted for the majority of the decrease.

site_title: Beijing summons G7 envoys over South China Sea statement
summary: Beijing summoned G7 envoys over their statement on the South China Sea, expressing anger at their "concern" over the region. The G7 statement emphasized peaceful management and settlement of disputes, without naming China, which claims almost all of the South China Sea. Beijing views the statement as an attempt to "amuse" itself, while the G7 urged countries to refrain from land reclamations and military outpost construction. The move is seen as a response to China's artificial island-building in the South China Sea, which Beijing considers a legitimate claim.

site_title: Doha oil meeting likely to yield 'partial output freeze': Sberbank
summary: Analysts at Sberbank CIB predict a 'partial output freeze' at a Doha oil meeting, supporting a limited rise in oil prices. The largest producers, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, are expected to freeze oil output, while Iran will likely not join due to its desire to raise production. The deal could bring initial relief but may disintegrate over time, with Brent crude oil futures potentially reaching US$45 per barrel.

site_title: OECD spend on refugees doubled to US$12b in 2015
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) reported a 6.9% increase in development aid in 2015, with spending on refugees doubling to $12 billion. This accounted for 20% of aid expenditure in five European countries. Despite this, aid to the most vulnerable countries remained at 0.3% of gross national income, falling short of the UN target of 0.7%. The OECD urged governments to develop long-term options for meeting future refugee costs and integrating refugees into societies.

images.alt_text: OECD countries more than doubled spending on the migrant crisis last year to US$12 billion, the organisation said on Wednesday.

site_title: Oil can top US$50 a barrel with freeze deal, Bank of America says
summary: Bank of America predicts oil prices can rise above $50 a barrel if an output freeze deal is reached in Doha, tightening global balances by 0.5 million barrels a day. This would push the oil market into a deficit in the third quarter, according to the US bank. The deal, agreed upon by at least 15 countries including OPEC and non-members, comes after a preliminary agreement to freeze output in February. Brent crude has already climbed 30% since the agreement.

site_title: JPMorgan quarterly profit falls 6.7%
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co reported a 6.7% drop in quarterly profit to $5.52 billion, down from $5.91 billion in the same period last year. Revenue from trading and investment banking declined, while costs to cover potential sour loans increased. This was the first US bank to report results since the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike in December. Analysts had expected earnings of $1.26 per share, which was lower than the actual $1.35 per share reported.

site_title: IMF sees US$1.3t in 'at-risk' Chinese company debt
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that corporate China's balance sheets are deteriorating, with US$1.3 trillion in borrowings at risk of default. This represents 14% of all debt at listed Chinese companies, a tripling of 2010 levels. The decline in financial health is attributed to slower economic growth and declining profitability. The IMF's Global Financial Stability Report highlights the growing risk of debt default, which could have significant implications for China's policymakers and the global economy.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund said Wednesday that corporate China's balance sheets have deteriorated to the point that some US$1.3 trillion in borrowings is at risk of default.

site_title: Mossack Fonseca says it's cooperating after Panama office raids
summary: Mossack Fonseca, the law firm behind the Panama Papers leak, is cooperating with investigators following a raid on its Panamanian office. The firm stated it is cooperating with authorities in the investigation into money laundering and organized crime. The raid was carried out by a new prosecutor and a special unit, but no details on the outcome or charges have been released.

site_title: "Living wills" for 5 out of 8 big banks fail US regulators' test
summary: Federal regulators said five of the US's eight largest banks - Bank of America, Bank of New York Mellon, JP Morgan Chase, State Street, and Wells Fargo - do not have credible plans to wind down operations during a crisis without public assistance. This comes after a test by the Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which was part of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform legislation. The failure of these banks' "living wills" raises concerns about their ability to withstand a financial crisis.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 2.69% higher on Wednesday, propelled by a 2.5% increase in China's exports, which rebounded from a 25% drop in February. Meanwhile, research outfit Iceberg Research released questions for Noble Group ahead of its AGM, and Singapore will regulate fintech firms only when they pose risks. Chinese shipbuilder Yangzijiang secured US$510 million in new orders, and ComfortDelGro's shares rose after new rules for private-hire drivers were announced.

site_title: Citi backs Britain's 'in' campaign in EU vote with six-figure donation: source
summary: Citi has made a six-figure donation to the 'Britain Stronger in Europe' campaign group in support of keeping Britain inside the European Union. This donation, estimated to be between 200,000 and 250,000 pounds, comes as some of the world's biggest banks, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan, have also donated large sums to the campaign. The move reflects the financial sector's concerns that a British exit from the EU could threaten its operations and global role.

images.alt_text: Citi has become the latest Wall Street bank to weigh into the campaign to keep Britain inside the European Union by making a six-figure donation to the 'in' campaign, a source familiar with the matter said on Wednesday.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB fund says it may be victim of US$3.5b fraud
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB fund has stated it may be a victim of $3.5 billion fraud, as payments to Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Co were denied. Swiss authorities are investigating two former UAE officials handling Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth funds that guaranteed 1MDB bonds. A report by a Malaysian parliamentary committee identified questionable transactions, including $4.2 billion in suspicious transactions. 1MDB is exploring all avenues to determine its legal position, but denies the claim that neither IPIC nor Aabar knew of the payments. The fund amassed over $17 billion in debt over six years.

site_title: German debt ratio sinking despite higher state spending
summary: Germany's debt ratio is expected to fall to 59.5% of GDP by 2020, meeting EU debt rules sooner than forecast, despite higher state spending. The Finance Ministry's new stability program aims to reduce public debt to 68.5% this year. Germany's public debt has risen to 2.2 trillion euros, but the country's growing GDP is offsetting the increase. The government debt ratio has fallen from 71.2% in 2015, with 2014 seeing Germany's first balanced budget since 1969.

site_title: Citic Envirotech invests 220m yuan in China sludge treatment project
summary: Citic Envirotech has invested 220 million yuan (S$45.9 million) in a sludge treatment project in Weifang City, Shandong province, China. The 700 tonne-per-day plant will treat sludge from six municipal wastewater treatment plants and has a 30-year concession period. This is Citic's first project in sludge treatment, with completion expected by the end of 2016, making it the largest in Shandong province. The project was funded by the proceeds from Citic's issuance of US$175 million senior perpetual securities in November 2015.

site_title: US retail sales fall, hurt by weak auto sales
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.3% in March, hurt by weak auto sales. This marks the first decline in retail sales since November. Economists had forecast a 0.1% increase. Excluding autos, gasoline, building materials, and food services, retail sales rose 0.1% in March after a revised 0.1% gain in February. The decline in retail sales suggests economic growth may have stumbled in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: US retail sales unexpectedly fell in March as households cut back on purchases of automobiles, further evidence that economic growth stumbled in the first quarter.

site_title: South Korea's ruling party to lose parliamentary majority: exit polls
summary: South Korea's ruling conservative party, Saenuri Party, may have lost its parliamentary majority in the general election, according to exit polls. The party is forecast to win between 118-147 seats, while the main opposition Minjoo Party is expected to secure 97-128 seats. The outcome is seen as a significant shift in the country's politics, with the ruling party facing a potential loss of power.

site_title: BBR acquires rest of Angels Medical
summary: BBR Holdings acquired the remaining 51% stake in Angels Medical Private for nearly S$27,780, based on the net book value of assets acquired. This acquisition will make Angels a fully owned subsidiary of BBR, with no material impact on the group's net tangible asset and earnings per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Global steel demand growth to dip in 2016, hit by China: Worldsteel
summary: Global steel demand is expected to fall 0.8% in 2016 due to a slowdown in China, with apparent steel use forecast at 1.488 billion tonnes. China's steel use is predicted to decline by 4% this year and 3% in 2017. Global demand is expected to stabilize in 2017, rising 0.4% to 1.494 billion tonnes.

site_title: UK banks plan to boost lending to households but not firms
summary: UK banks plan to boost mortgage lending, with expected increases in consumer borrowing, while business lending is expected to rise by the smallest margin in four years, reflecting the consumer-led nature of Britain's economic growth. Despite this, business lending is expected to remain static for large companies, and uncertainty over the EU referendum may be deterring investment. Mortgage lending is expected to become even more readily available, with banks targeting to boost market share and capitalize on strong demand from prospective homeowners.

site_title: Opec trims 2016 oil demand growth, says its output rises slightly
summary: Opec lowered its forecast of global oil demand growth for 2016, predicting a slower consumption rate, which would increase excess supply on the market this year. The group's output rose slightly in March, reaching 32.25 million barrels per day. This would result in a 790,000-bpd excess supply if production remains at the March rate. The revised forecast indicates a downward revision in demand growth, which could lead to further revisions.

site_title: Hi-P unit disposes of investment in startup for RM52.6m
summary: Hi-P International's indirect wholly owned subsidiary has disposed of its 4.44% stake in a startup for RM52.6 million, with a pre-tax gain of RM50.4 million expected upon completion. The investment cost was RM2.2 million. The disposal is expected to positively impact the group's financials for the 2016 financial year.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust's Q1 DPU rises 2.7%
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 2.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.71 Singapore cents for its Q1 2016, driven by rental growth in its multi-tenanted malls. Gross revenue rose 1.9% to S$55.6 million, while net property income increased 6.2% to S$36.7 million. CRCT attributes its rise to China's transition to a consumption-driven economy, despite "mounting downward pressure" on the country's economic growth. The trust remains optimistic about its market presence and plans to expand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.11 points to close at 1,723.11, driven by 468 gains and 390 losses in trading of 1.84 billion lots valued at RM2.06 billion.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust sells S$60m of 5% notes due 2020
summary: Croesus Retail Trust has issued S$60 million of 5% senior unsecured notes due 2020 at par as part of its US$500 million euro medium-term note programme. The proceeds will be used for financing or refinancing acquisitions and investments, and for major renovation works at existing properties. The notes were issued at a fixed yen interest rate of 2.65% and were swapped into yen at a forward exchange rate of 82.50 yen to S$1.

site_title: Frasers Property Australia sells Mulgrave business park
summary: Frasers Property Australia has agreed to sell the Satellite Corporate Centre in Mulgrave to Stockland for A$87.6 million. The property, previously owned and managed by Frasers Property since its development by Australand Property Group, will be completed by the end of April 2016. The sale is part of Frasers Property's asset management and capital recycling programme, aiming to redeploy capital to other opportunities.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Lian Beng's Q3 net profit down 5.3%
summary: Lian Beng's net profit for Q3 FY2016 decreased 5.3% to S$17.4 million, with revenue dropping 49.8% to S$101.6 million. The group secured new projects, including a S$117.6 million construction contract and a S$176.3 million civil engineering subcontract. Despite challenges in the construction industry, Lian Beng expects a sustainable flow of activities through FY2019, driven by its established reputation and proven capability.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Prada's Asia bet turns trendsetter into luxury's biggest loser
summary: Prada, the 103-year-old Italian luxury-goods maker, has seen its shares decline by 29% over the past three years, making it the worst-performing major luxury stock. The company's struggles are attributed to a strategy that emphasized adding stores in Asia without refreshing its product lineup, particularly at the lower end of the luxury price spectrum. Prada's Asia sales fell 16% last year, and its profit margin narrowed from 27% in 2012 to 14% last year. The company has announced plans to address its shortcomings, including introducing more affordable handbags and expanding its online presence, but analysts predict a gradual and uneven recovery.

site_title: UBP eyes joint ventures in Asia, but pauses in acquisitions
summary: UBP has completed its acquisition of Coutts International, expanding its Asian presence with assets under management of 14 billion Swiss francs. The bank, now with 130 billion Swiss francs in assets, will explore joint ventures to fuel further growth in private banking and institutional client space. However, it has paused acquisitions for now. This move follows the completion of the Coutts acquisition, which gives UBP a significant foothold in the region.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: ANZ appoints Vishnu Shahaney as CEO for Indonesia
summary: ANZ has appointed Vishnu Shahaney as president director and CEO of PT Bank ANZ Indonesia, effective within a few weeks. Shahaney, who has been CEO of ANZ Singapore since 2010, will lead the Indonesian bank based in Jakarta. He succeeds Joseph Abraham, who is leaving the role after seven years.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: PBOC seen averting cash shortage as US$155b leaves market
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), is expected to roll over medium-term loans to prevent a cash shortage, draining over 1 trillion yuan from the financial system this month. The PBOC will extend loan maturities and may reduce reserve requirements to stabilize the market and maintain liquidity. This move aims to keep borrowing costs low and address slow economic growth and capital outflows, which have driven the yuan to a five-year low.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit posts 3.7% rise in Q1 DPU
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 3.7% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.67 Singapore cents for the first quarter, surpassing its forecast. The Reit's gross revenue slipped 4.5% and net property income dipped 2.5% due to factors such as depreciation of currencies and higher costs. The Reit's annualized yield was 6.34% based on the market closing price per unit. This marks the Reit's first positive DPU result.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL DC Reit posted a 3.7 per cent year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.67 Singapore cents for the first quarter ended March 31, buoyed by net tax and other adjustments.

site_title: Alibaba, Ant Fin invest US$1.25b in China online food-delivery firm Ele.me
summary: Alibaba Group Holding and its Internet finance arm Ant Financial have invested US$1.25 billion in Chinese online food-delivery firm Ele.me, with Alibaba investing US$900 million and Ant Financial investing US$350 million. This investment aims to bolster Ele.me's position in the competitive online food delivery market. Ele.me, which translates to 'Hungry Now?', is part of China's online-to-offline (O2O) services trend, which includes taxi hailing and restaurant review apps.

images.alt_text: Chinese online food-delivery service company Ele.me has raised US$1.25 billion from Alibaba Group Holding and its Internet finance arm Ant Financial, Ele.me and Alibaba said in separate statements on Wednesday.

site_title: India's 2015/16 gold imports drop 16% y/y: NewsRise
summary: India's gold imports dropped 16% in the 2015/16 fiscal year, reaching 926 tonnes, due to higher prices and a jewellers' strike. In March alone, imports fell to 18 tonnes from 125 tonnes in the previous year. The strike, which lasted from March, was in protest of the reintroduction of excise duty on gold jewellery after four years.

site_title: Bank of England says will administer SONIA benchmark from April 25
summary: The Bank of England will take over the administration of the Sterling Overnight Index Average (SONIA) benchmark from April 25, replacing the Wholesale Markets Brokers' Association. The central bank will issue a further consultation on expanding the range of transactions underpinning SONIA later this summer.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England said on Wednesday it will take over the administration of a key British benchmark for interbank lending, the Sterling Overnight Index Average (SONIA), from April 25.

site_title: China said to mull investor quota change in push to open markets
summary: China's regulators are considering allowing global investors freer access to the nation's market through a quota system change. The plan comes after officials removed a quota system for the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor program in February. The move aims to boost appetite for Chinese securities, which could gain entry to global benchmark indexes, and help the nation's slow-growing economy. The Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor program, which enables offshore yuan to be used to purchase stocks and bonds, has a global outstanding quota of 471 billion yuan. The government's push for internationalization appears to be gaining momentum.

site_title: Oil producers risk severe price slump if freeze deal fails
summary: Oil producers risk a severe price slump if a freeze deal fails, following a 30% increase in Brent crude futures since a preliminary agreement was reached in February. The deal, which involves Opec and Russia, is set to be finalized in Doha on April 17, but tensions and discord among countries, particularly Iran, threaten to derail the agreement. If the talks fail, prices could tumble to $33 or even $30 a barrel, according to Saxo Bank. The Kremlin believes there's "hope" of concluding the pact without Iran, but Goldman Sachs warns of a "high risk" of failure.

site_title: Swedish spending on refugees to more than double this year
summary: Sweden's government plans to more than double spending on refugees to 50 billion crowns (S$8.35 billion) in 2016, up from an earlier estimated 19 billion, due to the record 160,000 asylum seekers who arrived last year. This increase in spending is expected to cover higher costs related to housing and other measures. Despite the rising costs, the government's budget deficit is seen narrowing to 0.4% of GDP, driven by faster economic growth forecast at 3.8%.

site_title: German institutes lower 2016 growth forecast to 1.6%
summary: Germany's leading economic institutes have lowered their 2016 growth forecast to 1.6% from 1.8%, citing further slowdowns in 2017 with a predicted 1.5% GDP growth. The institutes attribute the decline to robust private consumption and higher state spending in 2015, which helped the economy grow 1.7% that year, its strongest rate in four years. The government is expected to update its forecast on April 20.

site_title: Greek think tank IOBE sees economy in recession this year
summary: Greek think tank IOBE projects a 1.0% recession this year, with a deeper contraction expected after a 0.3% contraction in 2015. New fiscal measures will impact private consumption and employment, leading to a decline in GDP. Unemployment is forecast to rise to 25.2% this year. Despite this, new indirect taxes are expected to lead to zero inflation or slight deflation. Athens and creditors have yet to conclude a first review of compliance with reforms, paving the way for debt relief talks.

site_title: China COSCO in talks with Greek companies to bid for Athens freight terminal: paper
summary: China's COSCO is in talks with Greek companies Grivalia and PAEGAE to jointly bid on a 250 million euro rail freight terminal project near Athens, Greece. The terminal would have access to Greece's railway network and its largest port at Piraeus, aligning with COSCO's plan to build a European transhipment hub. Bids are due by May 31, and COSCO has already signed a deal to buy a 67% stake in Piraeus Port, further supporting its bid.

site_title: Brussels air traffic disrupted as controllers strike for second day
summary: A strike among air traffic controllers in Brussels has disrupted air traffic for the second day, cancelling about 50 flights from Brussels Airport. The strike began over a proposed dispute settlement, including a rise in the minimum retirement age. Despite increased capacity, some 400 scheduled flights were affected, with Brussels Airlines prioritizing intercontinental destinations. The strike was criticized by the International Air Transport Association, which called it a "kick in the teeth" for airlines and airport staff.

site_title: M1's first-quarter profit down 6.9% to S$42.5m
summary: M1's first-quarter profit declined 6.9% to S$42.5 million due to higher upfront customer acquisition costs, with revenue down 12.6% to S$257.6 million. Earnings per share fell 7.2% to 4.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Singapore stocks close in the black for 2016 after positive China export figures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 2.69% higher on April 13, 2016, reaching 2,890.41 points for the year, after China reported a 11.5% increase in March exports. The positive sentiment followed a 25% plunge in February. The STI is now up eight points for the year, marking the second time it has been in positive territory for 2016, with a 75.76-point gain. Turnover was 1.5 billion units worth S$1.4 billion, surpassing Tuesday's low of S$664 million.

site_title: Indonesia govt supports changes to central bank benchmark rate policy
summary: Indonesia's government supports Bank Indonesia's plan to adopt a new benchmark policy rate, aiming to influence market liquidity. The central bank plans to replace its current reference rate with the seven-day reverse repo rate. Minister Darmin Nasution stated that the new policy aligns with the government's expectations, and the central bank will announce the change on Friday.

site_title: China's output of ten metals fall 4.3% in Jan-Feb: stats bureau
summary: China's production of ten nonferrous metals in January-February 2016 fell 4.3% from a year earlier, reaching 7.612 million tonnes. This marks a reversal of the 5.8% rise in full-year 2015 production. Notably, production of semi-finished aluminium products increased 12.7% and semi-finished copper products output rose 8.5% year-on-year. The delay in releasing full data on China's oil product output and some metals production for the first two months of 2016 has been attributed to the National Bureau of Statistics.

site_title: Ringgit rises sixth day as oil surges on potential output freeze
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose for a sixth consecutive day as Brent crude surged to a four-month high on optimism about a potential oil production freeze at the Doha meeting. The currency gain was attributed to unwinding of dollar-long positions and support from oil prices. Russia's press secretary said a deal on freezing oil output was possible regardless of Iran's stance. The rise in oil prices may help sustain a rebound in the commodity and bolster Malaysia's finances as the region's only major net oil exporter.

site_title: China's steel glut: years in the making, years to resolve
summary: China is facing pressure to address its steel supply glut, which has flooded global markets and threatened the livelihoods of overseas producers. Despite Beijing's rhetoric, the issue is expected to take years to resolve, with production capacity exceeding 1.1 billion tonnes annually, and an estimated 300-400 million tonnes of surplus capacity. The glut was sparked by China's debt-fuelled stimulus in 2009, which drove up steel demand and encouraged rapid capacity expansion. The government has pledged to shut 100-150 million tonnes of old production capacity, but actual production is expected to remain high, with new plants continuing to come online.

site_title: Credit Suisse needs to strengthen board
summary: Credit Suisse needs to strengthen its board of directors after the bank disclosed almost $1 billion in writedowns linked to illiquid positions. The bank posted a bigger-than-expected loss in the fourth quarter due to US$633 million in writedowns and is projecting further writedowns. The bank's largest shareholders support its management and strategy, but experts, such as David Herro, suggest the need for more experienced board members to prevent similar blunders. Credit Suisse has proposed two new non-executive board members, Alexander Gut and Joaquin Ribeiro, to address the issue.

site_title: Asia: Markets track global surge on oil deal hopes
summary: Asia's stock markets rallied on Wednesday, driven by hopes of a deal between Russia and Saudi Arabia to limit oil output, which boosted energy firms. The yen retreated against the dollar after soaring over five percent, and US and European equities followed suit with healthy gains. Major Asian energy companies, such as CNOOC and PetroChina, saw significant gains, while Tokyo led the way with a 2.8 percent surge. The news raised hopes that the global oil glut can be addressed, although analysts note that actual production cuts are needed for lasting impact.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares surge in response to upbeat China trade data
summary: Hong Kong shares surged 3.2% on Wednesday, their best day in two months, following upbeat China trade data. China's March exports rose 11.5% from a year earlier, the first increase since June, and imports fell 7.6% from a year earlier. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) also raised its forecast for China's growth this year. Energy shares, led by Sinopec and PetroChina, rose 5.6% to a five-month high, while resources shares also surged.

site_title: Foreign investors continue yield hunt in emerging Asia bonds in April
summary: Foreign investors continued their search for yields in emerging Asian bonds in April, with Malaysian bonds seeing their largest monthly increase in almost two years. Inflows into Malaysian bonds reached RM11.5 billion, while Indonesian bonds also attracted foreign investors, with a 7.3 trillion rupiah increase in April. South Korea's bond market also saw inflows, driven by a stabilizing won. The global economic outlook, with interest rate cuts and increased monetary stimulus, is expected to continue supporting demand for emerging Asian bonds.

site_title: Australia economy keeps growing as worst of mining drag fades
summary: Australia's economy is expected to grow 2.6% this year, unchanged from the previous forecast, as the worst effects of the mining downturn fade. The country's GDP is forecast to expand 2.9% in 2017. Improving consumer spending, new home building, and export volumes have contributed to the better-than-expected growth. Analysts believe the drag on growth from mining will peak this year and ease thereafter, with some predicting the Reserve Bank of Australia may cut interest rates later in April.

images.alt_text: Australia's economy is seen weathering an unwelcome rise in the local dollar and uncertainty over China this year, while the worst fallout from a mining downturn may finally be over.

site_title: Update: JPMorgan said to cut about 30 jobs at Asia-Pac wealth division
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has cut approximately 30 jobs, or 5% of its headcount, at its Asia wealth management business, mainly affecting its Singapore and Hong Kong offices. The job cuts are part of the bank's effort to focus on wealthier clients.

site_title: EU threatens more action against cheap Chinese steel
summary: The European Union is prepared to take further action against Chinese steel dumping, which threatens 10,000 jobs in Britain. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker pledged support for the steel industry, which employs 360,000 workers across the EU. Juncker described the sector as a high-technology industry that needs investment and protection. The move comes as the industry faces challenges due to EU policies and the Brexit referendum.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks rise to 3-month high on upbeat trade data
summary: Shanghai stocks surged to a three-month high on Wednesday, driven by better-than-expected Chinese trade data. China's March exports rose 11.5% from a year earlier, the first increase since June and largest since February 2015. Energy and resource shares led the gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 1.4% to a closing level of 3,066.64 points. The data is seen as a sign that the economic slowdown may be bottoming, boosting risk sentiment in the short term.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB nears bancassurance deal with Sompo Japan
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd is close to signing a bancassurance deal with Sompo Japan Nipponkoa Holdings Inc, worth around US$200 million. The deal, which involves distributing general insurance products in Southeast Asia, is part of a lucrative bancassurance model where global insurers pay hefty fees for access to lenders' branch networks and emerging markets' growing middle classes. CIMB, Malaysia's second-largest lender, has about 1,000 branches serving 13 million customers in four Southeast Asian markets, making the deal a significant opportunity for the insurer.

site_title: Vietnam posts US$624m trade surplus in March
summary: Vietnam posted a trade surplus of $624 million in March, exceeding the government's estimated $100 million surplus. The country's exports rose 49.7% to $15.12 billion and imports increased 40.8% to $14.49 billion. This marks a significant improvement from Vietnam's first annual trade deficit in four years in 2015, where the trade deficit was $3.5 billion.

images.alt_text: Vietnam registered a trade surplus of US$624 million in March, its customs department said on Wednesday, beating a US$100-million surplus estimated by the government for the same month.

site_title: Toyota recalls 390,000 vehicles over fuel pressure sensors
summary: Toyota Motor Corp has recalled approximately 390,000 vehicles worldwide due to a potential fuel pressure sensor issue, which may result in leakage. The affected vehicles include models sold in Japan from December 2003 to October 2007, as well as the Lexus IS250 in Europe and other regions. A total of 64,000 Lexus IS250 and GS300 vehicles were also recalled. Toyota aims to tighten the fuel pressure sensor attachment to remedy the issue.

site_title: Watchdog wants more competition among banks, market listing process
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has proposed changes to encourage competition among banks and fairer treatment of customers. The watchdog has called for an end to certain contractual clauses that limit clients' choice of financial services providers. The FCA has also identified anti-competitive practices such as cross-selling and rewarding favored investor clients. Additionally, the agency has expressed concerns over unreliable league tables that may distort clients' decision-making. The FCA aims to improve the market listing process and promote informed choices among clients.

site_title: Julius Baer CEO tells AGM still looking at acquisitions
summary: Swiss private bank Julius Baer's CEO, Boris Collardi, stated at its AGM that the firm is still considering acquisitions to boost its business. Collardi emphasized the importance of carefully evaluating potential takeover candidates based on strategic, cultural, and financial criteria. Chairman Daniel Sauter noted that private banking is a cyclical business, which has been reflected in the turbulent start to 2016. The company aims to profit from industry consolidation if opportunities arise.

images.alt_text: Swiss private bank Julius Baer is still eyeing possible purchases to boost its business, its chief executive told shareholders on Wednesday.

site_title: China's big four banks, StanChart, ANZ to join yuan gold benchmark
summary: China's big four banks and three other major financial institutions, including Standard Chartered and ANZ, will join China's yuan-denominated gold benchmark, the Shanghai Gold Exchange. The benchmark, which includes state-owned banks and Chow Tai Fook, aims to increase transparency and pricing efficiency for gold trading in China. The new members will contribute to the price-setting process, marking a significant step towards standardizing yuan-denominated gold prices. This move is expected to improve market efficiency and attract more foreign investors to the Chinese gold market.

images.alt_text: Top Chinese banks, Standard Chartered, ANZ and the world's biggest jewellery retailer Chow Tai Fook will be among 18 members to join China's yuan-denominated gold benchmark, the Shanghai Gold Exchange said on Wednesday.

site_title: China central bank surveys banks on medium-term lending demand, rates unchanged
summary: China's central bank surveyed banks on medium-term lending demand without changing rates, maintaining 2.75%, 2.85%, and 3.00% for three-month, six-month, and one-year loans, respectively. This decision aims to adjust liquidity in the banking system. The move follows a similar operation in February and comes as the country's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Peabody, world's top private coal miner, files for bankruptcy
summary: Peabody Energy Corp, the world's largest privately owned coal producer, filed for US bankruptcy protection on April 13, 2016, citing sharp falls in coal prices and debt from its 2011 leveraged buyout of Australia's Macarthur. The company listed assets and liabilities between $10 billion to $50 billion. Peabody secured $800 million in debtor-in-possession financing from creditors to strengthen liquidity and reduce debt. The bankruptcy filing is the largest in the commodities sector since 2014.

site_title: Lufthansa plans full takeover of Brussels Airlines
summary: Lufthansa plans to acquire the remaining 55% of Brussels Airlines, which it already owns 45%, for a total price of up to $250 million. The move is driven by the airline's strategic location near the European Union institutions in Brussels. The planned takeover comes after a bomb attack on Brussels' airport and subway network in March, which cost the airline around $7.7 million per day. Lufthansa's supervisory board is set to discuss the acquisition on April 27.

site_title: Singapore and Norway reaffirm close and growing ties
summary: Singapore and Norway reaffirmed their close and growing ties, with Norway's Prime Minister Erna Solberg calling Singapore "one of our closest friends in Asia" during her visit. The relationship between the two countries has its roots in 1905, when Norway established a consulate in Singapore, highlighting the city-state's importance as a harbour for Norwegian vessels.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally on commodity bounce; NZ hits record high
summary: Australian shares rose 1.6% to a six-week high, driven by rebounding commodity prices and mining stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,054.7. Meanwhile, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index reached a record high of 6,777.9, up 0.8%. The gains were largely attributed to commodity price rebounds, with mining stocks leading the way.

site_title: Oil prices fall 2% after Saudi oil minister rules out production curb
summary: Oil prices fell 2% in Asian trade on April 13, 2016, after Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi ruled out a production cut, contradicting earlier reports of a Russia-Saudi agreement. This move, combined with a firmer US dollar, pressured prices. Oil futures dropped 1.9% for Brent crude and 2.06% for US crude, hitting a four-month high the previous session. The outcome of the April 17 Opec meeting, which may lead to an oil output freeze, remains uncertain, sparking investor caution.

site_title: Tata, Thyssen in high level talks on European steel joint venture
summary: India's Tata Steel and Germany's Thyssenkrupp are in high-level talks on a potential joint venture for their European steel operations, with shares allocated proportional to the businesses' values. The talks come after Tata Steel's announcement to sell its British business, sparking renewed media reports of industry consolidation in Europe. An agreement is not imminent, and other options besides a joint venture are being discussed.

site_title: EU, ECB will not block Italy bank fund, economy minister says
summary: Italian Economy Minister Pier Carlo Padoan stated that European authorities will not block a bank fund set up by Italian financial institutions to support weaker lenders. The government plans to approve new measures to speed up bankruptcy procedures, aiming to reduce 200 billion euros in non-performing loans. Additionally, the treasury is considering further cutting its 65% stake in Poste Italiane.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise sharply at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose sharply at the open on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.9%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 1.4%, and Paris's CAC 40 also increasing 1.4%. The gains were fueled by surging oil prices, building on previous day's bumper gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rally as Uniqlo operator soars on price-cut news
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 2.84% on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 16,381.22, driven by Uniqlo operator Fast Retailing's surge after its chairman announced price cuts to boost sales. The broader Topix index also advanced 2.55%. The move followed news that the clothing chain would roll back price hikes, which had dented sales. The rally came despite global market uncertainty, with US stocks also reaching fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Beauty obsession drives China selfie app's US$3 billion valuation
summary: China's selfie-editing app Meitu Inc has reached a valuation of US$3 billion in its latest funding round, surpassing household names like Yelp Inc. The app, which has 270 million monthly active users, helps users slim faces, lengthen legs, and conceal acne, capitalizing on China's growing obsession with physical beauty. Meitu plans to expand into facial recognition and smartphones, targeting 5 million smartphone shipments for 2016, and is set to go public in Hong Kong this year.

site_title: Billionaire's spree seen undermining India's airwave auction
summary: Billionaire Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Jio has been aggressively acquiring airwaves to provide 4G services nationwide, potentially undermining India's upcoming airwave auction. Bharti Airtel, India's largest mobile carrier, has also bought significant airwaves, reducing its need to bid for spectrum in the auction. Analysts expect the government to struggle in auctioning off its most sought-after spectrum at high prices, potentially forcing a second auction next year. This development could have significant implications for the Indian telecom industry.

site_title: Bribery probe rattles Och-Ziff, once the steady eddie of hedge funds
summary: Och-Ziff Capital Management, a $42 billion hedge fund firm, faces a bribery probe by the US Department of Justice, which may lead to a fine of $100-400 million. The probe, first reported two years ago, has already led to a $3 billion drop in assets under management. Several investors have exited the firm, citing the bribery investment as a factor. Industry consultants and executives at pension funds have raised concerns about the firm's ability to manage investments and have asked lawyers to review potential exit options.

site_title: 7-Eleven owner said to talk CEO succession amid power vacuum
summary: Seven & i Holdings Co, the parent company of 7-Eleven Japan Co, is scrambling to fill a power vacuum created by the departure of its CEO. The company's nomination panel plans to meet this week to discuss the future roles of top managers, including president Ryuichi Isaka, 58, who narrowly escaped being thrown out last week. Isaka's elevation to president and COO faces opposition from some within the company management, and the company has yet to offer him the roles. COO Noritoshi Murata may resign to take responsibility for the confusion.

images.alt_text: As Seven & i Holdings Co scrambles to fill a power vacuum created by the departure of its chief executive officer, the spotlight is back on the overseer of its Seven- Eleven convenience stores who narrowly escaped being thrown out last week.

site_title: Emerging currencies up as oil rally, China trade boost optimism
summary: Commodity-linked currencies rose due to a surge in oil prices, with the Malaysian ringgit and Australian dollar climbing 0.5% and 0.8% respectively. The news of a deal between Russia and Saudi Arabia to limit oil output lifted crude prices to their highest this year. Upbeat Chinese trade data also boosted sentiment, while the yen slipped off 17-month highs against the dollar.

site_title: BOJ Harada: Natural to ease policy immediately in response to big risks
summary: Bank of Japan board member Yutaka Harada stated it's natural to ease monetary policy immediately in response to big risks to the outlook. He mentioned the BOJ can consider various policy steps, including a rising yen weakening upward price pressure in Japan.

site_title: Gold comes off 3-week high as dollar, Asian equities climb
summary: Gold fell 0.5% to $1,249.40 an ounce as the dollar regained ground from the yen and Asian equities traded near 2016 highs, denting its safe-haven appeal. Chinese trade data offered hope the Asian giant was stabilizing, supporting risk sentiment. The metal had hit a three-week high of $1,262.60 on Tuesday, but technical resistance at $1,260 is expected to hold. Gold had its best quarter in 30 years in the first quarter, driven by a weak dollar and reduced expectations of US rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Gold fell from a three-week high on Wednesday as the dollar regained some ground from the yen and Asian equities traded near 2016 highs, denting the metal's safe-haven appeal.

site_title: UK regulator proposes new IPO process amid competition concern
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) proposes changes to the initial public offering (IPO) process to reduce favoritism and increase transparency for investors. The proposed changes would give analysts at firms not underwriting the IPO more access to company management and change the timing of prospectus publication to provide more information to investors. The FCA aims to address concerns that investment banks may allocate shares to favored customers, potentially shutting out other investors. The changes are part of the regulator's review of equity and debt primary markets, which generate significant revenue for UK banks.

images.alt_text: The regulator that helps oversee UK banks and brokerages proposed changing the process for initial public offerings to reduce favoritism and ensure that investors are better informed.

site_title: China's exports to North Korea up in Q1 despite sanctions
summary: China's exports to North Korea rose 14.7% in Q1, while imports increased 10.8%, defying international sanctions targeting Pyongyang's nuclear program. The main imported products were coal and clothes, while exports consisted of electromechanical products, labor-intensive goods, and agricultural products. This rise in imports is likely due to China's desire to maintain a strong economic relationship with North Korea despite the sanctions.

site_title: Iceberg takes aim at Noble ahead of Thursday AGM
summary: RESEARCH outfit Iceberg Research has released a list of 13 questions for Noble Group ahead of its annual general meeting (AGM) on Thursday. The questions include concerns over Noble's recent financing costs, a rejected bid for summary judgement, and valuation issues with Yancoal. Iceberg claims Noble is struggling with high financing costs and has reassessed the counterparty risk of the company. The research outfit also stated that Noble is expected to achieve a high return on equity (ROE) despite these challenges.

site_title: China's trade data soothes growth fears, boosts markets
summary: China's exports rose 11.5% in March, the first increase in nine months, as the country's economy showed signs of stabilisation. The data, however, was influenced by base effects and seasonal distortions. Despite economists' warnings that the growth is not necessarily driven by stronger global demand, the news boosted markets, with key stock indexes hitting three-month highs and the yuan firming. The trade surplus reached $29.86 billion, driven by strong imports of commodities such as copper and iron ore. The data has lifted investor confidence, with some predicting a stabilisation of trade data over the next six months.

site_title: Health Minister Gan declares war on diabetes
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong declared a war on diabetes due to the country's rising obesity rate and increasing consumption of excessive calories and fat, leading to a higher risk of chronic diseases. Despite Singapore having one of the highest healthy life expectancies in the world, citizens are experiencing longer periods of ill health. Gan aims to address this trend through measures to combat diabetes.

site_title: France to seek extra spending cuts, sticks to growth targets
summary: France plans to cut public spending by 3.8 billion euros in 2016 and 5 billion euros in 2017 to offset lower-than-expected inflation, despite sticking to growth targets of 1.5% for this year and next. The country's inflation target has been reduced to 0.1% for 2016 due to the drop in oil prices, which also led to lower sales tax receipts. France's public deficit targets remain unchanged at 3.3% in 2016 and 2.7% in 2017, despite more pessimistic forecasts from international organizations.

images.alt_text: France on Wednesday said it would curb public spending more to offset lower-than-expected inflation but stuck to growth forecasts of 1.5 per cent for this year and next despite more pessimistic forecasts by international organisations.

site_title: High-stakes oil and gas vote has Italy in a tizz
summary: Italy is divided over a national referendum on oil and gas drilling concessions, with environmentalists and the government at odds over a law change that allows existing concessions within 19km of the coast to last until the fields are depleted. The vote, set for April 17, has sparked concerns over health risks and coastal erosion, with some regions facing significant economic losses if the concessions are reversed. The outcome is seen as a test for Prime Minister Matteo Renzi ahead of a constitutional reforms referendum in October, with many observers predicting little impact on government coffers either way.

site_title: Tesco reports first quarterly sales growth for three years
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, reported its first quarterly sales growth in three years, with a 0.9% increase in UK sales at stores open over a year in its fiscal fourth quarter. The company's full-year operating profit before one-off items was 944 million pounds, exceeding analyst expectations. Tesco attributed the growth to its investment in prices to stay competitive in a challenging market, but warned that profit improvement would slow in the first half of the year. This marks a recovery for the company after a period of decline.

site_title: Luxury or bust for foreign automakers in Japan
summary: Foreign luxury car brands are gaining traction in Japan's car market, driven by high-end buyers like Tokyo businessman Randal Furudera. Despite Japanese cars being seen as dependable, Furudera prefers German-made brands like BMW. Sales of high-end foreign brands are thriving, with deep-pocketed buyers opting for their reputation and prestige over Japanese models. This trend is changing the perception of Japan's car market, which was once considered closed to overseas automakers.

site_title: McCormick walks away from Premier Foods takeover
summary: US spice maker McCormick Foods has withdrawn its takeover proposal for British food company Premier Foods, citing an inability to propose a price that would meet both Premier's board and its own shareholders' expectations. This decision comes after a statement from McCormick stating it would not be able to meet these requirements.

site_title: China's yuan gold benchmark to launch with 18 members
summary: China is launching its yuan-denominated gold benchmark on April 19, with 18 members including top Chinese banks, gold miners, and the world's biggest jewellery retailer. The benchmark will be set twice a day and will be used to determine the price of gold in yuan per gram. The move is seen as China's attempt to become a price-setter for gold, bypassing the US dollar's dominance. Foreign banks and the Shanghai Gold Exchange will also participate, marking China's biggest step in becoming a major player in global gold pricing.

site_title: Li & Fung said to weigh sale of US$400 million distribution unit
summary: Li & Fung Ltd, a Hong Kong-based sourcing company, is considering the sale of its US$400 million distribution unit, LF Asia. The unit, which distributes consumer and healthcare products in China and Southeast Asia, is valued at US$300 million to US$400 million. A sale would allow Li & Fung to focus on its main business of providing sourcing and logistics services to global retailers. The company has been discussing the sale with potential buyers, and a decision has not been made.

site_title: PayPal founders team up again with US$100 million round for Affirm
summary: PayPal co-founders Max Levchin and Peter Thiel have teamed up again, investing $100 million in online lending startup Affirm Inc. The funding round, led by Founders Fund, brings Affirm's total financing to $425 million. The company plans to introduce services such as loyalty rewards and financial management tools, aiming to encourage daily usage. Affirm will use the funds to support partnerships with larger stores and achieve growth goals, amidst a tightening startup funding landscape.

site_title: Condo, HDB rental transactions up double digits amid rent decline in March: SRX
summary: Condominium, apartment, and HDB rental transactions rose 35.5% in March, with 4,331 units rented, a 9.3% increase from the previous year. Rentals for private condominiums and apartments fell 1% in March compared to February, while the overall rental volume was 9.3% higher than the same month last year.

site_title: Shenzhen police gather information on online lenders as China cracks down
summary: Shenzhen police in China have started collecting information from peer-to-peer lenders, as part of a campaign to regulate the country's online financing sector. This move comes after the collapse of Ezubao, China's largest online P2P lender, which defrauded 900,000 investors of over $10.2 billion. Over 1,490 P2P platforms in China have faced operational issues, with more than half of their bosses absconding. The city is the first to take such action, requiring P2P companies to provide information on shareholders, executives, and clients.

site_title: Yen connection bruises Hong Kong's retailers as stocks plunge
summary: Hong Kong retailers face challenges due to the strong yen, which has driven up the cost of importing goods from Japan. Shares of retailers with Japanese product lines have plummeted, with CEC International Holdings Ltd's stock falling 32% this year. The yen's surge has exacerbated the Chinese territory's already gloomy retail outlook, with Hong Kong's retail sales declining 21% in February. Companies are expected to face a double whammy of increased costs and decreased demand, with some planning to close outlets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.740 points to 1719.470 on Wednesday, with a gain in volume of 65.95 million lots worth RM20.92 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 125 to 46.

site_title: BOJ's Harada: Consumer spending not as weak as data suggests
summary: Bank of Japan board member Yutaka Harada stated that consumer spending is likely flat or falling slightly, contradicting demand-side data. He attributed this to rising hourly wages and increased household savings. Harada reiterated the BOJ's readiness to ease policy if risks materialize, with speculation of potential easing as early as this month. The BOJ's next policy meeting on August 28 will likely debate further monetary policy easing, with asset purchases more likely than interest rate cuts.

site_title: China, Hong Kong: Stocks jump to 3-month highs on upbeat China trade data
summary: China's trade data showed a 11.5% increase in March exports, the first rise since June 2015, and a 7.6% decrease in imports. This data led to a surge in Hong Kong and Chinese stocks, with the Hang Seng index up 2.4% and the Shanghai Composite Index up 2.1%. Energy and resource shares were particularly strong, with oil prices reaching their highest level in 2016. The IMF also raised its forecasts for China's growth this year, citing the improving economic outlook.

site_title: Singapore to regulate fintech firms only when they pose risks
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), will regulate fintech firms only when they grow large enough to pose risks to the financial system. The MAS aims to encourage investment in financial technology to boost its role as a regional banking hub. The central bank has committed to investing S$225 million in fintech projects and has set up a FinTech & Innovation Group to promote the sector. Regulations will be tailored to fintech firms, differing from traditional banks, to encourage innovation and growth.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near 10-month peaks on China, commodities
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached 10-month peaks on Wednesday, driven by upbeat Chinese export data and a rally in commodity prices. The Australian dollar rose 1.1% to US$0.7710, while the New Zealand dollar climbed 3% to 75.50 yen. The moves were also influenced by a near 5% rise in iron ore prices and a decline in the yen. The strong currencies stood against the euro, which fell to a three-week low.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rally with other regional markets
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 1.3% to 8,640.00, driven by gains in technology heavyweights like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. The electronics subindex rose 1.4% and the financials subindex gained 0.9%. TSMC jumped 2.2%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.373 per US dollar. Asian markets rallied as risk appetite revived, knocking back the yen and oil.

site_title: Oil takes breather in Asia after rally fuelled by output freeze hopes
summary: Oil prices in Asia took a breather on Wednesday after sharp gains fueled by reports of a Saudi Arabia-Russia agreement to freeze output ahead of a key producers' meeting. Prices rose to their highest levels this year, boosting expectations of a wider deal to ease the oil glut. The meeting, which will bring together Opec members and non-Opec producers, aims to address the nearly two-year-depressed prices. The agreement between Saudi Arabia and Russia has sparked hopes of a broader agreement, but the outcome is still uncertain.

images.alt_text: Oil prices took a breather in Asia on Wednesday after sharp gains fuelled by reports of an agreement between Saudi Arabia and Russia on freezing output ahead of a key producers' meeting.

site_title: Global strategy to hunt tax evaders needed: Australia
summary: Australia's Tax Commissioner Chris Jordan proposes a global investigation into tax evaders linked to the Panama Papers leak, involving 28 countries. A joint investigation will pool data to track down tax evaders, with a focus on individuals and companies with offshore entities. The meeting, chaired by Australia, aims to establish a global strategy for collaboration and information sharing. The move follows the leak of 11.5 million documents revealing tax avoidance by world leaders, celebrities, and sports stars, leading to several countries opening legal probes and the resignation of the Icelandic prime minister.

site_title: Watered-down Thai new year festival kicks off
summary: Thailand's Songkran water festival kicked off on Wednesday, with authorities enforcing a more family-friendly celebration. The three-day event, traditionally a time for paying respects to elders and visiting temples, has become known for its massive water fights. Unlike previous years, the festival is being scaled back to remove alcohol, topless dancers, and other "indecencies." The focus remains on respect and spirituality, with revellers dousing each other in water to cleanse and renew themselves. The festival will run until Saturday.

site_title: Facebook to let users buy tickets directly
summary: Facebook is expanding into e-commerce by allowing users to buy tickets directly on the platform. The social networking giant will connect with ticketing leaders Ticketmaster and Eventbrite, offering a seamless purchase experience for consumers. Users will be able to buy tickets for selected US events listed on Facebook using a QR code integrated within the mobile app. The move aims to simplify the ticket-buying process and is part of Facebook's efforts to increase sales opportunities.

site_title: Hot stock: ComfortDelGro rises after new rules for private-hire drivers
summary: ComfortDelGro shares rose 3.6% to S$2.91 after Singapore announced new rules requiring private-hire car drivers to obtain licenses by mid-2024. The regulations, which apply to Uber and GrabCar drivers, require private-hire cars to be registered with the Land Transport Authority. The new rules aim to improve safety and regulate the private-hire industry.

site_title: Malaysia's biggest pension fund to double property investments
summary: Malaysia's US$178 billion Employees Provident Fund (EPF) plans to double its real estate investments, aiming to diversify its holdings from mostly bonds and stocks. EPF's real estate exposure is currently less than 4%. The fund, which manages retirement savings for 13 million people, is looking to buy more assets in continental Europe, including properties like 11-12 St James Square in London. This move aims to increase its real estate presence and provide more investment options for its members.

site_title: Taiwanese deported from Kenya "suspected of fraud in China"
summary: A group of 32 Taiwanese and 45 Kenyans were deported from Kenya to China after being acquitted in a cyber crime case. The Taiwanese, suspected of telecoms fraud in China, were accused of causing millions of yuan in losses and some victims took their own lives. China views Taiwan as a wayward province and has not ruled out using force to ensure unification. The incident has enraged Taiwan, which accuses Beijing of kidnapping. China has invited Taiwan law enforcement officials to discuss tackling such fraud.

site_title: South Koreans vote for new parliament amid discontent over sluggish economy
summary: South Koreans voted for a new parliament, with the ruling conservative Saenuri Party expected to regain a majority despite a sluggish economy. Voter turnout was low, potentially benefiting President Park Geun-hye's party. Voters expressed frustration with parliament's focus on protecting interests over addressing key issues like jobs and national security. A strong showing by Saenuri could lead to its candidate winning the 2017 presidential election, succeeding President Park.

site_title: China first-quarter growth slows to 6.7%: AFP survey
summary: China's first-quarter GDP growth slowed to 6.7% in January-March, down from 6.8% in the previous quarter, according to a survey of 19 economists. This marks the weakest growth in a quarter of a century. The government has stepped up policy support to stabilize the economy, which is expected to further weaken this year, with a median prediction of 6.6% for 2016. The slowdown has raised concerns over the Chinese economy, with global markets and ratings agencies Moody's and Standard & Poor's lowering their outlooks on China's sovereign bonds.

site_title: Cordlife's new COO also appointed executive director
summary: Cordlife Group appointed Tan Poh Lan as its new COO, effective Tuesday, who will also serve as executive director. Tan previously held CEO positions at various hospitals and healthcare firms, including Fortis Healthcare Singapore. Her appointments follow a bourse filing stating she would "work closely with the board".

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cordlife, Keppel, OSIM
summary: Cordlife Group appointed Tan Poh Lan as its new chief operating officer after CEO Jeremy Yee's resignation. Keppel Corp downplayed market talk of Floatec's possible dissolution. OSIM International faced scrutiny from Securities Investors Association of Singapore over founder Ron Sim's unintentional purchases of shares above his takeover offer price.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks climb at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose in early trading on April 13, 2016, driven by oil price rallies and reports of a Russia-Saudi Arabia agreement to freeze output. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong climbed 1.15%, while the Shanghai composite index gained 0.59%. The rallies followed similar gains across Asia, New York, and Europe.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rally in opening trade
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 1.34% at the start of trade on Wednesday, driven by sharp gains on Wall Street and higher oil prices. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 16,142.71, while the Topix index gained 1.28%. The rally follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as traders brush off new US President Trump threats.

images.alt_text: A painting found in the attic of a house in southwest France two years ago was attributed to the Italian master Caravaggio by private French experts who hailed its discovery on Tuesday as a great event in the history of art.

site_title: British minister reveals affair with sex worker
summary: British Culture Secretary John Whittingdale admitted to a past affair with a sex worker, occurring between 2013 and 2014. He ended the relationship after discovering the woman was trying to sell her story to a newspaper. Whittingdale claimed the affair had no influence on his decisions as Culture Secretary, but Labour criticized the press for using the information to hold him over.

images.alt_text: A British minister admitted on Tuesday that he had been in a relationship with a sex worker, but said that he did not know her occupation at the time.

site_title: China's swelling junkyards are readying iron ore's next threat
summary: China's growing scrap metal market poses a significant threat to the world's ailing iron-ore producers, with the country's scrap supply expected to double in the next decade and accelerate at an even faster rate. As a result, iron-ore prices are expected to decline, potentially contracting by 50% by 2040. China's middle class is driving the growth in scrap metal, with the nation's ore demand potentially falling by 50% by 2040 as recycled metal becomes a more profitable option.

site_title: Asia: Shares extend rally on China trade relief
summary: Asian share markets extended gains on Wednesday after China reported a 18.7% increase in exports and a 1.7% decrease in imports, suggesting the economy is stabilizing. Shanghai stocks rose 1.9%, Japan's Nikkei gained 2.4%, and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 added 1.1%. Oil prices pared losses, with Brent crude easing 27 cents to $44.43 a barrel, following a brief run-up on reports of a potential oil output cap. The rally boosted energy stocks and the Canadian dollar, while the yen and euro also gained.

site_title: China's missing vaccines challenge patients and drugmakers
summary: China's lack of approved vaccines for common conditions, such as pneumonia and cervical cancer, is hindering public health due to stifling regulations. Patients are forced to travel abroad, like Sam Ding, a tech professional in southern China, who crossed the border to Hong Kong twice to get his daughter vaccinated. The Chinese vaccine market is expected to grow at 17% a year, but more than 30 vaccine products aren't sold on the mainland due to registration timelines. The WHO recommends vaccines for all countries, but China's approval processes delay their availability, posing a challenge to global pharmaceutical companies.

site_title: Pound halts gains as 'Brexit' risk outweighs quicker inflation
summary: The pound halted its two-day gain against the US dollar as concerns about a potential Brexit outweighed a boost from a higher-than-expected inflation rate. The International Monetary Fund cut its UK growth forecast, warning of severe economic damage if Britain quits the EU. A poll showed 42% of voters support remaining in the single market, compared to 45% who back leaving. Sterling also fell against the euro, with the IMF's warning adding to uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The pound ended a two-day gain versus the US dollar as concern that the UK would vote to leave the European Union outweighed an earlier boost to the currency when data showed UK inflation quickened more in March than economists predicted.

site_title: Yangzijiang bags new shipbuilding orders worth US$510 million
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings) has secured US$510 million in new orders for six 400,000 DWT very large ore carriers from ICBC Leasing, a subsidiary of China's largest state-owned commercial bank. The orders, valued at US$510 million, are the largest dry bulk carriers Yangzijiang has ever received, with deliveries scheduled between 2018 and 2019.

site_title: New Zealand food prices rise in March
summary: New Zealand food prices rose 0.5% in March, according to Statistics New Zealand, with food making up nearly 19% of the consumer price index. This marks a slight decrease from the same month last year.

site_title: South Korea has 'room' to cut rate and sell more debt, Yoo says
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Yoo Il Ho said the country has room to lower its interest rate and issue more debt if needed to meet its 3.1% growth target for 2016. The benchmark interest rate is record-low at 1.5%, and the debt-to-GDP ratio is lower than most developed economies. Despite the International Monetary Fund's forecast of 2.7% growth, Yoo expressed caution and noted that fiscal policy may be necessary if the international economy worsens. The government has already introduced expansionary policies, and a further budget is possible if needed.

site_title: Australia consumer mood darkens in April: survey
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment index fell 4% in April, its second consecutive decline, amid concerns about the economy and family finances. The index, which measures consumer confidence, dropped to 95.1, with pessimists outnumbering optimists. Despite this, respondents were more confident about buying major household items. The decline in consumer sentiment contrasts with a survey of Australian businesses, which showed rising sales, profits, and employment. The Liberal government's upcoming budget may have contributed to the decline, with analysts suggesting consumer sentiment surveys may not accurately reflect spending habits.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.8% up on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.8% to 2,836.72, following a rally in crude oil prices that touched a four-month high. Energy-related stocks led the gains, with Ezra Holdings and Rex International among the most actively traded counters. The market's optimism is partly due to Wall Street's overnight gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Wal-Mart ties with ChannelAdvisor to boost online assortment
summary: Wal-Mart is partnering with ChannelAdvisor to expand its online assortment, aiming to increase the number of products on its website to 9 million items. The deal will make it easier for thousands of retailers and vendors to get their products on Wal-Mart's site, currently limited to around 500 third-party sellers. The partnership is part of Wal-Mart's efforts to boost its online business, following major investments in distribution facilities and technology platforms. Seth Beal, head of Wal-Mart's online marketplace, expects the number of third-party sellers to increase to thousands this year.

site_title: Japan pinball maker tied to iPhone hack set for terror fight
summary: Japan's Cellebrite Mobile Synchronization Ltd, a forensics unit of a pinball maker, is expanding its work against terrorism. The company's CEO, Masanori Yamaguchi, plans to spend up to $249 million to acquire or merge with companies to expand its data extraction business. Cellebrite has worked with law enforcement on iPhone hacks in terrorist attacks, including the San Bernardino and Paris shootings. The company has signed an agreement with Interpol to provide digital forensic equipment and training services. Demand for its services is expected to grow 20% annually, and Yamaguchi is open to teaming up with companies with unique technology.

site_title: Authorities raid law firm in Panama Papers tax dodging scandal
