summary: Panamanian police raided the headquarters of Mossack Fonseca, a law firm implicated in the Panama Papers tax dodging scandal. The raid occurred without incident and will include searches of the firm's Panama City headquarters and branches. The move follows the leak of documents revealing how wealthy and powerful individuals used offshore companies to hide assets. This is part of a global response to the scandal, which has had repercussions worldwide.

site_title: China has a 2.5 trillion yuan invite-only stock market that's booming
summary: China's National Equities Exchange and Quotations (NEEQ) market is booming, with over 5,000 companies listed and a total capitalization of 2.5 trillion yuan. Founded in 2012, the over-the-counter venue offers a less stringent path to listing for cash-hungry companies, attracting institutional investors. Despite concerns over market efficiency and volatility, regulators are considering smoothing the path for listed entities to move to China's public venues. The market is under direct supervision of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, which has increased scrutiny and enforcement in recent months.

site_title: Singapore-listed Sino Grandness looking to list subsidiary Garden Fresh in HK
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group, a Singapore-listed company, is planning to list its subsidiary Garden Fresh Group in Hong Kong. The application was submitted on March 31, with DBS as the sole sponsor. Upon completion, Sino Grandness will own 63.96% of Garden Fresh's issued share capital. This move aims to tap into equity and capital, with plans to change Garden Fresh's name to "Grandness Group" or another name chosen by Sino Grandness. The company expects to benefit from Garden Fresh's 70% turnover and 86.3% market share in China's loquat juice market.

site_title: OECD's Gurria urges G7 to coordinate fiscal spending boost
summary: OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria urged the G7 to coordinate a fiscal spending boost to bolster global growth, focusing on infrastructure, education, and productivity-improving policies. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe seemed receptive to the idea, but discussions with other officials are needed to set the G7 agenda. Gurria advised Japan to stick with its plan to raise its sales tax, despite some advisers calling for it to be shelved. This move comes as the global economy continues to struggle with low growth, with the Group of 20 calling for more fiscal spending and less reliance on monetary policy.

images.alt_text: OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria pressed on Wednesday for the Group of Seven rich countries to coordinate a a fiscal spending boost to bolster global growth.

site_title: Singapore set to forgo easing to save tools for 'Brexit', China
summary: Singapore's central bank is unlikely to ease monetary policy when it meets Thursday, maintaining its current stance to prepare for global risks such as a possible UK exit from the EU and a further slowdown in China. Despite the government's expansionary budget, the Monetary Authority of Singapore will reserve its firepower, with economists surveyed by Bloomberg predicting a likely delay in policy easing to October. The Singapore dollar is expected to weaken to S$1.40 to the US dollar by end-December, driven by heightened global risks and the International Monetary Fund's dimmed view of the world economy.

site_title: US crude falls on profit taking, oversupply worries
summary: US crude futures fell 46 cents to $41.71 a barrel in early Asian trade on Wednesday, driven by profit taking and concerns over a larger-than-expected build in US crude stocks. Despite Russia and Saudi Arabia reaching a consensus on an oil output cap, investors are skeptical about the move, citing the need for oil prices to drop below $50 a barrel to warrant an output cap. US crude stocks rose 6.2 million barrels last week, and official data is due out later on Wednesday, further fueling concerns about oversupply.

site_title: Gold eases as dollar ticks up, but still near 3-week high
summary: Gold prices eased 0.1% to $1,254.10 an ounce, despite a dollar strengthening and equities rising, as investors maintain a preference for the metal due to global economic uncertainties and potential US rate hikes. The metal had reached a three-week high on Tuesday, but pared gains after the dollar rebounded against the yen. Brent crude oil prices surged to a four-month high, driving energy equities higher, and investors remain bullish on gold's price rally in top consumer China.

site_title: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton declared Missouri primary winners, a month on
summary: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton have been declared the winners of the Missouri primaries, a month after the initial vote. Trump earned 40.84% of the vote, securing 25 delegates, while Clinton won 49.6% of the vote, securing 34 delegates. The close margins mirror the previous contest, with Clinton and Trump leading in the presidential race ahead of the next primaries on April 19 in New York.

site_title: Painting found in French attic is 120 million euro Caravaggio, say experts
summary: A painting discovered in a French attic in 2014 is attributed to Italian master Caravaggio, worth 120 million euros. Found in the attic of a house near Toulouse, the 1604-1605 painting depicts Biblical heroine Judith beheading an Assyrian general. Experts hail its discovery as a significant event in art history, praising the painting's exceptional condition despite being forgotten for over 150 years. French authorities have banned the painting from leaving France due to its "great artistic value" and potential identification as a lost Caravaggio work.

site_title: EU Commission buys time to decide on visas for US, Canada
summary: The European Commission has delayed a decision on introducing visa requirements for US and Canadian citizens by three months, asking EU member states and the European Parliament to discuss their stance. The move is seen as unlikely due to political considerations and the negative impact on Europe's tourism industry, which relies heavily on leisure travel from the US and Canada. The European Tourism Association estimates that introducing visas would cut a third of leisure travels to Europe, affecting millions of jobs and the EU economy. A decision is now due by July 12, 2016.

site_title: Gambling only a short-term fix for cash-starved states: study
summary: A study by the Rockefeller Institute of Government found that gambling in the US only provides a short-term revenue boost for cash-strapped states, with long-term growth slowing or reversing. Despite over a dozen states legalizing or expanding gambling since the Great Recession, revenues have softened due to market saturation and declining casino revenues. Lotteries revenue fell for the second consecutive year in 2015, and overall, gambling accounts for only 2% to 2.5% of a state's general revenue.

site_title: Volkswagen plans bonus cuts after diesel scandal pressure
summary: Volkswagen is considering significant cuts to bonuses for senior managers amid pressure from Lower Saxony, the company's second-largest shareholder, to address executive pay following the "Dieselgate" scandal. The company's 2014 compensation package for nine executives totaled 70 million euros, with variable pay exceeding 54 million euros. The supervisory and management boards are discussing models that could entail a substantial reduction in variable pay, aiming to set an example for executive compensation. The proposed changes are set to be approved on April 22 and published with VW's annual report on April 28.

site_title: 'Brexit' may alter, not cut, UK immigration, Open Europe says
summary: A report by Open Europe suggests that the UK's decision to leave the European Union may not lead to a significant reduction in immigration, as businesses and an aging population would continue to require a skilled labor force. The government could adopt a more selective policy favoring skilled migrants, potentially boosting the share of immigrants from outside the EU. This contrasts with the argument made by Brexit supporters that the EU's freedom-of-movement rules have depressed wages and put pressure on public services.

site_title: American Apparel lays off workers, mulls some outsourcing: LA Times
summary: American Apparel is laying off approximately 500 employees as part of its production overhaul, which may include outsourcing to another US manufacturer. The company aims to address a mismatch between workers and manufacturing, cutting down on garments made throughout the year to clear inventory. Following years of losses, American Apparel filed for bankruptcy in October and expects to be profitable in 2018, with CEO Paula Schneider stating that outsourced production will still be "American-made."

site_title: Brazil's US$8 billion intervention no match for impeachment glee
summary: Brazil's central bank sold $8 billion in foreign-exchange reverse swaps to weaken the real, which reached its highest level since August 2015 amid impeachment speculation against President Dilma Rousseff. The move follows a 14% year-to-date climb in the real to 3.4889 per US dollar. A committee of Brazil's lower house voted to recommend impeachment, with a vote possible within a week. The central bank aims to keep the real below 3.50 per dollar, but the move is seen as a test of its resolve in the face of market optimism over a potential change in government.

images.alt_text: A record US$8 billion intervention by Brazil's central bank couldn't keep the real from climbing to the highest level since August amid bets that president Dilma Rousseff will be impeached.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, HSBC, KfW arrange 3.5b euros for Egypt Power
summary: Deutsche Bank, HSBC, and KfW IPEX have arranged 3.5 billion euros in financing for Egypt's 14.4 gigawatt power plants, the world's largest gas and steam turbine power plants, to boost Egypt's generation capacity by 50%. The project, valued at 6 billion euros, is expected to be completed by 2018. The three lenders coordinated finance from 17 international banks, with Siemens AG building the turbines. The deal reflects the drive of both German and Egyptian governments to sustain close ties despite regime changes in Egypt.

site_title: Deutsche Bank freezes plans for North Carolina jobs over transgender law
summary: Deutsche Bank has frozen plans to create 250 new jobs in North Carolina after the state's transgender law, which prohibits anti-discrimination protections based on sexual orientation and gender identity, was enacted. The law also bars transgender people from using bathrooms or locker rooms in schools and other public facilities that do not match the sex on their birth certificate. This move follows other corporate protests of the law, which has sparked concerns over LGBT equality rights.

site_title: Pfizer must face revived Celebrex, Bextra safety lawsuit
summary: A federal appeals court revived a class-action lawsuit against Pfizer, accusing the company of misleading shareholders about the safety of its Celebrex and Bextra pain-relieving drugs. The 3-0 vote returns the case to the district court, where it will consider whether Pfizer is liable for statements made by its predecessors, GD Searle & Co and Pharmacia Corp, that allegedly concealed cardiovascular risks. The lawsuit, which began in 2004, seeks damages for investors who bought Pfizer stock between 2000 and 2005.

site_title: Better mental health treatment would boost nations' economies: WHO
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) states that investing in better mental health treatment yields a significant economic return, with every dollar spent producing a $4 return in improved health and productivity. Common mental disorders such as anxiety and depression cost the global economy $1 trillion annually, affecting 615 million people worldwide. The WHO estimates that increased spending on treating these disorders could boost countries' economic growth and development.

site_title: South Korea: Financial markets closed on Wednesday
summary: South Korea's financial markets closed on Wednesday due to a public holiday, resuming trading on Thursday, April 14. This article is not relevant to the provided content.

site_title: Fed's Lacker signals roughly four rate hikes could be needed in 2016
summary: Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker signals that the Federal Reserve may need to raise interest rates around four times in 2016, contrary to the policymakers' previous view of two rate increases. This prediction comes after the Fed cut its projection in March, citing concerns over global economic growth. Lacker's statement suggests a more cautious approach to monetary policy, aligning with the Fed's previous December projection.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve will likely have to raise interest rate around four times this year, Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker said on Tuesday.

site_title: Greece to submit tax, pension reforms to conclude bailout review
summary: Greece is set to submit tax and pension reform bills to parliament next week in an effort to persuade its international lenders that it is meeting the terms of its bailout deal. The latest review of Greece's progress has been delayed due to disagreements among lenders and resistance in Athens to unpopular measures. The review is expected to resume after the IMF spring meetings, potentially delaying a crucial cash handout to the debt-stricken nation.

site_title: Two Fed officials urge caution on timing of next rate hike
summary: Two Federal Reserve officials, Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker and Dallas Fed chief Robert Kaplan, urged caution on the timing of the next interest-rate hike due to slower US growth, a stronger dollar, and global weakness. They echoed recent calls by Fed Chair Janet Yellen and others to adopt a slow approach to policy tightening, which suggests that officials may not act when they meet on April 26-27. The officials expressed concerns about persistently low inflation risks undermining the central bank's 2% inflation goal.

site_title: US small business confidence sinks to fresh 2-year low
summary: US small business confidence hit a 2-year low in March, dipping to 92.6 due to persistent worries about sales and profits. The National Federation of Independent Business reported a 0.3-point decline, the lowest since February 2014. Economic growth is expected to slow, with GDP growth estimates below 1% for the first quarter. Small business owners are cutting prices to boost sales, while attitudes towards capital spending improved slightly. The NFIB warns that a recession signal may be flashing, prompting concern about the economy's trajectory.

site_title: Facebook's next frontier: chatbots, live video
summary: Facebook is expanding its Messenger app by allowing developers to build chatbots, enabling users to communicate with businesses one-on-one. The move aims to dominate enterprise transactions and customer service, shifting users away from third-party websites and phone lines. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg also announced the live video product, Facebook Live, is open to developers to create new features. The company is promoting live video through partnerships with celebrities and media companies to take on rivals like Twitter and Snapchat.

site_title: Nigeria says China offered US$6b loan for infrastructure
summary: China has offered Nigeria a US$6 billion loan to fund infrastructure projects, as both countries signed a currency swap deal to boost trade. The loan comes as Nigeria faces financial challenges due to the drop in crude oil prices. The announcement follows months of talks between the two countries.

site_title: Chinese investment in US rises to record, boosting jobs
summary: Chinese direct investment in the US reached a record $45 billion in 2015, creating 13,000 full-time jobs, according to a report by the National Committee on US-China Relations and Rhodium Group. This brings the total number of jobs linked to Chinese investment in the US to over 90,000 since 2000. Investors from China have also secured over $30 billion in deals and projects for this year, further driving economic growth and job creation.

site_title: China key to record global movie earnings
summary: Global movie earnings reached a record US$38.3 billion last year, fueled by China's 51.2% growth and young people's spending on cinema tickets. The US, Mexico, Germany, Spain, and Brazil also saw significant increases, with the North American box office surpassing US$11 billion for the first time. NATO president John Fithian attributed the growth to improved theaters, expanded offerings, and the moviegoing appetite of adolescents, citing the diverse casting of films as a factor. Box office receipts are expected to continue soaring with upcoming blockbusters.

site_title: China's "moonlight" generation puts tomorrow's growth on credit
summary: China's "moonlight generation" of young, tech-savvy consumers is boosting economic growth by embracing credit, despite stretching their own resources to breaking point. This cohort, who keep their savings in digital wallets, are spending and borrowing more, with household debt reaching nearly 60% of income levels. Policymakers see this as a welcome development, but experts warn of potential risks, including abuse of credit and a risk of a property bubble. As China's savings rate remains high, economists suggest that the moonlight generation's parents may bail them out when things go wrong.

site_title: US: Big oil rally propels stocks higher
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday as petroleum producers and large banks gained, driven by higher oil prices and reports of an agreement between Saudi Arabia and Russia to freeze output. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 0.94% and 0.97%, respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.80%. The gains were despite a downcast growth forecast from the International Monetary Fund. Aluminum producer Alcoa fell 2.7% after announcing job cuts, but other metals-related equities advanced.

site_title: Nauru becomes 189th member of IMF, World Bank
summary: Nauru, the world's smallest independent republic, has become the 189th member of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank. The tiny South Pacific island nation applied for membership in 2014 and has faced challenges in sustaining growth and ensuring fiscal and debt sustainability. By joining the institutions, Nauru gains access to financial support, technical assistance, and expertise in dealing with Pacific area issues. The move comes after South Sudan joined the IMF and World Bank in April 2012.

site_title: Worried IMF cuts world growth forecast, warns over Brexit
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its global growth forecast for the third straight quarter, warning of "severe" damage if Britain quits the European Union. The Fund cited weak growth, rising protectionism, and financial and political risks, including the Syria conflict and global warming. The forecast was lowered to 3.2% this year, down 0.2 percentage points from its January outlook. The IMF also warned of a risk of a full stall in global growth without efforts to boost investment and demand, particularly in light of the looming Brexit referendum.

site_title: World's once-biggest gem field idle as US$13 billion said stolen
summary: Zimbabwe's Marange diamond field, once the world's largest, has been idle since February 22, 2016, as security forces and the state-owned Zimbabwe Consolidated Diamond Co seized the deposits. The move was taken to curb illicit diamond trade, which President Robert Mugabe claimed has cost the economy over US$13 billion. The diamond field, a major source of diamonds in 2013, has been left unattended, with cattle grazing near the site. The seizure aims to reduce the economic impact of the illicit trade, which has contributed to the country's economy halving in size since 2000.

site_title: Oil surges to four-month high as Russians, Saudis seen agreeing
summary: Crude oil surged to a four-month high as Saudi Arabia and Russia were seen agreeing on an output freeze, according to a reported diplomatic source. The deal could cap production at OPEC members, including Russia, on April 17. Oil prices rose 3.9% in New York and 4.4% in London, with WTI reaching $41.78 a barrel and Brent reaching $44.45 a barrel. The market expects a "soft agreement" that would not significantly impact fundamentals, with a potential production cut in June.

site_title: IS ranks at lowest level since 2014: US official
summary: The Islamic State group's ranks have been reduced to their lowest level since 2014, with 40% of its territory in Iraq and 10% in Syria taken back by international and local military action. US Deputy Secretary of State Antony Blinken stated that IS's numbers are the lowest since 2014, with estimates ranging from 20,000 to 31,500 fighters in 2014. The US-led international coalition continues to push back IS fighters, and President Barack Obama will convene his national security team to evaluate progress and propose strategies to increase pressure on the group.

site_title: Satisfaction with finance, insurance and healthcare lower in 2015
summary: Singapore's customer satisfaction index fell 1.3% in 2015, with a national score of 70.2 points, after four consecutive years of improvement. The decline was attributed to poor performances in the finance and insurance and healthcare sectors. The finance and insurance sector declined 2% and the healthcare sector declined 2% compared to the previous year. The institute suggests that improving touch points, particularly in the banking sector, and enhancing perceived quality and perceived value could address the decline in customer satisfaction.

site_title: US dollar edges higher vs euro, falls vs Canadian dollar
summary: The US dollar edged higher against the euro but fell against the Canadian dollar due to a surge in oil prices, boosting commodity-linked currencies. Oil prices reached 2016 highs amid speculation of an Opec meeting that could alleviate the global oil glut. The Canadian dollar rose, while the dollar fell ahead of the Bank of Canada's interest-rate decision. The euro and yen also rose against the yen, amid reports of potential currency intervention by Japan to counter a rising yen.

site_title: Axa said to plan wealth sales that may fetch £500 million
summary: AXA SA, France's largest insurer, is in talks to sell its UK life-insurance and wealth-investment units, potentially raising £500-700 million. The company is likely to sell Elevate, a platform for UK independent financial advisers, and SunLife, a UK business providing life-insurance and funeral-costs coverage. Standard Life Plc is bidding for Elevate. Axa's UK business had €706 million of revenue last year, up 9.5% from the previous year. The sales are part of Axa's efforts to streamline its UK units.

images.alt_text: Axa SA, France's largest insurer, is in talks to sell most of its UK life-insurance and wealth- investment units, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Economic woes, threats from North shadow South Korea vote
summary: South Korea votes in legislative elections amid economic woes and heightened tensions with North Korea. President Park Geun Hye's handling of the economy is under scrutiny, with rising unemployment, plummeting exports, and high household debt. The opposition Minjoo Party frames the vote as a referendum on Park's policies, but internal infighting may split liberal votes. Military tensions on the Korean peninsula, including North's fourth nuclear test and long-range rocket launch, are expected to benefit the conservative Saenuri Party, which seeks a majority to push through legislation.

site_title: Amsterdam airport partly evacuated in security alert, man detained
summary: Amsterdam's Schiphol airport was partially evacuated and one person arrested after a security alert, with authorities describing the situation as "suspicious." The airport has been on high alert since the March 22 Brussels attacks. Television images showed heavily armed special military police patrolling the area. The incident occurred without further information from authorities, and the motive behind the alert remains unclear.

site_title: As Chinese banks speed up expansion in Australia, regulators edgy
summary: Chinese banks are rapidly expanding their presence in Australia, with total loans by Chinese banks growing 36% in the year to end-February, more than double the overall 9% growth in loans. This expansion is concerning for the Australian regulator, the Reserve Bank of Australia, which warns of the potential for systemic threats and overheated markets. The rapid growth of foreign lenders, spearheaded by Chinese banks, is also creating challenges for the country's four major domestic banks, which are seeking to improve shareholder returns and profits amid slowing revenue growth and stricter regulatory capital rules.

images.alt_text: China's banks are muscling into Australia by financing fast-growing Chinese property and corporate investments Down Under, invoking a warning from the Australian regulator that rapid expansion by foreign lenders is a potential systemic threat.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff brands VP a traitor, denounces 'coup'
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff has branded her vice-president Michel Temer a traitor and coup-plotter ahead of an impeachment vote scheduled for Sunday. Rousseff accused Temer of practicing the speech he would give if she is impeached, which she claims is evidence of a conspiracy. The impeachment vote is a result of a congressional committee's recommendation to oust Rousseff on charges of manipulating government accounts. If the lower house approves the impeachment, the case will go to the Senate, where a two-thirds majority is needed to confirm Rousseff's removal.

site_title: Uber and GrabCar drivers to be licensed by H1 2017
summary: Singapore to require ride-hailing drivers to be licensed by mid-2017, with their private-hire cars to be registered and subject to a demerit point system to protect commuters' interests and safety. Drivers must apply for a Private-Hire Car Driver's Vocational Licence and display a tamper-evident decal on their vehicle. The changes aim to regulate the chauffeured-services industry and promote fair competition between taxi services and private-hire services.

site_title: US keeps 'AAA' debt rating: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings has reaffirmed the US' top 'AAA' debt rating, citing the country's strong economy, 2.4% growth rate, and leading reserve currency status. Despite rising debt, Fitch notes it remains within the 'AAA' rating's tolerance.

site_title: Tokio Marine Life Singapore to get new CEO in June
summary: Tokio Marine Life Singapore's CEO, Lance Tay, will step down on May 31 after four years at the helm. A new CEO, identified by the insurer, will begin on June 1, 2016. The move comes amid a slowdown in the insurer's business in 2015, but its market share of the life business was high in 2014.

site_title: Oil rally lifts US, European stocks
summary: US and European stocks rose on Tuesday as oil prices surged to their highest level of 2016, driven by a potential agreement between Saudi Arabia and Russia to freeze oil production. The International Monetary Fund's downcast global growth outlook was largely overlooked, and investors focused on the oil rally. The Nikkei 225 in Tokyo also gained, while the yen fell back from recent highs. The gains were despite the IMF's warning of "severe" damage if Britain quits the European Union, which begins campaigning on June 23.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher led by miners; Italian banks plunge
summary: European shares rose 0.6% at the end of a choppy session, led by gains in mining companies, while Italy's banks fell 3.7% after a two-day winning streak was snapped. The Italian banking index reversed initial gains as investors questioned the effectiveness of a state-backed deal to support weaker lenders.

site_title: Trump, Clintons go way back, new documents show
summary: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton had a good relationship in the 1990s, with Bill Clinton inviting Trump to several White House events and even a photo opportunity in 1996. Trump was also congratulated on his 50th birthday by the White House. Although the released documents do not contain any startling revelations, they show the White House following Trump's activities in 1999 and advising Bill Clinton on how to respond to potential celebrity presidential candidates, including Trump. The documents were released in response to a Freedom of Information Act request.

site_title: CEO of Berkshire's Gen Re to retire; Jain's role grows
summary: Tad Montross, CEO of Berkshire's Gen Re, is retiring by year's end, with Ajit Jain's role expanding as he will report to Montross' successor, whose name hasn't been announced. Montross, 60, has served as Gen Re's chairman and CEO since 2008. Jain, 64, oversees Berkshire Hathaway Reinsurance Group and has been seen as a potential successor to Warren Buffett at Berkshire's helm. Montross' retirement comes after General Re's performance improved in recent years, with the reinsurer contributing $18.6 billion of float to Berkshire's overall $87.7 billion total.

site_title: Crisis-hit Brazil threatened by US$89b state debt time bomb
summary: Brazil's federal government faces a potential debt crisis, with states seeking to apply simple interest on debt owed to the federal government, which could cost the Treasury US$89 billion in lost revenue. A Supreme Court ruling in favor of a state last week could set a precedent for other states to demand the same treatment, according to Finance Minister Nelson Barbosa. The decision could have significant implications for Brazil's already struggling economy, which is experiencing a two-year recession.

site_title: Ford to revamp headquarters campus to emulate Silicon Valley
summary: Ford Motor Co is embarking on a $10 billion, 10-year remodeling project to revamp its headquarters and research campuses in Dearborn, Michigan, to create a Silicon Valley-like work environment. The project will consolidate over 70 buildings into 50 on two main campuses, featuring electric bikes, autonomous cars, and green spaces. New buildings will include a cylindrical glass Sustainability Showcase and a 700,000-square-foot design center. The goal is to reduce energy use by 50% and save water, while creating a vibrant workplace that inspires employees. The project will be completed by 2026.

site_title: Taxi drivers block streets in Buenos Aires after Uber launch
summary: Taxi drivers in Buenos Aires blocked major avenues after Uber launched in the city without authorization on Tuesday. The move comes as traditional taxis face resistance from ride-hailing apps due to safety concerns and tax issues. Uber stated the app would be available for download at 5pm local time.

site_title: Maybank tops bank sector in remarkable turnaround
summary: Maybank has topped the customer satisfaction index in Singapore for 2015, scoring 71.9 points, surpassing OCBC and DBS. The bank's remarkable turnaround is attributed to efforts to improve customer satisfaction, including a gap-analysis, staff training, and digital initiatives. Maybank's deputy CEO, Allen Ng, emphasizes the importance of customer satisfaction, stating that it is crucial for the bank's growth and loyalty. The bank plans to continue improving customer satisfaction through initiatives such as customer journey mapping and investing in employee training.

site_title: US reviewing Sinai peacekeeper mission, looks at automating jobs
summary: The US military is reviewing its multinational peacekeeping operations in the Sinai Peninsula, including the possibility of automating jobs using remote surveillance technology. The Multinational Force and Observers (MFO) mission, established in 1979, has been criticized after six peacekeepers were wounded by a roadside bomb. The US is considering ways to reduce its troop presence, potentially withdrawing hundreds of its 700 peacekeepers, and is looking at leveraging modern technologies to carry out the mission. The move may be sensitive to both Israel and Egypt, who rely on the US for defense aid and strategic reassurance.

site_title: US$ at 8-month low as oil boosts risk appetite
summary: The US dollar fell to its weakest level since late August against a basket of currencies, losing 5% over the past month, as investors shifted their focus to riskier assets amid rising oil prices and rallying global stocks. The dollar index dropped to 93.627, while commodity-linked currencies like the Australian dollar and Norwegian crown gained against the US dollar. The euro touched a six-month high of $1.1465.

site_title: US House speaker again rules out presidential run
summary: US House Speaker Paul Ryan has ruled out a late presidential run, stating "I made a really clear choice not to run for president. Therefore, I will not be nominated." This decision comes after speculation about his potential candidacy at the 2016 Republican nominating convention. Ryan's comments were made in a radio interview, further solidifying his position on not seeking the presidency.

images.alt_text: Republican US House speaker Paul Ryan ruled out a late run for the presidency Tuesday, squelching speculation that he could be in contention at an eventual contested party nominating convention in July.

site_title: UBS poll shows the rich may not quite retire after retirement
summary: A UBS survey of 430 affluent investors in Singapore and Hong Kong found that some high net worth individuals view retirement as a chance to start new businesses, particularly women in Singapore who are confident that their business ventures will support their retirement. However, many investors still plan for retirement as if it's one continuous period, holding over half of their portfolio in stocks, regardless of the retirement phase. The survey also found that investors rely heavily on spouses and friends for financial advice and take an active role in their adult children's financial decisions.

site_title: Is this the 'Socialist Moment' for Bernie Sanders?
summary: Bernie Sanders' strong performance in the Democratic primary can be attributed to his appeal to young white voters, particularly college students and young men and women in their 20s, who are drawn to his socialist message of breaking up big banks and expanding social programs. However, his electoral base is limited to this demographic, while older voters, African-Americans, and Hispanics tend to support Hillary Clinton. The Democratic Party's rules, which favor Clinton due to the automatic inclusion of super-delegates, also work against Sanders. As a result, Clinton leads in delegates, and Sanders' "socialist moment" may be short-lived.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Wilmar International expects robust growth in the region driven by the "Rise of the Asian Consumer", despite moderated growth and downside risks. The company believes its considerable footprint in China, India, and Indonesia will capture growth opportunities. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "hold" call for Wilmar, citing near-term valuations not as attractive, while DBS Group Research recommends Wilmar and Bumitama Agril, citing upside potential.

site_title: Samsung banks on virtual reality to stand out
summary: Samsung is on track to post a 10% increase in first-quarter profits, driven by strong sales of its new flagship smartphones, the Galaxy S7 4G+ and S7 Edge 4G+. The company's efforts to differentiate itself from lower-cost brands are centered around its virtual reality (VR) ecosystem, which includes a "VR optimised" chipset and a Gear 360 camera. Samsung aims to create an immersive mobile experience, enhancing its customers' lives and redefining their use of mobile devices. The company's focus on VR and its eco-system of experiential content is seen as a key strategy to justify premium prices and compete with Chinese phone makers.

site_title: Khaw outlines strategy to raise rail reliability
summary: Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan has outlined a strategy to improve Singapore's rail reliability, aiming for 200,000 train-km by the end of the year. The government is investing S$1 billion in hardware upgrades and will reskill maintenance crews. A new Singapore Rail Academy (SGRA) will be established to develop engineering and research capabilities, and improve industry standards. The academy will focus on training, accreditation, and certification, and collaborate with institutes of higher learning on applied rail research. The goal is to achieve a reliable rail network by 2030, with 360 km of rail network expansion.

site_title: Beware danger of US anti-free-trade rhetoric becoming government policy
summary: US presidential candidates are shifting from pro-free-trade rhetoric to protectionist policies, challenging the notion that promoting free trade is in the country's economic interest. Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders have embraced nationalistic economic proposals, including revoking the Trans-Pacific Partnership and imposing punitive tariffs on imports from China. This shift may lead to a backlash against free trade, potentially altering the US trade liberalization agenda and its role as a driving force behind the open trade regime.

site_title: SPH posts S$54.1m Q2 profit
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) posted a Q2 operating profit of S$54.1 million, a 22.3% drop from the same period last year, due to lower investment income. Despite a 4.1% decline in group operating revenue, SPH saw a 0.2% increase in operating profit. The media segment's operating revenue fell 6%, while property revenue rose 0.9%. SPH declared an interim dividend of seven Singapore cents per share. The company's CEO, Alan Chan, described the quarter as "challenging" but emphasized the group's efforts to transform the media business and pursue growth opportunities.

site_title: HKEx plans to launch Asian FX futures, gold contracts
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEx) plans to launch renminbi currency futures contracts against the Indonesian rupiah and Malaysian ringgit in the coming months, aiming to diversify revenue streams away from traditional equity trading. This move comes amid cooling investor demand for equities in Hong Kong and the mainland due to a weaker economy. HKEx also plans to launch a gold settled contract in the third quarter of 2016, building on the success of its offshore renminbi/dollar currency futures contract.

site_title: EU offers new plan to tackle corporate tax dodging
summary: The European Commission proposes a new plan to tackle corporate tax dodging, requiring large companies to publicly disclose tax and financial data. The proposal, which aims to eliminate billions of euros in lost tax revenues, would also cover tax havens. The plan, which requires companies with an annual turnover of at least 750 million euros, faces opposition from business associations and lawmakers, who warn it could damage EU companies and make them less attractive to investors.

site_title: Prices of private resale flats up 0.3% in March
summary: Resale prices of non-landed private homes in Singapore rose 0.3% in March, driven by increases in the Rest of Central Region (0.1%) and Outside Central Region (1.3%). However, the Core Central Region saw a 1.7% decline due to the launch of CapitaLand's Cairnhill Nine project. Resale volume jumped 47.6% to 577 units, with ERA Realty's Eugene Lim noting that bargain hunters remain active in the Core Central Region. Despite this, DTZ's Lee Nai Jia cautions that it's too early to determine if the market is on the mend.

site_title: Capacity constraints, expectations likely reasons for decline in satisfaction: CSISG panelist
summary: Singapore's healthcare sector experienced a decline in customer/patient satisfaction in 2015, with capacity constraints and evolving societal expectations as key factors, says Jeremy Lim, a partner at Oliver Wyman. The sector's traditional care delivery models and interactions with patients also contribute to the decline. To address this, healthcare providers must segment patients by clinical and service needs and work with regulators and payers to ensure innovative care delivery. Private hospitals excel in addressing clinical needs but struggle with managing costs.

site_title: SIAS calls on SIC to examine Ron Sim's unintentional purchases
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has requested the Securities Industry Council (SIC) to investigate OSIM International founder Ron Sim's unintentional purchases of shares above his revised offer price. SIAS President David Gerald wrote to SIC Chairman JY Pillay, citing the purchases as a potential issue in the company's privatization process. The shares were bought by Credit Suisse on April 5 at a price of S$1.38-1.39, leading to a revised final offer price of S$1.39.

site_title: Global economy risks slowing to stalling speed: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that global economic growth is slowing to "stalling speed" due to persistent slow growth, citing economic and geo-political factors. The IMF cuts its global growth projections for 2016 and 2017, expecting 3.2% and 3.5% growth, respectively. The organization attributes the slowdown to factors such as emerging market and developing economies, stressed economies, and violent instability in countries like Syria. The IMF calls for a multi-pronged approach to counter the threats facing the global economy, including continued monetary accommodation, fiscal, and structural policies.

site_title: Luxe London home mortgages highest in 10 years
summary: London homebuyers are stretching to purchase expensive properties, with 58% of £1 million+ homebuyers using a mortgage, the highest proportion in 10 years, according to Hamptons International. This compares to 31% during the 2009 financial crisis. The trend highlights increased demand for luxury homes in London, despite the high mortgage rates.

site_title: Banks must embrace newer technology to raise customer satisfaction: Numoni CEO
summary: Banks must adopt newer technology to boost customer satisfaction, according to Numoni CEO Norma Sit. Speaking at the Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore, Sit emphasizes the importance of digital banking in making services more efficient. She notes that customers increasingly prefer online services, citing her 80-year-old father as an example. The fintech industry is growing globally, with major cities and economic zones spawning fintech companies. Sit calls for banks to disrupt traditional financial systems and adopt technology to remain competitive, citing the example of Australia's fintech community and MIT's fintech course.

site_title: China says it is willing to work with rest of the world to tackle steel overcapacity
summary: China's foreign ministry stated its willingness to work with the world to address steel overcapacity, a global issue caused by declining demand. The request comes after Britain asked China to tackle the problem, citing cheap imports from China as a threat to its steel industry. China, the world's top steel producer, has ramped up exports to record highs, dragging down global prices. The country's production capacity is significantly larger than its demand, and shutting down poorly performing mills is needed to address the issue, according to a government official.

site_title: Flip-flop at SingPost shows board instability
summary: The chairman-designate of SingPost, Prof Low Teck Seng, abruptly withdrew his acceptance of the position, citing concerns about fulfilling his duties to his current employer, the National Research Foundation. The sudden change of heart has raised questions about the board's functioning and the selection process. The Securities Investors Association (SIAS) has called for a thorough and transparent selection process to find a suitable chairman, emphasizing the need for a steady hand to guide the company and restore market confidence.

site_title: Keppel FELS puts Floatec revamp in perspective
summary: Keppel FELS has downplayed market talk of a possible dissolution of the Floatec joint venture with McDermott. The company has stated that it will continue to support ongoing projects and pursue new opportunities, with a focus on cost optimization during periods of reduced activity. Analysts suggest that the limited tension leg platform contracting prospects and mounting cost-cutting pressure on oil and gas players have contributed to the potential rethink for Floatec, but the partnership between Samsung Heavy Industries and Technip remains strong in the international bid circuit for floating liquefied natural gas projects.

site_title: Repsol in final dash to stitch up gas deal in Vietnam
summary: Repsol is racing against time to finalize a gas deal with PetroVietnam for its Ca Rong Do field development in Vietnam, aiming to meet its 2018 or 2019 production start-up target. The pricing of the gas offtake is crucial for project sanctioning in 2016, allowing the field development to progress according to schedule. Repsol must complete the deal before the deadline to ensure the project's success.

site_title: Europeans should also vote on Brexit
summary: The article suggests that the decision on Brexit should not be solely based on Britain's economic advantages or disadvantages, but rather on what Britain can contribute to Europe. The EU's founding values, such as respect for human dignity and human rights, should be prioritized. The author argues that Britain's departure from the EU could lead to a more unified and prosperous Europe, as the UK's presence has often been seen as a hindrance to European integration. The author concludes that Britain should leave the EU, as the rest of Europe would be better off without it.

site_title: Rakuten Ventures doubles global fund to US$200m
summary: Rakuten Ventures, the venture capital arm of Japan's Internet group Rakuten, has doubled its Global Investment Fund to US$200 million. This follows a successful track record of early-stage investments in technology startups, including Carousell, ViSenze, and Coda Payments. The fund will focus on next-generation tech innovators that can build and sustain a competitive advantage in their respective verticals. Rakuten Ventures' managing partner, SaeMin Ahn, stated that the increased fund size is a boost to the Singapore ecosystem, while local serial entrepreneur Darius Cheung emphasized that funding is not the only factor in a startup's success.

site_title: S Korea woos economy class golf lovers
summary: South Korea's government aims to make golf more accessible by reducing costs and elitism. The goal is to increase participation among the general public, rather than just the wealthy. The government plans to develop more public golf courses and encourage walking between holes, rather than using golf carts. This move is part of a broader effort to promote a more inclusive and affordable sport, with the aim of increasing the number of golfers in the country.

images.alt_text: After double-digit gains over most of the 2000s, visitors to South Korea's 473 golf courses rose just 5.3 per cent last year, the slowest in three years, according to the Korea Leisure Industry Institute.

site_title: Hong Kong loses big by beating Moody's in court
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Appeals Tribunal largely upheld the findings of the Securities and Futures Commission against Moody's Investors Service, fining the rating agency HK$11 million for various failings in a 2011 report on Chinese companies. The SFC's actions have damaged its reputation and stunted the development of the offshore debt market for Chinese companies. Moody's report highlighted subjective and difficult-to-quantify risk factors that did not sit within fixed ratings bands, but the SFC's prosecution and tribunal's decision may have unintended consequences, such as limiting the flow of information in Hong Kong's markets and harming the development of its financial markets.

site_title: High yield junk bonds do better in a slow growth economy
summary: High-yield junk bonds underperformed in the first six weeks of 2016, with the largest fund losing 4.6% and the biggest ETF shedding over 5%. This was a stark contrast to the Vanguard Total Bond Market index fund, which gained 2.4%. The losses highlighted the failure of high-yield bonds to provide portfolio ballast during a downturn.

site_title: Govt moves to deepen support for the disadvantaged
summary: Singapore's government has announced measures to deepen support for vulnerable and low-income families. The KidSTART programme, a S$20 million initiative, will provide coordinated support to 1,000 low-income children and their families. The Safe and Strong Families programme will strengthen family-based care and community support for vulnerable children. Additionally, the government will increase cash assistance for elderly households, introduce equal maternity leave for unwed mothers, and regulate the early childhood sector through a new Early Childhood Development Centres Act.

site_title: Govt to buy only green printing paper from Q3
summary: Singapore's government plans to procure only certified green printing paper starting from the third quarter of 2016, as part of its efforts to support sustainable practices and mitigate climate change. The move is seen as a consumer influence on the agro-forestry industry. Additionally, the government will also buy electrical products with high energy efficiency, starting with air-conditioners and refrigerators. Minister Masagos Zulkifli emphasized the power of collective consumer voice in promoting sustainable business practices, citing previous actions by civil society and the private sector.

site_title: When tax avoidance veers into the immoral
summary: A law firm, Mossack Fonseca, has released 2.3 terabytes of information exposing individuals and corporations that have used offshore vehicles to hide money, with some linked to money laundering, terrorism, and other illicit activities. This is a significant leak, surpassing previous whistleblowers' releases. Singapore is poised to become the world's largest offshore banking center, taking over from Switzerland, but it is not inherently corrupt. The leak highlights the continued use of offshore banking centers for illicit activities, and Singapore's position in this market.

site_title: Turning point for EM economies
summary: Emerging markets (EM) have reached a turning point, with the EM current account going into surplus despite uncertainty over China. After the 2008 financial crisis, EMs faced headwinds of debt, de-population, and de-globalization, leading to a cooling of investor sentiment. However, the gap in performance between EMs and developed markets has narrowed, and some analysts expect better days ahead. The recent closure of the Goldman Sachs "BRIC Fund" raises questions about the value of the asset class.

site_title: SingPost's unlocking of value hinges on leadership
summary: SingPost's leadership is under scrutiny due to corporate governance issues, which have created uncertainty for the company. Independent director Keith Tay stepped down from the nominations committee, while chairman Lim Ho Kee relinquished his position and chairman Low Teck Seng turned down the role. The company's board is attempting to reassure stakeholders of stability and competence at the top, but the situation remains unclear. The outcome will depend on the current board's ability to address these concerns.

site_title: Luxury-rental plan abandoned at Manhattan's One57 condo tower
summary: Extell Development Co has abandoned plans to list 38 luxury rental units at its One57 condo tower in Manhattan, opting to sell them as condominiums instead. The units, on the 32nd-38th floors, will be listed for sale at prices starting at $3.45 million, citing a decline in luxury rental demand amid an abundance of supply. The decision comes as the median monthly rent for a Manhattan luxury apartment fell 3.5% in March to $8,228.

site_title: Emissions standards to be raised for new motorbikes
summary: Singapore to raise emission standards for new motorcycles, with large motorcycles (over 200cc) needing to comply with Euro 4 standard from 2018 and smaller motorcycles from 2020. The government will also study pollution by diesel vehicles to inform future policies, following the Volkswagen emissions scandal. Emission standards for new motor vehicles will also be raised, with diesel vehicles needing to comply with Euro 6 standard from September next year. The study on diesel vehicles aims to review future vehicular emission policies.

site_title: Foreign funds boost Asia investments to 5-year high on weaker US dollar
summary: Foreign investors poured US$22 billion into Asia's emerging markets in March, the highest five-year level, driven by a weaker US dollar and hopes for a Group of 20 currency deal. This surge in inflows follows a dovish US Federal Reserve and Chinese authorities' promises to refrain from yuan devaluation. The dollar index slid to a 7-1/2-month low, while Asian emerging markets saw broad inflows, with stocks and local currency debt gaining 8% and 4% against the dollar, respectively.

site_title: Marine industry looks to cruise ships, wind farms amid oil slump
summary: The marine industry is diversifying as oil prices slump, with companies turning to cruise ships, fishing vessels, and sea-based wind farms to maintain earnings. Singapore-listed Vard Holdings signed a deal to build luxury expedition cruise ships, while Ezion Holdings partnered with a Chinese state-owned enterprise to support offshore windfarms. The industry faces a glut of offshore supply vessels and declining charter rates, but sees opportunities in non-oil business, such as research and naval vessels, and the growing offshore renewables market.

site_title: Swiss AG extends 1MDB probe to ex-officials of Abu Dhabi state fund
summary: Swiss authorities have extended their criminal probe into 1MDB, a Malaysian development company, to two ex-Emirati officials of Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund for suspected offenses including forgery, bribery, and money laundering. The probe now includes ex-officials, not just 1MDB itself, amid conflicting statements on a $3.5 billion payment. Swiss AG will also seek mutual legal assistance from Singapore and Luxembourg to aid the investigation.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Index sectors cover 2/3 of GDP
summary: A survey by Singapore Management University's Institute of Service Excellence found that 2/3 of Singapore's GDP is covered by the 11 industry sectors studied in the Customer Satisfaction Index Survey 2015. The survey, which included responses from 42,501 unique customers and 2,330 companies, measured cumulative satisfaction with companies in the finance and insurance, healthcare, and other sectors. The CSISG study complements GDP measures by providing an assessment of customer satisfaction, highlighting the importance of producing better and more competitive products and services for economic growth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lorenzo International Holdings has entered subscription agreements for 30 million new shares with two investors, valued at S$2 million each. The company intends to use the net proceeds for general working capital purposes. Meanwhile, Keppel Data Centres Holding secured S$84.5 million in contracts for co-location and data centre services at Keppel Datahub 2.

site_title: Volume at a low as market gropes for direction
summary: Singapore stocks remained volatile, with the Straits Times Index closing 5.41 points higher at 2,814.65 on Tuesday. The market saw low trading activity, with a record low volume of 978.7 million units worth S$664 million. Despite this, some stocks such as Interra Resources and Wilmar International rose, while others, including top 20 actives, were priced below S$1. Analysts warned of potential risks, including a possible British exit from the eurozone and ongoing Greek bailout negotiations, which could impact financial markets.

site_title: Conditions ripe for wave of privatisations: OCBC
summary: OCBC Investment Research predicts a wave of privatisations in Singapore due to undervalued companies with large shareholders and low debt. The report highlights Dyna-Mac Holdings, PACC Offshore Services Holdings, and Wing Tai as potential candidates. Stronger corporates have cash reserves, and individuals are seeking investment opportunities, creating a favorable environment for privatisations. The brokerage believes investors remain optimistic about Asia's long-term prospects, despite short-term challenges.

site_title: Alibaba invests US$1b to control Singapore e-commerce site Lazada
summary: Alibaba has invested approximately US$1 billion to acquire a controlling stake in Singapore-based e-commerce site Lazada, valuing the startup at US$1.5 billion on a pre-money basis and US$2 billion on a post-money basis. This deal will enable Alibaba's merchants to access the South-east Asian market, while analysts predict a consolidation and shakeout among the region's e-commerce players. The investment is expected to boost logistics companies, including startups, and enhance consumer choices with lower prices.

site_title: UK inflation hits 15-month high
summary: UK inflation rose to a 15-month high in March, driven by airfares and clothing costs, reaching 0.5% year-over-year. Core inflation, excluding energy and food, increased to 1.5%, its strongest since October 2014. Despite this, the Bank of England's 2% target remains unmet, and economists expect no rate hike before early 2017. Shoppers reduced spending in the first quarter, and the economy contracted for the second month, adding to concerns about the global economy and Britain's European Union membership referendum.

site_title: Gold investment demand in China spurs ETF inflows and new products
summary: Gold investment demand in China is driving inflows into bullion-backed funds and prompting new products, amid growing confidence in the metal's price rally. The metal has gained 18% in 2016, with Chinese investors seeking gold as a safe-haven investment due to global economic fears and uncertainty. New products, such as ETFs and wealth management products, have been launched to tap into the growing demand, with holdings of top ETFs increasing by 63% and 13.5 tonnes. Industry players attribute the growth to volatility in China's equity markets and concerns over the yuan's devaluation.

images.alt_text: China's demand for gold bars and coins this year has been growing at a faster pace than jewellery.

site_title: Changjiang Fertilizer invests in 2 S'pore property firms; selling China assets
summary: Changjiang Fertilizer Holdings is acquiring Singaporean property firms WBH Investments and Cowealth Investments in a "very substantial acquisition" or "reverse takeover" worth S$13.8 million each. The acquisitions will be concurrent and subject to shareholder approval. The company will transfer its listing to Catalist and sell its Chinese assets, aiming to transform into a real estate developer and investor. The move is expected to increase market capitalization, raise the company's profile, and provide minority shareholders with an opportunity to recover some of their investment.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: KPMG launches matchmaking initiative for startups
summary: KPMG Singapore has launched the KPMG Digital Village, a matchmaking initiative that connects corporate clients with startups to access innovative solutions. The program, which includes fintech, healthtech, and logtech, aims to foster a symbiotic ecosystem for innovation. KPMG professionals will provide expertise in digital strategy, analytics, and cybersecurity to help startups develop solutions for business integration. The Digital Village will also include virtual and physical meeting places, with the goal of facilitating the adoption of innovation and technology by Singapore businesses to grow and be competitive internationally.

site_title: EIA sees 2016 US natgas production, consumption at record highs
summary: The US Energy Information Administration (EIA) predicts that natural gas production in 2016 will reach a record high of 74.76 billion cubic feet per day, surpassing 2015's record of 74.22 bcfd. This marks the sixth consecutive annual record high for US gas production. However, gas consumption is forecasted to ease to 76.24 bcfd, still topping the 2015 record high of 75.27 bcfd.

site_title: Robin Hu remains CEO of renamed media firm following sale to Alibaba
summary: Robin Hu remains CEO of SCMP Publisher Limited, a media firm including the South China Morning Post, following its sale to Alibaba Group. The sale, completed on April 12, 2016, removed the digital paywall, making online content free. Hu confirmed he is still in charge, citing Alibaba's purchase of media assets but not the listed company shell. The SCMP Group was renamed Armada Limited.

site_title: India's industrial output grows 2% in Feb: govt
summary: India's industrial output grew 2.0% in February, exceeding economists' forecast of 1.0%. This marks a reversal from a 1.5% year-on-year contraction in January. The data suggests a slight improvement in the country's industrial sector.

site_title: Goldman mortgage settlement is much less than meets the eye
summary: Goldman Sachs agreed to pay US$5.1 billion to settle accusations of wrongdoing before the global financial crisis. However, the actual amount the bank will pay is significantly lower, potentially as much as US$1 billion less, due to government incentives and tax credits. The settlement includes provisions that allow Goldman to reduce its bill through affordable housing projects, with the bank only required to pay 30% of the US$240 million allocated for affordable housing. Critics argue that the settlement amount was inflated for PR purposes, while the fine print enables Goldman to pay less than initially reported.

site_title: PUB exploring feasibility of desalination plant on Jurong Island: Masagos
summary: Singapore's PUB water agency is exploring the feasibility of building a desalination plant on Jurong Island, which accounts for one-tenth of the country's water use. The move aims to strengthen water security and resilience to droughts amid low water levels in a reservoir in Johor. Two existing desalination plants, planned to be completed in 2017 and 2019, will increase the country's desalination capacity to 120 million gallons per day. PUB will also work with industries on Jurong Island to use seawater for cooling, with fewer than 20 companies currently doing so.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil has been using seawater for cooling in its Singapore operations since the 1970s, and also uses the technology "extensively" at its new expanded petrochemical complex, which opened in January 2014

site_title: Cordlife appoints Tan Poh Lan as group COO
summary: Cordlife Group appointed Tan Poh Lan as its new group chief operating officer, tasked with increasing service offerings and growing the core business. She will work closely with the board of directors and senior management to strategize and improve operating performance. This appointment is part of the company's efforts to expand its services and enhance its overall performance.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Transport strategy prepares way for new technology
summary: Singapore Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan proposes a 15-year transition to driverless pods, replacing private cars, and aims to make the city-state car-lite. The 2030 transport strategy will facilitate new technologies, increase public transport accessibility, and reduce car dependency. The plan includes trials of self-driving pods and adjusting car and parking policies to encourage a shift away from car dominance. This move is expected to affect taxi drivers, but the government aims to help them adapt to the changes, building on a principle set by founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew to maintain a balanced transport system.

site_title: Brent pierces US$44, hits 5-month high on reports of oil output freeze deal
summary: Global oil prices surged to a five-month high on Tuesday, reaching $44 a barrel, as reports emerged of a potential output freeze deal between Russia and Saudi Arabia ahead of an OPEC meeting. Brent crude rose 1.6% and US crude rose 2.68% as analysts expressed skepticism about the news, citing concerns over inventory levels and potential new oil supplies. Industry analysts predicted further gains if the 200-day moving average is broken, while a report from the American Petroleum Institute is scheduled to be released later Tuesday.

site_title: US: IMF warnings slip by European stock markets as oil prices rise
summary: European stock markets rose on Tuesday, defying IMF warnings of weak global growth and a possible Brexit-induced economic downturn. The IMF cut its global growth forecast to 3.2% and lowered its eurozone forecast to 1.5%. However, oil prices rose above $40 per barrel, boosting market sentiment. Despite concerns about a slowdown in China, the IMF raised its growth forecast for China to 6.5%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.9% as US banks prepared to report earnings.

site_title: Nomura plans to shut down its European equity business: source
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, Japan's largest brokerage, plans to shut down its European equity operations due to years of failing to become profitable overseas. The move will affect around 1,000 employees in Europe and the Americas, with an announcement likely as early as Tuesday. This comes as the Tokyo-based securities firm cuts costs to stay afloat.

site_title: Analysts doubt ECB's move to spur growth, cut capex estimate
summary: Analysts are doubting the European Central Bank's efforts to stimulate growth by encouraging companies to invest in capital expenditures. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index firms are predicted to spend an average of 19 million euros on capex in 2016, the most bearish forecast in six years, with a 2.6% increase in capex expected from last year. This pessimistic outlook suggests CEOs are prioritizing balance sheet growth and shareholder returns over business investments, raising concerns about the ECB's effectiveness in promoting economic growth.

site_title: EU unveils plan to toughen tax disclosure rules for multinationals
summary: The European Commission has unveiled plans to toughen tax disclosure rules for multinationals, requiring them to accurately report their earnings in each EU member state. The move comes after the Panama Papers scandal, aiming to increase accountability without damaging competitiveness. The proposal would make public what multinationals earn in each EU country, increasing transparency.

site_title: IMF cuts global growth forecast again, warns of greater risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its global growth forecast for the third time in six months, now predicting a 3.2% growth rate for 2026, 0.2 percentage points lower than its January prediction. The IMF urges governments to take immediate action to shore up growth, citing concerns about the global economy. This latest downgrade reflects a slowdown in economic growth, with the IMF warning of greater risks to the global economy.

site_title: February 2017 date proposed for Fifa trial start
summary: US prosecutors have proposed a February 2017 start date for the FIFA corruption trial, with jury selection set to begin on February 27. Evidence must be submitted by June 30, allowing attorneys time to prepare. 40 people, mostly top football officials and sports marketing executives from the Americas, have been charged, with 15 already pleading guilty. The trial, sparked by a 2015 scandal, aims to hold accountable those involved in the massive corruption case.

site_title: Uber says gave US agencies data on more than 12m users
summary: Uber released its first transparency report, revealing it provided information on over 12 million US riders and drivers to regulators and law enforcement agencies between July and December 2015. The report showed 415 requests from law enforcement, mostly related to fraud investigations, with 85% of cases fulfilled. Uber did not receive any national security letters or Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act orders. The company has not disclosed similar requests from other countries.

site_title: IMF warning on Brexit fires up referendum campaign
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that Britain leaving the EU could inflict "severe regional and global damage", citing a potential 0.3 percentage point downgrade in British economic growth for 2016. Prime Minister David Cameron seized on the report, while opponents accused it of scaremongering. The IMF listed a Brexit as one of its seven main "downside risks" to the world economy, citing disrupted trade and financial flows. The warning comes just days before the official referendum campaign begins on June 23.

site_title: India's March retail inflation eases to 4.83% y/y
summary: India's annual retail inflation eased to 4.83% in March, its second consecutive month of decline, due to smaller rises in food prices. This eased expectations of a rate hike by the Reserve Bank of India. Food inflation also decreased slightly to 5.21% in March from 5.30% in the previous month. Economists had forecast a slowdown in retail inflation to 5% in March.

site_title: Most overseas ventures by Indian enterprises have failed miserably
summary: Tata Steel, once India's largest company, is putting an end to its losses in its ailing steel-making facilities in England. The company spent $12.8 billion buying Corus, but its UK assets now have a book value of "almost zero." Tata Steel's European operations incurred a significant loss, with a Ebitda loss of 3.4 billion rupees, compared to a profit of 871 billion rupees in India. The company plans to sell its UK steel business, citing concerns for its survival, and has employed 15,000 people in the UK.

site_title: Shell, Chevron await LNG's return from 'pause mode'
summary: Energy giants Shell and Chevron are waiting for a surge in demand for liquefied natural gas (LNG) as the market is currently in "pause mode" due to low prices. The over-supplied market has stalled development of new projects, with companies focusing on long-term demand growth. Experts predict a deficit of 75 million metric tons of LNG per year by 2025, requiring $250 billion in investment. As oil prices surge, LNG prices are expected to rise, with Shell and Chevron expecting prices to return to higher levels.

site_title: Emerging Europe growth stable thanks to cheap oil: IMF forecast
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its forecast for emerging Europe, predicting stable economic growth of 3.5% in 2016 and 3.3% in 2017. The growth is driven by cheap oil and the eurozone recovery, but elevated corporate debt hinders private investment. Inflation is forecast to be above target in Turkey but below target in countries like Hungary and Poland. Economic growth varies across countries, ranging from 1.8% in Serbia to 4.7% in Montenegro.

site_title: Singapore's Shanda buys 9.9% stake in Legg Mason from Trian
summary: Singapore-based Shanda Group agreed to buy a 9.9% stake in money manager Legg Mason from activist investor Trian Fund Management. The deal marks a significant move by Shanda to expand its presence in the global financial industry. Legg Mason's chairman and CEO, Joseph A Sullivan, expressed his company's welcome of Shanda as a long-term strategic shareholder, anticipating benefits from their expertise in areas of growth. The terms of the deal, including the price, were not disclosed.

site_title: Fitch cuts Saudi Arabia's ratings to 'AA-' from 'AA'
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Saudi Arabia's long-term foreign and local currency issuer default ratings to 'AA-' from 'AA' with a negative outlook due to weak oil prices, affecting fiscal and external balances. This move comes amid discussions at the Opec meeting in Doha, Qatar, on freezing output.

site_title: Industrial robot sales rise 8% in 2015 on autos and China
summary: Global industrial robot sales rose 8% in 2015, driven by demand from the automotive industry and China. The number of robots sold exceeded 240,000 for the first time, with China leading the market with a 16% increase to 66,000 units. Articulated robots and cobots, which collaborate with humans, are gaining popularity. Sales rose 9% in Europe and 11% in North America, driven by eastern Europe and the US, respectively.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

London's Heathrow Airport is considering increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade project, with no specific details provided. Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, has been named OCBC's incoming CEO, succeeding Helen Wong. MAS and the PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks have experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with CGSI downgrading Grab to a 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay has risen 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: IMF raises China outlook to 6.5% but warns of 'spillover'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its growth forecast for China to 6.5% in 2016, citing announced stimulus plans, but warned of "substantial spillover effects" on global expansion. The slowdown in China has severely impacted global growth, with a one per cent drop in Chinese investment potentially leading to a quarter of a per cent drop in growth in G20 economies. The IMF notes that policymakers should "act now" to address concerns about China's ability to tackle overcapacity and debt-fuelled investment.

site_title: US-based cruise liner eyes China market with dedicated liner
summary: US-based cruise liner Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings plans to launch a ship tailored to the Chinese market, Norwegian Joy, in March next year. The 20-deck liner will have a capacity of 3,900 passengers and will be based at ports in Shanghai and Tianjin. The ship will cater to Chinese tastes with more Chinese food options, casinos, and duty-free shopping. Demand for cruises in China is rising, driven by the country's growing middle class, with 50% of Asian cruise trips originating from China in 2014. The market is expected to grow to nearly $10 billion by 2018.

site_title: World's top traders call oil-market bottom as US$50 on horizon
summary: World's top oil traders predict the market has hit its bottom, with prices potentially reaching US$50 per barrel by next year. Executives from major trading houses, including Gunvor Group and Vitol Group, say a "rebalancing" of global supply and demand is underway, driven by declining US output and easing global glut. The market is expected to experience a multi-year bull run, with prices rising to US$60 this year and US$80 in 2017. However, some executives, such as Glencore's Alex Beard, remain cautious, citing large stockpiles and challenges in financing deals to trade oil from Iran.

site_title: Marine Parade exemplifies polyclinic bright spot
summary: The Marine Parade Polyclinic, managed by SingHealth Polyclinics, has achieved a record score in the Consumer Satisfaction Survey, with a score of 69.6 points, a 1.1% increase from the previous year. The polyclinic, renovated to cater to the health needs of the ageing population, has doubled in size from a single to a two-storey facility, with community and staff engagement during the planning phase. This marks a bright spot in the healthcare sector, where polyclinics have consistently shown high satisfaction rates.

images.alt_text: There was community and staff engagement during the planning phase, says Dr Koong

site_title: WongPartnership partners Middle Eastern practice for wider reach (Amended)
summary: Singapore-based law firm WongPartnership has partnered with a Middle Eastern boutique law firm, Al Aidarous International Legal Practice, to expand its reach in the region. The alliance, announced in 2016, aims to support clients in the Middle East and counter the decline of the oil and gas sector. WongPartnership has a presence in Abu Dhabi since 2008 and will now establish a presence in Dubai through the partnership.

site_title: IMF trims US growth forecast for 2016-2017
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) lowered its forecast for the US economy, predicting 2.4% growth in 2016 and 2.3% in 2017, citing a strong dollar and sluggish economies elsewhere. This marks a decrease from its January prediction of 2.6% growth in 2016.

site_title: Germany keen to test self-driving cars on the road
summary: Germany is set to allow self-driving cars on its roads, with Chancellor Angela Merkel promising to remove legal barriers. The ruling coalition will discuss a wish list of desired features and a timetable by the end of May, with the cabinet potentially creating the legal basis for testing such vehicles. The move comes as global car companies work on prototypes, with mass market availability expected by 2020. The government is also considering supporting the development and demand for electric cars, with industry leaders pressing for incentives to boost demand.

site_title: Gaza's architectural heritage fades, but one man resists
summary: A 46-year-old university professor in Gaza City has restored a 430-year-old Levantine-style palace, one of the rare remaining architectural heritage sites in the war-torn city. The palace, located in the Old City's Christian quarter, was rescued from neglect and damage after the professor spent his savings on its restoration. Gazan heritage specialist Fadel al-Otol notes that the city's rich history, dating back to 3,500 BC, is being lost due to population pressure, war, and neglect, with many historic buildings being destroyed or replaced with new construction.

images.alt_text: Prof Salama (above) and his daughter at their house, a 430-year-old Levantine-style palace. It is among the rare vestiges of Gaza City's architectural heritage, battered by war, time, population pressure and simple indifference.

Prof Salama and his daughter (above) at their house, a 430-year-old Levantine-style palace. It is among the rare vestiges of Gaza City's architectural heritage, battered by war, time, population pressure and simple indifference.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed as IMF cuts outlook
summary: US stocks opened little changed on Tuesday, following the IMF's downgrade of its 2016 global growth forecast to 3.2% due to worsening emerging economies and tepid growth in advanced economies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 19.38 points (0.11%) to 17,575.79, while the S&P 500 added 2.09 points (0.10%) to 2,044.08. Large banks are set to report earnings later in the week, with Alcoa already reporting a decline in first-quarter earnings and job cuts.

site_title: IMF cuts eurozone growth forecast amid 'major' challenges
summary: The IMF has cut its growth forecast for the eurozone to 1.5% this year, down from 1.7%, citing "major challenges" from the refugee crisis, terrorism, and Brexit uncertainty.
