The move comes after Tata cited a global steel oversupply, high costs, weak domestic demand, and a volatile currency. The sale process, announced by Britain's business minister Sajid Javid, has no set timeframe. This decision aims to reduce Tata's losses and adapt to the steel industry's challenges.

images.alt_text: The head of US Steel has accused Britain and the wider European Union of negligence over China dumping cheap steel on world markets.

site_title: Rajan builds record reserves to strengthen Asia's worst currency
summary: Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan has built record foreign-exchange reserves to strengthen the rupee, which is Asia's worst-performing currency. The reserves grew to $359.76 billion, driven by inflows of $4.1 billion into stocks. Rajan aims to counter potential volatility amid slowing China growth and potential US interest rate hikes. The rupee rose 0.1% to 66.40 per dollar, marking its largest jump since September 2013, as overseas investors returned to India's stock market.

site_title: G7 foreign ministers oppose provocation in East and South China Seas
summary: G7 foreign ministers strongly oppose provocation in the East and South China Seas, where China is involved in territorial disputes with countries like the Philippines, Vietnam, and Japan. The G7 statement calls for stability and adherence to international maritime laws. China claims the seas have huge oil and gas deposits and an estimated $5 trillion in trade is shipped through them annually. China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Lu Kang said the G7 statement is "exaggerated" and China will not recognize any judgments from international courts.

site_title: World Bank sees solid East Asia growth despite global rout
summary: The World Bank has revised its growth forecast for East Asia, predicting a 6.3% expansion for developing economies in the region this year, down marginally from 6.4%. Despite a slowdown in China, the lender expects China to grow at 6.7% and other countries to grow at 4.8%. The report notes that global risks, including a slowdown in high-income countries and financial market volatility, threaten the region's outlook, emphasizing the need for countries to adopt policies that reduce exposure to global and regional risks and promote inclusive growth.

site_title: UK's CMA voices serious concerns over Hutchison-Telefonica deal
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has expressed serious concerns over the proposed merger between Hutchison 3G UK and Telefonica UK, citing potential increased prices and reduced quality for UK consumers. The CMA has urged the European Commission to prevent "long-term damage" to the UK mobile telecoms market. The companies have been asked to either divest the Three Mobile or O2 mobile network business or allow for carve-outs from the divested business. The CMA's concerns follow a full in-depth investigation by the European Union into the proposed 10.3 billion-pound bid for British mobile operator O2.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares edge up, supported by China policy view
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.4% on Monday, driven by a bullish mainland market after China's March inflation came in lower than forecast, fueling optimism about Beijing's monetary policy. China's inflation figure remained at 2.3%, while wholesale prices declined 4.3% but at a slower pace. The Hang Seng index rose to 20,440.81, and the China Enterprises Index gained 1.2% to 8,807.06 points.

site_title: Myanmar FDI hits record high of US$9.4b in 2015/16
summary: Myanmar saw a record-high foreign direct investment (FDI) of US$9.4 billion in the 2015/16 fiscal year, with 217 projects, according to official data. This growth reflects interest in the country as one of Asia's last remaining untapped markets, with a surge in last-minute approvals before the handover of power to Aung San Suu Kyi's administration.

site_title: Malaysia's first sharia-compliant airline suspended: official
summary: Malaysia's first Islamic-compliant airline, Rayani Air, has been suspended for three months due to failing to adhere to aviation regulations. The airline, which launched last December, was criticized for last-minute delays and cancellations, as well as pilot strikes. The Department of Civil Aviation has announced a safety audit to determine if the airline is "fit" for flying again. The suspension comes two years after Malaysia faced twin aviation disasters, including the downing of MH17.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's first Islamic-compliant airline has been suspended for three months after it failed to adhere to aviation regulations, a senior official said Monday, as the government announced a safety audit of the carrier.

site_title: Oil price dips on prospects for producers' meeting
summary: Oil prices declined on Monday due to concerns over the outcome of a producers' meeting in Qatar, which aims to freeze current output levels. Brent crude futures fell 27 cents to $41.67 a barrel, while US WTI crude eased 21 cents to $39.51 a barrel. Analysts expect a production freeze to have limited impact, and some forecasters predict a rebalancing of the oil market by the end of 2016, allowing prices to recover. Global demand is forecast to grow at a mean annual rate of 1.4% between 2016 and 2020.

site_title: OSIM shares 'inadvertently' purchased at higher price: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse clarified that OSIM International shares were purchased "inadvertently" at a higher price than the original final offer, between S$1.38 and S$1.39, due to a mistake in the offer process. The shares were bought for and on behalf of OSIM founder Ron Sim's privatization attempt. The offeror revised the final offer price to S$1.39 on an ex-dividend basis, with the final dividend of two cents. The revised price was applied to all shareholders who accepted the original offer.

site_title: BP bonus backlash intensifies as investor adviser urges rejection
summary: BP faces opposition to its pay package at its annual meeting after British shareholder advisory group ShareSoc recommended rejecting the remuneration report. The group criticized CEO Bob Dudley's $19.6 million compensation package for 2015, citing a record loss of $6.4 billion and a 20% increase in pay despite the loss. Shareholders and advisors, including Royal London Asset Management and Institutional Shareholder Services, also oppose the pay plans, calling them "over-generous" and "unreasonable."

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks end higher after inflation data
summary: Shanghai stocks rose sharply on Monday after China's inflation data showed it remained above 2%, signaling a stabilizing economy. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.64% to 3,033.96, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.99% to 1,952.48. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index also increased 0.35%. The gains came as investors viewed the data as a positive sign for the mainland economy.

site_title: Malaysian state sets stage for polls amid scandal
summary: Malaysia's Sarawak state dissolved its assembly, paving the way for an election amid a huge financial scandal surrounding Prime Minister Najib Razak's 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) fund. The opposition and electoral reform advocates say the ruling coalition retains control via "money politics" and media control. A recent survey found most people in Sarawak support the current government, which is expected to maintain its grip on the state, potentially boosting its position in national polls.

site_title: Australia-India consortium wants to restart historic gold mine
summary: An Australian-Indian consortium is seeking to restart gold mining in the historic Kolar gold field in Karnataka, India, after a 14-year hiatus. The mine, which operated from 1857 to 2001, produced 25 million ounces of gold. The consortium plans to take advantage of resurgent gold prices and India's efforts to monetize its gold reserves and reduce imports to boost its economy. A government tender could lead to the sale of mining leases held by Bharat Gold Mines Ltd to the highest bidder, paving the way for a potential restart.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares end lower as financials weigh
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares ended lower on Monday, weighed down by financial firms' poor loan performance and interest rate fixing scandal. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 6.10 points to 4,931.50, while the S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.08 per cent to 6,725.11. Gains in natural resources stocks were unable to offset the losses.

site_title: LG Electronics says Q1 operating profit likely up 66% vs yr ago
summary: LG Electronics expects a 66% increase in first-quarter operating profit to 505 billion won (S$593.7 million), beating analyst expectations. The company attributes the boost to healthy appliance sales and falling television panel prices. Revenue is forecasted to be 13.4 trillion won, down 4.5% from the previous year. The firm will formally report its earnings in late April.

site_title: Heatwave shuts more than 250 Malaysian schools
summary: More than 250 Malaysian schools were closed due to a heatwave caused by the El Nino weather phenomenon, which has severely affected food production and caused chronic water shortages. Temperatures soared above 37 degrees Celsius over a 72-hour period, prompting authorities to protect the health of 100,000 students. The heatwave is expected to ease soon, with the inter-monsoon season starting last week. The severe temperature rise has also affected paddy fields and rubber plantations, leading to price hikes and slowing vegetable production.

site_title: China Telecom gets new chairman after ex-head resigned amid investigation
summary: China Telecom has appointed Yang Jie as its new chairman after the previous chairman, Chang Xiaobing, resigned amid an investigation for alleged disciplinary violations. Yang Jie, who was acting head, took over the role following the resignation. The move comes after the ruling Communist Party's anti-corruption watchdog accused Chang of "serious violation of discipline".

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slip as soaring yen hits exporters
summary: Japanese stocks declined on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 falling 0.44% due to a strong yen affecting exporters. The Nikkei 225 lost 70.39 points to 15,751.13, while the Topix index fell 0.61% to 1,279.79. Despite efforts to stabilize the currency, the yen's value continued to impact exporters, leading to a decline in Japanese stocks.

site_title: Daily Mail confims talks with potential Yahoo bidders
summary: The Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT) is in talks with "a number of parties" over a potential bid for Yahoo, a struggling US internet giant. The talks are at an early stage and there is no certainty that a transaction will occur. DMGT's bid could take two forms: either a private-equity firm acquires Yahoo's core web business and merges it with the Mail's global online operations, or the private-equity partner acquires the entirety of Yahoo's core web business with the Mail taking over the news and media properties. Yahoo has set an April 18 deadline for preliminary bids.

site_title: Yen advances despite efforts to cool safe-haven currency
summary: The Japanese yen continued its advance, reaching 17-month highs, despite government efforts to cool the currency. The yen's strength is hurting exporters, such as Toyota and Sony, as it makes their goods more expensive overseas. The dollar slipped to 107.90 yen, while the euro gained 123.11 yen. Japanese authorities have warned against the yen's rapid gains, but are unlikely to intervene due to the upcoming Group of Seven summit, which could generate allegations of currency manipulation.

site_title: OECD's Gurria: Japan has room to raise sales tax to 15%
summary: OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria stated that Japan has room to gradually raise the national sales tax to 15% to fund rising welfare spending. This move is also seen as a way to implement structural reforms. However, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's plan to raise the sales tax to 10% next year is still on track, despite some advisers calling for a delay.

site_title: Indonesia finance minister: govt considering cutting corporate tax rate to 20%
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Bambang Brodjonegoro, announced the government is considering reducing the corporate tax rate to 20% from 25% in an upcoming revision to the income tax law. The move is part of efforts to boost economic growth. Brodjonegoro stated that the 20% rate appears "adequate" and will be presented to parliament for consideration.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is considering cutting the corporate income tax rate to 20 per cent from 25 per cent in the upcoming revision to the income tax law, the finance minister told lawmakers on Monday. "We are still doing our review, but 20 per cent looks adequate," Bambang Brodjonegoro said in a meeting with the parliamentary commission overseeing taxes.

site_title: Ringgit outlook brightens in Moody's survey as reserves climb
summary: Malaysia's ringgit outlook is turning brighter, according to a Moody's survey, with 53% of respondents predicting the currency will be around 4-4.2 per dollar over the next 12 months. The nation's improving trade surplus and foreign-exchange reserves, as well as the halt in the US dollar's appreciation, are supportive of the ringgit. Foreign-exchange reserves rose to $97 billion, and the trade surplus widened to 7.35 billion ringgit, contributing to the currency's 10% rally this year. However, the survey also shows a slowdown in GDP growth to 4-4.5% this year from 5% in 2015.

site_title: Brazil president's fate on knife edge in impeachment vote
summary: Brazil's impeachment vote against President Dilma Rousseff is set to take place on April 17 or 18, with a two-thirds majority needed to send her case to the Senate. The lower house vote is on a knife edge, with a survey showing 289 deputies in favor and 115 opposing impeachment. The outcome is uncertain, with 109 deputies still undecided. If Rousseff is impeached, Vice President Michel Temer would take over as president. The country is gripped by recession, corruption scandals, and intense passions, with protests and barricades expected during the vote.

images.alt_text: A tense, divided Brazil held its breath and braced for disturbances on the streets Monday ahead of a vote to decide whether President Dilma Rousseff should face impeachment.

site_title: North Korean two-star general defected to South last year: Seoul
summary: A North Korean two-star general defected to South Korea last year, according to Seoul. The senior general had handled spy operations targeting South Korea at the North's General Bureau of Reconnaissance. Details of the official's name were not disclosed by the unification and defence ministry spokesmen in Seoul. This rare high-level military defection is seen as a significant development, highlighting the divisions within the North Korean military.

site_title: Standard Chartered said to start US$4.4b Asian asset sale
summary: Standard Chartered is seeking to sell at least $4.4 billion of assets in Asia, including stressed loans to Indian companies and other assets, to pare its balance sheet after booking record impairments. The bank is reviewing its business lines and customer relationships to identify assets for restructuring or disposal. CEO Bill Winters aims to reduce assets by $100 billion.

site_title: Wisetech Global debut augurs well for Aussie tech firms
summary: Australian freight software company Wisetech Global Ltd's shares rose 13% on its debut, signaling growing confidence in the tech sector amid the global commodities slump. This follows seven of Australia's 10-largest tech listings in the past two years. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull aims to refashion the economy as a technology hub, leading to increased acceptance of the tech sector's potential for growth.

site_title: Seoul: Won strengthens to 1-week high, stocks slightly down
summary: The South Korean won reached a one-week high, closing at 1,146.5 to the dollar, a 0.6% increase from Friday's close. Foreign investors sold a net 16.8 billion won worth of shares, offsetting demand for the dollar from dividend payments. Meanwhile, South Korean shares were slightly down, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing 0.1% lower at 1,970.37.

site_title: Malaysia's Feb factory output up 3.9% year-on-year, slightly below forecast
summary: Malaysia's February industrial production rose 3.9% year-on-year, slightly below the forecasted 4.0%. The growth was driven by increases in electricity output (10.5%), manufacturing, mining, and exports, particularly palm oil and electronic products. However, a private manufacturing index showed factory activity contracted for the 12th consecutive month in March, indicating a slowdown in the sector.

site_title: Update: China March consumer inflation stable, but producer prices fall again
summary: China's consumer price inflation rose 2.3% in March, below expectations, but producer prices fell 4.3% for the fourth consecutive year. The labor market remains a key factor supporting consumer prices, but recent data shows mixed conditions. China's economy has struggled with a correction in the real estate market, weak global demand, and high corporate debt levels. The country's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Bank of East Asia drops most in six weeks as Li re-elected
summary: Bank of East Asia Ltd (BEA) dropped 2.1% after investors re-elected Chairman David Li as a director and renewed his board's mandate to sell shares, the largest intraday loss in six weeks. Billionaire Paul Singer's Elliott Management Corp, which targeted BEA, may have suffered a setback in its attempts to weaken the Li family's hold over the lender. The annual shareholder meeting's resolutions indicate that investors do not expect a sale of the bank in the near term, and Elliott's opposition to a share sale mandate was rejected with a significant margin.

site_title: Japan households' inflation expectations hit 3-year low: BOJ
summary: Japan households' inflation expectations decreased to a 3-year low in January-March, reaching 75.7%, down from 77.6% in December. This is the lowest level since March 2013. The Bank of Japan's survey also found that 80% of households expect inflation to rise five years from now, also a low level. This data keeps alive expectations of additional monetary stimulus from the Bank of Japan.

site_title: Doha oil meet may not deliver 'bullish surprise': Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs expects the Doha oil producers meet on April 17 to not deliver a bullish surprise, as production levels in 2016 remain at average annual forecasts. Russian and OPEC production levels are expected to remain steady, hindering oil market rebalancing. A production freeze at recent levels is unlikely to have a significant impact on the market.

site_title: New Zealand to review foreign trusts in wake of Panama Papers
summary: New Zealand has ordered a review of its foreign trust laws following the release of the Panama Papers, which revealed weaknesses in the country's disclosure rules. The review, led by tax expert John Shewan, aims to determine if the current rules are fit for purpose and if improvements can be made. The move comes as more than 11.5 million leaked documents show widespread exploitation of offshore companies for tax avoidance. New Zealand requires foreign trusts to be registered and maintain detailed records, but Shewan's review will consider potential changes to disclosure rules.

site_title: Greek talks with IMF, EU lenders drag on, compromise seen
summary: Greece and its international lenders are nearing a compromise on a review of bailout reforms, which could unlock more aid. The review has dragged on due to a rift over Greece's projected fiscal shortfall by 2018. The EU and IMF have agreed to use 3% as the baseline scenario, but the IMF believes Athens will miss its 2018 surplus target, while the EU institutions believe it's feasible. A positive review could unlock up to 5 billion euros in aid, crucial for Greece to repay debts and address unpaid domestic bills.

site_title: China March vehicle sales up 7.8% year on year
summary: China's vehicle sales in March rose 7.8% year-over-year, reaching 1.92 million, according to the China Passenger Car Association. For the January-March period, sales increased 6.8% from the same period in 2015. The China Association of Automobile Manufacturers is expected to report wholesale data for March on Tuesday.

site_title: Korean banks face uphill battle to raise regulatory capital
summary: South Korean banks face a significant challenge in raising regulatory capital due to international supervisory authorities' concerns over the structure of their Additional Tier 1 securities. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision questions the 30-year maturity of these securities, which are counted as perpetual in Korea due to the option to extend the maturity. This has led to delays in Woori Bank's AT1 issue and poses a risk for the bank, which has lower capital ratios than its peers. The regulator is exploring solutions to resolve the issue and persuade Basel authorities that these bonds are effectively perpetual.

site_title: Malaysia said planning as much as US$1.5b islamic bond sale
summary: Malaysia plans to sell up to $1.5 billion of global Islamic bonds, with maturities of 10 and 30 years, to refinance $1.2 billion of Shariah-compliant debt due in July. The sale coincides with a rebound in the ringgit and improving sentiment, following an indebted state investment company's asset sales and lower sovereign note default risk. The proceeds will be used to refinance debt and take advantage of a rising Brent crude price, which has brightened the outlook for the oil exporter's finances.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars edge up on commodity rally
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars edged up on Monday, driven by a rally in commodities. The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7566, while the New Zealand dollar stood at 73.45 yen. The gains were muted by a rising yen and a steep decline in the Aussie dollar last week, which saw a 5% loss. Investors were drawn to the Aussie dollar due to lower interest rates in Japan, with Australian government bond yields at 1.8%, compared to record lows in Japanese securities.

site_title: Oil prices rise in Asia as Doha meeting, US report loom
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Monday, extending last week's gains, driven by data showing a drop in US production and stockpiles. Dealers await the April 17 Doha meeting of oil majors, hoping for output limits to address the global glut. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 13 cents to $39.85, while Brent crude increased 15 cents to $42.09. Analysts expect the meeting to discuss a production freeze, but some believe a production cut would be more effective in boosting prices.

site_title: StarHub, Huawei demonstrate gigabit speed indoor 4G coverage
summary: StarHub and Huawei partnered to provide superfast 4G coverage in indoor locations, showcasing the world's fastest one gigabit per second (Gbps) indoor coverage solution. The solution combined StarHub's 55MHz frequency spectrum to deliver gigabit-bandwidth from a small cell base station. Commercial trials are ongoing, with StarHub aiming to deploy the solution when supported phone models reach Singapore's shores. This milestone comes after StarHub's deployment of Huawei's small cell solution to boost indoor network capacity and speeds for customers.

site_title: Alibaba-backed deals rekindle US$39b China buyout debate
summary: Alibaba-backed deals have reignited a US$39 billion buyout debate for Chinese companies listed on US exchanges. Since June, a buyout for dating app maker Momo Inc has stalled but may proceed after Alibaba-backed companies joined the deal. Meanwhile, 40 Chinese companies have received buyout offers, with only seven having completed the process. The trend's direction remains uncertain, with opinions split among investors and analysts.

site_title: China internet regulator says web censorship not a trade barrier
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) has denied that its internet censorship system, known as the Great Firewall, constitutes a trade barrier. The US Trade Representative had previously labeled the blocking of websites by Beijing as a trade impediment. The CAC stated that its online censorship aims to protect national security and safeguard user information security, and that it abides by World Trade Organization principles. The blocking of websites such as Google's, Facebook's, and Twitter's, as well as many global news sites, is mainly related to "national security" concerns.

site_title: Singapore fund seeks court ruling on Mitsui Life takeover price
summary: TIHT Investment Holdings, a Singaporean private equity firm, has asked the Tokyo District Court to review the price Nippon Life Insurance Co paid to buy its stake in Mitsui Life Insurance Co, claiming it was too low. The takeover price was set at 560 yen per share, significantly lower than the estimated embedded value of 1,746 yen per share. TIHT claims the process ignored embedded value, a measure used to gauge the worth of life insurers. The deal was valued at about 334 billion yen, as Nippon Life acquired 92.16% of Mitsui Life's voting rights.

site_title: Hot Stock: OSIM shares jump to S$1.39, Ron Sim's final ex-dividend offer price
summary: OSIM International shares rose 2 cents to S$1.39, following Credit Suisse's announcement of Ron Sim's final ex-dividend offer price. This marks the end of Sim's privatization bid, with shareholders receiving S$1.41 per share. The offer price was announced after the company's shares opened 2 cents higher on Monday morning, with 3.1 million shares changing hands.

site_title: France bewitched by 'Bojangles', a book full of joy and tears
summary: A French author, Olivier Bourdeaut, has become a literary sensation with his debut novel "Waiting for Bojangles," a heartwarming tale of a boy growing up in a bohemian home. Despite struggling with dyslexia, Bourdeaut wrote the book in seven weeks and won three top literary awards. Critics praise the book's unique blend of humor and pathos, comparing it to Muriel Barbery's bestseller "The Elegance of the Hedgehog." The novel has been translated into 13 languages and has resonated with readers, who have reported laughing and crying while reading it.

site_title: Asia: Shares, dollar start week on the back foot
summary: Asian stocks began the week on a weak note, with Japan's Nikkei index falling 1.3% due to a strengthening yen and subdued business investment. The dollar hit a 17-month low against the yen, prompting warnings from Japanese officials. China's consumer price inflation was less than expected, but deflationary pressure remains. Despite this, Chinese shares rose 1.8-1.9%. The dollar index fell 0.2% to near its lowest since October, while euro and yen rose. Crude oil prices edged higher after a 6% gain on Friday.

site_title: Japan's Suga: Recent FX moves are one-sided and speculative
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that recent currency moves are one-sided and speculative, and the government will take necessary steps. The dollar fell to 107.63 yen, its lowest since October 2014, amid the Group of 20's agreement to avoid competitive currency devaluation. Suga clarified that Japan can intervene in response to one-sided currency moves, despite the agreement.

images.alt_text: Chief Cabinet secretary Yoshihide Suga told a news conference that the government was monitoring the foreign exchange market closely with a sense of urgency.

site_title: Seoul: Won up on broad US dollar weakness, stocks edge down
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.5% to 1,148.6 against the US dollar due to global dollar weakness, despite potential selling triggered by dividend payments. Stocks edged down with no strong catalysts, and foreigners were expected to sell about 33.1 billion won worth of KOSPI shares. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.2% to 1,968.37 points, with Samsung Engineering Co Ltd shares gaining 6.4% and chipmaker SK Hynix Inc down 1.6%.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; TSMC, Hon Hai down on sales results
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.7% on Monday, with TSMC and Hon Hai Precision down 1% and 1.1% respectively, due to disappointing sales results. The electronics subindex sank 0.6% and the financials subindex lost 0.9%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.449 per US dollar. The decline was attributed to the companies' weaker-than-expected sales figures, which weighed on the overall market.

site_title: Chinese buyers double their Aussie property investments again
summary: Chinese buyers have doubled their Australian property investments for the second consecutive year, with spending reaching A$24.3 billion in the 12 months through June 2015. This surge in investment has driven a 55% jump in home prices across Australia's capital cities over the past seven years. The US remains the second-largest foreign investor, with spending of A$25.1 billion in 2014-15. The government has tightened scrutiny of foreign investment amid concerns that locals are being priced out of the property market.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares struggle as financials weigh
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index easing 0.4% due to financial stocks being weighed down by an increase in poorly performing loans and a scandal over interest rate fixing. Banking stocks led the decline, with Westpac Banking Corp and Macquarie Group dropping 1.2% and 1.3%, respectively. However, the energy sector outperformed, with WorleyParsons, Origin Energy, and Santos rising 3.7%, 3.4%, and 2.35%, respectively.

site_title: Bank of Italy conducting supervisory inspection at Bank of China offices
summary: The Bank of Italy is conducting a supervisory inspection at Bank of China's Italian offices, amid allegations of aiding illicit money flows from Italy to China. Italian prosecutors seek to indict 297 people, mostly Chinese, and the Milan branch of Bank of China on charges of smuggling over 4.5 billion euros between 2006 and 2010. The inspection is routine and unrelated to the ongoing 'River of Money' probe, which focuses on Bank of China's relationship with defunct Money2Money.

site_title: Moody's says rate cuts to hit Thai banks' margins, profits
summary: Thailand's major banks cut their minimum lending rates, but Moody's Investors Service says this move is "credit negative" due to reduced net interest margins. The rate cut, which was a surprise, may not improve credit demand, as the economy is expected to remain subdued. Moody's forecasts 2.5% real GDP growth in 2016, down from 2.8% in 2015. The banking sector credit growth has slowed to 4.3% in 2015, down from 11% from 2010 to 2014.

images.alt_text: A rate cut by Thailand's major banks is "credit negative" because it will squeeze net interest margins (NIMs) while funding costs are unlikely to change over the next two to three quarters, Moody's Investors Service analysts said on Monday.

site_title: China Railway Materials Co suspends debt trade, cites payment issues
summary: China Railway Materials Co Ltd suspended trading in 16.8 billion yuan (S$3.51 billion) of debt instruments due to payment issues. The company cited shrinking business and sliding operating performance as reasons for the suspension. This marks the first time a central government-owned enterprise has halted debt instrument trading due to repayment problems. China's debt market has seen an increase in defaults over the past year as the economy slows. The company is currently discussing restructuring and debt payment issues.

site_title: Biggest shipping-container maker plans 6b yuan share sale
summary: China International Marine Containers Group Co (CIMC), the world's largest shipping container maker, plans to raise up to 6 billion yuan (S$1.25 billion) through a share sale to fund business expansion. The company will sell yuan-denominated stock to a maximum of 10 investors at 13.86 yuan per share, a discount of 8.2% from the previous day's close. The funds will be used to develop a financial-leasing arm's business park in Shenzhen and other assets. This move comes amid a global slump in container-shipping rates and overcapacity in the sea-freight market.

site_title: Gold nears three-week high as 'risk-off' mood increases demand
summary: Gold prices surged to a three-week high, reaching $1,251.09 an ounce, amid a "risk-off" mood and decreased bets on interest rate hikes. The metal gained 1.5% last week, its largest weekly increase since March, as investors sought haven assets amid global stock market weakness. The rally follows the Federal Reserve's dovish posture and rising demand, with RBC Capital Markets raising its average gold-price forecast for 2016 by 9%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.210 points to 1716.190. Volume reached 32.7 million lots worth RM11 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 57.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall as yen rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 losing 1.13% and the Topix index slipping 1.2%. The Japanese yen strengthened, contributing to the decline. Machinery orders dropped 3.4% in February, according to government data. The yen's rally and weak machinery orders data led to the stock market downturn.

site_title: Hwa Hong buys half of London building
summary: Hwa Hong Corporation's unit, Singapore Warehouse Company, acquired a 50% stake in Capital Herbal Limited and purchased the 3-7 Herbal Hill property in London's Clerkenwell area for £24.8 million. The 32,935 square foot property consists of seven floors of office accommodation. The deal was completed with a total cash payment of £24.8 million, equivalent to approximately S$47.37 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, SingPost, Sheng Siong
summary: Olam plans to invest US$150 million in Nigeria for animal feed mills, poultry breeding farms, and hatcheries. Singapore Post saw top-level changes, with Keith Tay Ah Kee stepping down as nominations committee chairman. Sheng Siong Group purchased a Housing Board commercial property in New Upper Changi Road for S$53 million.

site_title: Abenomics rebuked as BlackRock joins US$46b Japan pullout
summary: BlackRock joins US$46 billion Japan pullout, as foreign traders dump Tokyo's stock market for 13 straight weeks, the longest stretch since 1998. The benchmark Topix index is down 18% in 2016, with overseas traders losing faith in Japan's economic recovery under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. This pullout would be a significant blow to Abe's growth strategies and the Japanese government's efforts to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Hedge funds place record bullish yen bets amid volatility surge
summary: Hedge funds have placed record bullish bets on the Japanese yen, with speculators increasing wagers to the highest since 1992, as the currency rallied to a 17-month high. Despite Japanese authorities' efforts to curb the yen's advance, hedge funds remain optimistic, with Deutsche Bank and Bank of Singapore stating the yen is "not overvalued." The yen strengthened 0.3% to 107.80 against the US dollar, with analysts attributing the surge to justified fundamentals. The yen's volatility surged to a four-year high, defying rhetoric from Japanese authorities.

site_title: China March CPI unchanged at 2.3% y-o-y, below forecasts
summary: China's consumer price inflation in March remained unchanged at 2.3% year-over-year, below market expectations of a 2.5% increase. Producer prices fell 4.3% from the previous year. The data suggests China's economic growth may slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% down on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.3% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index at 2,799.82, following a weak opening despite a Wall Street rally on Friday. The blue-chip index had shed 8.5 points. Trading volume was 195.9 million shares worth S$45.6 million.

site_title: Asia: Stocks decline as Japanese shares slump amid economic data
summary: Asian stocks fell 0.4% to 125.83, driven by a slump in Japanese shares amid a decline in machine orders. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped ahead of Chinese data on inflation and factory prices, while energy producers climbed as US oil topped $40 a barrel. Investors lost faith in central bank policies, with Japan's Topix index declining 1% and the benchmark equities gauge down 18% in 2016. China is set to report consumer and producer price data, and futures on Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.2%.

site_title: Don't fear China, say top currency analysts seeing Asian gains
summary: Top currency analysts predict gains for emerging-Asian currencies, despite China's slump. ING Groep NV and Commonwealth Bank of Australia forecast at least seven of 10 currencies to appreciate by year-end, driven by China's support for yuan gains and stable fixing against the dollar. Analysts expect the yuan to strengthen 2.7-3.5% and the US dollar to drift lower, generating Asian currency strength. Gains are expected in currencies like the Malaysian ringgit, Taiwanese dollar, and South Korean won, with Thailand's baht also predicted to strengthen.

site_title: Foreigners seek South Korean stocks, bonds in March after three months of selling
summary: Foreign investors boosted South Korean bond holdings by 570 billion won in March, marking the first time in four months. This follows a pullback of 4.2 trillion won in February. Swiss investors led the increase, followed by Australians and Chinese investors. The foreign inflows support comments from policymakers that market volatility is settling down.

site_title: Tale of two Chinas is emerging as economy slows, Fidelity says
summary: China's economy is slowing, with a tale of two countries emerging as regions focused on services and consumption experience growth, while those reliant on resources struggle. Fidelity's latest survey indicates a deteriorating corporate climate, with China scoring 4.1 out of 10. Economists predict a deceleration in GDP growth, with some forecasting a "bumpy landing" or "lost decade" of economic stagnation. The Chinese government faces challenges in slowing down the economy without a crisis, with a "soft landing" deemed unlikely.

site_title: China: Shanghai rallies at open after inflation data
summary: China's Shanghai stocks rose 0.74% in the first few minutes of trade on Monday after inflation data showed inflation above 2% in March, easing concerns about deflation. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 21.95 points to 3,006.91, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 17.28 points to 1,931.60. In contrast, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.56% to 20,255.84. The rally was seen as a positive sign for China's economy, despite ongoing trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Obama to meet Fed Chair Yellen on Monday
summary: US President Barack Obama will meet with Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen on Monday to discuss the economy and Wall Street reform. This meeting, attended by Vice President Joe Biden, comes as the Fed signals caution on interest rate increases due to global economic concerns. Obama has overseen a steady economic recovery since the 2008 financial crisis, nearing the end of his term in office.

images.alt_text: US President Barack Obama will meet with US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen (pictured) on Monday to discuss the economy and Wall Street reform, the White House said on Sunday.

site_title: China's US$6b tech funding boom signals flight to quality
summary: China's venture capital market is experiencing a boom, with investors pouring in $6 billion for top startups like Didi Kuaidi and Alibaba's finance affiliate. Despite a global downturn in venture deals, China's investments surged 50% to $12.2 billion in the first quarter. Larger startups are attracting major backers, while smaller operators are struggling. The market's polarized, with top 20% of startups getting 80% of the funding.

site_title: Panama furor rumbles into second week as global pressure mounts
summary: The Panama Papers scandal continues to unfold, with global pressure mounting on governments and financial institutions to address tax evasion and transparency. UK Prime Minister David Cameron has been forced to provide more information on his wealth, while European officials pledge measures to require companies to report offshore bank accounts. Iceland's prime minister has resigned, and Malta's government faces a confidence vote. The scandal has undermined public trust in governments worldwide, with over 20 nations launching probes into the leaked documents, and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to host a meeting on April 13.

site_title: UK economy lost steam in Q1, industry survey shows
summary: The UK economy lost steam in Q1, according to a survey by the British Chambers of Commerce, with domestic demand slipping for both services and manufacturing companies. Key gauges, such as sales growth and consumer confidence, stagnated or fell, indicating modest economic growth with potential downside risks. Manufacturing exports picked up slightly, but services exports declined to their lowest since 2011. The survey cited "mounting global and domestic uncertainties" as reasons for the weaker outlook, without mentioning the June 23 EU referendum.

images.alt_text: Britain's economy lost steam in the first three months of the year, according to a major survey of businesses that showed domestic demand slipped for both services and manufacturing companies.

site_title: UK to criminalise firms whose staff abet tax evasion
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron announced plans to make companies liable for staff facilitating tax evasion, targeting firms with lax supervisory mechanisms and those that promote tax evasion. The measure is expected to be written into law this year. This move comes after the Panama Papers leaked exposed tax avoidance by the wealthy. Cameron also faces criticism for his own tax affairs, following the leak of his father's investment fund. The UK has launched a £10 million taskforce to scrutinize the leaked files.

site_title: Japan Feb core machinery orders fall 9.2% month-on-month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 9.2% in February, a 12.4% decline in median estimates, indicating subdued business investment. This marks a reversal from January's 15.0% rise. Year-over-year, core orders fell 0.7%, less than the 2.7% drop in median estimates. The data suggests a slowdown in capital spending over the next six to nine months.

site_title: CDL names Kwek Leng Beng's son deputy CEO, appoints new CFO
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) has appointed Sherman Kwek Eik Tse, the son of real estate tycoon Kwek Leng Beng, as deputy CEO, assisting CEO Grant Kelley in overseeing key divisions. Kwek Eik Tse will relinquish his investment and China CEO roles. CDL also named Yiong Yim Ming, 42, as new CFO, replacing Goh Ann Nee who resigned in January. Kwek Eik Sheng, nephew of Kwek Leng Beng, has been appointed head of asset management, overseeing the group's asset portfolio. The appointments took effect from Monday.

site_title: Obama cites lack of 'day after' plan in Libya as biggest mistake
summary: President Barack Obama cited the lack of a "day after" plan for Libya's governance after the US-led NATO attacks in 2011 as his biggest mistake in office. He stated that intervening in Libya "was the right thing to do," but acknowledged the chaotic aftermath and the rise of the Islamic State in the country. Obama defended his decision, saying it was a close call, but Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's support was pivotal in persuading him to broaden the goal beyond just saving Benghazi residents to regime change.

site_title: Obama 'guarantees' Clinton e-mail investigations to be fair
summary: President Barack Obama has guaranteed that there will be no political interference in the investigation into Hillary Clinton's e-mail practices, stating that the Justice Department and FBI operate independently. He expressed skepticism about the government's classification process, but maintains that Clinton has not jeopardized national security. Obama also pressed the Senate to hold a hearing for his Supreme Court nominee Merrick Garland, despite Republican opposition, warning that refusal to do so could set a precedent.

site_title: Fujimori headed to run-off in Peru presidential election
summary: Keiko Fujimori, daughter of jailed former Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori, led the first round of the country's presidential election but failed to win more than 50% of the votes, forcing a run-off in June. Fujimori, a conservative, trailed behind Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, a center-right economist, and Veronika Mendoza, a leftist candidate, with exit polls showing Kuczynski and Mendoza nearly tied. The run-off is expected to determine the fate of Peru's free-market economic model and may impact the country's mining industry.

site_title: World Bank trims 2016, 2017 East Asia growth forecasts, cites risks to outlook
summary: The World Bank has trimmed its economic growth forecasts for developing East Asia and Pacific to 6.3% in 2016 and 6.2% in 2017, citing risks such as uncertainty over China's growth, financial market volatility, and further falls in commodity prices. China's growth is expected to slow to 6.7% in 2016 and 6.5% in 2017, while Malaysia and Thailand's growth forecasts have been lowered to 4.4% and 2.5% respectively. Indonesia's growth is expected to accelerate to 5.1% in 2016 and 5.3% in 2017, contingent on an ambitious public investment program.

site_title: Mystery US$9b in extra cash perplexes India
summary: India is experiencing a mysterious spike in cash, with US$7.5 billion to US$9 billion more than anticipated, leaving economists perplexed. Central bank Governor Raghuram Rajan suggests that the increase may be due to election-related spending, including money for votes and campaign expenses. However, some economists argue that it could be related to faster-than-expected economic growth in rural areas or the removal of larger bank notes from circulation. The cause of the sudden cash influx remains unclear.

site_title: Janet Jackson promises 2017 tour after family delay
summary: Janet Jackson has announced she will resume her 2017 world tour after suspending all dates in 2016 to start a family with her husband Wissam Al Mana. The pop star, who is 50 next month, had postponed all tour dates, including the European leg, and initially denied rumors of cancer. She now promises to honor all existing tickets and offer refunds for those unable to attend. No further details about her family plans have been shared.

site_title: Pain in India's real estate market spells opportunity for Godrej
summary: India's real estate market is experiencing a downturn due to sluggish sales, unsold inventory, and a new regulatory bill that restricts developers' ability to divert funds. However, larger developers like Godrej Properties Ltd are thriving, with residential sales more than doubling in the quarter ended Dec 31. The company expects its best year ever for new project acquisitions and is seeing brisk business, with a 53% increase in profit to 2.13 billion rupees in the nine months ended Dec 31. Godrej Properties will focus on its top four markets and is well-positioned to take advantage of the current weakness in the market.

site_title: A 92 US cents chip for driverless cars is a windfall for Japan maker
summary: Nippon Ceramic, a Japanese company, controls about half of the global market for ultrasonic sensors used in autonomous vehicles, which cost 92 US cents. The company expects demand to double in the next five years, with projected sales of 25 billion yen by 2020, and plans to invest 1 billion yen to expand manufacturing capacity. Analysts predict Nippon Ceramic's net income will nearly double by 2018, driven by the growing demand for driver-assistance features in vehicles. Several major automakers, including Toyota and Google, aim to introduce driverless cars within the next five years.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust sells Tuas property for S$16.5m
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) has agreed to sell its remaining leasehold interest in a 4-storey industrial building at 23 Tuas Avenue 10 for S$16.5 million, a 5% premium above its book value. The building has a gross floor area of 102,310 sq ft and a remaining land tenure of about 40 years. The sale proceeds will be used to repay debt, fund refurbishments, and potential acquisitions. The sale is expected to be completed in June 2016, pending approval by JTC Corporation.

site_title: Kerry, G7 ministers to visit Hiroshima atomic bomb memorial
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry and other G7 foreign ministers visited the Hiroshima atomic bomb memorial on April 11, 2016, marking the first by a US administration official. Kerry ruled out an apology for the 1945 atomic bombing that killed 140,000 people, citing the importance of the US-Japan alliance. The visit aimed to strengthen ties with Japan, with Kerry being the first US secretary of state to visit Hiroshima. This was not the first US visit to the memorial, as Nancy Pelosi visited in 2008.

images.alt_text: John Kerry and other G7 foreign ministers on Monday were set to make a landmark visit to the memorial site for the world's first nuclear attack, as a US official ruled out an apology for the World War II atomic bombing that left 140,000 people dead.

site_title: Germany suggests plan to combat tax havens
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble has proposed a 10-point plan to combat tax havens, including creating an international network of company registers to list actual owners and urging other countries to join the automatic tax information exchange agreement. This plan follows the Panama Papers leak, which exposed the use of offshore firms by wealthy individuals and world leaders. Germany has already implemented tougher administrative measures and standards, and Schaeuble believes international cooperation is crucial to combating tax evasion and money laundering.

site_title: Daily Mail parent in talks with private equity for Yahoo bid
summary: The parent company of the Daily Mail, Daily Mail & General Trust PLC, is in talks with private equity firms about a potential bid for Yahoo Inc. The bid could take two forms: acquiring Yahoo's core web business with the Mail taking over its news and media properties, or merging the two companies into a new entity with a larger equity stake for the Mail. Bids for Yahoo are due on April 18, with Time Inc also considering partnering with a private equity firm on a bid.

site_title: US banks' dismal first quarter may spell trouble for 2016
summary: US banks' dismal first quarter may signal a troubled 2016, with analysts citing concerns over economic growth in China, low oil prices, and near-zero interest rates. This marks the worst start to the year since the 2007-2008 financial crisis. Poor loan growth and capital markets activity are expected to contribute to the poor results.

site_title: SunEdison's TerraForm Global acquires solar farm in Uruguay
summary: TerraForm Global, a holding company of SunEdison, acquired a 26.4-megawatt solar farm in Uruguay for $35.4 million, completing its first acquisition since struggling parent SunEdison's debt issues. TerraForm Global aims to distance itself from SunEdison, which is facing potential insolvency proceedings due to $1.4 billion in loan defaults. The acquisition is part of TerraForm Global's efforts to create a self-sustaining portfolio of assets, which may help it if SunEdison seeks creditor protection.

images.alt_text: TerraForm Global Inc, a holding company founded and controlled by clean-energy developer SunEdison Inc, did something Friday its parent has struggled to do recently: complete an acquisition.

site_title: Target Australia chief resigns amid probe into rebate scheme
summary: Target Australia's managing director Stuart Machin resigned amid an investigation into a rebate scheme that allegedly inflated earnings. Machin denied involvement but took responsibility for the accounting issues. The scheme involved bringing forward supplier rebates to boost first-half profits. Machin's resignation comes after he was set to shift to a senior executive role in July. The investigation is ongoing, and the outcome is unclear.

site_title: Oil extends gains as US rigs idled before Doha freeze talks
summary: Oil prices extended gains, rising 1.9% in New York after the US idled more rigs ahead of Doha talks on freezing output. The US saw its lowest level of active oil rigs in 16 weeks. Venezuela urged producers to freeze output first, while Saudi Arabia said it would agree to a freeze if joined by other suppliers. Crude oil prices rebounded after reaching a 13-year low, with West Texas Intermediate rising to $40.47 a barrel. Brent crude also gained, adding 1.2% to $42.45 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil extended gains after its biggest jump in almost two months on Friday as US drillers idled more rigs ahead of talks between the world's biggest suppliers about freezing output.

site_title: Brazilian scientists find new Zika-linked brain disorder in adults
summary: Brazilian scientists have discovered a new Zika-linked brain disorder in adults, acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), which attacks the brain and spinal cord. This autoimmune syndrome is similar to Guillain-Barre syndrome, which has already been linked to Zika. The discovery adds to the growing list of neurological damage associated with Zika, and researchers are investigating the reasons behind this connection. The study involved 151 patients who visited a hospital in Brazil and found six cases of ADEM, with symptoms lasting about six months. The findings have sparked concern and calls for further research into the causes of Zika's effects on the central nervous system.

site_title: Riots, deportations headline spoof 'President Trump' front page
summary: The Boston Globe published a satirical front page on April 10, 2016, imagining a Donald Trump presidency, with headlines including "Deportations to begin" and "Markets sink as trade war looms." The mockup sparked nationwide riots and curfews, and Trump responded by calling the newspaper "stupid." The Globe's editorial warned that Trump's vision for America is "deeply disturbing" and urged Republicans to reject his populist rhetoric and consider alternative nominees.

site_title: Cruz, Sanders notch gains in White House primaries
summary: US presidential primaries saw gains for Republican Ted Cruz and Democrat Bernie Sanders. Cruz won all 13 Colorado delegates, his fourth consecutive victory against Donald Trump. Sanders also made gains, although no specific delegate count is mentioned. The victories come with 10 days to go until the pivotal New York primary. Cruz's win marks a tightening of the Republican field, while Sanders' gains suggest he may be closing the gap with front-runner Hillary Clinton.

site_title: Korean election brings Park's labor-law overhaul to a crossroad
summary: South Korea's parliamentary election is set to determine the fate of President Park Geun Hye's labor-law overhaul package, aimed at boosting economic growth and employment rates. The package, which includes allowing more temporary workers and easing dismissal rules, faces opposition from labor unions and analysts estimate it will need 150-180 seats to pass. The ruling Saenuri party's support rating has risen to 39%, while the opposition's remains steady at 21%. The outcome will decide whether the package can be fast-tracked, with Park's economic revival goals hanging in the balance.

images.alt_text: The fate of President Park Geun Hye's effort to spur economic revival through an overhaul of labor laws hangs in the balance this week as South Koreans go to the polls for a parliamentary election.

site_title: India's audacious plan to bring digital banking to 1.2 billion people
summary: India's government has launched the Unified Payment Interface (UPI), a digital payment system designed to bring banking and financial services to its 1.2 billion population. The system, backed by India's central bank and retail banks, uses biometrics-enabled national ID, Aadhaar, to facilitate easy transactions. With over 80% of Indians enrolled in Aadhaar, the UPI is expected to bring banking to the unbanked, replicating Kenya's successful M-PESA system. The system's success hinges on low transaction fees and user experience, with costs expected to decrease over time.

site_title: India's budget for climate adaptation inadequate: activists
summary: India's government has faced criticism for its inadequate climate adaptation budget, with 3.5 billion rupees (S$70.89 million) allocated for the next two financial years. Environmental experts consider this amount insufficient given the country's size and climate challenges. The allocated funds have not yet been used for climate adaptation activities, according to the environment minister.

site_title: Iraq boosts oil production to record before talks to cap output
summary: Iraq increased crude oil production to a record 4.55 million barrels per day in March, ahead of an OPEC meeting to discuss output caps. This boost comes as the country seeks to shore up revenue, which has been squeezed by plummeting oil prices. Iraq's oil minister had previously suspended participation in the cabinet due to government disarray, but the country is still expected to support an agreement to cap production at January levels. The OPEC meeting will take place on April 17 to discuss a possible freeze in crude output.

site_title: Argentina, creditors agree US$253m more in default settlement: mediator
summary: Argentina has reached settlements with additional creditors holding defaulted sovereign bonds for US$253 million, bringing the aggregate amount of settled claims to approximately US$8 billion. The settlements, reached with several groups of creditors, are part of a 14-year legal battle over Argentina's historic default. The country has made significant progress since President Mauricio Macri's election, moving swiftly to settle the debt dispute. Argentina is set to make a historic return to the international capital markets, with plans to issue up to US$12.5 billion in new bonds to pay all settled claims.

site_title: China's Zhou confident Latin America economies will grow
summary: People's Bank of China governor Zhou Xiaochuan expressed confidence in Latin America's ability to weather the global economic slowdown, citing "moderated" economic growth in 2015. Despite challenges and uncertainties, Zhou believes the region has the potential for sustainable growth. The statement was made during the annual meeting of the Inter-American Development Bank, highlighting China's optimism about Latin America's economic prospects.

site_title: Solution on Greece will be found soon but without debt relief: German finance minister
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that a solution for Greece will be found in the next few weeks, but it will not include debt relief. Instead, Greece needs to implement reforms to become a competitive economy. Schaeuble argued that debt relief is not a priority, as Greece already has high debt maturities and interest repayments have been deferred for 10 years.

site_title: Hit by Panama row, UK's Cameron announces new tax evasion law
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron announced a new tax evasion law, making companies criminally liable if employees aid tax evasion, amid damage from the Panama Papers scandal. The move comes after Cameron published tax records to address criticism over his personal finances. He had admitted to benefiting from selling his share in his father's offshore fund in 2010. The new law will be introduced this year in an effort to repair the damage and restore trust.

site_title: Kerry apology for Hiroshima bombing not on table: US official
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry will not issue an apology for the atomic bombing of Hiroshima during his visit to the city for G7 talks. A State Department official stated that a formal apology was not on the table, but Kerry expressed sorrow for the tragedies that befell American and Japanese citizens during the bombing. Kerry's visit is seen as a step towards potentially becoming the first US president to visit Hiroshima, paving the way for President Barack Obama's possible visit next month.

site_title: Brazil capital ramps up security for impeachment vote
summary: Brazil's capital, Brasilia, has increased security measures ahead of a crucial vote on President Dilma Rousseff's impeachment. Barricades have been erected on the Esplanade of Ministries to separate supporters and opponents, with officials anticipating 300,000 people gathering later in the week. Rousseff faces impeachment for allegedly juggling government accounts, a charge she denies constitutes an impeachable offense. The vote is scheduled for Monday, with a subsequent vote by the lower house of Congress set for next weekend, amid a massive recession and plummeting approval ratings for her government.

images.alt_text: Workers erected barricades on Sunday along Brasilia's Esplanade of Ministries to separate supporters and opponents of President Dilma Rousseff's impeachment, on the eve of a crucial vote on her political fate.

site_title: Peru votes on Fujimori daughter in chaotic election
summary: Peru held a chaotic election, with 40-year-old Keiko Fujimori, daughter of ex-president Alberto Fujimori, winning top spot in opinion polls. Despite attempts to ban her and widespread mistrust over her father's legacy, she survived to reach a second-round runoff against either ex-prime minister Pedro Pablo Kuczynski or left-wing lawmaker Veronika Mendoza. The election was marred by allegations of vote-buying and deadly attacks, casting doubt on the legitimacy of the results.

site_title: German criticism of ECB gets louder as politicians say savers are losing out
summary: German conservative politicians are criticizing the European Central Bank's interest rate policy, saying it's hurting ordinary Germans' retirement provisions and potentially boosting the right-wing. Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble and other politicians blame the ECB for the success of the right-wing Alternative for Germany party in regional elections. The ECB's policy, which includes cutting interest rates into negative territory, has led to a loss of 343 billion euros in interest on savings between 2010 and 2016, with some politicians warning of asset bubbles and excessive debt.

site_title: Turnbull pledges A$490m for Western Australia infrastructure
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's government has pledged A$490 million for infrastructure in Western Australia in the upcoming financial year. The investment aims to address the state's low share of goods and services tax revenue. The allocation follows a similar investment last year, as Western Australia continues to receive the lowest revenue from the tax, relative to population. This move comes amid concerns over the state's finances and the impact of iron ore price drops on its budget.

site_title: Pound may get little relief from slight inflation uptick
summary: The pound is unlikely to receive significant relief from inflation, which is expected to have quickened to 0.4% in March, its fastest pace in over a year. This data, set to be released on April 12, comes as traders shift their attention away from the UK's European Union membership vote. The potential exit from the world's largest single market also weighs heavily on sterling, making a boost to the pound this week unlikely. Economists expect a muted reaction to the data, indicating a lack of significant impact on the currency.

site_title: Austria to stay tough on migrants: new interior minister
summary: Austria's new Interior Minister Wolfgang Sobotka has vowed to maintain the country's hardline stance on migrants, continuing the policies implemented by his predecessor Johanna Mikl-Leitner. Mikl-Leitner, who will become acting regional governor in Lower Austria, has overseen the introduction of border fences, tougher controls, and annual caps on migrant numbers. The move is part of Austria's efforts to build "fortress Europe" and stem migration from the Balkan region. Sobotka has expressed a commitment to these policies, despite criticism from some quarters.

images.alt_text: Austria's new Interior Minister Wolfgang Sobotka said on Sunday he would stick to the hardline stance on migrants pushed by his predecessor, Johanna Mikl-Leitner.

site_title: Frenchman sets out to become first person to cross Atlantic on stand-up paddle
summary: A Frenchman, Nicolas Jarossay, has embarked on a solo 5,000-kilometre journey to become the first person to cross the Atlantic on a stand-up paddle. Leaving Praia, Cape Verde, Jarossay aims to paddle into the French Caribbean island of Martinique in approximately two months. The 38-year-old firefighter and endurance sports enthusiast is using a modified paddle, 7 meters long and 83 centimeters wide, to tackle the challenge.

site_title: The long and short of it: higher volatility ahead
summary: Market volatility is expected to rise in the coming weeks as short-selling and short-covering continue to play a significant role in price movements. The Dow futures market's gyrations, driven by oil prices and US interest rate expectations, are influencing local market movements. With the US economic outlook weakening, investors are bracing for a fresh round of shorting, potentially exacerbated by a strengthening US dollar and weak oil prices. Index volatility is likely to increase, driven by the uncertainty surrounding the global economy and the US dollar.

site_title: IMF defends negative interest rates despite risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has defended the use of negative interest rates by central banks, citing their potential to deliver additional monetary stimulus and easier financial conditions despite significant risks of slow growth and boom-and-bust cycles. The measure, taken by six central banks, aims to loosen credit and stimulate consumer spending and investment. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde has previously expressed support for the unorthodox rates, while the IMF's top officials acknowledge the need for close monitoring and supervisory scrutiny to mitigate potential risks.

images.alt_text: Six central banks, notably the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan (pictured), have taken the unprecedented measure, aimed at loosening the reins on credit to help spur consumer spending and investment.

site_title: Marking three years in Singapore, Uber says it has learnt much here
summary: Uber marks its third year in Singapore, having evolved from a ridebooking app to a vehicle financing platform. The company credits the country's forward-thinking leadership and vision for a Smart Nation as key factors in its growth. Singapore's open environment for introducing new technologies has allowed Uber to test and adopt intelligent marketplace improvements. Under the guidance of General Manager Warren Tseng, Uber has learned valuable lessons and best practices in Singapore.

site_title: MAS eases rules on ETF transactions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has eased rules on financial advisers, allowing them to directly facilitate ETF transactions for clients, provided orders are in writing or electronically. About 20 financial advisory firms have applied for permission to do so, citing the opportunity for more business from a lower-cost investment product. This move is seen as a step towards giving retail investors access to a wider pool of investments, following regulatory proposals aimed at expanding the Securities and Futures Act Dealing Exemption.

site_title: Much tighter security at US airports this summer
summary: The US Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has announced increased security measures at airports this summer following the Brussels airport bombings. TSA head Peter Neffenger said that public areas are vulnerable to attacks, and the agency is taking steps to improve security, including more armed police officers, explosive-sniffing dogs, and random searches. The TSA plans to double its bomb-sniffing dogs and increase vetting of airport workers. Passengers can expect longer security lines and more visible police presence, with some areas being checked by local law enforcement before arriving at the airport.

images.alt_text: The US Transportation Security Administration says people will see a much more visible police presence at US airports in the months to come and an increase in bomb-sniffing dogs as fast as they can be trained.

site_title: China stanches flow of money out of the country, data suggests
summary: China has stemmed the outflow of money from the country, with its foreign-exchange reserves growing for the first time in five months, according to recent data. The reserves, valued at $3.21 trillion, rose by $10.3 billion in March, reversing the decline seen in previous months. This shift is attributed to the weakening dollar and China's efforts to stabilize its currency, the renminbi. Economists and bankers believe China will continue to prevent a broad fall in the renminbi, with the country's central bank placing large bets in currency markets to maintain its current exchange rate.

site_title: UK's Cameron releases tax records to calm Panama Papers storm
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron released his tax records to address questions about his personal wealth raised by the Panama Papers scandal. The records show Cameron received a £200,000 gift from his mother in 2011, sparking suggestions he may have avoided inheritance tax. Despite his initial reluctance, Cameron published his tax records, which show he paid £75,898 in tax on £200,307 income in 2014-2015. The move was seen as an attempt to regain control of the narrative, but it has been criticized by Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn as a "weasel-worded" admission.

site_title: Japan won't rule out currency devaluation: Suga
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said the G-20's agreement to avoid competitive currency devaluation does not mean Japan cannot intervene in response to one-sided currency moves. Suga clarified Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's comment, stating it referred to "arbitrary intervention" rather than responding to a one-sided move. Japan is watching currency markets and prepared to take steps as needed, with the Bank of Japan's negative interest rates policy under scrutiny.

site_title: Tech start-ups snap at the heels of Asian private bankers
summary: Asian private bankers are facing disruption from tech start-ups, known as fintech companies, which offer innovative services such as aggregating bank statements and providing smarter investment insights. Start-ups like Mesitis are gaining traction, with some private banks integrating their software into their systems. Despite concerns over the value of traditional banker/client meetings, fintech companies believe they can chip away at both businesses by leveraging customer data and offering more efficient investment portfolios. The region's billionaire wealth is expected to overtake the US within a decade, prompting private banks to take note.

images.alt_text: Scanning a bank statement into a computer may not sound particularly high-tech, but it's unsettling some of Asia's private bankers.

site_title: SunEdison's financial woes imperil solar projects globally
summary: US solar energy giant SunEdison is preparing for bankruptcy, five months after aggressive growth, due to a cash crunch and $12 billion in debt. The company has sold off large ventures, including a 500-megawatt solar plant in India, and has dozens of projects in development. Several projects, including a solar plant in central Texas and a wind venture in India, are at risk of being re-bid or cancelled. A bankruptcy would rank among the largest by asset value involving a non-financial company in a decade.

site_title: New party to seek vote on possible Hong Kong independence
summary: A new Hong Kong party, Demosisto, was launched by student leaders Joshua Wong and Nathan Law, who were at the forefront of 2014 pro-democracy protests. The party aims to campaign for a referendum on Hong Kong's future, including possible independence from China. The party's key policy is to push for a referendum, with independence as one of the options. Wong hopes the referendum could happen in 10 years' time. The party plans to collect public views and contest the city's legislative elections in September.

site_title: Check your (tax) privilege
summary: Singapore taxpayers can review their tax privileges by visiting the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) website. The top tier personal income tax bracket was 22% from 2003 to 2005. In contrast, the current top tier tax bracket is 22% as well. Taxpayers can also check their own tax brackets and income levels on the Iras website to understand their tax obligations.

site_title: Seize opportunities despite the risks
summary: Achal Agarwal, senior executive of Kimberly-Clark, delivers a graduation speech emphasizing the importance of seizing opportunities despite risks. He shares two personal examples of taking risks, including joining PepsiCo in China in 1997, which changed his career and life. Agarwal stresses that "how" is as crucial as "what" in achieving success, highlighting the need for a mindset of taking risks, empowering teams, and cherishing relationships. He concludes by encouraging graduates to seize opportunities, focus on the "how," and build lifelong relationships.

site_title: Narrowing the gender gap in S'pore boardrooms
summary: Singapore's corporate boardrooms are narrowing the gender gap, with the percentage of women on boards increasing from 8.3% in 2013 to 9.5% in 2015. However, Singapore still trails behind neighboring countries and the global average. To further improve diversity, the government is considering a more proactive approach, including quotas and targets, rather than relying on a light touch and moral suasion. Companies, particularly those in the Straits Times Index, are encouraged to set diversity targets and disclose their plans to achieve them, with the goal of reaching 20% female directors by 2020.

site_title: Canadian Pacific's plan to set up trust draws US anti-trust concern
summary: The US Justice Department has expressed concerns over Canadian Pacific Railway's plan to set up a voting trust to allow its CEO to run Norfolk Southern Corp in advance of a proposed takeover. The trust structure, meant to allow investors to be paid while the railroad operates on its own, would risk harming competition, according to the department. The US Army has also voiced opposition to the deal, citing potential national defense concerns. Canadian Pacific's CEO, Hunter Harrison, has defended the plan, citing similar arrangements in the past and the potential for a seamless merger once regulators sign off.

site_title: Prices of homes in London's outskirts surge ahead of fast rail network
summary: Home prices in London's outskirts are surging ahead of the opening of the Crossrail rail network, with values in West Ealing rising 29% in the past year. The project, which will cut commute times to the City, is attracting buyers looking for a quick and affordable commute. Property prices in areas such as Palmers Green and Highgate have also increased significantly, with some areas seeing values jump over 30% in the past five years. Experts predict that the trend will continue, with commuter markets outperforming central locations in the next five years.

site_title: Planemakers vie as Delta nears decision on jets
summary: Delta Air Lines is nearing a decision on upgrading its single-aisle fleet, with three planemakers - Airbus, Boeing, and Bombardier - competing for the order. The airline is seeking to replace its MD-88 planes for shorter domestic flights, with options including the CS300 aircraft. A Delta order would be significant for Bombardier, which is struggling to land major customers for its C Series jetliner. The decision could come as early as this month, with Delta considering ordering new narrow-body planes in instalments rather than replacing its entire fleet with a single purchase.

site_title: Military background can be of use in a startup, says former colonel
summary: Former Singaporean Colonel Lawrence Lim, 43, has joined crowdfunding platform CoAssets as its new Chief Operating Officer (COO). Lim, a former chief of artillery, brings military experience to the startup, citing the importance of systematic structures and strong values in business. He aims to help the platform expand regionally and implement a performance appraisal system. Lim believes a military background can be beneficial in a startup, teaching values and processes that are essential for efficient operation.

site_title: First approved crowdfunding platform raises S$1.74m
summary: Singapore's first approved crowdfunding platform, FundedHere, has raised S$1.74 million in seed capital from three high net worth individuals. The investment will be used to strengthen management, increase marketing efforts, and build a pool of accredited investors. FundedHere, which received regulatory approval three weeks prior, aims to connect startups in South-east Asia and China with accredited investors, with a target of registering 1,000 investors and securing over S$5 million in funding for 20-25 startups by the end of this year.

site_title: PE firm targets more manufacturing, industrial acquisitions in region
summary: A private equity firm, ShawKwei & Partners, aims to make two deals in the manufacturing and industrials sector in the US$50-150 million range. The firm, which has US$500 million of assets under management, sees a "good time for investing" amid the current market conditions. This follows the recent merger of precision manufacturers Beyonics and Chosen Holdings.

images.alt_text: Private equity firm ShawKwei & Partners hopes to make two more deals in the region amid "a good time for investing", founder Kyle Shaw told TheBusiness Times as his firm announced the merger of formerly Singapore-listed precision manufacturers Beyonics and Chosen Holdings.

site_title: Multigenerational homes that fit just right
summary: Multigenerational homes are gaining popularity in the US, with 56.8 million Americans living in such households in 2012, up from 46.6 million in 2007. These specially designed homes provide separate living spaces for extended family members, promoting harmony and flexibility. Builders like Lennar, Toll Brothers, and CalAtlantic Group are catering to this demand, offering 1,100 NextGen homes in 2015. Experts attribute the trend to the 2008 recession, high student loan debt, and rising rents, as well as the desire for multigenerational families to live together and support each other.

site_title: Applying for job online? Let 'robots' assess you first
