summary: Job seekers may face challenges when applying online due to automated recruiters and algorithms. Companies are using technology to scan resumes for keywords and identify top candidates. To increase chances, job hunters should carefully review job descriptions, align their experience, and highlight transferable skills. Keeping an online persona up-to-date and being prepared for video interviews or task-based assessments can also improve prospects. Experts advise job seekers to personalize their communication and strategy, rather than relying solely on online applications.

site_title: Defending against terrorism
summary: Businesses in Singapore can contribute to keeping their employees and public premises terror-proof by practicing zero tolerance of security complacency and implementing alertness and willingness to be involved. Government standards for improving building security and ensuring quick emergency response are also crucial. Key measures include installing closed-circuit surveillance systems, fortifying existing buildings with blast-resistant materials, and incorporating security-by-design considerations from the beginning. Cyber security is also essential, with technologies such as intrusion detection and data lake platforms helping to detect and respond to terrorist threats.

site_title: Star Wars leads winners at MTV Movie Awards
summary: The MTV Movie Awards took place on April 10, 2016, where Star Wars: The Force Awakens led with 11 nominations and won the top award for movie of the year. Lead star Daisy Ridley won best breakthrough performance. Other winners included Charlize Theron for best female performance, Will Smith for the MTV Generation Award, and Melissa McCarthy for the Comedic Genius award. The ceremony featured irreverent moments and a profanity-laden tone, with hosts Kevin Hart and Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson setting the tone with their opening remarks.

site_title: Elliott faces uphill battle in Bank of East Asia confrontation
summary: Hedge fund Elliott Management Corp faces a tough battle at Bank of East Asia Ltd's shareholder meeting, where it's seeking to weaken the Li family's hold on the lender. Elliott has accused the Li family of mismanagement and improper representation of shareholder interests, calling for the bank to explore a sale. However, analysts say the hedge fund has little chance of success due to the strong shareholder alliance, with the Li family and other major investors controlling over 44% of the bank's shares. Elliott's efforts are likely to be met with resistance, with the bank's board expressing confidence in its management.

site_title: Tablet-toting employees replace tellers as banks in US go digital
summary: US banks are shifting towards a digital model, with many replacing traditional tellers with tablet-toting employees to help customers navigate technology. The number of tellers in the Washington area has dropped by nearly half in 10 years, outpacing a 17% national decline. This trend is expected to continue, with Citigroup estimating that an additional 30% of US banking jobs could be eliminated by 2025. High-tech branches are becoming more common, with employees trained to assist with digital transactions and customer consultations.

site_title: Reporting of company earnings to set market direction this week
summary: US stocks experienced their largest losses since an early-year rout due to interest rate uncertainty. However, the start of earnings season this week could lead to a market rebound if profit growth meets modest expectations. Despite tariff uncertainty, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. Other notable events include a mandatory offer for PSC shares by Popiah king Sam Goi and a US$220 million funding round for eSIM platform Airalo.

site_title: Copper prices stage biggest weekly loss in three months
summary: Copper prices fell 3.6% last week, the largest weekly loss since January, due to concerns over demand growth and ample supply in China. Despite a lower dollar, copper stabilized at $4,650 a tonne, near a six-week low. Analysts say "risk-off" sentiment and China's focus on cutting costs rather than production are contributing to the decline. However, some signs suggest China's economy is stabilizing, with exports likely returning to growth and bank lending picking up, which may support copper prices in the coming months.

site_title: 1990: Debut of ultimately ill-fated CLOB
summary: In 1990, Singapore's Stock Exchange of Singapore launched CLOB International, an over-the-counter market for Malaysian and foreign shares. The market initially performed well, but its fate took a turn when Malaysia imposed capital controls in the Asian Financial Crisis, freezing CLOB shares worth billions of ringgit held by 172,000 Singapore investors. The same year, tycoon Oei Hong Leong launched a S$2.6 billion hostile takeover of SingLand, and Singapore saw its first case of insider trading, with United Insulation Services fined S$45,000 for illegally acquiring shares of Wah-Chang Electro Plating Ltd.

site_title: For some non-profits, changing the world begins in Seattle
summary: Seattle is a hub for non-profit organizations focused on global health, with companies like Cascade Designs and PATH developing innovative products and treatments. The city's tech industry, led by Microsoft co-founders Bill Gates and Paul Allen, has driven this growth. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and other philanthropic efforts have invested heavily in global health initiatives, creating jobs and economic activity. Seattle is now home to over 12,000 jobs in global health and nearly $6 billion in economic activity, with many nonprofit leaders emerging from the city's tech and academic institutions.

site_title: NY transportation agency tweaks capex to spark funding for bus terminal, rail tunnel
summary: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is considering extending its capital spending plan by three years to free up $7.5 billion, potentially funding a new bus terminal or rail tunnel under the Hudson River. The agency's current plan ends in 2023 and has little funding for long-stalled projects. With reduced spending at the World Trade Center, the agency could allocate $2.5 billion annually for capital projects, supporting a new bus terminal or rail tunnel. The projects are essential due to the overburdened infrastructure network between New Jersey and New York, with a new tunnel needed to prevent catastrophic delays.

site_title: Illustrator of Paddington Bear dies at 96
summary: Peggy Fortnum, the renowned illustrator of Paddington Bear, has died at 96. Born in 1919, Fortnum's career spanned over four decades, during which she illustrated more than 80 books, including Paddington Bear, and was known for her unique style and attention to detail. Her illustrations captured the essence of the character, imbuing him with a sense of optimism and vulnerability. Fortnum's legacy will be remembered for her contributions to the world of children's literature, and her work continues to be celebrated through various adaptations and publications.

site_title: Negative interest-rate policies get qualified nod from IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has defended negative interest-rate policies, stating that while there are limits to how far and long these policies can be implemented, they can deliver additional monetary stimulus and support demand and price stability. The IMF notes that negative nominal interest rates, introduced by several central banks, aim to encourage private spending and support price stability. However, the policy has been met with opposition in Japan, where business and savers are concerned about the erosion of their money's value.

site_title: More supply and use of nuclear power seen in Asia despite Fukushima disaster
summary: Nuclear power is expected to remain a significant source of energy globally, despite the Fukushima disaster, according to William Magwood, director-general of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's Nuclear Energy Agency. Many countries, including China, Bangladesh, and Pakistan, will increase their use of nuclear power, with China becoming a major supplier of reactor systems. The agency's director-general emphasizes that nuclear power is "here to stay" and is fundamentally safe, citing advancements in technology and safety measures that will allow reactors to operate safely even without power.

site_title: Manny Pacquiao wins farewell fight against Tim Bradley
summary: Manny Pacquiao won his farewell fight against Tim Bradley on April 10, 2016, with a unanimous decision victory. Pacquiao knocked down Bradley twice before securing a comfortable win. The 21-year professional career for Pacquiao came to an end with this performance, following his loss to Floyd Mayweather in May 2015.

site_title: 'Three-no generation' seeks voice in South Korea vote
summary: In South Korea's general election on April 13, 2016, a new generation of "three-no generation" voters, characterized by high unemployment, homelessness, and lack of marriage prospects, is expected to make their voices heard. Millennials, frustrated with record-high unemployment and widening inequality, are expected to turnout in large numbers, with over 55% saying they would "definitely vote". This marks a significant shift from previous elections, where younger voters had historically low turnout.

site_title: Staff training ensures no prima donnas
summary: BANK of Singapore has invested heavily in staff development over the past five years, spending US$30 million on human resource initiatives and programs. The bank has increased training hours to 46,000, with relationship managers receiving 90 hours of training, six times the mandated 15 hours. CEO Bharen Shaari aims to ensure staff are aligned to the bank's approach, including portfolio reviews, to achieve sustainable revenue. Under his guidance, BOS has increased the number of relationship managers to 314 and expanded its private banking business.

site_title: 'Deeply saddened' by sister's claim that I had abused power to mark LKY's death anniversary: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed sadness over his sister Dr Lee Wei Ling's claim that he abused power to commemorate their father's death anniversary to establish a dynasty. Dr Lee made the accusations on her Facebook page, stating they were "completely untrue." The PM denied the allegations, describing them as baseless and unfounded.

site_title: Colonial to shippers: seek space transfers before rules change in July
summary: The Colonial Pipeline has reminded shippers to seek space transfers before July, when a change in rules will restrict trading space on the clogged fuel artery. Shippers must give Colonial 8 weeks to approve requests, as the US Federal Energy Regulatory Commission considers protests from shippers who claim the restriction will limit access. The new rules aim to address perpetual crowding on the pipeline system, which has been full for nearly four years and saw a 50% increase in shippers since 2013.

site_title: Dubai to build tower taller than Burj Khalifa
summary: Dubai plans to build a tower that will surpass the height of its Burj Khalifa, currently the world's tallest skyscraper. The viewing tower, costing around $1 billion, will be designed by Santiago Calatrava Valls and feature observation decks, restaurants, and a boutique hotel. Scheduled for completion before 2020, the tower will add value to surrounding properties and provide a unique viewing experience for potential buyers.

site_title: Wealth management high-flyer in Shanghai crashes, execs arrested
summary: Wealth management firm Zhongjin Capital Management in Shanghai has faced a major crisis after 21 executives were arrested on suspicion of "illegal fund-raising" on April 5. The firm had been promoting short-term financing products with double-digit returns, attracting investors. The arrest is linked to China's shadow banking sector, where irregular behavior is common. The incident has raised concerns about the firm's legitimacy and the risks faced by investors. The incident highlights the complexities and risks of China's financial sector.

site_title: Volkswagen CEO seeks cut to board bonuses: sources
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller plans to propose a significant reduction in bonuses for the carmaker's management board, following criticism from a major shareholder about paying top managers' bonuses while the company deals with the diesel emissions crisis. This move comes amid an escalating dispute with powerful labor leaders over a new strategy. The proposal is set to be discussed at a supervisory board meeting.

site_title: Three oil majors have debt ratings cut by Moody's on price rout
summary: Moody's Investors Service cut the credit ratings of three major oil companies: Chevron Corp and Royal Dutch Shell Plc by one level, while Total SA's rating was reduced by two steps. The downgrade is due to the expectation of low oil prices causing leverage concerns and negative cash flow for Chevron and elevated leverage for Shell following its BG Group acquisition. The rating reductions reflect Moody's concerns about the companies' debt levels and ability to generate cash.

images.alt_text: Three of the world's largest energy companies had their credit ratings lowered by Moody's Investors Service on the expectation that oil prices will stay low for longer and cause leverage concerns.

site_title: The selling power of star athletes
summary: Marketing executives are seeking the next big stars in sports to promote products and create connections between brands and consumers. Major sports stars, such as tennis players Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal, golf pro Adam Scott, and soccer player Neymar, have partnered with luxury brands like Uniqlo, Tommy Hilfiger, and TAG Heuer. These partnerships have resulted in increased sales, with some brands seeing sales double or triple year-over-year. The goal is to target mass-market sports, such as soccer, to reach a broader audience and tap into the growing middle class in developing markets.

site_title: Economists see MAS standing pat on monetary policy this week
summary: Economists predict the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will maintain its monetary policy stance this week, with no changes to the Singapore dollar policy band or its level. This unanimous consensus comes after months of concerns over the impact of sinking oil prices and turbulent financial markets.

images.alt_text: Economists also say that the expansionary Budget announced by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has removed the catalyst for a possible MAS policy change, since fiscal policy will help with the heavy lifting to support gross domestic product (GDP) this year.

site_title: China to cut steel capacity to 1.13b tonnes
summary: China plans to shut 100-150 million tonnes of crude steel capacity over the next five years, reducing total capacity to 1.13 billion tonnes by 2020, still exceeding domestic needs. Domestic steel consumption is forecast to be 630-700 million tonnes, with exports remaining at 100 million tonnes, resulting in production levels of around 800 million tonnes. To restore the sector's health, 200 million tonnes of capacity would need to be cut. The goal is to increase efficiency and utilization rates to 80%, aiming to control steel output and mitigate the impact of overcapacity.

site_title: Indian temple fire kills over 60, more than 200 injured-TV
summary: A fire at a Hindu temple in southern India's Kerala state killed over 60 people and injured 200, who were gathered for a fireworks display to mark the Hindu new year. The fire, caused by a fallen firework, spread quickly and damaged the temple building. State authorities have taken in many of the injured, and officials have confirmed the high number of fatalities. The incident highlights the risks associated with large public gatherings and the use of fireworks.

site_title: Valeant CEO Pearson may be held in contempt by Senate committee
summary: A Senate committee may initiate contempt proceedings against Valeant CEO Michael Pearson for failing to appear for a deposition related to an investigation into drug pricing. Pearson was subpoenaed to testify on April 27, but did not comply. The Senate Special Committee on Aging has called on Valeant to testify, and Pearson has cooperated with the inquiry by providing thousands of pages of documents. This is the latest blow to Valeant, which has faced controversies and setbacks in recent months.

site_title: Positive March economic data calms market fears
summary: Positive economic data from China and elsewhere has calmed market fears, with analysts predicting a temporary upturn in the global economy. China's housing market shows signs of recovery, with prices rising in both first-tier and smaller cities, and the country's foreign exchange reserves increasing for the first time in five months. However, structural issues such as SOE debt and a global trade slowdown remain concerns, and analysts warn that market volatility could return if the global economy strengthens.

site_title: Hardcore heritage
summary: Damian D'Silva, a renowned Eurasian/Peranakan chef, has reopened his restaurant, D's Joint, at the hipster food court Timbre+ in Singapore. The restaurant offers a menu of traditional dishes, including nasi lemak, fish and chips, and anchovy pasta, all made with care and attention to detail. D'Silva's cooking is known for its bold flavors and old-school techniques, which set it apart from modernized versions of traditional dishes. The restaurant's prices are reasonable, with most dishes ranging from S$8 to S$16. D'Silva's passion for heritage food is evident in every dish, and his commitment to traditional recipes is a breath of fresh air in the modern Singaporean food scene.

images.alt_text: D'Silva's itek tim (above) gets all its robust flavour from pork bones, duck and salted vegetables with just the right amount of tartness. Seh bak (left) is an intense braise of pig parts from intestines to skin, in a gravy reduced to syrupy thickness.

D'Silva's (above) itek tim gets all its robust flavour from pork bones, duck and salted vegetables with just the right amount of tartness. Seh bak is an intense braise of pig parts from intestines to skin, in a gravy reduced to syrupy thickness.
Highlights at D's Joint include Stingray smothered with home-made sambal.
Whole squid - stuffed with its roe - cloaked in a buah keluak sambal.
Hakka fried pork and chicken pops marinated with fragrant ginger.

site_title: Cameron publishes tax details in bid to move on from Panama
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron has published his tax details, showing he paid £402,283 in tax on £1.08 million in earnings since 2009. The move aims to move on from the controversy surrounding his personal finances, including offshore funds linked to his father. Cameron also announced a task force to probe leaked documents from the Panama law firm, Mossack Fonseca, which revealed his father's involvement in an offshore fund. The task force will investigate potential wrongdoing and boost the government's record on cracking down on tax avoidance.

site_title: Honouring business leaders in style
summary: The Singapore Business Awards, Singapore's oldest and most prestigious business award, was held on March 31, celebrating outstanding business leaders and companies. Robert Yap, executive chairman of YCH Group, won the top Businessman of the Year award, while Piyush Gupta, CEO of DBS Group Holdings, received the Outstanding Chief Executive of the Year award. Other winners included Shafie Shamsuddin of PT Trans Retail for Outstanding Overseas CEO and Ang Kiam Meng, CEO of Jumbo Group, who received The Enterprise Award for his company's growth and success.

site_title: India temple fire kills over 100 people watching fireworks
summary: A massive fire at the Puttingal Devi temple in southern India on Sunday killed over 100 people and injured scores more, who were watching an unofficial fireworks display. The fire, which started after a firework landed on an unexploded stash, triggered a blast, and residents described hearing a huge explosion before racing to look for survivors. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has announced compensation for the families of those killed and injured, and medical teams and helicopters are being deployed to help with the disaster.

site_title: Triyards wins 44m euro contract to build LNG ferries for Dutch firm
summary: Triyards Holdings has secured a 44 million euro contract to build two liquefied natural gas ferries for Dutch ferry operator Rederij Doeksen. The ferries, featuring single-fuel LNG propulsion systems, will carry up to 600 passengers and 64 cars, meeting stringent emissions requirements. The vessels are scheduled for delivery in the second quarter of 2018, marking a focus on the large ferry market and environmental aspects of marine transportation.

site_title: Diamonds not forever to millennial generation
summary: Diamond prices have dropped below 2006 levels, with luxury items rising at above-inflation rates. The diamond industry's efforts to maintain high prices have failed, with demand for luxury jewellery only increasing 1.9% annually from 2004-2013. The industry's reliance on older generations, who were more easily influenced by marketing campaigns, has also contributed to the decline. In response, De Beers has cut its marketing budget and formed the Diamond Producers Association to revive industry-wide advertising.

site_title: Barclays deal done, BOS continues expansion drive
summary: The Bank of Singapore (BOS) is expanding its presence in Greater China, offshore Japan, and the Middle East as part of its strategy to gather more clients and assets. Following the acquisition of Barclays' private bank business in Hong Kong and Singapore, BOS CEO Bahren Shaari stated that the South-east Asia region is the bank's biggest market. BOS continues its growth drive, despite brisk growth in the last three years.

site_title: 'Star Wars' leads winners at profanity-laden MTV Movie Awards
summary: The MTV Movie Awards honored "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" as the top winner, taking home 11 nominations and beating out other blockbusters. Lead star Daisy Ridley won best breakthrough performance, and hosts Kevin Hart and Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson set the tone with curse words and irreverent humor. Other winners included Charlize Theron for best female performance, Will Smith for the MTV Generation Award, and Melissa McCarthy for the Comedic Genius award. The event celebrated unpredictable and irreverent moments, with a focus on diversity and representation.

site_title: Sri Lanka PM says Chinese port project 'not a threat'
summary: Sri Lankan Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has stated that the country's Chinese port project, "Port City," is not a threat, but an opportunity for economic growth. The $1.4 billion project, initiated by Chinese President Xi Jinping, aims to include real estate, a marina, and a Formula One racetrack. Wickremesinghe emphasized that the project will not compromise Sri Lanka's security and navigation freedom in the Indian Ocean. The project has raised concerns about China's "String of Pearls" strategy, but Wickremesinghe assured that no military base will be established.

site_title: Sanders wins Wyoming to extend victory run
summary: Bernie Sanders won the Wyoming Democratic caucuses, extending his winning streak in his bid to defeat Hillary Clinton. Sanders secured 56% of the vote, despite Clinton's significant lead in delegates. The victory boosts Sanders' momentum ahead of the New York primary on April 19, but Clinton remains the clear frontrunner for the Democratic presidential ticket. Sanders has won eight of the last nine contests and is closing the gap with Clinton, but a remarkable turnaround will still be needed for him to secure the nomination.

images.alt_text: White House hopeful Bernie Sanders extended his winning streak in his bid to pull off a shock and defeat Hillary Clinton, grabbing victory in the Wyoming Democratic caucuses on Saturday, US media said.

site_title: Vietnam government sees new faces but policy shift unlikely
summary: Vietnam completed its leadership transition with 21 new faces in the cabinet, retaining key figures such as finance minister Dinh Tien Dung and deputy premiers Vu Duc Dam and Pham Binh Minh. Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc took office, succeeding two-term premier Nguyen Tan Dung, who drove a pro-business agenda but faced challenges in banking and public debt. The new government aims to reform the economy, manage public debt, and comply with the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership trade pact. Despite changes, the new government is expected to stick to the same strategy.

site_title: BHP CEO says commodities may have bottomed, Australian reports
summary: BHP Billiton CEO Andrew Mackenzie expressed optimism that the slump in commodity prices may be nearing its bottom. He stated that the decline in prices has stopped, and the company is well-positioned for a rebound or another slump due to cost-cutting efforts. BHP cut its dividend for the first time in 15 years in February amid the collapse in commodity prices, which led to a 92% tumble in first-half profit.

site_title: Europe: Equities rise as oil stocks, Italian banks advance
summary: European equities rose on Friday as Italian banks surged, with UniCredit gaining 9.7% and shares in BP, Total, and Eni rising 3.3-4.3%. The STOXX Oil and Gas sub-index led gains, driven by encouraging US economic data and hopes that global oil oversupply is ending. Despite a fourth straight week of losses, the FTSEurofirst 300 index ended 1.2% higher, with German shares also up 1% on a survey showing exports rose more than expected in February.

site_title: SpaceX rocket booster makes breakthrough landing at sea
summary: SpaceX successfully landed its reusable Falcon 9 rocket booster at sea, marking a breakthrough in the company's quest to develop a cheap, reusable rocket. The rocket, which separated from its main stage 2.5 minutes after launch, landed on an ocean platform about 185 miles northeast of Cape Canaveral. This achievement follows a successful ground-based touchdown in December and is a major milestone for SpaceX in the burgeoning commercial space launch industry. The reusable booster is expected to be test-fired and re-launched later this year.

site_title: The yen's puzzling surge, explained in one Morgan Stanley theory
summary: The yen surged to its strongest level since 2014, defying expectations, as Japanese government bond yields remain negative for many maturities. Despite concerns over the nation's economy, the yen rallied over 3% against the dollar this week. Analysts attribute the surge to a shift in the bond market, suggesting that investors are seeking safer assets and are willing to accept lower yields for the yen. This unexpected move has left currency traders and analysts perplexed, highlighting the complexities of the global financial market.

site_title: US says concerned that EU tax campaign hits mainly US firms
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew expressed concerns to the European Commission that its tax review campaign could disproportionately harm US companies, citing examples of American firms like McDonald's, Amazon, and Apple. Lew urged the EU to reconsider its approach, stating the US felt targeted. European Commissioner Margrethe Vestager denied targeting US companies, stating the EU is recovering illegal state aid to restore competition, and only a handful of US companies have been involved in such cases over the past 15 years.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew told Europe's powerful competition commissioner that the EU review of tax breaks given to multinationals could have an "outsized" impact on US companies.

site_title: China steel exports hurt market economy status, industry official
summary: China's steel exports are hurting the country's market economy status, according to Liu Zhenjiang, head of the China Iron and Steel Association. The surge in exports has driven up raw material costs and production, creating a "vicious circle." Liu emphasized the need to control steel output rather than just cutting capacity. This statement highlights the challenges China faces in maintaining its market economy status amidst a rapidly changing global market landscape.

site_title: Director buying rises but value sharply lower; selling stays consistent
summary: Directors' buying rose, with 17 companies purchasing shares worth S$1.01 million, while selling among directors remained low. Buyback activity also increased, with 11 companies repurchasing shares worth S$7.62 million. Significant director trades included Huationg Global's CEO purchasing shares at S$0.129, iX Biopharma's independent director buying 100,000 shares at S$0.38, and Mermaid Maritime's CEO resuming buying at S$0.11. Substantial shareholder trades included PSL Holdings' Hadi Negoro Suman acquiring 1.75 million shares at S$0.60 and Golden Agri-Resources' Silchester International Investors LLP selling 10 million shares at S$0.425.

site_title: Latin America oil producers call for action to improve prices
summary: Latin American oil producers are urging action to stabilize the global crude market and improve prices. Ecuador's Oil Minister Carlos Pareja warned that waiting for the market to balance itself would be "catastrophic." Venezuela, which relies heavily on petrodollars, is particularly concerned about the decline in oil prices. Ecuador and other Latin American nations, including Colombia, are calling on OPEC and non-OPEC nations to freeze production to reduce the global glut. However, doubts remain about the likelihood of a deal due to differing positions from major producers, including Saudi Arabia and Iran.

site_title: Australia's Rio Tinto to take longer to pay as resource slump bites
summary: Rio Tinto, one of the world's largest miners, has doubled its payment terms to up to 90 days for suppliers, from 45 days. The move aims to sustain jobs and supplier relationships in a tough global commodity market. The change applies to contracts valued at US$3 million or more, with smaller suppliers receiving payment in 60 days. The company is also expanding a financing program to support suppliers. This move follows rival BHP Billiton's 60-day payment terms, and Rio Tinto's CEO Sam Wash has invited suppliers to contact the company for potential exemptions.

site_title: Tax scandal weakens Cameron ahead of EU referendum
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron's popularity has slipped ahead of the EU referendum, with only 34% of respondents saying he is doing well, down from 39% in February. The scandal over his tax dealings and a steel sector crisis have damaged his credibility, with Labour opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn's popularity rising to 30%. Cameron's government faces criticism for its handling of the crisis and the EU referendum, with some experts warning that his ability to lecture others on tax evasion may be damaged.

site_title: UK economy may be heading for its worst quarter since 2012
summary: The UK economy may have grown at its slowest pace in over three years in the first quarter, with a 0.3% increase in gross domestic product, according to new estimates. This would be the worst performance since the fourth quarter of 2012, which was the last time the economy shrank. The slow growth may further cloud the outlook for the economy, with a second consecutive month of contraction reported in July.

site_title: Delta said to near jet order as planemakers scrap for deal
summary: Delta Air Lines is nearing a decision on upgrading its single-aisle fleet, with Airbus, Boeing, Bombardier, and Embraer competing for the order. The second-largest US carrier is considering replacing its McDonnell Douglas MD-88 workhorse jets for shorter domestic flights. Delta may make a decision as early as this month, with Bombardier's C Series jetliner seen as a key contender, as the airline seeks to replace its 116-jet fleet with a single purchase or installments.

site_title: Pacquiao wins farewell fight against Bradley
summary: Manny Pacquiao won his farewell fight against Tim Bradley by unanimous decision, knocking down Bradley twice en route to a 116-110 victory on all three judges' scorecards. Pacquiao, 37, dominated the non-title welterweight bout, showcasing his trademark combinations to overwhelm Bradley. After the fight, Pacquiao announced his intention to retire, citing a commitment to his family and a desire to serve the people of the Philippines, where he is seeking election to the Senate next month.

images.alt_text: Manny Pacquiao scored an emphatic victory over American Tim Bradley here on Saturday, sealing his 21-year professional career with a vintage performance in his farewell to boxing.

site_title: North Korea tests rocket engine as US talks up missile shield
summary: North Korea tested an engine for a new intercontinental ballistic rocket, claiming a "big success" and increasing its nuclear strike range. US Defense Secretary Ash Carter reiterated plans to deploy a missile defense system in South Korea, despite Chinese opposition. Carter stated the system is necessary for protecting US and South Korean forces, not China. The US is also set to operate F-35 fighters with South Korea and Japan.

site_title: Twitter names PepsiCo CFO Johnston, Martha Lane Fox to board
summary: Twitter Inc has added Hugh Johnston, CFO of PepsiCo, and Martha Lane Fox, a British technology entrepreneur, to its board. The move aims to bolster the company's diversity and gain traction with a wider global audience, as Twitter struggles with a slowdown in growth. The new board members bring consumer products expertise and international commerce experience, which Twitter plans to leverage to increase conversion and expand partnerships.

site_title: Italy raises 2017 deficit goal, sets up tussle with Brussels
summary: Italy has raised its 2017 fiscal deficit goal, setting a potential conflict with the European Commission. The country now forecasts 1.2% economic growth this year and 1.4% in 2017, down from previous forecasts of 1.6%. This move is seen as a challenge to the Commission's concerns about Italy's reluctance to cut public debt. The Italian government's decision may lead to disagreements with Brussels, adding to the tensions surrounding Italy's 2016 budget.

site_title: Mitsubishi Chemical to boost drug-capsule capacity: Nikkei
summary: Mitsubishi Chemical Holdings Corp plans to invest 20 billion yen (S$249.66 million) over five years to increase its drug capsule production capacity by 70%. The company will expand production lines in the US, Europe, and Japan to meet demand, particularly in the Middle East where pork-based gelatin products face resistance on religious grounds. This move aims to bolster its lineup of plant-based drug capsules.

site_title: Boxing: Pacquiao promises action as finale nears
summary: Manny Pacquiao, a 37-year-old Filipino boxing superstar, is set to retire after his final fight against Tim Bradley in Las Vegas on Saturday. Pacquiao, who has been in the sport for 21 years, promised an action-packed finale to his career. The two fighters weighed in at the MGM Grand Garden Arena, both within the 147-pound limit, ahead of their highly anticipated bout. This will mark Pacquiao's last professional boxing match, with the outcome expected to determine the winner of their long-standing rivalry.

site_title: US keeps Apple encryption battle alive in drug case
summary: The US government has pressed Apple to help crack an iPhone in a New York drug case, keeping the encryption battle alive. The Justice Department sought to compel Apple under the All Writs Act, a 1789 law giving law enforcement wide latitude, after the US Drug Enforcement Agency and FBI seized the iPhone in 2014. A lower court judge had previously sided with Apple, ruling that law enforcement lacked authority to compel the company to comply. The case remains ongoing, raising questions about law enforcement access to devices with strong encryption and user privacy rights.

site_title: France, Germany halt Airbus export credit amid UK probe
summary: France and Germany have suspended export credit facilities for Airbus jet deliveries amid a potential corruption probe in the UK. The move follows Britain's decision to suspend financing and alert the Serious Fraud Office. This expansion of the fallout affects both Airbus and Boeing, leaving them without government-backed financing for deliveries. The US Export Import bank's delays have also paralyzed the industry, with Congressional delays preventing support for Airbus. The UK's decision is part of the probe into Airbus's declaration of overseas agents, with the company itself notifying UK authorities.

site_title: Starting a multi-family office sprint
summary: Wealth management firm Wealth Management Alliance (WMA) has launched its first client after just three weeks of operations, marking a significant milestone in the growing demand for family offices in Asia. Founded by Stephan Repkow, WMA aims to provide integrated services to wealthy families and experienced wealth managers, offering a "no-kickbacks" remuneration model and state-of-the-art IT infrastructure. With an estimated 200 single family offices in Asia and over 3,000 globally, WMA expects to secure at least half a dozen more clients in the coming year, catering to the needs of ultra-high net worth individuals and families seeking efficient wealth management and transmission to the next generation.

images.alt_text: Ven Sreenivasan

site_title: Women's clothing retailer J.Jill taps banks for IPO: source
summary: J.Jill Group, a women's apparel retailer, has tapped Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, and Jefferies Group as underwriters for a possible initial public offering. The private equity firm TowerBrook Capital Partners LP, which acquired J.Jill last year, is seeking to raise approximately $150 million, valuing the company at $750-800 million.

site_title: SocGen board supports management after Panama Papers leak
summary: Societe Generale's board of directors has backed the bank's executives after analysis of the leaked Panama Papers revealed it was one of the most active lenders in setting up shell companies in Panama. The bank had created 979 shell companies since the 1990s, but said it had abided by all rules and was proactive in fighting tax fraud. Chairman Lorenzo Bini Smaghi stated the board was "especially vigilant" to ensure compliance with anti-money laundering and tax evasion rules, and expressed full support for management.

site_title: BMW launches car-sharing in Seattle in US push
summary: BMW has launched its car-sharing service, ReachNow, in Seattle, offering 370 BMW and Mini vehicles for short-term rental, delivery, and chauffeur services. The service aims to cater to metropolitan mobility needs and follows the company's successful DriveNow service in Europe. Analysts predict a 30% annual growth in the car-sharing market, with BMW expected to generate $5.69 billion to $8.61 billion in revenue by 2020. This move follows similar car-sharing initiatives by rival manufacturers, such as Toyota, Ford, and General Motors.

site_title: US judge orders deposition of Bernard Madoff
summary: US Bankruptcy Judge Stuart Bernstein ordered Bernard Madoff, 77, to submit to a deposition in a lawsuit over profit withdrawals from his Ponzi scheme. The deposition will be limited to discussing 91,000 transactions and will only be used for the profit withdrawal issue. Madoff will be deposed at the North Carolina prison where he is serving a 150-year sentence. Former customers hope the deposition will reveal how much more money they lost than previously credited, with Madoff's testimony potentially helping them in their litigation against third parties they believe aided the fraud.

images.alt_text: Bernard Madoff must submit to a deposition by lawyers for some former customers who lost money when the imprisoned swindler's firm collapsed in December 2008, a judge ordered on Friday.

site_title: France 'wrong' to designate Panama as a tax haven: president
summary: France has designated Panama as a tax haven, sparking criticism from Panamanian President Juan Carlos Varela, who calls the decision "wrong" and "unnecessary." The move follows the Panama Papers revelations, but Panama has implemented reforms to curb anonymity for companies incorporated in the country. The designation could deal a blow to Panama's financial services sector, accounting for 7% of the country's GDP. France's finance minister has urged the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to follow suit, but Panama has threatened retaliatory measures, including blocking French investment and withholding public tenders.

images.alt_text: France's decision to put Panama back on its list of tax havens in the wake of the Panama Papers revelations is "wrong," Panamanian President Juan Carlos Varela said on Friday.

site_title: Sanders accused of 'discourtesy' in Vatican invitation
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders has been accused of showing "monumental discourtesy" by a senior Vatican official for lobbying for an invitation to a church-sponsored conference on economic and environmental issues. The conference, hosted by the Pontifical Academy of Social Sciences, will take place in the Vatican just four days before the New York primary. Sanders' campaign is seeking to capitalize on Pope Francis' emphasis on issues of poverty and environmental stewardship, while also addressing criticism of his inexperience in diplomacy.

site_title: Former NSA chief urges US-Silicon Valley deal on encryption
summary: Former NSA chief Keith Alexander urges the US government and Silicon Valley to find common ground on encryption concerns before a significant terrorist attack. Alexander says the US and tech companies must work together to solve problems and find a balanced solution. The debate over encryption was sparked by the FBI's attempt to force Apple to unlock an iPhone in the San Bernardino shooting. Alexander argues that current policies have been outpaced by technological change, and the US needs to help the policy community catch up.

site_title: Iceland government survives confidence vote
summary: Iceland's parliament rejected an opposition motion of no-confidence in the government, which is struggling to recover from the "Panama Papers" scandal that forced the prime minister to step down. The motion was rejected by 38 votes to 25 with no dissenting voices from the majority government's ranks. Another motion calling for parliament dissolution was also defeated, leaving the government's position intact.

images.alt_text: Iceland's parliament on Friday rejected an opposition motion of no-confidence in the new government, which is struggling to shake off revelations from the leaked "Panama Papers" which have already forced the prime minister to step down.

site_title: US$30b of rail projects spanning 11,000km being built in Africa
summary: African countries are investing heavily in rail infrastructure, with over $30 billion planned or underway, spanning 11,000km. The projects aim to improve trade between countries, currently at 13% of total trade, and are expected to boost economic growth. Chinese companies, including GE and Alstom, are poised to benefit from the investments, with many countries borrowing heavily to fund the projects. The rail infrastructure is seen as a vital component in transforming trade in the region, with Kenya's initial stretch set to be completed by 2017.

site_title: Lee Suet-Fern conferred Chambers lifetime award
summary: Singapore's Lee Suet-Fern, managing partner of Morgan Lewis Stamford, was conferred the Lifetime Achievement Award at the 2016 Chambers Asia-Pacific Awards for her significant contribution to the legal community, marking the first time a woman received the honor.

site_title: Keith Tay steps down as SingPost committee head
summary: SingPost's board has undergone significant changes with Keith Tay stepping down as committee head and chairman, effective immediately. He will remain a member of the nominations panel. Zulkifli bin Baharudin has taken over as new nominations committee chairman, aiming to bring in fresh eyes and new blood. The company sees these changes as paving the way for board renewal and transformation, following a similar departure by outgoing chairman Lim Ho Kee.

site_title: US government gives M&A bond investors a wake-up call
summary: The US government's crackdown on big corporate mergers over tax-avoidance and antitrust concerns may not significantly impact the M&A bond pipeline, but could make debt financing more difficult in the future. Two high-profile deals, Pfizer and Allergan, and Halliburton and Baker Hughes, have been thrown into question, but bankers are hopeful that more deals will not be affected. The estimated US$150 billion bond pipeline remains intact, with many deals still expected to proceed, including Teva's purchase of Allergan's generics business.

site_title: Cool sanctuary
summary: Japanese expatriate Mitsuya Nakata has recreated his Tokyo apartment in his new one-bedroom, 850 square-foot unit in Beach Road, Singapore. He worked with BoConcept's interior stylist Chloe Chee to achieve a similar look and feel, using the same retailer for furniture and decor. Nakata prioritized cool comfort and a modern aesthetic, incorporating white walls, grey sofas, and blue accent pieces. The space is designed to be functional, with a coffee table that doubles as a dining table, and features his book collection and art pieces. Nakata has made the transition to Singapore an easy one, citing the country's safety, cleanliness, and perpetual summer as advantages.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Mad about chocolate
summary: A growing number of artisanal chocolatiers in Singapore are creating niche products with unique flavors and high-quality ingredients, challenging the dominance of foreign brands. Local chocolatiers like Lim Jialiang of Demochoco, Leela Titus of Leela's Fine Chocolates, and Jay Chua of Wild Nibs are experimenting with single-origin couvertures, unusual flavors, and traditional techniques. Despite challenges such as high raw material costs and limited foot traffic, these chocolatiers aim to establish a reputation for their products and attract customers seeking distinctive and high-quality chocolates.

site_title: Re-employment age rises to 67 from July 2017
summary: Singapore's re-employment age will rise to 67 from July 1, 2017, while the law supporting a 10% pay cut for workers reaching 60 will be removed. The government will continue to support employers who re-hire workers above 65 voluntarily.

site_title: Panama Papers threaten Macri's shine in Argentina
summary: Argentine President Mauricio Macri's reputation is under threat from the Panama Papers scandal, which has revealed his involvement with two offshore companies. Macri, a free-market reformer, has been accused of tax dodging and financial crimes, despite vowing to crack down on corruption. An investigation has been launched into his financial dealings, and opposition lawmakers are calling for him to testify before Congress. While Macri denies any wrongdoing, analysts say the scandal may have a significant impact on his presidency, particularly in a country where corruption is widespread.

site_title: Olam to build animal feed mills, breeding farms, hatchery in Nigeria
summary: Olam International is investing $150 million to establish animal feed mills, breeding farms, and a hatchery in Nigeria, with $100 million committed to Kaduna State and $50 million to Kwara State. The project aims to produce 600,000 tonnes of poultry and fish feed yearly and over 1 million hatching eggs weekly. The investment is expected to boost poultry production and reduce reliance on imports, with Olam using locally sourced wheat bran to buy corn and soya from local farmers.

site_title: Ron Sim ups offer price for OSIM to S$1.41
summary: Ron Sim's offer price for OSIM has been finalized at S$1.41 per share, a two-cent increase from the revised offer price of S$1.39 announced on Tuesday. The offer price includes a S$0.02 dividend, and all shareholders who tender will receive the total amount. The Securities Industry Council (SIC) intervened on Tuesday to halt trading of OSIM stock after the initial offer price was announced. The final ex-dividend offer price is S$1.39.

site_title: OECD convenes global tax expert meeting on Panama Papers
summary: Tax officials from around the world will meet at the OECD on April 13 to discuss joint action following the Panama Papers revelations. The meeting, attended by members of the Joint International Tax Shelter Information and Collaboration (JITSIC), aims to tackle common risks, especially tax avoidance. The gathering follows calls from government officials for the OECD to convene a special project meeting, with the OECD stating it presents a first opportunity to act on the 'Panama Papers' body of information.

site_title: Germany to get tough on dirty diesels by empowering city bans
summary: Germany to implement ordinances allowing cities to ban older diesel vehicles from streets with high emissions. The move aims to reduce pollution, with 10,000 deaths attributed to diesel exhausts and NOx emissions annually. The ordinance, set to be enacted this year, will provide local authorities with the tools to ban vehicles with emissions exceeding EU-Norm 6 limits, currently set at 80 grammes per kilometre. Towns can choose to impose a "blue sticker" on compliant vehicles, while those not meeting the standard will be restricted from inner-city areas.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Innovalues and Triyards Holdings received broker recommendations. Innovalues was upgraded to a "buy" with a target price of S$1.00 due to its strong financial and operating metrics and potential for a strategic review. Triyards Holdings reported a 15% year-on-year rise in revenue and a 4% increase in net profit, with a 44% contribution to its full-year estimate. Noble Group was downgraded to a "neutral" rating due to its high debt levels and focus on asset-light business model.

site_title: Impact fund raiSE invests S$1m in Bliss
summary: The Singapore Centre for Social Enterprise (raiSE) has invested a record S$1 million in local social enterprise Bliss Group to fund expansion plans in Singapore and Indonesia. Bliss Group, a food and beverage company, provides jobs for marginalized groups and operates a restaurant, kids' cafe, and catering business. The investment is the largest known in an SE in Singapore to date, supporting the company's growth and job creation.

site_title: Short-term rental: It's in the phrasing of contracts
summary: Singaporean short-term rental providers have been using clever wording in tenancy agreements to offer short-term stays despite the 6-month minimum lease rule. These "diplomatic clauses" allow for early lease termination without penalty, effectively allowing for short-term rentals. This practice appears to be a loophole in the current rules, allowing providers to offer short-term stays without technically violating the law. The URA has stated that this practice is still breached, highlighting the need for stricter regulations in the short-term rental market.

site_title: From workout to wardrobe
summary: The athleisure movement is gaining popularity in Singapore, with city-dwellers incorporating sportswear into their everyday wardrobe. Brands like Lululemon, Nike, and Under Armour are leading the trend, which has become widely accepted as chic streetwear. Athleisure is no longer limited to the gym, with people wearing athletic wear for casual outings, such as coffee runs and shopping. High-fashion retailers are also tapping into the trend, with some incorporating sporty elements into their collections. The market is expected to grow, but authenticity and functionality remain key.

site_title: Property agents who broker short-term stays playing with fire
summary: Singapore's Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) warns property agents against facilitating short-term leases of under six months, as they may be implicated in breaching the rules. Agents who refer customers to accommodation operators or owners for short-term stays may risk losing their licenses. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) will also scrutinize the whole chain of property owners and intermediaries for breaches of its minimum-stay requirement. Agents who engage in these activities are deemed to be either desperate or not well-informed, and the CEA takes a serious view of infringement, consulting with the URA on permissible transactions.

site_title: Shenzhen, Shanghai home sales plunge after rules tightened
summary: China's home sales in Shanghai and Shenzhen plummeted sharply after authorities tightened rules to prevent a property bubble. Sales in Shanghai fell 60% and in Shenzhen 28.2% in the week following new regulations. The measures, including higher down-payment requirements and restrictions on non-residents, have reduced the pool of eligible buyers and eased prices by 3-4%. Despite this, developers remain optimistic, citing low inventory levels and continued demand.

site_title: Art of classical French
summary: Jerome Bocuse, son of legendary French chef Paul Bocuse, discusses the upcoming Asia-Pacific leg of the Bocuse d'Or competition in Singapore, where nine teams will compete to represent their countries in the Grand Finale in Lyon. Jerome emphasizes the importance of classical French cuisine, citing the need for chefs to "get the basics right" and "be faithful to your cooking." The competition aims to promote Bocuse d'Or by hosting it in different countries, including Singapore, to showcase diverse cuisines. Team Singapore, led by chef Yew Eng Tong, will compete for the first time in Singapore, with the goal of pushing the creative envelope and achieving perfection.

images.alt_text: CHEF JEROME: 'The most important thing I've learned from my father is to be faithful to your cooking.'

The event (above) takes place over two days near the end of January in Lyon, France, and next week the Asia-Pacific Selection will take place here in Singapore. Chef Menard says that winners of the Bocuse d'Or have gone on to 'bright futures in the industry'.

site_title: No regrets raising rates in December: Yellen
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that she doesn't regret raising interest rates in December, citing the economy's substantial progress. The Fed has delayed further rate increases, but Yellen said it remains on a "reasonable path" towards higher rates as economic growth continues.

site_title: Giants' battle for Yahoo may spark antitrust concerns
summary: A potential bidding war is brewing over Yahoo, with companies like Google, Verizon, and Time Inc set to join the competition for the struggling search engine and media company. Despite its declining fortunes, Yahoo remains a significant player, attracting 202.5 million unique visitors in November and generating 84% of its revenue from ads. However, its inability to establish a profitable advertising business has put it at a disadvantage to Google and Facebook. Verizon is considered a leading contender, with the potential bid sparking antitrust concerns, particularly if it were to acquire Yahoo and AOL, combining their data-gathering capabilities.

site_title: PSLE T-score to make way for scoring bands in 2021
summary: Singapore's education system is set for a "paradigm shift" as the government aims to move away from an overemphasis on academic grades. Starting in 2021, the Primary School Leaving Examination (PSLE) will introduce scoring bands, replacing the current T-score system. The change aims to promote a more holistic education, focusing on students' learning and mastery rather than precise scores. The new system will also allow for greater flexibility in the Secondary One posting system, with the Direct School Admission (DSA) scheme to be reviewed for more options in secondary schools for students with specific aptitudes and talents.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: More help for laid-off workers
summary: The Singapore government has launched the "Adapt and Grow" initiative to help laid-off workers, mainly professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs), return to work quickly. The initiative includes three schemes: Career Support Programme (CSP), Professional Conversion Programme (PCP), and P-Max, which offer wage support, training and re-skilling opportunities, and recruitment incentives to employers. The CSP has been extended to six months for all PMETs, while the PCP will cover over 20 sectors, and P-Max will increase its targeted placements. The goal is to help workers quickly find employment and reduce the duration of unemployment.

site_title: Toronto condos: one in 10 owned by foreigners
summary: A study by Canada's national housing agency found that one in 10 condos built in downtown Toronto since 2010 are owned by foreigners. In Vancouver, 6% of newer condos were owned by foreign buyers, with 7.4% in the Greater Toronto area and 10.1% in the city centre. The study attributes foreign investment, particularly from mainland China, to driving up prices in these markets.

site_title: Employment Pass criteria tightened to favour S'porean Core
summary: Singapore's Employment Pass criteria will be tightened to favor Singaporean Core, with assessments considering the proportion of locals hired, firm commitment to nurturing the local workforce, and relevance to the economy. Companies deemed "triple weak" - those with weak local hiring, commitment, and relevance - may have their work pass privileges suspended, affecting their Employment Pass applications. The move aims to address the "local-foreign divide" and strengthen Singapore's overall competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Assessments of applications for Employment Pass will soon be expanded to take in three "company-related" factors, including the strength of the Singaporean Core in the company applying for the pass, Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say said on Friday.

site_title: Poland banks might spread out mortgage conversion costs
summary: Poland's president's office is considering allowing banks to spread out the costs of converting foreign currency mortgages into zlotys over several years, a move aimed at helping borrowers who took out loans in Swiss francs in 2007-2008. The proposed bill has been criticized for putting too much strain on banks, with costs estimated to be around 70 billion zlotys (S$25 billion). A revised draft bill may allow the central bank or Guarantee Fund to lend money to banks, spreading costs over 20-30 years at a rate of 2-3 billion zlotys annually.

site_title: Fed minutes, play on banks main features; STI down 10 pts for the week
summary: The US Federal Reserve's March Open Market Committee meeting minutes showed most governors opposed raising interest rates in April, boosting stocks. However, this momentum was short-lived as Wall Street indices dropped on Thursday. In Singapore, the Straits Times Index fell 10 points over the week, with weak and subdued trading volume. Key economic news included the announcement of a £10b upgrade at London's Heathrow, an Indonesia graft case, and the retirement of OCBC CEO Helen Wong, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor.

site_title: G-20 summit should be about economics, not politics: China
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi urged the Group of 20 (G-20) summit to focus on economics rather than politics, warning that inserting non-economic issues could impact regional stability. The summit, set to be held in Hangzhou in September, will bring together world leaders, including Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Barack Obama. China seeks to discuss global economic growth, while Japan, hosting the G-7 summit next month, plans to address territorial disputes and North Korea's nuclear ambitions.

site_title: China seen jolting market by paring copper stockpile
summary: China is expected to release a significant portion of its record-high copper stockpiles onto the global market, potentially causing a major shock to the copper industry. The move, which could be as high as 10,000 tonnes per month, would be a significant blow to global copper prices and producers, particularly during the traditionally strong demand period in China. This decision reflects the country's struggling economy and reduced demand for copper, which has been hit by slowing construction and electronics manufacturing.

site_title: Building the no-brand brand
summary: Muji, a Japanese retailer known for its minimalist design, is expanding its product line to include a hotel and car. Chairman Masaaki Kanai envisions the hotel as functional and simple, with Muji bicycles for guests to use. A Muji car is also in the conceptual stage, with electric vehicles potentially used for farmers. Despite economic slowdowns, Muji plans to continue its expansion, with 3,300 sq ft stores opening in Singapore featuring an "Open Muji" concept for community interaction. By 2017, Muji aims to have more overseas stores than in Japan, driven by growth in China and the US.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Markets starting to take threat of yen intervention seriously
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso warned that the government will intervene in the foreign exchange markets if necessary to prevent the yen from surging in value, causing the currency to retreat from its 17-month high. The yen had surged after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's statement that Japan should avoid intervention, but analysts say the government's hands are tied by Abe's pledge and the upcoming G-7 summit. The Nikkei 225 stock average gained 0.5% as the yen closed at 108.78 to the dollar.

site_title: Pattaya's scenic stunners
summary: Pattaya, Thailand, is a popular golfing destination with over 30 courses along its eastern seaboard, designed by top architects like Pete Dye, Jack Nicklaus, and Schmidt/Curley. Notable courses include Laem Chabang International Country Club, Pattana Golf Club & Resort, and Siam Country Club, which feature championship layouts, scenic views, and challenging holes. The region's growing popularity is evident with planned new golf course projects. Visitors can access Pattaya via Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi International Airport, with various accommodation options available, including beachfront hotels and resorts.

site_title: Facebook working to combat drop in personal sharing: sources
summary: Facebook is working to combat a decline in personal sharing among its 1.6 billion users, as people are less willing to post updates about their lives with growing friend lists. The term "context collapse" describes this shift, where personal content is shared in smaller audiences on other services like Snapchat and Instagram. Despite a 21% drop in original sharing of personal stories, Facebook claims overall sharing has remained strong. The company has introduced tactics such as live video tools and reminders to encourage more personal posts, with CEO Mark Zuckerberg emphasizing the need for inspiration.

site_title: Banks at risk of bad-debt blowout as Aussie steelmaker collapses
summary: Australia's Arrium Ltd, a steel and iron ore supplier, has handed control to an administrator after lenders rejected a US$927 million recapitalisation plan. Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, and National Australia Bank each lent A$250 million to Arrium, with a combined A$1 billion loan at risk. The banks may recoup less than 50 cents on the dollar, leading to a potential blowout in bad-debt expenses. The commodities bust is impacting companies and banks worldwide, with bad-debt provisions set to rise to their highest in eight years by 2018.

site_title: India becoming new centre of oil demand growth
summary: India is emerging as the new center of oil demand growth, driven by its expanding economy and manufacturing sector. Despite the global oil price crash, India reduced its oil imports by $60 billion in 2015, buying 4% more oil. India's oil demand is expected to triple since 1999, similar to China's growth during that period. The country is investing in energy-producing assets and partnering with Iran to develop a port and joint projects, mirroring China's approach a decade ago. India's economy is expected to surpass Japan as the world's third-largest oil user this year, with a growth rate of 6 million barrels per day through 2040.

site_title: US adds China's Internet controls to list of trade barriers
summary: The US has added China's Internet controls to its list of trade barriers, citing "outright blocking of websites" as a significant burden to foreign suppliers. China's Great Firewall, which blocks popular global sites like Google, Facebook, and Twitter, has worsened over the last year, with eight of the top 25 most popular sites blocked in China. The US trade office considers China's Internet censorship a matter of national security, but experts say China's approach is unlikely to change, highlighting the gulf between the US and China's approaches to regulating the internet.

site_title: Aramco IPO could raise US$106b for Saudi wealth fund
summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund could receive $106 billion from the sale of a 5% stake in Aramco's parent company, according to the Sovereign Wealth Fund Institute. The Public Investment Fund (PIF) would control over $2 trillion of assets if Aramco is transferred to the fund, making investments the source of government revenue. The listing of Aramco may happen as soon as 2017, with Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman stating that this move could increase the PIF's cash pot and enlarge domestic markets.

site_title: Aussie PM to lead 1,000-strong business delegation to China
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull will lead a 1,000-strong business delegation to China, focusing on building on the free trade agreement (FTA) between the two countries. Turnbull will meet with President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang, aiming to capitalize on China's shift from an export-based economy to a major consumer spender. The visit comes amid concerns over China's assertiveness in the South China Sea, but no discussion on the topic is expected. The trip aims to boost trade and engagement between the two countries, particularly with Australia's economy reliant on Chinese trade.

site_title: Citi's head of equities Derek Bandeen to retire: memo
summary: Citi's head of equities, Derek Bandeen, is retiring, according to a memo reviewed by Reuters. Bandeen joined Citi in 2008 from Morgan Stanley and will remain with the bank until a replacement is found. The news was reported earlier by the Wall Street Journal.

site_title: 'Good response' to SkillsFuture Credit in Q1
summary: Acting Education Minister Ong Ye Kung announced that approximately 18,000 Singaporeans have used their SkillsFuture credits to attend courses in the first three months of 2016, with around S$5.2 million disbursed. This is considered a "healthy response" and shows that 17% of users are 60 and above, and nearly half are under 40. The government plans to expand eligible courses to 12,500 and introduce new initiatives, including a rationalized Post-Secondary Education Account and SkillsFuture Credit for people with disabilities.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

This shift reflects the growing influence of hedge funds in venture funding, as they seek to diversify their portfolios and capitalize on emerging markets.

Despite ongoing US-EU trade talks, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: ANZ considering sale of stake in Malaysia's AmBank: sources

Brave's plan aims to reduce consumer exposure to online ads, but the publishers argue it could harm their revenue streams.

site_title: I am so going to figure out how to game the new PSLE rules
summary: A Singaporean father of two is skeptical of the new PSLE grading system, which uses broad bands instead of precise scores, and the Direct School Admission (DSA) scheme, which aims to recognize achievements in non-academic areas. He believes the changes will not reduce pressure on parents to excel and will instead shift the focus to extracurricular activities, potentially creating a generation of "incredibly proficient individuals" who are not well-rounded. He argues that the real issue is the high correlation between getting into a good school and later success, and that the government should focus on reducing gaps in quality of teaching and resources between schools.

The social network has quintupled its revenue in four years and is larger than 27 Dow members, making it the largest omission. Analysts argue that Facebook's high share price and industry dominance justify its inclusion in the average, but its exclusion may be due to the distortions caused by other large companies like Alphabet and Amazon.

The unusual trading volume, however, sparked no further explanation from the company.

site_title: SMW 2016 a platform for green, digital shipping
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore has expanded the events at the 11th Singapore Maritime Week (SMW 2016) to 31 from 15, focusing on digital shipping and emerging industry issues. This move aims to enhance the resilience and relevance of the highly cyclical shipping sector by promoting communication and collaboration on digital technologies and new regulations.

site_title: Europe: Global stock markets in mixed end to volatile week
summary: Global stock markets in Europe ended the week on a mixed note, rebounding on Friday after a volatile week. London's FTSE 100 index rose 1.1%, aided by rising oil prices, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also climbed. Despite poor manufacturing and trade figures, investors seemed to shrug off concerns about the global economy, with some stocks gaining due to mining and healthcare sectors. The US stock market also reached fresh records, driven by the S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Some condos being run as serviced apartments
summary: Two Singapore condominiums, Oxley Thanksgiving Residence and St Thomas Lodge, are operating as serviced apartments despite lacking planning permission. A third, also in District 9, is set to open. The properties, owned by Chinese temple Poh Ern Shih, are listed for short-term stays on Atas Residence's website. site_title: To be or not to be with EU
summary: In the lead-up to the June 2016 EU referendum, Londoners overwhelmingly support remaining in the EU, with 58% backing the "Remain" campaign, while eastern London boroughs like Havering, which borders the city, are more Euro-sceptic. Residents in these areas cite concerns over immigration, job competition, and economic uncertainty as reasons for wanting to leave the EU. However, some in these areas, including a local lawmaker, express doubts about the potential consequences of a "Leave" vote, while others, like a businessman, see EU free-movement rules as vulnerable to terrorism.

site_title: Distressed businesses may offer opportunities for buyers
summary: Moody's downgraded Singapore's major banks to "negative" due to a weakening economic outlook across the region. Depressed commodity prices, a global economic slowdown, and rising US interest rates have created a perfect storm affecting South-east Asian economies. However, for cash-rich investors, these challenging conditions can lead to better deals as distressed companies may need to dispose of assets or consolidate. This presents opportunities for buyers to strike more favorable deals amidst the economic uncertainty.

site_title: HSBC celebrates 20 years of CSR
summary: HSBC celebrated 20 years of corporate social responsibility (CSR) in Singapore with a volunteer appreciation event, raising funds for disadvantaged children. The event featured a relay race on Segway vehicles, with each lap raising S$1,200 for charity. Minister for Social and Family Development Tan Chuan-Jin led one of the teams. The event aimed to promote community engagement and philanthropy, highlighting HSBC's commitment to CSR in the country.

site_title: Ringgit's 2016 surge likely to slow down
summary: Malaysia's ringgit has surged 10% against the US dollar in the first quarter of 2016, its largest quarterly gain since 1973, driven by foreign investors returning to the market due to better oil prices and easier monetary policies. However, analysts expect the rally to slow down as Malaysian assets become pricey to investors. The ringgit's recovery is attributed to a resilient economy and increased interest in longer-tenor debt, but concerns remain over valuations and leadership at the central bank, with a new governor set to take over in April.

site_title: OSIM clarifies final offer price of S$1.41
summary: Credit Suisse, on behalf of Vision Three Pte Ltd, has announced a final offer price of S$1.41 per OSIM share for the takeover of the lifestyle products group. Shareholders who have accepted the offer will receive the final offer price or the final ex-dividend offer price depending on the settlement date.

To succeed, new managers should focus on coaching, developing others, and performance management, and establish clear expectations and boundaries. They should also get to know their team on a personal level, address team pain points, and learn to lead and manage up.

site_title: Malaysia's Proton gets government bailout package
summary: Malaysia's government approved a 1.5 billion ringgit bailout package for struggling national car maker Proton to help pay its debts. The package comes with conditions for the company to develop a turnaround plan and is aimed at supporting 60,000 workers. Proton, formed in 1983, has struggled with poor sales and quality issues, and its chairman, Mahathir Mohamad, recently resigned amid calls for Prime Minister Najib Razak to step down. A taskforce will monitor the car manufacturer's transformation.

With only 99 units produced, the GTA Spano is expected to be priced close to S$4 million, targeting collectors in the region.

site_title: Oil rebounds above US$40, with eyes on Doha

Brent crude rose $1.79 to $41.22 per barrel, while US benchmark West Texas Intermediate gained $2.10 to $39.36 per barrel. Traders await the April 17 meeting, led by Russia and Saudi Arabia, to discuss stabilizing prices and tackling a vast supply glut. However, conflicting signals on an agreement have kept prices volatile, with some analysts warning that the market may experience further fluctuations.

site_title: Blackstone to shut mutual fund after Fidelity pulls out

The fund will no longer accept new money and will be liquidated by May 31. This move follows a large redemption by Fidelity, which had invested almost $1 billion in the fund in 2013. The fund's investment adviser will convert all holdings to cash and cash equivalents to meet redemption requests.

site_title: SMRT completes internal probe into track accident, appoints external reviewers
summary: SMRT Corp has completed its internal probe into the March 22 track accident that killed two employees and appointed external reviewers from Keppel Corp, Transport for London, and a former MTR Corp executive to review the findings. The investigation aims to determine the cause of the accident.

site_title: France visitor numbers up in 2015 despite attacks
summary: France welcomed 84.5 million foreign visitors in 2015, a 0.9% increase from the previous year, despite jihadist attacks in Paris that killed 130 people. The attacks limited growth in the capital, but a 22.7% rise in Asian tourists, particularly from China and India, helped drive the increase. The number of Chinese tourists reached 2.2 million, up 38% from 2014, and Indian tourists also saw a 48% increase. France aims to attract 100 million foreign tourists by 2020.

site_title: Owners of Swiss payment firm Global Blue test appetite for US$2.3b sale: sources
summary: Global Blue, a Swiss shopping tax-refund payment firm, is being considered for a potential sale valued at approximately $3.06 billion. The business provides VAT sales tax refunds and services to over 100,000 customers daily, with a network of 270,000 partners in 43 countries. A sale process has yet to begin, with the owners reviewing options to exit the business and maximize value.

site_title: Shanghai wealth management firm comes crashing to earth as executives arrested
summary: Shanghai wealth management firm Zhongjin Capital Management's executives were arrested on April 5 on suspicion of "illegal fundraising" in China's shadow banking sector. The arrests came after the company's offices were closed suddenly, with investors paid off but unable to withdraw funds. The firm had promised double-digit returns to investors and had a high-profile image, but police say it was engaging in irregular fundraising practices. The arrests are part of a broader crackdown on illegal fundraising by the Shanghai municipal government, and the case has raised concerns among investors and employees about the risks in China's shadow banking sector.

site_title: China foreign minister says clarification needed on Panama Papers
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi said clarification is needed on the Panama Papers, a massive leak revealing offshore financial arrangements of wealthy individuals, including relatives of Chinese leaders. Wang acknowledged the matter, making him the most senior Chinese official to comment, but declined to elaborate or confirm if China will investigate. China's anti-corruption fight will continue, with the government citing broad public support, despite criticism that the campaign is focused on internal power struggles.

site_title: Hedge funds investing in China lost 7.4% in first quarter
summary: Hedge funds investing in China suffered a 7.4% loss in the first quarter of 2016, largely due to a slowing Chinese economy and stock market volatility. The losses were attributed to aggressive shorting of local markets and offshore trading of the yuan. This marks a significant reversal from the previous year's 7.5% gain. The decline also outpaced that of emerging market leaders Brazil and Russia, which saw 16.9% and 18% gains, respectively.

site_title: Goldman Sachs gives Blankfein US$7m long-term incentive
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein received a US$7 million long-term incentive award, bringing his total compensation for 2015 to $30 million. This makes him the highest-paid CEO among US lenders for the fourth consecutive year, despite a 28% decline in net income. His total pay package includes US$14.7 million in restricted shares, a US$6.3 million cash bonus, and a US$2 million salary.

site_title: US wholesale inventories fall sharply, point to weaker growth
summary: US wholesale inventories plummeted 0.5% in February, the largest decline in nearly three years, suggesting a sharper slowdown in first-quarter economic growth than previously thought. This decline, combined with a revised 0.2% drop in January, points to a potential catch-up in economic growth in the second quarter. Economists expect the economy to grow at less than a 1% annual rate in the first quarter, down from 1.4% in the last quarter of 2015.

site_title: Royal London says to oppose BP CEO's pay package at AGM

European stocks also rose, curbing demand for gold as a safe-haven asset.
