She would be the first woman to head the world body, succeeding Ban Ki-moon. New Zealand formally submitted a letter to the UN General Assembly nominating Clark, who currently heads the UN Development Programme. Clark's bid aims to capitalize on her leadership experience and make the UN more accountable.

site_title: SRX Property expands into valuation service
summary: SRX Property has launched "SRX V-8", a full valuation system aiming to make valuations more accessible and transparent to retail users. The service costs less due to its use of big data and technology, and provides detailed property comparables. This move aims to fill gaps in the real estate market, particularly in price discovery, which is currently dominated by institutions. CEO Sam Baker believes the service will provide a transparent pricing mechanism, reducing risks in the marketplace and giving users confidence in arriving at a price for a home.

site_title: Asia Square could sharpen CCT's edge
summary: Capitaland Group's office real estate investment trust CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) may acquire Asia Square Tower 1, a completed Grade A office development, to enhance its portfolio profile and stay competitive in Singapore's office market. CCT's current assets are mostly "legacy assets" outside of Marina Bay, and acquiring Asia Square would allow it to enter the new CBD. The tower's price has decreased to $2,700-2,800 per square foot, and its occupancy is around 90%. CCT's parent company, CapitaLand, has expressed a willingness to buy the asset at the right price, and the trust is also considering selling its One George Street property to reinvest in another asset.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Tesla misses Q1 delivery forecast, blames parts shortages
summary: Tesla missed its Q1 delivery forecast, shipping 14,820 vehicles in the first quarter, 48% more than last year. The company blamed parts shortages for the Model X SUV and "hubris" in adding too much technology. Despite this, Tesla reaffirmed plans to deliver 80,000-90,000 vehicles this year. The company's shares fell in after-market trading.

site_title: MPs call for better pulse on effectiveness of policies
summary: Singaporean MPs called for a better understanding of the effectiveness of government policies, citing concerns over over-measurement and unintended consequences. They suggested reviewing indicators and eligibility criteria, while also considering more accurate metrics to determine policy success. The success of the Productivity and Innovation Credit scheme was highlighted, with some MPs criticizing its use in purchasing unnecessary equipment. The government was advised to strike a balance between accountability and speed in implementing policies, and to involve stakeholders in the crafting and implementation process.

site_title: Vintage gold
summary: Classic cars have outpaced the general market, with prices rising 17% last year and 490% over the last decade, according to the Knight Frank Luxury Investment Index. This performance has surpassed traditional investments such as watches, art, and wine. The top 10 most valuable cars ever sold have been auctioned in the last three years, with prices reaching over $1.4 billion in North America in 2015. Experts attribute the growth to a sustainable market driven by educated enthusiasts and manufacturers' support for vintage cars, making it more social and feasible for collectors.

site_title: Job openings in US decreased in February to 5.45 million
summary: US job openings decreased to 5.45 million in February, a drop of 159,000 from the prior month, according to the Labor Department. This marks the first decline in job openings since 2015. The pace of hiring accelerated, suggesting a strengthening labor market.

site_title: Panama Papers case another stark reminder to secure digital systems
summary: The Panama Papers, a massive leak of 11.5 million documents from Mossack Fonseca, is the largest leak of confidential documents in recorded history, dwarfing previous leaks like WikiLeaks and Edward Snowden's episodes. The leak, which includes 2.6 terabytes of data, has significant financial implications, affecting politicians, celebrities, and business leaders worldwide. The incident highlights the dangers of data breaches and the need for robust digital security measures to prevent such leaks. It also underscores the importance of having systems in place to detect and respond to data breaches promptly.

site_title: Japan pension fund seen posting torrid annual loss
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) is expected to post its worst annual loss since the global financial crisis, potentially around 6 trillion yen (S$74 billion), when it reports results on July 29. This is three weeks later than usual and comes ahead of a summer election. The fund's decline is attributed to market fluctuations, with SMBC Nikko Securities Inc estimating a significant loss. The news is expected to provide a piece of bad news for the Japanese government ahead of the election.

site_title: Top China bankers' salaries halved in 2015
summary: China's top bankers saw their 2015 salaries halved by a record 50% due to Beijing-mandated pay reforms. The reforms, implemented last year, targeted state-owned firms' executives, with chairman and president compensation reduced. Key figures, including ICBC's Jiang Jianqing and UBS' Sergio Ermotti, saw significant pay cuts, with Jiang's compensation dropping to 0.3% of JPMorgan Chase's Jamie Dimon's total. The move aimed to curb excessive executive compensation and transform state-owned enterprise reform efforts.

site_title: Weak oil, slide in Dow futures hit STI
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 34.43 points lower at 2,800.92, following losses in Japan and Hong Kong. Weak oil prices, a 3% drop in US$35 per barrel, and speculation about the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike in June contributed to the market's decline. Banks and Singtel led the selling, with the overall market recording an advance-decline score of 137-266, excluding warrants.

site_title: China developer brings homes of the future to S'pore
summary: China-based property developer Qingjian Realty has launched The Visionaire, Singapore's first smart-home executive condominium (EC) featuring an app-enabled system with 10 Samsung smart devices. The units, located in Canberra Link, Sembawang, will offer features such as smart air-conditioners, smart locks, and IP cameras. Buyers can opt out of the smart features for a price reduction of S$7,000 to S$8,000. The project is expected to top out in October 2018 and will comprise 632 units, with prices estimated to be in the range of S$750,000 to S$800,000.

site_title: LinkedIn to open S$80m data centre in Singapore
summary: LinkedIn is set to unveil its seventh global data centre, valued at S$80 million, in Singapore. The centre, which will serve a third of the platform's global traffic, marks the company's first international data centre outside the US. The facility is part of LinkedIn's expansion efforts to meet growing demand for its services. The new data centre is expected to support the company's mission to connect professionals worldwide.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Rickmers Maritime units surged 38.6% in heavy trading on Monday, with 105 million units changing hands, before closing at 11.3 Singapore cents each. The trust management attributed the surge to unknown information not previously announced. Swissco Holdings proposed to acquire the VM Group, comprising several companies, from Melvin Rodrigues. The acquisition will be completed through restructuring, with companies forming part of the VM Group to be acquired by Swissco.

site_title: Credit Suisse focused on organic growth in Asia: CEO
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam emphasized the bank's focus on organic growth in Asia, taking a "counter-cyclical" approach to hiring bankers. Despite concerns over China, Thiam expressed confidence in the region, citing its 20% return on capital and long-term growth potential. The bank is prioritizing organic growth over acquisitions, viewing it as cheaper and less risky. Thiam also defended the bank's stance on tax compliance, following the Panama Papers scandal.

site_title: See the TAC cup as half-full and address all issues positively
summary: The Singapore government has allocated up to S$30 million over five years to support trade associations and chambers (TACs), recognizing their importance in industry upgrading and transformation. TACs face four major issues: relevance, tackling industry-level broad-based issues, politicking, and limited revenue streams. The government's support aims to empower TACs in areas such as funding, training, and certification, potentially increasing their relevance and membership. A more positive approach to addressing these issues, including mentorship and cross-collaboration, is encouraged to drive industry growth and synergy.

site_title: Tech startups choose to stay private in IPO standoff
summary: US technology companies have avoided initial public offerings (IPOs) for the fourth time since data collection began in the early 1990s, with no tech company going public in the first quarter of 2016. This unusual drought is attributed to the current market conditions, where investors are wary of taking on new risk due to stock price swings and the low valuations of many companies. Several large tech companies are choosing to remain private, valuations that are too high for IPO investors, and instead opting to raise funds in the private market.

site_title: Mergers of Asian stock exchanges unlikely: HKEx chief
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEx) chief Charles Li does not foresee mergers of Asian stock exchanges due to sovereignty issues, but aims to build Asian derivatives exchanges for commodity traders in 3-5 years. HKEx, the new owner of the London Metal Exchange (LME), plans to create financial products and cash spot markets for commodities trading in China. Li acknowledges Southbound trading has missed expectations due to differences in investor bases and education needs.

site_title: Few takers among car buyers for balloon payment loan scheme
summary: Singapore's UOB has re-introduced the balloon payment car loan scheme, offering customers a lower monthly instalment with a higher interest rate and a final lump sum payment after four years and 11 months. The scheme aims to provide financial flexibility, but few car buyers are taking it up due to concerns over the large final payment. Leasing schemes, which require a lower downpayment, are instead attracting buyers looking to sidestep vehicle financing restrictions. UOB data shows that Singapore car owners typically hold onto their cars for 4-5 years, but the balloon scheme's drawbacks may outweigh its benefits for many.

site_title: Alaska Air sees acquisition of Virgin America as key to US West Coast
summary: Alaska Air Group has agreed to acquire Virgin America for $2.6 billion, aiming to become the fifth-largest US carrier and strengthen its presence on the West Coast. The deal, announced on Monday, will give Alaska valuable space at major California airports and lucrative transcontinental routes. Alaska Air must now integrate Virgin America's brand, which is beloved by customers, while achieving annual cost savings of $225 million. The acquisition will also create a tougher competitor for JetBlue and propel Alaska Air into the top five American carriers.

site_title: Japan set for major stimulus, including 'helicopter drops' of money
summary: Japan is poised to implement a major stimulus package, including "helicopter drops" of money, to boost its economy, which is at risk of a renewed recession. The package, announced by officials, will combine fiscal stimulus and monetary easing, with the Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor Haruhiko Kuroda indicating a potential boost in quantitative easing and interest rates. The government plans to front-load budget spending, including public works, and is considering an additional budget to increase spending. Analysts suggest the stimulus package could be worth up to 5 trillion yen, with the BOJ buying 90% of new government debt, weakening the barrier to increased spending.

site_title: Chinese 'parachute kids' flock to US schools
summary: Chinese students, known as "parachute kids," are increasingly flocking to US schools, with many opting to complete their high school education abroad. According to Hailun "Helen" Zhou, a 17-year-old from Sichuan province, it's a trend her father's friends started, with many sending their children abroad for education. Zhou, who has spent two years studying in California, plans to graduate this spring. This trend is driven by a desire for international education opportunities, with many Chinese parents seeking to provide their children with a better education abroad.

site_title: Squatters a barrier to protecting Delhi's ancient monuments
summary: Squatters are occupying ancient monuments in New Delhi, India, due to the city's high demand for land and limited resources. The 16th-century Atgah Khan tomb and other protected sites have become homes for millions of poor and homeless families, making conservation efforts challenging. Conservationists and officials are struggling to balance preservation with the needs of the community, with some sites being demolished by authorities to make way for development. The government has limited funds to protect the monuments, and disputes over ownership and stakeholder interests hinder progress.

site_title: Panama Papers: Singapore authorities doing the 'necessary checks'
summary: Singapore authorities are reviewing leaked tax documents from a Panama law firm, known as the "Panama Papers", to determine if any individuals or entities in the country have engaged in wrongdoing. The Ministry of Finance and Monetary Authority of Singapore are conducting necessary checks and will take firm action if evidence of wrongdoing is found. Authorities worldwide, including several countries in Europe and Asia, are also investigating the leak, which involved over 11.5 million documents.

site_title: US services grow at faster pace for first time in five months
summary: US service industries experienced a growth acceleration in March for the first time in five months, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing index rising to 54.5 from 53.4. This signals moderate expansion and alleviates concerns about a broader economic slowdown. The services sector accounts for 90% of the US economy, and the robust growth in industries such as construction, finance, and retailing is supported by strong payrolls growth and rising wages.

site_title: Living the car life
summary: Luxury automotive brands Ferrari, Rolls-Royce, Bentley, and BMW have launched various lifestyle accessories for their customers. Ferrari's Spring/Summer 2016 Lifestyle Collection features a fashion line inspired by its Gran Turismo road cars, while Rolls-Royce's cocktail hamper is crafted from American walnut and fine leather, complete with integrated lights and platinum-rimmed glasses. Bentley's Signature Touch smartphone features a bespoke service, exclusive content, and advanced technology. BMW's "Montblanc for BMW" special edition includes high-quality pens, leather goods, and accessories. Meanwhile, Audi's Sport Racing Bike is a lightweight, high-performance bicycle designed for enthusiasts.

site_title: Oil near one-month low on unexpected US demand drop
summary: US gasoline demand fell in January for the first time in 14 months, causing oil prices to drop near a one-month low. The decline in demand, combined with doubts over an output freeze among oil producers, has cast uncertainty over the global supply glut. Oil producers are set to meet in Doha on April 17 to discuss an output freeze, but a recent surge in Russian oil production has raised concerns about the outcome.

site_title: Disney COO Staggs to step down as search for new CEO widens
summary: Walt Disney Co's COO Tom Staggs will step down on May 6 as the company expands its search for a new CEO to replace Bob Iger, who is set to retire in June 2018. Staggs, 55, had been seen as the likely successor but was not guaranteed the job. The board aims to evaluate a "robust slate of candidates" and may consider Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook's COO, as a potential candidate. Staggs will remain employed as a special adviser to Iger through September.

site_title: Independent listings committee gives applicant the go-ahead in first ruling
summary: The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) independent Listings Advisory Committee (LAC) has issued its first ruling, approving a Singapore real estate investment trust's (Reit) listing application despite non-compliant bill financing arrangements. The LAC accepted the applicant's representation that the transactions were common market practice in the relevant foreign jurisdiction and that the non-compliant proceeds were not used to fund operations. The ruling provides transparency into the listing process and will be reported twice a year, starting in 2016.

site_title: De Souza calls for ABSD to be removed for S'poreans
summary: MP Christopher de Souza calls for the removal of the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) for Singaporean buyers, while keeping the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) in place. The move aims to revive the lacklustre property market, which has seen a slowdown in construction activity and growth in the sector. De Souza advocates for a gradual approach to easing cooling measures, citing the Australian model as a potential example. The government has previously introduced the ABSD and TDSR to stabilize the property market, but Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has stated that it is premature to relax these measures.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel DC Reit's chairman, Lim Ho Kee, will step down on May 10, 2016, and Low Teck Seng will replace him as chairman. UOB Kay Hian maintains its target price at S$2.23 and expects the change in leadership to be a step in the right direction for the company. Meanwhile, OSIM International has received a cash offer of S$1.39 per share, and OCBC Investment Research recommends shareholders to accept the offer due to its reasonable price-earnings ratio.

site_title: Microsoft strikes partnership with banks on blockchain tech
summary: Microsoft has formed a strategic partnership with R3, a consortium of 43 financial institutions, to accelerate the use of blockchain technology. The partnership aims to provide cloud-based services and tools for blockchain software deployment. The first commercial deployments are expected to go live in about a year, with Microsoft potentially winning business from banks due to its preferred vendor relationship with R3. This move puts Microsoft ahead of rivals like IBM and Google in the blockchain technology market.

site_title: Japan March services sector PMI falls to 50.0 from 51.2 in Feb
summary: Japan's services sector PMI fell to 50.0 in March from 51.2 in February, marking the lowest since expansion began last year. The index remains above the 50 threshold, but it's the lowest reading since services activity started expanding in April 2022. This sign suggests the economy is losing momentum, with new business stopping growth.

site_title: Olam prices US$300m 5-year fixed rate senior notes
summary: Olam International Limited priced a US$300 million, 5-year senior note at a final coupon of 4.50%. The notes were successfully priced following an intraday book-building exercise, attracting over 65 investors and an over-subscribed orderbook. Asian investors accounted for approximately 87% of the allocation, with European investors receiving the remainder. The joint lead managers and joint bookrunners were Credit Suisse, DBS Bank, and The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited.

site_title: Alpha fund buys rest of 78 Shenton Way
summary: Alpha Investment Partners, a property fund managed by Keppel Corporation, has acquired the remaining half-stake in 78 Shenton Way, a Singapore property, from Commerz Real for S$301.5 million, pricing the entire property at S$1,665 per square foot. The transaction reflects a 4% net yield and includes two towers built on a site with a 66-year lease term. The purchase was facilitated after Commerz Real appointed CBRE to find a buyer and Alpha entered the market earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Keeping tabs on new sea law a good move
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) supports the UN's expansion of the 22-year-old United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) to include a new legally binding instrument on marine life conservation in areas beyond national jurisdiction. ICS emphasizes the need to ensure shipping interests are protected, citing the importance of maintaining freedom of the high seas, navigation rights, and the current balance of rights and obligations between flag, coastal, and port states. The ICS will closely monitor developments in ocean governance and cooperate with the World Ocean Council and International Maritime Organization.

site_title: India flags off its fastest-ever train
summary: India has launched the Gatimaan Express, its fastest train, with a top speed of 160 km/h. The train, part of a $135 billion modernization plan, offers luxurious amenities, including hostesses and bone china crockery. However, its speed is only half that of trains in China and other countries. The train, running from New Delhi to the Taj Mahal, aims to improve India's crumbling railway system and cater to the 23 million daily train passengers.

site_title: Surfing the value 'tsunami'
summary: Investors have returned to buying value, driven by a surge in gold and US high yield bonds, despite a rocky start to 2016. Asian local bonds have shown signs of life, and the Asean markets may provide a surprise. However, China's value remains, but patience is required due to unchanged economic growth fears. Japan's move towards negative interest rates has exposed a good entry point, and corporate restructuring remains a key theme. The global strategist retains overweight exposures to Japan, Korea, Taiwan, selected European markets, and US high yield bonds, while recommending patience for China and a focus on Asian bonds for yield.

site_title: Major banks set up thousands of offshore firms: Le Monde on Panama Papers
summary: Major banks including HSBC, UBS, Credit Suisse, and Societe Generale set up over 4,500 offshore companies through Panama-based law firm Mossack Fonseca, according to Le Monde. The firms cited by Le Monde rejected any wrongdoing, stating they only engage in legitimate offshore arrangements and conduct thorough vetting of account holders. The Panama Papers leak revealed 365 banks worldwide had used Mossack Fonseca's services, with the banks emphasizing compliance with regulations and fiscal rules.

site_title: Ford announces new investment in Mexico amid election-year controversy
summary: Ford Motor Co announced a $1.6 billion investment to build more small cars in Mexico, starting in 2018. The move counters criticism from Donald Trump, who has accused US companies of "sending jobs to Mexico." The San Luis Potosi plant, set to open in 2018, will employ 2,800 by 2020 and likely produce the next-generation Ford Focus compact and a hybrid model. This investment follows a trend of automakers expanding production in Mexico to take advantage of lower labor costs and favorable currency exchange.

site_title: Tunisia e-site in Panama Papers hacked, goes offline
summary: Tunisian e-site Inkyfada, investigating the Panama Papers scandal, was hacked and went offline hours after posting its first findings. The hackers posted false information under the site's name, which has been identified but not the perpetrators. The hacking comes amid several countries' vows to investigate tax evasion following the leak of 11.5 million confidential documents.

images.alt_text: Inkyfada, an electronic magazine investigating any Tunisian involvement in the so-called Panama Papers, came under attack by hackers on Tuesday just hours after its first postings on the scandal.

site_title: France puts Panama back on tax haven blacklist
summary: France will put Panama back on its blacklist of uncooperative tax jurisdictions, following media revelations about a Panamanian law firm linked to offshore firms. The move comes after a Panamanian law firm specialized in setting up offshore firms was exposed. This decision aims to combat tax evasion and ensure countries cooperate with international tax authorities.

site_title: ArcelorMittal hits US$3b rights issue
summary: ArcelorMittal successfully completed a $3 billion rights issue to reduce debt, with a total subscription rate of 126.9% and issuing 1.6 billion new shares. The company aims to use the funds to bolster its balance sheet amid a global steel glut. The move follows a $6.7 billion loss in the fourth quarter, largely due to a writedown in the value of its mining operations. The company's CEO, Lakshmi Mittal, said the industry faced a "very difficult year" in 2015 due to price falls and excess capacity in China.

site_title: Lower GDP growth in US reflecting weaker productivity
summary: US economic growth is expected to be around 2% this year, lower than previous expansions, due to easing productivity and uncertainty over innovation's impact. Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago president Charles Evans attributes this to a slowdown in global economic growth, particularly in emerging markets, and uncertainty about international prospects. Evans forecasts two more rate hikes this year and a gradual path of rate increases, citing a "shallow path" for policy normalization. He also notes that the US population is aging, leading to slower labor force growth, which limits the impact of monetary policy.

site_title: Temasek sees valuation concerns in Chinese technology industry
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investment company, expresses concerns over the valuation of China's technology industry, citing high expectations and valuations in pre-IPO rounds. The company is considering moving to earlier-stage investments as valuations increase for companies nearing initial public offerings. Temasek's China investments, including a 6% stake in China Construction Bank and a 1.98% stake in Alibaba, have contributed to the company's record S$266 billion portfolio, a 19% increase from the previous year.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on uncertainty over rate hikes
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday due to uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones fell 54.71 points, the S&P 500 lost 8.72 points, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 35.01 points. The uncertainty has weighed on market sentiment, causing stocks to fall despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Total says costs still unacceptably high in oil and gas
summary: Total's executive Arnaud Breuillac urged oil and gas companies to cut costs and work together to generate further savings, citing unacceptably high costs as a necessity to sustain businesses. Total has already cut operating costs by 1.5 billion euros and aims to cut 2.4 billion and 3 billion more in 2016 and 2017, respectively. The company plans to be patient on new project sanctions until oil prices recover, and will focus on delivering projects, operational excellence, and innovation to manage the downturn.

site_title: Eurozone lender sees end of Greek reforms review by end April, early May
summary: International lenders may conclude the review of Greek reforms by the end of April or early May, allowing for debt relief negotiations to start. Eurozone and IMF officials aim to reach an agreement on reforms by April 12, with talks on debt relief possible only after successful reforms review. The review has been delayed due to negotiations on politically difficult steps, such as pension reform and income tax reform, which the Greek government has struggled to implement.

site_title: US trade deficit widens in February, but exports rebounding
summary: The US trade deficit widened 2.6% in February to $47.1 billion, exceeding expectations, as exports rebounded 1.6% to $118.6 billion, the first increase since September. Imports rose 1.3% to $225.1 billion, driven by food imports and lower oil prices. The trade deficit, adjusted for inflation, reached $63.3 billion, the largest since March 2015. Despite the increase, economists suggest economic growth moderated in the first quarter, with estimates below a 1% pace.

site_title: IMF "indispensable" part of rescue programmes -ECB's Weidmann
summary: European Central Bank's Jens Weidmann stated the International Monetary Fund is a crucial part of eurozone countries' bailout programmes, describing it as "indispensable." This comes after an apparent IMF conference call transcript was leaked, sparking concerns about staff pulling out of Greece's rescue programme. Weidmann emphasized the ECB's insistence on the IMF's involvement in the programme, which is currently being negotiated.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: OSIM International's Chairman Ron Sim raised his offer to buy the remaining 30.75% stake in the company to S$1.39 a share, up from S$1.32 a share. Singapore's private sector saw improved operating conditions in March, driven by stronger domestic demand. Credit Suisse focused on organic growth in Asia, and Singapore ranked third among 50 'future-ready' cities. The STI closed lower on weak oil and Dow futures, finishing with a 34.43-point loss.

site_title: Cameron must explain family's tax arrangements, Corbyn says
summary: UK opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn calls on Prime Minister David Cameron to explain his family's tax arrangements after leaked documents from a Panama law firm revealed his late father's involvement in an offshore investment fund. Corbyn urges Cameron to crack down on tax evasion and avoidance in British overseas territories. Cameron's office denies the prime minister owns shares in any companies, but Corbyn suggests an independent investigation is needed to determine if tax is owed. The issue comes as the UK government hosts an anti-corruption summit in May.

site_title: Noble Group launches US$1b loan facility: sources
summary: Noble Group has launched a US$1 billion 364-day revolving credit facility with an interest margin of 225 basis points over LIBOR, nearly double the 85 basis points from last year's loan. The move comes after the company received a credit rating downgrade and aims to partially repay its debt maturing in May. Eight banks, including Societe Generale and HSBC, have mandated as lead arrangers for the loan, which will help Noble Group address its debt obligations.

site_title: Diamond and scroll break auction records in Hong Kong
summary: A rare 10.10 carat vivid blue diamond, the "De Beers Millennium Jewel 4", sold for HK$248.29 million (S$43.24 million) at Sotheby's in Hong Kong, breaking the record for the most expensive piece of jewelry sold at auction in Asia. The sale came hours after a scroll painting by Chinese master Zhang Daqian sold for a record-breaking HK$270.68 million. Despite a slowdown in China's economy, the sales suggest demand for top-quality collectibles remains strong in Asia.

site_title: OECD points to German investment deficiency as growth risk
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has warned that Germany's failure to boost investment, particularly in 'knowledge-based capital', poses a risk to its long-term economic growth. Despite low interest rates, the German government has prioritized maintaining a balanced budget over investing in areas such as intellectual property and management skills. The OECD urged Germany to reduce restrictive legislation and provide more support for municipal investment projects to strengthen productivity and competitiveness.

site_title: Oxley, Metro Global form JV to provide hospitality services
summary: Oxley Holdings Limited has formed a joint venture with Metro Global Pte Ltd to provide hospitality services through Metro Global Solutions Pte Ltd (MGSLP), equally owned by both companies. MGSLP will manage properties provided by or solicited by Oxley. This partnership aims to expand Oxley's offerings into hospitality services, complementing its existing property management capabilities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall despite mainland gains, energy stocks tumble
summary: Hong Kong's main stock index fell 1.6% to a one-month low on Tuesday, driven by a decline in the energy sector amidst slumping crude oil prices. The China Enterprises Index also dropped 1.9%. Despite this, mainland market indexes advanced to near three-month highs due to policy support. Oil giants like Sinopec, PetroChina, and CNOOC plummeted after oil prices fell 2% overnight, reaching one-month lows.

site_title: Swissco in proposed acquisition of marine group VM
summary: Swissco Holdings announced a proposed acquisition of the VM Group, comprising VM Marine International Ltd, VM Services Ltd, and Savannah International Offshore Ltd, from Melvin Rodrigues. Swissco's wholly owned subsidiary Swissco International Pte Ltd will acquire the VM Group, with the restructuring to be completed upon completion of the acquisition. No definitive agreements have been entered into. The acquisition is subject to further review and approval.

site_title: Painting by Chinese master fetches record US$35m in Hong Kong
summary: A painting by Chinese master Zhang Daqian, "Peach Blossom Spring," sold for nearly US$35 million at an auction in Hong Kong, more than tripling its expected price. The 1982 work, valued by Sotheby's Asia as "monumental," was bought by the Long Museum in Shanghai, founded by Chinese tycoon Liu Yiqian. The sale suggests strong demand for quality Chinese art despite a slowdown in the global art market, which saw a 7% decline in sales in 2015.

site_title: Update: OSIM shares halted after trading at final offer price
summary: OSIM International halted trading after reaching its final offer price of S$1.39 per share, including a two-cent dividend. The company's founder and CEO, Ron Sim, had sweetened his offer by seven Singapore cents before markets opened. The stock traded as high as S$1.37 before coming down to S$1.37, where it last traded. No explanation was given for the trading halt, with an announcement expected.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO defends bank over Panama Papers
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam defended the bank against accusations of tax avoidance and shady dealings in the Panama Papers leak. Thiam stated that Credit Suisse only endorses "legitimate" offshore arrangements and insists on knowing the beneficial owner of any offshore structure. He also said the bank would not engage in business with entities that fail to disclose this information. Thiam's comments come after HSBC also distanced itself from the revelations, with the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) set to release more information in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: The CEO of Credit Suisse said Tuesday the bank does not endorse offshore accounts for tax avoidance or shady dealings, the latest bank to defend itself against accusations made in the Panama Papers leak.

site_title: Japan Post, FamilyMart tie up in overseas delivery services
summary: Japan Post Holdings Co Ltd and FamilyMart Co Ltd have agreed to tie up in overseas delivery services, utilizing FamilyMart's convenience store network. FamilyMart will also increase the number of Japan Post Bank ATMs at its stores. This partnership aims to expand Japan Post's delivery services globally.

site_title: Top four Thai banks cut key lending rates in bid to aid growth
summary: Thailand's four major banks, including Bangkok Bank, Siam Commercial Bank, Kasikornbank, and Krung Thai Bank, have cut their key lending rates by 15-25 basis points in an effort to stimulate the country's flagging economy. The rate cuts aim to help smaller businesses and alleviate financial burdens on clients, particularly in the agricultural sector. The move is seen as a response to the Bank of Thailand's recent downgrade of its 2016 growth forecast and the impact of a severe drought on the economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Tuesday, closing at 1,718.08, down 7.16 points. The index saw 1.71 billion lots traded, with 364 gains and 453 losses.

site_title: China bank regulator says lenders should tighten overseas risk control
summary: China's banking regulator has instructed lenders to tighten risk controls in their overseas branches, following alleged compliance failings in China's top banks. The China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) emphasized the need for staff to clarify their responsibilities, strengthen risk judgment, and conduct adequate checks on clients. The move comes after investigations into money laundering in China's ICBC Madrid branch and alleged illicit earnings through Bank of China's Milan branch. The CBRC also urged lenders to strengthen internal control and compliance in their overseas branches and improve accountability.

site_title: NEC Asia Pacific appoints new CEO
summary: NEC Asia Pacific has appointed Tetsuro Akagi as its new CEO, effective April 1, 2016. Akagi, a 30-year NEC veteran, replaces Toshiya Matsuki, who has been promoted to executive vice-president of NEC Corporation and president of NEC Global Business Unit. Akagi will oversee business operations and expansions in the Asia-Pacific region to drive growth. He previously served as managing director of NEC Australia and will also hold senior positions at NEC Corporation.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on weak oil, slide in Dow futures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 34.43 points to 2,800.92, closing lower on weak oil prices and declining Dow futures. The STI was led by losses in banks and Singtel, with an advance-decline score of 137-266. Oil prices dropped 3% to around US$35 per barrel, and the US Federal Reserve's possible interest rate hike in June contributed to the market's weakness. Brokers expect heightened volatility to return after a four-five week calm period.

site_title: Indonesia will lower income tax rate for individuals: finance minister
summary: Indonesia's finance minister plans to lower income tax rates for individuals to make the tax system more competitive. Current rates range from 5 to 30%. The move aims to boost tax compliance, as only 27 million registered taxpayers exist despite a need for 120 million. No specific timeline or details on proposed changes were announced. The move follows efforts to address Indonesia's significant budget revenue shortfall this year.

site_title: German private-sector growth hits eight-month low in March: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector experienced its slowest growth in eight months in March, with the Markit PMI index falling to 54.0 from 54.1, according to a survey. Despite this, the overall business activity remained solid, driven by vibrant services. The reading, below the 50 mark that separates expansion from contraction, indicates Germany's economy remains robust, despite weaker demand from emerging markets.

site_title: Bank of England policymakers disagree on pace of capital rule tightening, eye EU vote
summary: Bank of England policymakers disagree on the pace of tightening capital requirements for banks, with some wanting to move faster to 1% buffer and others supporting 0.5% by 2017. The majority agreed to review again in June, when the EU referendum result will be known. The buffer aims to mitigate cyclical shocks, but its initial impact will be limited, particularly for larger banks. Policymakers also debated the balance between regulation and liquidity, with some seeking to ensure resilience while others prioritize trading. The decision will be reevaluated in June.

site_title: French business activity stagnates in March as services weaken: PMI
summary: France's private sector activity stagnated in March, with the services sector failing to break the 50-point threshold for expansion. The Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) for services rose to 49.9, while the overall PMI index rose to 50.0, indicating a slight improvement from the previous month. Despite another round of price-cutting, the services sector remained weak, particularly in hotels and restaurants, which have struggled since the November attacks. The stagnation contrasts with positive hard data on consumer spending and industrial output.

site_title: Eurozone business growth barely accelerated in March
summary: Eurozone business growth barely accelerated in March, increasing only 0.3% from the previous quarter, according to a survey. The Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) rose to 53.1 from 52.7, but fell short of expectations. Companies cut prices, with the output price index increasing to 48.6, and new business growth decelerated. The data is disappointing for European Central Bank policymakers, who had hoped for a boost in growth and inflation. The eurozone's inflation rate remains below 2%, and unemployment remains high at 10.3%.

site_title: Japan's Lawson aims to accelerate overseas presence: CEO
summary: Lawson Inc, a Japanese convenience store firm, aims to accelerate its overseas expansion and surpass its Japanese store count in 5-10 years. The company currently operates 761 stores abroad, mostly in China, and plans to consider acquisitions to boost its international footprint. Overseas operations started slow in 2010 but are expected to grow, with Asian countries and North America being key markets. Japan remains a crucial market for Lawson, with potential for growth in new niche categories.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks tumble as yen, oil prices weigh
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index plummeted 2.42% on Tuesday, its lowest level in over a month, as a strengthening yen and falling oil prices hit exporters and energy firms. The Nikkei 225 fell to 15,732.82, while the Topix index dropped 2.64%. The losses were attributed to a weakening yen and declining oil prices, which weighed on exporters and energy companies.

site_title: European equities steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened sharply lower on Tuesday, following another heavy sell-off in Asia sparked by a fresh plunge in oil prices. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.9%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices dropped 1.8% and 1.4%, respectively, due to weak economic data.

site_title: China announces restrictions on trade with North Korea
summary: China's Commerce Ministry has banned imports of North Korean gold and rare earths and exports of jet fuel and other oil products used to make rocket fuel, following new United Nations sanctions. The move aims to starve North Korea of funds for its nuclear and ballistic missile programs. This is in line with the Security Council's resolution, which expanded sanctions after North Korea conducted a fourth nuclear test and launched a long-range rocket in February. The ban is expected to significantly impact North Korea's mining sector, which is a key part of its economy.

images.alt_text: China's Commerce Ministry on Tuesday banned imports of North Korean gold and rare earths and exports to the country of jet fuel and other oil products used to make rocket fuel, a move in line with new United Nations sanctions on Pyongyang.

site_title: Schindler unloads Japanese business to Otis after accident
summary: Schindler, a Swiss-based elevator maker, is selling its Japanese business to Otis, a unit of United Technologies. The sale follows a 2006 accident that halted new installations in the country. Schindler plans to remain in Japan to fulfill legal and societal obligations related to ongoing cases. No financial terms were disclosed for the deal.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares slip as lower oil price hurts risk appetites
summary: The South Korean won and shares declined on Tuesday as global oil prices dropped, reducing investors' appetite for risky assets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index fell 0.8% to 1,962.74 points, its lowest close since March 9. The won fell 0.8% to 1,155.1 to the US dollar. The decline was attributed to the lower oil price, which diminished investor demand for riskier assets.

site_title: German factory orders decline in February
summary: German industrial orders declined 1.2% in February, down from a 0.5% increase in January, due to weaker foreign demand. Domestic demand edged up 0.9%, while foreign demand fell 2.7% from the eurozone and 2.1% from outside the single currency. This drop was attributed to weaker demand for German-made goods, both inside and outside the eurozone.

site_title: China: Stocks end near 3-month high on policy support
summary: Chinese stocks rose to a nearly three-month high on Tuesday, driven by government policy support and improving economic data. The CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.3% and 1.4%, respectively, closing at their highest levels since January 8. Beijing's measures include infrastructure investment, tax reforms, and debt-to-equity swaps to ease banks' troubled loan portfolios, boosting investor confidence. However, thin volumes suggest that confidence remains fragile.

images.alt_text: Chinese stocks rose on Tuesday to their highest in nearly three months, as a series of government measures and improving economic data revived investor appetite for riskier assets, but thin volumes indicated that confidence remained fragile.

site_title: India's central bank cuts key interest rate to 6.5%
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India, cut its key interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 6.5% on April 5, 2016, marking a five-year low. The benchmark repo rate was lowered from 6.75% to facilitate economic growth. The move was in line with market expectations, aiming to stimulate lending and boost economic activity.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi to meet China's foreign minister
summary: Myanmar's new Foreign Minister Aung San Suu Kyi will meet China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi in Naypyidaw, marking her first international diplomatic move since her party took power. The meeting aims to address border disputes, Beijing-backed mega-projects, and China's influence in Myanmar, where the country faces economic challenges. Suu Kyi has shown a pragmatic approach to dealing with Chinese interests, and the meeting is seen as an attempt to balance relations with its giant neighbor and largest trading partner.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's new foreign minister Aung San Suu Kyi will meet her Chinese counterpart in Naypyidaw Tuesday, an official said, in her first act of international diplomacy since her pro-democracy party took power.

site_title: Singapore appoints Russian cybersecurity expert to advisory panel
summary: Singapore has appointed Eugene Kaspersky, founder and CEO of Kaspersky Lab, to its International Advisory Panel for the National Cybersecurity Research and Development Programme. Kaspersky joins a panel that includes experts from the US, Israel, and Singapore, aiming to develop cybersecurity R&D capabilities to tackle emerging threats. The programme, valued at S$130 million, is crucial for Singapore's digital nation development, according to Kaspersky.

images.alt_text: Russian cybersecurity expert Eugene Kaspersky has been appointed to the International Advisory Panel for Singapore's National Cybersecurity Research and Development Programme.

site_title: Australia central bank holds rates at 2%
summary: Australia's central bank left its cash rate unchanged at a record low of 2% amid signs the economy is recovering from a mining downturn. The Reserve Bank of Australia made the announcement following its monthly policy meeting, with no expected move as predicted by analysts. This decision maintains low interest rates, supporting the economy's steady growth.

site_title: Singapore private sector posts improvement in operating conditions in March
summary: Singapore's private sector saw improved operating conditions in March, with the Nikkei Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 52, its fastest pace in a year. Stronger domestic demand boosted new order growth, but new export orders fell for the first time in five months. The rate of improvement remained modest, with employment and purchasing activity falling slightly. Experts expect the recently announced budget to boost demand and growth momentum in the second quarter, but overall growth remains relatively lacklustre.

images.alt_text: Business conditions in Singapore further improved in March, as stronger domestic demand boosted new order growth to its fastest pace in a year.

site_title: Yen heads to 18-month high aganst US dollar
summary: The yen reached an 18-month high against the US dollar, trading at 110.84 yen, amid investor concerns over the US equity market sell-off and fading expectations of a near-term interest rate hike. The euro also weakened, while the South Korean won was hardest hit, shedding 0.81% against the greenback. Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated the central bank's inability to reboot Japan's economy alone, urging government reforms. The yen's strength is attributed to uncertainty, global economic fears, and lower commodity prices.

site_title: MPA to grant 10% concession on port dues for bulk carriers from April 15
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) will grant a 10% concession on port dues for bulk carriers starting April 15, 2016, due to the current shipping industry downturn. The concession applies to bulk carriers with a port stay of not more than five days and will last for one year. This move aims to yield S$18 million in savings for shipping companies over a year, on top of existing concessions such as the Green Port Programme incentives.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Update: India cuts interest rate to lowest since 2011, but raises reverse repo
summary: The Reserve Bank of India cut its policy interest rate by a quarter percentage point to 6.50%, the lowest since 2011, in an effort to control inflation. The move aims to stimulate economic growth and encourage investment. However, the RBI also raised the reverse repo rate by 25 basis points, a surprise move. The central bank's priority remains controlling inflation, but the decision may help improve business conditions for industrialists. The RBI has pledged to continue monitoring macroeconomic developments and may consider further policy action if necessary.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde says risks to weak global recovery are increasing
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warns of growing risks to the global recovery, citing China's slowdown, lower commodity prices, and potential financial tightening. Frustration with inequality is fueling protectionism, echoing populist candidates in the US presidential election. Lagarde cautions against protectionist forces, noting the perception that elites hold power over common people. The global economy's outlook has dimmed, with the expected transition of growth from emerging to advanced economies not occurring as expected.

site_title: Fed's Evans repeats call for 'shallow' US rate hikes
summary: US Federal Reserve policymaker Charles Evans reiterated his call for two interest-rate hikes this year, stating that a "shallow funds rate path" is appropriate to mitigate economic growth risks. This stance aligns with the FOMC's March median forecast, despite concerns about slowing economic growth in China. Evans' comments, made in Hong Kong, are similar to those he made last week in New York, and do not influence monetary policy this year.

site_title: AccorHotels buys luxury home rentals company onefinestay
summary: AccorHotels, Europe's largest hotel group, acquired British luxury home rentals company onefinestay for 148 million euros, aiming to combat the rise of online home-sharing platforms like Airbnb. onefinestay has a portfolio of 2,600 properties in four cities. The acquisition, part of AccorHotels' reorganization efforts, also includes a 64 million euro investment to grow the company worldwide. The deal will help AccorHotels expand its presence in high-end serviced accommodations.

site_title: Coffee wars: South Korea's cafe boom nears saturation point
summary: South Korea's coffee shop market is experiencing saturation, with nearly every building in fashionable districts boasting a coffee shop. The number of coffee shops has more than tripled to 49,600 in 2015, outpacing overall coffee consumption. Chains like Starbucks and local players are competing aggressively, with some cutting prices and others focusing on quality and expansion abroad. The market is becoming increasingly crowded, with convenience stores like 7-Eleven offering affordable cups, leading to financial struggles for smaller chains.

site_title: Top China bankers' salaries halved in 2015 after state sector pay reforms
summary: China's top bankers saw their 2015 compensation slashed by 50% due to state sector pay reforms implemented in 2015. The reforms aimed to curb misuse of non-salary benefits and hold managers responsible for firm performance. Top executives, including ICBC's Jiang Jianqing and UBS' Sergio Ermotti, saw their pay reduced to 0.3% of their US counterparts' total compensation. The move was partly due to China's weak economy and shrinking profits, with interest margins and non-performing loans at a 10-year high. The reforms are part of the government's state-owned enterprise reform efforts.

site_title: France PM warns extreme Islam winning the propaganda war
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls warns that extreme forms of Islam are winning the propaganda war in France, citing the Salafists' influence on social networks. He pledges to increase security and defense budgets, following deadly attacks in 2015 and 2016. Valls criticizes the use of the headscarf as a challenge to France's secular society, saying it represents the "enslavement of women." France bans the Muslim face veil in public, and Valls seeks to distinguish between wearing the veil as a fashion statement and as a political gesture.

site_title: Peugeot pledges sales drive in new mid-term plan
summary: Peugeot has outlined a mid-term plan to drive sales growth, aiming to introduce a new vehicle each year for each of its three brands and increase revenue by 10% by 2018 and 15% by 2021. The company, which has recovered from near-bankruptcy, plans to expand its product and technology offerings, including 11 hybrids or all-electric cars, and increase production in Southeast Asia. Peugeot also aims to find a manufacturing partner in India and reduce costs per vehicle to 700 euros. The plan builds on a two-year turnaround that brought the company to its highest profitability in 14 years.

site_title: Facebook tests tech to help blind people enjoy photos
summary: Facebook has begun testing a new artificial intelligence technology to help blind people enjoy photos on the platform. The technology uses machine learning to recognize objects in pictures and describe them aloud. The feature, being tested on mobile devices, aims to provide visually impaired users with a similar experience to others on Facebook. The technology, developed by Facebook's accessibility specialist, has made its debut after Microsoft's Cortana Intelligence Suite was announced. The feature will be expanded to devices with other operating systems and more languages, with the goal of providing a similar experience to others on the platform.

site_title: Thai central bank expects more commercial banks to cut rates
summary: Thai's central bank expects more commercial banks to cut interest rates following Siam Commercial Bank and Kasikornbank's rate reductions. The move aims to support small and medium enterprises and align with the central bank's easy monetary policy. Assistant Deputy Governor Jaturong Jantarangs stated that the rate cuts are in line with the bank's goals.

site_title: Malaysia most-improved in bond risk as oil rises, 1MDB cuts debt
summary: Malaysia's bond risk decreased the most among investment-grade nations in six months, driven by a rally in oil prices and a state-investment company's debt reduction efforts. The country's credit-default swaps dropped 80 basis points to 153 basis points, unwinding a surge of 98 basis points in the previous six months. The government's plan to repay short-term debt and boost foreign-exchange reserves has alleviated market concerns, but analysts remain cautious due to ongoing corruption scandals and potential political risks.

site_title: China state planner sees consumer, property prices rising in 2016
summary: China's state planner expects consumer prices to rise modestly in 2016, while property prices in major cities like Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen may also increase. The National Development and Reform Commission aims to keep annual consumer inflation at around 3% to reflect rising labor costs and price fluctuations. Producer prices are expected to continue their downward trend, and the Chinese yuan may face slight depreciation pressures due to a strengthening US dollar. Wage rises are expected to slow as the economy slows, and job opportunities may decrease due to overcapacity and automation.

site_title: Two Vietnamese women contract Zika virus, first in Vietnam: Government
summary: Vietnam reported its first two cases of Zika virus infections, both women in stable condition, in late March. A 64-year-old woman in Nha Trang and a 33-year-old woman in Ho Chi Minh City tested positive after three rounds of tests. No further infections have been found among their relatives and neighbors, according to the Health Ministry.

site_title: Seven long weekends for 2017, up from six in 2016
summary: Singapore to have seven long weekends in 2017, up from six in 2016, with 11 gazetted public holidays. The Ministry of Manpower released the list, which includes the additional long weekend on Labour Day.

site_title: Philippine central bank sees no urgent need to change policy
summary: The Philippine central bank's governor, Amando Tetangco, stated that there is no urgent need to change monetary policy, following March's inflation rate of 1.1%, which matched expectations. The central bank expects inflation in 2016 to be near the low end of the 2-4% target range, indicating a slow move towards the target.

site_title: Australia's booming education sector lures investors, boon to economy
summary: Australia's student housing market is booming, attracting investors and driving a home building boom. The country's proximity to Asia and enviable quality of life make it a top destination for foreign students, with numbers increasing by 10% in 2015. However, a lack of supply has led to overcrowding and exploitation, prompting investors to step in. Goldman Sachs and Blue Sky are launching A$1 billion funds to invest in the sector, aiming to provide up to 10,000 student beds by 2019.

site_title: Indonesian group to control Newmont Mining unit
summary: An Indonesian group, led by businessman Arifin Panigoro, is set to buy a controlling stake in Newmont Mining Corp's local operations in Indonesia. The deal, expected to be announced this week, has been approved by Indonesian President Joko Widodo as it is in the national interest. The deal will control Newmont Nusa Tenggara, which operates the second-biggest copper mine in Indonesia, the Batu Hijau mine. Details of the deal, including the size of the investment, were not disclosed.

site_title: A conversation with Panama's suddenly notorious offshore lawyers
summary: Panama's notorious offshore lawyers, Jurgen Mossack and Ramon Fonseca, discussed their firm's decline in a four-hour interview. They acknowledged the end of their lucrative shell company business and considered scaling back international franchising. Mossack expressed frustration with Fonseca's political ambitions, which drew unwanted scrutiny from regulators and the media. The duo's firm, Mossack Fonseca, played a critical role in helping global leaders move money offshore, according to recent reports. Their partnership has begun to fray, and their business is in retreat.

site_title: HNA to buy Tysan stake for HK$2.62m, adding construction
summary: Chinese conglomerate HNA Group Co agreed to buy a 66% stake in Tysan Holdings Ltd for about US$340 million, with a price of HK$4.53 per share. The deal expands HNA's presence in construction and property development. Tysan's shares jumped to a 25-year high following the announcement. Trading was suspended on April 1, and the acquisition is expected to further strengthen HNA's position in the industry.

site_title: US judge approves BP settlement for 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill
summary: US Judge Carl Barbier approved a settlement for BP's 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, with the company agreeing to pay up to $18.7 billion in penalties. The settlement includes $12.8 billion for Clean Water Act fines and natural resource damages, and $4.9 billion to states, with payouts to be staggered over 18 years. The settlement, reached in 2015, holds BP accountable for the largest environmental penalty of all time and marks one of the most extensive environmental restoration efforts ever undertaken.

images.alt_text: US Judge Carl Barbier granted final approval on Monday to BP Plc's civil settlement over its 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill after it reached a deal in July 2015 to pay up to US$18.7 billion in penalties to the US government and five states.

site_title: South Korean won falls sharply after global oil price drop
summary: The South Korean won fell sharply against the dollar on Tuesday, dropping 1.0% to 1,158.5 per dollar, amid global risk-off sentiment triggered by a decline in oil prices. This move was part of a broader trend of currency volatility.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit one-month low, NZ retreats from record high
summary: Australian shares fell 1.6% to a one-month low, led by Nine Entertainment's revenue warning. New Zealand stocks touched a record high before retreating 0.5%. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 4,916.4, while the S&P/NZX 50 index closed at 6,709.8.

site_title: Wisconsin up for grabs as Trump, Clinton seek upsets
summary: US presidential primary candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are competing in the Wisconsin primary, with Trump seen as an underdog against Senator Ted Cruz. Trump's recent controversies have alienated women voters, prompting his wife Melania to boost his flagging support. The winner of the Republican primary will claim 42 delegates, potentially altering the nomination race. Meanwhile, Clinton leads Bernie Sanders in New York and Pennsylvania, and Sanders is seen as a dark horse candidate despite his low delegate count.

images.alt_text: Wisconsin takes center stage Tuesday, when the Midwestern state votes in the US presidential primary race, with Republican frontrunner Donald Trump and top Democrat Hillary Clinton seen as underdogs against their never-give-up rivals.

site_title: Oil prices extend losses as output freeze hopes fade
summary: Oil prices declined further in Asia as hopes of a production freeze by key producers faded. The April 17 Doha meeting aims to cap output at January 2016 levels, but Saudi Arabia's reluctance to agree to limits unless Iran joins has reduced market expectations. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 15 cents to $35.55, and Brent crude declined nine cents to $37.60. Analysts say a sustained recovery in oil prices would require cuts in global supply and increases in demand, rather than just a freeze.

images.alt_text: Oil prices tumbled further in Asia Tuesday on dwindling hopes that key producers will reach an agreement to freeze output when they meet this month to discuss a global supply glut.

site_title: China limits coverage and denounces Panama Papers' tax haven revelations
summary: China has limited coverage of the Panama Papers, a massive leak of documents revealing financial wrongdoing by wealthy individuals, including those close to Chinese President Xi Jinping. The leak, published by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, linked offshore companies to the families of Xi Jinping and other powerful Chinese leaders. China has blocked certain search terms and removed related stories online, sparking international criticism. The move has raised concerns about China's efforts to suppress information about its own leaders and potential financial dealings.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks began the week on a low note, falling 0.91% and 0.29% respectively. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 20,311.86, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell to 3,000.94. This decline follows a negative lead from Wall Street and despite a strong US jobs report at the end of last week.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda, with eye on economy and markets, says ready to ease more
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated his readiness to expand monetary policy further, citing market moves as key factors in deciding when and how to ease stimulus. Despite a moderate economy recovery, Japan's business sentiment worsened, and inflation remains stagnant at 2% target. Kuroda emphasized the BOJ's willingness to take action, including negative interest rates, asset purchases, or deeper rate cuts, to accelerate inflation. The BOJ will evaluate economic, price, and market developments before making any decisions.

site_title: Thai March consumer sentiment at 5-month low: survey
summary: Thai consumer confidence fell to a 5-month low in March, according to a university survey, due to a severe drought affecting the farm sector and concerns over the global economy. The central bank lowered its 2016 growth forecast to 3.1% from 3.5%, exacerbating consumer concerns. Consumers expressed worry over the cost of living, with the drought's impact worsening. This marks the lowest sentiment level in 5 months.

site_title: Singapore's top three banks face increasing challenges at home and abroad: Moody's
summary: Singapore's top three banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, face increasing challenges at home and abroad, according to Moody's Investors Service. The ratings agency changed the outlook on the banks to negative, citing weakening growth momentum and corporate financial conditions in Singapore, as well as slower economic and trade growth abroad. Moody's affirmed the banks' deposit ratings and senior debt at Aa1, but noted rising pressure on asset quality and profitability due to higher loan delinquency rates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 7.04 points lower on Tuesday, closing at 1719. The market saw a higher volume of 44.1 million lots worth RM23.9 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 82 to 68.

site_title: Abe seen facing 6t yen pension fund loss after Japan vote
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) is expected to announce its worst annual loss since the global financial crisis, with a potential decline of up to 6 trillion yen (S$73 billion), due to the decline in stocks. The fund's review of its investment strategy, under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics package, has led to a significant shift towards equities. The announcement, typically made in July, will be delayed until after a summer election, as part of Abe's strategy to keep bad news before the election.

site_title: Credit Suisse 'primarily focused on organic growth' in Asia
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam stated the bank is primarily focused on organic growth in Asia, prioritizing cost-effective and less risky methods. Thiam also mentioned the bank is acquiring relationship managers from smaller outfits, taking a "countercyclical" approach. Despite Western banks shedding Asian private banking assets, Thiam remains confident in Asia and plans to tap into emerging wealth in the region.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks fall as oil price dip sparks risk-off sentiment
summary: The South Korean won dropped 1.0% to 1,158.5 against the dollar, and the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.7% to 1,964.50 points, its lowest in a month. The decline was attributed to sliding oil prices, sparking risk-off sentiment. Foreign investors were net sellers, selling 123.9 billion won worth of KOSPI shares. Analysts expect the index to post the biggest daily percentage loss since early February, but may recover if oil prices calm down, potentially reclaiming the 2,000 level.

site_title: Honeywell CEO Dave Cote could retire as soon as next year: WSJ
summary: Honeywell International Inc CEO Dave Cote could retire as soon as next year, according to a Wall Street Journal report. Cote has been the CEO for 14 years. The company named Darius Adamczyk as its first president and chief operating officer, a newly created role seen as a step toward designating a successor to Cote.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on stronger yen, lower oil
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Tuesday due to a stronger yen and falling oil prices. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.49% to 16,044.03, while the Topix index fell 0.58% to 1,295.21. The yen's strength dented exporters, while lower oil prices hung over the market.

site_title: Oil extends decline as US crude supplies seen expanding glut
summary: Oil prices declined for a third consecutive day, falling 1.2% in New York, amid concerns over increasing US crude stockpiles. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 2.85 million barrel increase in inventories last week, the highest level in over eight decades. Oil-producing countries are discussing a potential deal to freeze output, but Saudi Arabia's deputy crown prince said Iran must also cap production. This has stalled oil's rebound from a 12-year low, with West Texas Intermediate falling to $35.27 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil extended declines for a third day before US government data forecast to show increasing crude stockpiles kept supplies at the highest level in more than eight decades.

site_title: Aussie falls second day on prospects RBA to say rally a concern
summary: The Australian dollar dropped 0.4% to 75.75 US cents, its second consecutive decline, amid speculation that Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Governor Glenn Stevens may signal that the currency's recent rally is a concern. The currency's recent surge to a nine-month high is seen as overvalued, with Commonwealth Bank estimating it is now strong enough to worry the central bank. The RBA is expected to keep interest rates at a record-low 2% and Stevens' comments on the currency will be closely watched.

site_title: Philippine March headline inflation rises to 1.1%
summary: Philippine inflation rose 1.1% in March, matching analysts' and the central bank's expectations. Core inflation remained steady at 1.5%, while consumer prices increased 0.1% from the previous month. The central bank aims for a 2-4% inflation target for 2016 and 2017. This inflation rate is within the bank's forecast range of 0.6-1.4% for March.

site_title: Singapore ranked third among 50 'future-ready' cities
summary: Singapore has been ranked third among 50 'future-ready' cities globally, behind San Jose and San Francisco, according to a Dell ranking. The city's high ranking is attributed to its skilled workforce, infrastructure, and opportunities for innovation, growth, and profitability. London and Washington DC ranked fourth and fifth, respectively. Singapore's strong economic performance and ability to attract talent have contributed to its high ranking, with the city's government recognizing the importance of innovation and digital age transformation.

site_title: UK's Farage says Dutch "No" would boost Brexit support
summary: UKIP leader Nigel Farage says a Dutch "No" vote in the EU treaty referendum would boost Brexit support, citing a symbolic victory against European integration. A Dutch vote against the treaty would embolden British voters who believe they're alone in Europe in holding eurosceptic views, Farage said. The UK referendum on quitting the EU is less than three months away.

site_title: BOJ newcomer Sakurai warns against frequent policy change
summary: Bank of Japan board member Makoto Sakurai warned against frequent policy changes, advising the central bank to act boldly when major risks threaten Japan's economic fundamentals. Sakurai, a former think tank executive, joined the BOJ's nine-member board on Friday, succeeding economist Sayuri Shirai. His comments came as Japan's economy faces challenges.

site_title: Rickmers Trust manager says not aware of reason for trading surge
summary: Rickmers Trust Management stated it was unaware of the reason behind a 38.6% surge in its unit trading on Monday, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange. The surge was the second most active trading on the exchange, with 105 million units changing hands. The units closed at 11.3 Singapore cents, still up 36.1% from the previous day's close.

images.alt_text: Rickmers Trust Management said on Tuesday morning it was not aware of the reason behind the surge in trading of its units on Monday, which prompted a query from Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Japan Aso: To front-load FY2016 public works spending to spur growth
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso announced plans to front-load FY2016 public works spending to spur economic growth. The government aims to sign contracts for 80% of public works spending during the first half of the year, as instructed by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. This move is part of efforts to stimulate the flagging economy.

site_title: China Inc's record foreign deal spree shows fear of weaker yuan
summary: China Inc is on a record foreign deal spree, with the value of offshore acquisitions reaching $97.4 billion this year, driven by concerns over a weakening yuan. Strategists forecast the yuan will decline 3.3% to 6.7% by year-end, and China's firms are taking advantage of the opportunity to diversify assets abroad. The government is encouraging foreign dealmaking to win know-how and global market share, but authorities are struggling to stem capital outflows while allowing businesses to become world-class. This trend is expected to continue, with assets being cheap abroad and borrowing costs low globally.

site_title: Hot stock: OSIM shares up after founder raises offer
summary: OSIM International shares rose 3% at the opening bell on April 5, 2016, after chairman and CEO Ron Sim increased his privatization offer from S$1.32 to S$1.39 per share. The counter reached S$1.40 before trading at S$1.395. The offer, now at S$1.39, will close on April 17.

images.alt_text: Shares for OSIM International gained 3 per cent at the opening bell on Tuesday, after its chairman and CEO Ron Sim raised his privatisation offer for the firm before the market opened.

site_title: US does not plan to grant Iran access to US financial system
summary: The US government announced it will not grant Iran access to the US financial system, according to a State Department spokesman. President Barack Obama stated that the US is not looking to permit dollar-denominated transactions with Iran and foreign companies can work through European banks. This decision aims to limit Iran's access to the global financial system.

site_title: Icelanders protest in their thousands as PM snubs calls to quit
summary: Thousands of Icelanders protested in Reykjavik against Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson, who is accused of benefiting from offshore investment accounts in tax havens. The opposition party, Pirate Party, has called for a motion of no confidence and a vote of no confidence, which may take place on Thursday. Gunnlaugsson has refused to resign, urging parliament to approach the matter "calmly and honestly." The protests, which drew over 4,000 people, are part of a growing movement to hold the government accountable for its actions.

site_title: Clinton, Sanders agree to a April 14 debate
summary: US Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have agreed to a debate on April 14, five days before the New York primary. The debate will be held in Brooklyn, New York, and will be carried by CNN and NY1. Sanders' campaign confirmed his acceptance of the debate invitation. This marks a significant development in the Democratic primary race, with the New York primary being a crucial test of support for both candidates.

site_title: White House race offers rare cable news ratings surge
summary: The 2016 US presidential campaign has generated record cable news audiences, with Fox News, CNN, and MSNBC experiencing significant viewership increases. The surge is largely attributed to Donald Trump's divisive rhetoric and controversies. However, experts warn that the increased viewership may be short-lived, as the campaign's focus shifts to governance after the election. The cable news channels' struggles to adapt to changing viewer habits, particularly among younger audiences, are also a concern, with social media platforms and the internet becoming increasingly popular sources of news.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.86% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.86% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index dropping 24.32 points to 2,811.03. The decline was attributed to mixed US monetary policy directions and slumping oil prices, which had fallen to one-month lows. Oil-related counters, including Noble Group, Ezra Holdings, and Keppel Corp, were among the most heavily traded stocks to fall.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OSIM, SPH Reit, Frasers Centrepoint Limited, GLP
summary: OSIM International raised its offer for shares to S$1.39 per share, a 38.8% premium, with the offer closing on April 25. SPH Reit announced a 1.4 Singapore cent distribution per unit for the second quarter, with gross revenue growing 1.2% to S$53.09 million. Frasers Centrepoint Limited sold a fully occupied office building in Australia for A$46.8 million. Global Logistic Properties successfully completed a syndication of a 65.55% stake in US industrial assets for US$1.3 billion in cash.

site_title: GLP completes syndication of US industrial assets
summary: GLOBAL Logistic Properties (GLP) has completed the syndication of a 65.66% stake in its US industrial assets, selling them for $1.3 billion in cash. The assets will transition from subsidiaries to associated companies, marking the end of GLP's ownership. This move was part of the firm's planned syndication strategy, allowing for greater investor access and diversification.

site_title: Siemens approaches Emerson to buy network power unit
summary: Siemens AG has approached Emerson Electric Co to acquire its network power business for up to $4 billion, allowing Emerson to focus on its core industrial automation and heating and air conditioning divisions. Emerson is in early-stage conversations with Siemens about divesting the business, which makes power systems for data centers. The potential deal would enable Emerson to shed a non-core business and streamline its operations.

site_title: United Airlines offers ground workers 30% raise over five years
summary: United Airlines reached collective-bargaining deals with almost 30,000 employees, offering a 30% raise over five years.
