site_title: Singapore ranks high in OECD report on fake goods
summary: Singapore ranks third globally in the production of counterfeit goods, with 3.3% of the world's fake goods seized worldwide in recent years, according to an OECD report. Despite this, the country is not considered a major producer of counterfeit products, with the bulk of its exports consisting of genuine goods. The OECD estimates the global market for fake goods is worth $461 billion, with China accounting for 63.2% of the world's fake goods.

site_title: Emirates puts pinch on BA with 10th daily London trip
summary: Emirates, the world's largest international airline, will add a 10th daily London flight in October, increasing capacity to 4,600 seats daily and 70 weekly flights. The new service will operate from Gatwick, complementing its existing six flights at London Heathrow. The move strengthens Emirates' challenge to British Airways, which operates 76 flights from Heathrow, Gatwick, and London City to New York. The high-frequency operation from London will increase passengers bound for Asia, the Middle East, and Africa through Dubai, further siphoning off British Airways' long-haul market.

site_title: Charting a course for success
summary: Mitsui OSK Lines, a 132-year-old Japanese shipping giant, is diversifying its operations in a challenging business environment under the leadership of President and CEO Junichiro Ikeda. The company has been hit hard by a decline in oil prices and fleet over-supply, prompting Ikeda to urge his colleagues to aspire towards excellence and resilience. To address this, MOL has downsized its bulkships and containerships operations, recording an extraordinary loss of 179.3 billion yen in the fiscal year. However, the company is bullish on its LNG carrier segment, which has secured long-term contracts guaranteeing stable income. MOL aims to expand its revenue streams beyond traditional bulkships and containerships, with a focus on geographic diversification and reducing its environmental footprint through ship bunkering.

site_title: Hong Kong main index falls the most in 5 weeks after S&P downgrade
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index plummeted 1.3% to 20,498.92 on Friday, its largest one-day loss in five weeks, following Standard & Poor's downgrade of China and Hong Kong's sovereign credit rating outlook to negative. The China Enterprises Index also fell 1.8% on Friday, marking its biggest decline in five weeks. The downgrade led to a decline across the board, with the energy sector being the biggest decliner.

site_title: Airbus profit slides as engine glitch, cabin delays crimp output
summary: Airbus reported a 23% decline in first-quarter earnings to 501 million euros due to engine issues with its A320neo and cabin equipment shortages affecting A350 deliveries. The A400M transport plane is also experiencing production issues. Despite the setbacks, CEO Tom Enders expects stable financial performance and on-track delivery of 650 aircraft this year. Airbus plans to accelerate A320neo production and bring forward delivery of some older A320 models to fill gaps. Net income fell to 399 million euros from 792 million euros in 2014.

site_title: French manufacturing activity slows in March as orders drop: PMI
summary: French manufacturing activity slowed in March, with the purchasing managers' index falling to 49.6 from 50.2 in February, marking the first time below the 50-point line since last August. Output improved slightly, but new orders dropped at the sharpest pace since August as companies cut prices to hold on to market share. Manufacturers also shed jobs at the fastest pace since 2014, suggesting the sector's struggles will continue.

site_title: Cambodian passenger train back on track after years-long hiatus
summary: Cambodia's passenger train resumed a regular weekend service after a years-long hiatus, with Prime Minister Hun Sen inaugurating the first trip. The nearly 270-kilometre route, which passes through farmland and follows part of the country's scenic coast, will run once a day in either direction from Friday through Sunday. The train service was suspended due to decades of war and neglect, but the country's peace has allowed for its rebuilding. The resumption marks a significant step in revitalizing the country's transport infrastructure.

site_title: Jaya enters into term sheet in S$237.6m proposed acquisition
summary: Jaya Holdings has entered into a non-binding term sheet for the proposed acquisition of Heduru Moni for approximately S$237.6 million. The initial consideration of S$178.2 million will be paid through the issuance of new shares, with an earn-out consideration of up to S$59.4 million subject to future performance. Heduru Moni, a micro-lender in Papua New Guinea, has a historical net profit of S$11.7 million and S$19.9 million in FY2015 and FY2015, respectively. The acquisition aims to leverage Heduru Moni's ability to grant loan approvals within 24 hours.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower; STI hit by triple whammy, down for fifth straight day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore fell 12.42 points to 2,862.30, marking its fifth consecutive loss, despite a 0.4% gain on Thursday. The decline was attributed to a triple whammy from the US Federal Reserve keeping interest rates unchanged, the Bank of Japan's decision not to expand monetary stimulus, and a 2.6% drop in oil prices, which led to a 3.6% decline in the Nikkei 225.

site_title: Airbus's 957b-euro order book doesn't guarantee success: Gadfly commentary
summary: Airbus's first-quarter earnings slumped by half due to production problems with the A320neo, A350, and A400M aircraft. The company has a massive order book of 957 billion euros, but delivery issues hinder its success. Despite its significant backlog, Airbus's earnings per share declined amid production delays and quality issues. The struggle highlights the complexity and challenges of manufacturing commercial and military aircraft, which can be time-consuming and costly. Airbus's future success depends on overcoming these production hurdles.

site_title: Satellite data latest tool in Indonesia's fight against illegal fishing
summary: Indonesia has signed an agreement with Silicon Valley tech firm Spire Global to use miniature satellites to track and pinpoint the location of illegal fishing vessels in its waters. The deal allows Indonesia to monitor its vast territory, including in the South China Sea, where clashes with Chinese vessels occurred last month. The satellites can detect and track ships, providing authorities with real-time data to respond to suspicious vessels. This upgrade is part of Indonesia's efforts to combat illegal fishing, which costs the country billions of dollars in lost revenue each year.

site_title: MCT's Q4 DPU up 1%
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 1% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.02 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended March 31, with net property income rising 3.5% to S$55 million. Despite weak retail sentiments and office market, the Reit manager attributed steady results to active asset management and cost management. Gross revenue increased 1.9% to S$287.8 million, while property operating expenses declined 5.3% to S$67 million. The portfolio occupancy rate inched up to 96.6% as of March 31.

site_title: Fed meets on interest rates but markets eye June decision
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at its two-day meeting, citing weak inflation and uncertainty surrounding the Brexit vote. The economy grew at a 0.9% pace in the first quarter, down from 1.4% in 2015, and the industrial sector remains weak. Markets are focused on the June decision, with economists predicting a potential rate hike if data and market developments support it. The Fed has emphasized financial stability, particularly in light of global market turbulence, and Chair Janet Yellen's dovish stance has given the committee room to wait and see what happens in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Weak inflation and the prospect of more financial turmoil ahead of Britain's Brexit vote are expected to keep US monetary policy on hold Wednesday when the Federal Reserve wraps up a two-day meeting.

site_title: Lufthansa cancels nearly 900 flights due to German union strike
summary: Lufthansa has cancelled nearly 900 flights due to German union Verdi's airport strikes planned for Wednesday. The airline's overall 1,500 flights to and from German airports, including Frankfurt and Munich, will operate at only 40% capacity.

site_title: Teh Hooi Ling takes over as new AWARE president
summary: Teh Hooi Ling has taken over as president of the Association of Women for Action and Research (AWARE) for 2016-2018, succeeding Winifred Loh. The AWARE board includes Louise Tagliante as first vice-president, Ranjana Raghunathan as second vice-president, and other members.

images.alt_text: AGGREGATE Asset Management partner Teh Hooi Ling is the Association of Women for Action and Research's (AWARE) new president.

site_title: Market stuck in a losing streak
summary: Singapore's stock market ended the month on a losing note, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.7% to 2,874.72, marking its fourth consecutive decline. The market's trajectory over the next month will depend on the US dollar's movements, with analysts predicting a potential downturn if the US Federal Reserve becomes more hawkish. Despite this, the market remains buoyant, with DBS Group Research pegging a range of 2800-2965 for the STI until end-May, citing a "cautious and data-dependent" approach from the Fed.

site_title: New raid on Panama Papers law firm: report
summary: Panamanian authorities conducted a raid on a storage property linked to Mossack Fonseca, the law firm at the center of the Panama Papers scandal. Prosecutors are investigating organized crime, according to La Prensa newspaper. The raid, confirmed by the public ministry, is ongoing but details are not available. This move comes as authorities continue to scrutinize the firm's role in the scandal, which exposed widespread tax evasion and money laundering.

images.alt_text: Panamanian authorities launched a new raid Friday on an address linked to the law firm at the heart of the Panama Papers scandal, local media reported.

site_title: Impact of South China Sea tensions 'limited'
summary: Credit Suisse has stated that geopolitical tensions in the South China Sea are unlikely to have a major impact on investment decisions or performance. According to Chief Investment Officer John Woods, few events have lasting effects on markets, and investors should not be overly concerned about the ongoing contest of sovereignty claims.

site_title: Ascott buys into London property via joint fund with Qatar
summary: The Ascott, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has invested £52 million (S$100.4 million) in a 108-unit property in Islington, London through a joint fund with Qatar Investment Authority. This is the third investment by the £600 million fund, which focuses on Asia Pacific and Europe. The purchase marks the latest move by the fund to expand its presence in the European serviced residence market.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Trek 2000's auditors lodge Acra report over documentation deficiencies
summary: Trek 2000 International's auditors, Ernst & Young, have submitted a report to the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) regarding documentation deficiencies in the company's financial statements for the year ended Dec 31, 2015. Trek 2000 is addressing the queries and has converted its trading halt into a voluntary suspension. The company has not specified the nature of the deficiencies or the potential impact on its financials.

site_title: VW hikes provisions for emissions scandal to 10-20b euros: sources
summary: Volkswagen is increasing its provisions to cover the emissions scandal to 10-20 billion euros, up from 6.7 billion euros, according to sources. The increased amount includes compensation for customers, vehicle repairs, and a possible fine by the US Department of Justice. The figure will be spread out over two years and may exceed 20 billion euros but is unlikely to be significantly above that amount.

site_title: China's yuan opens slightly weaker on broad US dollar strength
summary: China's yuan opened slightly weaker, hitting its lowest level in nearly a month, due to the US dollar's broad strength. The yuan opened at 6.5051 per US dollar, down 0.3% from the previous midpoint rate, and reached an intraday low of 6.5100. This follows the US dollar's 0.5% gain last Friday and its holding of strength in early Asian trade.

site_title: Philly soul singer Billy Paul dies
summary: Billy Paul, a renowned Philadelphia soul singer, has died at 80. Known for his uplifting voice and hit song "Me and Mrs Jones," Paul was a Grammy Award winner who helped shape modern R&B. He faced controversy with his racially charged politics, particularly with the release of "Am I Black Enough For You?", which was initially met with commercial failure. However, decades later, the song gained popularity among white audiences, with Paul later stating it had become a black cultural icon, and was praised by artists like Questlove as a forerunner of soul icons Stevie Wonder and Marvin Gaye.

site_title: Elite homeowners in Paris seek end to pain with Socialist loss
summary: Elite Parisian homeowners are optimistic about the prospect of a new right-wing president in 2017, who may ease taxes on the wealthy and abolish the wealth tax. The tax, introduced by Socialist President Francois Hollande, has led to a decline in luxury property prices, with homes valued over 2 million euros losing 3.7% in the past six months. Potential candidates, including Nicolas Sarkozy and Francois Fillon, have pledged to abolish the wealth tax, boosting demand for luxury homes and fueling a modest recovery in the Paris market.

site_title: A magnitude 6.0 earthquake strikes disaster-hit Ecuador: USGS
summary: A magnitude 6.0 earthquake struck Ecuador on April 22, 2016, 100 km north-northwest of Portoviejo at a depth of 10 km. This quake occurred as the country was still recovering from a deadly 7.8 magnitude quake that killed 587 people. The USGS reported the latest quake.

site_title: Give companies incentives to tackle modern slavery
summary: A global business worth $150 billion fuels modern slavery, with 36 million slaves worldwide, mostly in Asia. The global outsourcing rush has made it difficult for corporations to monitor working conditions, and the seafood industry in Thailand is a major hub for forced labor, with an estimated 500,000 trafficked individuals. To combat this, the Stop Slavery Award will honor corporations that eradicate forced labor in their supply chains, and consumers are encouraged to make informed purchasing decisions. Incentives, such as low-risk and high-profit opportunities, are needed to motivate companies to take action against modern slavery.

site_title: Adjacent innovations: boon or bane for corporates?
summary: Companies must balance their innovation portfolios by investing in core, adjacent, and new innovations to achieve long-term success. Adjacent innovations, such as creating new products or services for existing or new customers, can contribute to revenue growth, but may lead to market leadership decline if not managed properly. Examples of successful adjacent innovations include General Motors' GMAC Financial Services and OnStar, while others, like hotel chains and the rental car industry, have seen disruption due to failure to adapt. To avoid this, companies must actively disrupt their core and adjacent innovations, requiring an enlightened board and proactive C-suite executives.

site_title: Microsoft Q3 profit down 25% at US$3.8b
summary: Microsoft reported a 25% decline in quarterly profits to US$3.8 billion, despite a 6% drop in revenues to US$20.5 billion in the fiscal third quarter. The company is shifting towards a services model, with gains in business cloud computing and Office software. Revenue from Windows dropped 2%, while phone revenues declined 46%. However, Surface revenue surged 61% due to the introduction of new devices. Microsoft's CEO, Satya Nadella, stated that the company is seeing momentum in its cloud services and Windows 10.

site_title: A Chinese eye delivers new perspectives on Europe's migrant crisis
summary: Chinese artist Liu Xiaodong's exhibition "Migrazioni" in Florence, Italy, explores Europe's migrant crisis through 182 works, including paintings, photography, and a video documentary. Liu traveled to Prato, a Tuscan suburb with a large Chinese community, and witnessed the influx of Syrian refugees trying to reach northern Europe. The exhibition aims to bring together the quiet, visible presence of the Chinese community and the more prominent, global issue of refugee migration, reflecting on the nature of migration and its impact on European society.

site_title: China's yuan edges down, trend of general stability intact
summary: China's yuan weakened slightly on Friday, closing at 6.4823 per US dollar, 0.04% weaker than the previous close. Despite the slight drop, the currency remained stable, with a trend of general stability intact since early January. China's economy showed signs of improvement, with better-than-expected economic data in March. However, capital outflows from emerging markets, including China, are expected to continue putting downward pressure on the yuan.

site_title: Abe's party wins tight by-election in test for Japan summer vote
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling party, the Liberal Democratic Party, won a closely fought by-election on Hokkaido, a northern island, with 44-year-old candidate Yoshiaki Wada securing 43.1% of the vote. The election, held to replace a deceased former foreign minister, is seen as a test of voter sentiment ahead of an upper house election in July. The outcome may influence Abe's decision on whether to call a simultaneous lower house election, with analysts suggesting the tide is turning away from a 'double' election.

site_title: FCOT Q2 distributable income up 19.5%
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 19.5% increase in fiscal Q2 distributable income to S$19.35 million, driven by the resilience of its Grade B offices in Singapore and an Australian acquisition. Distribution per unit rose 2.9% to 2.45 Singapore cents, despite a higher unit base resulting from a private placement in 2015.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Microsoft says game over for Xbox 360
summary: Microsoft is discontinuing production of its Xbox 360 console, marking the end of a successful 11-year run. Over 80 million units have been sold since its launch in 2005, with the console also introducing Microsoft's Kinect motion-sensing game device. The Xbox 360 was Microsoft's primary gaming console until the launch of the Xbox One in 2013.

site_title: Tipping his hat to the open source model
summary: Red Hat CEO Jim Whitehurst expresses his optimism about the open source movement, calling it the biggest change in society since the industrial revolution. He attributes this to the company's success, which has become the first billion-dollar open source IT company under his leadership. Since joining in 2008, Red Hat's stock has tripled, and Whitehurst sees the open source model as a game-changer for society.

site_title: STI dividend yield best in Asia: SGX report
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) boasts the highest dividend yield in Asia, at 4.1%, surpassing Hong Kong's 4% and Taiwan's 3.9%. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) attributed this to the country's beaten-down valuations, making dividend yields more appealing. Other Asian markets, such as Thailand and Kuala Lumpur, also have above-average dividend yields, while Indonesia and China lag behind with lower yields. The report noted that Singapore stocks with recently declared dividends have an average yield of 3.8%.

site_title: Best housing sentiment since 2014 lifts Canadian confidence
summary: Canadian confidence in the housing market has reached its highest level in 18 months, with 39.4% of respondents expecting local housing prices to rise in the next six months, according to Nanos Research Group. This is a significant increase from the previous week and the lowest share of respondents expecting lower prices since November. The Bloomberg Nanos Consumer Confidence Index also rose to 55.9, its highest level since December, indicating a strong real estate market that is offsetting weakness elsewhere in the economy.

site_title: Architects also hurting from real estate woes
summary: The real estate downturn has negatively impacted architecture and engineering services firms in Singapore, with 940 redundancies reported in 2015, a significant increase from 240 in 2013. Larger firms are diversifying their services to stay afloat, with DP Architects and Aedas expanding their overseas operations. Smaller firms face challenges securing government infrastructure projects, but may team up on projects to level the field. The Singapore government has pledged to boost public sector construction projects, but industry players remain skeptical about its impact on smaller firms.

site_title: China says population has reached 1.373 billion
summary: China's mainland population reached 1.373 billion at the beginning of November, up 33.77 million since the 2010 census. The urban population accounts for 55.88% of the total, with 16.15% over 60. The population is expected to peak at 1.45 billion by 2050. China's one-child policy was relaxed last year to allow all couples to have two children, aiming to redress the population imbalance. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit's target price is revised to S$1.49, maintaining a "buy" rating. The reit's redevelopment of 8 and 10 Tuas, expected to be ready in H2 2017, is seen as a positive opportunity. With expected refinancing savings and a revised distribution forecast, the target price is increased. The reit's yield is currently trading at 8.2%, near a 1-standard deviation discount to its trading range, making it a "buy" opportunity.

site_title: A golden throne for the Guggenheim
summary: Maurizio Cattelan, a renowned artist, has come out of retirement with a new sculpture, a functioning 18-carat-gold toilet, to be installed at the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan. The piece, titled "Maurizio Cattelan: America," is a scatological apotheosis of wealth, sparking concerns over economic inequality and the concentration of wealth. The sculpture's installation is expected to generate significant reactions, with museum officials anticipating queues and potential damage to the piece. Cattelan's return to the art world follows a decade-long documentary, "Maurizio Cattelan: Be Right Back," which debuts at the Guggenheim as part of the Tribeca Film Festival.

site_title: Kuwait to restore full oil output in '3 days' after strike ends
summary: Kuwait's state oil firm, Kuwait Petroleum Corp, is set to restore full oil production within three days after thousands of staff ended a strike in a surprise about-turn. The strike, which began on Sunday, had slashed the emirate's output from 3.0 million barrels per day to 1.5 million. The strike's end came after the union announced an "extremely successful" strike that had made the government pay attention to their concerns, prompting a gradual return to normal production.

site_title: Panama president vows tax cooperation with OECD: Kyodo
summary: Panamanian President Juan Carlos Varela has pledged to cooperate with the OECD on sharing tax information, following the "Panama Papers" scandal that exposed offshore dealings of wealthy individuals. Panama has agreed to join the common reporting standards, aiming to avert redesignation as a tax haven. The OECD's technical team is set to visit Panama this week to finalize the agreement. This move comes after Panama's Vice President, Isabel De Saint Malo, expressed willingness to cooperate with the OECD last week.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.38% on Tuesday, following a Wall Street rally, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,928.7. 61.1 million shares worth S$57.9 million were traded, with gains outpacing losses 98 to 34.

site_title: Japanese govt promises to back quake-hit companies
summary: The Japanese government has pledged to provide financial support to companies affected by a series of quakes on Kyushu island, including up to 350 billion yen (S$4.4 billion) from a reserved fund. The announcement came after earthquakes measuring up to 7.3 magnitude struck the region, killing at least 42 people and forcing major companies to close factories. However, the government declined to comment on whether the disaster would impact the timing of a planned sales tax hike next April.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust's Funan Mall to be redeveloped into a lifestyle destination over the next three years, starting July 2016. DBS Group Research downgrades its recommendation to "hold" due to limited upside and compressed forecasted total return. Soilbuild Business Space Reit's Q1 FY16 DPU fell 4.7% year-on-year, and the research firm slashes its target price to 75.5 Singapore cents due to weaker rental outlook. Despite concerns over industrial environment, analysts maintain a "hold" recommendation for both trusts.

site_title: Toyota, other major Japanese firms hit by quake damage, supply disruptions
summary: Toyota and other major Japanese firms face production disruptions due to damage from recent earthquakes in southern Japan. At least 41 people were killed in the quakes, which have caused supply chain disruptions and highlighted the vulnerability of Japanese companies to natural disasters. Toyota will suspend production at most of its vehicle assembly plants for a week, while Honda and Nissan have also stopped production. Renesas Electronics, a semiconductor manufacturer, has sustained damage to some equipment and will assess damage before deciding to resume production. The disruptions reflect the challenges faced by Japanese companies in addressing supply chain disruptions caused by natural disasters.

site_title: Dubai property prices down 10% in Q1: JLL
summary: Dubai residential property prices fell 10% in Q1 2016 due to a strong dollar and reduced spending by buyers following the oil price slump. This marks the continuation of a three-year softening of the market, driven by tougher borrowing regulations and higher transaction fees. Apartment and house prices dropped 10% and 11% year-on-year, respectively, while rents fell 5%. Despite this, JLL remains positive on the long-term outlook due to future growth drivers such as the Expo 2020 and mega infrastructure developments.

site_title: Stake contributions help lift CCT's Q1 DPU
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a boost in distributions for the first quarter, driven by maiden contributions from its stakes in CapitaGreen and Raffles City Singapore. The trust is still searching for a tenant for CapitaGreen's top floor. CCT's earnings were offset by a dip in its wholly owned assets, but the new contributions helped make up for the shortfall.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise but caution expected ahead of key data
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.9% on Tuesday, following gains in overseas markets, ahead of March export orders data scheduled for release on Wednesday. The data is forecast to show a 12th consecutive month of decline, reinforcing a gloomy outlook for the island's economy. The main TAIEX index rose to 8,742.73, with shares in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. nearly 1% higher. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.285 per US dollar.

site_title: Oil producers mull output freeze in Doha, Iran stays home
summary: Major oil producers met in Qatar to discuss a potential output freeze, aiming to boost prices amid a supply glut. The talks, attended by 15 countries including Saudi Arabia and Russia, are a follow-up to previous discussions. However, Iran refused to participate, citing its historic production quota. Despite this, some officials believe a freeze agreement is possible, with estimates suggesting Iran can add only 500,000 barrels per day by the end of the year. A draft agreement calls for freezing output at January levels until October, with a monitoring committee to be set up.

site_title: Qantas trims domestic expansion as election dents demand
summary: Qantas has reduced its planned domestic capacity expansion for the second half of its financial year due to the prospect of a federal election and a decline in consumer confidence. The airline now expects capacity additions of 0.5-1% compared to a 2% forecast in February. This month, Qantas removed three US services and redeployed planes to fly to Hong Kong and Singapore. The move aims to adjust to changing demand and mitigate the impact of the election on the airline's business.

site_title: China sees property sector making greater contribution to economic growth
summary: China's property sector contributed significantly to economic growth in the first quarter of 2016, with property investment growth accelerating to 6.2% and national sales growth reaching a near three-year high. This growth, driven by official stimulus measures, met expectations and resulted in a 6.7% economic growth rate for the quarter. However, prices are expected to continue coming under pressure due to large inventories, and there is divergence between property prices in major cities and smaller cities.

site_title: BlackRock wields its big stick on CEO pay like a wet noodle
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest investment manager, rarely votes against CEO pay packages of companies that prioritize short-term gains, despite its chairman and CEO Laurence Fink's vocal criticism of such practices. In a 96.2% voting record, BlackRock supports pay practices at companies most of the time, compared to other money managers and public pension funds, which often reject pay policies. A shareholder proposal is being considered to require BlackRock's board to evaluate its voting practices and make changes to align with its stated principles.

site_title: Confidence among US homebuilders little changed in April
summary: US homebuilders' confidence remained steady at 58 in April, indicating a lackluster housing market despite a strong spring selling season. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo gauge has been at 58 since February. Despite better buyer traffic and optimism, current single-family home sales dropped, and the six-month sales outlook improved slightly. Low borrowing costs and solid job creation are expected to sustain growth in the single-family housing market, but faster wage growth and a higher supply of homes are needed for a stronger rebound.

site_title: Interesting times ahead for Singapore retail scene
summary: Singapore's retail scene is undergoing significant changes due to technological advancements and tax developments. Challenger Technologies, a well-known electronics retailer, plans to close its flagship store and shift focus to its online platform, hachi.tech, which is expected to account for 50% of revenue in 3-5 years. Online shopping in Singapore has grown 38% per year, with total spending projected to reach S$6.9 billion by 2018. The GST relief for imported goods below S$400 and the ability to shop online from overseas suppliers without Singapore GST apply, giving consumers an advantage.

site_title: China Q1 GDP grows 6.7 % year on year, meeting expectations
summary: China's economy grew 6.7% in the first quarter, meeting expectations and suggesting a slowdown may be bottoming out. Fixed-asset investment growth accelerated to 10.7%, while industrial output and retail sales also showed signs of improvement. These results ease concerns about a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy, providing a positive outlook for policymakers.

images.alt_text: China's economy grew 6.7 per cent in the first quarter from a year earlier, meeting expectations and providing additional evidence that a slowdown in the world's second largest economy may be bottoming out.

site_title: GIC ties up with Korean retailer player Shinsegae to develop mall
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has partnered with Shinsegae to develop a prime retail mall in the Incheon Free Economic Zone for $197 million. The 59,730 sqm mall is scheduled for completion by 2020 and will feature entertainment, leisure, and lifestyle facilities. Located in Songdo, it is positioned as a one-stop dominant regional city-centre mall.

site_title: S$50 Dinner deals
summary: In Singapore, several mid-range to upscale restaurants offer three-course dinner deals for S$50 nett per person. 999.99, led by chef Masano Saito, serves high-quality food at affordable prices, including dishes like pan-seared striploin and truffle with pomme puree. Jiang-Nan Chun Four Seasons Hotel offers a satisfying three-course meal, including dim sum and jasmine tea-smoked chicken. Long Chim, a Thai restaurant, provides robust flavors and sharing plates at a budget of S$100 for two. :pluck, a stylish hole-in-wall restaurant, offers inventive food with a gastrobar vibe, while The Naked Finn serves affordable seafood options. Other restaurants, such as Sum Yi Tai, Tang Restaurant and Bar, and 5th Quarter, also offer unique dining experiences within the S$50 budget.

site_title: Celebrating Singapore theatre in style
summary: The Singapore Theatre Festival is set to return this July with eight plays tackling topical issues, including the city-state's history, language policies, and social issues. The festival's crowning jewel is Hotel, a five-hour epic by Alfian Sa'at and Marcia Vanderstraaten, which explores 100 years of Singapore's history through the lives of ordinary folk. Other plays include My Mother Buys Condoms, Grandmother Tongue, and GRC, which address issues such as moral panic, language policies, and racial demographics. Tickets go on sale on April 18.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: China will increase SMEs' access to financing: central bank governor
summary: China's central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan announced plans to increase access to financing for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). This move aims to address the challenges these companies face in securing funding. The central bank's statement follows concerns about SMEs struggling to access financing. The decision is seen as a step to boost economic growth, which is expected to slow down.

site_title: Education as a unifying force
summary: Bulgarian economist Ilian Mihov, Insead's Asia dean, discusses the global business school's efforts to build a thriving learning and research community. Mihov, who has been at Insead for 20 years, emphasizes the school's global identity and its commitment to diversity, with students and faculty from 174 countries. Insead's Singapore campus, which opened in 2000, has been a success, and the school plans to expand its presence in the Middle East with a new campus in Abu Dhabi. Mihov also highlights Insead's research output, with its professors publishing more articles in top academic journals than other top business schools. He notes that the school's vision, established by its founder Georges Doriot, is to promote peace and prosperity in Europe by bringing together people from different countries.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Emerging currencies slump after Singapore eases monetary policy
summary: Emerging currencies plummeted Thursday after Singapore's central bank eased monetary policy, sparking fears about Asia's developing economies. The South Korean won fell over 1% against the US dollar, while Singapore's dollar dropped nearly 1% for its largest drop in five months. The move was seen as a response to the country's main opposition party's electoral victory, which could lead to policy changes. The decision also raised concerns about the stability of other emerging market currencies, such as the Indonesian rupiah and the Thai baht.

site_title: Not a happy Chinese New Year for Singapore retailers in February
summary: Singapore retailers experienced a 9.6% drop in total retail sales excluding motor vehicles in February, with a 3.2% decline compared to the same month last year. Despite a 51.3% surge in motor sales, the weak retail performance has prompted economists to warn of threatened economic growth. The decline in retail sales, particularly in categories such as food and beverage, electronics, and telecommunications, has raised concerns about consumer spending and economic sentiment.

images.alt_text: Chinese New Year was not enough to lift retail sales in February this year, prompting some economists to declare that consumption in Singapore is already at such low levels that economic growth will be threatened.

site_title: Panama insists 'committed' to financial transparency
summary: Panama has reaffirmed its commitment to financial transparency, following the Panama Papers revelations, and is willing to engage in international dialogue to implement OECD reporting standards. The country's vice-president and foreign minister stated that Panama's path to financial transparency is irreversible and is open to ongoing dialogue with relevant technical teams. This comes as Europe's five largest economies proposed a blacklist of tax havens, including Panama, and urged the G-20 group to end the secrecy of shell companies.

site_title: The BOE is poised to take over a key UK rates benchmark
summary: The Bank of England is set to take control of the Sterling Overnight Index Average (Sonia), a key UK interest rate benchmark, on April 25. This move comes after the Wholesale Markets Brokers' Association, which currently calculates Sonia, will transition to publishing the rate on behalf of the BOE. The BOE aims to "own" the benchmark, ensuring market rates align with its bank rate, and views reform of Sonia as necessary due to its critical role in sterling markets and limited market size. This change aims to address market-rigging scandals surrounding the London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor).

site_title: Mori to spend 400b yen building 3 Tokyo towers
summary: Mori Building Co plans to spend approximately 400 billion yen (S$4.95 billion) on constructing three high-rise towers in the Toranomon area of Tokyo over 10 years. The project, part of a one trillion yen plan, includes two office spaces and one residential tower, with completion expected by 2019. The development may seek a partner to fund the project, which could impact rental prices in central Tokyo, already experiencing a surplus of new office space ahead of the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

site_title: Phone makers, telcos see potential in hi-res audio
summary: High-resolution audio (HRA) has seen a surge in demand, driven by lifestyle shifts and advancements in technology. Smartphone makers, telcos, and music companies are capitalizing on this trend, with prices for HRA products increasing from $300 to $3,000. The growth of streaming services and increased storage capacity have reduced constraints on audio quality. Hardware manufacturers, such as Apple, Sony, and Samsung, are also investing in HRA technology, with some incorporating it into their phones and audio accessories. Telecoms carriers are taking note, offering streaming services and integrating HRA capabilities into their offerings.

site_title: Satisfaction with healthcare falls 2% in 2015
summary: The Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG) survey revealed a 2% decline in the healthcare sector's satisfaction rating from 69.6 points in 2015. The decline was primarily attributed to general practitioners, healthcare providers, and restructured hospitals, scoring 69.4, 69.7, and 68.6 points respectively. In contrast, the polyclinic sub-sector continued to improve, with a 1.1% increase to 69.6 points, and patients who made appointments reported higher satisfaction ratings across all touch points. The study suggests that appointment-making allows patients better control over their time and expectations, leading to improved satisfaction.

site_title: US dollar firms vs euro, yen as Chinese exports rise
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen on April 13, 2016, after improved China trade data showed exports returning to growth for the first time in nine months. The dollar rose almost 1% against the euro and 0.7% against the yen. This move was attributed to increased investor risk appetite, with traders shifting away from safe-haven currencies like the yen and euro. The Canadian dollar fell 0.4% against the US dollar after the Bank of Canada left interest rates unchanged.

site_title: US defence chief visits Philippines amid sea dispute with China
summary: US Defense Secretary Ash Carter visited the Philippines amid tensions with China over the South China Sea, where China claims almost the entire sea and has been asserting its claims. The visit comes ahead of a ruling on a Philippines-China arbitration case and as the US and Philippines conduct joint military exercises. The US has been conducting "freedom of navigation" patrols in the area, drawing rebukes from China, and has pledged $40 million in funding to the Philippines for maritime security. Carter's visit aims to reassure the Philippines of US security backing for a rules-based approach to settling disputes.

site_title: Europe stocks jump most in a month as miners rally on China data
summary: Europe's stocks jumped the most in a month, with commodity producers leading gains after China's exports rose the most in a year and imports narrowed. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index climbed 2.5% as lenders surged 6.1%, with the UK FTSE 100 Index turning positive for 2016. The rally was driven by optimism over China's economy stabilizing, with Italy's FTSE MIB Index also advancing 4.1%.

site_title: Brexit vote would damage UK economy, may push BoE to cut rates
summary: The UK's vote to leave the European Union on June 23 would likely hurt the economy, with 31 of 35 economists polled saying it would have a negative impact. The Bank of England may cut interest rates for the first time since the financial crisis, with 17 of 26 economists predicting a rate cut. The UK's economy could experience recessionary effects in the short-term, with some economists estimating a 1.9% growth rate for 2016 and 2.1% for 2017.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as crude rally buoys energy shares, yen drops
summary: Asian stocks rose for a sixth consecutive day, driven by a 4.5% surge in crude oil prices, which boosted energy producers. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index increased 0.9% and the Topix index in Japan rose 1.6%. A deal on freezing oil output between Russia and Saudi Arabia is expected to further fuel gains. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 1%, while Australia and New Zealand's major indexes also gained.

site_title: BP sees flat global oil supply in 2016
summary: BP Chief Economist Spencer Dale predicts a flat global oil supply in 2016, citing increased Iranian output offset by drops in other regions. Iran is expected to ramp up supply by 500,000 barrels per day within six months of sanctions lifting, but further growth may be challenging. Dale does not believe Iran will be a game-changer in the long term, suggesting that the impact of increased Iranian output may be limited.

site_title: Shippers profit as carriers suffer amid the crisis
summary: A new report by Xeneta argues that big volume shippers are not paying the best shipping rates, contrary to industry perceptions. According to the report, high-volume shippers are often locked into long-term agreements that leave them paying above current market rates, while others take advantage of low fuel prices and megaship capacities. The report suggests that third-party logistics firms are benefiting from these agreements, with some making significant margins from short- and long-term contracts with big volume shippers. This disparity could widen due to the influence of factors like fuel prices, potentially exacerbating the container shipping crisis, which is expected to result in losses of over $5 billion in 2016.

site_title: Tale of two Chinas is emerging as economy slows, says Fidelity
summary: China's economy is experiencing a slowdown, with a "tale of two Chinas" emerging as the country shifts from an export-based economy to one centered on consumption and services. Regions like Yunnan province in the south, with 8.7% growth, are thriving, while areas like Liaoning in the north-eastern rust belt, with 3% growth, struggle. China's GDP growth is projected to slow, with a consensus of economists predicting 6.7% growth, and some warning of a "bumpy landing" or "lost decade" of economic stagnation.

site_title: Brussels airport closed due to air traffic control action
summary: Brussels Airport was closed on April 12, 2016, due to industrial action by Belgian air traffic controllers. The airport has been operating at limited capacity since reopening after an Islamic State bombing on March 22. The airport's management is seeking operational solutions with the trade union, and the nearby Charleroi airport only accepted landing aircraft with no takeoffs.

site_title: Entire Australian village is listed for sale
summary: A small Australian village, Tarraleah, in Tasmania, has been listed for sale with a price tag of up to A$13 million. The village, originally built in the 1920s for hydroelectric workers, has been restored to a high-class standard and attracts tourists with its lake, golf course, and wildlife. The sale has drawn interest from China and Singapore, with a new buyer set to own dozens of homes and 35 Highland cattle. The sale is expected to fetch A$2.1 million in annual revenue.

site_title: Panama scandal forces Britain to open up on taxes
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron released a summary of his taxes for the past six years, following a trend set by other politicians, including Finance Minister George Osborne and Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn. The move marks a shift towards transparency, with commentators saying it could lead to all MPs publishing their tax details. Experts believe the immediate fallout will be limited, but the revelations have reinforced an image of Cameron and his inner circle as a wealthy elite governing for the rich, sparking calls for greater accountability.

site_title: Australia unveils new A$5 note in currency overhaul
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia unveiled the design of a new A$5 bill as part of a currency overhaul to improve banknote security. The new bill features innovative security measures, including a distinctive top-to-bottom window, to prevent counterfeiting. Governor Glenn Stevens stated that these new features will help keep Australia's banknotes secure. The design change is part of a broader effort to improve the security and integrity of Australia's currency.

site_title: Parliament: New Cybersecurity Bill to be tabled next year to strengthen online defences
summary: Singapore's new Cybersecurity Bill, set to be tabled in Parliament next year, aims to strengthen laws against online crime by requiring operators of critical information infrastructure to secure systems and report incidents. The bill will also empower the Cybersecurity Agency to manage cyber incidents and raise cyber security provider standards. The move is part of efforts to enhance the country's online defences.

site_title: Update: Singapore's AGC to offer MLA 'expeditiously' to Swiss authorities on 1MDB probe
summary: Singapore's Attorney-General's Chambers has agreed to provide mutual legal assistance (MLA) to Switzerland in the 1MDB probe, expediting the process. The MLA request seeks information and documents on "certain fund flows" from 1MDB and related entities. This move follows a Swiss investigation into two former Emirati officials suspected of embezzlement, with the Swiss authorities also seeking MLA from Luxembourg. The two officials are presumed innocent, and the investigation aims to establish the facts through international cooperation.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Owner of Primark, AB Foods offers to buy Illovo sugar stake for 5.6b rand
summary: Associated British Foods (AB Foods) has increased its offer to buy Illovo Sugar Ltd, valuing the African producer at 11.5 billion rand (S$1.02 billion). AB Foods, owner of Primark and Kingsmill bread, already owns 51% of Illovo and offered 25 rand per share for the remaining portion. The new offer is 20 rand per share, totaling 5.6 billion rand. This expansion aims to strengthen AB Foods' sugar business.

site_title: World Bank: Loan demand rising as developing countries face headwinds
summary: The World Bank expects nonmarket rate lending to reach $43 billion in the current fiscal year, surpassing the total of $150 billion over the past four years. Lending to developing countries is expected to exceed $42.4 billion, with IBRD lending reaching $25 billion. The bank aims to help countries accelerate growth in a weak global economy, with loans being used to signal policy reforms and commitments. World Bank President Jim Yong Kim notes that the loans are complementary to the International Monetary Fund's role and aim to support vulnerable populations.

site_title: Promise of emerging market countries is wishful thinking
summary: Brazil, the largest economy in Latin America, is experiencing a severe economic slump and a political crisis that could lead to the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff. The country's economy has been shrinking since 2014, with a cumulative decline of 8.5% in gross domestic product, and a national unemployment rate of 9.5%. The crisis is attributed to macroeconomic mismanagement, including cheap credit, government spending, and deficits. A massive scandal involving Petrobras, the national oil company, has further fueled public outrage and discontent. Experts warn that Brazil's casual tolerance of graft may be fading, but the country's economic and political dysfunction remains a significant challenge.

site_title: Australia's big banks wander deeper into regulatory quagmire
summary: Australia's major banks, including Westpac and ANZ, are facing increased regulatory scrutiny over suspected benchmark interest rate rigging. The banks have denied wrongdoing and are set to face potential financial penalties, which could dent earnings and shareholder returns. Public pressure is mounting on Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to order a sector-wide inquiry, with the opposition Labour Party promising a Royal Commission if it wins the upcoming federal election. The banks' performance has been weakened by stricter capital rules, higher loan losses, and a cooling housing market, with the Big Four banks down between 14% and 19% on the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index this year.

site_title: Boeing lands four orders for 747-8 Freighter, first of the year
summary: Boeing has booked four orders for its 747-8 Freighter, the first sales of the year, following declining demand for the jumbo jet. The orders bring the total to 23, including 11 freighters and 12 passenger models. Boeing expects global trade to pick up this year, potentially increasing air cargo demand by 3-4%. The company plans to cut annual 747 production to six from 12 this year.

site_title: WTO cuts world trade growth forecast to 2.8%
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has cut its global trade growth forecast to 2.8% for 2016, lower than its previous estimate of 3.9%. The new forecast expects trade to rise to 3.6% in 2017, breaking a six-year trend of growth below 3%. Risks to the forecast include a slowing Chinese economy, worsening financial market volatility, and exposure to exchange rate movements.

site_title: Wild child
summary: The McLaren 570S is a two-seater mid-engine sports car that offers an engagingly entertaining drive. With a 3.8-litre twin-turbo V8 producing 570 hp and 600 Nm, it has a lightweight carbon fibre chassis and advanced airflow management system. The car features independent adaptive dampers and a unique floating tendon in the door design, providing better body control and a more immersive driving experience. With its raw and communicative handling, the 570S is aimed at purists who prioritize driving fun over refined comfort.

site_title: IT spending could be a casualty of economic uncertainty: Gartner
summary: Gartner predicts worldwide IT spending will fall slightly to $3.49 trillion this year due to global economic uncertainty. The strong US dollar and saturated smartphone and PC markets are major contributors to the decline. Spending on devices is expected to decline 3.7% to $626 billion, while IT spending growth is forecasted to be 1.6% in constant currency, down from 2.4% last year. Organizations are cutting costs, forcing them to invest in digital businesses and services at a time of limited revenue growth.

site_title: US: Stocks rise with petroleum shares gaining
summary: US stocks rose modestly Friday, with petroleum-linked stocks posting strong gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 36.23 points (0.21%) to 17,578.19, while the S&P 500 rose 5.73 (0.28%) to 2,047.64. US oil prices surged 6.6%, lifting shares of Chevron and Anadarko Petroleum. However, the broader market weakened late in the session, likely due to investors taking money off the table before earnings season.

site_title: Fed's Kaplan says weak data show there's no need for April rate hike
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan expressed skepticism about a potential April interest rate hike, citing weak economic growth data. The Atlanta Fed's GDPNow model estimates 0.1% annual growth in the first quarter, inconsistent with job numbers showing solid employment gains. Kaplan remains open to a June rate hike, but emphasizes the need to be patient and cautious, allowing events to unfold before making a decision. The Federal Open Market Committee meets April 26-27 and June 14-15, with investors lowering odds of a rate move at either meeting.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan said he doesn't back an interest-rate increase this month in light of a puzzling weakening of economic growth, though a June tightening by the US central bank remains a possibility.

site_title: Toyota, Ford lead China auto sales increase after tax cut
summary: China's passenger-vehicle sales rose 6.8% in the first quarter, led by Toyota and Ford, as consumers took advantage of a government tax cut and discounts from manufacturers. Deliveries climbed to 5.64 million units, with Toyota boosting sales by 28% to 291,000 units and Ford delivering 14% more vehicles to 314,454 units. The tax cut, implemented in October, is expected to boost the auto industry's growth, with China's industry on track to exceed a 6% growth forecast. Chinese carmakers also cut sticker prices for entry-level SUVs to intensify competition.

site_title: Indonesian regulators want banks to trade more derivatives
summary: Indonesian regulators are finalizing measures to encourage banks to trade promissory notes and money market derivatives, aiming to deepen the country's financial market. The central bank governor, Agus Martowardojo, said the goal is to reduce default risks and boost interbank trade. Current rules allow lenders to use promissory notes, but banks stopped trading them after the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis. The authorities plan to issue regulations based on loans with underlying collateral or trade transactions, and will also issue more treasury bills to encourage larger money market trading.

site_title: Malaysia's Eco World Intl gets nod for RM2.2b domestic IPO
summary: Malaysia's Eco World Intl has received regulatory approval for a proposed domestic initial public offering (IPO) of its unit, Eco World International Bhd (EWI), valued at RM2.15 billion. The IPO will fund projects in the UK and Australia and repay borrowings. Eco World Development Group, the parent company, expects to retain up to 30% of EWI's share capital. The IPO will be led by joint principal advisers Maybank Investment, CIMB Investment, and Hong Leong Investment.

site_title: Sectoral, company-level help to tackle economic challenges: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Industry S Iswaran stated that the government will implement sectoral measures to tackle economic challenges, in addition to providing individual company-level support through the Industry Transformation Programme (ITP). This plan aims to foster growth and help companies adapt to changing economic conditions. Iswaran emphasized the importance of a multi-faceted approach, combining sectoral and company-level measures to address the current economic challenges.

site_title: Seoul: Won flat, stocks edge down as profit-takers hit Samsung
summary: The South Korean won remained unchanged at 1,156.1 per US dollar, as investors took profits from Samsung Electronics Co Ltd after the tech giant beat expectations with its first-quarter operating profit guidance. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.3% to 1,965.20 points, with Samsung Elec's shares down 1.9% and making up 19.1% of the Kospi's worth. Foreign investors purchased 42.4 billion Korean won worth of KOSPI shares, while stocks like LG Display Co Ltd and Naver Corp rose 3.7% and 3.5% respectively.

site_title: High stakes for gaming across Asia-Pacific
summary: The Asian-Pacific gaming industry experienced significant changes in 2015, with a 34.3% decrease in gross gaming revenues in Macau due to a clamp-down on conspicuous spending and money laundering. This shift has led to Cambodia benefiting from the fallout, with NagaCorp's profit increasing by 27%. The industry is expected to continue changing, with integrated resorts (IRs) becoming the new norm, and valuations expected to fall due to non-renewal risks and cannibalisation. Governments are expected to look towards gaming as a source of income, and properties in lower-cost destinations are expected to be attractive.

site_title: Trumpanomics and US federal debt: fantasies over facts
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump has proposed eliminating the US$19 trillion federal debt over an 8-year period, but experts say this is mathematically impossible. Trump's budget plan would require drastic spending cuts or tax increases, potentially eliminating entire programs such as Social Security and Medicare. Balancing the budget would require significant cuts, but even that would not repay the existing debt. The proposal has raised questions about Trump's understanding or motives, with some suggesting he may have been unclear or cynical about his plan.

site_title: Citi's globalist CEO
summary: Citigroup CEO Michael Corbat has successfully transformed the bank since the 2008 global financial crisis, focusing on simplicity, smaller size, safety, and strength. Under his leadership, Citi has shed non-core assets, reduced headcount, and improved its capital position. The bank is now positioned for long-term growth, with a focus on globalization, urbanization, and digitization. Corbat aims to maintain Citi's global footprint and leverage its scale to innovate and deliver services to clients worldwide. Despite headwinds in emerging economies and the energy sector, Corbat is cautiously optimistic about the future, citing a potential oil market recovery and stable prices.

site_title: EU banks, investors push EU to fix flaws in ABS revival plan
summary: EU banks and investors are urging the European Union to fix flaws in a plan to revive the asset-backed securities market and boost financing for small businesses. The plan, which offers preferential capital treatment to qualifying securitizations, needs to be aligned with existing prudential rules. The proposal could cause an "arbitrary division" between currently available securities and those issued under the new standards, leading to losses for conservative investors. The EU must address concerns about moral hazard, regulatory arbitrage, and a lack of interest in penalized financial instruments to avoid "cliff effects" with severe consequences.

site_title: Australia shares fall a 3rd straight session, hit 1-month low
summary: Australian shares fell for a third consecutive session to hit a one-month low, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dropping 70.9 points or 1.4% to 4,924.4. The weak commodities market weighed on the index, with New Zealand's benchmark also falling 0.4%. This marks the lowest level for the Australian index since March 2.

site_title: Obama, Xi agree to fully implement North Korea sanctions
summary: US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to fully implement sanctions against North Korea, in a meeting that came despite a recent Pyongyang missile launch. The White House said both leaders committed to strengthening coordination on addressing North Korea's nuclear and ballistic missile threats. The agreement includes the full implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 2270, and both leaders reaffirmed their commitment to achieving denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower despite Wall St gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.47% due to a stronger yen weighing on exporters. Despite this, the benchmark index recovered from its slide from the previous week. On Wall Street, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: 'Suspicious' activity at North Korea nuclear complex: US think tank
summary: US analysts at the US-Korea Institute at Johns Hopkins University say satellite images of North Korea's main nuclear complex show suspicious activity that could be linked to re-processing plutonium for additional nuclear bombs. The activity is centered around exhaust plumes from a steam plant used for processing plutonium. The reactor, mothballed in 2007, has been renovated after North Korea's third nuclear test in 2013. Experts say the facility could produce enough plutonium for one nuclear bomb per year. The US National Intelligence Director has also stated North Korea could extract weapons-grade plutonium from spent fuel rods in weeks.

site_title: Drought rules pushed Californians to cut water use by nearly 25%
summary: California residents and businesses reduced water use by nearly 25% from June 2015 to February 2016, meeting the state's goal of conserving enough water to supply 6 million people for a year. The mandatory cutbacks, implemented by Governor Jerry Brown, resulted in a savings of 1.19 million acre-feet of water, equivalent to the annual usage of cities like Los Angeles, San Francisco, and San Diego. Regulators are now considering whether to lift or adjust the cutbacks following a wet winter, with some water districts already relaxing conservation measures.

site_title: Culinary soulmates
summary: Chefs Ivan Brehm from Bacchanalia and Hideaki Sato from Ta Vie in Hong Kong recently collaborated on a two-night Four Hands dinner event, featuring Sato's signature dishes and Brehm's new creations. The eight-course menu showcased their differing cooking styles, with Brehm emphasizing layering and Sato focusing on simplicity and seasonality. The collaboration was a success, with both chefs praising each other's techniques and philosophies. The event highlighted the benefits of collaborative dinners, with Brehm noting that it was an eye-opening experience for his team. The two chefs also discussed their culinary backgrounds and future plans, including Sato's potential to open a restaurant in Tokyo.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Vietnam seizes Chinese oil tanker: state media
summary: Vietnam's coast guard has seized a Chinese oil tanker, the Qiong Yangpu, which it claims entered Vietnamese waters. The tanker was carrying 100,000 liters of oil and was captured on Thursday in the Tonkin Gulf. The three-man crew was handed over to police. The incident is part of a longstanding territorial dispute between Vietnam and China over the South China Sea, where China has been aggressively patrolling near contested islands. Vietnam regularly chases Chinese fishing vessels out of its waters, and this is the first time authorities have held a boat and its crew.

site_title: US dollar near 17-mth low vs yen after Japan PM's currency comments
summary: The US dollar hovered near a 17-month low against the yen after Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's comments suggested the authorities were cautious towards arresting the yen's appreciation. The yen traded near 110.300 yen, its lowest since October 2014, amid expectations that the Federal Reserve would not hike interest rates aggressively this year. Abe's comments also highlighted Japan's concerns about intervening in currency markets, which could impact its economy and relationships with other countries.

images.alt_text: The US dollar hovered near a 17-month low against the yen on Wednesday after taking a fresh knock overnight on comments by Japan's prime minister which suggested the authorities were cautious towards arresting the yen's appreciation.

site_title: Seoul: Won moves gingerly ahead of ECB decision; stocks edge up
summary: The South Korean won fluctuated near a five-month high ahead of the European Central Bank's interest rate decision, closing at 1,135.2 to the US dollar. Foreign investors continued to buy South Korean shares, lifting the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) 0.5% to 2,015.08 points. Refiners and screen manufacturers, such as S-Oil Corp and LG Display Co Ltd, gained 1.6% and 3% respectively, while Posco rose 3.1%. The ECB's decision is expected to impact the won and global markets.

images.alt_text: The South Korean won zigzagged in and out of negative territory on Thursday as a wait-and-see mood spread ahead of an European Central Bank interest rate decision later in the day.

site_title: The overseas prospect
summary: Christophe Weber, Takeda's first foreign CEO, marks the one-year anniversary of his appointment, expressing confidence in the company's transformation. Under his leadership, Takeda has streamlined its businesses, focusing on three therapeutic areas and emerging markets. The company has grown its revenue from 1.42 trillion yen in 2011 to 1.78 trillion yen in 2015, despite shrinking profits. Weber believes Takeda has enough products to drive organic growth for the next five years, but patent expiries will impact the company's finances. He is focusing on external partnerships to drive innovation and has established a 10-year partnership with Kyoto University to develop cell technologies. Weber is optimistic about Takeda's prospects, despite challenges, and is committed to balancing the company's geographical contributions to its total business.

site_title: Iceland gets the first jolt from Panama leak: Bloomberg View
summary: Iceland's Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson faces a political crisis after allegations emerged that he hid a conflict of interest related to his wife's offshore company, which held bonds issued by collapsed Icelandic banks. The company, Wintris, was declared legal and paid taxes, but Gunnlaugsson's decision not to disclose the company's existence has raised questions about his integrity. The Progressive Party, led by Gunnlaugsson, has lost popularity, and the anti-establishment Pirate party is pushing for a no-confidence vote, which will take place later this week.

site_title: Sotheby's Hong Kong HK$3.1 billion auction, defies downturn
summary: Sotheby's Hong Kong auction house defied expectations with HK$3.1 billion in sales, beating projections. The sales were boosted by Chinese billionaire Liu Yiqian's purchases, including a Zhang Daqian painting for HK$270 million and a Leonard Tsuguharu Foujita painting for HK$39.4 million. The auction also set a record for the most expensive jewel sold in Asia, with the sale of the De Beers Millennium Jewel 4 for HK$248.3 million. Sotheby's reported a 17% increase in sales over last spring's auction season.

images.alt_text: Sotheby's beat expectations at the debut of the Hong Kong auction season with HK$3.1 billion (S$540.43 million) in sales of paintings, jewelry, watches, wine and Chinese works of art.

site_title: China central bank says to keep reasonable growth in credit and social financing
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced it will maintain prudent monetary policy to ensure reasonable growth in credit and social financing. The PBOC reiterated its use of various monetary policy tools to maintain liquidity and will continue to push forward reforms on interest rates and the exchange rate. This decision aims to address concerns about slowing GDP growth and its potential impact on policymakers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of "the spirit of enterprise and caring" in driving Singapore's continued progress. COE premiums for passenger cars increased, while Keppel and Sembcorp saw their stocks rise due to oil-rig orders. PSA is issuing US$500m 10-year bonds at 2.5%. Amid 1MDB probes, several senior BSI employees left the Singapore office. Ascendas Hospitality Trust plummeted 10% after canceling a sale process. Chope Group expanded into Indonesia through acquisition.

images.alt_text: Singapore's continued progress pivots on "the spirit of enterprise and caring", said Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat on Wednesday in his Budget 2016 roundup speech.

site_title: Controversial India-backed coal project awarded mining leases in Australia
summary: A controversial India-backed coal project, Adani's Carmichael mine, was awarded mining leases in Australia's Galilee Basin, worth $21.7 billion, despite environmental concerns and legal challenges. The Queensland state government set strict conditions to protect the Great Barrier Reef and local interests. Adani plans to commence construction in 2017, pending resolution of second-tier approvals and legal challenges, which have delayed the project for six years. Conservationists argue the mine will threaten the reef, while the Indian conglomerate emphasizes its commitment to environmental protection and local interests.

site_title: Panama will form commission to review financial practices
summary: Panama will establish an independent commission to review its financial practices following the leak of the "Panama Papers," which exposed financial arrangements of world leaders. The commission, comprising domestic and international experts, will evaluate practices and propose measures to strengthen transparency. The leak, published by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists and various news organizations, revealed financial dealings of prominent figures, including Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The move comes as governments worldwide investigate possible financial wrongdoing by the rich and powerful.

images.alt_text: Panama said on Wednesday it would form an independent commission to review the country's financial practices following the leak of information from a local law firm that has embarrassed a clutch of world leaders.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open down on fresh growth fears
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks fell on Wednesday, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to concerns over the global economy. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong dropped 0.38% to 20,100.00, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.44% to 3,039.74. The decline was attributed to caution over the global economy.

site_title: Twitter to stream NFL Thursday night games: Bloomberg
summary: Twitter has won a deal to broadcast Thursday night National Football League games online, according to a Bloomberg report. Twitter was bidding against Verizon, Yahoo, and Amazon, with Facebook dropping out of the bidding last week. The NFL had previously partnered with Twitter to deliver video and content to fans daily. The news sent Twitter's shares up nearly 2% in premarket trading.

site_title: South Korea's cafe boom nears saturation point
summary: South Korea's coffee shop market is experiencing saturation, with nearly every building in fashionable districts boasting a coffee shop. The market's growth has slowed to 8% in 2014, down from 20% annually between 2008 and 2012. Convenience stores like 7-Eleven are cutting prices, forcing smaller players to adapt. Some chains, like Ediya, have raised prices to improve quality, while others, such as Caffe Bene, have incurred significant losses and are expanding overseas. Despite this, Starbucks remains a dominant player, with over 860 stores in the country.

images.alt_text: Starbucks Coffee Korea, a 50-50 joint venture between the world's biggest coffee chain and South Korean hypermarket operator E-Mart, now has 860 stores in the country.

site_title: De Beers said to raise diamond prices for first time since 2014
summary: De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, has raised diamond prices for the first time in over a year, with increases of up to 2% in a recent sale. This move is seen as a sign the industry may be recovering from its biggest slump since the 2008 financial crisis. The sale was comparable in size to De Beers' prior US$610 million offering of rough diamonds. However, some experts remain skeptical about a sustained price rebound, citing slowing demand from China and an industry-wide credit crunch.

images.alt_text: De Beers raised diamond prices for the first time in more than a year in a sign the industry may be recovering from the biggest slump since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: SurveyMonkey expands to mobile-apps data one year after CEO's death
summary: SurveyMonkey is launching SurveyMonkey Intelligence, a mobile app-tracking tool, one year after CEO Dave Goldberg's sudden death. The product will track app usage, customer characteristics, and peak usage times, providing businesses with valuable data to find and retain customers or deploy targeted ads. The move marks SurveyMonkey's first major initiative under new CEO Zander Lurie, who credits Goldberg for the company's growth and culture. The tool will be available in free and paid versions, and is expected to bolster the company's revenue, which is on track to reach $200 million this year.

images.alt_text: In its first major initiative in the year since the sudden death of its chief executive, Dave Goldberg, SurveyMonkey is expanding its survey business to tap into booming demand for mobile apps.

site_title: Indonesia to scrutinise names in 'Panama Papers': finance ministry
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Bambang Brodjonegoro, has announced that the country's tax authority will scrutinize taxpayers named in the Panama Papers data, aiming to chase offshore undeclared assets. The move comes as Indonesia faces a revenue shortfall due to low commodity prices. A tax amnesty plan, which offers tax discounts to individuals and companies declaring concealed wealth, is expected to help cover the shortfall, with parliament set to debate the bill this month.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's tax authority will scrutinise taxpayers named in the data leaked from a Panamanian law firm as part of efforts to chase their offshore undeclared assets, the country's finance minister said on Tuesday.

site_title: SIA, Lufthansa broaden codeshare operations
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and the Lufthansa Group have expanded their codeshare agreement, providing SIA passengers with access to over 20 new routes in Europe and Lufthansa and Swiss passengers with access to SIA-operated flights in Southeast Asia and the Southwest Pacific. The new codeshare flights will be available through SIA's booking channels, and the partnership also includes joint fare products and aligned corporate programs for corporate travelers. The agreement is subject to regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

Thanks to a joint venture agreement signed last November, Singapore Airlines (SIA) and the Lufthansa Group are expanding their codeshare agreement which will deliver better connections and new codeshare destinations for passengers.

site_title: Fed's Mester doesn't want to wait too long on rate hike
summary: Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester stated that the Federal Reserve should gradually raise interest rates this year due to the economy's resilience. She expressed concerns that waiting too long to follow up on the December rate hike could lead to more aggressive rate increases, negatively impacting the economy. Mester's comments suggest she is poised to back a rate hike soon, despite having supported the Fed's March decision to stand pat.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve should still raise interest rates gradually this year given the economy's resilience, a top Fed official said on Friday, explaining she did not want to wait too long despite having supported last month's decision to stand pat.
